Since the game is not stored on a server you are capable of hacking into it with a simple save editor that can be found online, and then you can guve yourself infinite of anything, you can also change the skin color of any of your characters to something outlandish, like hot pink, or lime green, or blue. You can give your characters any weapon or apparel in the game, and food/water/energy will no longer be a problem! So yeah, I just play this game for the missions where you go out on expeditions.

Fallout Shelter is a fun game about creating a fallout shelter as the title suggests. The game has a very creative aspect to it creating a layout and ideal arrangement for a fallout shelter. In the 'Fallout' game series this is the only free game available, I suggest this is a great start for someone who wants to get into the fallout games. There are vast differences to this game and the other Fallout games as it is entirely cartoon like unlike a more realistic game in the series such as 'Fallout 76' or 'Fallout 4'. I would highly recommend this game to anyone including people that might not show interest towards a post-nuclear destruction game. I hope that if you play this game you'll have as much fun as me!

This is a fun and addictive F2P game. Even though it does offer in-app-purchases to speed things up, I haven't felt the need to spend a single cent after 120 hours of play time. This game is very easy to learn and play unless you're terrible at organisation because there is a fair amount of micro-management from time to time.
There's no reason not to give this a go if you're looking for a unique and relaxing single-player experience.

I do enjoy the base building mechanic as its simple yet effective. Having main rooms like Power, food or water is effective but this only truly works if you invest cash into the game to get yourself a Mr Handy as they can collect these whilst being offline. Overall it is fun because you can meet youre favourite characters in the game, for example Piper, Mr Burke and Mr Tenpenny and many more, You can also send out your Vault Dwellers to go collect items such as caps, clothing, weapons and Junk (which will be useful later on). But if you can best to send them out with Stimpacks, and Radaway (25 of each) will say that they level up as well when outside the vault, which i found to be a quick way, the max level being 50. Best stats to get to 10 because you can train your dwellers with special rooms (example being a gym for strength), Strength, Endurance, Intelligence and Luck. Endurance being the key one as it allows your dweller to have more Hitpoints.

Overall fun game very simple, Good Overseers

The short version? 50 million people downloaded the game on Android, before it even got to PC. So get it already. It's free.

The longer version. A serious warning up front. This game seems like a walk in the park - until it suddenly isn't. You can lose an entire vault, the fruits of months of realtime work, within minutes. So, let's avoid this, or more precisely, let's talk about how to avoid the possibility until you feel able to face the challenge.

Resources (energy, water, and food) are produced in production rooms. Rooms need energy, dwellers need water and food. The value of the production room does not give you its actual output. So, 20 dwellers do not need production rooms showing 20 food and water. Instead, every dwellers has skills (in Fallout normally called attributes, "special"), and the skill of the dweller in a production defines its output. More skill means more production, even if the room is not upgraded. In consequence, get a feel for what your vault needs by keeping an eye on your resource storage. If it fills up, however slowly, you're peachy.

This game has clearly defined progressive danger steps. Every tenth dweller adds a new threat (most notable until the 60th). So when you work on getting the feeling for production, I suggest doing so with nine dwellers.

Now that you know how to handle resources, let's go back to the core of the game, rooms need energy. If the energy storage of your vault even once falls below the line on the storage meter, you are in the process of losing your vault. Don't say you weren't warned. The reason why energy is more important than food and water is simply that there is no food and water without energy.

Getting a feeling for resource storage is not rocket science, so the real problem are the dangers. First, on the uppermost level of your vault build your first power room. The dwellers in it need strength for production, which also gives them resilience in a fight. Until you become really good, this is your best line of defense against intruders.

However, the true danger is random fires and infestations. With one exception, both fires and infestations do NOT spread diagonally. I am aware that 50 million people ignore this and every "best vault build" on the net tells you otherwise, but develop your vault keeping this in mind, and you cannot lose your vault...

... until you willingly and purposefully choose to have your 50th dweller !!!

The second your vault has fifty dwellers, infestations include radscorpions. They teleport. They not only rot out every dweller they find, they drain your energy storage even while in an empty room. So as long as you are not an expert in the game's mechanics and as long as you do not have the proper equipment, one of two things will happen. The merciful version kills all but three of your 50 dwellers and you may have a chance to start from scratch. Accent on "may". The cruel version kills only fifteen, but leaves you with an empty energy storage.

Well then, now that you are spared the nasty surprise, let's talk about the fun factor. FOS is a blast. Could there be more contents? Sure. Could some things be done better? You betcha. But FOS has that elusive ingredient, which once upon a time made Sid Meier's Civilization legendary. You start the game to do nothing more than the half hour of maintenance - and then your tummy rumbles, because, hey, you didn't even sip some water in the last eight hours.

Oh, one more technical tip. Unlike what the FOS wiki states, a higher Luck skill outside the wault does not give you better items, but more caps. Perception rules item quality in loot.

At the end, a word about shop items. If you don't buy items on principle, you can stop reading here.

The starter pack and the lunch boxes contain resources. The game sometimes asks you to collect a certain amount of resources. The ones from the pack and the boxes do not count towards this goal. So, the only obvious use of purchased resources is emergency fill-up after a botched radscorpion infestation. Throwing money at this problem would most certainly help, but given the hit dweller corpses cause to happiness, don't presume it will solve the pronlem all on its own.

The early value of the pack and the boxes is twofold, skilled dwellers and the chance for a rare or better weapon. A single rare or better weapon in your energy production room guarding the vault entrance makes a huge difference early on. Skilled dwellers before having the rooms to train them yourself are sheer gravy. There is a catch with both, though.

Part of the game's fun is to figure out, which items are worth keeping and which aren't. When you buy boxes, make sure you have the item storage space - and remember, a dweller, who loots the wasteland, may come back with 40 items.

The catch of skilled dwellers is a little tricky. You want your highest level dweller to roam outside for loot. The starter pack gives you a brutal advantage to this end. However, when you just started, your average vault level will rise significantly with the starter pack. So don't forget to give one of the weapons coming with the pack to your guard room. Raiders are not much of a trouble throughout the game, except this early.

I hope that this short review gives you a fighting chance without the frustration of a vault wipe-out.

An underground, post-apocalyptic base-builder simulator? Please, sign me up!

It's a relaxing and casual game. If you're the type to base build and love to find loot, this could be the game for you.

The biggest issue I have while playing with this game is the Radscorpion Attack (I had the Radscorpion spawn twice in a row, with a 30 second period in between). Please remove them from the game or at least delay when they would start spawning until most of the vault has good gear. They're really annoying to deal with since they have a high amount of HP, They constantly move every 15 seconds, and they suck out more power leaving your entire vault powerless the moment that thing is finally killed. Combine this with the fact that it's very clunky to assign dwellers into a room to deal with the radscorpion and you'll get the greatest troublesome experience.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

You may wonder why someone would post a negative review with over 100 hours logged into the game.

Well...I enjoyed the game.  Played it waaaay back when it first came out (both on mobile and the Bethesda app), and after a recently replay of Fallout 4 fired it back up and have been having fun with it.  Got lots of dwellers.  Bought a bunch of stuff on sale (just to admit my level of investment).  Had just started leveling some max-stat characters and was about to start running them on quests...

And my save is corrupted.  Game crashes when trying to load my vault.  It looks like this is something that can happen when using cloud saves, which I did because I'd bounce between my desktop, laptop, and Steam Deck (which played it well).  I looked around for possible fixes, and nothing I found worked.  So all this time and effort (and a bit of money) put into this vault, gone.

It's a shame.  This is a fun little time-waster of a game.  But losing it all like this stings a little.

CRASHES CONSTANTLY

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda
¬º tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¬º tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8‚Äì10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you‚Äôve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don‚Äôt leave them too long or they‚Äôll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

I used to really love this game and play it all day long on my phone and PC. Despite the huge bugs and issues with difficulty cliffs causing your colony to collapse and lose weeks of progress, it was fun.

Then out of the blue, years after release, the devs replaced core features and gameplay balance with microtransactions.

They've taken a perfectly good idle colony builder game and gutted into a money-grubbing mobile game that's a serious hazard to anyone vunerable to gambling addiction or financial exploitation.

[h1] I finally did it [/h1]

After 60 hours on pc,
and according to statistics 60 more hours on ipad
120 hours into the game on my main vault i have finally 
reached two big goals, achievements and Story.

[h1] Vault stuff [/h1]

The vault 370 (which was named after my Gamer Tag Kons37 at the time)
was created on ipad in 2016 (presumably).
It started with a dweller (which name i dont recall) who is now named first
dweller. There is a also a dweller named One year fallout shelter, but
he isn‚Äôt that interesting, I don‚Äôt plan on making a 6 or more year dweller
but maybe if the vault reaches 10 years.

[h1] Little Device History [/h1]

As mentioned enough times, the world was created 
on iPad Air 2 in 2016, I have 60 hours on iPad, but
i stopped playing Fallout shelter once I transferred my progress
in 2021, I transfered to my current PC witch had :
[b] Ryzen 3 2200g, a 1TB HDD, 8 gb of ram. [/b]
Soon after I got a gaming PC where I played for about three months on,
this is also where I started playing with mods, the pc had :
[b] Intel i7-4700k, an RTX 2070 super, 32gb ram,
an M.2 boot drive and an HDD Storage Drive [/b]
I sold that pc, and then finally got my one and only main PC
running. It consists of :
[b] Ryzen 7 3700x, an RTX 3060 TI, 32gb ram, 
1TB Dual M.2 storage, 6TB Surveilance HDD storage and 
a lot of Fans. [/b]
This is where I am currently playing fallout shelter on,
and I‚Äôm not planning to upgrade anytime  soon, so it‚Äôs 
to be expected I shall play a lot longer on this pc.

[h1] Dwellers [/h1]

I currently have 9 of the 23 legendary dwellers, and 200 dwellers total.
I wanted to collect them all, but i did start optimizing ressource output 
and scrapped tons of Legendary Dweller outfits and weapons and replacing
them with rare counter parts, i will soon start re-aranging rooms for a third
time and probably be done with the vault layout.

(100 M / 100 F)

My main dwellers are currently ; Kons, Leon, Andrew, Elizabeth.
Kons, Andrew and Elizabeth we're my first and best quest team i had,
they started out with legendary Raider outfits and Raider swords,
after i gave them heavy merc gear and gave one of them a minigun.
Then i gave them power armor and varius Laser Gatling-guns.
Now i finally gave them all X-10 Mk 6 Armor with "Revenge" to all my
Dweller's living in the highest floor.

[h1] First Feat [/h1]

I also reached all Scrap Items but that isn't a big feat.
Tough it was one of the first big things i reached, i didn't document it
but it was a big moment i presume.

[h1] 100% Achievements [/h1]

I have reached all achievemnts recently, it wasnt super hard
but also required a lot of waiting for raider attacks, lot of weapon
upgrading, scrapping and changing to maximise my defense.

[h1] 100% Quests [/h1]

Then i completed all quest's, i reached 100 quest's a while ago
but it didn't update the achivement when transfering from ipad to pc.
So i did a lot of side quest's too, most of the times waiting for mr.handy quest's.

[h1] Legitness? [/h1]

I haven't paid for anything till 2 days ago, where i bought the starter pack
because i wanted to have that aswell, i also have been using the "Fallout
shelter modpack" from Nexus mods. Link here : https://www.nexusmods.com/falloutshelter/mods/2
I have been using it to get 100% scrap rate and more mr.handys per etage,
also that nuka cola factories produce nuka quantum [b] LIKE THEY SHOULD [/b]
while some may find this cheating i was already a long way in and the game's
limitations are really frustrating, that i can only hold 100 items when
exploring doesnt make it any better.

I never used any mod to give me unlimited ressources or materials, tough 
this mod has the ability to do that, tough i never used it, you can change 
settings to make it easier / cheesier.

[h1] Continue playing? [/h1]

I am planning on finishing the game, tough i might publish a save file
someday if somebody want's that.
First gotta work on the room layout, storage is a big thing, get all 
dwellers respectably max stats for the dedicated room and have most 
if not all reach level 50.

[h1] Pet‚Äòs and Pet names [/h1]

I have a lot of pets (tough only 31/98) unlocked.
I only sold one pet this entire time (accidental)
but have kept every other pet i have found, 113 
so-far, minus one.
I named a few pets after pets of my family or friends
They are mostly with named dwellers.

[h1] More Vaults? [/h1]

370 isn't my only vault, but it's my best one and
will be till i reach 100% where i will make a 60
Dweller vault, till then i will continue crafting recycling
and producong more weapons till my vault has reached
perfection.

Despite being a promotional maneuver for upcoming Fallout 4, it is way more fun and balanced than the game itself.
Jokes aside, it is a good managemnt game and selfless dictator simulator. Latest updates made the game even better with all these quests and new enemies & mechanics and all this stuff. It can be played if you're stoned or drunk af and want to chill for some time, having some music or video playing in background. Probably can cure insomnia too. There are minor issues with this game being a PC port and UI though, also odd game design choices with radscorpions being more dangerous than deathclaws (who became too smol) and same stuff on Wasteland Log that you can read (oh no the Vicious Dog is too dangerous, but taking down a goddamn Yao guai is fine)
Nonetheless, this game can be both challenging and relaxing, so I can recommend it to everyone.

Steam's review character limit is too low to aptly encourage somebody to try this game. It's truly a certified hood classic.

As an idle game it excels in all aspects with excellent active playing content, good offline grinding, not to mention the great quality of not going overboard on pay-to-win mechanics. One should note, however, this game is a rather large time commitment and it really is a long term project. Don't go into it expecting to be able to grind for as long as you want, when you want, because it simply does not function that way. In all honesty the game's design is genius because it forces recurring active gameplay or you cannot progress.

Lastly, the game is a great creative outlet as you're more or less able to do whatever you want. 

Oh and it's free. Just get it. :)

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I used to think this was good because i'm already a fan of Bethesda Games but you should:

1) Worry about any program that doesn't provide any means to uninstall it. There are no uninstall options for this on my system anywhere including the expected traditional places and tools i am using like IOBit Uninstaller.
2) It really is a bit of a scam designed to encourage people to spend lots of money buying pointless lunchboxes that offer mostly crap, and once you have done it once it doesn't much serve any future purpose.

I think for what this game is (effectively a mobile game), and the time I spent in this game I can somewhat recommend this. Essentially this game is a base building simulator with people and tasks you micromanage, and for the 12 hours I played I found it to be engaging. I liked the quests where you travelled out of the bunker, and the loot you could get, but with the long waiting times on the way and back it sometimes took a while to get stuff done. This is where microtransactions came into play as specific currencies could speed up processes. I never bought into this crap, and I managed to build a halfway decent place for my people. I think overall I'd recommend this as it's free, and I got a little bit of joy out of it, 5/10

This game hasn't been designed for computers and definitely not for offline playing. I had about 100 crashes when I tried to play it offline, it went fine when online. Which is absurd, this is a computer game, not a phone game. Also, I dislike that game time passes even when the game is off, because this makes no sense, I may not want to play for a week without my game suffering. Also, I had some kind of emergency while I was  away from the computer, when I returned, I had 7 of the 23 dwellers I had alive. Everyone else was dead. I got angry and quit the game, thinking I can revive them later. Nope. When I turned on the game today, surprise surprise, I have only 7 dwellers and nobody to revive. So basically my game went from fine to zero just because I wasn't on the computer for 15 minutes. Well, thanks but no thanks. This is nothing worth wasting your time on. It's something a 10yo may enjoy, but grown ups usually can't.

Game is a lot easier than it was from 2015-2020. (I max'd out on mobile)

You gain way more caps, lunchboxes, and dwellers. Revive costs and unlocking rooms/cost of them are very cheap. Daily objectives are very easy and give very generous rewards. Game is not pay to win in anyway, spending money is just a quality of life. You can easily play this game and enjoy every bit of content without spending a dime.

I would recommend this game to any Fallout Franchise lovers. Good graphics, quests, items, pets, weapons, armor, etc. There is even a crafting system for weapons, outfits, and armor like Fallout 4. It's like sims, but post-apocalyptic.

Near end-game content becomes a grind and rng for completing your storage collection of all the legendary items (There are a lot!). So you may be max level with everything, but you may have not of gotten that Fatman or T-51 Armor.

Replay ability is really only necessary if you are trying to play the game a certain way and restrict yourself. This is kind of a *makes single save file* kind of game.

Fallout Shelter is a free-to-play mobile game where you build and manage a Vault and take care of the people inside it, even though 99% of Vaults in Fallout were sinister experiments. There's microtransactions to skip the inevitable waiting times that come with doing anything, or to get better loot. It initially came out in 2015 as part of a marketing campaign for Fallout 4.

The gameplay is puddle-deep and mindless once you get to understand it, as F2P mobile games generally are: simple resource management, building rooms, and sending out Vault dwellers to scavenge or do quests. Most of [i]that[/i] is just waiting around for bars to fill up, unless you buy the microtransactions. There isn't any story or endpoint at all, which oddly enough means it has better story than Fallout 4, which is an RPG with 90% bad writing and a stupid plot where most of your problems are only solved by shooting at them.

There's a recurring problem of people's saves being deleted or corrupted, with no apparent way to get them back even if you spent money on them. Bethesda took an RPG franchise about the nature of post-apocalyptic society and turned it into a Skinner box that doesn't even work right. The art is pretty good though, so I'll give it that.

[h1]Ingame purchase not received and no help from either Steam or Bethesda - FRAUD[/h1]

I am no stranger to this game as I played it 6 or 7 years ago when it came out on mobile.  Where I really screwed up was assuming that Steam and/or Bethesda could complete their obligation of a $3.99 in game transaction.

After installing the game recently and playing it, I remembered how useful the Mr Handys were for maintaining my shelter.  I went to the store to buy a 5 pack of them for a very affordable $3.99.  I bumped up my Steam Wallet to make the purchase, the purchase went through... and I never got my Mr Handys.

No problem, file a ticket with Steam to let them know what happened, right?  Yeah, I did that, and in the reply to the ticket, Steam said there was no refund for items consumed ingame.  Great, except that I never received them and they do not exist in my game.  How were they consumed, exactly?  Problem is that you have no recourse in these circumstances as you cannot get an actual human to look at the facts and examine what items are present ingame.

Filing a ticket with Bethesda was fruitless too, as they advised me to request a refund from the retailer that I got the game from.  So, if the publisher of the game (Bethesda) cannot help me because I purchased the game item through a third party distributor (Steam), and the third party distributor refuses to help, why would I even bother with the third party distributor?  Why not just go directly to the publisher of the game?

That is what I suggest everybody do since it's apparent Steam will not assist in broken ingame transactions.  I've been a Steam user for years and have spent thousands of dollars on the platform.  Glad it only took a $4 transaction failure for me to learn to not trust them.  I hope they enjoy the $4 as that is the last dime Steam will see from me, ever again.

I've played Fallout Shelter for years on a tablet. I loved it there. (Although, I found the increasingly aggressive attempts to monetize it annoying.) Now, I've attempted to run a vault on the PC. (Full disclosure: I played in Survival Mode. In my opinion, it's the best version of the game.)

I HATED it. The "current" PC version is clearly an old buggy build that time forgot. It saddles you with an insanely steep learning curve that stonewalls you unless you pay. I guess when they couldn't monetize the PC  version of FS the same way as the mobile version they gave up on it.

Don't waste your time or bandwidth on this relic. If you think you'll like Fallout Shelter then download the mobile one and resist the ads option when speeding up your rooms. You'll be a lot happier.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Probably not the best introduction for the franchise, but here goes.

The game is self-explanatory and easy enough to jump right into with little guidance, a little trying on your first run, but consider that as the initiation to the game, as the second run you should have almost everything laid out mentally for a successful run.

-	Not really an idle game, especially at the start of a new game, but you set yourself up for minimal work later.
-	Personnel leveling, again you get them to level 50 s fast as you can and when you have the facilities and equipment in place you ‚Äòreplace‚Äô them with better developed level 50 personnel.
-	Quests are recycled and get monotonous (for me personally)
-	Base building is limited and storage even worse the more advanced you get

It was a short-lived venture with this title, as even in the background for me became tedious, not to say others won‚Äôt enjoy it.

Recommended : ‚ÄòErk‚Äô yes
Replayability : Droning but there
Drawbacks : Limited in where it could have gone

Pros: You build out your own Fallout Shelter and manage the dwellers, power, food, water, defense, etc. Basic game that anyone can play. Not overly complicated. Does provide something come back to and keep growing, but keep in mind this isn't a game you just sit and play for hours on end as there are timers. (See Cons)

Cons: Definitely has a pay feature to speed things up so you're not waiting sometime hours for completions on quests, skills, etc. The wait times on quest traveling and training can be rather long and have that mobile game feel to make you come back hours later. This is not a game you sit and just keep playing all day as eventually you will run out of things to do besides collecting items your base produces.

fun shelter sim life

I forgot why I stopped playing this game on the bethesda launcher, but now that its come to steam and I have had a 60 hour refresher I can review it.

First its just your standard free-mium, whale-user hunting, base building game with a fallout skin on it. 
Second radscorpion attacks that you can't fight because they jump between rooms too fast and will drain your base's power so that you can't do a damned thing about it.
Third some of the room skills and clothes that help with them DO NOT aesthetically mesh.

This game has a random emergency event system that has fire, ghouls, animals or raiders attack your base, and most are fine and defensible.
Most come through the vault door, so posting a strong guard helps a lot, but some can happen in any room like fire, molerats, or radscorpion burrowing in and draining your power.
The molerats are fine as long as you don't ignore them and send settler there ASAP they will be contained and dealt with, but the radscorpions do not wait.
They burrow in and by the time that you can move a settler from an upper floor or even across you vault they will have already moved to another room.
Basically you are out of luck unless they burrow into an already populated room with good enough weapons to kill it and their absurd health pools.
I don't know how many times my vault became unplayable because of too many radscorpion attacks that either killed my residents, or made it so I couldn't feed, water, or heal them.
I seriously have an easier time fighting off and/or dealing with the aftermath of deathclaws that can near one shot my settlers invading my vault than these things.

As if that wasn't enough the armor stats and which outfits help you in what room is all weird.
You would think that a radiation suit would best help with a settler assigned to a nuclear reactor, but it doesn't. It only helps with water production and only battle armor and military clothes help with power generation.

Worst part is that bethesda has basically given up on this game in favor of whale hunting in china with Fallout Shelter: Online, so this game with stay the unforgiving sh*t show that it is.

[h1]The more invested you get, the worse it becomes.[/h1]

The hit boxes on characters and rooms are AWFUL! I've often tried to click on a dweller to check on them, only to accidentally send them to a room on a different floor. The larger the vault became, and the more things I had to micromanage, the more annoying this got.

Also, there are "tasks" which you get rewarded for completing, such as "put out so & so fires." The problem is that the progress count sometimes resets on me. The only correlation I've noticed is when steam cloud isn't quite synced, which happens often. And some of these tasks can take a long time and depend on chance.

To make things more annoying, after my vault reached a certain size, the game would frequently have Deathclaws attack. It became much more frequent than attacks by Ghouls or Raiders. It had gotten so common, that I just felt annoyed each time.

Between the sheer amount of things to micromanage when your vault gets bigger, and the sloppy or otherwise buggy game mechanics listed above. I eventually got disgusted and uninstalled this game.

And no, I'm not gonna spend money on the Nuka Quantum. (read: freemium currency) They do nothing to mitigate any of the problems listed above anyway.

This game is mostly fun but has some dramatic flaws which aggravate me. Power generation is this game's primary flaw. It seems to have some arbitrary scale between how many power generation stations you create, and how much power is needed to run the vault. As an example, say you build 8 of the most powerful power generation modules available in the game. Which should be MORE than enough to maintain the balance of power (so to speak). Well, your power bar remains at 50% no matter what you do. Then, you have a random radscorpion attack on say, a water module. Your dwellers successfully kill the scorpion, and all of a sudden, your power bar is down by 75%. I do not see how my many hours of power generation to maintain the status quo, is suddenly destroyed by an attack on a water module.
Next most painful flaw in this game is when you click on a toon to check it's status. Out of nowhere, the toon immediately runs to exit the module (room) it is in, attempting to escape to who knows where? I want to check all my toons in a room to ensure they have the best armor/weapon available to them ... but I have to chase the SOBs to the elevator, to catch them and place them back in their proper location.
I suppose my primary complaint is that I have to click on each and every module (power, water, food) in order to "harvest" that module's output. Like some fricking clickfest, every 30 seconds I have to sweep across the screen with dozens of mouse clicks to ensure the (power, water, food) is delivered. Fricking Farmville
I could go on, but I need another beer. Like so many games before it, this is a love/hate relationship. The flaws are major and annoying. The positives are diametrically enjoyable and fun.
As a completionist, when I finish this game, I will then never play it again.

Fallout Shelter is a free-to-play game in the Fallout series; the player to creates their own vault and acts as the overseer. It's a resource management game - you have to make sure there is food, power, and water for your vault dwellers.

Each vault dweller starts with a vault suit and their fists as weapons. These can be upgraded as you discover/manufacture better weapons and outfits. items can be found outside of the vault. Additionally, you can build rooms that allow you to manufacture items.

As the game progresses, you build more rooms in your vault to allow your residents to develop their attributes, and assign them jobs based on those attributes to make each room run efficiently.

You can also send up to 25 vault dwellers out into the world as explorers, to bring back money and items. And you are able to send parties of dwellers out to go on quests. The quests yield higher values of loot, and have fun little storys.

There are microtransactions within the game - you can buy bonuses that speed the game along, but they aren't really necessary. This is not a game you play all at once, it's a game you play for 10 minutes at a time and then come back later to collect on the outcomes of your decisions.

For example, you may choose to develop a vault dwellers strength attribute but putting them in a gym. That will take X amount of time in real time to achieve. The higher the attribute, the longer it takes to develop it. The same is true for manufacturing weapons and outfits, and your key resources (water, food, power).

Should you buy it? Yes, absolutely, it's free!

Is it fun? It is, but it's also an exercise in patience. The way I play it is I get up in the morning, put in my 10 minutes or so, and close it up until after dinner. A friend called it "the game you play between other games."

As of this review, this game has had over 100 million users over the various platforms it supports.

So I was casually playing Fallout shelter when I hear my doorbell ring. I wasn't expecting any friends, so I looked out the window, and saw a man standing at my door, and I didn't recognize him. So, I went on over and answered the door."Hello there" I said nonchalantly. He responded with "Hi, I was wondering if you had a few minutes to hear the word of God?" So I said "Unfortunately, no, not right now. I'm a bit busy, but if you give me your address, I can swing by later tonight and I can tell you about Atheism." So he says back "Well, sir, um... I don't want to give my personal information out to random people..." So my response is "What? Why? You don't want a random stranger knocking on your door in the middle of the day and trying to shove their religion down your throat? Kinda hypocritical, don't you think?" He just looked completely befuddled as he turned away and started walking down the street, off to his next house. As he stormed out, a couple of the passerbys started to whistle and cheer, soon my neighbors joined in and even some drivers. I gave a wave and went off with a feeling of accomplishment.

So I've played games like this before, like Tiny Tower and Doomsday Preppers on Android, and oh my lord did I play them... Being fairly new to Steam, I knew what to expect from this type of game more or less, but would like to catalogue what types of games I do enjoy on my cloud profile, hence now playing this game  after I've spent hundreds of hours on previous other games like this before of which there are no more records....

Anyways, this is Fallout themed and perhaps the most polished version of these type of games I've played or seen so far, to the scope of my knowledge. It is however a very popular type of genre that has been cloned before frequently.

That being said, I would advise people against going in on too much of these games other than enjoyment. I've started playing this mostly because, as with many of my gaming experiences, many of it has gone undocumented, so this is probably one of the last of these types of games I'll play unless something greatly more advanced or rewarding comes along.

Its a semi-idle clicker type of grinding game... You can have it open while watching a show on the other screen and it keeps one interacted and engaged in a relaxed manner off the side. However, I'm starting to develop an aversion to, above anything else in games, especially in free-to-play, I'm fighting the clock. 

I always imagine developers thinking that their player bases grind so hard for things they can add with a few command buttons but they are waiting for the spenders to purchase things on merit of enjoying the experience and looking to advance. So that brings me back to my point on enjoyment. In future when markets are more competitive in rewarding consumers first in blockchain platforms fighting the clock will see a re-emergence. We need a net-zero economy principle to drive these type of markets. Because eventually these games become a subverted clock watcher while you wait 20 hours for a quest to finish while you endlessly farm food, water and power as events script you to net-zero pre-meditated progression, which is a perfect metaphor for farming in real life.

Anyways... give this game a try, its pretty good for a time-waster, and its a bit more involved than some of the other similar games in the genre that I've played and experienced before.

A fun game that is free to play. Money helps speed up the game, but is not the only way to win. Like a farming game you grow and gather things for your characters. After you make the headquarters you go on quests. It moves slowly sometimes, but keeps being action packed in the end. Instead of gushing about how this is the greatest idle game of all time, I'm gonna share with you some major tips and tricks that will definitely help you out when planning your vault.

[b]1.The population sweetspot for the early-game is 30 Vault Dwellers[/b]
- A vault population of 30 will unlock the four essential training rooms for raising the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats necessary for critical resource production (Strength for Power, Perception for Water, Agility for Food, and Intelligence for healing items), while also keeping your vault easy to manage and preventing the more difficult emergencies from spawning. This way you can focus on building up a core team of well-equipped, well-trained dwellers in preparation for the mid-late game and won't have to worry about being wiped out by Radscorpions or Deathclaws the first time they attack your base :3 

[b]2.Expanding or Upgrading a room increases the threat level of dangerous incidents that occur in that specific room. [/b]
-Expanding rooms increases the danger level linearly to match the higher worker capacity, meaning it's generally always safe to expand rooms as long as you have enough dwellers to fully staff them. 
UPGRADING rooms is where it gets tricky: upgrading a room DRASTICALLY increases the health and damage output of infestations that occur in rooms. 
- A radroach infestation that occurs in a level 1 room can be safely dealt with by workers wearing nothing but their jumpsuits and wielding their bare fists. 
- To deal with a level 2 infestation with the same level of efficiency, you'll want all of your workers to be wielding actual weapons like shotguns and rifles, which deal 6-7 times more damage than bare hands. 
- For fully upgraded level 3 rooms, you'll want your Dwellers to not only be wielding top-shelf weapons, but be a high level with decent S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats as will. 
-- This becomes especially noticeable when dealing with mid-late game threats like Radscorpion attacks. A Radscorpion that tunnels into a small level 1 room can be solo'd by a level 1 dweller with a sawed-off shotgun. If that same Radscorpion tunnels into a level 3 room, it can potentially wipe out a full team of level 20 dwellers armed to the teeth with laser rifles if you don't keep an eye on their health and radiation levels.
-Threats that can move between rooms (such as the aforementioned radscorpion) will scale up or down to match the level of the room they're currently in, so you don't have to worry about threats from high level rooms killing low-level dwellers in low-level rooms.

[b]2.Re-roll Vaults for better starting gear! [/b] 
- Lunchboxes can contain literally ANYTHING including Legendary-grade Dwellers and equipment, and you're guaranteed 3 Lunchboxes at the start of each game via some very easy-to-complete overseer objectives that you can finish in the first 5 minutes of gameplay (sucessfully rush one room, collect 50 water, and level up one Dweller). 
The game has save slots for 3 separate vaults, so if you pull something decent but think you can still roll better, you can still keep the first vault while rolling a second and third. 
- 7 out of 9 starts gave me starting equipment I was happy with, although I could just be really lucky (yes, I'm running 7 vaults at the same time - 4 on the Switch and 3 on Steam). Below are some examples of notable loot I've pulled.
Vault 502 (switch):  Two Rare Dwellers and a Rusty Laser Pistol (one of the best common-grade weapons)
Vault 619 (switch): One Rare Dweller and a Gauss Rifle (very good rare-quality weapon)
Vault 777 (steam): -Giddyup Buttercup and Military Circuit Board (Legendary junk, but useless during the early game except that they can be sold for 200 caps each)
Vault 420 (steam) - Bespoke Attire (+4 end rare outfit) and a Missile Launcher (extremely good legendary weapon)
Vault 619 (steam) - Bittercup (Legendary Dweller) 
Vault 777 (steam - rerolled): a Guided Missile Launcher (insanely good legendary weapon) and some Nuka Cola Quantum (used for speeding up travel time and training) 
Vault 000 (switch) - rare junk and 500 bottlecaps x3
Vault 422 (switch) - James (legendary dweller), Advanced Labcoat (+5 int rare outfit), Commander Fatigues (+7 str legendary outfit)
Vault 916 (switch) - Hardened Shotgun (decent rare weapon), Lincoln's Repeater (legendary weapon), Star Paladin Cross (legendary dweller)
- Personally I recommend re-rolling until you have at least one Rare Dweller and one Rare Weapon so you can immediately start going on wasteland expeditions right out of the gate, since that's how you'll be obtaining the vast majority of your equipment for the rest of your dwellers. 

[b]4. Don't waste caps upgrading your Vault Door![/b]
The Vault door slows down attacks that come from the surface (raiders, feral ghouls, and deathclaws, but NOT radroaches, molerats, or radscorpions), however it doesn't keep them out completely, nor does it weaken them in any way, and you'll always have to fight off the attack regardless in order to resume normal gameplay.
Surface invaders will always move through your vault linearly from top to bottom, engaging any vault dwellers they come across and skipping over unoccupied rooms. Stationing your strongest fighters on the first floor and your weaker dwellers on the lower levels is a good way to stay safe. 

[b]5: Managing Dweller Happiness[/b]
- Your entire vault receives a production bonus based on the overall happiness of the residents, and some of the random Overseer objectives you'll receive will ask you to max the happiness of a set number of dwellers. 
- Dwellers start with 50 happiness by default and gain happiness when assigned to the job that they're best suited for, up to a minimum of 75, and slowly increasing with work performance.
- Dwellers can lose happiness by failing at rush jobs, spending a long time at low health, or by suffering from radiation poisoning. 
- Making babies will immediately max-out the happiness of the couple to 100.

[b]6. Assign Dwellers to training rooms and expeditions before logging out![/b]
- Time will continue to pass even when the game is closed, and dwellers will continue to gain progress towards S.P.E.C.I.A.L. training, item crafting, exploration, and child development for as long as you're offline at the same rate as they would if you had the game open, only stopping when the task is complete. However, resource drain is limited to a fixed amount while offline (I think it's capped at 10 minutes worth of consumption) so you don't have to worry about your dwellers dying from starvation or dehydration while closed out. 
- This is the main reason why I can run seven vaults at the same time; this is a true idle game that allows you to make significant progress without having to leave the game open.
- Incidents and invasions will not occur while the game is closed, so your everyone inside the vault will be safe while you're away.

[b]7. In-game Purchases are not necessary to enjoy the game![/b]
-Turns out, everything that can be purchased for real $$ can be earned in-game for free - however, some like the Mr. Handy robots are exceptionally rare (I've only found ONE so far across all seven of my vaults, and it was as a random quest reward).
Mr. Handy's will automatically gather resources for you and will assist with vault incidents without requiring food and water like regular dwellers do. While definitely convenient, they aren't at all necessary to progress through the game, and my main Vault on the Switch gets by just fine without using any. 
- There is a $5 starter pack that contains a guaranteed Legendary Vault Dweller, legendary weapon, legendary pet, a load of caps and Nuka-Cola-Quantum, AND a Mr.Handy robot, which personally I think is a VERY solid deal if you don't want to re-roll vaults.
- I uh, wouldn't recommend gambling on regular Lunchbox purchases unless you're the kind of person who REALLY enjoys gambling, or loves the Bethesda and wants to support the devs with $$.

Surprising for a free to play game with monetary transaction, this fallout inspired base builder survival game sets itself above the rest. It does this in a lot of minor ways, which enhances the overall game including such things as romances, finding new settlers in the wasteland, training your resident's skills, sending out your team for missions, invasion from wasteland creatures, romance, gear making and much more. Tapping on the huge lore and world building of fallout, the scenarios and missions are on the funny and humorous side, enough to make you appreciate the wit but not enough to dumb it down. In the end you will be spending a lot of time balancing your resources and managing your residents. While these plus points are among the attractive bit to keep you invested, it is still a freemium which you can pay to get exclusive and higher powered cards in the form of gear, resources and even people. However despite that, you can still not spend a cent and yet still enjoy the game for quite a while with the content packed into it and storyline. There are daily and weekly challenges that keeps the game going and fresh.

Every time I come back to this game, it always is enjoyable. It may be slow and may allow for micro-transactions but, honestly, I never have spent a dime while having gotten quite far in the game. The game is timeless, I would know I got it on my phone before I got it on pc and have had a fairly similar experience. It is different than much of the rest of the Fallout franchise but I still love it anyway!

This game is the single greatest thing to ever grace our plebeian existence. It moved me to tears, made me laugh out loud, question authority, and commit hate crimes. The art direction is masterful, the colors more vibrant than my LSD-induced visions. I met my wife playing this game (she was eaten later but I digress); I was playing this game on my Steam Deck one night at the local bar. She came up behind me and said, "Is that Bethesda's hit MMORPG Fallout Shelter (2017)?". I said, with a smirk, "what else?". We went in the back and she gave me a pity kiss on the forehead. Fast forward a year and we get married. I also got a promotion after my boss realized I played this game.
All in all, a masterpiece that everyone should revere and worship as the greatest game of all time.

Announced during E3 2018, it seemed to be only a "sparring partner" to the long-awaited Fallout 76 but over time it is proving to be a real highlight of the Bethesda library.
The main rule is: build only according to the inhabitants and not vice versa.
The game is to all intents and purposes a management challenge in which energy, water production and food management require constant monitoring to ensure that the level of happiness among the inhabitants remains high, constant threats such as fires, invasions of cockroaches and mole rats, incursions of raiders regularly undermine such happiness. The main feature are the "sprints" that is forced accelerations of production in a given plant. If the vault-boy shows the thumbs up, the sprint has been successful with increases in happiness and production but if the outcome is negative then the aforementioned dangers take over. The inhabitants suffer damage from radiation and generics, treatable with stimpaks and radaways if present in the warehouse, if they are not there they can also die but at the price of a handful of caps the inhabitant can be brought back to life. The external missions are the interesting part of the game, they activate after the construction of the overseer's room but it is better to get a good amount of Nuka-Cola Quantum.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Some of the reviews for this game don't seem to realize that this was a throwaway teaser for mobile devices that came out with the announcement of Fallout 4. Subsequently it had the unfortunate effect of really selling Bethesda on the power of microtransactions, but hey, that's on the public, and not Bethesda (for once). 

You could play this for free while you waited for your oil change, almost completely oblivious to the fact that spending money on it was an option. As far as I know you can still play the game, such as it is, for free, and in no time at all, you will have spent more time than it took them to develop it. The fact that modern generations will bankrupt themselves on "fidget spinner" games is not Bethesdas fault (for once).

I made a steam account not long ago and have already logged far too many hours playing Fallout Shelter. Mindless and sorta addictive game.

Fallout Shelter is an iOS and Android game that was ported to the pc based off of the Fallout franchise. The game has you managing resources such as power, food, and water as well as sending dwellers out to the wastes to collect supplies such as weapons, armor, junk, and bottle caps. The junk that you gather can be used to craft gear that you will occasionally find blueprints for and the caps allow you to expand your vault and revive dwellers if needed. You will eventually be able to send dwellers out to complete quests that payout with bigger rewards such as Nuka-Cola quantums and lunchboxes, this games form of "loot boxes".

The game itself is a fun time waster and doesn't require you to spend any money on it if you don't want to, however if your a completionist expect this game to bog down your completion score for quite awhile. In order to 100% I had to resort to some "unconventional methods", I would guess it would take no less than a couple of real world years and a small fortune to do so otherwise.

I would say the worst part of the game is the shameless use of loot boxes and the achievements that encourage you to buy them.

The game nails that Vault-Boy aesthetic and lets you collect some familiar characters and gear from Fallout 3 & 4. I would say that once you reach late game it losses it's appeal with no real end game, I would compare it to staring at an ant farm if the ants where wearing X-01 power armor. For the all time low price of free, it's worth checking out if your a fan of the franchise.

It's a serviceable mobile game ported to PC. Now, while I have a ridiculous amount of hours in this game, I tend toward repetitive behavior so bear that in mind.
Honestly, this is kinda just "Waiting: THE GAME". It has lovely visuals, definitely has the Fallout vibe going for it, but ultimately the bulk of your productive time in this game is you being AFK. It's a mobile game gambit of letting you pay real money for rewards you'd have to spend tens of hours to earn through gameplay, or otherwise waiting days while items get crafted. Dwellers can leave the vault and explore the wasteland to collect randomly generated gear and loot. But the longer they are out there, the longer it takes them to get back. To get some of the best drops, they have to be out there for literal days, then  take yet more days to return. 
The most fun I had with this  game was honestly when I modded in the ability to skip the waiting on almost everything. But when you take that away you realize there's only a shell of an experience here. The combat system is frustratingly slow, and your only active role is healing your dwellers as they DPS. 
It's decent at very best as a short experience, but I honestly can't recommend this game to anyone.

[h1]A microtransaction store hidden behind a game[/h1]
If this was a $20 full game to buy that would have been great. Instead, it is a free game designed to sell you random worthless junk that masquerades as useful items. This is a classic example of creating problems to sell solutions.

Not to mention the UI isn't very smooth either. You can't even auto un/equip your dwellers, which means a disturbing amount of clicking to give guns each time you rush different rooms and get attacked by raiders. 
You know what's the worst? When you want to rush a room and then arm your dwellers if the rush fails. If they are injured you need to use a stim-pack first... I mean, come on. The whole game is designed to waste your time in a parasitic predatory manner, making you feel the pressure to spend real money to speed this tedious experience up. 
I had SO MUCH FUN playing quests. Only to do a few and then be stone walled from doing more. Real life hours to travel to the quest, log out, login, do the quest, real life hours to travel home, log out, login later, collect items. What a chore. No real game does this. This is not a game. This is a time wasting machine that wants to sell you time saving items.

I wanted to play this game and every time I get on I get to do things for 30 seconds-5 minutes and then that's about it. 
Play any further and you'll be punished by the game. 
It is a very frustrating trickling water style experience, which greatly encourages spending real money to make things go faster. This, of course, is a trash way to play a game. 
I feel sorry for the addicts this game reeled in that spent thousands on cola. Truly depressing when you think about it.

What the absolute f*%k is Bethesda doing to such an awesome franchise? Between this, TES Blades, ESO (Doesn't even have Oceania servers LOL) and FO76 the whole lot may aswell be dead. They do not care about your deeply invested interest in the Fallout or TES universes, they only care about sucking money from your wallets. It is utterly depressing because if they gave us actual games people would spend so much more and not be disillusioned about Bethesda's crap marketing.

Slow-pace gaming gives you a false appearance in extending your Valut. The worst result is dropping your Valut happiness if you extend too much rooms but no extending your populations. What's more the game needs more patience and wise strategies. Maybe I will recommend this game If the game can pace up its game pacing, but it didn't, and maybe it fits the players who has a lots of free times and patience, but not me :)

So I wake up in the middle of the night in my 2 bedroom apartment. I find me roommate passed out face down on the wooden floor. I think nothing of it and go back to sleep. The next morning I wake up to go to work and there is a homeless guy asleep on my couch. My roommate woke up still drunk and had made friends with a bum. And this is the second time he let a stranger off the street just stroll in and pass out. Great.
You are probably thinking what does this have to do with my arts and crafting.
Well I bought this product and proceeded to cover everything my roommate owns in glitter. Every T shirt, every book, ever pair of shoes, his bed... I covered his entire life in glitter. He will have glitter in every crevice of his existence until he dies.
Did some track out all over my apartment? yes. Does the carpet look like a care bear farted all over it? Yes. Did he threaten to kill me? Sure. But will he ever let another stranger sleep on the couch? No Will I ever have to worry about a random guy off the street murdering me in the night? No
All the security for just $12.44. Unbelievable Staggering Value. Cannot recommend enough.

ITS IN THE GAME
ok

First off, I'd like to simply say, yes this game is fun.

I will start at the most basic level. This is meant to be a pay to win game. You buy loot boxes, and pet boxes, Mr. Handy boxes, and you can buy a starter box. But don't kid yourself. The only box with anything in it worth buying is a Starter box for $5, and you can only buy 1 of them (in their store). Also the game's mechanics make it bonkers with how faster, and much difficulty scaling is. It's just at some point you feel like at end game, even with the best gear (named legendaries like Dragon's Maw, or the named Gatling Lazer, etc) mixed with either the +4 to 4 attribute items or simply X1 VI Power Armor you're basically just bringing Stimpacks/Radaway sitting there just literally watching the game use terrible AI for you to kill enemies with insane amounts of Health. I'm not even kidding, I've played level 50 missions before running them solo, and in groups of 3, it feels very much the same, only solo takes a little longer, and you expand less healing items. But you still sit there killing Alpha Deathclaws for like 3-5 minutes regardless.

So here is the biggest issue I have: You're exploring, and let's say you're lucky enough to get a pet that spawns the Mysterious Stranger 2-7.5 times faster. You see him more often, and get jackpots, and start building. But, here's the kicker, you finally get your workshop going and you can only make basic items, or you have to wait several hours or days to make a legendary (in theory early on) so while you're waiting, you get radroach attacks, radscroption attacks, one of my least favorite vault door attacks, feral ghouls, and then you're in shock, because you had pushed to far too fast by mistake or ignorance, and a group of Deathclaws rip through the vault doors, and kill everyone. Because let's say you have your best people in the wasteland doing runs, and you can't call them back in time, or you made your best female characters pregnant. Also let's say you had no idea about those periodic Deathclaw attacks. So that's just usually 3 of them, and you go through like 10 attacks. (If you're playing for a few hours a day during a Legendary item crafting process) Most new people can't survive one attack, let alone like 10+. So your game is dead, you wasted money on the store, and got nothing. Of course all Bethesda says is "Thanks for the money."

There are methods to make the game easier in game, such as doing story missions, and using the various SPECIAL buffing things like the Academy, and so on. You have to sit there for about 50 hours per attribute x 7 per character to fully max out a character. Having max Strength is usually always important unless you get a Rusty Weapon, or something with a high low end damage (like 14-15, etc) If you have Rusty Weapons, Strength becomes meaningless, so invest in Rusty Plasma Rifles mid game, they have a flat 17, which allows any character to just deal that damage regardless of Strength. Strength also does not increase damage over the limit of 17. So plan out how you want each character designed. 

I would have to say the most useless, and important attribute is Luck. But Luck is so random, and situational that it almost appears to do nothing. But end game, I've pulled 3 legendary items in a single room, where the mission only said 1. They were also too random to be part of the mission, and I have done said mission multiple times, and never duplicated it. I have had 4 end game files. I can honestly say two big things: Attributes can go beyond 10 (from item bonuses), but I think that may simply be for stuff like the Reactors, Restaurants, etc. I haven't seen much in the way of improved damage during missions from items beyond a 10 natural Strength.

Also important to note the weapon you choose to use. The highest end damage tends to be, and this is simply my opinion: Bad. I mean, yeah, you can get Fatmans, and Rocket Launchers, or Plasma Throwers, or even melee, probably the most two common melee weapons are the Baseball Bat, and the Pickaxe. But be warned: 1) Area damage seems incredibly nerfed, it can be split up many ways, and it feels like enemies take less and less damage from it. 2) Melee weapons are incredibly restricted, and your dweller using it, can end up doing nothing during combat if two other dwellers decide to engage in the monsters face with firearms. Why? Who knows. Why it's a good idea to use a Sniper Rifle, Laser Rifle, or Plasma Rifle point blank I will never know. But it blocks all melee dwellers usually from attacking at all, and they reposition far away doing nothing, except standing there. All throughout this time you could be fighting Deathclaws in the vault that hit the entire room, or Rad-Ghouls, Scorpions, etc that constantly cause radiation damage. So that melee dweller can actually die from not being able to engage and attack - That's bad AI.

In closing, I feel like this game's combat mechanic system is so poorly made, it was designed for a top down game that became a 2D side scroller. You can see the way the dwellers constantly move to different angles, or go around obstacles that would normally be easily ignored in 2D. This is one of the biggest issues with this type of combat mechanic. A Dweller may try their best to attack an enemy, and instead of remaining in position to help quickly kill an enemy, they reposition, and sometimes in an extremely bad way. They can literally let enemies get an entire round of attacks off, because they chose to reposition, which to the viewer seems literally meaningless, because it's a 2D game. But the game treats the environment as 3D top down, so it makes moves and actions that seem strange sometimes. - Well, I hope you enjoy this pay-to-win - high difficulty paced scaling game. Because if you play the way it seems designed, you'll be spending a lot of money getting set up, unless you find ways around this.

Fallout Shelter

This is definitely one of the more fun little survival game. For someone that maybe hasn't played a lot of the Fallout series it is still enjoyable to go along the story line with. However... I think this might be a little more fun if you play the actual Fallout games. Simply because it has certain references and even the little game show that asks you questions that previous game knowledge would cause it to make more sense. Either way - this is definitely a time consuming little game that can keep you on your toes. 

Achievement hunters: This game can be a bit of a grind - not going to sugar coat it. However, if you are down for the challenge it is very rewarding. This game can definitely sink a lot of time - for any "completionists" out there there is 1 achievement that will give you heart burn and that is the collection of 20 legendary dwellers. You can gain a couple from quests, sheer luck from a new dweller at the vault either radio station or found in the wasteland... not great chances. All I will say is you get a free lunch box every 7 days - do with that information as you will. Oh - Raider attacks, the count will only accumulate on a single vault, personally I did a survival vault and had a 20 dweller population (anything over starts other events other than raiders). Good luck!

Let‚Äôs be honest - things generally don‚Äôt go very smoothly for the humans living within the Fallout universe's underground vaults. Bethesda‚Äôs Fallout Shelter for iPhone and iPad gives us the opportunity to try our hand at doing better, to (hopefully) provide a better life for the citizens of the post-apocalypse. Balancing the need to produce food, water, and power - all while fending off radroaches, raiders, and other dangers is a good challenge‚Ä¶ at first. But oddly, once you succeed the fun fades away because of the lack of a planned-out endgame.


What could possibly go wrong when putting us in charge of a vault? In Fallout Shelter‚Äôs earliest (and most fun) moments, it turns out the answer is pretty much everything. The core gameplay loop is easy to understand - as new citizens are born or recruited into your vault, you must dig into a mountain to construct Living Quarters for them to sleep, as well as Water Treatment Plants and Cafeterias to produce their food and water, and Power Plants to keep all these factories operating.

Things build instantly, but you do have to wait to earn enough Caps to pay for construction - and Fallout Shelter commendably doesn't try to make us to pay to speed things up. In fact, you can't.

Citizens, who are drawn in the signature Fallout Vault Boy art style, are assigned to work in specific factories via simple drag controls, and they earn resources more rapidly if you correctly match a citizen‚Äôs stats to the factory in which they work. It‚Äôs satisfying to get everyone working in the perfect job and see your vault begin humming along. The catch is that for the first few days you never feel like you have enough people or enough resources to man every station you need manned, and that shortage creates the interesting decisions of Fallout Shelter. Do you want your shelter to have clean drinking water, or enough food to eat? Can you scrimp and save for another housing room?

It‚Äôs a fun game of trade-offs. Every time it feels like you might be getting ahead, a random raider attack, fire, or radroach invasion has the potential to knock your perfectly planned equilibrium out of whack. It kept me on my toes and kept me coming back, and so did the constant obscure references to Fallout Lore and amusing (albeit sparse) writing. The cheesy lines couples say to one another before obediently heading off-camera to make a baby are a particular highlight.


Unfortunately, the bigger your vault grows, the more this thoughtful balancing act fades away. Fallout Shelter gets easier the bigger your vault is - not harder. It feels backwards. My 150+ population vault has more than 25 people with no job at all, just wandering the floors. I no longer need to optimize my factories, because I have an excess of all resources. My citizens want for nothing, and I have no more buildings to unlock or goals to work towards. I can expand my vault deeper and build a sixth Power Plant or third food-producing Garden, but that would just give me an even bigger resource surplus. Have I won? Is this it?

Fallout Shelter is desperately in need of a set of endgame goals or resource sinks to look forward to and build towards, or else players will see all the game has to show us in around a week of steady play.

Fallout. I love the series, love this game even...
but...as so many others have noted, this game is riddled with issues that cause either players to have "failing" vaults, or create an inability to actually 100% this game. I have put in 48 hours and essentially "beat" the game. I have a successful vault with no issues on resources and a increasingly powerful amount of dwellers who roam the wasteland and complete missions with ease...yet...I have only ever received 1 legendary dweller.
I also apparently have only been attacked by raiders around 20 times.
This creates a really annoying problem that Bethesda does not seem to care about. I continually get death claw attacks and fight them off with ease...so what am I supposed to do? Leave my vault/game on for endless hours just to finish that annoying RNG spawn of raiders? The legendary dwellers just did it in for me. As I have played the game for almost 50 hours and complete numerous, numerous missions, opening loads of chests, I have received 1 legendary dweller. This leads me to believe that even if I DID spend hundreds of hours, micro managing every little mission to excellence, I could still inevitably end up never completing that achievement. This means it is a money grabbing achievement...and thus is just blatantly distasteful.

Cheesecake recipe

Ingredients
Ingredient Checklist
Crust:
1‚Äâ¬Ω cups graham cracker crumbs
¬º teaspoon ground cinnamon
‚Öì cup unsalted butter or margarine, melted
FILLING:
4 (8 oz.) packages cream cheese, softened
1‚Äâ¬º cups sugar
¬Ω cup sour cream
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
5 large eggs
TOPPING:
¬Ω cup sour cream
2 teaspoons sugar

Directions-instructions Checklist
Step 1
Preheat oven to 475¬∞F. Place a large pan filled with 1/2 inch water in oven.

Step 2
Make crust: Mix graham cracker crumbs and cinnamon; add butter or margarine. Press crust onto bottom and 2/3 of the way up a 9-inch spring-form pan lined with parchment. Wrap a large piece of foil around bottom of pan. Freeze until filling is prepared.

Step 3
Make filling: Use an electric mixer to mix cream cheese, sugar, sour cream and vanilla. Blend until smooth and creamy. Scrape down sides of bowl. Whisk eggs in a bowl; add to cream cheese mixture. Blend just until eggs are incorporated.

Step 4
Remove crust from freezer and pour in filling. Carefully place cheesecake into preheated water bath. Bake for 12 minutes; turn oven to 350¬∞F and bake until top of cheesecake turns golden, 50 to 60 minutes. Remove cake to a wire rack to cool.

Step 5
Make topping: Combine sour cream and sugar; spread over cake. Cover and refrigerate at least 4 hours.

When there's nothing left to do in the game except get 18/20 of the legendary dwellers that seem no where to be found... its time to write a review. 

This game would totally have my recommendation if I could get to 100% without playing for YEARS longer just to get the last achievement. Psshhh... free game, cool... but that was such a let down at the end. WHY would anyone want to grind out that last achievement?! Ugghhh... I didn't want to give up 6 months ago but I still haven't made any progress on it.

Surprisingly, they do update the game with holiday-themed missions and costumes for dwellers. It is still very anti-climactic once you have the last achievement. (Maybe even the second to last achievement you'll inevitably have left to complete; clearing 100 objectives. Sounds easy, right? It's a good game, but very much built for mobile. In this case, that means a lot of the conveniences and design language of desktop games aren't incorporated, (blocky, touch-oriented menus, limited organizational ability, etc.) and the play style is in many ways designed to continually draw you back and keep your attention in a way desktop games don't. The gameplay is... insecure, almost. As though if you leave and don't have a pressing reason to return, you won't come back- and thus, rather than adding depth and nuance to the mechanics or devising a compelling narrative reason to see the game through-it has daily quests, and incident timers, and...

It's okay. Decent, or alright, even. 

For a desktop game, though- competing against games that do more than the mobile-oriented gameplay of acting as a time sink through repetitive and grindy surface-level mechanics- it's outcompeted. Once I round out the last (5, at time of writing) few achievements I've yet to get, I fully expect to uninstall the game shortly thereafter and never play it again. 

For what it is, it's decent enough. If you like that, you'll like it. If you don't, this game is not going to change your mind, just because it happens to have the aesthetic of a fallout game.
