This game feels like a ploy to force players to make purchases. You either have to wait a really long time for something (getting any kind of resources, building things, playing the game in general), or make purchases through their game to speed things up. Attack events are enraging because your citizens don't defend, or once they try to attack, the enemies just up and leave so you can never defeat any opponent. You also can't leave your browser open in the background killing time while you do other things because it just pauses the game. From someone who plays civilization management and base building games, this could've been a great game, but falls short through design. I would caution anyone interested in playing this game to be prepared to spend a lot of time waiting, or just be okay spending money for every little thing.

Fallout Shelter is a shallow AFK game with a goofy and light Fallout sprinkle, no story.

"I have done nothing but collect resources and modify dwellers for 3 days!" Seriously the amount of managing dwellers and collecting resources gets tedious. 

The Missions, accessed by the Overseer Command Centre, aren't the most thrilling either. Exploration consists of setting up a party of 1-3 dwellers with your best weapon/armour, waiting real time hours for travel, then dragging them from one room to another, clicking to heal and collect loot. The crit system is cool

The "Fallout" aspect itself is weak too. There is no story in any missions, examples being "help BoS" [Bethesda sucks BoS d***] or "find grate ingredients with cheesy puns" 

Overall, once you've felt like you've experienced everything, you'll find nothing's worth replaying, and the secret is the micro-transactions to speed up your progress and make it less of a slog (I assume)

And the notches on his pistol numbered one and 19 more

Now the stranger started talking, made it plain to folks around

There was 40 feet between them when they stopped to make their play
And the swiftness of the ranger is still talked about today
Texas Red had not cleared leather 'fore a bullet fairly ripped
And the ranger's aim was deadly with the big iron on his hip

It was over in a moment and the folks had gathered round
There before them lay the body of the outlaw on the ground
Oh, he might have went on living but he made one fatal slip
When he tried to match the ranger with the big iron on his hip

Big iron, big iron

Fallout Shelter is your typical, freemium, time sink based idle game. That is to say, you make a few decisions then wait in real time for resources to collect and tasks to finish and then make some more decisions, and the process can be sped up with real world dollars. 

I remember being told this was a fun little time waster and that is more or less true. It is uncomplicated and made a bit more fun by things occasionally going wrong. But in this day and age there is a million idle games out there and I don't see myself recommending this one over any of the others. There is no real gimmick (except its set in the fallout universe) and maybe looks a bit better than your average idle game, but at the end of the day it is so bog standard. There is nothing really here to either make you think, or wow you, or feel anything other than that little dopamine hit you get from the numbers going up.

More over, I think the timing of things in the game makes it actively worse than many other idle games out there. Playing this game there is a bit to do early on, but then it peters out to a collection or decision roughly every few minutes with nothing to do in between. In my opinion idle games either have to have significant breaks in between clusters of decisions, so you can log out and do something else and maybe come back in a few hours or a day, OR little decisions actively flow in every few seconds so you having something to do. Fallout shelter tries to take the middle road, letting you collect things and make decisions every few minutes. What exactly am I supposed to do for those 2 minutes? Its not long enough to leave and not short enough to just sit there.

But, as is always the case with these sorts of games, that is the point. It keeps you hooked but also bored so you spend money. You want to leave, but to make any real progress you need to sit there and either find something else to do, or just be bored. 

Bottomline, there is nothing special about this grindfest of a game and I cannot recommend it. There are more interesting games out there, even for free.

I have played this game some more and am changing my review. If you play this game you need to realize it is a game that you play for about 1 hour or less at a time. Then you save & exit. You will not return to the game for however long you want, but it will be at least 3+ hours later usually. Some pointers that are not laid our very plainly. 

Pregnancies take about 3 hours to happen. Children mature after about 3 hours. DO NOT EXIT THE GAME WITH PEOPLE GOING OUT EXPLORING, OR TO A QUEST. You can exit after you set them to return to the vault. If you exit while they are on the way our, they will be dead when you log back in. If they are set to return before you exit, they will be at the vault when you log back in.

All in all a fun and challenging co-op game. While the game could be played without cards, the card selection allows players to tweak builds and create different skill sets to accomplish goals: Grenade deck, Melee build, DPS build, Medic deck, and Speed build to name a few of the more common skillsets.

Recruit mode is easy, a casual player can bust through this. Veteran offers challenges to a new player, but a seasoned player should breeze though it. Nightmare setting is the first major hurdle. It has gone through several iterations and is currently playable and challenging if the player does not use an exploit. With exploits--all levels are easymode.  Though Nightmare setting was unplayable through the middle quarter of 2021, the devs patched it into a workable game (as of Jan 2022). With a good team that understands their roles, communicates with each other, and is generous with what the game provides--you'll have a challenge (some failures) but also some epic wins.

There are glitches.
There are cheats.
There are exploits. And if you play that way, fine by me. Play your own game, have your own best experience whatever that may be.

My only real complaint (besides the Stalker family being really OP) is that the DLC is releasing so close to the release of the game. It's as if by design the devs were already working on the DLC at the same time as the core game--in which case it should have been included in the core game. It is a bad industry standard to set, kinda feels like designers are just squeezing players for any $$$ they can as fast as they can.

This game is a symbiosis of simulation and strategy where you literally ¬´dig¬ª your way underground for a better life. 

That's why it reminded me of ¬´Diggles: The Myth of Fenris¬ª videogame, where you also build your life underground with the gnomes.

We are given the role of overseer of the shelter and equip it. The main resource is the dwellers. Each has its own unique skills, which can be developed in the game. Dwellers can work, learn, go on quests and have families.

The only thing that might irritate, that this game is sessional. Collect resources, complete quest, came out and repeat. The reason for this is the time to do the job. Craft weapon or a costume can take more than a day, depending on the skills of the dwellers.

Also, the quests themselves can seem tedious because the firefights with the enemies are in turn and can last quite a long time.

Conclusion:
The game is good. I liked the cartoonish gameplay design, which is based on the image of a ¬´Vault Boy¬ª. It looks very organic. I recommend it to all fans of the Fallout universe.

Finally my chance to prove my post apocalyptic skill by being the overseer of a vault. And my science teacher said I would never do anything to advance mankind. I decide where and how many water generators, electric plants, and food developing plants to make. I get to determine who will explore the wasteland, who will breed, who will die. Ha Ha Ha. I am the god of the wasteland. 

I feel a need to make a few additions to this review. This game is free. Since no one but clergy men and saints work for free , the developers have to get their money somewhere. Bethesda gets their money through the sale of lunchboxes, quantum cola, and other accessories. 

Do you need to buy any of this stuff? Only the box of robots seems necessary. Without these robots you will not be able to collect resources when you are out of the game. This can cause real havoc on your vault. These robots cost $5.  If you can't afford $5 you probably should be looking for a job rather than playing this game. The lunch boxes give you extra caps, weapons, or vault dwellers, but these can be acquired through playing the game. The quantum cola lets you skip irritating wait times, like the 5 to 10 hour wait before you can do any quest. If you have the patience you need never use a quantum cola.



conclusion:

though the game is free, you will probably land up spending $5. If you are patient, you need not spend a dime more. If you don't mind chaos you won't need to even spent the $5.

This game is really fun for a 2D cartoon art style game. There's a lot of stuff to do, do quests, build more, get more dwellers, get clothes for your residents and a lot more! Though once you gett 200 dwellers the only thing(s) you can do is arm every one of them with the best weapons you can get, give the the best clothes with boosts for their S.P.E.C.I.A.Ls or just send them to rooms specified on a skill to level them up. You can also create more Voults and then start all over again. Once you've done everything that can be done, then start all over again, or you can just compete with your friends of who has a better Voult in design or in the Dweller's S.P.E.C.I.A.L, maybe even both, or you can compete in who gets the maximum amount of Dwellers faster, who builds a Nuka-Cola Quantum factory first. There several possibilities! All-in-all this game is fun. I really recommend trying it.

Fallout shelter is a well rounded game for a fallout spin-off title. this game have quite a bit of progression the diverse number of different rooms, weapons and items will have you sink a lot of hours for fallout shelter. 


Pros: 
the game has lots of buildings for the player to unlock 

the wide variety of weapons and items keeps the player interested


Cons: 

items are behind a paywall using the lunchbox system 

mobile game architecture 

lunchbox can restrict the player from getting certain items

the game has a downtime system where there is really nothing to do for certain times.

overall this a fallout spin off game that's really a mobile game ported to PC and console.

Many people write that they got bored of the game after a few months... it is because we as humans are impatient by DNA and the way we are programmed growing up.
Many things you do not know.. or may not have discovered are below... if you do know.. have you revisited the game to see all the additions over the past year?
[list]
Did you know....
[*]If you stay logged in while dwellers are out, they can find secret locations?
(14 mini interactive search, seek and combat missions in one hour)
[*]The Overseer office now have tons of quests currently 24 not including X-Mas ones.
[*]Your vault has bonus skins for the rooms. Christmas Diner  is really cool!!
[*]On all holiday's now they have endless quests all levels of difficulty
(CHRISTMAS IS AWESOME!)
[*]Combat and choices have increased in dialog based on level of dweller
[*]New rooms now added with more planning of vault
[*]More weapons, gear, and animal companions and blueprint fragments!!
[*]Found 22 Nuka-Cola in one hour of play. No need to pay but helps move along if you do.
[*]Found 18 Lunchboxes in 2 hours of play. No need to pay but helps move along if you do.
[*]Found 2 animal quests and containers from roaming dwellers deployed.
[*]Found 2 Discover Only legendary blueprints. Unlocked a new special room!
[*]New DISCOVER ONLY blueprints from roaming dwelling quests.

Take in account when I did the set it and forget it style of play... I was bored quickly.

So I said you know what, lets watch a movie, play for 2 hours and see what happens.

[h3] Suddenly 4 hours had passed and so many things popped out and just kept coming [/h3]

I only write this to advise many, that I played this game on its release, a year after and now two years after. Each time more refreshed, entertaining, and if you can be patient, the new discoveries are really neat and well done. Not easy at higher levels and tactical for sure.

So be patient, do not close the game and then suddenly expect to be amazed.
Do NOT let it run with "Set it Forget It", then  walk away because you can miss so much.
This is not made for those who want now now now... it is a grind at times, and other times s9 much to do. Evaluate the risk, have patience, and get rewards.

Wow... that sounds condescending as hell, but I don't mean it to be.

I've enjoyed the Fallout series for years, and this game definitely captures the spirit of the series.  I've always loved the 'retro-futuristic' look of the game.  They perfectly captured what the future would look like through the lens of 1950's America.

This is a casual game, but it is designed to entice you to buy in-game boosters to speed up the pace.  You don't *have* to do that but, if you don't, you can expect things to move at a snail's pace.  This isn't really a big deal for a game like this - it's not like it's non-stop action.  But, it does require patience to see any real progression.

It's fun and a pleasant distraction.  Just don't expect much instant gratification.

Lots of fun. Pretty easy-going game. Not a lot to do in a single sitting, but a great click-based game to play with your morning coffee! One year of Fallout Shelter with my coffee building the most complete shelter I could imagine!

I love this game. I mean, it is fallout. It does not consume a lot of time, as it is heavily based on timers that tick away while you are not even playing. You mostly have to occasionally pop on for 10 minutes or so, collect resources, spend your caps, expand your vault, check on your explorers, and you are done. Best of all it is completely free, and while there are loot boxes, I find it that you can play it very well without spending anything. You can also earn some nuka cola and loot boxes by various finishing tasks and quests. I understand this kind of game may not appeal to everyone, but I enjoy it and strongly recommend it!

Fallout Shelter does a good presentation of the series' ambiance (especially Fallout 4) and universe, with a new kind of gameplay that's obviously more suited to mobile gaming, but still functions well on PC. 
The whole "managing of your Vault" deal sets this game as a drastically better version of Fallout 4's Vault-Tec Workshop DLC. 
Overall a nice little game to kill time.

It has a tendency to crash frequently though, so be aware of that.
I mostly played Fallout Shelter on my phone, but enjoyed it on PC as well. Overall it's fun being the Vault Overseer. Definitely kept me entertained when I had to kill time.

When I started this game for the first time three weeks ago it was just the thing I needed. A slow, not too complicated management game that you could hop on and hop off whenever you had a few minutes to spare. It can't be binged since it's one of those phone/facebook games based on timers and that's good. I never really felt like spending real money on microtransactions and I guess people that might want to force it to be binge-able are the only ones that will.

The games management side can be fairly addicting, and that's how it felt for about 30+ hours but eventually the repetetive nature of it, especially the questing minigame caught up with it and it became more chore than fun and relaxing.

I've just gotten to where I could build the final type of room and I think I'll call it quits here.

Ok.. so After 10 Hours.. i can review this game.. So Fallout shelter is good.. its not perfect but its good.. One Positive is that... well its free.. now there's more positives its not just that its free obviously.. i love the fact that you can send people out to the wasteland and another positive is that you can EARN caps more easily then buying them.. Its Not Essential to Buy them with real money so goes with lunchboxes and everything else.. i feel that if your bored and want to play a great free game.. This is a good Option.. the reason why its not perfect is that after a few hours into the save file it feels more needed to buy lunchboxes.. i know i just said that its not essential.. and it isn't but its harder to get lunchboxes then caps on purpose.. but for what this game is.. its great. 7/10

This little game is slowly restoring my love and passion for fallout. Allow me to elaberate my testimony and experience with fallout... The first one i played was 3 but i was 12 years old at the time so i didnt understand much or have the time to play much. Years later i join the Army and learn about 4 and New Vagas. Quickly my passion for it grew I played and I played the fallout games. Then fast forward another few years i get married and 76 comes out so of course i get it! I loved the game but i hated the community and people in the game they started to slowly kill the vibe I had for fallout. Then a few months later I'm scammed out of my only few legacies by a couple of teenagers. I uninstalled the game a hated fallout for a long time. I've taken a good break from it and the xbox so i got a pc and here i am. So far I'm absolutely loving this. The soundtracks, the mechanics, the equality of it being challenging and fun is what makes it even more fun. It gives me a fallout 3/4 feel so I can appreciate that. Plus it was free cant complain about that. So i guess what I'm saying is thank you.

This game brushes so close up to perfection that I cannot believe they do not charge real money for it. I did a massive tips video on this game, and I finished it with a glowing review: [url=https://youtu.be/eOH4xiunf-g?t=6261]Full Review and Tips Guide[/url]

The biggest upside of this game is that it favours a drop-in drop-out style of playing, so you can play it through the day without having to invest hours at a time. Also, I super super super love the fact they don't make you wait for buildings to construct.

The only downside is that once you have a vault full of super dwellers, technology, weapons, tech and caps, the challenge sort-of goes away. After around 80 hours I was breezing through objectives and vault attacks. But, getting over 100 hours of fun out of a free game is still amazing.

I started playing it without realising it's was a mobile game ported to PC...so yeah most of the time I just wait for the timer to run out. I'm not pointing it out as a bad game just tedious. Building up stats takes weeks, literally. I don't think anyone can ever complete it, it's pretty much a simulation program where you just keep testing different possibilities.

Few things that makes the game a bit annoying at times is - First the camera auto focus during incidents or when you click on a room make me misclick on dwellers pulling them out of the room or level them up by accident. Second the Level Up button has quite a bit of area to trigger and is prioritised over every other menu or buttons or even through the floor, so in case a dweller is right underneath some menu you can actually level them up by accidental clicks. I want those Level Ups to help them refill their HP, with limited number of weapons it became a requirement for me to micro manage each dwellers equipment.
One the plus side it's a trap, the game can be addicting for some. It's difficulty is casual with detailed visuals, making it enjoyable.

I'd recommend the game because it was fun...until the timer went out of control. Also you need to be really patient to gather all the achievements, could take a year or so. Go through some guide to make things a bit easy on yourself before plunging in deep, some mistakes can be expensive.

There are huge time sinks employed, painfully (and annoyingly) obvious attempts to encourage in-game purchases to boost dwellers and speed up progress. Hey new players! You see the expensive pricing of the Vault tech lunch boxes? Do you want to get more of them for free? Then I recommend you use a save editor! 

What is a save editor? It's a program that allows the user to manipulate the save data for the app. 
Are there save editors for other games? Yes there are! 

Warning, save editing might wipe your save data if you do not use it correctly. 
Save editor I use: https://rakion99.github.io/shelter-editor/ use at your own risk. 
Have a great time guys, 
(much better then using the time skip method) 

Why you shouldn't time skip wasteland wandering: 
From my personal experience. 
Messes up the game's internal clock, for some reason causing more and more raid events, lack of wasteland items.

Fallout Shelter is a beautifully simple game from a structural point of view. You have a vault. You can build rooms in the vault, and people can do things in the rooms. Your main resource in Fallout Shelter are bottle caps. You can earn these by completing achievements, leveling up dwellers, rushing production, sending dwellers on missions, and etc. For those that want to speed things up, there is also the option of purchasing bottle caps via micro-transactions. Each of the rooms will require a certain number of bottle caps to build. Because of this, it is very important to plan your Vault in order to optimize production rates and minimize costs.

If you're into base-building and resource management, but don't have the time or patience to sit and play for hours on end, this game is probably for you. It's one of those game that you can pretty much pop in and out of as you please. (Just be careful so you don't forget any dwellers out in the wasteland.) It's not the most complex game, but it has enough layers to keep me entertained. The art style is very iconic and appealing, at least in my opinion, and really lends itself well to this kind of game. Yes, there are micro-transactions in the game, but they are completely optional (as they should be). You can still get nuka-cola speed boosts just by playing the game and completing quests. Also, it's free to play, so what do you have to lose?

It's pretty fun but if you want to progress faster just get a few pets and lunchboxes. Just know that everything is on a timer such as when you can get resources from rooms or when your dwellers return from the wasteland, its a good game to play a little then close it.

To be clear I have spent about 50 bucks on the game. A set of Mr. Handys each vault. A bunch of 32 pks of Cola, and 1 starter pack.
I had no complaints --- frustrated with the mouse at times and toons that just take of running when clicked upon, or the automatic zooming in continually.
But the worst was when I hit 100 toons and for some odd in my own head reason I assumed that a Nuca-cola plant would produce bottles of cola periodically.
What a fool ---- you get food n water.
I was assuming a loyalty type bonus so as to not have to continue to pay to play too much.
Shame!
For this reason I say no --- don't waste your time or especially your money.
I went from tossing a couple of bucks in as like a video arcade game ( feeding quarters ) to feeling downright scammed.
To be fair I  wasn't promised anything, however I expected more from Bethesda.

We all know Bethesda Softworks love to torture their users, and with this game they start to show mastery in the art of inflicting pain and agony on the world.

The game starts off slowly but soon you're getting into it and the achivements come rolling in;  You're hooked. Then, just before you complete your shelter, just before you complete that 97% tough-to-get achivement, just as you see all remaining achivements on a single row on the community page they strike: They corrupt your savegame.

So simple, yet so brilliant.

You can still start the game, you can still load the shelters you made when you first started playing. But you CAN NOT load your main shelter.  Oh, no. Try that and the game crashes.

You'll uninstall, throw your computer out the window and sulk in the corner. Then when you randomly see the Fallout Shelter logo in your Steam Library two years from now it will still hurt. You'll be reminded of the shelter you will never get to finish, the achivements you will never get and the money your st**d ass sunk into this pile of festering bitrot before Bethesta Softworks finally lifted the vail from your eyes and showed you who they truly are.

It's fun but I've kept a notebook of successes and failures. After several hundred rushes, the failure rate was 54% over all. Rushes were attempted at between 15-39% chance of failure. 

Power room was the worst by far at a 61% failure rate when the stated percentage chances were between 15-39%. 

Water and food were far less severe than power but were always higher than the displayed percent chance. I wonder if it's to frustrate people into buying lunchboxes since those can give resources.

Don't get invested into the game. There's so many guides for min-maxing and the like, min-maxing in a free to play, non-competitive game is a loser thing to do. The game isn't that hard. It barely needs to be opened except to do the out of vault quests.

Don't spend money on the game. If they're willing to fudge numbers to make things work against you more often, they'll lie about other things. Plus spending money in a F2P game makes you part of the problem. Don't be part of the problem and don't be a min-maxing loser in a single player game.

Play it for what it is and it's a decent enough way to kill some time.

Few games are this good when they are released alongside other 'triple A' games as was the case with this game when it was released on the day fallout 4 was announced. The dialogue is peak fallout wit and humour, and there is a lot of it, and for some reason I've never grown tired of it even when I read the same thing over.

It's even so well constructed that you can play multiple playthroughs and have your vault organised in completely different ways. I've played on the bethesda launcher and FS was also the last game I played on mobile. Even though I still have my saves and found out there was a guide to transfer saves from android only, which I still have, I kept wanting to experience the early playthrough of creating a vault from scratch. Really fun and comfortable time playing. Sometimes the game plays itself and is still enjoyable as a management sim, plus it is one of the best games I have played while still being free and not ever feeling like the store is being thrown at you to use it.

and seriously..if you don't end up checking this game out at least try to find some of the things the dwellers say in a video somewhere...it's so charming.

I really dont have a problem with this game. The concept is great but the execution is so minimal and hamstrung by hours of bloat and waiting that clearly its just to demolish your time. Which honestly all this game seems to accomplish is to drag fallout's name through the mud. I'm sure I'll plug an embarrassing amount of hours into this game but I'm a big fallout fan and this game was clearly not made for people like me. I sink time into games as a hobby, not something I flick at occasionally on my phone. This game exists as a fishing net litmus test to see if your willing to pony up in order to get the content you want.  I dont know. I see all the time and care that went into the art and game systems, the loving recreation of iconic characters in vault boy style, and I'm left wondering if that time and resources could be better spent.

Edit: I've played 35 more hours and yea this stands.

Wonderful game. I've played much longer than the 1 hour shown here. I downloaded the game directly from Bethesda and have played to what I think is the end. There is no conclusion to the game, and it is strictly a world-building (vault-building) endeavor with outside missions and exploration.

Having reached this point (only one mission left), maximum of 200 people at level 50 or approaching, and no space left for additional storage or other rooms (all levels are occupied by rooms), I'm pretty sure that I'm done. It's been a long but fun trip, though.

Some suggestions, and I'm sure not exactly new:

1) Increase the maximum occupants from 200 to some ungodly upper limit.
2) Add the ability to expand to other vaults to continue building.
3) Add an infinite number of possibilities for missions.

I noticed one "bug" during my journey. I don't know if it's Bethesda's attempt to be more "woke" with respect to relationships or just an oversight, but when a baby is born, you are given the option to name it. Usually, but not always, the baby's last name is the same as the father's. But frequently, the baby's default last name is that of the mother's. It's more of an annoyance than anything else because I liked to keep track of families.

Again, a great and sometimes funny, cute, dark  experience.

Just wish it could go further....

I tried this when I had first installed it.  The game is free - so why not?  Of course me being how I am, I didn't at first "get" the game, and failed miserably, thought it wasn't for me, etc.  But it turns out, once the mechanisms and strategy make sense, the game is very generous to people patient enough to keep slogging through some of the slow spots.

Gameplay basics:

- Build an elevator / room system for taking care of people.  At bare minimum it will need power, water and food (which is magically "produced" in restaurants), and living quarters, though the living quarters don't really have to be occupied.  Living quarters can be occupied by male and female occupants, which may result in pregnancies, and subsequent babies being born.

- Each production room has an associated character trait which will generate the highest production.  So matching up occupants to the right rooms will usually make them happier and always more productive.

- Chose when to upgrade rooms by priority to maintain production levels to keep up with population.

- Send some people out into the outside wilderness to try to find stuff and hopefully live to bring back the goods!  These include crafting items and weapons.

- Raiders, fires and cockroaches will attack your base.  Save up on health packs to prevent people from dying during these disasters!

The tricky part is making sure production is such that if you shut the game off, and try to live a normal life, and come back again, that the economy will allow recovering from the broken-down state - it might not if it wasn't balanced right.  This is a fairly feature-rich game especially for being free to play.  There are in-game purchases available if you want to support the developer, but these aren't required to succeed in the game.

It's a nice little time-waster with a good sense of progression. Yes, there are microtransactions to "assist" with progress but they aren't inherently necessary. You start out with a decent amount of Quantum (used to rush tasks), the Mysterious Stranger appears quite often, and when you find and click him he'll grant you anywhere between a few hundred and couple thousand caps, so it's actually fair and you don't need to pay for extra, and also quests give you a pretty good amount eventually. There's also quite a few times where the game will give you lunchboxes which contain premium items which otherwise you'd have to pay for. Basically, its a fair and fun little game and I'd say worth a shot

Fallout Shelter is a basic concept game, and I have no issue with that. Build your underground vault and try to expand and survive. With plenty of rooms to build, dwellers to acquire, and weapons to find, this game is simple but fun. Ill admit it can get boring at times but overall the game at its core is still a fun pass time for Fallout fans.

One of the most challenging games I've ever played...I'll start off by mentioning the most irritating feature in this game, not to do with the actual gameplay, but more an option you can't turn off, this is something very important you should know, before getting this game, because it heavily affects gameplay:

This game has an irritating autosave feature installed into it, which you can't even turn off. Meaning, if a devastating incident happens in your vault, such as creatures or raiders killing stacks of people in your vault, and you quit out to try to load into a save before the incident happened, it just loads you straight back into the disaster, there is no possibility of being able to load into any old saves before the disaster, because the autosave keeps saving automatically, just about 24/7; there is a 'save' button you can click, but what's the point when the autosave just saves over it?? You have no 2nd tries when an attack happens, you literally have to get it right and stay on top of it on the first try, because of the stupid autosave feature. I just really hope the devs read this, and seriously consider at least bringing in the option to turn it off, because it provides no contribution whatsoever to this game, only being an extreme irritation and incredibly game-crippling feature.

ANOTHER THING I NEED TO POINT OUT HERE IS THAT I WOULD ONLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME FOR MATURE AUDIENCES, 18 AND UP! (I put it in caps to immediately bring this part to any readers' attention, because this is very important to know, before getting this game, if you have any kids, or if you are under-age), because of a sexual theme being in this game - you can make women pregnant in this game; when you put a man and a woman into a Living Quarters together, and leave them there for a while, they'll start out by talking, then dancing, then they'll kiss a couple times, then run into the bedroom together and disappear around the wall. It's not as explicit as Sims 4, where you can sort of see what they're doing, in this game, when they disappear around the wall in the bedroom, all you see is green smiling faces appearing and disappearing around the bedroom for a couple seconds, then they both come out, with the woman suddenly being pregnant. Still, it is suggestive enough that I would still not recommend this game to anyone under 18, this game is definitely one that belongs in the 'mature audience' category. 

Anyway, to get to what this game is actually about, and what makes it so worth playing: the aim of this game is to keep your dwellers alive and happy. There are only 3 types of supplies you need to keep maintained in order to do this: power, food, and water. At the start of the game, you only have a small amount of rooms available to choose from, when building, just very basic power, food and water supply rooms, and also a couple other things, like storage rooms and living quarters, which you need to support population; the more living quarters you build, the more dwellers will be able to live in your vault. It is very hard to maintain these supplies with the basic rooms you have to choose from, and the small amount of dwellers that arrive at your vault, and especially when the first attacks from the wasteland outside start happening against your vault. 
But I promise you, it is TOTALLY worth sticking around and giving this game a chance, because, the more you understand this game, and how it works, the easier it becomes, and that's when it becomes super fun and addictive! :D The more dwellers you gain in your vault (either from attracting them from the wasteland to your vault by crafting a radio room - which attracts dwellers out in the wasteland to your vault -  or breeding them, from pregnant dwellers), the more rooms you unlock, different ones that make it so much more easier to survive in this game, like more effective power, food and water supplies than the basic ones you start out with, that help you produce and collect supplies much faster, and weapon and armour rooms that are very handy for equipping your dwellers with armour and weapons to defend themselves against attacks against the vault. You can also collect weapons and armour as loot from sending dwellers out into the wasteland to explore for loot, which I would highly recommend you do at the very beginning of your game, sending at least 3 dwellers out into the wasteland to find guns or armour, to be ready for the first attack against your vault. You can also craft an Overseer's Office later on, which allows you to send up to 3 teams consisting of 3 dwellers each out to do quests, which awards you far more weapons, armour, and loot, and caps (the Fallout currency in this game) than wasteland exploration does. 

You can also make your dwellers more skilled at producing supplies faster if you put them in the right room, according to the stats of their skills. Skills are portrayed as .S.P.E.C.I.A.L. in this game, which stands for the 7 different skills dwellers each have, which can all be raised and improved from training rooms: 
STRENGTH - Not need for combat, but good for power rooms, so dwellers with higher strength skills should be tasked with maintaining power rooms.
PERCEPTION - Works the same way as the strength skill, the same with all the other skills, this one's good for water rooms. 
ENDURANCE - Good for both combat and rooms, the only room this skill is good for though, is the Nuka-Cola Bottler room, the final and most effective room that unlocks at 100 dwellers, that supplies both food and water in one. Unusual that endurance is the skill needed to maintain this room, as the previous basic food rooms require the agility skill...anyway, endurance is also the go-to skill to have for wasteland exploration and quests, as higher endurance means more health for your dwellers, making them take longer to die against attacks.
CHARISMA - This skill is not important for any vault rooms OR wasteland/quest exploration, but it does improve the rate at which female dwellers can become pregnant, when putting a female and male dweller together in the living quarters; higher charisma means the whole process of becoming pregnant, talking, kissing and then becoming pregnant, goes faster, which can take a painstakingly long time if the dwellers have low charisma. 
AGILITY - Good for both rooms and combat, being good for basic food rooms (Diners and Gardens) and increases your rate of fire in combat, how often your dwellers will fire their weapons when attacking enemies.
LUCK - This one is also good for both combat and rooms, as it increases your dweller's chances of collecting loot from wasteland/quest exploration, and is good for rushing rooms, an option you can select on a room to fast-forward production and collect the supplies from it immediately; rushing, which always has the chance of backfiring, no matter how high or low dwellers' luck is - if the rushing is a success, you collect the supplies, if it fails, an incident happens in the room, such as fires or enemies popping up into the room, and the dwellers have to quickly maintain it. When you click the 'rush' button on a room, it'll say 'Chance of incident,' and show you the percentage of the chance of the incidents that could happen; the average percentage normally starts out at 30%. Each time you rush a room, the percentage goes up higher and higher, but goes back down to normal if you leave it for a while to let it refresh, after rushing once or twice. I would strongly recommend only rushing rooms when the percentage is at either 30-40%, any higher, and the chance of an incident NOT happening becomes incredibly rare. While having high luck doesn't eliminate the chance of incidents happening, it lowers the starting percentage by a huge amount, lowering the average 30% down to 10%! The lower the percentage, the more times you can rush in a row, with higher chances of success.

This game is fun, it lets you be the overseer of any vault, including Vault 111 which is the players Vault in Fallout 4. I've played this game for 5 hours and haven't had many problems with it. The things I like about this game are: You can make your own vault, you have references to other Bethesda games (A NPC in your vault can say "Someone stole my sweetroll" which is similar to a line that a guard from Skyrim has [the guard says "let me guess, someone stole your sweetroll"]), you can also learn something about the Fallout lore (I saw my Vault Dweller that was outside of the vault say something like "Super mutants are asexual, some were even female"), you also have to help your vault survive certain problems like a radroach infestation. There isn't anything bad about the game I can name.
Basically: If EA bought bethesda.

"We are delighted to confirm
your admission to -

- The College
Of Advanced Technology."

Our Father who art in heaven -

- may You always
be with my son, Peter Andreas -

- who is now leaving
his childhood home.

May he never forget the plight of life -

- or his obligation to You,
Almighty Lord.

Let him not be tempted
by the decay of city life -

- and lay not up for himself treasures,
where moth and rust doth corrupt.

As is Thy will,
all that are bred and born in darkness -

- will one day appear, and sentence
shall be passed upon them.



Amen.

I have saved up some money -

- which I meant to give to you
when you left home.

But since you have chosen
a different path...

...you get nothing.

You will, however, get a gift.

This watch, which my father gave
to me on the day that I left home -

- I give to you, in the hope that
it will soothe your hardened heart.

And open your obstinate mind.

When, one day, you turn away
from the path to perdition -

- you will open
your misguided heart to us.

- And to Our Lord in Heaven.
- It's pitiful to watch an old vicar...

...whom I've only known for his inhuman
rigour, seem so sentimental.

- You cannot refuse...
- What?



Father's self-righteous piety?
This gift of grace?

Apologise.
Apologise for what you said!

Never!

Hit me again.

Hit me again like you normally do.

Beware!
Beware His intrepid curse!

Since Father is predicting my future,
he should know that in this house -

- I've always felt like a stranger
and a homeless person.

- Exiled be he who defies The Lord!
- Amen!

Peter? Peter Andreas?

Here is a little something
for the journey.

And remember, if you need help,
your older brother is in Copenhagen.

Thank you, Mother.

very relaxing and fun game

Overall the game is fine i guess but I have several issues.

1:
Being a completionist and completing this game is hell in order to get one achievement you basically have to spend money or spend thousands of hours to get it legit as it requires loot boxes in order to get the drop needed and playing for several hours a day every day you can realistically only get 1-5 a week which seems fine until you realise you need hundreds of loot boxes in order to unlock 20 legendary dwellers.

2:
Save files being corrupted is a real issue that still has not been fixed nor do I think there will ever be a permanent fix. at any given time your game could decide to crash and end up deleating or corrupting your save file which means ALL PROGRESS YOU HAVE MADE IS GONE AS WELL AS ANY REWARDS FROM LOOT BOXES WILL BE GONE AS WELL, meaning that even if you spent money to speed up progress it could all be lost at an instant. This has happened to me twice just this year alone.

3: Combat is boring and is not intuitive. In game combat is just a stat check;if you have the hp/damage to kill something you win if not you die. On top of this how a dwellers S.P.E.C.I.A.L affects combat makes no sense and is not explained. If a player has to create a tutorial outside of the game for you then you have done something clearly wrong. (For example the E in special stands for Endurance and it effectively increases the max hp of a dweller, but because the UI in the game is trash there is pretty much no way to know this because the bar doesn't change in size nor is there a numarical value for you to know it changed, its just a bar. The only way to ever know that increasing endurance even does anything is to try and set up tests to try and figure out if a dweller with higher E loses a lesser % of their healthbar than one with lower endurance. AND ON TOP OF ALLL THIS there's a hidden mechanic that completely changes a dwellers hp. If you equip an outfit onto a dewller that increases their E then every time they level up they GAIN EVEN MORE HP. Which turns out that this mechanic is extremly important for late game as its pretty much one of the only ways to survive the highest level bosses, but if you didnt know about this mechanic you would get stuck in endless death cycles not understanding why you cant progress because of a hidden mechanic that is not stated anywhere in the game. And that was just 1 of the S.P.E.C.I.A.L Traits that a dweller can have and all of them have either poorly explained mechanics (That you can't tell the differnce of increaseing it or decreasing it because of the UI but Ill get to that) or mechanics that are just not explained at all

4: The USER INTERFACE (UI)
Dear god is the interface garbage. The interface in this game seems to be desinged to hide as much information as possible for some god forsaken reason. as stated in my section a dwellers HP is near impossible to tell you never know how much hp is left or how much max hp you have because there is no numaricle value or even a percentage all you have is a tiny green bar that slowly depleats as you take damage. for other SPECIAL stats you have no way to know how it affects your dweller in combat because the UI does not give such information. Want to know how your Strength affects your chances on being able to open loot? too bad you dont get to know, now what about Perception is there somthjing in the HUD or UI that shows you your chances of gaining a critical hit? too bad, what about Agility?  did the developers bother to put in a number on the UI that shows how it affects/what yourt current attack speed is? of course not because designing a good UI is aparently too much.

5: User Interface continued
Now to talk about Actual combat, when you are in combat there are two "types" of damage you can take normal damage that just decreases ur hp and can be increased with a stimpack and radiation damage which decreases your max hp and is shown with a red bar slowly encroching on your hp bar, this can be removed with rad away. Now heres the problem once your dweller hits a certain threshhold a clickable button appears where you can fix theMOST RECENT THRESH HOLD HIT meaning if you had say 30% hp the button for a stimpack appears and clicking it heals u and say when 70% radiation the rad away button will appear now what happens if the health button appears but then you hit the radiation threshhold? well now the rad away button appears meaning YOU CANNOT HEAL YOUR DWELLER and in late game where enemies do massive damage this stupid  bug will kill hundreds of your dwellers as they will get 1 shot before u can heal them because the time it takes for the heal button to come back they're allready dead. 

This game is alright but it has wayyyyyyy tooo many issues with basic gameplay  and gamebreaking bugs with the lack of a proper tutorial for most aspects of combat being non existant. This game has been out for years and they still have not fixed game breaking things or even bothered to make the UI better when all they would need to do is add some numbers, now if all u wanted was to see what being an overseer would have been like than try it out, but i repeat DO NOT SPEND MONEY BECAUSE U CAN LOSE A SAVE FILE AT ANY TIME!!!!!

This isn't a very in-depth game, in fact it's closer to an idle once you eventually hit that point (in these games) were you can no longer freely use your resources. You have three survival resources: power, food, and water. Power is your only real concern, it's not really a survival game. There are raids, missions, and exploring. Raids are fairly easily defended (upgrade your vault door ASAP or station 2 people there permanently), but it's a slight on the game that you can only have 2 people in your vault door area even though Raiders can have 3. Missions unlock after you place a certain building and the ability to run multiple at once is walled behind your dweller (population) count. Exploring can be done at any time, but if send them for too long w/o the proper stim-packs or rad-packs (heals/cures radiation) they'll die and you'll be forced to pay $ to revive them (Mr. Handy's do not die).

Overall it's a fun relaxing game but is limited... once you beat it there's no real reason to play again. Fun for a few weeks or months, but not really much of a game. If you spend too much in the in-game store you'll rush the game and it won't be as exciting. Part of the fun is slowly gearing your people with gear you find / craft / unlock yourself. Though it doesn't hurt buying Mr. Handy packs or Pet packs -- they don't really add much to the game "cheat" wise.

Overall fun gameplay, simple, but nice sound and graphics.
Unfortunately the nice experience is ruined by the clunky interface - managing the day-to-day activities in a larger vault is a slog, taking away much of the fun and turning the game into a nasty chore. The whole interface layout is very prone to miss clicks, un-selectable buttons at times and obscured objects,
To even greater frustration the game is absolutely unforgiving sometimes, throwing very tough monsters at the player at times when resources are scares and dwellers are in bad condition.
The Fallout game series is is one of my all time favorites, I've got several hundred hours on the mobile version. Try as I might, but I couldn't really love this one. Every time my vault develops further and the game begins to unfold all its good sides, I get mauled into submission by the unfair monster waves while the whole game interface makes it even harder to resist the destruction.
Technical and gameplay issues set this Fallout tittle at the very bottom of my liked games from the series.

The game's fun to play and all, but I've experienced some pretty big problems with the game. 

First; You can only have 3 separate groups go out on quests. I have so many vault dwellers either staying inside the vault and have them max out their S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats or have them go out and explore to occupy them. I want to have more than 3 groups out for quests so that I won't be staring at the screen for hours doing completely nothing.

Second; There is way too much unused space in the building area. With me, being someone who makes my vault organized with each floor consist of 2 3-room-merged rooms, 1 2-merged room, and 2 elevators in between them, I managed to max out my vault to 200 vault dwellers while I still have room to spare. Unfortunately, it gave me about more than 8 completely unused floors for my vault, and I have absolutely no idea on what I should use it for. I'm sure a lot of people would say that I should fill all of that space with storage rooms. Really? 8 floors consisting of nothing but storage rooms? Not only will that make the electricity production be through the roof but I don't see myself in need of that much storage space. I want to be given a reason to use all of the remaining space that I have. I wouldn't even mind having more vault dwellers in my vault. This also brings me to my next problem with the game.

Third; The vault dweller cap. Why only 200? Why not bump it up to about 250 (or even have it be as high as you want it, as long as you have the room for it), in order to have all of the empty space in the building area be of use. I wanted this game where you not only have to worry about raids, infestations, and lacking resources, but overpopulation too. It would make the game a lot more interesting.

It's a decent time-waster puzzle game. With a few tweaks, it could be turned into a classic. I'm surprised Bethesda doesn't release a patch for the PC version that puts it into "classic" territory. 

Some obvious stuff to fix (off the top of my head):
The worst design decision is that it cannot be paused. 
The UI is clunky/fiddly in some places, which becomes more annoying with the clock ticking and no room for "dammit, I want to see Molly's stats!" Considering how often you have to check stats to see who should go where, for example, it seems kinda weird that the UI is ill-suited to this task.
Attacking raiders don't seem to kill or loot, which seems kinda dumb. People ran into the base and attacked structures but didn't disable anything, attacked people but didn't really hurt them, won and left without taking anything.

It's fun for what it is and as a little F2P game on the Steam better than most. It's a clock game where everything you want to do will take hours or days and is a bit of a frustration engine as invariably anything you want to just bop in, start new cycles cycling around the clock and improve things a smidgen gets interrupted by some attack that after awhile is no threat but just a time sink as you wait for the baddies to croak so you can get on with things.  The other icky bit is you're essentially running a eugenics program as you kick out all your original dwellers as you train up all your new babies to have full stats and maximum Endurance at level one so that when you level them up to 50 they'll have max hit points.  Finally, a lot of the campaign quests become lying and deceiving the baddies to infiltrate their bases and acquire info tidbits, which yeah is some variety from "we're from Vault Luke Skywalker and we're here to rescue you" of most of the quests but ostensibly you're creating a Vault of the Nazis comfortable with the ends justifying the means.   Or at least I did.  It's easy enough that a run where you keep all Vault Dwellers and never lie seems doable so I might just wrap up and shelve my Nazi Vault and try a Truth and Justice Superman Vault and see how that goes.  Might fail a few quests that way, I just hope it's not a chain breaker and that the game lets me proceed with the campaign where not lying and having to fight ALL the baddies because it's a no lie run still lets me finish the quest challenges and unlock the next leg of the campaign.  If you like building up little bases and equipping up your toons you'll dig it as for challenge, it's more frustrationsauce in lieu of challenging.  Cheers!

Honestly, I enjoy this game and it can be challenging at times. I think that people that only have around 9-15 hours in the game definitely haven't finished the game ( unless p2w but then that wouldn't be as fun or challenging I think ) and/or one of their vaults've died. The times where you do quests and send people to the wasteland is pretty neat as well, mostly quests though since you actually get to interact with something there. Also if you don't manage resources well then your vault is kind of screwed too. I remember I used to play this on my Ipad a couple years back and I had around, say 60 dwellers? And afterwards my whole vault was destroyed by a couple of deathclaws :( . It's a great time killer and it can be a thing to play when you're really bored and I don't really get bored of playing it. I'd give this game a solid rating of 7.7/10.

Well its good fun, satisfying, well done etc. but if you want to play it like its any other comparable game , then prepare to spend a lot of real ¬£/$

Yes, 'technically' most content is not completely locked behind a pay wall (At least as far as I got) , but everything is 'time wall-ed?' You quickly get to a point where you've built everything, upgraded everything that you can from free content, and in order to progress from there you need to take on harder expeditions outside your vault. The thing is, even basic 'short' excursions at this point take several hours of IRL time before they begin/end; if you forget to buy/dont buy enough stimpaks/radaways before you send your people out, the expedition is a complete loss and you either lose your guys and their equipment, or cancel the trip and have to wait irl hours to try another one.

I enjoyed the game a lot up to 17 hours or so and then realised that it was either spend ¬£5/$7+ per play session or give up. I chose the latter. If you're one of those people who can/like to play 'background' games throughout a day, while doing something else; you'll probably love this game and its absolutely for you. If however you like to binge games and play solid 2-4 hour sessions after work or on a day off, dont bother.

A fun simple game at the start, there is plenty of room for growing into the more challenging aspects of it's end game design where a significant amount of fun is to be had. You don't have to buy anything, but the starter packs are probably worth it if you're really into this game and love getting to the points of doing quests sooner rather than later, especially if you enjoy the challenge of survival mode. In any case, a great small time investment or distraction to have running at odd times in the background as a reward for study or work pursuits. Worth your time and energy if you enjoy these kinds of games and this is the type of game that would make you fall for these types of games. Criticism? Could be more complex...? Bloody good deal for a free game though that only has in game purchases as an option. With ample time on this game, Fallout Shelter truly astounds me as an inexplicable joy. The subtle, yet intricately beautiful elements of this game rocked me to the absolute core like no other game had before: implementations of real-time elements, base building, resource management, and workforce direction seemed to hold itself at the top of its craft. Not once in my years have I encountered a game that so beautifully weaves these aspects together into a seemingly abstract form of art. What initially begins as a willful endeavor for survival quickly and elegantly manifests into a contemporary marvel of thriving video game design. Fallout Shelter's pacing, story, game mechanics, and soundtrack all amalgamate to create a game unrivaled in its industry.

The award-winning game's story is written with inspirations from epics - it is pristine from the story's exposition that this game borrows from previous successes; John Green's "The Fault in Our Stars" (referencing the game's amorous yet passionate romance developments as an enduring mechanic), Angie Thomas' "The Hate U Give" (playing into social contexts of racism and sexism as encountered within a much culturally diverse setting), and Dr. Seuss' "The Lorax" (a riveting allusion to climate change) are all notable sources that foster Fallout Shelter's compelling narrative. The game utilizes widely-used mechanics in terms of pacing, but adds impressive twists to ensure that my experience as a consumer is unparalleled whatsoever. Fallout Shelter's soundtrack is the ultimatum as a final impression: albeit not being the centerpiece of this game's immersive feel, it rather serves as a reminder of the brutalities of apocalypse; a reminder, of sorts, of the very real world outside. While this tampers with my personal experience - it wakes me out of my ethereal, paradisaical slumber, yet concurrently is a beguiling aesthetic.

If I were to sum Fallout Shelter in one sentence, I would put it forth as an entrancing, once-in-a-lifetime take on mortality that delivers skillfully. To be framed as a contemporary classic, Bethesda's Mona Lisa sets forth a higher standard for the entire video game industry.

overall review : 

Positive :
- Good game for killing time
- Can be quite fun and challenging 
- Gameplay is simple yet need a bit of planning and strategy. 

Negative :
- You only get 4 lunchbox at the beginning from finishing tasks and about 1 per week from daily login. After that, you have to be lucky to get tasks that give out lunchboxes. Unless you buy in cash
- The mysterious guy is hard to locate, and harder as your vault is getting larger. 
- Dwellers literally stopped coming after hitting 18 population, you have to either breed or use the radio room. Which means putting your dwellers out of their work in the meanwhile.
- Lunchbox is too random, but one item that is guaranteed : junk. You are guaranteed to get 1 junk every lunchbox but not armor or weapon... so if you're unlucky (like me), you'll get no weapon or armor from the first 4-5 lunchboxes and had to retry. 
- Gets boring after hitting 40-50 population, because you basically repeat everything you've done since the beginning. Sending out dwellers for quests is the only saving grace... but most of them took too long (could go from 1 hours to flat out a whole day). 

Overall rating : 3.5/10

This is a really enjoyable point & click / idle game in the fallout universe, which is packed full of content. You definitely do not need to pay for anything to advance as you have an objectives system and quests where you can earn lunchboxes, pets and nuka-cola.

The dialogue can be seriously funny with some good references, there's lots of outfits and weapons to craft too. It's a great game to chip away at and have fun with, there's also a good range of achievements to complete for the completionists out there.

A couple of things I would love to see added to the mechanics would be a 'Harvest all' button when all your supplies are ready to collect, instead of having to click each singular room. Furthermore it would be brilliant if you could alter your room layout without having to destroy the rooms and re-buy them for maximum caps, this is especially annoying when you've fully upgraded your rooms.

Overall I would highly recommend this as non-time consuming game which is completely free and does not require you to spend real money to advance.

The real game is developing strategies to progress without having to open up your wallet and spent your hard earned money on Bethesda micro-transactions.

Even if you succeed in not paying Bethesda, it will spite you by disrespecting your time.

Hey do you want to do some Questing? That'll be 6 quantums or 10 hours real time.
Hey do you want to craft a legendary weapon? That'll be 30 quantums or 7 days real time.
Hey do you want to train SPECIAL faster? That'll be 4 quantums or 6 hours real time.

The game will try to screw you over every opportunity it gets like delaying level up on dweller when the exp bar is full or spawn deathclaws or radscorpions when you re-enter the game.

Don't get me started on Radscorpions spawning in your vault, the consequences behind the Radscorpion is such cancer that it has more damage, health, radiation than bosses in the game and your store of electricity will completely vanish, what a joke.

Fallout Shelter is a free game where you simulate building your own shelter in the Fallout world.  It's free and enjoyable.  You build rooms to supply your dwellers with food, water and electricity.

You can send your dwellers out on quests for resources and possibly special dwellers.  It's the same game from your phone and I find it easier to play with a mouse and keyboard rather than scrolling on your phone.  It's enjoyable and even though you can pay for content like crates providing resources, special dwellers, Mr Handy's or nuka cola you don't need to spend a cent because you can earn them from playing the game and doing quests and any purchases don't feel forced because you can earn them on your own.
yes

I used to play this on mobile a few phones ago and enjoyed the concept though always had a struggle with the learning curve on how to most efficiently enlarge the vault without bankrupting resources or losing characters to raids and such. I truly wish there was more thought put into it for updates because it's a great base game and could have been built upon so much more.

That being said, it is essentially an idler you need to regularly check in on and pending on your play style is pending how much checking back in on it you'll have to do.

An addictive, free game with a charming aesthetic. If you are a fallout fan and want to play dolls house with your very own vault, this is the game for you. It's free to play as well, so worth giving it a try although it is first and foremost designed as a mobile game with microtransactions like 'Tiny Towers' so actions like crafting items and going on quests do have a wait time unless you fork over the money to speed things up, so if that's not your cup of tea, I'd recommend you pass on this game.

Overall though, it's a good little game to kill some time and the wait times aren't too bad if you got the patience to just play it casually, when you have a spare minute in between doing other stuff.

This is an example of a PC version of a game that is worse than the console version.  The most egregious is trying to select units.  The hit box is terrible so the game thinks you're clicking thin air, even when do you click sometimes all it does is highlight the model and not bring up the menu it's supposed to.  Other times you won't have clicked a model at all but it acts like you did and you end up dragging someone to a different room instead of what you were trying to do.  This is especially bad on high level quests when your dwellers' lives depend on you healing them.  I just had a squad wipe because of this.  I had played the console version and never had this problem.  The reason I tried to switch to PC was because of stability.  I got the stability but far worse control performance.

Note* Get off my lawn Achievement, you will need 29< dwellers inside the vault for the raiders to spawn. Go above this number and they won't spawn anymore.

Note* Overseer Achievement, you will have to level up a dweller from LV1 all the way up to LV50. Using a dweller with a high LV from the start won't work.
Not very faithful to the story of Fallout, though it makes up for it in its somewhat engaging gameplay.

However it's by no means perfect - it's fairly simple to max out your dwellers complete all the questlines. Radscorpion infestations are ridiculously overpowered and the drop rate to get the rare dwellers is abysmal, bordering on obscene. A fun way to while away the hours and spend a bit of time in the wasteland.

This game saved my life.

I am 31.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Have you ever played one of the Fallout games and wondered "What would life be like inside a vault? How would they manage the resources and keep everyone happy?" 
No, neither have I! But if you want a fun, easy to get into management game that takes a very different view at the world of Fallout, this game is for you! 
Set dwellers to produce the resources needed to keep them alive! Send them out on quests! Attract more dwellers and unlock more rooms so you can train your dwellers to better survive! Build bigger and better weapons to defend what is yours from raiders, ghouls and other invaders!

Note to new players: A dwellers health is, I believe, determined by their Endurance *when* they level up. Increasing their Endurance does *not* have a retro-active effect! So the best thing is as soon as you are able to train Endurance, get everyone up as high as you can before setting them to work and levelling up

Fallout Shelter is a free-to-play simulation were your goal is build your very own underground vault tec bunker. (YOU!) are the overseer of your vault, defend your dwellers and settlement from the hazardous dangers of the unpredictable wasteland, while the managing resources, population, and your occupants happiness.

The most pointless game you will ever find. 

I truly do not understand how this braindead RNG heavy lootbox storefront has such high reviewscores. 
To anyone who is stupid enough to have wasted a cent buying lootboxes and therefore told the creators that this garbage is worth the effort and therefore shouldnt bother making actual games - there are ways to get as much as you want for free, use google.

The entire game is literally built around making you buy currency or lootboxes. Gear and items all come in lootbox form and literally everything you can achieve in the game can be easily achieved with the push of a button - if you have the currency. 

There is NOTHING to strive for. No difficulty, no learning curve, nothing - the game literally only exist to trick people to pay for imaginary numbers instead of spending days going through lootbox after lootbox getting them.

I spent a few hours clicking the magical buttons to make my characters into uber vaultdwellers, only to see what the "endgame" or rather, point of the game would be after you had everything. The entire endgame is as RNG as it gets, as you send out your characters into different dungeons or into the wastelands, and wether or not they survive is completely up to rng.

If i had spent weeks on getting 3 guys maxed out, gearing them up in powerarmor and laser weaponry only to have them lost to RNG id probably feel really shitty - luckily i valued my time slightly higher.

It doesn't really stand apart from other Mobile Games, in terms of Gameplay, so aside from saying it's all Pay to Win (as they all are) I'll touch on the particular issues that might discourage people from playing:

- Compared to playing this on a mobile, the platform for which it was designed, playing it on PC is absolutely abysmal, there is no way to quickly do things, some mouse movements aren't registered at all, and dragging and dropping causes the mouse to get incredibly out of sync.

- For achievement completionists, the achievements of this game will run you well over 100 hours of play, if not that it will require you to spend a lot of real money, as they contain "legendaries".

In truth the game is fine. Just fine.

I started playing Fallout Shelter on mobile years ago and just got back to it again on PC after a long hiatus. What can I say? It's an incredibly fun, cute game that will keep you amused for quite some time. The best part is that you can advance in Normal Mode without having to spend any money.

There are a few issues to be aware of, though. First of all, there is no end game at all. Once you've maxed out your vaults, that's it. That's the end of the game. Because of this, the micro-transactions have always been a bit questionable to me. The goal of micro transactions should be to enhance game play, right? But because there is no end game, all that happens is that you shorten gaming time so that what might have taken you months to complete without micro-transaction will take you only weeks.

To use an analogy, imagine if you decided to pay an extra $5 for a roller coaster ride that allows you to "jump the line" ahead of everyone else so you don't have to wait 15-20 minutes to go again. Also, the ride goes faster, making for a more exciting experience. So, you pay the $5 and everything, and the ride is indeed intense. But because the coaster went twice the speed, the ride lasted in half the time. This is how micro-transactions work in this game. You're just paying to finish the game faster, not to make the most out of it.

Another issue I have is Survival Mode. Remember that Fallout Shelter started out as a mobile game. Because of this, it  shares some of the terrible mechanics that people have come to hate about freemiums. In the case of Survival Mode, What happens with freemiums  is that you're given a "board", load out or a card hand (like in a poker game) that seems random and therefore playable if you use strategy and skill. But in reality, some boards are designed to fail no matter what you do while others are not. When you fail, you think, "Oh, I must have done something wrong this time; let me change up my strategy." But it's not that. Some of the load outs seem designed to frustrate you into buying micro-transactions.

In the case of Survival Mode, I don't think that every load out (dwellers, stats, weapons, etc.) is doable with strategy. For example, some vaults, you'll get legendary weapons, outfits and dwellers from the start, making Survival Mode more challenging than Normal mode, but able to be completed. Other vaults, you will just barely squeak by with anything, and it will be very hard to get it up and running past Level 16 without suddenly needing to buy something from the store or rage quitting. I just want to put that out there because it bothers me to think that people could be beating themselves up not breezing through Survival Mode when the reality is that they just got a weak load out that will make mincemeat out of strategy.

Bottom line, stick to Normal Mode, which definitely utilizes skill and is more fun to play. Survival Mode plays more like an online poker game or mobile game, as in P2W but tricking you into thinking that it's more an issue of you needing to bone up on your skills.

Quite a few things about the game play that I don't like. Firstly, it's a free to play game, designed to be almost impossible to play without spending money to speed things up, or buy pieces in the game. There really needs to be a pause button, but because there isn't, I close the game if I need to go to the toilet or anything away from my computer screen, I may or may not come back to it. It's slow as hell, because they want you to spend real money to speed it up. Too many raids and attacks, kills your people and you can't ever get enough supplies. Having to pick up the people to move them is extremely annoying, especially in a raid. When you set your armed people onto the attackers or raiders, once the attackers leave the room, your people don't follow them, they just stand around like idiots. The proportion of pregnancy to the kids growing up is way out, either they are pregnant for years, or the kids grow up really quickly. Overall conclusion: Frustrating as hell, don't waste your time.

I started my main vault in 2015 on an Iphone 4 and after 200 hours there isn't anything left for me to do. All dwellers are maxed level and stats, all geared with top tier legendary weapons and outfits. A variety of pets are available for various missions and objectives. Robots for all the automatic resource gathering. I have rearranged the layout twice to optimize rooms as strategy/focus changed (Population/Leveling/Training/Gathering/etc).

There does seem to be some issues with achievements on my transferred game save. I probably have to start a new save to try and complete some of the harder ones.

EDIT: 167 hours in, and I must say, the game passes the time by real fast! I'm a professional procrastinator, so this game came in handy these last few months.  

I (unfortunately) wasted my money on lunchboxes and Mr Handy's, until I realised you can simply change your computer's time to advance production of weapons or to let my dwellers reach quest destinations in the wasteland. FML. FML. FML.

But hey, at least now I can share my knowledge with others and (hopefully) you won't be making the same mistakes I did.  Also, Google beforehand which SPECIAL stats are most useful for Quests (to my knowledge, Agility, Strength, Endurance and Luck are most useful, so send out dwellers that have high points in those categories).

Just some food for thought.
