This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

A nice little idle game within the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/22380/Fallout_New_Vegas/]Fallout[/url] universe giving you a taste of overseeing your very own Vault and its survivors. It is a complete experience with great humour, cameos of famous Fallout characters, quests that tell stories, little random events that happens not only to the Vault but to the people you send out to explore the Wasteland and configurability in individual survivor loadouts (clothes, weapon and pet). 

There are microtransactions available in-game, but I have been a free player from the start and have been able to enjoy plenty of content and play time.

When I saw a friend playing this on PS4 and how much joy he got out of it (and remembering that I spent many happy hours with Sim Tower all those years ago), I really hoped that this game was available on Steam and going for a song. So I was overjoyed to find that it is, it's free and not a crappy port. I really wanted to like this game and I do. Bethesda have, in a very rare case for them, made that very easy to do in their best (but also simplest) Fallout release since acquiring the IP from Interplay. It is the closest to the original games (in theme and spirit, if not in style) and the only one Bethesda should have made. It is, however, abundanly clear and ironic that their best work is one that they originally made for consoles and mobile phones, one that they give away for free while charging mucha dinero for steaming piles of dog faeces such as FO 4 and 76. If console and mobile games are the only things they can get right, they do not deserve their mountain of gold nor being considered a AAA game studio, IMO.

A fun little FtP idle game set in the Fallout universe. Pretty easy to understand, with a lot of resource management and clicking. If I had one gripe, I'd say that it gets a little repetitive before the Overseer's Office becomes available so you can send your vault dwellers on quests. However, once it does, these break up the monotony nicely and help it feel more like a standard Fallout game. It's a good game to waste an hour or two every day on without constantly feeling like you have to grind for good gear and items. Be sure to keep an eye out for the Mysterious Stranger - if you hear an ominous tone, look around your vault and click him for a hefty Cap reward.

It's a management sim. It basic and simple, yet not to complex to get a person confused. It does take forever to get things up and running effectively. Patience is a must. This side scrolling compartmentalized structure is a unique experience in the Fallout universe. I have other vaults on other devices, and it is possible to build a thriving vault. The only downside is that the resident cap is 200, and it limits how big your vault can be. It pauses when you leave and resumes when you come back, which is nice, but not so much for the people outside the vault. I have had many vault members die because I did not check back in time, even when you give them the best gear and equipment. This game has micro-transactions. Some micro-transactions are better than others. Lunchboxes, animal carriers, and Mr. Handy are the best for the value. It is one of the only loot-box systems in the gaming industry that I actually like to spend money on. I spent hours on this game, and very few in frustration. Also, it is a great game to the kill time if needed.

At first I was going to give this a thumbs up, but ended up changing my mind after "playing" for 139 hours so far. Fallout Shelter is very management heavy which is fine. You place your dwellers in different rooms which produce different resources, you can send them out into the wasteland to gather items and send them on quests which will reward you with all kinds of items. That's a brief summery of the things you can do in Fallout Shelter;... sounds cool right? Well...

If your impatient this "Free" game will tempt you into purchasing in game items with real world money to speed up different things in the game. See everything in Fallout Shelter is completed over time... real world time which means; crafting weapons, clothing, training, traveling and questing takes time hours in many cases sometimes days! This is where you can purchase with real world money an item that can speed up time.

1. Fallout Shelter isn't very interactive, you set up your dwellers then exit the game.

2. There's not much of a battle system

3. Items and rewards are extremely bland & not exciting at all 

4. Finally, if your interested in collecting achievements/trophies there's one that will either cost you an insane 
    amount of time or real world money. You have to collect 20 unique legendary dwellers which you can only 
    get from "lunch boxes", lunch boxes are rare to get & getting a legendary dweller from one is extremely 
    rare on top of that!

Has the same MO as every other freemium game: it primes you with tons of goodies at the beginning and then hides the rest of its content behind timewalls that can be skipped with the in-game currency (which you can conveniently pay for). You can also buy lunchboxes for random drops of weapons, rare dwellers, caps, etc but its obvious that the value and uniqueness of the stuff in them drops off steeply with time. 

Not gonna lie, I've played nearly 50 hours of this game and I got pretty far into this game. I've unlocked nearly every room and now the first thing I do every morning is check up on how my dwellers are doing and click on all the notifications. I'm more than a little embarrassed to have played it this far. I should have deleted this long ago. 

tldr: Just a shitty freemium game imported to pc; don't play unless you want a product specifically made to form bad habits in you.

A port of a mobile game centered around base building with a bit of dungeon crawling mixed in, all in the classic Fallout flair.  Oh, and a nice pile of micro-transactions to make life easier or more convenient but at least here they're in a Free to Play game instead of one you have to buy first (*cough*76*cough*).

Graphics are good and match the kind of cutesy art style of the "Fallout Guy" franchise mascot.  Nothing amazing, but it does its job well.

Sound is kind of 'meh' but does at least keep to the Fallout theme well in music choices and sound effects though the Incident Alert klaxon is annoying enough you'll probably be turning the sound off entirely just to shut the blasted thing up (it really needs its own mute button).

The core base building gameplay loop is fine for casual gaming, being centered around wait timers that will tick down even when you're not actively playing so it's a sort of game you just check in on for a couple minutes at a time throughout your day.  Anyone old enough to remember Tamagachis, this is the Fallout version.

The dungeon gameplay, or 'Quests' aren't all that complex, but do provide a nice mini-game sort of distraction to break up the base-building.  You basically just go room to room killing all the baddies with the vault dwellers you've trained up which could get boring, but it doesn't take too long either so it doesn't overstay its welcome.

The game even has plenty of classic Fallout humor, but most of it is tucked away rather than shoved in your face.  If you zoom in on a room with multiple dwellers, for example, you'll start seeing their banter.  Or if you read through the logs of one you have exploring the wasteland there are a few gems sprinkled in there.

All in all, it's a fun little time user good for a casual audiences but is probably going to feel too slow paced for the more 'hardcore gamer' crowd that will likely feel pressured into buying stuff to keep up a faster pace of progression.

Fallout Shelter (2015 on IOS, 2016 on PC)

Originally out on the cellphone, Fallout Shelter gives you the role of The Overseer to manage your very own vault, Build up your vault with everything the people need, from food to water and living spaces, ever expanding as your vault grows in size. Fight off bandits and any other scum trying to steal your resources. Send dwellers out to explore the wasteland to recover gear, weapons and resources for you to use. Complete quests with a team of dwellers for more loot. You can even get characters from the Fallout games to join your vault. Its a pretty fun game to play, if you invest the time into it. Was a great game to play during boring lectures at University.

While it's fun for a while (I've been playing for more than a year), it's not worth investing too much time or ANY real money.

The main quests offer interesting storylines, and the prospect of getting rare or legendary items keep you coming back for more. So does a degree of freedom to the layout and upgrades to your vault. The crafting doesn't seem necessary when you do a lot of quests, because the rewards alone should be enough to equip your dwellers, so you most likely will end up filling your warehouses with a huge amount of junk.

However, the game tends to crash every now and then, and a crash at the wrong time corrupts your save - rendering your vault unrecoverable. So if you've made considerable progress and it crashes - there is a chance that your precious vault is no more. Aside from that, the quests become repetitive after some time (there are WAY too few locations, it's as if you're visiting the same places over and over later on). There are also vault incidents that at higher levels (deathclaws) are frustrating and happen too often, so it's imperative that you have a well-equipped army guarding the rooms adjacent to the vault door at all times.

And so it's difficult to rate this game (despite it being free) because it's designed for long-term gameplay (as in finish a quest, upgrade a room, and get back later), while being totally unreliable due to the crashes that can make you lose everything...

This game is pretty bad, so here are my complaints. 

Quests are boring, sitting there for a minute in each room waiting for your dwellers to finally shoot the enemy is really boring and time wasting. It feels like it's forever until you finally progress to the next room only to do the same thing again. There is no option where you can autoplay the mission. You have to do it yourself.
My second complaint is when you don't play the game for a long time, you will start to lose resources over time such as water, power, or food.
My 3rd complaint is that there's only a limit of things you can do a day. It's not something you can grind for a few hours.

 Fallout Shelter puts you in control of a state-of-the-art underground Vault from Vault-Tec. Build the perfect Vault, keep your Dwellers happy, and protect them from the dangers of the Wasteland.

BUILD THE PERFECT VAULT
Create a brighter futureunderground! Select from a variety of modern-day rooms to turn an excavation beneath 2,000 feet of bedrock into the very picture of Vault Life.

OVERSEE A THRIVING COMMUNITY
Get to know your Dwellers and lead them to happiness. Find their ideal jobs and watch them flourish. Provide them with outfits, weapons, and training to improve their abilities.

PROSPER
A well-run Vault requires a variety of Dwellers with a mix of skills. Build a Radio Room to attract new Dwellers. Or, take an active role in their personal lives; play matchmaker and watch the sparks fly!

EXPLORE THE WASTELAND
Send Dwellers above ground to explore the blasted surface left behind and seek adventure, handy survival loot, or unspeakable death. Find new armor and weapons, gain experience, and earn Caps. But dont let them die!

PROTECT YOUR VAULT
From time to time, idyllic Vault life may be disrupted by the dangers of post-nuclear life. Prepare your Dwellers to protect against threats from the outsideand within.

Vault-Tec has provided the tools, but the rest is up to you. What are you waiting for? Get started building your Vault today for FREE.

Fallout Shelter is typical farm simulator with Fallout aesthetics. Unfortunately, farming is all that there is. That would be enough for time killing, but I expected to play Fallout Shelter and to manage Fallout vault, not some vague postapocalyptic underground farm. The only thing this game can offer is wish to play actual Fallout. 

Two main complaints about mechanics are SPECIAL system and Wasteland missions.  
First, SPECIAL system is totally redundant here. The only paramater that matters is endurance and it has to be maxed at 1st dweller level, because it determines maximum health increase of dweller that happens only  at level gain. There is zero explanations of this mechanic in game, so, player has no clue that his dwellers have low health and why. All other six parameters don't play any major role at all. They slightly speed up resource gain and can be maxed at any level without consequences. They may be affecting something when dweller is sent to wasteland they role is so much less than endurance and weapon damage. And this brings us to second thing. 
Wasteland is reduced to 2 backgrounds and 2 types of missions. 1 mission is when dweller goes to wasteland on its own and collects resourses until your call back. There is no interactions, no decisions, just automated resource collection. Second type of mission is one that requires three dwellers. They go to same building, thet you click on all rooms there, click on all enemies, wait until enemies are dead, click on dwellers to heal them, click on all boxes and order end mission. Sometimes enemies ask something but there is no consequences. And this is all. No mechanics, no diversity, no gameplay. I don't ask for much, but may be make not everything the same? At some early point, when your vault is developed a little, when you got the basic principles of resource balancing, game just ends. It turns into monotonous routine. Yes, you can update weapons and costumes from rare to legendary, but there is no challenge and no reward for doing so. On the other hand, getting legendary dwellers are impossible without paying for starter packs. There is absolute zero chance to get them from lunchboxes. Oh, lunchboxes. They are supposed to be some random high reward for hard task, but often they just give random common junk. It is so much easier to just craft legendary items rather get some from lunchbox. Thank god, it is not necessary to spend money to maintain vault here.

I am a big fan of idle games, and this is a good mix of idle and... not idle gameplay. However, I am also a completionist, and good lord are some of the acheivements a menace to get. The "Raise a Vault Dweller to 50" is misleading - you need to raise a Vault Dweller from 1 to 50, and the rare/legendary Dwellers you get randomly don't count.
Speaking of the Legendary Dwellers... I've played 50+ hours at the time of writing this, and I only have 3 Legendary Dwellers (I haven't spent any money in this game). You can only get legendary dwellers from lunchboxes and a couple of quests. If you want to keep your sanity, do NOT go for this achievement. You will crumble up into a pile of dust before you reach the goal legitimately. Otherwise, this is a fun free game to put a few hours into.

I have enjoyed this time sink game so far. It's a pretty simple concept that keeps me interested several hours in. For a free to play game you can't really ask for a whole lot more.

Basically you create a shelter underground and have to build up a community to improve your situation. You have to maintain power, water and food resources and can recruit new survivors who find your shelter. Sometimes you get raided by enemies and you can equip your survivors with clothing, armor, weapons and companions such as pets. You can also send your survivors on quests to find resources or attack enemies, etc. You can match up male and female survivors in the same place and they might hit it off and have a child, adding to your overall community survivor totals, etc. You can name or rename all your survivors to whatever you want, creating your own family structures within your community, etc.

Some games were made for grinding and this is one of the better ones. I continue to want to see what happens next.

A decent worker-placement and base management game, if weirdly sanitized compared to its source material.

The good is mostly in the theming and stratgic base management business. 

The game's weaknesses are concentrated in its monetization, as should shock no-one. In this game, you pay money to make things happen faster and to buy grab-bags of potentially-useful items.

In short, you pay to turn the difficulty down and play the game less. That said, if you're going to charge for that kind of thing, do it in a free-to-play game. Doing it in a game with an upfront price, like for example Fallout 76, would just be gross and exploitative.

If at any point you feel like putting money in to this game, it probbly means you have gotten bored of it. Find something else to play instead.

This game combines the action-packed life of being in charge of large groups of people, with the semi-monotony of waiting for something to happen, resulting in a game that constantly keeps you on your toes. While at times it's difficult to manage all of the different needed rooms, the payoff that you get when a Raider Attack is stopped dead in it's tracks before reaching the second floor is worth it. One heed of warning, however,  that I didn't realize when playing for the first time: The game runs even when it's not open. You can quit the application, but a rooted time-keeping system makes certain events happen while you're offline. Most of the time, it's just things like dwellers having children, and rooms producing resources. Occasionally, though, you might miss out on new dwellers coming to your vault, only to never be let in.
Overall, I'm a huge fan of this game and its mobile counterpart, but it requires planning and budgeting to the fullest. Highly recommend.

The game mechanic that makes me not recommend is the dweller health calculation.  Dweller health only goes up based on the endurance stat at the time of level up, so if you level up to 50 and then train endurance you get nothing, and the dweller is basically a throw-away.

Also, I was excited to get power armor and bulldoze the wasteland, but apparently power armor is kind of junk in this.  (it's special stats aren't really useful for combat and doesn't provide any actual defense)

That dweller survivability thing is really irritating and could easily have been fixed.  Otherwise I'm addicted to this game.

As a free product, it is absolutely worth a try.
Unfortunately it has a very high longevity in the short term but almost absent in the long term.
Being very intuitive at the beginning it totally captures you and you are busy for hours and hours managing the cave, mentally planning the location of the environments, choosing the most suitable tasks for each of the survivors, but in the long run it becomes very repetitive and since they are not required special skills to move forward, all you need to do is level up to keep up with the growing strength of the enemies storming the base. If you have time to wait (or Nuka-Cola bonus bottles) you can play the missions, where you just have to click on the rooms and watch almost helplessly the clashes between your three men chosen for the mission and the various enemies you encounter. These missions are very useful in the beginning for obtaining powerful weapons and clothes, but later on the relative importance of these loot decreases tediously.
Technically, with mouse and keyboard the typical gaps of a touch game are accused. For example, you feel the lack of a multiple selection, because you are forced to drag men from room to room by taking them one at a time. It would have been practical to be able to manage survivors by being able to organize them into numbered groups that could be saved and recalled directly with the push of a button, as it works in hundreds of games simpler than this.
Nonetheless, it is an interesting strategy management game from which something deeper could be developed.

Played this on PS4 a few years back and I actually enjoyed it a lot managed to platinum it but I didn't even try was playing the game and it's a great little challenge as it goes through trying to level up characters, find the best weapons and armour to find and give birth to more settlers in order to unlock more rooms. Need to a total of 100 for all the room unlocks and it's not easy you get raided and as you level up your settlers the raids get harder, from just plain raiders to Deathclaws that can wipe your base out in mins. Don‚Äôt have the right mind set and strategy for defence and attack you can see all your hard work go to pieces believe it's happened to me a couple of times. 

The game is different and sometimes it's a nice little break from other games to work out what to do next should you send some of your strongest on a mission or hold back as you don't know what will happen, I've done just that sent out 3 of my strongest on a quest to go get a legendary weapon schematic for only 2 mins later a raid happen luckily I managed to defend it off but depends on what comes. So far I have managed very well without paying any real world money even did that on PS4 so I've taken the same stragesyt take it slow and plan accordingly and I've done better for my 4th vault attempt lol, it's a great little game I recommend it a lot.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 fucking minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

The game was developed by Bethesda Game Studios and Behaviour Interactive, published by Bethesda Softworks, on Microsoft Windows (Bethesda / .net and Steam), iOS, Android, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, and Tesla vehicles, released on 15th of June 2015 (First release / iOS) and 29th of March 2017 (Steam), simulation and tycoon genre and what I review is the latest 1.12 version on 25th of May, 2017 (yeah, this game hasn't been updated since two months after being ported) on Steam platform.
Good and simple base building spin-off Fallout game though it has different characteristics from previous series, very innovative and unique 2.5D side-scrolling and "overseer a vault" concept.

[h1]Story 8,3/10[/h1]

The story follows a player who runs a Vault-Tec Corporation vault as the overseer and must survive in the vault with the dwellers in it by employs the dweller to their respective skills such as strength for power resources, perception for water resources, and agility for food resources, marry off a dweller couple to produce offspring or use a radio studio to attract new dwellers from the wasteland, arm them with weapons and outfits, train their SPECIAL to add their performance, craft weapons, outfits and themes from junks, and send 'em to wasteland.
In quests, there are many interesting and neat exclusive stories and events such as investigating ruthless raider cults, searching a "mythical utopia", rescuing a missing Diamond City detective or a Thanksgiving cook, saving a couple of a drink sponsor, scare off some raiders, fight off "thieves" in Christmas, etc.

[h1]Gameplay 8.8/10[/h1]

The main gameplay in the vault is mediocre for example harvesting goods (can be done by Mr. Handy) , crafting items, and mating and train the dwellers that only relies on time (can be cheated using the device time), even the rush feature will be useless other than to complete the objective if you have got three or more Mr. Handys.
However, the gameplay when your dwellers exploring wasteland or in a quest was quite good, for example the SPECIAL of a dweller which'll affect what they find in the wasteland, fairly inexpensive paid items, good exclusive stories, items and characters in quests, limited-time events (reused every year) and dialogue choices with full sentences instead of just "sarcastic" and "what's going on?".
The things i dislike are save data that's likely to disappear (can be overcome), lucky or unlucky if you're a free player facing a radscorpion or ghouls attack with only sawed-off shotguns and 38. revolvers and the combat system for not having timeskipper which over times becomes boring

[h1]Graphics 9,1/10[/h1]

2.5D Unity engine graphics with cartoonist theme that derives from Vault Boy a.k.a. Vault-Tec Corporation mascot and side view of the game, all I can say is the graphics and styles of this game are excellent for a -500mb size mobile game.
Even though this game's been ported to many platforms, even to PlayStation 4 and Tesla vehicles, the graphics still don't have or aren't upscale(d) is fairly disappointing. 
The old film slideshow, radiant green, and children's cartoon paper (?) from the 50s UI following from Fallout 4 and the previous installment like a characteristic of a Fallout game series are classy.

[h1]Sounds 9,3/10[/h1]

The retro background music with melodic and rhythmic musical instruments, each rooms ambience sounds, and cool sound effects which all of them are well packed.
The only drawback is that there's no official singer unlike the previous installment, so there's no known song in this game unlike "Big Iron" from New Vegas or "Uranium Fever" from Fallout 4.

[h1]Replayability 8/10[/h1]

Since this game doesn't have an ending or endless play, you can replay the game at any time, either for an event, mood to play, or to get fairly easy achievements

[h1]Overall 8,7/10[/h1]

The experience feels like a solid and somewhat fun foundation for a deeper and better game that just isn‚Äôt here (yet). There are no vault decoration or customization options. No options to trade with other players or trade caravans. There is no need give any thought to the specific positioning of the rooms in your fault, beyond keeping your most essential buildings near your power plant in case of emergencies. There is no need to craft specific items or think about production lines. Any or all of these features would make Fallout Shelter a deeper and more rewarding game in the long term, as we see in similar mobile games, including very casual mobile hits like FarmVille 2: Country Escape and Township

It is a fun game, but be prepared to spend some $ to enhance your experience. The cost may be held to a minimum with discipline, but if you are a completionist on a budget it might be wise to avoid this one.

[h1] A Good Mobile Port from my Beloved universe: [/h1]
Fallout Shelter is a free to play game where you are an overseer tasked with building and maintaining a vault in a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland.

[h1] Gameplay: [/h1]
Game is a mobile port. It is a 2-D game. it consists of building a vault and keeping vault dwellers happy by providing food, water and electricity. The game is of 2 parts vault building and doing quests. each quest has time to complete like any other free to play game. You send dwellers out for doing quest The quest takes place in outside vaults mostly in a procedurally developed vaults. The ultimate aim in this game is to keep your dwellers happy and equipping and training them to be best. As it is a free to play game, everything in this game is time bound. So to speed things up we need lunchboxes[spoiler] [other name for lootboxes to evade gambling accusation :) ] [/spoiler]. This is the micro-transaction part which most free to play games employ to generate revenue. But gotta give credit to them for employing in a fair manner. You can get atleast 3 (or more depending on your luck) of these lunchboxes per week for free. So those who wait can get everything in this game if you are willing to trade your time. 

[h1] Atmosphere and Story: [/h1]
The world is ravaged by nuclear fire and many people  enter into vaults to survive. With this premise most of the time we will be looking at the vaults from a 2-D point of view and managing it. While doing quest its is of same with dwellers arriving at different procedurally developed vaults to do pre-destined quests. For a 2-d free to play game, the music is good. 

[h1] Other features: [/h1]
This game has no DLC's or multiplayer content. This is a purely single player game.

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1]
This is one of the good free to play game. If you are a fallout fan then you must play it. Others who are new to this series should give it a try. You don't need to know anything about fallout to play this game. The micro-transaction part is also well done. But there are some achievements in game that will definitely require to open those lunchboxes to get it. So achievement hunters beware, if you are not spending any money it may takes months to get those achievements[spoiler] (Play mobile version before to get to know the game if you are achievement hunting to optimise your time and gameplay) [/spoiler]. Overall it is a good game that everyone must give it a try.

After enough playing I realized that this game isn't really good due to the following points:

1) Clumsy interface:
When you open the game after 24 hours you find that it has been "running" on its own like clicker games. In other words the resource generation has been going on on its own.

* But when you're playing it directly you need to constantly click on a room to receive the generated power / food etc. Why? This is just a clumsy interface design which interrupts your thought process.

* When people level up you need to click on them in order to upgrade their stats. This is again a redundant game mechanic which serves no purpose. And what makes it really annoying is that you need to do this multiple times because the first click will usually select the person instead of upgrading him.

* There are some people who're walking all around the rooms. Why? It becomes very difficult to select them because the UI prioritizes clicks to a room over clicks to a person.

2) Broken gameplay design:

Consider this, you're people are all working peacefully. Suddenly there's a breach. How in the hell are they able to break through a door, like butter, that was upgraded to level 3? But let's leave aside that part and consider the gameplay during a breach:

* All your vault mates will ignore the intruders and continue doing their jobs. Does that make any sense to you?

* _You_ need to manually arm the dwellers (but you get weapons much later in the game). So you need to have at least one dweller with weapons and _manually_... yes, you read that right! _Manually_ move that dweller to the room in which intruders have gone to.

* As your dweller fights the intruder, they'll quickly go to another room. So what does your dweller do? He stays in that room doing nothing. Really smart!

* Sometimes you would have armed people in the room with the weapons (in order to avoid the stupid gameplay mechanic mentioned above). In this case these dwellers will get back to their job once the intruders go into another room. So either you now need to move these dwellers to another room    -OR-   remove the weapons from their inventory and provide the weapons to someone else's inventory.

* In case you moved dwellers who were performing a task into another room then they'll stop doing their jobs once the intruders are dealt with. They'll start loitering around the entire vault. The onus is on you to identify those people once again and reassign them back into their room.

* Typically the vault intrusions will happen a lot! And it will upset multiple rooms at once. Combine all the broken gameplay mechanics mentioned above and you're looking at micromanaging the UI as your vault becomes bigger.

3) Lots of bad design choices:

* You get dwellers only when you create more rooms. And there will always be more empty rooms than you have dwellers. Keep that in mind while you're adding rooms.

* If you quit the game your explorers will keep "exploring" AKA die. Most of them will be dead. So you need to keep spending money to revive them and get them back. There's no way of setting up a rule or making them have the sense to return back when their health is low. The onus is on you to micromanage that while you're AFK.

 Summary: There is a _looooott_ of grind in this game. You'd be better of getting the fallout single player by paying an upfront amount and enjoying that game for several hours than playing this one where you're endlessly dealing with one bad design element after another.

Firstly its' a Free game with well composed 2d Falloutboy style animation, with only a few minor bugs ( I've noticed the mysterious stranger not showing up even though the audio plays for him and you have only 4 rooms to find him in or delays in picking up weapon animations ). 

Essentially, you build up a vault and its dwellers, collect caps and resources, expand / upgrade your vault rooms to make more or better resources, upgrade your SPECIAL stats for each vault dweller to improve their happiness and overall contributions in the vault. There is lots to time-synced grind for caps and resource peaks, lots of waiting for rooms to produce goods too which means you probably load this game up on a lunch break or before bed and leave it to collect. 

There some combat event sequences that can happen, you can send your vault dwellers into the wasteland to find caps, junk, gear, weapons and fight wasteland creatures, sometimes your vault gets attacked and you have to have station dwellers to defend it. There are also exploration sites you can visit to uncover caps, junk, gear, weapons and fight monsters hiding through the building(s). 

If you enjoy the fallout universe you will likely enjoy this ! 

8/10

It is a free easy wating simulator no-brainer game and spinoff to Fallout 4. 

Session Routine
- building different rooms in the vault (rather in the beginning)
- assigning dwellers to different rooms/ tasks/ training 
- gather ressources/ dweller levelups in the vault
- sending dwellers on quests to different locations for items/ crafting ingredients. Up to 3 quests in a session, 
   but can be accelerated with in-game currency Nuka Cola

Pros
+ good to play if you don`t want to spend much time playing ( ~15 minutes)
+ some nice humorous Fallout4 references/ dialogues/ stories    
+ microtransactions are completely not needed and irrelevant (no pay2win) 

Contras
- after few hours you discovered all game mechanics and it becomes repetetative
- some elements don`t have any influence on the gameplay, are rather game filler

While free, it tries to take your money every way it can. Also, like every Bethesda game, it's filled to the brim with exploits or bugs. I can always understand monetizing a free game in some way or another, that's forgivable to certain extents. That said, this game lacks basically anything resembling stuff to do, or content of any kind. Very little weapon or gear variety that actually matters - most is junk that clutters your inventory. There's some annoyingly stupid mechanics mixed in there as well - ignoring the "cola conveniences" aspect they use for more money. I realize this is a mobile game and was ported due to popularity, but wow does it unfortunately feel like a mobile game. Don't be fooled by my hours - it's almost all AFK. If you've never played it before, you'll have fun for the first while - after that you'll realize you did everything the game has to offer after you've built your first room or explored your first mission/point of interest.

oh, dear heavens no, i wouldn't recommend this game.
for starters, it's kind of a buggy mess. aside from, you know, regular bethesda sloppiness, the controls are ridiculously asinine and the game simply CANNOT parse commands. if you click on a "dweller" and try to drag him into another room, you'll find that you usually end up giving that command to either another random dweller (that you did NOT click on), or simply scroll around the screen.
Boy, i hope you weren't trying to move someone very far, and i REALLY hope you weren't in a hurry! because it isn't going to work, and by the time they get there, whatever incident it was will have spread. lol!
nothing scales well at all. once your vault list reaches ~100ish, it starts becoming tedious to do anything. it takes literally weeks (no really. literal. weeks.) to make high tier weapons and armor (you are better off just not doing that, obviously). 
i cannot stress how low bethesda sets the bar on this game.
as far as fallout, the reason i even installed the game in the first place, simply.... no. things that cannot be, are. things that are, cannot be. Bethesda has apparently been enjoying their time smearing their shit all over FO lore, so if you like FO, just don't pay attention... it's better to think of this game as it's own separate universe, from someone who has never had an original idea in their lives (which is what it is. bethesda couldn't come up with an interesting, new setting if their life depended on it. and even if they could, they wouldn't because that would be risky than copying someone else's work and sprinkling SJ and shitty marketing tactics on it).
i could look past most of this, honestly, if anyone can tell me what part of this game is "fun."
the waiting? the dragging dwellers places, and then waiting? giving commands and waiting? trying to do things and waiting? honestly, even when you "play" this game, there really isn't any "playing" going on. no real thought, strategy, or skill is involved. it's not a very interactive game, at all. almost every instant of the game is simply  waiting for arbitrary lengths of time. and when you're done with that, you wait some more. you can upgrade your room and wait a little less, but... we're talking about a few hours shaved off of a few days, in a lot of cases.
if you don't believe me, that's cool, man. it's a free. definitely check out other games while you "play" this one. stellaris is a good companion, or maybe MtG Arena.

This game is not very good. It is very slow paced, I mean very slow paced. Yet, if you log out and come back after a long time, some of your people may be dead, killed. This is the kind of game to play little and often.  Within 5 minutes I had 2 fires start in the same UNUSED room, which then spread because no one can get there fast enough. I also did a quest that needed survivors around level 6+, I sent 2 level 7 persons there. Then when I entered the room with the 'boss', he started throwing grenades that killed both of them in 2 hits. I don't get it because it said it was an easy task, no warning was given that it was dangerous, or hard. Either way, I haven't quested since, and to be frank, I doubt I will play this game again. This Fallout game is not bad, I only played for so long, but that was because it was not very intriguing for me. It's not for me, but can be for others, so i'll give a description and a heads up about it.

It is a nice little shelter game with building your own homestead and caring for vault dwellers and arming a few of them for adventures. But I am constantly on the brink of a crisis when it comes to resource meters. 

I need dwellers to unlock things, but more dwellers increases food and water demand, and more food and water rooms to meet the demand increases the electricity demand to run them all, and building any kind of room and/or digging out dirt to make more room requires a good chunk of caps that are tough to get without things like lunchboxes or packs to provide cap rewards.

It is one of those games where you need grit and have to pull through tough situations and best plan out things in hard times. But gets nice to watch progress overtime. And of course, it is a free game, so it try's to tempt you with in-game purchases so help you progress/maintain.
for everyone that loves fallout , its a great time spender :)

Fallout Shelter has been an imbecile game from day one and it still is. You're given a vault to manage, some cancerous inbreds to pilot and some blueprints to build. The issues in Fallout Shelter spread wide and are so dumb you're left to wonder if anyone working on this project actually cared about it.

First issue is the tutorial won't let you build anything and is an agonizing piece to go through. They made the instructions for children 5 and below. It's useless, annoying and leads nowhere. So you are forced to scrap one vault to get rid of the absolutely horrid build path they force on you.

From that tutorial onward, half the time you'll pick inhabitants in the shelter it will be by accident. You always end up having to redo assignments because of the clumsy drag and drop controls.

Second, this game can't be paused. If you need a bathroom break, be careful, because 9/10 the game will wipe your vault at the same time. Speaking of randomly generated events, they are fixed to guarantee your progression is slowed down as much as possible in a bid to incite your wallet to be used.

Third, there's barely anything Fallout in it, but the lipstick they put on the pig. Weapons don't have stats, it doesn't matter who uses what. You can equip a team of scientists with baseball bats and its the same as if they had laser rifles. It's incoherent, botched and quite frankly not worth suing anyone over.

I don't recommend this game, it's made to exploit people's troubles, not challenge anyone on a fair play field.

This game is for anyone who enjoys the Fallout universe as well as having a consistent time sink option.  Easy to pick up and understand with no pay wall barriers.  Quests to complete, lots of upgrades to your shelter to be had & good variety of dwellers.  Cool looking artwork and just a solid game if you're not looking for anything too heavy.

This game is free. It is a mobile port. It has microtransactions. It is a waiting simulator. It is singleplayer. Graphics are cartoony.

It is literally just a free, micro-managing, waiting game that you check in on once in a while. That's it. That's ALL it is. Whether you prefer to do this inbetween other obligations while working on your PC, or simply once or twice throughout the day, or even every other day.

Fallout Shelter just puts you into the propaganda-style Vault introduced in the Fallout series, it has good humor, and it is interesting enough for a free game to warrant my recommendation.

And to all of the people who passionately dislike this game. It's still Fallout, maybe not an open world shooter. This is not a game you are supposed to rush. It is not a game you are supposed to "win". It does have microtransactions, but you can earn those readily ingame as well, without paying. All those negative reviews ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about these various non-sensical issues are just trash.

The game has good humor, it is very relaxing to watch your dwellers do whatever they do, and frankly since its release on mobile platforms, it has come a long way with a lot of updates and new features. For a FREE game, it is absolutely recommendable. But buyer beware I guess, if you are an elitist moron who thinks you HAVE to rush through the game and "win", then you probably will not enjoy it.

I have played fallout shelter across many platforms and I have never gotten bored of the game once. If you're looking to scratch your fallout itch, but don't want to dive into any of the main titles (fallout 4, fallout new vegas, fallout 76, etc.) this is the perfect game. While it may require more investment of time than other idle games, it can definitely be a hands off experience. However, there's something peaceful about watching your little vault dwellers run around and do their jobs. Even if you haven't played a fallout game before, this is very beginner friendly and will introduce you to the mechanics and themes of fallout without being chased and eaten by a yao gui.

While i understand the game is "FREE" it is extremely high maintenance, you must play often otherwise your vault will not "develop" the game doesn't pause except for disasters, otherwise everything else carries on running while you are not in the game.

One of the most annoying things i found in the game is the lack of defense for the vault. Putting dwellers in the front door of your vault does NOT necessarily mean they will hold back enemies. While you can train and harden your dwellers, it does not stop the enemy from passing through the front door of your vault, instead the enemy gets "Bored" and moves further on into your vault causing more damage and mayhem which could easily be avoided if the game allowed the player or "Overseer" to construct defensive turrets or some sort of deterrent.

Upgrading the Vault Door is a waste of Resources & Caps, they break down the door anyway.

That said! After my 25 hours of playing the game, i am fed up of having to baby sit every single individual in my vault to make sure they have a weapon, armor and stimpacks.

I would honestly rather play something with optimized survival options. eg: Something that allowed me to prevent entry into the base/vault/structure by means of health & defences, sort of like a Zombie horde survival game only 2D.

Very addicting, i recommend restarting and getting the first lunchboxes over and over until you get a decent start, it can be a bummer on some starts and take you a lot longer to get past the beginning otherwise. Don't over do it, a few 500 caps, a dweller/decent pet, and a high damage weapon will do you. [do the rush room success, then collect 50 water and skip the 50 food task. you might get a few extra lunchboxes this way for a slight boost. tasks vary sightly sometimes but for the most part these will 8/10 times be the first 2 lunchbox tasks]

other than that i really enjoy the game and working on a full vault of people raised from level 1 to have full stats.... try to start with endurance training as often as possible as it is the only stat that scales from level one and it affects max hp all the way up to level 50 which is max.

I do not recommend this game if you don`t have self-control. You start playing for 5-10 minutes and then you slowly start to get addicted and instead of playing when you have some free time, you put off other real-life things in order to come back to the game and complete quests or level up dwellers. 

I also do not recommend this game if you plan to get all the steam achievements. The one where you have to get 20 legendary dwellers is next to impossible to get if you don`t buy lunch (aka loot) boxes... You could get it, but you would have to grind A LOT. My guess is that you would need at least 400 hrs. This wouldn`t be that bad if there was a better "end game", but after a while everything seems so repetitive and boring that, in my opinion, it`s not worth the hassle...

That being said, if you don`t find yourself in either category and just want a game in which you can waste 20 minutes a day, this might be an ok game for you. I would, however, recommend that you do something productive with those 20 minutes and not waste them playing this :)

When the slavic potato interNIET strikes again, or there is just for a few seconds nothing to do, the funny FALLOUT SHELTER is your savior! A game, which made me love it first point straight on as a fan of the Fallout Universe, eventhough it certainly has it's ups and downs like every game.

GRAPHICS: (24/25)
I find it difficult to value this term, since it's not meant to be a laborious and realistic thing. It's all in the adorable comic style of the Vault Boy and all the Vault Tec drawings in Fallout games, which is a very neat one. It just fits like a fist on the eye or an ass on a pot and is well designed for all platforms!

SOUND: (21/25)
The exhilarating music is gloriously fitting to Fallout and each room provides you with it's own environmental atmosphere like you actually stand in it. The guns provide different sounds, partially even from Fallout 4 / Fallout 76, eventhough I'm having sometimes weird cuts in a few action sounds like error-barking dogs and glitching gunshots.

GAMEPLAY: (22/25)
The game get's explained in all the details you need and the control is primitevly easy, so you don't have to strain too much about the game. Perfect for little opportunities where you wait on your comrades getting online - if you have any comrades at all - eventhough sometimes the hitboxes for picking items and dwellers is a bit buggy. In general it makes a lot of fun, eventhough I'd wish myself more features actually and more exciting quests. The game runs mostly without issue, unlike most people would expect from Bethesda.

CONTENT: (22/25)
Everything from Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 seems to be included into this game in terms of legendary dwellers, outfits, weapons and a bit of story as well. For Fallout fans, the cr√©me de la cr√©me (or however to write that) and the whole idea I think is very creative and extraordinary. The only thing that runs out is the motivation, when there's nothing to do anymore and you have to wait hours until dwellers come home from a raid or improve their skills.

SUM: 89/100

Fallout Shelter (FS) is one of those free games that you can't stop playing, due to a judicious mix of random elements and set strategies. 

As a vault manager, you have gained the resources to build your own vault, provided you keep the resources going. You need caps to hire the laborers to dig elevators and excavate rooms. You need resources to construct simple to advanced rooms, to supply the vault with food, water, energy, and other vital needs, from barber to weapons manufacturing. AND you need vault dwellers. You have to train some to improve them, use the rest to run the facilities, and send a few out into the wasteland to scavenge. You also have missions that can gain you extra loot, blueprints, and more. And if you introduce two citizens together and they have enough charisma, they may decide to make babies... 

There technically is no end to this, until you ran out of missions/quests, or you have maximized the citizens and/or the vault completely and you've built all you can built. But only your management skills can get you there... Can you recruit some of commonwealth's famous citizens? Can you survive ghoul or deathclaw attacks? How about other underground critter attacks? Will your vault become a tomb of your ambitions, or the crowning glory of the wasteland? 

All of this was presented in a very nicely parallaxed view that you can zoom in and observe the citizens at their jobs. But it's not that simple. As your explorers of the wasteland return (and you tell them when to come back) they can bring back loot, which can be used by workshops to build things, as well as various uniforms and weapons. Many uniforms can improve the citizen's SPECIAL attributes. And the better his or her attributes fits the job, the more s/he produces at that job. It all adds up. 

And due to all the bad critters wanting into your vault, you need some serious firepower, lest you find your vault littered with corpses after a deathclaw raid... But you can't build the more advanced stuff until you have the modern stuff... and you need a medical facility to build stims and whatnot to keep the adventurers out and about... 

It's all spinning plates and competing priorities. And that's what makes it fun...

Resembles those web-page-based CGI games, but without the tension of multiple countdown clocks staring at you and the endless timed midnight crises that program you to get up in the middle of the night if you strive to become a serious player. Clocks countdown stop running after the round ends after you leave the game. Therefore, when you open the game, you pick up where all the operations have finished their (last) round of countdown and you can start by reaping all the finished goods and utilities. 

The game starts a bit slow if you buy a starter pack, literally, nothing happens and need you tending to for minutes: either you spend some bucks to start off faster, or you hang in there until you get the Overseer's office to start sending out exploration groups to specially tailored series of tasks. Is it worth it to spend a few bucks for the starter pack? I say yes, because it is a free game to begin with. The developers to deserve a bit of our appreciation. But does one need to spend more money on the lunch boxes, pet cages or quantum nuka-colas? I say that depends on how serious you want this gaming experience to be. It is quite possible to sink too much money into this game, putting it above an average (small?) game, if you aren't patient enough, though.

Fallout Shelter has some good ideas and in a sense, it's a bit like Dungeon Keeper. You level up your dwellers, put 'm to work and equip them with some familiar items and you expand your vault as you go along. That's a bit weird from a story perspective but whatever, it's one of the few (if not only, not counting mods) Fallout-themed building games we'll probably ever get.

Unfortunately, 'casual' mode is far too easy so you switch over to survival mode for a challenge, right? Well ... The challenge in this game is more in being sure to save and exit on time and logging in a few hours later on when the tasks are done rather than continuously playing the game because you will at some point be overrun and run out of Rad-away and Stimpacks or simply be incredibly annoyed at the endless amount of accidents and raids (Deathclaws appear at 35 dwellers on survival) that just take up a ton of your time that you would really, really want to spend on expanding your vault and micro-managing everything. 

The focus should have been far more on exploration and wasteland combat rather than defending your vault. Not only is it unrealistic that everyone and everyone and their mom barges down the door every 3 minutes, it's also terribly annoying. At some point you'll be in control of it and it stops being a challenge so then it just becomes busy work as you sit there waiting for the raiders to finally keel over and die long after the fight is over. The way you have to defend your vault by dragging people onto chambers (which doesn't work all too well on the PC version, for some reason, you can only drag them into the top half which often causes workers to be assigned to the wrong rooms for me) or assigning them a (temporary) defense job in that room is extremely tedious and doesn't really work well with the speed at which attackers move through your dungeon, err, vault. 

Then there's the fact that your dwellers can not auto-stimpack themselves. You have to monitor their health bars continuously. The health bars disappear when they run around and they will also obscure each other's health bars. Then there's the fact that unless you level up your characters, you can not click any other icon above their heads but leveling up early means you'll forfeit a lot of health because all your dwellers have low endurance so later on in the game, you'll be forced to get rid of all your high-level, low-endurance dwellers and start from scratch if you want to get dwellers that don't require a ton of stimpacks during each fight. Can you see how Bethesda really put thought into how to annoy you into getting those lunchboxes with high endurance dwellers? 

And what about the having an extra job in the form of having to log back into the game on time to make sure your explorers aren't killed in the wasteland? Not a problem on casual but in survival, there are no second chances. Woe you if you use the "X" to close the program, it doesn't auto-save and it won't remember your command to return dwellers so it'll kill 'm off! (So make sure you Save and exit from the options menu). I guess that can be forgiven to some extent, it is a port after all but the fact that you have to log back into a game to check if your explorers aren't dying is just busy work and obviously done to make the game more addictive rather than functional. 

Games should allow you to simply log off and go about your day and start 'm back up as if you were never gone unless they're persistent multiplayer games if only for the sake of the mental health of the player.

I guess what Bethesda really wants you to do is just buy their stuff so you can boost your way through the game. Buy more lunch boxes, buy more pets, buy more handyman ... Here's a hint for you: don't allow Bethesda to violate the series any further and just use a savegame editor for stuff you normally would have spent money on.

The game is quite an interesting and simple asylum management simulator. We take on the role of the Superintendent and must control the situation in the shelter: happiness, health, satiety and the number of people, their clothes, weapons, electricity for shelter and in general all the welfare of the shelter. (Fight raiders and monsters that they want to take our shelter and lives from our people)
Moreover, in this we have complete freedom. You can really build anything, the only question is whether people will survive in this 'building'...

As our development progresses, new rooms, characters, room customization options and many interesting quest tasks will open and the game will not make us bored, at least for the next 100 hours.

I really liked this game, because even taking into account that it is completely free, you can open everything in it, nothing really depends on whether you put money into the game or not. It's all about time.

The game is really addictive, the only thing that depresses me - the appearance of being ported from mobile devices. Because of this, it has a kind of strange mouse control, but for me personally. This isn't bothers everyone, but I didn't like it. On this, in principle, the cons of the game ends.

I advise this game to anyone who does not have money on the account, but you really want to play something interesting. That's what you need.

A cute little time waster game, perfect to have open while watching a podcast or political debate. You can train your dwellers in specific skills and put them to work, or train them in everything, give them the best weapons, and send them out to explore or tackle missions. The ability to play out the missions is such a nice touch, it really gives you the illusion that the game isn't a wait-to-play like Clash of Clans. The Nuka-Colas that speed up wait times aren't that hard to find either, making it so you hardly ever have real downtime in game. 

7/10

It's pay to win. Perhaps I should've known, since it was free and not a demo, but I was disappointed all the same and feel I should warn you. 

It has problems with corrupted saves, which means if you put irl money into it you might lose it with no warning.

It is abandoned even though the store is still running. Which means no fixes for the game corruption problem that might lose you your money investment, no updates, and no new features. Seasonally, they re-release decorations.

The interface also has problems and lacks important features. You cannot pause the game and you cannot speed it up, so you're stuck with a very slow-paced game. During emergencies, you must click and drag each individual you want to send to help, and fight auto-focus features to do it which lowers your response time. There are no security staff roles you can assign so they automatically respond to emergencies, either.

I would have preferred to pay $15 for a small game that worked, than get for free a game which does not work. I was hoping for something that felt like early "Oxygen Not Included" with a Fallout theme, but instead I got an abandoned beta game that is restrictive in an effort to extort money without guarantee that money will not be wasted. 

If you play it (it is free, so why not) I do not recommend you invest a lot of time or any money at all into it.

Let's first mention that the game is free and you only spend your time, so if you have nothing better to do, might as well try it. 

The game has microtransactions but they're not very intrusive, you get informed of them once, they're under the first menu button (F1) and you can earn a few teasers that scream at you "Look how handy these lootboxes are, wouldn't it be nice if you bought MORE of them!?" The lootbox rewards are ultimately conveniences though, you don't need them.

What you do need, is overseer mentality. The wasteland is a dangerous place and it will come to your vault, and like a true overseer it is your job to maximise utility while keeping your vault dwellers safe, oblivious and happy. They'll do as they're told, or they'll get sent to the wasteland and will only be allowed back in with decent loot! Also, people will basically breed on demand, and with anyone except (close) relatives. 

Keeping a steady production of babies is key to a well populated vault. Don't overdo it though, pregnant women won't participate against disasters and the toddlers take a while to turn into adults, so they're temporary resource hogs before they're useful.

Gameplay is superficially straightforward but I'd recommend getting some information on the underlying mathematics (unless you like figuring that out yourself, in which case, do. It's not hard, but it may be tedious). Some mechanics are pretty opaque, like your water/food/power needs. You get nifty bars with a green marker in them that indicates your needs versus your total stores of these necessities. Sadly, the marker has no relation to your actual production so it's mostly a half-arsed guess if you're producing enough to stay above the green line. Dipping below it is basically bad, you get punished immediately, even if you have enough production to keep your levels stable.

What actually bugs me about the game though and why I'm not recommending it, is that it's a game that rewards you for not playing. If you save and shut down your vault, the vault on the next load progresses 3 more minutes of in-vault resource handling, at which point the vault officially pauses. But not everything is treated the same.

Production like food, water, power, stimpacks will keep producing until you can claim the next set of products, your vault dwellers will consume for up to 3 minutes worth. Extended duration activities like training timers, crafting timers and wasteland travellers will keep running (protip: don't send an explorer out on Survival mode just before you go to bed unless the dweller's basically immortal). Pregnancies advance, and useless kids become functional adults. Most importantly, negative events do not happen. 

That last bit unfortunately means that it frequently becomes more efficient to shut the game down, than to actually play it. I've ruined my first few vault attempts 'cause I kept the game active, waiting for a quest party to arrive or an explorer to come home, while taking the resources as they were produced. I tried to use the Rush mechanic against temporary deficiencies but early game it is extremely unreliable if not outright disastrous.

So, people need to do their romance thing before they breed? Shut down the game. Travellers need to return to help fill empty rooms? Recall them, and shut down your game. Babies need to drop and children need to grow up? Shut down your game. Basically if nothing requires your immediate attention in the next 30 seconds, just quit. 

Especially on survival mode, if I kept trying to "actively" play, I just kept getting disasters which eventually started killing people because a bunch of women were pregnant and my explorers with extra needed weapons were still coming back. If I'd quit, no disasters would happen, the pregnancy timer would keep running, the explorers would come back, and I'd log in to a vault with more resources, more functional people, and more weapons.

So that's why I'm giving it a "No". It's far from a bad game to play, it's just that it insists on not wanting to be played. "Hey Fallout Shelter, I want to play you and do stuff, that OK? No? Ok, 'No' it is."

The lunchboxes are usually a pain to get, but the special sodas you buy to speed stuff up is actually shockingly plentiful sometimes on quests. [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is a surprisingly good management game. It's a mobile game that is somehow [b]not[/b] pay-to-win or demanding of time. 

The game is a city builder with basic combat mechanics that can be boiled down to rotating units between rooms based on their health and equipment.  You manage 3 resources and can directly intervene through a % risk for a brief boost. With a well-managed vault, you don't need such boosts and the boost isn't tied to any digital currency. After the initial setup phase, the game never demands more than 20 minutes of gameplay in a session. The game can be played very infrequently if you choose to not do exploration missions. 

Combat is all about equipping dwellers with weapons and leveling them through maintaining resource facilities or exploring. Management is basically just done once a day. Exploring is risky but it can be calculated and managed to a non-risk by planning to play the game at certain times. Weapons can be acquired through in-game purchase via loot boxes, but these weapons can be earned fairly, so the game is not pay-to-win. 

The game features a hard mode that blocks re-saves and has permadeath for vault dwellers. Players buying weapons to stop these types of games from failing is likely how Bethesda profits from this game. Hard mode is challenging and fun to invest time into.

The game is a great little time waster...UNTIL IT CORRUPTS YOUR SAVE. 

Pros:
-Easy to play, easy to master: once you figure out the basic mechanics of the game, thats pretty much all there is
-Put in as much time as you want: While the game does reward investing your time into it, it can be just as fun for a more casual player
-FREE!: As in not pay-to-win. You can achieve the same results with a bit of time investment as with spending money in the cash store
-Sense of achievement: It really feels rewarding when you send your first maxed out dweller out into the wastes to explore

CONS:
-Combat: feels very repetitive and tedious; takes way longer than it should, especially at higher levels
-Dead end: you can rapidly run out of things to build in your vault
-Lackluster quests: The quests can quickly begin to feel repetitive; despite attempts at adding flavor, they all pretty much boil down to: "go somewhere, kill everything"
-AT SOME POINT YOU WILL LOOSE YOUR SAVE: If the game crashes for any reason your save file will be  irreparably corrupted, and your only option will be to start a new game.

I had nearly 100 hours into the game, and while I was becoming  bored with it, I could hardly argue considering I paid nothing for it. I only had a couple more achievements left that I was holding out for when my game crashed. I didn't think much of it until I tried to reload my save, only to have the game crash again. After a few more attempts, I did a quick Google search, to find that I was far from the only person to have this issue. Worse yet: there was no way to fix it. over 90 hours of grinding ended up being for naught. While I could start a new game to get those last few achievements (and frankly this would probably have been easier than continuing my old save) the whole situation left such a bad taste in my mouth that I just want to wash my hands not just of this game, but the franchise as a whole.

This is THE idle game. It has slow pacing by being designed as a phone game, meant to be checked in with once or twice a day, micro-managed if that's your thing. 

As someone who likes stupid, idle games this one's kept me coming back. The monotization is both non-aggressive and surprisingly fair for a mobile game.

Early game things are rather simple and dull, but there is a tangible sense of progression. This is where the desire for the games in game loot boxes is hottest, but you can still earn a few of them a day by just cycling through the really easy to do missions in hopes of getting a legendary weapon/dweller-- something that's nice for the early game

Later game, once you've unlocked all the facilities and have missions on farm, crafting all of the shiny legendary items is easy and the game becomes more of a collectathon vault building game, where even 100$ of the in game lunchboxes won't give you much of substance. Seriously, I have no desire to ever purchase lunchboxes or anything of the type. Once you get three Mr Handies you're safe to just let the game idle, too. 

All together a fun game, if you don't mind how inactive it is. It's why I play it.
While the first 24 hours of the game is fairly entertaining, it seems more like a grind after that, 48 hours later and you're bored shitless. Well, I should say, I am.

Lengthy build up game. Quests are worked in real time. 5h 7h 15h +++ Shorten with Nuka Cola (Prem currency). In addition, there are many negative random effects that quickly wipe out a vault. Raider Death Claws Ray Scorpions are in constant attack. I have a huge base with 180+ residents. there is no real goal anymore. without the bots patrolling each floor and automatically harvesting the room, you would click dead. It's ok to play in between, but otherwise I wouldn't invest any money, in order to get more bots for the floors, you would have to pay something. The boxes you get are equipped with random loot, which is mostly scrapped into senseless junk. It is extremely rare that there is something good in it. Many have written that what you pay for the current vault only counts, yes that is true. If the vault is broken, your money is also broken. ;) Have fun with the game.

This game was originally released as a mobile, and then ported to the computer and console.  This shows up in small ways, where the game seems designed for a different interface than the one you're using.  That being said, I stopped playing on mobile because when my vault got large it was too difficult to try to see what was going on and select individuals on such a small screen...playing on a laptop solves that problem nicely.

Like many games, this one is most fun at the beginning.  As your vault starts to get larger, you have to spend more time managing resources and balancing factors like production vs. questing vs. training time for your dwellers.  It can be monotonous, or it can be challenging, depending on if you enjoy that sort of thing or not.

There are a /lot/ of achievements available for the game, and while you can buy your way out of the most difficult ones, they are all possible to achieve for free.  Just realize that doing so will take hundreds of hours.  If you're enjoying using the game to kill time and you're not in a hurry, that's not a problem.  If you're looking to rack up some quick achievements, though, you probably want to get the beginning ones for this game and then move on to another one.

The true joy of the game is in the references.  This game is fully set in the larger Fallout universe, featuring "legendary dwellers" that are characters in the other games, equipment that you can find and use in the other games, and even featuring a weekly trivia quest that requires you to answer questions about the other games in the series (or else be attacked by raiders).  For a fan of the series, it's a great way to immerse yourself on a regular basis without getting stuck in front of a console for 40 hours straight.  For someone not familiar with the games, it's a nice idle game that might provide a good introduction to the larger Fallout world.

This review is coming from a guy who doesn't know shit about Fallout series and also for someone who has never played management/ colonial sim games before. This game is meant for people who want to get a gist of how management games might turn out for you for free. This game is meant for people who are struggling to pass time. 

There is no story to be told. There is not much grinding to be done. Nothing. All you have to do is keep your "dwellers" (as they call in game) alive from looters and monsters. They just happen to raid your "vault" (your safe bunker) at random intervals. 

Personally I felt some mechanics just don't make sense. For example, if your dweller succumbs to radiation or injuries, he dies. You might think that it's all over. You just have to take what's left of him (like gear, weapons, etc) and arrange for a new dweller in his place. But NO. You can revive him with in game currency which turns out to be incredibly cheap for some reason. It doesn't matter if he is arm less or he's a walking tank. You can revive him for just 100 coins. This is exactly why you don't feel the pressure to keep your dwellers alive. Even if they mow down more than half of your vault, you'll just be like, "Nah, it's all good fam, here's a few 1000 coins, and boom it's like it never happened." It's just impossible to fail at this game. 

At the start of the game, they call you "Overseer". It makes you think that you are in charge of your group of people and every decision you make might result in success or failure of your people. But as you play on, you realise that you're just making use of your people to get the job done. You just use them like tools and machinery for your personal benefit. Even if you screw up, you can get them back. 

You don't have to pay for loot boxes at all. Just send your dwellers on quests or let them wander off into the wasteland, and as they return you'll see that they come back with OP gear and weapons every single time. As I said, there is very little  grinding involved.  

Don't get me wrong. This game was a good experience for me. It helped me pass time a lot. But once you reach a certain threshold, it's just repetitive. I know this game is for free, and you can't expect a whole AAA experience, and that's why I have recommended this game. Probably this game was made by the devs to promote the Fallout series. And they are successful in doing so. They've caught my attention.

You get what you give in this game, in a very positive way. If you choose to make in game purchases (buying Lunchboxes, Pet crates, and bottles).
