If you like tediously working on a base for hours only to have the game go from difficulty 3 to difficulty 10 and destroy everything you created, then this is your game.

Don't play this game or if you do, don't get more than 59 dwellers. After carefully balancing and progressing in this game for 44 hours, little did I know that after building a community of 60+ dwellers (max is 200), base raids go from being a significant nuisance to wiping out your vault. Just look up Deathclaws. Three of these killed about 10 of my dwellers. All dwellers were equipped with guns and clothing, but of course my best gear had been sent out on Quests and into the Wasteland. You can only have 15 Stimpaks and 15 Rads in the game. At this level, you'd need more than that to keep your dwellers alive during a single raid, and need to equip each Quest team with 15 of each as well. After spending around 3000 caps to revive my dwellers, there was a mole rat attack and it wiped out my ailing dwellers (and the remainder of my enthusiasm for this game) where I had no caps and Stimpaks left. The better guns take hours and hours to craft and with raids occurring roughly every 5-10 minutes, well, I wouldn't waste any more time on this game. I assume now in retrospect that you would have to max out at least 10-20 of your dwellers with all SPECIAL stats and best guns and clothing inside the vault before acquiring your 60th dweller - this would take probably double or triple the time that I spent.

These base raids are dumb as well - the moment anything enters a room with dwellers, all dwellers systematically lose health at an alarming rate. It doesn't matter their level, they all have low health and all lose it fast the moment any enemy enters the room. Even if a single enemy is left in the raid, the next room that they enter will eat away at all 6 dwellers' health constantly even without radiation, and they will have less than half of their health left by the time you can send more dwellers to their death in the same room.

I am guessing that other reviewers on average spent less than 40 hours on this game and simply are unaware of what I have mentioned.

Back in 2015, after fans of the Fallout series heart that they would have to wait a couple of months more before they could play Fallout 4 https://store.steampowered.com/app/377160/Fallout_4/, Bethesda offered a solution to ‚Äúease‚Äù the wait.

[h1] A free-to-play fallout game. Oh, dear‚Ä¶[/h1]

Now, it would be unfair of me to say that I, or anyone else, was surprised when Bethesda announced that this would be a free-to-play smartphone game with micro-transactions. I mean, that‚Äôs how mobile games work right, also, ‚ÄúDo you guys not have phones?‚Äù (Blizzard spokesperson, 2018). What did surprise many of us was when this game got ported to consoles and PC (or, rather, Steam). 

[h1] He who shelters us from the atomic wasteland, and to whom we own everything we have, including our lives [/h1] 

In Fallout Shelter you play as an overseer of your very own vault. You use your mouse to move around the vault, click and drag your vault dwellers around, build new rooms and just take care of your vault. It works well, actually. You get a bunch of random vault dwellers, you assign them their roles and you watch them do their thing and improve at it. As they do their stuff, they will make stuff for you and you can use that stuff to make your vault bigger, better and so on. You gather various resources to make your vault function properly and make sure that everyone in it is happy. It sounds quite relaxing, doesn‚Äôt it?

[h1] I thought that I would have fun with this game‚Ä¶ [/h1] 

I was actually glad when this game was announced for PC. I thought that I would have a nice little game to run in the background as I do work and stuff and only check on it, every now and then. That is how these games work too. You play them for a little bit, you turn it off, you do something else and when you come back you check and see how much your vault dwellers have accomplished. 

[h1] ‚Ä¶ but I wasn‚Äôt having much fun because I didn‚Äôt have enough of a certain resource. [/h1] 

Now, as I was playing this game, I noticed that my vault wasn‚Äôt improving all that much. I mean sure, I built a few rooms and I assigned each of my vault dweller something to and that was that. I had to wait, I guess. I kept waiting for a long time for anything to happen. My vault dwellers were improving, sure, but they were improving rather slowly. I thought that something might be wrong with the game. So, I kept turning the game on and off, checking to see if anything was changing, but not much did. However, everything changed when I finished a certain goal got this one resource. A lunch container.

[h1] Don‚Äôt forget to pack a lunch box. If you don‚Äôt have one, Bethesda will be more than happy to sell you a few. Of course, they are completely optional [/h1]

Sure, they are optional, technically, but the amount of cool things I got from one of these lunch boxes put everything I worked hard to achieve as an overseer to shame. I got so much caps, lots of power, a dog companion and even a vault dweller that looked like a God when compared to other vault dwellers.

[h1] Once you open your lunch box, the game gets fun again‚Ä¶ until you finish your lunch [/h1]

So, I played around with the new vault dweller and bought a few new things that I didn‚Äôt even plan on buying until much later (because of all the caps I got from that one lunch box) and was having fun again, but, really soon, I got to that point where everything was running smoothly and I could only wait. My new God vault dweller was out of the Vault trying to find adventures and loot. So, I was back with nothing to do but check on the game every now and then. 

[h1] I thought you might not have had your fill, so I brought you another lunch box. Don‚Äôt forget, you can always buy more from us. Of course, they are completely optional [/h1]

I got another lunch box as a reward for finishing a quest and after opening it, the game suddenly got fun again. I got a bunch of cool stuff, a robot maid and basically, lots of cool things I could never even dream of getting when I was just, you know, playing the game. That‚Äôs when I decided to stop.

[h1] Fallout Shelter just wants you to have lunch [/h1]

This game only ever seems to be fun after you open one of its lootboxes. Otherwise, it‚Äôs just a boring grind/waiting festival. Normally, when I play free-to-play games they at least let me have some sort of fun with the promise of more if I fork over some cash, but not Fallout Shelter. Fallout Shelter basically says: If you want to have any sort of fun, you have to pay but don‚Äôt think that that one time purchase will last forever. 

The sad thing is, I can really see how this game would have worked if Bethesda made it so you could actually make more progress without opening lunch boxes. To make any sort of progress in this game, you have to wait for a very very very long time. Too long for most of us. 

[h1] Sure, other mobile games do this too, but not many of them do it so soon [/h1]

I‚Äôm not going to say that this is the worst free-to-play game out there, because it isn‚Äôt. There are much worse games (probably) out there but that isn‚Äôt saying a lot. Point is, if a free game tells me that the only way I can have any sort of fun in it is to buy things, I will, respectfully, find another game. Fallout Shelters thinks that just because it has ‚ÄúFallout‚Äù in it, people will forgive all of its intentional grindy mechanics and pay up so they can have little bits of fun.

[h1] There are much better free-to-play games out there [/h1]

Honestly, I know my review isn‚Äôt all that great and detailed but I think I can safely say that, unless you are willing to spend some money OR are willing to wait an excruciatingly long amount of time, you won‚Äôt find anything fun to do in Fallout Shelters. 

Next game: Fallout New Vegas

Fallout Shelter is a great Fallout spinoff that I can play for hours!

"Fallout Shelter" is and always has been a cheap way for Bethesda to make more money off of those who can't control their wallets and get way too invested in a game built to eat up your money much better than any game with a static price can.

Although my Steam time relays that I have only played a few minutes of this game, I played this game back when it came out on a different platform, therefore this isn't an accurate assessment of my time with the game. It was more like I spent hours wasted on this title back at its first release and am back to relay how detrimental these titles are for the masses. Although it isn't any news that these cheap "free-to-play" experiences are predatory and disguise their tired gameplay loops and grinding with flashy rewards, they really amount to nothing in the end. With these sorts of games, your only objective is progress forward. Of course, this is the goal of all games, and really, all media that wants to give you your money's worth, but "Fallout Shelter" is a continuous money investment if you have problems with controlling how much you spend. 

Even if you are patient and wait for everything to progress naturally, you are going to be in for a long and tedious experience that only rewards you with flashy animations and a sense of accomplishment that, at the end of the day, are gone and forgotten. There is no true sense of accomplishment or complex thinking that goes into how you manage your vault in this game, especially if you invest money into it. Here, you see a real lack in the gameplay department, with little exploration or wonder, no true puzzles or problem solving beyond simple resource management, and nothing besides a bigger vault filled with one-dimensional vault denizens that only exist for your profit to show for time invested. Along with no story elements at all accompanying such a lackluster gaming experience, little value is attributed to this "free-to-play" cash cow that took little to make but takes a lot from the invested consumer.

I could say plenty about how much of a disgusting business practice this is, and to an extent, I did, but I have talked plenty about how gross such practices are in previous "free-to-play" reviews, therefore I will not go into detail just how unhealthy and predatory these types of games are, but if you are interested, check out my reviews for "AdVenture Capitalist" and "Soda Dungeon", they highlight exactly why I despise developers who allow themselves to abuse the consumer in such manipulative ways. "Fallout Shelter" may look pretty for one of these types of titles, but it is just as bad, if not, worse than its peers due to the sheer popularity of the "Fallout" franchise and offensive abuse of the fan's strong feelings for an understandably nostalgic series.

[RATING: 1.9/10]

Once upon a midnight levy while I camped there prone and ready,
Over many a quaint and curious streak of performance poor,
While I aimed, clearly tracking, suddenly there came a tapping,
As of some one here attacking, then dispatched by my placed Claymore.
`'Tis some noob,' I muttered, `exploding into bits of gore
Only this, and nothing more.'

Ah, distinctly I remember it was in the village tower,
And each separate dying player wrought his corpse upon the floor.
Eagerly I wished for ammo; - vainly I had brought the crossbow
From my misses bursts of sorrow - sorrow for the lost streak scores
For the rare and radiant rifle whom the gunsmiths forged from iron ore
Bulletless here for evermore.

And the thundering certain noise of each fired shot
Strained me - enraged me with fantastic envy never felt before;
So that now, to match the contents of my clip I stopped shooting
`'Tis some noob below on the ground floor -
A new player and not hardcore; -
This it is, and nothing more,'

Presently my angst grew stronger; hesitating then no longer,
`Sir,' said I, `or Madam, truly your forgiveness I implore;
But the fact is I am camping, and so rudely you came attacking,
And so carelessly you came backing, backing into my planted claymore,
That doubtless was I that I heard you' - here I backtracked to the source; -
Dog tag there, and nothing more.

Deep into that hallway peering, long I stood there wondering, cheering,
Grinning, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;
But the silence was broken, and here appeared a notification,
and the words spoken of kill confirmed, the points added to my score
Thus I pondered, and a gunshot pulled my mind back to the war
Merely this and nothing more.

Back into the tower camping, hand on mouse is damping,
Soon again I heard a tapping somewhat louder than before.
`Surely,' said I, `surely I should have taken scavenger pro;
Let me see then, what thereat is, and this enemy - my knife will soon gore
Let my heart be still a moment and as I crawl out on the floor; -
'Tis a drone and nothing more!'

Over there I flung the flashbang, when, follow'd the blind and ear rang,
In there stepped the soldier of the same username before.
Not the least obeisance made he; not a minute stopped or stayed he;
But, with mien of lord or lady, ran hastily to the second floor -
Proned upon my old position just around the tower door
Proned, and aimed, and nothing more.

Then this new player beguiling my sad fancy into smiling,
By the lack of awareness that he bore,
`Though thy gun is new and loaded, thou,' I said, `soon you shall be exploded.
Consequence of so carelessly barging to that second floor
Tell me why thy thought to camp prior to thou explored!
Cursed the player, which I ignore

Much I thankful this player to bring me a gun so plainly,
Though its attachments little synergy - little relevancy bore;
For we cannot help agreeing that no competent virtual soldier
Ever yet would refuse a firearm delivered to his front door
Though the munition in the chamber could have numbered more
Tis was a blessing, I implore

Excellent for the one handed

I recently spawned a small human, and have found myself sitting at my PC for hours with one hand available and the other attempting to rock an angry gremlin. One hand is useful for a wide variety of things - but most games seem to be rather bias in favour of two. In short, I've been playing a lot of Fallout Shelter this month because I can do it with a single mouse click. Since I've managed to rack up 60 sleep deprived hours on the game, I figured I'd write a review. I'll make it brief, do you know how slow it is to type with one hand?!

Pros:
Only requires one hand.
Free to play that doesn't require you to spend money to build an awesome vault.
Very extensive amount of gameplay, way more than were on mobile on release.
Quests have interesting and amusing lore / dialogue.
Very polished, everything is well implemented and balanced.
Addictive.

Cons:
You'll lose a great deal of time.
You can give your vault a significant boost with spending money - but you don't need to.
Extreme micromanagement might get boring fast for some.
Addictive.

That's all I'm gonna say - you don't need a breakdown of what it is and how to play it. If you're bored and have plenty of free time, enjoy micromanaging and want to save the lives of gingers from a cult in a quest, this is the game for you.

This is a gateway game showcasing the gist of the franchise, teaching you to manage resources and to be a good overseer. The game is entertaining early on but after a while, it becomes monotonous. It has no long term appeal due to the nature of the game. It is moderate on the difficulty scale if you're hunting for achievements. It took me about 96 hours to complete the game and I did make a guide for this.
 
Achievements take a lot of time and need some calculated grinding. The 'Get Off My Lawn' achievement was particularly hard for me and well, I paid my way out of the 'Blast From The Past' achievement. 

I do play this game on iOS and yes, it does kill time, but on the PC, it's just about right for someone who just started gaming and/or who has come across this franchise. The game could have been much better for the PC in terms of design. The controller could have been integrated in a better way.


Regards.

Fallout shelter was originally a mobile game where you create your own vault and populate it with dwellers to perform different tasks like generate power, grow food and other tasks to keep your vault running. It has all the makings of a standard app game where you perform a few tasks then exit the app and return to it a few hours later to collect resources and check on how things are going. Your vault unlocks different rooms based on the number of dwellers you have, and you use the Fallout universe currency of bottlecaps to purchaser things. There are no premium currencies like in other mobile games but there are loot boxes and items to speed up tasks to be done immediately.
You can also send your dwellers on quests, however most of the quests involve exploring a building which is your dwellers going room to room fighting enemies. The combat is done automatically with almost no interaction from the player other than using healing items and performing ‚Äúcritical hits‚Äù which is a one-click event. This game is mostly about waiting for events to happen and checking in every few hours like most mobile games of the same genera. While the Fallout spin is fun at first it quickly becomes repetitive and feels more like a chore than a game.
Good game, considering a second play through which is rare. Worth your time for sure.

The game requires grinding away at tasks for hours to earn coin so the next room can be made. This would not be too bad, but the "micro transactions" offered to speed things up are silly. Is $5 - $20 considered "micro"? Who buys dollars worth of fake stuff in a free game? There are downloadable save game files loaded with coins, crates, bottles, boxes, coins...etc. Just load one into the game, and POOF! You've saved $500 in micro transactions. But you'll still grind trying to  recruit another vault dweller before the next room is unlocked.

I checked the game out on PC as it was recently released in Tesla cars. The Tesla version is actually superior as the "micro transactions" are removed, and the game runs a little quicker (i.e. giving two rewards instead of one).

I can see the addictive nature of the game with rewards, rare items, upgrades, pets, cards, missions...etc. But don't be dumb. Buying anything in this game is worse than buying lottery tickets. Buy a Tesla instead, play the game without micro transactions.

Even tho I'm a little late to the party with this review. There are a few things that might help this game if the developers still care.

Rearranging rooms tool. Yes, this might seem unrealistic in the world of fallout but organizing rooms by shifting them around instantly (even a small fee) saves time and money with players who care more with the Aesthetics of their vault.

Upgrade the vault doors. I would honestly love it if you could put more at the entrance, wether that be turrets, Assaultron, Eyebots, animals or more guards spots outside I would very much accept that in this game.

Expand the universe with this game. Y'all did a great job with exploration, but what if you can raid other settlements?
play with friends? Send a fake settler to another vault? Steal their secrets? sabotage their base before either paying off raider (which would be expensive). Have an investigator to help out who the spy is to battle this.

Animal Shelter. I want more animals in this game but it seems rare or even impossible to get any since playing this game. Make it fun as well by using Breeding stats like Pokemon.
You can even make it funny by cross-contaminating species, with fallout's mutation possibility, it not that far fetch to do so.

Lastly, just do...more. In this sense I mean is do a Halloween month theme or Christmas theme, do updates with the community. it has been a couple of years since I last booted this game up and honestly, nothing has changed. Its the same ok idle game that has the potential to be more.

Would I recommend this game? hmmm, it depends. Short term play? Yes, do too how much I do like the style and somewhat lacking game play that makes me check up on my peeps. long term play? no not really.

Thought I'd give this game a go since it's free and I am definitely impressed considering this is free to play.

The game itself is extremely slow paced, it seems like more of a mobile game than your typical fallout game but again - it's free so it makes sense that it's not totally action packed. I am finding it pretty addicting to purchase lunch boxes so if you're playing on a budget, it's a good idea to refrain from purchasing any. It is completely possible to play without spending any money, it's just super slow. I recommend grinding out the objectives as quick and as often as you can to get rewards which will help you progress. You will get a rush of new dwellers which will slow to a complete stop, so try to start the process of procreating as early as possible. Other than that, I personally love the aesthetics of the  game and am so far thoroughly enjoying getting a little fallout fix.

If you're interested in something super chill that you don't have to completely pay attention to, I do highly recommend this game. Even if you want something to grind, I would still recommend this but just keep in mind that it is a slow grind and there isn't really anything to do while you're waiting except read over the tips etc. Hope this helps! Remember it's free to download so there's no harm in trying :)

An interesting resource management game centered around the Fallout universe.  It‚Äôs fun, and there is a learning curve, but is well done for the most part.  It‚Äôs built around providing food, water and energy to your colony inside your Vault, and assigning the right workers to the right task.  It‚Äôs good for 20-30 hours but then the repetition sets in.  It‚Äôs free, so there is some in game monetization, but it can be completely ignored even if it is a bit obnoxious.  I‚Äôm a Fallout fan so I really enjoyed it as there is lots of fan service...give it a try.

Fallout Shelter, TL;DR: Cute, low-effort, yet polished - great as a "background" game or for those new to colony sims.
FS is a lighthearted colony simulator with the kind of point-and-click simplicity that makes it a great game to kill time to or keep running in the background. It's gamplay feels much more relaxed than others of its kind, with just enough unpredictability and alternate play modes (occasional point-and-click quests and combat) that break up the main focus, which is resource management/building. It's no Rimworld or Dwarf Fortress, in terms of complexity or learning curve, and it's easy enough to catch on to quickly I'd imagine even kids could play this. (Just be warned your kid will become very familiar with novelty firearms after playing this.)
At best, it's polished, cute, and intuitive. At worst, it's nothing truly remarkable, and colony/resource management vets will likely get quickly bored by the limitations and slow pace. 
3.75/5

It is one of the best games you can play on your mobile phone, but on PC you have better options.

Even now, considering the age of the game, i find it hard to judge how i feel about it (so i'm unsure if this review is helpfull).
On the one hand its rather fun to kill time with, you can easily get to the end game without spending money on it, and still fits rather well into the fallout universe imho.
On the other hand, the monetization really becomes a burden the further you progress, and i found myself spending more time not playing then actually playing the further i got into it. Mostly because of the time required to get any where later on, witch in turn is inline with mobile game design tbh, on PC its a burden imo though.

Survival mode is a bit of a mixed bag i found, i do enjoy the extra challenge though, it does feel like this mode really shines on a mobile device not so much on PC. It's not impossible on PC either, but its not something to leave running on the side, keep your play sessions short (as you would on a mobile phone during a work or school brake for example) and gtfo when things get stale.

Overall i do still like it, sadly most my time played is on the Bethesda platform, so my steam profile does not really reflect that.
Despite its flaws, imho if this type of game is your thing, its not a bad addition to your Library.

The mechanics of the game are not too bad for a free to play game. But this is a mobile port to its fault. Basically the "features" that would be considered necessary for a mobile port in this PC version makes it very difficult to play the game. Mostly this has to do with mouse tracking. I can't count the number of times I have wanted to select a settler only to have the game level him up instead. And considering that you benefit quite a lot from waiting to level up until you have equipped an endurance boosting piece of clothing this is [i]really[/i] annoying. You would think that having pinpoint mouse precision in a PC port would be a given. But no, not in this POS lazy port. Furthermore I have even tried to have it corrupt a save game when at a point the game crashed and when I tried to reload the game it just crashed again every time. Considering the time requirement to get anywhere (without paying out that is) that is a large amount of time going to waste basically because Bethesda don't do quality control.

Moderately fun game, with flaws that make it less enjoyable.

Considering how much of your work is sim-management, the UI for that is unpolished.  The Gear menu helps you find a dweller who excels in a particular skill, but you can't drag them from there or use that list to directly reassign them to the room you want.  The list would also benefit from the ability to sort it by trait.

The game doesn't scale up well to large displays.  Instead of showing more rooms and area, everything just becomes bigger.  You can zoom out, but maximizing the window doesn't stretch it to your screen.  It insists on keeping the original aspect ratio, even though there's no good reason.

Assigning dwellers to fight off raiders is confusing; sometimes they remember which room they originally came from and return to it after the fight, other times they think they've been reassigned to the new room.

Clicking outside a menu is inconsistent.  Sometimes it cancels the menu and selects the thing you want, other times it just cancels the menu.  Like when the clipboard is up and you click on a different room - here it would be nice if it selected the new room and kept the clipboard up for it.

The game would benefit from some quality-of-life tuning of the UI.

In terms of gameplay, pacing is off.  There are short periods where you're overwhelmed, and other long, boring periods where you're waiting for supplies to be generated.  A knob to speed up or slow down the passage of time would be welcome.  Maybe at the same time the devs could fix the cheap exploit which allows you to cheat the game by changing your system clock.

Another exploitable bug that should be fixed: Wearing clothing that grants an endurance boost apparently increases the amount of additional health capacity a dweller gets when leveling up.

Micropurchase pricing is WAY off.  Maybe if they had some options for ~30 cents I'd be interested.  You can play this game without spending any money at all, it just means more waiting around.

An apocalyptic fantasy about what it is like for the ultra wealthy to shelter in place with their best friends.

(Stubborn fans - do not read this, go do something useful in your life)

What the game IS NOT about (considering the user-defined tags):
- it's NOT free-to-play, it's pay-to-win - there is no way to gather legendary dwellers other by buying boxes or waiting for months (literally) for a quest
- it's NOT not survival for anyone who ever played survival games, the only "survival" element there is keeping food/water indicator high for the whole vault - which is easy as
- is NOT base building, it has nothing with building or bases. You do not have much variability around

What the game IS about:
- clicking to place a "room"
- clicking to assign a dweller to it
- clicking on EACH room to gather resource from it
- clicking on EACH dweller to level up 
- clicking on EACH dweller to grow a skill
- clicking on EACH item you want to "sell"
- waiting for HOURS (literally) to go on a "quest" (on which you do nothing but more clicking)
- waiting for HOURS (literally) to craft a thing
- waiting for HOURS (literally) to train a dweller
- not waiting but PAYING REAL MONEY to get the above instantly - and then to make even more clicks!
- not getting all achievements because the only reliable way to get legendary dwellers is to PAY REAL MONEY

In fact this game is nothing but a PAY-TO-WIN CLICKER with a nice look (which I do admit). Still, I don't understand whom the game is intended for:
* For a Fallout fan, the game is waaaay too far from everything they love about the series
* For a clicker fan, the game is waaaay too complex

Huge disappointment, you did it Bethesda, finally ruined the franchise this time.

This game can be fun despite having no relation to reality. After a nuclear war you can still construct huge underground structures because reasons. Power is made in a room with no inputs. Food is grown in a 50s dinner with no inputs. When raiders attack, they punch through your foot thick steel door with rusty swords to steal your electricity. The 1950s sexism makes itself felt too, because as soon as anyone becomes pregnant they lose all nerve and run screaming from any and all emergencies. 

If you can put up with all that though, the gameplay is fun and involving, like a digital dollhouse anyone can learn to enjoy.

Fallout shelter is a free to play game for mobile players. This game will not be addicting at all, and you will get bored quickly.
Pros:
Variety in citizens, armour, and weaponry.
Overseers quests give you a reason to play more.
Interesting dialogue between the characters.
cool system of how you decided to handle things, with power, water, and food.
Cons:
Boring after 5 - 10 hours
You can take advantage of the game mechanic of charisma to create mass farms of pregnant women. Then overnight you will literally have just gained dozens of dwellers.
Nothing to do but wait for everyone
Room variety may be cool, but no one will last that long
Sending people out overnight without 20 stimpacks and 20 rad aways will kill them
quests are boring after your first mission
Odds of failing in a rush are much bigger than said

All in all, 4/10 game. You can sink a few hours in, then you will forget this game and move on. Free to play, so I don't know what I expected. But I know plenty of amazing free games. (SCP: Secret Labatory, Warframe, Crusader Kings, Conqueror's Blade.) Just boring, I mean you can consider this fallout clash of clans. But with less to do and worse artwork.

I really did give this game a chance, I really did try. But it stresses you out on things that do not get you any progress, and then has you wait for hours and hours for things that matter. For example, you send some of your people out to explore, they will only reach their destination in 12 hours. UNLESS of course you pay real money! And when the mission is over, they take another 9 hours to RETURN! UNLESS you - again - pay real money.

If you do not want to toss tons of bucks at the game, you will be stuck waiting a SHIT ton. A frustrating heck ton. Tagging this game as "Free to Play" is almost a scam at this point. It's "Free to possess" but "Pay to enjoy".

Aside from this, the game is really annoying to play, the hitboxes of most things are really tedious, overlap and are too small. The game often zooms you in all the way instead of clicking and responding with the thing you want. Made me feel very uncomfortable way too often.

I played this game a few years ago when it was newer.  Sim city with guns and the trademark Fallout look and feel.  Never liked Sim City much myself but did play it for two days, before squeezing out all the strategic challenge (there is very little).  Similarly Fallout Shelter was fun but limited in strategic interest.  Still, I played it a lot for a couple weeks.  Great value for my lack of money!  But once you learned how to run the vault there was never any real challenge, just the constant accumulation of more stuff.  And then beyond a point there was not even that much new stuff.  So what to do?  This dynamic is pretty much unchanged, but's it fun to revisit.

What has changed is the addition of "Quests", which are missions you can send a small group of three of your dwellers on out in the wastelands.  They play out in locations obviously adapted from the vault, so side-view of a plane of rooms, connected by doors and elevators (which all work).  Your guys enter these locations and move from room to room, where monsters may be, and if so, they fight.  Then you  click on sparkling things and get rewards -- guns, suits, junk, caps, etc.

Quests are a lot more interesting then just sending dwellers out to the wasteland, because you get to see what they are doing, and have a slightly higher level of control and hence some (but not very much) more strategic decisionmaking.  Pretty cool!

The other big addition since I played it years ago is a pay-to-speedup-game feature called Nuko Cola.  You get a few of these as rewards in game, and can buy as many as you want using real money.  Each one speeds over 2 hours of some wait, for example the wait to train dwellers in training rooms.  I didn't use them at all so can't comment, but if you enjoyed this game a lot except the waiting and you're rich, maybe you'll want to re-try it.

All in all well worth the $0 I spent on it!

Pros-

#1.Good graphics

#2.Can feel rewarding when you get anything new

#3.It is FREE

#4.If you like Fallout it is worth checking out


Cons-

#1.Waiting is sooo boring

They did this on purpose hoping we would pay real money for it but allegedly there is 2 ways around that.

I have not tried either way and am not suggesting you do but some claim this is how to get more enjoyment without paying.I dont want to pay for it and I dont want to cheat either but to play it normally the waiting time is too long that I would rather play the sims or something else.

A.The first way is to change the clock time of your pc

B.The second way is  type ' fsse fallout shelter ' on google search to learn how to edit it/cheat

As I said I did not try either but with how it is designed my only 3 options are to pay,cheat or not play it anymore and sadly I am picking the last one

#2.The dwellers do not have enough personality compared to say the sims


The bottom line-

Even people who claim to have paid real money say it is not worth it as sooner or later something bad will happen and kill all your dwellers.

I looked up the cheat and that looks way too easy if you can edit it to anything.If I had already beat it than that could be fun but to me just speeding up the default waiting times is all I wanted.I dont know if the cheat offered that or the changing your pc clock would do it?

Leave me a comment bellow and explain it please.

However i cant really recommend it since its kind of boring and one of these games who try to trick you into spending money on worthless things to speed up how fast you gain new stuff or travel from a-b.

The graphics are really good and its kind of interesting to build your own vault.
But there are only like guess 15 different rooms to build that you can upgrade and merge together.
here you people work and produce energy/food/water and later on guns/clothing ect.
Now and then you are hit with random events such as a fire, or raiders breaking though your vault door in seconds and hten run and gun every room until they are dead or you are dead.
Dont worry they are really easy to defeat.

You can also send people out of the vault for exploration and bring back money or random stuff you do unfortunatly only see a text overview of what they are doing and encounter.
However once you build an overseer office you can go on real quests and example explore fatorys and find loot.
But its pretty boring, you typical meet the same enemy in almost every room. Example i raided a factory in a quest and it had only small rats comming out of the ground in every single room...  that was annoying. ;-(
After you kill the rats you can collect money and look and run home.
Your new stuff can be sold, used on your people or crafted into other things.

Well all in all pretty game, but its boring to play, and you just sit there waiting 5-10 min to get more food/water/energy.

Addicting game, based on the Follout world, but plagued with poor implementation issues:
- Incident statistics is totally off. If you model the chance of incident as a random event, you will figure out immediately that the people, who was responsible for that feature, got a F in their statistics class.
- Object interaction is flawed and imprecise - people feel very sticky when you have a well developed and populated bunker, that every time you try to scroll, you actually get a dweller dragged around. Drop in over another room, and dwellers in start swapping their positions. Not all mouse clicks are correctly registered accurately, and that depends on the projection, e.g. your current point of view. In addition, mouse position offset is confusing and requires weird position when you want to place a dweller in a room, oftentimes resulting in placing the former at the incorrect one.
- Not everything from the game mechanics is obvious. Hints may reveal how some things work, others are a total history. You cannot see how much HP a dweller has. 
- Lack of balance of incidents/enemies, and it is difficult to understand what makes them stronger, e.g. if you have a single dweller with very high level, and that determines how difficult the game becomes, there are cases where a single incident way wipe your bunker off. Say goodbye to long playing hours and money spent on that bunker, unless you spend more real money to buy caps and revive your fallen dwellers, but you will have a hard time getting the bunker back in balance.

All in all, the game is pretty nice in the early hours of gameplay. The more you expand, the more obvious it becomes to see how many things are messed up. As this game comes with the standard microtransaction model, the idea might be that Bathesda makes a quick buck, then gently makes you walk away. 

The game has been available also for mobile devices for several years now, and it's a shame that all these nasty issues have never been addressed.

#79 Fallout Shelter

Let me start by saying its not a bad game.  Its actually kind of fun, using a lot of different elements together to craft an addictive game.  So why don't i recommend it.  Lets start with the obvious.  Its a mobile port, and it brings with it all the annoying mobile port schemes.  In-app purchases, daily log-ins, real time time advancement, and the slog/grind of not buying anything to advance.  The worst of the worst is the slog of a free to play game.  If you don't buy any of the in-app add-ons everything takes forever.  Example: (this also goes for the real time advancement) A typical mission requires three vault keepers, but it takes them anywhere from 1 hour to 20 hours to get to their mission location, again real time.  But a Quantum Cola can  get you there now for the price of 1-7 colas.  Now if you don't buy them in the store, you might find one or two on the second or third leg of a mission, otherwise you have to wait for them to get there.  You can't go on a mission until you have a control room, and you can't get a control room until you have a certain amount of population and caps.  Crafting is the same way, it takes 2 days and 4 hours to craft a theme for a room, and anywhere from 4 hours to 12 hours to craft a weapon or outfit, these need junk, which you can only get on missions or by having a peep explore the wasteland.  Now you do get lunchboxes with cards  in them which can provide various boosts, like a pet, or a handy helper, sometimes a rare dweller or weapon, but those dry up pretty quick and average about 1 box for 10-15 tasks completed.  So its log in and play a few minutes, save and exit, rinse and repeat.  For a mobile game, where most are played in 5-15 minute intervals this fine, but for a pc ported game, this is annoying.  

So its a naw from dawg.

Astoundingly free to play, Fallout Shelter really grabs you out of the gate and makes you want to simultaneously buy and play all the Fallout AAA's (Except 76) and buy things on the Shelter Store. I don't, but I do have a desire to. Which is a first for passive management games I've tried.
It will remind you in minor ways of a super-simplified Terreria-Sims hybrid, where you both lose detailed control of your characters and don't want to murder your people. While you cannot walk away and leave your Vault to do its thing without passively killing everyone, you can leave the game and come back later to very few problems.
If you don't have to have massive environmental design control, and have something else to do while you have timers ticking, save that Sims money and try this out.
*Note: Terreria is still legendary.

Pros:
Small package that can sit on your SSD even if not played.
Free if you don't buy gameplay accelerators.
Seems to run on Potatoes (May need to be baked though).
Enough variety to keep you intrigued.
Fairly good tips and tutorial.
Active timeline that keeps working after you logoff.
You can do other things while you let it farm (While in proximity). ie. Read a book; Learn spanish.
Simple but pretty graphics.
Humorous Innuendos + Non-Graphic Violence.
Full Controller or KB/MS support.

Cons:
No multiplayer or similar connectivity, so no trading with friends.
No included timeline acceleration (they make you buy Nuka-Cola for that).
Quests can sometimes be way under level, but still destroy a well equipped party.
Some stats and pet bonuses are not explained (How does that stat help me?).
No time scheduling for explorers (no auto-return unless they have full inventory, you have to logon to keep them from dying in the wasteland).
Auto-Save only (you can't save progression to a slot, and then reload if all your people die).
Once your start down a big disaster hill, the only way to recover is to clear out a mess of things and start from scratch if you want to keep your inventory.

Unfortunately, the bigger your vault grows, the more this thoughtful balancing act fades away. Fallout Shelter gets easier the bigger your vault is - not harder. It feels backwards. My 150+ population vault has more than 25 people with no job at all, just wandering the floors. I no longer need to optimize my factories, because I have an excess of all resources. My citizens want for nothing, and I have no more buildings to unlock or goals to work towards. I can expand my vault deeper and build a sixth Power Plant or third food-producing Garden, but that would just give me an even bigger resource surplus. Have I won? Is this it?

Fallout Shelter is desperately in need of a set of endgame goals or resource sinks to look forward to and build towards, or else players will see all the game has to show us in around a week of steady play.

This game can be really fun. It's enjoyable, calming, and it makes you think. The one thing that reaaally gets me peeved however and my whole reasoning for writing this review is how literal merciless this game can be. I used to be play this game a lot about a year or two ago.
 Why did I stop? All of my dwellers died.
 How?
 Well they were attacked, and attacked, and attacked, over and over again until there was absolutely no reason for me to continue playing the game. At my weakest, I was constantly being attacked until everyone died. I'd used all my money to revive the ones that died only for them to die again. I was left with no dwellers nor any money.
And well, many months later it's happened again. I thought it may have just been bad luck or timing on my part but no. It seems to be programmed to literally kick you at your lowest moment until you've lost any and all motivation to play the game. It's not a the more you play the harder the game situation. My previous vault I can't say I was too far or prosperous at the time of it's falling. 
This time I was simply running a bit low on power and medicine and well, now everyone is once again dead- killed by mutant rats! How lovely. Three back to back rounds until no one was left.
If your looking to chill and have fun but also want a bit of a challenge I recommend this game. Though be prepared to become completely devastated as you watch all your hard work quickly diminish into nothing but three dwellers and 5 coins.

This game is fun to play but needs work.  It's awkward to play.  I'm playing it on a PC but also played it on the PS4.  Here are some of the issues I have with this game:

1.  When the alarm begins to sound, the camera automatically pans and zooms to the affected area.  There's no setting to disable it.

2.  While the alarm is active, Dwellers cannot be put outside to explore and cannot be assigned to work.  I'm forced to wait until the incident is over to do that.  The game needs to make left clicks do that regardless of alarm state, and make right clicks move Dwellers temporarily to help during emergencies.

3.  Mr. Handy is useless to me.  It only patrols one floor and it can't collect the icons when Dweller level up or training is complete.  There is no option to set waypoints or let us assign it to more than one floor.

4.  Some outfits are gender-specific.

5.  Electricity, water and food require harvesting (stupid). 

The only aspect of the game I actually like is the exploring.  When I send dwellers into the Wasteland, they level up without my needing to manage their every step.

A vault simulator, this game is not.

This game is not a instant satisfaction game  every action takes time to do. Produce power/food/water/equipment takes anywhere from 1 min to 3 hrs or more so it may take some time getting used to. Its a sit back watch your vault and manage resource survival game =).

I like this game, which is why it annoys me so much that I have to write this. I got to the endgame in Shelter -- cleared most of the quests, got to the last floors I could build to, crammed as many people as could fit into the building -- and then, one day, with no warning, [i] my save data disappeared. [/i]

I was shocked and upset, as one tends to be in these sorts of situations. I checked the cloud save for my files -- nothing. I checked the steam file folders -- nada. I went deep diving in the AppData files and other such folders game devs squirrel saves into -- zilch. So, perplexed, I went to google.

From what I could gather, this is a problem that's been around since its initial Steam release. Sometimes the data will just cease to be for no reason. I have yet to see any official addressing of the matter by Bethesda or Todd, or any word of fixes. Sometimes renaming Vault1.sav.bkp to Vault1.sav brings back your save, according to a Steam forum post I found; can't confirm, as it didn't work for me. My dwellers are, for all intents and purposes, dead.

Other versions of the game don't seem to have this issue; the app and Switch port seem perfectly happy to go about their day without killing all your little dwellers out of nowhere.

[b] TL:DR -- Sometimes the Steam version will just delete your save out of the blue. If you really want to give micropayments to Bethesda outside of Fallout 76, go for the original app or the Switch version. [/b]

I really like the idea of this game, especially as it's in the Fallout universe. Build your shelter (base) with resource generators for people to work in (who require the resources to survive) all based on their stats, and over time accumulate coins and rewards that you can use to further upgrade your shelter and outfit your people. 

A simple premise, but the game does a great job at it, and the graphics are splendid (the audio, not so much.) You can also send explorers out into the world who will find goods and gear, though you have to pay attention to their health as they will encouter dangers (all played in the background). Recall them and they'll bring their spoils back (gear to make your people tougher).

There is a birth mechanic whereby two of your people may decide they 'like' each other (nudge-nudge) and one ends up pregnant - after some time, a child appears and eventually becomes an adult. In this way, you continue growing your population (which requires more workers for more resource producing rooms for more advanced rooms like training and medical).

There are danger events that will occur in your shelter ranging from an infestation of radiated rat attacks to fires to scavanger assaults. Any people stationed in affected rooms will fight (the rats, fires, assaults, etc.) and this is why better gear for them is useful. In and of itself, an okay idea to liven up what would otherwise be a bit of a mindless idle-state game.

But that's where the problem comes in, as well. Despite everything about the game I really enjoy, here are a few issues that keep me from wanting to really put any more time into it (let alone spend any more real money...)

- The pregnant weapon constantly scream while the emergencies are occurring, and it is annoying AF.
- The screen 'autozooms' to a room with an emergency, and their is no way to disable this. Again, annoying AF.
- While emergencies are happening, resource production is halted in those rooms (but not consumption...) Worse, during scavenger attacks (which are VERY frequent) then all resource production halts even if those rooms are far away from the invaders.
- Finally, despite this being basically an idle-state game, resources DO NOT COLLECT AUTOMATICALLY. If you don't click your water or food rooms when they have "made" their goods, your people will get angry, get sick, and die.
- And what's particularly atrocious (and the primary reason I have stopped playing) is that when you quit the game, while it is offline resources are STILL BEING CONSUMED. So you come back after a few days and all your resources are in the red. If you have positive production, you can eventually get them back up, but this supposes that you don't have emergencies occurring (which you will.)

It's such a great idea for a game, and for a few hours it's a thrill to play and see evolve. But these issues I mentioned are, all combined, too much for me. And that last what... Who the hell programs a game to keep running even while you've shut it down WITHOUT some automated options to keep the gamestate from being ruined when you return? So I cannot recommend. (At least not the Steam version. I've read read the Android version will actually 'stop running' if you close the memory process...)

After 160 Hours of play time, probably 90 Hours just trying to get Legendary Dwellers, I still recommend this game. It's quirky, funny, weird, odd, and so many other words to describe it.

While this game won't be for everyone, it will be very entertaining to some. It's like having your own Vault full of little human ants/super soldiers you are training to progress in the game. Great game to check in on between a busy schedule or in between other games. You can pass anywhere from 5 minutes to an hour+ during each sitting.

The main downfall of this game, is the rate at which Legendary Dwellers are dropped, for those trying to get 100% Achievements. My first month, of 70 Hours, I had 9/20 Legendary Dwellers. 0 the next month, and finally, whoop de doo, my 10th Legendary Dweller the month after.

There are In Game Purchases of A Starter Pack, Bottles, Lunch Boxes, Pets and Mr. Handys. However, Legendary Dwellers only come at a rate of 50-60 Lunch Boxes, which will take you like 1000 Hours, or $100+, which is unjustified.

That being said, this is a great game to check out, but don't bother working towards the Legendary Dweller Achievement, or you'll be saying to yourself, 'Go on Quest. Find Treasure. Repeat.'

One important thing to note before playing: this game is not for the impatient. A lot of fun things to do here - from resources, crafting, to going on quests in the Wasteland - involve waiting for hours and hours, sometimes even for days on end. Whether the experience after all that waiting is worth it is up to the individual player.

I, for one, am not a patient person in general, so I play a modded game, if only to see the growth potential of a vault that I could never see or even notice under normal, unmodded circumstances. I am well aware that I'm cheating my way through the game, but after playing this game on mobile and being frustrated by how much time I have to invest in this game, I figured that playing this game with a mod would be alright.

In any case, it's free to play. I suppose the only thing that can be lost here is one's time, and even that can be controlled by the player by deciding whether or not they should invest their time in this game.

THE. Most. Boring. And. Shallow. Game. Ever! Even. For. Freemium!

Thought it may be a game like "Oxygen Not Included" or "Craft the World" or "This War of Mine"... as it is feels similar designed like them at first glance. But, by far not. While it has some elements, like attributes of the characters (dwellers), they add little to none to the game. 

You are not building in this game. You only PAY caps (money) for placing rooms ready. You are not digging in this game. You only have to PAY caps to remove stones if they are in the way. You are not managing anything in this game. All you can do is, keep pressing RUSH buttons. There are just 2-3 disasters, but you have no control over the disasters or solving them. Just keep watching and hope your dwellers will manage the situation. You are sending dwellers to the Wasteland, but you can't do anything. It's all just a chance game, picking things from a list of events and giving you a log of it. 

And, of course, typical for freemium games, it all takes lots of time, to complete anything. Though, there's not much to complete, all you can do is, wait or keep pushing rush buttons. 

There are literally only 2 resources that truely matter, caps and nuka cokes. And both, can be bought with real money. All the other things in the game like outfits and weapons and pets, are just for collection (even the inventory is created in this way, so you have the feeling you're missing and just hope, you may randomly collect one of the missing ones). You're not using any other resources ever for anything, than just caps (the in-game money currency) to only pay for building rooms and pay for upgrading them. That describes the whole game, actually.

You can't manage shit in this game, and almost everything is just a random chance. Simply. Boring. To death. You're better looking for one of the other mentioned games, as they truely excel. This one feels rather like a money-making experiment, as comparable to similar games, it feels, there has been little effort and work involved in creating this game.

Moreso, the Fallout franchise has been used to get people knowing the franchise interested in it. On itself, if it weren't for the Fallout branding, this game would have had no chance of surviving...

It's a grind-y pay to win game, with all the tedium that comes with that.  The user interface is annoying and frustrating at times.  Some of the disasters, like fires, get tedious and boring very quickly.  Be prepared to discard your first and maybe second vault as you figure out optimal build strategies.

My biggest annoyance is the way it punishes you for shutting the game down for a few hours so you can, like, have a life outside gaming.  Several times now I've come back to the game to find that my power, which was full, and which is generated at DOUBLE the usage, has fallen below the redline.  Then the game decided to shut down one room - my cafeteria.  And by the time I got power above the redline again, food was below the redline.  It's ridiculous and stupid.  Apparently my vault USES power while the game isn't running, but it doesn't PRODUCE any.  Asinine.  The same thing happens during protracted quest runs.

The user interface was designed by drunken monkeys.  It's very frustrating, especially during the all-too-frequent disasters.

Besides that, though, it's an entertaining little sim that that can be played on computer or tablet.  It has a lot of inside humor.  It'll be more fun if you've played other Bethesda games.

I am not recommending this game, not because its a bad game or i don't like it (don't get me wrong), I am simply not recommending this game because one achievement is practically unattainable.  This is meant to be a mini-game (like a phone game).  So to add an achievement that less than 5% of your players have attained, along side of players like myself with more than 100hrs into this game going for that achievement is unreal.  I am left to think that is the one and only "unattainable" achievement which is meant to lead you into just keep playing knowing only 1 in 1 million people are going to be randomly selected to receive it.  Now before you get on the wrong track, receiving this final achievement wouldn't encourage me to quit playing the game.  On the contrary, its a sense of completion and accomplishment to keep you going and feeling good about said game.  So when the last achievement is fixed/re-evaluated, I would totally recommend this game.  I'm just not on board with the misconception that all these achievements are "ACTUALLY" obtainable.  Fix it, so I can fix my review (because i really do like the game).

TL;DR: Passes the time, but highly encourages MTX. 7/10

It's a fun and interesting game to play in passing with unique elements that tie into the Fallout universe. Spending real-world money is highly encouraged to expedite expeditions as well as get better gear quicker, but the game itself is perfectly playable without add-ons. When you don't pay-to-play, you can expect 5+ hour wait times for completing quests and other such things, which isn't awful. All-in-all, this game is much better as a mobile game than a console/PC one, but that's okay.

Edit: As others have said, this game has a tendency to crash every so often (like most Bethesda games), so if you value your progress ***AND ESPECIALLY IF YOU SPEND MONEY ON THIS GAME AS NEITHER STEAM NOR BETHESDA WILL REFUND LOST PURCHASES*** backup your game.

Fun little time waster between other games. Like all mobile games it lacks any real depth and is basically designed to drain your wallet as fast as possible. Thankfully, the game is one of those paradoxical free to play games that is actually more fun when you don't purchase the microtransactions (adding to a sense of challenge and progress that would otherwise be lacking). Spent $5 for the starter pack for a vault, but aside from that no real desire to spend more (just keep 3 groups of your dwellers completing quests at all times and you will get lunchboxes, quantum, etc fast enough).

Also for those who care, the Blast from the Past achievement ... talk about a money pit for that one. Either have to spend $1000 worth of lunchboxes or grind grind grind for 1000 hrs. I highly recommend not going for it or using save edits or something. This achievement is NOT in the console versions so its inclusion here is strange to begin with.

Quest update makes end-game more interesting to play and most importantly, getting Caps, Lunchbox, sometimes Pet as a rare rewards.

Vault is generally fun to manage but comes with some major complains:
1) HP is not retroactive, which means dwellers obtained from lunchboxes are generally useless because their HP stats cannot be maxed well. HP is very very important in late game quests because high level quest's enemies are very deadly, as well as frequent Deathclaw/Radscorpion attack. So if the dwellers are not grown from level 1 with at least 15 Endurance (which is the most efficient way to get by crafting +5 E Sturdy Wasteland Gear and max train Endurance on level 1 dwellers before leveling), the Overseer is gonna have a rough time.
2) Without Mr.Handy, Electric is gonna drain at a heavy rate despite having a lot of generators. But Food and Water aren't.
3) Low tier production rooms are generally useless after unlocking new ones.
4) Lunchboxes rewards does not scale with the progression in Vault. In short, crappy rewards most of the time. Also issue (1). Not recommend to buy via cash.
5) Can't sell specific amount of items, only can sell 1 by 1 or sell all.
6) Overseer have to plan well on room layout, because Dwellers will not go interact incident on an empty room, even they are on same level. Nor there is an option to have emergency/security team (in which according to Fallout Lore, they do have various management team). Vault door only can have 2 dwellers to guard instead of 4, which is not good.

It's as pointlessly addictive as any other city building game, but it has a few things that really make it stand out. The quests you can send your dwellers on are fun; the SPECIAL points have bonus points both inside and outside the vault so you have to choose whether to keep stronger people inside in production, or outside to get better loot. 

There are only so many dialogue options for the random wasteland quests (I've done the 'food critic' quest about 5 times now) but it's still a better minigame than anything in, say, Tribez. 

After a certain point it's hard to save up enough money to do anything worthwhile. It's taken me 3 days to upgrade one room for a measly +3 production. But that only means checking in for a few minutes to either send out or recall explorers, so if you don't care about timing it's great.

I haven't paid any money for extra perks.

Fun little casual resource management game. Not really a game you would play for hours at a time because most things are time-throttled, e.g, a quest that takes 2 realtime days to even reach, making outfits or weapons that take days or even weeks to complete. Lots of irritating "features" like the vault perspective meaning that you accidentally pick up things through walls, the inexplicable decision to make left and right click on the mouse do exactly the same thing, instead of making one for selecting and one for moving the vault view around, Bottle and Cappy invariably turning up in the middle of a vault raid.

Still, it's free, the graphics and sound are cheerful, and the gameplay is simple and easy to learn, so it still gets a thumbs up.

Can't not mention that if you're an OCD completionist, you will be massively disappointed in that they've included a steam achievement which is basically impossible (get 20 legendary vault dwellers) because you can only gain them from loot boxes. The math works out that you would have to open THOUSANDS of them to get it. Bad form, Bethesda. Bad form.

All I can say is that this isn't the best game in the world, but it's not the worst either. I do have a lot of fun playing this but after the first twenty minutes, things kinda come to a crawl, especially if you ran out of caps and you're waiting for a dweller to come back with some good loot or waiting on a room to give out food, power, or water. All in all, this is a game best played in short bursts, not in one sitting. The graphics are great though the game does have some glitches but the glitches doesn't deter my game play at all. And best of all, it's free!

The game starts off as a charming diorama of Vault-Tec life where you manage your dwellers' everyday post-nuclear existence. It is a slick, well-polished simulation that takes advantage of the rich, irradiated world of Fallout. The signature retro art style is there, the lore references are plentiful, and the Vault somewhat comes alive when your dwellers multiply and start to occupy those underground rooms. They dutifully toil away at their jobs, even if their days are extremely shallow and repetitive. But it's a [i]Vault[/i] dammit, and it's [i]yours[/i], and it's [i]teeming[/i] with these artificial lives!

All in all, a harmless, super casual game if you ignore the sparkling tin lunchboxes Bethesda tries to sell you.  

Until 72 hours later, you've gotten inexplicably attached to your simple, mindless citizens and the mechanical yet satisfying tasks of leveling, training, and breeding them, when the game suddenly decides it's over. It bugs out and you are stuck at the loading screen, forever locked away from your babies who are probably wondering why their Overseer has forsaken them. You know there are ways to fix this that involve messing with the save files and whatnot. But sometimes, it's easier to just let go...

... and leave a pointless negative review instead.

I wish there was a 'Neutral' option for reviews, this game would certainly fall in this area for me.
Like many others, I enjoy the Fallout franchise... to an extent. I loved Fallout 1 and 2 back in their hay-day to the point of obsession, so when Fallout 3, New Vegas and Fallout 4 came along I was more than willing to jump head first with no questions asked. 
The same cannot be said for Fallout Shelter I am afraid. This is a glorified mobile game, and although it has been done well, with story-line quests, character bloodlines and key NPC's from the newer Fallout games remodelled into the Pip-Boy format, it is worth remembering that all mobile games are essentially cash-grab.
The same can be said here, with 'lunch boxes' being the loot-box criteria here, alongside the option to purchase bottle-caps with real money. Although this is not game-breaking and yes, you 'can' complete the game without ever spending more than the initial game price tag, this will take far more grinding than the game is worth. For the first 50 levels you should be fine, and the game  is enjoyable. But once you start unlocking the higher tier rooms you will find that caps are very hard to come by, so purchasing them will be another story altogether.
All in all, another cash-grab mobile game, albeit as good one.
TL:DR
Pros -
* Nice little vault builder/time sink
* Good to see NPCs from the Fallout series in Pip-boy models
* Easy to play, looks good, runs smoothly on most devices
* At least it's not 76

Cons
* Cash-grab mobile game from a company that really doesn't need the influx
* Real-time waiting for quests (10+ hour journeys before you even get to start the mission, 5 hours return)
* Nuka-Quantum is the 'diamond resource' which is rare to find, encourages to buy with real money to shorten journey times
* Bottle-caps become difficult to find (2100 caps per small room, for last few builds upgrades cost even more. Lucky to get 20 caps from level-ups or luck bonus)

Yeah, it's Bethesda, a company with a good reputation for quality work.
Yeah, I had a bunch of fun playing this.

My fun was diminished last week when (as I figured out later) I accidentally sold some special items that I wanted to keep, when returning from a quest. At that point, I figured out that Bethesda has zero avenues for solving player problems within the game. They'll help you solve your money problems, and they'll let you submit bug reports they'll never answer directly, but there's no way to say, "Hey, the game glitched. Will you help me fix it?" They're simply not interested, apparently.

My fun evaporated today. There was an objective to kill feral ghouls without weapons. Some feral ghouls invaded the vault, so I unarmed my defenders. In the first room, I had only two defenders. Both died. Okay, fine, they died. I revived them. Repeat, I REVIVED THEM. I gave them RadAway and Stimpaks. I made sure both were in perfect health. Then I moved on to something else. When I went back to that room, rats were there. Zero Dwellers. I looked everywhere within the vault, but they were nowhere to be found.

After spending a fair amount of money on this game, I am EXTREMELY disappointed that: (a) the company has no system to help players when the game glitches, and (b) the game can glitch pretty fucking hard. I will never play it again.

Fallout Shelter is a fairly simple building management game. Gameplay revolves around earning caps to buy facilities to provide life-sustenance (food, water, energy), crafting stations (for better weapons and gear), and training rooms (to improve your dwellers' stats). Caps are earned by leveling up your dwellers, scavenging, and completing missions and milestones. Dwellers level up by simple being assigned to work stations or defeating bad guys (which are found on missions and occasionally in your vault, should there be an attack or infestation). There are rare lootables to be found in the game, as well as crafted. These can be in the form of gear or weapons, but can also be characters which are more powerful than your average slob that shows up on your doorstep. In addition, you can find pets that accentuate abilities on the characters you assign them to. You can also breed within your vault, which always gets an Overseer's thumbs up!

Fallout Shelter is essentially Fallout Extreme Light. It's a mobile style game that does have some real time elements, meaning that traveling to locations can take real time. This time can be sped up by using Nuka Cola (which can be found in the game or purchased with real dollars in the store). Outside of that, the game is completely playable without having to Pay2Win. If you run out of Nuka Colas, you just need to come back to the game later after the travel timer has expired.

Exploring Overseer missions are pretty fun. You get to actually explore the building from a side perspective. Hidden rooms are covered in a fog of war and are randomly generated. So is the loot. This makes the game replayable and always offer some satisfaction for the curious. Ultimately, you want to continue upgrading rooms for the increased vault size and equipping characters with better and better gear.

It's a fun time-killer that I keep coming back to in short visits.

A cute little overseer game.
The first 30 hours of game time are spent building a vault in a post-apocalyptic time, and the experience is awesome. The game is very busy at first, has great little stories, and lots of humour.

After finishing the first phase of the game ,reaching 100 dwellers and having a balanced vault. The game slows down significantly, and you are practically only left with waiting out the long missions wait time, or throwing money at the game to speed them up. Unfortunately the missions themselves aren‚Äôt very exciting. The fighting mechanic is semi-automatic, and isn‚Äôt very comfortable, completing the missions has little to no challenge. And the only thing good about them is the amount of resources they generate, and the funny stories.
The best part of the game is the initial build of the vault. It has meaning full choices, and you can build a perfect vault. 
The worst part is that the game doesn‚Äôt scale well, and when your vault gets too big, the game doesn‚Äôt offer many tools to help make the management of so many dwellers simpler. One example is the battle management, there is no simple way to heal an entire room, or move a big group of dwellers all at once from one room to another.

All in all, the game is defiantly worth playing, if only for the achievement of reaching 100 dwellers, which is probably the most fun I have had in any game I played.

Fallout Shelter puts you in control of a state-of-the-art underground Vault from Vault-Tec. Build the perfect Vault, keep your Dwellers happy, and protect them from the dangers of the Wasteland.

BUILD THE PERFECT VAULT

Create a brighter future‚Ä¶underground! Select from a variety of modern-day rooms to turn an excavation beneath 2,000 feet of bedrock into the very picture of Vault Life.

OVERSEE A THRIVING COMMUNITY
Get to know your Dwellers and lead them to happiness. Find their ideal jobs and watch them flourish. Provide them with outfits, weapons, and training to improve their abilities.

CUSTOMIZE
Turn worthless junk into useful items with Crafting! Customize the look of any dweller in the Barbershop.

PROSPER
A well-run Vault requires a variety of Dwellers with a mix of skills. Build a Radio Room to attract new Dwellers. Or, take an active role in their personal lives; play matchmaker and watch the sparks fly!

EXPLORE THE WASTELAND

Send Dwellers above ground to explore the blasted surface left behind and seek adventure, handy survival loot, or unspeakable death. Find new armor and weapons, gain experience, and earn Caps. But don‚Äôt let them die!

PROTECT YOUR VAULT

From time to time, idyllic Vault life may be disrupted by the dangers of post-nuclear life. Prepare your Dwellers to protect against threats from the outside‚Ä¶and within.

Vault-Tec has provided the tools, but the rest is up to you. What are you waiting for? Get started building your Vault today for FREE.

This game is free and you can, with patience, earn all the achievements without spending anything. The quests are funny and contain many references to the other Fallout games. This game requires you to plan things out (keeping money aside to build new rooms, sending teams out at night so they'll arrive at their destination in the morning, etc.). At times the game requires your whole attention, but I mostly let it run while doing other stuff on my computer, switching back when I heard the sirens or the radio calls.
After a month of playing, I have all the achievements except one (Collect 20 legendary dwellers), and I might not keep playing to get that last one, as I expect it will take [b]months[/b], since you can only get those dwellers in lunch boxes and I don't want to buy any. I would have preferred to find them in quests instead. I also managed to get the same legendary dweller (Preston Garvey) twice, which does not makes sense to me.
Could use a couple of minor updates, but still very fun.

I'm going to present this in as balanced a way as possible.

The game is good fun and it's extremely enjoyable if played in a limited way. After your initial build up do not sit there waiting for stuff to happen, log out and come back later. My current playtime is from short bursts of 5-15min 1-2 times a day which is the best way to enjoy it.

Don't rush thing, don't use cola to speed stuff up and save it for events worth it. Enjoy the experience in short bursts slowly building up. This is not a suitable game for playing for 30+ minutes, everything is just waiting after about 15min. Don't try and play it like that or you're gonna have a bad time and/or waste real money.

It is pay to win, but this is only an issue if you intend to rush the game which ruins the experience in most regards. If you insist on buying stuff wait for sales, you also likely lack inventory space for loot you bought so keep that in mind.

Backup saves, I hear people complaining about losing saves. It hasn't happened to me but that doesn't mean it won't happen to you. There are also Save game cheats, I've heard these can corrupt saves. Just be aware.

I think I like this game because I have been immersed in a MMORPG (Massively Multi-player Online Role Playing Game), and the game "Fallout Shelter" does not, nor would I think could it, translate to an internet-based game.  I also like the apparent immediacy of certain actions that need to be taken in order to progress forward in the game.  Naturally, the character development while leveling up is always a plus.  I would recommend this game to other players.

Pros: The game is fun, family friendly, and free. Micro-transactions are not spammed towards you. This game has a more lighter feel to it. More comedy and no gory stuff. Though I do prefer my gritty fallout series this game allows for a break from that stuff.

Cons: Unfortunatly this has microtransactions. This game revolves around waiting. Waiting to train. Waiting to go to quests. Waiting to come back from quests. Microtransactions allow you to purchase stuff to help progress or pass the waiting times. Don't give into that crap. Bethesda is a money hungry coporation that doesn't give a crap about its player base.....just so long as your giving them money. This game does crash alot or it did for my first 20 hours. Sometimes randomly crashes on start-up. Sometimes randomly crashes mid-game which really shouldn't be happening to a small game like this. But that is likely because Bethesda wants to put little money into this cash cow. For those reasons alone Im giving this a negative review but by all means give this game a try.

[i]War‚Ä¶ war never changes. Unless it‚Äôs Fallout Shelter.[/i]

So I‚Äôve been playing Fallout Shelter for quite a long time and I‚Äôm sure i got everything I could out of this game. 

It was fun. 101% fun playing. Every single quest, every event and the whole idea of it is pure fun. Even the grind I had to deal with makes the game more fascinating. The ‚Äúcartoonish‚Äù and ‚Äúcardboard‚Äù art-style makes it look cute and adorable. It is a humorous family-friendly game which anyone is suitable to play. 

The idea of Fallout Shelter is simple: You start with several dwellers and a Vault to populate. You build new rooms, increase population with newcomers or ‚Äúrelations‚Äù, get resources, make and find some equipment, well‚Ä¶ you expand and progress. [b]NB:[/b] There is no ‚Äúaging‚Äù in FS.

Now, there are two ways you can play Fallout Shelter: On Normal Mode, or when you check the box of ‚ÄúSurvival Mode‚Äù. First one is smoother in a way your dwellers can be revived after they die. The Survival mode is when they cannot be revived plus several other difficulties. The most important thing to know is that there‚Äôs a game mechanic when you send your dwellers to a wasteland to get resources and etc. If you quit the game ‚Äì they are on their own. You can give them some amount of medicine supplies which will slowly go down the count. So you will HAVE to check on your Vault daily to avoid accidents.  And I assure you that it is a disaster if a Legendary Dweller dies. 

200% concentration required. 

VaultTek Recommends: Please avoid playing Survival mode if YOU ARE NOT PREPARED.

So, if you are into sandbox games like myself, then you will find Fallout Shelter a very enjoyable game. It‚Äôs a pity the game is not cross-platform and you can‚Äôt share your PC game progress onto your mobile device and back (Hope someday they will support this).

Fallout Shelter is a management simulation game where you're transported to a world destroyed by nuclear war, your job is to create a thriving population in a ever-growing vault. When I first downloaded this free-to-play game a few months ago I wasn't sure if I'd enjoy it due to the fact the game is real-time so it can take awhile to do things BUT I found that I truly enjoy real-time games such as Fallout Shelter. It's so satisfying to watch your vault go from a tiny unhappy place to a underground paradise. If you enjoy these kind of games I suggest giving Fallout Shelter a try after all it's free so you have nothing to lose. I do have to say it's nothing like Fallout 3 or 4 since it is a spin-off game the only thing they really share is the devastated world they live in.
