Very slow paced game. Actions take hours to perform while you're offline. It's a nice game to log into for a few minutes each day to check on your vault and assign new tasks to your dwellers.

You definitely don't need to purchase anything with real money to progress, and I'd actually advise against spending real money. I think the fun of the game is to slowly build up your vault with the limited resources you earn -- you won't feel that sense of accomplishment if you just buy your way past the early-game. You can still earn the real-money items by completing quests, so it's not a big deal.

I usually play stressful PvP games, so this is a good change of pace for me.

[b] Your game is saved locally in C:\Users\youraccount\AppData\Local\FalloutShelter. If for some reason your Local files are deleted, you will lose your save files and all your progress. Great Game until the higher levels due to inherently bad game balance.  I quit the game after I had one room get infested with mole rats which I coulldn't wipe out fast enough, despite have fully armed dwellers in those rooms, so they multiplied.  At this point You burn thru stimpacks to keep them alive but the dps of these creatures is overwhelming when you have 80 dwellers and your characters they drop like flies.  You then have to revive them to save your vault, which costs caps and soon enough, i burned through 15,000 caps and still I hadn't wiped out the mole rats.

  Now, your vault is littered with level 20 toons, is still infested, your broke so you cant revive them, all your resources start to suffer because you have no one working, and soon the game is done because its a cascading effect.  At lower levels this isnt as much an issue as you can get gear easily enough thats high enough in level to take on challenges to the valut.  

The issue  at higher levels is that better gear is very hard to get, since it takes literally 4 to 5 times longer to craft and only marginally better (really an enhanced shot got does 1 more damage but takes 5 times as long to create? gimme a break).  You can essentially make one good piece of gear  at a time because you cant buy rare components, you have to forage them so to say with quests, which also is bottle necked since you can go on many quests at once, and takes hours of real time or the better part of a day to finish.  Pure frustration for a great game.  

In essence you become under powered

While the game is playable there are a few things wrong with it.
1. Dragging dwellers when you want to move the camera.
2. Dragging the camera when you want to move dwellers.
3. Roaches are harder to kill than a Feral Ghoul attack.
4. Dwellers running back and forth in vault not attacking?
5. Setting targets resets if any enemy moves.
6. Dwellers moving to different spots for no reason in combat delaying there attack.
7. Clipping issues when units occupy the same spot.
8. Quest with no enemies displaying a weapon attack requirement.
9. Can't collect from explorers if you have a few dwellers waiting in line that you want to add later.
10. Enemies attacking an open vault door if a dweller is exiting it.
11. No shots per turn on weapons. (Some shoot more than others, not sure if damage is per shot tho)
12. Can't set targets as battle is beginning wasting the 1st round of shots. (I always kill targets 1 by 1)
All this just makes things a little frustrating especially if you have a finite amount of meds on you.

Overall, its okay.  The game itself is good and if you've played Fallout 4 the cross-over references are fun.  But it is heavily designed to push you to want to make in-game purchases WHICH ARE EXPENSIVE and single use.  Plus once you play for awhile you'll figure out that you DID EVERYTHING WRONG because there are quirks you have to know about to build correctly.  So you'll really want to start over with a new vault but any previous purchases would be lost.  Not cool.  I'd rather have just paid to buy the game and there not been in-game purchases.  Or, at the very least, for the purchases to be more reasonable AND persistent (if you started a new game/vault all prior purchases would be available in that new game).

This brings a rather well known aspect of the Fallout Universe to the light of day. Usually where you come from is of vast importance to who you are and who you want to be. However within the common Fallout environment that is left behind so much that the "Vault" you came from, that your family survived because of, becomes legend. A thing of mythological value, relegated to the mysterious, the arcane, and the unknown. 

Here you get to see the troubles and difficulties such a mythological "utopia" can be. Demystifying vault life to a broad introspection. Not from the 1st person perspective consuming your focus but from the abstracted position where you monitor everything within the vault. In essence: Overseeing survival of the many instead of just you.

The game-play is mostly very good.  You get to explore the wasteland, build your vault and inhabiting community, develop their skills, outfit them.  It's thoroughly enjoyable... EXCEPT FOR THE MICRO-PURCHASES.  I know it's "free-to-play", but that's just code for "we designed the game to make people impatient so that they'll spend a ton of money to make the game actually tolerable."  That's a HORRIBLE business model for at least two reasons: it's greedy and anti-consumer,  I would have gladly paid $20+ for this game and $1-$10 for seasonal upgrades.  As it is, I believed the game was worth at least $20, and purchased lunchboxes for about that amount.  I'm not disappointed so far with that purchase, but I will be when they run out and I'm expected to purchase more to make the game continue to be enjoyably playable without completely unnecessary headaches that were purposely made part of the game in order for Bethesda to make $$$$$$$$$$$$$.  This game has made me like Bethesda a lot less.

Fallout Shelter is a fun time waster.  Unfortunately, if you want to get all of the achievements, it will take a long time due to the loot-chest requirement to get 20-legendary dwellers.   Only a hand full are given as a quest reward, the rest are strictly random from the Vault-Tek Lunchboxes.  Lunchboxes are gained only through quest reward, weekly report card or through cash purchase (Pay to win).  From what I have played, there is less than 5% chance of getting a legendary vault dweller per lunchbox.
A nice little build-a-vault-game, great for spending a little time. But it lacks the depth to be motivating in the long term.

Simple mechanics, good for people who want a distraction, without having to tap candy or blocks.

Pro: 
Game seems to know when its about to kill a Dweller, and moves on to another victim.
Simple collection technique, reasonable learning curve.
Fun.

Con:
During Vault attacks/emergencies, directing a Dweller to another room to help can sometime reassign them to that room.
No easy way to sort Dwellers by Health (i.e.; who needs StimPaks the most).
During mission battles, clicking and dragging to have a specific Dweller aim at a specific target causes the Dwellers stats to show up, which blocks 1/4 of the screen.  In small rooms, thats a pain.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]

In Fallout: Shelter, you are a Vault Overseer. You are tasked to ensure that the dwellers you have invited into your vault are happy, you have to make sure you manage your resources carefully - to make sure you don't run out of power, food or water - and you must assure that your shelter is secure for your dwellers to live in from raiders and the odd Deathclaw attacks.

As a fan of the Fallout series, I saw this on Steam and thought that I would try it again and see what it was like on pc. I had an idea of what to anticipate from playing it on my phone and the E3 footage from a few years back when Fallout 4 was announced so I knew what I was diving into. To be quite honest, Fallout Shelter after a week already feels lacklustre and tiresome. I've invested a few hours in the game and I'm pretty much done with wanting to play it anymore. Here are some deductions why.

[h1]Reasons[/h1]

[b]1:[/b] Once you've got 30+ rooms, managing the interface and each vault dweller becomes an ordeal. Having to handle well over 50 dwellers with a menu becomes tedious and frustrating. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt that it's more manifest than mobile versions as I invariably select dwellers accidentally on mobile but it would've been nice to see an improvement to manage each dweller more easily.

[b]2:[/b] You have to click on each room to collect resources from it. When you have 15 resource-producing rooms, it's needlessly tedious. When you have five to six rooms? Sure, it adds some interactivity to the game. But later on, it's just a big pain in the ass and absolutely nothing else. There is the option to purchase Mr Handy's to collect the resources but only for the one floor. The purchasing of Mr Handys can rack up drastically if you can't be arsed clicking on each finished resource when you have 15-16 floors.

[b]3:[/b] As the overseer, what am I progressing towards? More rare dwellers? Oh boy. So I can send them out exploring to collect more guns and outfits, with a solid guarantee that 90% of what they collect I already have (despite only having around 10-15% of the total weapons/outfits in the game)? There's no incentive. It's not worth the tedium for these truly tiny payoffs.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Fallout Shelter is a game with little purpose, and its replay value suffers excessively as a result. Incredibly bothersome adversarial mechanics, lacklustre end-game goals, and a largely absent sense of direction make what could be a fun free-to-play builder into a tedious and often pointless-feeling exercise in repetition. Beyond that, aggravating controls make managing your vault late in the game even more frustrating than it should be.

Can't recommend the game due to severe logical faults.
1. How can a RAID from literally 3 RAIDERS steal 20% of all my resources if all of them are killed in the vault door room - the very first room, and defensive area - before they even enter the shelter at all?
2. Why are the resources not returned if the RAID is unsuccessful and all RAIDERS are killed?
3. How come I can only place 2 defenders in a 2 space room which should allow 4 defenders per se, but since it's a defense room, it should even allow 6-8?
4. Why can't I add at least a basic weapon system to the defensive area?
5. If you close your game, the game still runs for a fixed amount of time (seems to be a few minutes). After that, resource consumption stops. But the people on mission in the wastelands are NOT stopped, effectively killing them if I don't remember calling them back before going to sleep. Why is this design decision necessary? To feel more mobile-clicky?
6. Why is exploring the wastelands dangerous, getting back to the vault from the wasteland totally safe?
7. Why do I even bother?

This is not a base building game, as you don't have to maintain resources necessary for building it.
This is not a tower defense game, as your means of defense is laughable, and stolen resources are integral part of the game, and not avoidable.
This is not a strategy game, as 80% of the game is luck/random.
This is not a card collector game, as you can not upgrade or evolve your cards, and the game mechanics are not stone-paper-scissors.
This is not a management simulation, as it is lacking any depth necessary for that.

The PC adaptation of the mobile game, Fallout Shelter is a game about resource management.

Build a vault for people to live in, invite people to live in your vault, and have them work in their ideal roles while you try to survive in the tough world.

I personally don't feel it's engaging enough to devote too many hours while sitting in front of your computer, but it's certainly worth trying out if you are used to playing mobile games.

You have a message *beep* ''Good morning! This is Vault-Tech speaking! You have been choosen to live inside a vault shared by other lucky people and boy oh boy! Isn't that wonderful? Now since this is one of a kind offer, we do have a little something to make it a once in a blue moon chance, think of it, as a promotion... If you got it right, then yes! You have been selected as the Overseer with the advantage of numbering your vault! To accept this offer, you have to give us your personnal information with your signature and send it to Vault-Tech Inc. and if I were you, I wouldn't miss this for anything. So, interested in building the chaotic future underground?''

[h1] Story: [/h1]

By some miracle, you have been hired by the shady company Vault-Tech as the Overseer with the task of creating and expanding an underground civilization. As you progress, you soon discover that you are not alone under the wasteland as ghouls, raiders and other species tries to invade and feast on your dwellers while some survivors wants to find refuge in your vault.

[h1] Gameplay: [/h1]

No need for the keyboard in this game since it's a point and/or drag control feature by the mouse or the touchpad in the laptop.

You start in this game by just having a small handful of dwellers and some caps, with time you develop your vault with better resources than before with improved power plants, cafeteria, water treatment plant, this three representing the basic resources while the power is the most needed and crucial, and other types of rooms present in the game and caps represents as the main currency for such development as the Nuka-Cola Quantums are a special type of currency mainly used to speed up quests, finishing crafting equipment and such. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L system is in the game as well the dweller's leveling, not only for combat outside of the vault, but to increase the productivity of the indicated room's perk. Outfits, weapons and junk are also included in the game, each with their own statistical values in the sections of ''common'', ''rare'' and ''legendary'', while junk  is, fundementally, for crafting recipes, this also includes the dwellers and pets well. In case you can't go on quests, at the start, and tired to wait for your dweller to return the vault, you have objectives to complete, the harder they get, the better is the reward.

The EXP system is based around how many dwellers you got, the more you have, more rooms and upgrades will unlock, unfortunately, the limit of dwellers only goes up to 200, I wonder what would happen if it reaches 201...

By choice, you can play in the ''Survival mode'', which by the name you can tell that it sounds like fighting a deathclaw in Fallout New Vegas with your fists, in other, short and less complicated words, the need of resources increases, more daily visits of raiders and ghouls and with the removed feature of reviving your dead dwellers.

Microtransactions are present in the game, you can buy lunchboxes, which can give you random rewards, Nuka-Cola Quantums, caps and other stuff available at the store, totally avoidable and doesn't make a big impact on the gameplay, unless you like donating money... or burning it.

The game's design is more 3D while the characters are 2D with bright colors combining with the destruction present outside of the vault.

Achievements are as well unlockable, not with dwellers, unfortunately. Most of them are easy which you just have to upgrade some rooms, complete a certain number of quests which is on the medium difficulty and change hairstyles of the dwellers, near hard but not that much. The hardest one being ''Blast from the past''  which, in order to complete it, you need to have 20 legendary dwellers, sounds easy right? The truth is, the only way to get them is by either spending money on microtransactions, owning lunchboxes through objectives, completing quests or trying your charisma and luck at the radio studio.

[h1] Glitches/ bugs/ errors report: [/h1]

The only thing that happened to me was the game crashing once without saving it which lead me to repeat the same stuff but in case of this constatly happening, like what the community says, it's best to always save the game, even when in doubt and on quests, when the characters die, they, sometimes, glitches through some walls and it is barely impossible to click on them to collect their stuff.

[h1] Overall: [/h1]

Patience is a requirement for this game if you want to have the best vault ever, it'll take weeks and months for you to complete it, if you want to get everything and every character maxed out but, from my perspective, I believe the main currency in this game should've been more usable than the microtransaction store, using caps to buy different and unique weapons and outfits or even using it at some quests where there's hostages or even pay somebody to work in your vault. This game should've been more explored and a complete different experience from what I was expecting when I first played it.

I really like the design of the game with a guide that tells me the information of weapons, outfits, pets and dwellers as well the fact that the dwellers sometimes breaks the fourth wall, truly is funny as hell!

Do I recommend it? For people who are bored and like this type of games, sure, I mean, it's a fun little strategic game, even tho in my opinion, more ideas should have been created to make it more unique.

Score: 6/10

Went in with low expectations but looking at the review gaves me some expectations, however minor. I was pleasantly surprised. Despite appearing pay-to-win, it's not by any means. Granted, it is slow going at first but once you put some time in, it starts to snowball and everything goes a lot faster. For a free game, it's worth giving a try, especially considering that the in-game world still progresses even when you're not playing.

I share the common criticism that it lacks depth, but not enough to make it unplayable. Also, the lack of an ending or real goal does hurt it a bit. In short, I'd just say there's worse ways to spend your time. A solid 7/10. If you're into management games, it's fun, albeit slow fun.

Fallout Shelter was probably the first serious idle clicker game I played. I'd played various web browser idle clicker games, but I didn't get involved as much compared to Fallout Shelter. I probably spent a $100 over the 1710 hours I've accumulated. Probably less than a 100 hours of actual playtime which really is just maintenance and some timed clicking for battles. The rest is just running in the background and occasionally watching for Mysterious Stranger popups for bonus cash or some daily goal.

Anyways, as someone who became a fan of the series starting with FO3 and in love with the lore, Fallout Shelter is a really nice niche game. I don't know what the state of it is now as I haven't played in probably a year or two. You can get into the game now and get all the weapons, outfits, and pets as well as maximizing all your vault dwellers statistics with careful planning and strategy guides. I could imagine you could spend a whole year or two since accumulating the holiday events items takes time, but you could probably play this game for years. I have too many games I still want to play, so I don't imagine myself revisiting this since I've pretty much gotten all the achievements.

Finally, I'd like to say that I really liked this game so much that I hope they release an improved sequel.

I've been playing this game for quite a long time with my old account, now I'm back to play it with my new one. The game is pretty simple yet fulfilling (in the early stages at least). You get to place the rooms needed for supplies, bigger population and to train your dwellers. Make sure you aren't low on any resource and equip your dwellers with the best weapons to defend the vault from dangers. You get to send your dwellers to the wasteland to do some quest or just to find more supplies, armors, weapons and more people.

For the long run, you'll find that this game is pretty boring and repetitive. Although there're many "quests" to do, they're just gonna be almost the same "go out of the vault and do some killing and/or looting" kind of thing. Some of the quests' backstories are pretty funny tho. There are microtransactions, like, to buy nuka-cola quantum which is gonna come in handy for speeding up the time of crafting, for skipping objectives, for instantly completing trainings, etc. So, yes, to get complete achievements for this game is either you work your ass off and be one of the most patient human beings or spend quite a fortune to buy some nuka-cola quantums to help you get the achievements faster.

All in all, it's a really good game for killing time. Don't stress yourself too much for playing this game. Just enjoy the process or move on to another game if you feel bored.

===================================================================

[list]
[*] Can be repetitive
[*] Quests can be buggy
[*] Can be time consuming to earn all achievements
[/list]

[u] Other points: [/u]
[list]
[*] Available as mobile app (no sync to PC)
[*] Can go all Vault-Tec crazy on your dwellers
[*] Beware of Radscorpion infestations
[*] Achievements do not stack (e.g. Complete 100 objectives)
[/list]

Great game! I began playing on IOS and as far as I can say it's a perfect game for ANYONE to pick up and play for free! It's fantastic how a game like this is available across platforms as well as mobile so you can play anywhere at anytime! The game doesn't require internet connection to play however you do need it to access the store where you can take part in many micro-transactions. The downside to the payments available is that most of them consist of buying 'loot-box' style things and receiving random gifts. The positive is, though these gifts can vary from decreasing the time certain actions take to increasing traits of the game. If this review helped please be sure to say so and if you have any questions be sure to drop them down in the comments below! Thank you for reading and enjoy fallout shelter!

It's a fun game. Slow burn early on, but it does become boring after a while. That being said, if you want a post-apocalyptic vault management sim, then I guess you could try it out. My least favorite part of the game is running out of space for all the dwellers to stay and stuff.

First of all and most importantly, this game is definitely not pay to win. This alone makes it really good for a free to play game. I have almost 50 hours on PC alone and have never spent even a cent in it but I have a complete and working vault with all the bells and whistles. Gameplay could have been deeper with more customization options but I wouldn't call it shallow either. You get what you pay for, except I got even more.

Of course if you want to collect all in game items or get certain achievements quicker then money can get things moving faster. Seeing how scummy Bethesda have been lately I wouldn't recommend spending money. Nevertheless it's the last Fallout content I can say I had fun with and it doesn't even mess with the lore that much, something amazing when you consider... Bethesda.

I've been playing Fallout shelter on my Android for years now.
And for quite some time on Steam too.
Fallout Shelter is just a great game.
Real slow-paced gameplay; Unlocking new rooms
Leveling up your dwellers, equipping your dwellers.
Sending them out to the wasteland to find junk or weapons etc.
Everything you do and everything you'll improve will eventually result in larger waiting times for things to finish.
U can compare it with Clash of Clans a little.
Difference is that there is no multiplayer in fallout shelter.
And no real purpose either.
U'll be leveling up, finding gear, making better gear etc. until you reach a certain limit.
If u're into that kind of games, then "Fallout Shelter" is for you.
I've enjoyed it a lot, and still do.

Try not to buy the lunch boxes or anything, I've had quite the experience opening them.
and the rewards are not worth the dough.

Further more; the Achievements seem to be a bit wonky every now and then.
If you're hunting for them, then I advice you to focus on 1 Vault for all of them.
Because the Progress will not stack across the 3 (possible) Vaults.
It's not worth spending too much time for, but if you want to spend small amounts of time every now and then just to manage everything quickly and then leave again, this is the game for you.

Fun little game. It starts slow so its one of those that you startup and play for 10-15 mins here and there. Once you get up and going theres enough to keep you playing for longer period.
I read a few of the strat tips online before I invested too much time. I will say that there is a huge downside to trying to grow too fast. Once you go over certain numbers of dwellers the game starts sending harder events. I would suggest getting to 40-55 dweller range then packing up on weapons/gear to equip and training your dwellers points. 
First is raiders(Attacking from door). Then its roaches/moles(Spawning in random rooms). Then scorps/ghouls(Scorps spawn in random room. Ghouls from front door and they cause radiation damage). Then at 60 dwellers deathclaws start attacking. Just be sure to have the gear to deal with these before pushing numbers too high and the game goes pretty smooth.

Wow, did I really spend that much time on this silly game? If only Fallout 76 had been able to keep my interest like this. This is a good game to leave running in the background while you do mindless busy work. And it's free.

EDIT: I tried to get the "Blast from the Past" achievement by stockpiling lunchboxes which I got from quests and objectives: I only got 1 legendary dweller out of 90 lunchboxes.

- A mobile game port full of micro-transactions and pay-2-win mechanics. Slow progression during crafting of weapons and outfits, and training to gain SPECIAL stats. You speed things up using Nuka-Cola, which can be acquired in quests, lunchboxes or buying them with real currency. There are also lootboxes which can be bought with real currency called lunchboxes and pet containers which provide in-game items.

- Several bugs encountered such as inaccurate Steam achievements tracking, clunky controls, and inaccurate objective tracking (objectives are in-game tasks that you need to complete in order to gain caps, lunchboxes, pets, or Nuka-Cola).

+ It's a great past time as you do quests, craft weapons and outfits, train dwellers to reach their maximum stats and levels, and collect from ordinary to legendary pets and dwellers.

I beat this game a long time ago and forgot to write a review. You can play this game in any way you want but i play it like a idle game and for an idle game its pretty cool. Its very detailed in a lot of areas with lots of fun quests. I dont think i spent any money on this.  I did start playing this game a long ass time ago, maybe 2 years ago off and on. The main thing i can tell is the core game never changes. The tutorial is what most of the game is. I cant recommend this game if you didnt like the tutorial. This game is more is more. You get more stuff but nothing actual changes. Having better stuff doesnt help you as much as you think it does. As for beating the game, I mean I did every quest. Even the repeatable ones. As far as i can tell, the choices you make during them doesnt make a huge difference. Sometimes you can skip a fight which is what i reccomend or you can force a fight. I think 50 percent of the choices are like that. Still fun to fight. For a free game that you can put on most devices, i say its better than average but dont expect quick anything. It takes awhile to get better stuff, it takes while to get more people. You get the picture. The quest are always fun. Just fighting is fun so ill give it that. One tip is when you start a vault, they usually give you rare stuff to survive to the mid game and if you dont get what you want, I would start another vault on another file. Im not sure how many vaults you can have but each one can be completely different from one another. Another tip is power and water is most important f I remember right. Happinesss doesnt do anything from my expirence. If they starve, its ok if u need to make tough choices. You can torture your people like that if you really want to. The game doesnt take death seriously. Its fun if you need a good laugh or whatever. Probably the most advance thing you can do is organize your stuff or plan out your vault. You can make your vault anyway you want. My only tip  is to put bedrooms on the very end. If you build a bedroom first and then extend from there, it makes it super tough to delete it months or years later and then your screwed. I do like all the weapons are clothes in the game. When they reach lvl 50, thats when i dress them up in silly stuff. Anyways, game is defiantly above average and i like it but its game where its takes a lot time and commitment to get the most out of it. Oh theres also no downside to deleting or kicking people out. Very handy when you in the red. Also spend you quantium wisely cuz it does become super rare after you do everything in the game. Anyways, its a cool interesting game which i recommend but it make take months to get where you want your vault to be at or get a certain unlock. I think I talked about everything. I have more tips but this is a review so ill end it here. Its best played your way and do your own thing.

Summary:
The quality of this game is just what you'd expect from a Bethesda game, with Fallout 4 and 76 in mind. It's just as dull, except it's a minigame and not AAA. Developed halfheartedly and without any effort. Just to have something to throw on the mobile market. Anything. Don't waste money on this!

The long criticism list:
- astonishingly idiotic game concept. there's nothing happening and nothing to do, but if you leave the game running and go to the bathroom you might come back to find half your dwellers dead. Reason: they are too stupid to take a stimpack. That's why survival mode isn't necessary more challenging as much as it's more annoying / frustrating
- incidents keep interrupting whatever you do. they take forever to go away and block all functionality
- annoying UI. scrolling or equipping dwellers is such a pain. many animations you have to sit through. informations lacking in some menus, functionality lacking in others. no overview for dwellers you have sent out, you have to scroll 25 pages. maybe this game wasn't supposed to be played on phones, but on smartwatches...
- responds badly to user input. sometimes just nothing happens, if you click on something. sometimes it just keeps zooming in and out instead what you want. buttons aren't exactly where they are displayed, they're offset due to badly programmed 3d, sometimes offset quite a lot. so are rooms. 
- certainly not for PC; more incidents while game is idle, as well as resources empty. if you restart the app, it loads long
- save files get corrupted over and over (3 attempts ended with broken/deleted save, 2 times on phone)
- no interesting rooms (last unlocked ones do the same the first do: generate food. just... more of it)
- bad balance & no progression. You need a rare weapon from one of these lootboxes and it will carry you through the game. at least you can get some for free. Also all this legendary junk, but crafting takes waaaay too long
- out of the 7 stats only 2-3 are required. rest is filler
- utterly stupid dwellers, complete morons! these idiots dont use stimpacks, they don't return from expeditions when on low health (they rather die), they only grin stupidly...
- fights so incredibly very extremely lethargicly slow. they fight automatically, so you watch bored, but they don't take stimpacks automatically, so you have to watch them like a babysitter. every 10 or 15 sec these stupid morons need a stimpack spoonfed or they die.
- bugs (of course)
Still better than Fallout 76

Fallout Shelter is a great game with a huge hangup, that being the fact that it can periodically delete itself from your computer along with your saved game. I have started over four times and I am done giving it chances. Play at your own risk.

I play this game for a good month and at my peak had a population of about 70 people. For some god forsaken reason though the devs thought more people meant more and harder attacks which I guess makes sense. the real kicker was when I had a deathclaw attack followed up by yet another deathclaw attack. I used all my heath packs on the first deathclaw attack so all my dwellers were badly hurt to near death. The final thing was when I tried to to rush the food because I was low for the attacks and did not anyone else to die of hunger, this was a mistake. I had myself a molerat invasion that swiftly took out my entire vault within minutes. All I am trying to say is that they need to scale back the attacks a bit. I would still suggest you play this game though because up until this event I got 28 hours of free entertainment from this game.
very cool game

Tried the handheld version before; got bored fast. But my main issue is that you'll have to watch over the game constantly in order to collect the various resources your vault dwellers are generating every two minutes. If you just leave the game to run in the background while you do something else, then your vault faces the possibility of thirst, hunger, or running out of power. You're basically playing a nanny throughout this game until your dwellers produce more babies to increase the vault population (and manpower needed for the various tasks), which can take forever. I'm in the game for hours and the babies haven't come out yet, so the game's pacing is pretty slow to say the least.

Basically, it's your typical sit-and-get-bored mobile gameplay. Many people seem to dig this game enough to give it a pass, but IMO, it works better as a mobile game, when I'm bored out of my ass enough when I'm outside to play this kind of click-and-play game to take my mind off things, not when I'm sitting at home trying to get engaged with a game I can actively take part of.

Also, the random events can get a little annoying, particularly the raider one. I kinda wish there's just one simple button where you can get your dwellers with the best weapon to go after the raiders. What happens is, after the raiders break into your vault, you can send two vault dwellers (there's only enough room capacity for two) to the entrance and fend the raiders off. But after killing one of them, the raiders will move on to another room - but the catch is, you don't know which one they're gonna go next! So you have to sit there like a dumbass before you can send your "fighters" to the raiders' next target, which by then they'll have start attacking your more helpless dwellers. If you have plenty of good weapons later on, yes, you can just equip every single of your dwellers with those and this wouldn't be a problem. But early-game like me, and you're fucked, forced to buy those stupid lunchboxes so you can get more and better weapons.

Also, why couldn't you just send your dwellers to attack the raiders' base so that they would stop attacking? It makes no sense at all.

Finally, why couldn't we just explore the wasteland on our own? I don't know if it's a feature that only unlocks later on, but seeing just text descriptions of what the dweller explorer is doing out in the wasteland is a travesty compared to the Fallout games' exploration. Has Fallout sunk this low?

You know, I like this game. I really do enjoy it and would love to recommend it to everyone who has no money to spend on any paid games. Unfortunately, I cannot recommend it due to the lack of innovation and care given to the mechanics of the game itself. 

For years I have played this game on and off. To start off the microtransaction store was broken for a long time (back when I was dumb and addicted to microtransactions). As quickly as their clumsy team could muster it, the issue with the store was fixed. Ridiculous amounts of money can be spent on the generous amount of nonsense they offer within the store. It isn't as predatory as other microtransaction based games but surprise mechanics are still unappreciated. 

The worst part of it all is that as long as this game has existed the UI and mechanics are still nearly the same as when the game launched. No innovation to make things simpler and/or more fun. This is why I cannot recommend the game. They pooped out a product, as they so often do, and let it die in stagnation as soon as it became moderately functional.

Disgusting game.

Totally AWFUL mobile port that is buggy, and bogged down with microtransactions and  just doesn't cut it on PC. My rig is an 8th Gen i7 @ 5.0GHz (OC) & a GTX 1080 ti, and Fallout Shelter often lags between 4-19 fps (totally unplayable), yet at other times it spikes to over 1400fps - INSANE. Lots of other users have experienced this same nonsense - a few don't - who knows why. Naturally, this PC rig rips through anything else I play with ease BTW.


Initially, the game looks cute & nostalgic if you are a fan of the Fallout series, but the unplayable lag, excrutiating waiting to click one single item, and then wait 5-10min to one-click something else is absurd...B-O-R-I-N-G. The Bottom Line is this: The Game simply was NOT FUN. It feels & looks like a sim-builder game when it 1st launches, but it's not. Everything relies on RNG, & skill has little if anything to do with it. I actually put in several hours, playing multiple vault types, and nothing really matters. Even the 'Achievements' bored me - they didn't seem to represent anything other than simply enduring the game. Mobile Games are for tablets and phones - and have no business on PC.

If you enjoy the Fallout series (and Who Doesn't) - then play Fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas, or Fallout 4, but this Fallout Shelter is a P2W Mobile Steaming Pile POS clicker. You've been warned LOL - Happy Gaming.

[h1]Details[/h1]
[quote]
[h1]Trapped in a Vault for 200 years?
Thank the Atom that Facebook survived.[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1791457309
Fallout is a rich universe and this resource-management game allows you to be the Overseer of a Vault. Build facilities, grant jobs, build families, explore the wastes, recruit wanderers, repel raiders. All at the click of a mouse!

[b]Hook[/b]
A storm was coming, and one man was to shelter the last people on Earth: he was the Overseer.

[b]Mechanic[/b]
A side-on subterreanean grid of rock to drill out and fill with rooms, lifts and utilities.
- protect your tiny vault-dweller population
- dig-out and expand your Vault.
- earn caps by performing tasks
- maintain power, food and population
- women bearing children and small children are invicible, however unable to work - so families need to be planned
- occasionally, build a taskforce to go and run a mission into the wastes
- keep the caps, power, food, happiness and population booming as you grind your way through all those achievements
- the game also provides timed-challenges and the option to buy power-ups with real-cash transactions

[b]Accessibility[/b]
- super user-friendly layout
- nice, classic iconic Fallout Pipboy styling
- small avatars and large Vault that requires scrolling to events off-screen can cause confusion
- while no profanity, there is violence - and sex is obviouly alluded too (love hearts)
- graphically looks like a flash game suitable for classic Facebook genre

[b]Delivery[/b]
- a grinding, resource-management game that maintains it's appeal by offering a lot of customisation and variety as you play
- the game would work well on mobile or social-media; it has daily challenges and offers pay-to-win shortcuts
- it is a bit too cutesy to be considered a weighty addition to teh FAllout universe, however it keeps to canon

[/quote]

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[quote]
[h1]Now, it is not isometric nor is it 3D, however it is a solid Fallout game. 
It does have layers of skill to it and is a lot of fun. 
By far the most light-hearted entry into the Fallout universe, but not one to be dismissed. 
A guilty pleasure for when you want a break from splattering ghouls into a bloody mess[/h1]

Pros:
- attractive game-style
- really challenging resource-management game
- plenty of variety
- lots of achievements and all the classic hooks to push players to invest time (and money)

Cons:
- it's one you cannot take too seriously
- the micro-transactions are never too far away, but you can grind through fairly nicely without paying a single bottlecap

7/10: a campy game with a satisfying vault-building premise - better than awful camp-building!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1748238549 

[/quote]

Fallout Shelter is an adorable "manage your people" game.  You take the role of the Overseer and your job is to take care of your Vault and make sure first that your vault produces food, water, and power so that it can sustain the whole vault.  Simple enough at first but then you have to have more power the more rooms you create and you have to manage the look of the vault.  Raiders, radiated cockroaches, and random fires are a tremendous pain in the ass, but i digress.  If you want a game that you can just relax and chill while watching the game go this is the game for you.  Oh and I must warn you this was originally supposed to be a mobile clicking/farming for resources game but on the PC it looks and runs so much better, believe me I know.  There are microtransactions but they are not necessary in the slightest.  I've put 2.5 hours into this game and I haven't put a cent into it and I've already gotten 16 settlers and that includes a legendary one. I definitely recommend this game.

What I imagine is a faithful port of the mobile game, onto your computer. I have not played the mobile version, only this one, so if you have played the mobile game, and want more of the same grinding content, then you'll feel right at home. If you want a different experience from what you've already played, this is not it.

You can occasionally meet famous "dwellers" (NPCs) from previous Bethesda Fallout titles (Three, New Vegas, and Four only), there are ways to train your dwellers to improve them, and protect your dwellers from harm (Deathclaws, Raiders, and the dreaded Radroach) or send them out INTO harm to get you scraps of military clothing and tape.

It's a desktop version of a mobile game, expectations should be low anyways. Good for killing time.

yeaaa... pretty good game...

A great game despite the microtransactions!

Fallout Shelter is one of my favorite Fallout games in that it is something very different, most people would be turned away from microtransaction but 'free' games almost immediately but I'm glad I gave FOS a try!

The game makes it actually much easier to earn premium currency than other games I have tried, which is a huge plus than it just being more of a cash grab to shell out money. I only do pay for these games if I genuinely enjoy them, and FOS is just that!

I am very happy this is also on Steam as the whole closing/opening application on your phone makes it quite hard to keep progress from time to time. The steam version feels much more secure on my progress than the phone version which gives me a relief when wanting to spend USD for more in-game items.

As good as it is as it comes down to the Quest mechanic and storybuilding for myself, I do have some cons in general.

First, I feel there should've been a 'family tree' sort of thing introduced, and to some people it probably doesn't matter but I'm pretty sure you can breed any two adults as long as they are opposite sex and adults, which means inbreeding is possible, while it does not hold any meaning in the game. I also feel implementing it would be a good challenge as inbreeding would cause some problems down the line for dwellers affected by it.

Another thing is progress saves, while it is much less obvious on the Steam version, it still persists that sometimes you can lose progress or things you have done for no reason at all, be it a problem with the game, Steam, or the Cloud. I feel it should be more secure so people spending money on the game itself don't lose the money's worth if their game decides to freak out.

Another thing I think I should bring up is the 'Bottle & Cappy' Quests, which are stated to be 'available for a limited time', which however is false as I remember that quest line being available right when the app came out on iOS. That being said, don't feel pressured to finish it within the 'time limit' as there is none, completing the quests as well is very well worth it for free caps and free nuka cola.

TLDR;

Pros:
- Quest mechanic is tons of fun
- Easy to earn 'premium' currency/items
- Storybuilding for those who like it
- Interesting artstyle in how the buildings/vaults make it look like you're peering into a dollhouse
- Easy to pick up and put down when needed; not a game you pursue hours on end and great for short attention spans

Cons:
- iCloud Save is Finnicky at times earning lost progress or mistakes
- Inbreeding is possible (personal con)
- 'Limited Time' is false.

It's a mobile game brought to pc. Loads of microtransactions and micromanaging. It is a unique experience despite all the obvious mobile game fallacy's. You can build your own vault which is neat. You must keep up with getting electricity, water, as well as food for your dwellers. You can also let a dweller go explore the wasteland by dragging them to outside the vault. That is your main source of items and caps, until you unlock quests. You can get little amounts of caps and lunchboxes by doing little side missions the game assigns to you. They do not give much, because they want to emphasize questing and letting a dweller explore the wasteland. You have to wait a large amount of time for exploring or quests to even start, unless you speed them up by using nuka cola quantum. Which you can only buy with real money, unless you get super lucky and get them from a lunchbox. All in all, it will hold your attention for a few minutes, then you close it out and wait the several hours it will take to get somebody back. It is a time waster in all the right senses, I give it a 5/10.

This is a free game I'm pretty fond of, if only because you don't have to buy anything to progress.  I mean, you can if you want to, it's just really not necessary.  It's also a fabulous time waster, as I can lose an hour easily with my 3 vaults.  The writing is also a bonus-- my personal favorites are the flirt lines between vault dwellers (they're a good kind of cheesy) and the stuff being said when a vault dweller does quests alone.  It may not be the deepest game out there, and it may bother some that there's no real end to the game (afaik), but I still think it's worth checking out if you want to lose some time.

I ignored the game for a long time, but my curiosity finally caused me to download the game. 

What I feel was good: 

- Giving you multiple things to do such as quests
- Training the dwellers 
- Customising the dwellers
- Exploring the wasteland 
- Better rooms to unlock later on, giving you a reason to expand your fault

What I feel was wrong: 

- The incredibly long waiting times for nearly everything 
- Needing to pay for things (although I'm okay with it since you don't need those things to advance in the game) 
- Feeling as if training dwellers is more of a job than a game sometimes 
- Losing my vault due to it being deleted 

Since it's free, I really cannot complain about it. It was fun for what it is.

[h1]Fallout Shelter[/h1]

The game is quite an interesting and simple asylum management simulator. We take on the role of the Superintendent and must control the situation in the shelter: happiness, health, satiety and the number of people, their clothes, weapons, electricity for shelter and in general all the welfare of the shelter. (Fight raiders and monsters that they want to take our shelter and lives from our people)
Moreover, in this we have complete freedom. You can really build anything, the only question is whether people will survive in this 'building'...

As our development progresses, new rooms, characters, room customization options and many interesting quest tasks will open and the game will not make us bored, at least for the next 100 hours. 

I really liked this game, because even taking into account that it is completely free, you can open everything in it, nothing really depends on whether you put money into the game or not. It's all about time.

The game is really addictive, the only thing that depresses me - the appearance of being ported from mobile devices. Because of this, it has a kind of strange mouse control, but for me personally. This isn't bothers everyone, but I didn't like it. On this, in principle, the cons of the game ends. 

I advise this game to anyone who does not have money on the account, but you really want to play something interesting. That's what you need.

I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with this game, and no, not because it's Bethesda. :P

I absolutely love the base concept of the game, and when everything is going smoothly and totally under control, I'm content to just sit around for hours "playing" the game, doing quests, sending out teams to scavenge the wastes, and so on. I enjoy the ambient sounds of the vault, too, though some of the sounds of other things--I'm looking at you, ferals--aren't so good. cx

The trouble I have with this game starts with the early game. It's free to play, sure, but they strongly encourage you to buy into their microtransactions by throwing some tough stuff your way before you're necessarily ready to deal with it (I mean if every vault started with a compliment of Fat Mans and Gatling Lasers to give to your dwellers then maybe it wouldn't be so bad, but you have to go find those or find the junk needed to craft them, and you can't even start crafting until you reach a particular number of dwellers in the vault, and it's not cheap). Not to mention the constant nagging that I have "low storage space" (dude I have 250+ free slots, go away), though that's more just a minor nuisance.

Overall, I feel the pros do outweigh the cons, although I definitely need to stress that microtransactions are deplorable and, as much as I enjoy opening lunchboxes to see what I'm gonna get, I strongly recommend -not- buying them, especially when they're not on sale--$14 for 40 is still bad, but it's better than $30 for 40.

[h1]Review[/h1] 
I personally dont mind these grinder, afk type of games aslong as they offer fullfilling gameplay. Fallout shelter is just a mobile port and it definetly looks like it. But i really like fallout so i gave it a shot.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Fallout shelter is more of a mix between a management game and a afk grinder game. You basically come back every day and click on everything and it makes these nice sounds and fills up your bars and gives you some sort of progress. You can build downwards into a mountain and upgrade your basic rooms. There are around 24 rooms aviable And they deliver various goods or services to you. You train your citizens or send them on quests to gather items so you can defend yourself against random attacks from invaders.

This is already where the negatives come. There isnt much to strategically plan. You cant fortify your base really, the waves of monsters are devastating in the beginning until you find out that the monsters strength gets higher the more dwellers you have. So keeping your vault pre 24 and 49 dwellers is a key goal and basically one of the only few ways to really get progress in the game. They only start to be annoying but not something that is a threat. So you treat the game as an idle game by setting all unneeded dwellers to training .

The ui is at times terrible you constantly missclick and there is no viable method to sort your citizens and send them to rooms they fit best to work in. Its a real hassle but the idea behind the whole managament system of a vault isnt bad. It starts out really fun but as soon as you are having a couple of weeks into the game you find out more things that bother you.

During quests you traverse trough buildings and only click on loot while in combat you can barely do anything except target specific things or click at the right time to get a critical hit.

The whole gameplay isnt bad per se its just a bit underwhelming and only in the beginning kinda complicated. 

Also if you see achievements as part of the game, have fun unlocking them without using sam or adding (lots) of lunchboxes to your game as one requires you to get 20 legendary dwellers. There are like 22 in total and they dont stack meaning you have to probably open over thousands of lunchboxes to get all of them.

[u]Story[/u]
Yes the ingame quests even deliver some sort of story with minor dialogue choices that mostly end up in two outcomes but can offer some hilarious stories or dialogues. Its definetly not on par with new vegas jokes but its not bad either.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Great artstyle that doesnt get old. Looks good on the phone and looks good on the computer. The game is very stable but it can be annoying that it kinda paused/reloads if you did something else like browsing youtube videos for a while.

[u]Sound[/u]
Battle sound effects are pretty poor but the rest is pretty neat. Especially gathering ressources is pretty fullfilling.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I dont really recommend this game since it does offer interestening ideas but as a managament game having bad ui and oversight over everything it totally kills the game. Its just overall lacking in many things and thats sad because the game could have been so much more but in the end its just a borefest to grind out lunchboxes in order to 100% the game.

Youll get several hours of fun game play out of this game before you really notice the slow down if you dont spend money. I would recommend at least playing it until that point or spend money on the game to continue the consistent fun when you get deeper into the quest lines.

Some rules for playing:
 - don't buy lunchboxes,
 - don't lvl up dwellers with low endurance (give them armor with +E first) - they get additional hp based on endurance they have when lvl up - making their E higher later or giving them better armor - doesn't work retroactivelly!
 - don't buy lunchboxes,
 - special dwellers from lunchboxes are useless in later game - they have already high lvl and even when you increase their endurance and give them best armor when leveling up - they will still have not enough hp,
 - don't buy lunchboxes,
 - if you have ruined couple of vaults - and you know how to run your vault - start new game and wait for first launchbox - if you have armor with +7 to endurance - you can continue. If not - erase vault, start over - check first launchbox... (repeat for next 10h if needed - it's worth it),
 - don't buy lunchboxes,
 - don't buy lunchboxes,
 - don't buy lunchboxes.

Seriously - lunchboxes are quite useless. You have to be out of your mind to buy them for real money.
Beside that - great time killer.

A very fun free game. Can get repetitious after about 50 hours or so, but had alot of fun building my vault, venturing into the wasteland, and meeting all the new people there are to meet/kill out there. Many weapons and outfits to find and create to make your vault stronger to defend against attacks from raiders, feral ghouls, and Deathclaws.

if your going for the achievements, you should get most of them. The one that is the most challenging, and the one I stopped trying for, was to get 20 Legendary people. After 125 hours, I got 6. 3 you get through doing the quests that become available after you build the Overseers office, and the rest you can only get by collecting lunchboxes. I have collected 163 of those, and only got 3. Sooooo....

Was fun while it lasted and from what I hear, this is better than Fallout 76 LOL.  If you haven't tried it, but like the Fallout world, give it a go. Not super exciting, but does get addicting. Happy hunting in the Wasteland.

Also it be nice to have the ability to completely revamp your colonist such to change men to women, also to do a complete make over if desired.   Perhaps you could even add turret and robots to protect your shelter as raids to your shelter get harder and more frequent in nature.  Things like that to keep it fresher and more interesting long term.

A prime example of how bad of a company Bethesda now is.

-Pay to win garbage
-Microtransactions
-Gambling
-Incredibly long wait times in order to motivate you spending money on this shit
-Can get really fucking boring at times
-Next to nothing to do at times, forced to close the game and wait

I've never spent any money in this "game" and I never will, it can be enjoyable at times, but that's about it.




A final message from someone who absolutely loves Skyrim, Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas:
Fuck you Bethesda, you're not getting anymore money out of me.

If you don't spend money, deathclaws will come and eat your friends. Like all pay to win games, Fallout Shelter is a great time if you turn on cheats. It's built to make spending money feel rewarding, so opening lunchboxes without spending money can be pretty cathartic. The game as it is intended is predatory and terrible. Do not play this game if you do not intend to cheat.

One poorly timed deathclaw attack made it impossible to recover my vault. My resources and defenses couldn't stand against the waves of attacks that followed. It's a shame that an otherwise enjoyable game is built to motivate the purchase of more lunchboxes, with the additional dwellers, items, and resources they contain. Although the game is [i] possible [/i] without participating in microtransactions, spending money makes the game a good deal easier. I personally don't enjoy having to bash my head against a wall in order to advance in a game that discourages playing for free. Of course I also suck at resource management games which colors my opinion, but the game's difficulty is motivated by a commercial need for severe resource scarcity rather than by some artistic decision about game mechanics. Even though some people may end up enjoying the game, my recommendation remains unchanged. I don't think this is a game that curious people should pick up because of its major flaws as another in the long line of mobile cash-grab games. And that's a shame because it has some charm.

Fallout Shelter is free to play except for the fact it constantly tries to persuade the player to buy "pay to win" advantages you may receive upon purchasing lunchboxes. The primary game play runs on a loop which is easy to grasp - as new people are born or recruited into your vault, you have to dig into the mountain to create living quarters for them to sleep, as well as water treatment plants and cafeterias to manufacture their food and water, and power plants to keep all these factories running.

Fallout Shelter is best in its early stages. When your vault has developed itself strongly, all fear of failing and thus the fun will quickly vanish. Combine this with the absence of persistent long-term objectives, and you experience it for a few days, but it does not have long-term appeal. I still recommend playing this when you are burnt out from other games or looking for something easy to put time in.

One of the best free to play games I have ever played. 

Uses all the lore from the Fallout games...thankfully not Fallout 76. So if you enjoy the story of previous games, chances are that there will be a nod to it in this one.

The cartoon graphics are charming, but also have a hidden depth. When you put 3 of the rooms together and upgrade them completely, there is a lot of depth that goes into the animations. *Oh and make sure you click on the "Stranger" (guy in hat and trenchcoat) that periodically appears. Drops lots of useful caps. Appears every 15-20mins*

Send dwellers into the wasteland to level them the fastest. The quests are fun, with daily, weekly and special event quests. Also the game is completely free to play, no need to buy anything...unless you want to get all of the achievements in this lifetime. I am stuck on the Legendary Dwellers. They come from quests and in the lunchboxes. The lunchboxes can be purchased or found during quests. 

All in all this is a brilliant game, highly recommend you give it a go if you are a fan of the Fallout series or if you enjoy management games.

At first this game is an apparent 2* piss poor mobile game. Once you get to grips with the pace of the game you realise it's the best fallout game. I'm not even joking. 5* masterpiece. 

Ensure you find and use the editor rather than buying lunchboxes!

What I like to do is use starter packs to build and populate a complete vault, then switch it to survival mode and let decadence take effect until only a handful of dwellers are alive in the wasteland, then have them return to begin the role play of a crew who find an desolate vault. 

.
reeeeeeeeeeeeee

It's not that I don't recommend trying this game. Have at it, if it sounds interesting to you. It's free to try, obviously. The problem I have is that the game leads you to either wait around and deal with constant problems to fix, or pay money to get around waiting. Honestly, I feel the game would be better if it cost money and skipped on the pay to make it less painful tactics. I hope they make another game like this that just gives you a cost up front and then lets you enjoy playing the game.
just love it

Pretty entertaining early on but like all f2p+mobile games it pushes a timegate/lootbox grind onto you pretty early on, and seems to actively reduce the odds of you finding in anything useful in lootboxes (IE lunchboxes) after the first 4-5 rapid fire ones you are given in a new vault. it can still be pretty fun early on, but after about a hour of playing it devolves into something you pop into for twenty minutes a day to collect resources/do a quest/recall people from wasteland/quest and then log back out till tomorrow type deal.

Its okay to play, but strongly discourage people from giving into the lootbox gambling.

This was an amazing game. My goodness, is this fun to play. No wonder it was originally designed as a mobile game because (like usual Bethesda titles) it's addictive as s**t. It unmistakably has that mobile game feel. The whole 'wait three hours for this to finish' stuff which isn't so bad but also the whole 'or finish now by buying this thing that will speed it up and give us your money and credit card details'. Honestly, if you download a free Bethesda game; you get what you paid for. And they need to make their piles of money somehow. I guess. Not that I've given them a cent for this. It's by no means necessary, which is good. Otherwise, I probably would have given up.

The game has a cool combination of 2-D player models on a 3-D background, which I really liked. It has galore of references and winks to previous games in the Fallout series which I loved. It was so cool even if I didn't understand a good chunk of them. Fallout 3 references I got the biggest kick out of. I will admit it does control better on PC than the mobile version. But you seem to get much better luck on mobile version with the loot crates...huh. It does feel great to play and it's so much fun...but not without drawbacks.

As I said, free game - you get what you paid for. Dear heck. The animations and model can be really lazy. As in, just re-colour but mostly just re-use the same models for everything with a different name. The arms of dweller tend to clip through themselves and if you look closely their guns tend to float behind their hands(which they don't even attempt to hold anyway). Your dwellers are pathetic as. It's hard to tell if they're just super weak or if the enemies are jacked on roids or something. Stimpacks do seem to be much much stronger than ever in this game (which is probably to compensate the paper skin and cardboard bones of your dwellers).

The pathetisism is only made worse by how OP the rad scorpions are now. Geez, they're an absolute menace! Only in the vault. In the wasteland they're quite different. What? Yeah, I'm not kidding. The death claws are complete midgets now. Like, seriously. My dwellers might be taller than them. Huh? Kinda weird how a fifteen ton (or whatever) weight vault door powerful enough to withstand a nuclear explosion can't stop a small group of angry monkeys that have leprosy. Also known as Ghouls. Don't even get me started about how annoying it is to heal your dwellers when anything and everything busts through your sheet-metal vault door to kill everyone. It's so unresponsive! My dwellers keep dying like morons because I have to sometimes click three times to heal one dweller. And the buggers keep running around like a headless chook when I'm trying to heal them and they just drop like flies. Freaking heck. Speaking of unresponsive: F**K THE MOBILE VERSION! It's so bad! It's controls are so unresponsive I can't do most of anything. I just gave up on it after a while because I was sick of it's s**t and the PC version is better anyway.

The mission most of the time don't even make sense. On multiple levels. You don't even have to stick with the requirements some set when you're on the mission. And the buildings all look the same. They're all just 'copy and paste this here and that there'. Ugh. The combat is completely different in the Wasteland and in the Vault. Outside it works pretty understandably: someone attacks then someone is hurt. Simple. In the vault: don't need to attack, everyone gets hurt by everything. What even? Why are they even different? Why? The was the camera forces you away can be really annoying if you're looking for the mysterious stranger and his sound cues suck. The sounds are liars, I tell you. I look to the sounds and he's somewhere completely different. Sneaky blending in little bugger. Sending out dwellers into the wasteland for supplies can be fun, unless there's a opportunity to enter a building. In which case there's a chance you're either screwed or okay. Mostly screwed. Seriously, they suck. Like, what even is this? I've also noticed they've recycled Elder Scrolls sound effects in here. Even though this is Fallout. What's wrong Bethesda? Can't tell the difference between them now?

So, yeah. It's a great and addictive game. Unless you're on mobile. And have a short temper. And hate lazy game design. In which case you might not like it. I can tolerate it. Probably just because of how addicting Bethesda games are. Good thing they make games and not drugs. Chances are they wouldn't work and would only be addictive. Freaking Bethesda. As long as there's money involved, eh?

I like this game, but allow me to name the reasons you might not.  I will assume you're familiar with Fallout games already, since this game seems to be tailored to the fans.

1.  The game is extremely simplistic and limited.
2.  The game is not an active game (except during quests and incidents)
3.  The game expects you to think, plan, and wait.  Thus their money-making..  Read below.

* Also worth mentioning: The game is quite easy, unless you don't understand it.  The in-game tutorial provides little information on how you're actually expected to play the game, being that it's pleasantly lore-friendly.  They expect you to read through the manual, found in your Pip-Boy at the bottom-right of your screen.

But anyway, allow me to go into more details.

1.  What you see is what you get with this game.  Even on quests, it's set up where you go room-to-room like in your own Vault.  The size, particularly width limitations, kind of force you into a single setup of 2 elevator shafts and 8 rooms per floor..  

2.  The game isn't designed to sit and play.  You're an Overseer, your job is to tell other people what to do, then lean back and do your own thing.  It's designed to do things, close the game, and come back hours later or the next day.  There are a few incentives to sitting and staring at the screen, but it'll be boring, monotonous, and mindless.

3.  The game's designed for you to expand slowly, and send your Vault dwellers out into the Wasteland to find supplies..  You should always make sure you have your needs covered before doing anything new..  This includes building new rooms or expanding old rooms!  Even upgrading an existing room raises the difficulty of the incidents that happen in it..

I find the game fun, and see no need to spend anything on it.  The pay options are to speed up time..  But if you're impatient, you really shouldn't be playing this game to begin with, in my own opinion.

Why negative review?
Because at v13.13 and I'm STILL back in FO4 and bloody Boston frame-rate drops and game crashes every 10 minutes now.
I don't have any gripe against Bethesda- they make excellent games, but... they really should get a new Head of Nerdness in to optimise the programming.
It looks great, is well designed.. but doesn't work properly at the post 15 Level stage, which is what you're basically trying to achieve (its about then you get to make good weapons to defend your Vault). So its ultimately frustrating and completely pointless.

Well- I suppose I do have a gripe against Bethesda. I love their games in terms of content, but always end up pissed off with them, because they don't work properly in ways that are sufficiently critical to game play- to make you stop playing.

And the crashing wipes out the 'hours played' too I guess, I've about 40  hours on my fourth Vault alone, not 5 total as stated above.

Only started playing because i broke a finger, essentially making me one handed. For a game where you just click the screen its fun and addicting. HOWEVER it is COMPLETELY RNG DEPENDENT.

after my third vault, I finally know how long each room can be, and what I need to build up, so I start a new one. Every dweller i send out barely gets any drops, meanwhile the lunch boxes they handed me out didnt have any guns. I had 2 10mm pistols do defend myself until I had an overseers office or a weapons workbench.

Right about now I feel like my luck has gotten better. Well im up to 50+ dwellers, but unfortunatly I had a lot of rooms where I didnt have any dwellers in for a time. The RNG bot decided to drop a pack of mole rats in an empty room and continues to multiply them everytime they have another adjacent room. I tried my best to save them, used up all 35 stimpacks that i had in a matter of seconds. Also the armour that you equip doesn't seem to do any DT.

After about 25 Dwellers died I just deleted the save. After that attack I felt like the game either expected me to have a non pregnant dweller with a gun in every room, or its just telling me to quit playing. and for the meantime im still playing it until my hand gets free from my bum finger.

If i learned anything about this game is to try to stop playing it befor RNGesus decides to smite me.

Bethesda...

So I played this on a variety of platforms, but the PC is definitely the superior version.
I am glad however that bringing my saved data over from Android was so damn easy (and possible).  I had lots of hours on my phone with this game but I always found it extremely glitchy as it would often crash or run slowly and in the early incarnations the microtransactions sometimes failed (though the Google Pay integration helped that tremendously).
On the PC I have had zero issues, which is what you'd expect.  The game runs smooth and no problems with the Steam Wallet integration for purchases.
The game itself is a fun way to pass some time.  It isn't really in depth and a lot of the mechanics are about waiting (quests are the worst) and much of the interacting is just finding things and clicking them.  I find all of the tie ins to previous Fallout games fun to spot and remember.  While the game is free and there is no real pressure to buy anything I found dropping a few bucks here and there gave me a modicum of joy back when the game seemed "stale".  Opening a lunchbox and getting a Legendary Dweller or Weapon was always a treat as was opening a pet crate and getting a pet with a super useful ability.
My one major complaint is the lack of expansion to the game.  Once you've built your vault to be sustainable and have all the rooms you need there is nothing more to build.  They haven't added much content for the core of the game itself.  I would have loved to have seen new room types added like a playpen for your pets to hang out in, or upgraded versions of the skill training rooms and some additional cosmetic room designs.  There is a lot of untapped potential with adding just small things like this, but it seems unlikely Bethesda will ever do anything of the sort.  They occasionally have seasonal themed events going on (the norm with most mobile games) but these are lackluster in most regards.

Mind numbing, Boring, with a really stupid AI that is propped up with cheap parlor tricks to make the game seem like it's good. Frankly the biggest shock is other games have stolen code from it for their own game. I guess if you aren't trying to make a good game, why copy a good game. 

Biggest complaint about the game is how hit boxes don't line up with the actions. I thought the screen on my tablet was going out, now on PC it does the same thing, so the dev's made off center hit boxes so you can't perform actions by clicking where indicated.  

  Instead of being challenging, game just throws literally random shit at you when you are doing either too well, or too bad. The entire game is designed to keep you taking care of bullshit fires(sometimes literally), because there's no real content to this game. 

I only play it because I literally want something mind numbing at the end of my day, I will likely delete it soon, as there is good games that don't use cheap tricks to pretend to be well developed. If you never want to spend money and don't mind feeling like you wasted your life, then give this game a chance. If you like being entertained, a good story, entertaining graphics, or character growth, then this game isn't for you. If you like staring at a screen mindlessly while a terrible game plays itself with little to no interaction from yourself, well you know the rest.

[i]"I admit, I've never seen another Vault, but ours MUST be the best." ~ Vault Dweller[/i]

Fallout Shelter is a entertaining little time killer which made its way, quite successfully, over from mobile/tablet.

As the overseer of your own vault you get to build rooms to expand your vault, staff rooms with dwellers to keep the vault running and try to keep raiders at bay.

All of the dwellers in your vault can be renamed for customisation (as can the pets) and once the barbershop unlocks [spoiler](at population 50)[/spoiler] your dweller's appearance can also be customised (but not the pets).  Equip your dwellers with weapons and stat boosting outfits to make your vault the best vault a vault can be.

Quests can also be unlocked through the overseer's office [spoiler](at population 18)[/spoiler] to send your dweller's out on specific missions.  Alternatively you can just send them out to wonder in the wasteland, they might find something useful (better chance the longer they're gone).

Well worth the cost of the game!

[u]tl;dr (summary)[/u]
[u]pros[/u]
[list]
[*]customise your dwellers
[*]build your own vault
[*]quests
[*]pets
[/list]
[u]cons[/u]
[list]

I started playing Fallout Shelter within days of it's release 2 years ago.  The game had a chronic issue with save files disappearing or corrupting, forcing the player to constantly manually back up the save game files every time you played to counter this.

It seemed like that after a while that the problem had been dealt with and so I stopped the constant file back up and enjoyed Bethesda's little time-water.  I even made a couple in-game purchases to support the game.

Fast forward two years (almost to the day) and I started the game to find out that the problem had never been solved.   The Vault that I had spent two years building (aiming for 200 dwellers with max level/max stats) had corrupted and, with no manual back up, has been forever lost.

Multiple backups of save game files is something from the 1990's and has long since been solved so why it is still an issue for this game is beyond me.  Personally, I think everyone who has had this issue should post a negative review to alert potential new players away from the game.

Many would ask "Why bother?  It's a "free" game."  To this I would say that Bethesda HAS made money from this game and will most likely continue to do so.  They have obviously done little or nothing to fix the issue and most likely never will since any revenue from the game is trivial by their standards.

Also, let's be honest, they've got bigger problems as they are busy imploding their company.

Almost fun game with visual appeal.  Annoyingly amateurish programming.  Clicking is either amazingly imprecise, or the precision is in choosing any possible element you didn't want over the character that you're directly on. Once in a while the rng throws you a bone.  If Bethesda wanted me to recommend the game to others, they would have to fix the very real issues with the game.  They have enough fans that they won't bother. Cheers!

Free and Fun For Fans of Fallout, but...

YOU HAVE TO NAME YOUR PEOPLE WITH NUMBERS, because health bars have no numerical display anywhere (like really? WTF?) and each dweller's max HP is based on their Endurance at each level-up (a number which can vary greatly over time and from dweller to dweller). Roughly, a lvl 1 dweller has about 100 hp, a lvl 50 dweller raised with 1 Endurance has about 300hp, and a lvl 50 dweller raised with 17 Endurance (the maximum amount possible) has over 600hp. This is a huge range of values and SOMETHING YOU NEED TO KNOW IN A GAME THAT IS ENTIRELY NUMBER-BASED. Without viewing your save file in an unofficial editor, you will never know the actual number, instead only inferring values based on how much damage they take relative to one another.

What can I say... Fallout + Old School Facebook games + a twist = Fallout Shelter
