Fun at the beginning, frustrating towards the end.
One can see this is a mobile port, but this doesn't bother. Easy concept with basic management of the vault. There is some questing, leveling, training, impregnating, looting, plus Mr. Handy and Pets. The game is loaded with fallout references and has quite a big load of humor. 
Now, the problem here are small issues and difficulty carve. The deathclaws and radscorpions (btw. seriously? I ware killing those with the spear in original Fallout) are serious challenge. That wouldn't be a problem normally, but the click boxes are not align correctly, and health bar is eaten rapidly (btw. I don't know why but the damage is always much bigger in the larger room then in smaller ones). At the end although player is clicking on the dweller, the stimpacks and rad aways are not always activated, and dwellers die. Again, that wouldn't be a tragic, but like game says itself, rushing rooms is main caps earner (and at some stage radscorpions occur frequently). Sure, one can pass the rushing future, as well as turn the radio for vault broadcasting only, but deathclaws and radscorpions will still come. At earlier stage of the game incidents are somewhat countered with mysterious stranger and "cap and bottle", but later with larger vault it is really hard to keep up. This is not only due many floors to be scanned, but also due click boxes problem, as well as positioning. The last one is mainly Mysterious Stranger problem, who likes to show just behind the dweller or in the corners of the room that are not visible from all perspectives. With almost no arrival sound while zoomed out that renders him almost completely obsolete, and reducing him to a "lucky shoot" only.
Now, some people are saying the save future is flawed since it doesn't safe basic resources. Well, if one will study closely the truth is revealed. This is a future not a bug. Mr Handy can collect those while not playing the game, and since those are extremely rare, but can be easily bought up, well it's the player and his/her wallet problem :) 
Speaking of micro-transaction, generally they are not so bothersome like in other games. Sure Quantum Cola can speed things significantly, and pets, robots and legendaries can improve things significantly but the game is still fun to play without paying.
Speaking of I really don't understand Nuka-Cola plant. The description is wrong, as it's not producing Nuka Cola. It looks like it was suppose to produce Quantum Cola at the beginning, but developers found it too powerful and change it for resources. That move makes on the other hand some buildings questionable.
The game runs without problems under Steamplay (Linux).
Perfect for anyone who enjoys management, levelling up and construction. I think it's a terrific game, especially great for short bursts when you're having a break or waiting for something.

These attacks were so very annoying and made no sense to me since I wasn't even heading out into the wasteland and yet these creatures constantly were finding us, breaking the doors, and somehow making their way through my entire 8 floor vault.  Not cool...not fun...no more playtime for me.  If you enjoy the game then I say great for you, but after 19 hours, I have had enough and will not be playing this anymore.  Thank you for reading.

If you like SimTower, or similar games like Project Highrise, you might like this one. If you are content to wait awhile while your rooms produce (2-30 min real time), and don't mind managing hands on with matching your characters attributes to the rooms, and constantly monitoring your consumption to production ratios, you will be rewarded.

But, if you are only in it for your characters to run the quests, odds are, you will be disappointed. Be forewarned, this one does continue calculating time in the background while you are not playing it, and room production is in real time.  Fortunately while you aren't playing the game, the negative game events (infestations, fires, raiders etc) don't happen, and production appears to be autocollected since the characters don't die. There is no way of pausing the game, nor of manually speeding up the game. However, you can finish some tasks faster (such as armor or weapon building or speeding up overseer quests) with Nuka Cola Quantum, which you can either find by your characters going on quests, or by buying with real world money. There is no shortage of microtransactions in this game, unfortunately.  You can even buy "lunchboxes", which contain loot cards, or pet crates, which contain pets that enhance your characters, with real money, although some quests do reward them as well.

As far as free to play games go this one is fairly good and non-exploitative.  The special currency Nuka Quantum can be earned in game just from doing quests and completing missions, and none of the buildings are locked behind needing the currency. Lunchboxes are kind of a bummer to have a RNG box but you can also earn them in game.

It does however have some short falls.  End game gets repetitive since once you've built out your vault its mostly crafting legendaries, training/collecting vault dwellers, and continuing to do quests.  The quests also suffer from a limited background scene pool and are missing some variety in Fallout enemies such as the robots and super mutants.

Also from a game play perspective it hampers the experience that you can't set dwellers exploring the Wasteland to automatically return when they run out of stimpacks, which feels needlessly punishing if you only want to log in once a day or so like you'll likely want when you reach end game.

Characters such as Butch and Lucas Simms make an appearance. Neat game to kill time or when you have nothing else to play.

I love this game! I first played it on my kiddo's Switch, since she wasn't really using the damn thing, and got addicted pretty quick. So, when I purchased more Switch games for her and she started hogging it, I decided to pick it up on the PC. I have to say, as a native PC gamer, that it's a lot easier to navigate here. I love the customizable hotkeys and simple but appealing interface. 

Like most free games, it does have microtransactions. You can either get what are essentially loot boxes containing random items, all of which can be obtained by playing the game normally, or Nuka-Cola to speed up time-constrained things. The game is still completely playable and fun without those purchases, so don't let that put you off!

Also, if you're worried that it won't be fun because you're part of the tiny percentage of people who haven't played any of the previous Fallout games, don't. I had next to no knowledge of the Fallout universe when I started playing Shelter and it never stunted me. There are trivia encounters where they ask you questions about previous games, but those are uncommon and all the answers can be found on Google (or, in my case, by asking your nerd boyfriend who HAS played all the Fallout games).

I really love this game but it gives me every reason to hate it. I have spent many many hours playing this game and for whatever reason it says I have 2 hours of play time on record which doesnt bother me. The part that does bother me however is the fact that after starting the game that I had all those hours in to I realized that ALL of my items were missing. All 35 of my characters had above average weapons and armor that took a very frustratingly long time to aquire and now every one has on vault suits and no weapons which will be awesome when its time for my shelter to be attacked. All 15 of my nuka cola were gone but for some reason it decided to spare my caps. I have no idea why it happened. Nothing went wrong with it while playing and I always shut down the game properly rather than just just exiting out of it. As much as I love this game I cant recommend it unless you are a HUGE fan of frustration and aggravation.

While it is a mobile game, it does a great job at making itself not feel quite like a mobile game.  It is very fun, very addicting, but can grow to get a bit repetitive or dull if you play it for long sessions.  Its a great game to spend anywhere from a few minutes to an hour a day on, and does a decent enough job at keeping your attention.

End game is a bit lacking, especially when your vault basically becomes max sized.  You can basically do everything and collect everything there is in this game, although i'd imagine it would take quite awhile.

This was a mobile game at first so there are micro-transactions.  While they are briefly advertised to you, I never once felt like micro-transactions and Lunch Boxes were being forced on me nor did I feel like they were overly advertised.

My overall verdict on this game is a 8/10.  The best element of this game is balance,  Bethesda Game Studios did a great job balancing this game, and keeping just enough content in front of the player to either hold their attention or ultimately draw them back into the game.  I've lost count of how many times I've revisited Fallout Shelter over the years!

Great little game, lots of fun in a lightweight package. Low resource usage, loads fast, plays fast (except waiting for items to complete, time to destination on quest, etc). Simple, cartoonish graphics, 2D view with perspective ("almost 3D"?).

I've yet to find a pay wall, you can play for free & have fun doing so. Gameplay is faster if you buy robots ("Mr Handy") and Nuka-Cola Quantum, but that's up to you. I've played nearly 300 hours & spent under $20 at this writing. The game hasn't crashed except when my computer did (including power outages).

Aside from mouse pointer accuracy (think shotgun instead of rifle), I have no complaints about this game. It will challenge you at times, but any decent game should present challenges. Hark, I hear the Wastelands calling...

What a GREAT time waster. the perfect game for busy people. Easy to pick up and put down. But don't think that you can't spend a few hours on this game either. If you are patient you don't have to spend a dime for their pay for extras. Have fun!

Not too bad for a mobile game port. 

Doesn't require spending money on. I never did. You could if you like, but there is only one thing to buy. Lunchboxes, which contain pets, dwellers, caps, items etc but there is nothing you can't obtain in the main game with patience. 

Just a fun little management-lite game. Not a lot of depth to it, but enough to be fun to click in between doing other things while you're on your PC. Most mobile games are just blatant cash grabs with little to no, and mostly mindless gameplay. This is one of the few mobile games I've ever actually put more than 5 minutes into so, maybe that says something for it all by itself. 

If you like Fallout, or like achievement hunting, or both, definitely install it and click away, using your dwellers to play out weird fantasies by renaming them and breeding them etc. 

:D

This game was original a mobile game, which you really can see by the very simplistic gameplay.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
You are the overseer of a vault and have to manage it. There are a different rooms you have to build and maintain. There are people in your vault which different skills the S.P.E.C.I.A.L skills from the series. Each room have a skill assigned to them. If you put a dweller with the same skill, will the room work more effecient. This is basiclly whatthe game is about at the start. However it will pick up, when you got dwellers with higher skills, that can scavenge for you and later, go on quests. This game does have some RNG to it. First of all, when you sent of your dweller to the wilderness, there is a chance they die out there especially if you just leave them for hours. The loot they bring back also depends on the amount of time they are out there and it also seems to be affected by your luck skill. There  is also loot crates in this game and you will get them frecently while playing. These give everything from resources to a known NPC like Preston Garvey or an OP fatman.

[h1] Story [/h1]
There are not really a story. There is quests you can go on and they do have small stories to them. However, there is no "main quest" and the stories isn't good or serious like the orignial series.

[h1] Other [/h1]
This game is a free game and a mobile game, so there is a "P2W" part, but it is not really gamebreaking. This game will does NOT have a paywall and gives you the oppotunity to use money for completing the game faster, but it is in no way necessary to enjoy the game. The game does have a starting package which will help you in 1 of your vaults. I bought that for 5‚Ç¨ and helped get through the boring start.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
This is a fun little game you can play if you are bored or want to shit a chill with a movie and a cold drink. If you are like me, it is hard to just sit and do nothing while watching series and movies. This game is perfect for that "stay busy" feeling.

The quest to find a management sim to replace my HunieCam Studio addiction continues. And continues to fail.

   Well over an hour in, I don't seem terribly adept at making much progress [i]or[/i] screwing up spectacularly. So while I can't personally attest to how much forking over extra dough helps, I'm inclined to believe those who say that this game requires an extraordinary amount of grinding if you're not willing to, ahem, "make a small donation" in order to speed it all up.

   Honestly, after said hour-plus, I'm kinda bored. I'm still happy to "recommend" it, 'cause it's free, it's cute (in a bleak kinda way), and I can see it appealing to a certain kind of person. Since I'm not much of a "grinder", I'm sadly [i]not[/i] that kind of person.

   And whoa, some of the [i]prices[/i] you can choose to pay! I'll pass...but it was a mildly interesting experience for a wee while at least. (I certainly understand more about human reproduction now. Not to put it indelicately, but I believe one of my womenfolk may have canoodled in the diner with two men, while another woman watched. I'm not sure how she got pregnant otherwise...)

   Verdict: 6.5/10.

Fallout Shelter makes no apologies for its outrageous nature. It's a power fantasy in every sense of the phrase, placing you in a world rife with destructible environments and giving you creative instruments with which to destroy them. There are intermittent technical problems, and scripted moments detract from the freedom found elsewhere, but in the end, Fallout Shelter provides a spectacular, explosive sandbox experience.

The plot revolves around returning protagonist Rico Rodriguez, who's arrived in the fictional Republic of Medici during the height of Sebastiano Di Ravello's military dictatorship. The story here is forgettable, but delivers an effective invitation: dozens of military installations cover the world map, and it's your job to blow them up for the rebel forces.

Rodriguez himself is a mashup of masculine action stars and comic book characters, so it makes sense that I often felt like a superhero in his shoes. By supplying you with a wingsuit, parachute, and grappling hook, Fallout Shelter gives you an effective means of transportation, as well as a smooth, nuanced traversal system.

There is a steep learning curve, but with practice, I was leaping from helicopters, gliding through enemy bases, and floating over farmland with ease. It's thrilling to leap from a cliff, free-fall for 10 seconds, grapple to a nearby rock, and use the momentum to launch back into the air with parachute deployed. Rico actually felt like a hero learning his new skillset. It's as if Avalanche Studios combined Batman, Spider-Man, and The Punisher, and thrust its creation into a vivid Mediterranean landscape.

I'm really confuzed why this "game" has so many positive reviews, it's barely a game. It's made just for micro transactions, if you like that go for it. It's ridiculously easy, no challange. Only good thing it's free to install.

Fallout Shelter is a game where the player owns his vault and can manage as he want.
The player starts with some dwells that helped build the vault, given the status of each one, if one has higher strength, it is logical to go to one of the resources that requires this status. When more features more dwells will be accurate and vice versa. They may come from the desert or as babies of the next generation.

The player can send dwells on missions that may take real time. As soon as they arrive at the destination, you have to explore by clicking and attacking the mission boss and waiting for the return of these dwells to arrive.

We must defend the vaut of the invaders from time to time, and for this the player can equip their dwells with a booed number of Armor and Weapons, being able to Crafting or catch of the dead enemies.

The only drawback to this type of games is that they are repetitive after some time, but I think the Fallout Shelter is great for chilling out in short breaks.

But attention!!!! Always record before you leave the game because otherwise you will lose all progress.

And besides it‚Äôs free, existing almost for each platform, so anyone who wants to spend a good bit in the short pause strength in it.

From the very beginning the game has small issues, but they are for the most part bearable. It feels like a rather bad PC port because of how often you will be unable to click dwellers even though you were clicking right on them, and you will often accidentally move one when trying to click-and-drag the screen. The way combat works also makes it so you will waste stimpacks and radaway very quickly, even more so when the game decides to have a difficulty spike around 50-60 dwellers.
Invasions are also done extremely poorly, and you might as well not bother upgrading your vault door or even bothering to have someone sitting on defense because of how little they matter in the end. Enemies will move from room to room so fast that your actual defending dwellers will be unable to keep up and deal any significant damage, and because combat causes a whole room to take damage over time a single entirely-random radscorpion or deathclaw attack can require you to waste half your entire supply of stimpaks. There's no actual challenge to take on, and balance never really exists in the game.

The game itself quickly becomes very frustrating to play, however. Once you reach a certain point you will end up facing enormous problems and are almost forced to pay. Not too surprising for a game like this, but considering the frustration with many other features of this game its hard to convince yourself to drop any money on it. 

Honestly, its really hard to recommend, especially if you want a game to throw money at. It has a ton of design problems that you can't even play around due to how awkwardly events are programmed. It's worth trying since its free, but you will likely uninstall before you ever consider purchasing something.

Fallout Shelter is a rather lazy mobile cash in of the franchise. It lacks any kind of depth or challenge and is the kind of mindless busy work you expect from similar management sims that are a dime a dozen in any app store. Super mutants and the Brotherhood of Steel are inexplicably missing, and missions are a randomly generated exercise in tedium. This is especially true once you fully upgrade a few dwellers and they become virtually impervious to anything the Wasteland has to offer, at which point the game really starts to cry out for an Auto Play button that would auto clear missions and auto grab the loot, while you browse the web or watch a movie. There is a Survival mode which is supposedly more challenging, but considering how broken the click detection is, I can only imagine the kind of frustration that mode would entail. If losing dwellers because the game refuses to acknowledge your clicks on the stim pack button was not frustrating enough, just wait until it starts playing with your camera, zooming in every time a dialogue starts or flying to a different room altogether because something ‚Äúimportant‚Äù is happening there. The idea of being an Overseer and running your own vault is an exciting one, but sadly, this is not it.

Lacks the depth and many possible aspects of an actual game (its a mobile game, after all), but a good way to kill time every now and then. Though its wiser to grab a book :)

First, let me say that I liked this game. It's a new take on the Fallout universe and it's fun to build. It was highly addicting, at first, but quickly becomes monotonous. Nothing ever really changes. You have the occasional attack by raiders or beasts that have little trouble destroying the vault door (with pistols or claws) and then go on a rampage through your vault. The dwellers on the floor will fight, but the rest just go about their business as if oblivious to the flashing red lights and alarms. The expeditions aren't any better. Six hours to travel to kill some raiders holed up in some SD Mart or office building. Of course, you can use some Quantum, which is rare and usually requires much more than what can be looted so must be purchased with real money or just wait and wait and wait while trying to remain interested in what's going on back at the vault. There too is a bunch of waiting to build skills so dwellers are more capable at their duties and more combat effective. I liked this game, but I cannot recommend it to any other than those with a lot of time to kill that just casually peek in on their vault from time to time. I played six days and lost interest. Have no real desire to go back either so my vault is probably dead or in dire straights anyway. In short, it's a shooting star that fizzles out rather quickly.

Survival, crafting, base building and micro management game developed by Bethesda as an offspin for the Fallout series. It is well made and fun to play.

Fallout Shelter is a Free to Play (F2P) idle progression game that wears a mask. It pretends to be more of a base building game and a survival crafting game but really it is just another idle progression game. You must send a dweller out into the Wasteland to explore and bring home resources and those all important Caps. You don't controll that dweller it just does everything on its own and it takes time, while that dweller is out there you concentrate on building your base out, you can build power, storage, living quarters and a canteen for food. Each room must have at least one dweller in to produce whatever resource they are making, it takes time. You can eventually have upto 6 dwellers in a single room which speeds up the process of making resources and you can also build a large variety of rooms. 

Dwellers each have their S.P.E.C.I.A.L skills that can be trained up in training rooms similar to the Fallout series and more dwellers can be found in the Wasteland or by opening lunchboxes. Lunchboxes can be either found when doing quests in the Wasteland, by completing challenges or you can choose to buy them with real money. Most of your dwellers will come from breeding with each other in the living quarters. Once a male dweller warms upto a female dweller they will begin dancing and one thing leads to another and you have a child.

Once you have built the Overseer's Office you can send upto 3 dwellers on a quest in the Wasteland to fetch certain rewards, these can be anything from Nuka Cola Quantum, Lunchboxes, Pets, Outfits, Weapons and so on. There are quite often new daily and weekly quests to go on and when there are Seasonal updates such as Halloween or Christmas there are also some special outfits and themed quests you can go on too. Seasonal updates also change the look of diners and living quarters in your vault.

All in all this is a very fun free game to play, I love the fallout theme, the base building and crafting gear or weapons, personally I like the idle progression type aspect to the game and I think that the fact you don't need to spend real money in the game to enjoy it has been done really well, all things can be earned in game without spending money.

[h1]Fallout Shelter[/h1]
Fallout Shelter is a free2play mobile game based on the Fallout franchise that was ported to pc and console due to its popularity. The story is extremely minimal; you are the overseer of a vault, and your job is to build and maintain your vault. giving your dwellers jobs, making them happy, have them "reproduce" so you have more dwellers to populate the vault, protecting them from the wasteland (or sending them out into the wasteland to look for supplies). and when you get enough dwellers (18 to be precise) you can send a team of dwellers on special missions that can get you some decent supplies if completed. but the main job of an overseer is...to rebuild America. pretty much the game is a resource management sim based in the Fallout universe. you have to juggle power, food, and water. if you don't have food or water, your dwellers die, the more dwellers you get, the more rooms you'll need, which means you need more power, you also need to make sure your dwellers are happy, so they make more resources. There are also other rooms, such as stat rooms (which train your dweller's special stats), med bays and science labs (which allow you to produce Stimpacks and Radaway respectively), crafting rooms (where you can craft weapons, outfits and even themes that change the decor of your diners and living quarters), dweller quarters (which you need for housing dwellers as well as dweller "reproduction") and many more!

[b]Pros[/b]
+ Simple click and drag gameplay, that's easy to learn
+ A cute cartoony art style
+ Fun quests to send your dwellers on
+ You can customize your dweller's names and appearances.
+ a survival mode for expert players. Your vault will have constant attacks, resources deplete faster and if any your dwellers die, they die permanently (this mode is not for the faint of heart)
+ It's free

[b]Cons[/b]
-  Lootboxes. Lootboxes in any game are absolute garbage, do not buy them! Don't make the mistake I did and buy fallout shelters Lootboxes (i brought the cheapest pack when the game was first brought to pc, and I only ever did this once), because if you lose your save file, all that money you spent is wasted. But if you REALLY want them for whatever reason, you can always get a Fallout Shelter savefile editor and just spawn some in. and for those who are worried... No, because it's an offline, singleplayer game, so you won't get a VAC-ban for editing the savefiles (mainly pointing this out because I've seen people ask that question in the past), also, no, there is nothing wrong with "cheating" in a single player game.
- It can get a bit repetitive and boring after a few days
- This is more of a minor complaint, but I wish that there were more enemy types that you could encounter on quests (some example that would be cool; Super Mutants, mirelurks, Enclave soldiers, robots, giant ants or even synths. More varieties of enemies would have been cool)

All in all, the PC port of Fallout Shelter is okay for a free2play game (unlike the Xbox and PlayStation ports of this game. Those had absolute shit controls). It can get quite boring after a while though, but at the very least it's free.

A lot of these free to play games are pretty cheap and unenjoyable, however, Fallout Shelter is a very good example of NOT this. Instead of rare and legendary items being a hassle to get to like in other free to play games, Bethesda's game is very generous by offering a Vault Lunch Box at leasy every 7 days launching and playing the game, and offers these lunchboxes as rewards for quests by sending out vault dwellers or by completing challenges around the vault. Of course there is an option to purchase them if you really want to. For me the game doesn't get boring, collecting vast amounts of loot, items and weaponry is always a thrill as I increase the strength of my vault and ensure each and every vault member becomes stronger and stronger on their own with higher levels and better weaponry. A game which allows you to get high up, for free and with some fun, is what Fallout Shelter is. The combat system is simple, yes, but it doesn't seem to get to me as I build my vault larger and stronger, explore the locations of the wasteland, and complete all of the quests I got with my special team of elite vault dwellers. One of the best free to play games out there, for sure.

Fallout Shelter does not offer a story-filled experience, but the action revolves around gathering resources and clicking. It, like many other idle games, consists of short sessions during which only the necessary things are done. The collection of resources takes place in an instant, and no other activity takes much time.

In addition to collecting, the brave can be sent to explore the environment and their activities will be monitored in real time in the form of text. In this case, your own imagination acts as an illustrator. A fun feature, even though the events are almost the same all the time.

The visual style works just as well as the original Fallout. It even works so well that it gives the desire to play through Fallout: New Vegas again.
Fallout Shelter is a bomb-proof package for a true fan, in which even real money may be accidentally embedded.

I have played Fallout Shelter on Android and iOS first, but always felt there was something missing. For me, mobile is a system for casual gaming only, where you make few clicks and then close the game for couple of hours or a day. I was never very interested to advance in the game on its mobile version. I have decided to play this game again on PC and boy the experience is totally different! I like it a lot. When I have some work to do on my computer I keep it open but do not ignore it and keep playing and making some changes. Those little Dewllers has become important to me! The game is very addictive and I am taking my time in advancing.

I have to say that the game plays very well with mouse and keyboard as well as a controller (I used both Steam and PS4 controllers). The experience is flawless in both cases. I thought this game was a casual one that is why it is available on mobile platform but if you play it more you will know that it is not, it is more a game of micromanagement that needs you to play actively. You will advance faster and grow further if the game is open and you actively playing it which I like.

Fallout Shelter is more fun on PC than on mobile, The micromanagement aspect of it needs you to have the game open and you actively playing it. I rate Fallout Shelter 4.0 stars out of 5.0 for the addicition and replayability values.

So what is there to say? It's any other Fallout. But, without all of the fun fighting mechanics or missions. It's clever, and simple. Being an Overseer is fun, and it puts you into the shoes of a real one. It's brighter than most Fallout games, it's easy to control, and the premise is easy to grasp. So, in all, I recommend Fallout Shelter to anybody who thought, "I wonder how it feels to manage a vault."  Play if you don't have the money for Fallout 4!

Pros:
--Free to play (but do have optional micro-transactions)
--Simple and relaxed concept. Equip and send someone scavenge the wastelands, or send a team of 3 do quests. Build and upgrade your vault shelter.
--Great for achievements hunters. They`re somewhat easy to do, but require some grinding. On a side note about the legendary dweller one, you can found duplicates of a legendary dweller you already have and they`ll all count towards the achievements. You have the achievement with 20 Sarah Lyons, for example.

Cons: 
--That being said, doing all this stuff will eventually get repetitive. Although, some quests will appear for a limited time. Like in Halloween or Thanksgiving period, and give limited edition outfits and stuff.
--The click and drag function can get glitchy by having the camera dragged instead of a dweller, it`s really annoying.
--Strangely enough, no super mutants in this game. I mean, seriously?!? Human kindness wasn`t even great enough to put Strong as a legendary dweller. Sad..

Great time killer, over time, not all at once.

The best tip I can give anyone who gives this a go is to be patient. Don't worry about trying to rush progress. 

The game is also intended for those who intend to spend time over several months playing it, so if you like to smash out progress, then this isn't the game for you.

Even with a lucky start, progress will be slow. Even once you have made progress, progress will be slow. 
To make a legendary weapon, it takes 10 days to craft. I'm at the point where only legendary weapons will improve my dwellers and that kind of time for crafting massively delays any real progress once you get to the midway point of the game. Missions are beginning to take between 1/2 and a full day to travel to. 

This is in no way a negative review, the only negative aspect I have found in the game is the quest combat, which has gotten my dwellers killed a couple of times as they sometimes like to run to the opposite side of a room before they start shooting the first enemy they passed. Sometimes they just forget to shoot at all for like 10 seconds. Sometimes you will get a mission which requires everyone to be in hazmat suits, but be aware, it's a trick. Forget the radaways because the real danger is damage.

All in all, solid game, solid gameplay for what it is. Enjoyable but it starts to fade as you make progress and realize further progress takes ridiculous time.

Fallout Shelter is a charming little casual Free 2 Play basebuilding game.

The game is playable without Pay 2 Win features which is a definate improvement over most Free 2 Play titles.   There is no PvP mode, which further reduces the problematic behavior of Pay 2 Win.

Unfortunately there aren't purchase limits and most of the purchases are "boxes" with unknown content.  Two negative points on the whole Pay 2 Win aspect. 

For Linux users it works near perfectly with Linux under SteamPlay.

As of the game itself, it is plenty fun and will keep you occupied for several hours.   It is well worth the try.  I more then recommend the game.

A good game for wasting time, entertaining and the beginning but becomes repetitive in the endgame. The most fun part in my opinion is when you are just starting out and setting up your vault. It‚Äôs a good game, even if it is old and isn‚Äôt updated anymore.

Basically a clicker game with some resource management and explore-fight-and-loot quests once you have the overseer center to send your dweller out to specific locations, not just wasteland exploration in general. And if the game runs you MUST click the rooms to collect power, water and food (or have Mr. Handy do that) or you will quickly have everyone die.
It starts of very slow and only becomes more of a real game that keeps you occupied once you have the overseer command center and some dweller to spare for sending them out on quests. I'm currently at a bit over 80 dweller and have frequent attacks by very strong ghoul hordes or those ... upright giant rat like creatures. They do a LOT of damage so I have my upper floor full of guards, the whole 3-room barrack just after the vault door is just full with heavily armed guards by now as they cause so much damage otherwise if they break through. And I go through the stimpaks at frightening paces.
Keeps me quite busy.

But it becomes hard to manage the vault at this size already. You barely ever see the spy to click him and it needs crazy amounts of caps to upgrade rooms like the nuclear plant or the water purification facility (9000? 15,000? Seriously??). The quests don't yield even remotely enough caps to handle this and the weapon I find are way too weak and mostly useless but salvage gives only items that are of no need to craft the high level ones. I basically have a storage of 120 nearly constantly full but can't craft anything useful as the items I lack never drop in salvage or quests or exploration. Free exploration causes usually the explorer to end up dead as the mobs over a few hours or over night just get too much. Can't send them off with so mach stimpaks to survive and reviving them costs quite a few caps again...

So with a bit over 18 hours in after a few month I must say I enjoyed the recent Halloween event but don't feel to pay a cent for this nor play much further. It just seems pointless grindy and frustrating inventory management after a while.

Maybe one of the very best free games ever made. Addictive, clever, with varied contents, and micro-transactions are not mandatory to have fun. IMO somewhat rekindles the elements that made Dungeon Keeper a joy to play, without trying to imitate it (War for the Overlord, Dungeons). I actually prefer this game over those two examples!

Fallout Shelter is a free to play management game with quests, combat, and baby-making. Everything is very easy to learn and pick up and all of the different activities are more than enough to keep one occupied.

The Vault Dwellers, the characters you control, all work very smoothly and offer some humorous comments or easter eggs from time to time.

My only gripe with the game is that it will get stale after a while, but before then you should be able to get in plenty of time to enjoy all of the various actions and events Fallout Shelter has to offer.

10/10, really worth giving it a try.

This is a cute game, but it was a little disappointing. I dislike the push to spend real money for things, but I guess that's to be expected with free-to-play games. Also, it turns out this is not the kind of game you can put down for a week then come back to and remember how to play. In all, not something I wanted to spend more time on.
Good game

In Fallout Shelter you manage your own post-holocaust vault and fill it with inhabitants. In order to run it properly you need to be able to balance the set-up of the vault. You need power, water, food et.c. and you also need people with specific skills on the right places in order to maximize the output of specific resources.

As you grow your numbers of inhabitants you can dig deeper and expand your vault. You can equip and send your inhabitants into the wasteland. Either on specific missions or just to explore. Defend your vault against raiders and much more.

Overall its simple to learn but still very enjoyable and addictive. I can highly recommend this one.

Fallout Shelter started as a typical BS "freemium" game, made for mobile phones.  The mobile game market is aimed at those who are susceptbile to addiction, and the games exploit players in a way very similar to gambling.  There are lots of slot-machine-like sounds, and visual stimuli for completing milestones and objectives.  Payouts are randomized to encourage habitual attention.  Unlike gambling though, you'll never get money back out of it.

The game is also a grindfest, making you perform tedious tasks, and wait for long periods of time.  The waiting times gradually increase, eventually getting to as much as 2 WEEKS to complete tasks.  That's 14 days of real-world time.  For example, it would take 1 dweller with decent stats 2 weeks to make one top-level weapon.  The reason it's so difficult to accomplish anything is simple: if you make players feel impatient, the most addicted players will pay real money to advance toward their goals.

The gameplay mechanics are severely broken.  The combat is sluggish, and not interactive in any significant way.  The "mysterious stranger" random events are frequently interrupted by incident events, which automatically move the camera away from the Where's Waldo 5-second mini game, which by the way is already almost impossible due to the time limit.

Games like this are not made to be fun.  They're made to exploit players.

If you play this, expect to check in for a few minutes at a time, while you essentially babysit the game all day.  Every day.  Forever.  It's more of an obligation than an actual game.

They could easily make it more fun by reducing the requirements to complete objectives, or by speeding up combat, or adding V.A.T.S. to combat, or by increasing the variety of activities available.  They won't do that though, because it's a lazy cash grab.

Fallout Shelter is a beautifully simple game from a structural point of view. You have a vault. You can build rooms in the vault, and people can do things in the rooms. The vault is just a two-dimensional grid laid out like you're looking inside an ant farm (except it's a people farm). Rooms are 1x3 in dimension, elevator shafts (of which you only need one, thankfully) are 1x1, and most rooms can be "merged" - just build the same room type next to it, and it will expand into a 1x6, and you can add one more room next to that for a 1x9. The latter is the maximum size of any room. You keep building and building to advance in the game.
Inside these rooms, you place your vault dwellers, grabbing them Roller Coaster Tycoon style and plucking them up and setting them down where you'd like them to go. What happens in the rooms? Things! Let's explain the basic mechanics.
The first mechanic to know is resources. You have power (electricity), water, and food. Those are your necessities. You have a baseline requirement for each of these resources, and you gather them by building rooms that generate them. If you have insufficient power, some of your other rooms will stop functioning. If you have insufficient water or food, your vault dwellers will start losing health over time. The only reason I can tell that water and food are separate resources is that Bethesda felt like there needed to be three things to "balance" production of. You also have caps, which are the currency you use to build and upgrade rooms.
The second mechanic is dwellers. Your vault starts with a few people, and from there you go through a tutorial explaining how to build rooms, which rooms to build, how they work, and how to progress. Here's the gist: you build your three resource rooms, you assign people to them, and then you also build "living quarters." Living quarters are where your vault dwellers will produce offspring (the euphemism for sex in Fallout Shelter is a confetti-explosion of happy-faces in front of an obscured corridor in the living quarters), and those offspring eventually become adults, and those adults eventually go on to work in rooms or produce other offspring. The details go beyond that, but we'll get there.
The third and final major mechanic is the wasteland. The wasteland isn't something you interact with - you send vault dwellers into the wastes and they go "explore." You can monitor the status of their exploration via text feed on the exploration UI (you can't actually see what they're doing). During exploration, your dwellers will gather currency, weapons, and outfits. They will also fight enemies and gain experience in doing so. Over time, they will take more and more damage (you can supply them with HP potions [stimpaks] and anti-radiation consumables [Rad-Away]) as the wasteland increases in difficulty the longer they're away from the vault. Eventually, you'll want to "recall" them to the vault so you can collect their plunder. During their return, they take no damage and have no encounters, so as long as you get to them while they're still alive, they'll come back.
Bethesda lays a pretty cut-and-dry groundwork for a game here, and I think that's intentional. By making the basic mechanics quite easy to understand, Fallout Shelter is a more approachable and friendly game than the sort of thing Bethesda typically makes. It's casual.
The depth comes in the form of learning how to expand your vault effectively without overstretching your resources or underdeveloping your vault dwellers. So let's talk about those.
As in the Fallout games of yore, your vault dwellers have something called their "S.P.E.C.I.A.L." stats. Those, in order, stand for Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck. They are the quintessential RPG character stats. Each dweller is born with pretty boring stats, and they also start at level one, so there is a leveling system, too. Leveling does not increase your SPECIAL stats. Instead, leveling only increases a dweller's hit points, and leveling is achieved by either working in a production room in the vault (making power, food, water, nuka-cola, stimpaks, or rad-away) or exploring the wasteland.
A character will gain experience while you're not playing, and they level up pretty often (my peak level character right now is at 32, though most are in their mid-high teens). Increasing SPECIAL stats has to happen in dedicated "training" rooms, with each room devoted to a particular stat. Over time, dwellers in these rooms will gain a single point in that stat, which you must acknowledge (you can't just leave the game sitting for days, sorry) for each point gained in order to continue the training. Obviously, the higher a given stat gets, the longer it takes for training to boost it another point. While training, dwellers gain no experience, either, and thus won't level up.
he purpose of the SPECIAL stats is in increasing the effectiveness of your dwellers at particular tasks. Want Johnny Nuclear to be better at running the power generator? Send him to the strength training room for a day. Once his strength is at the level you want, send him back to the generator room. Fallout Shelter doesn't just use these as a way to boost the output of resources from these rooms by quantity, but instead in terms of how long it takes the room to spawn new resources. Resources are managed in terms of an absolute quantity, but because they're consumed over time, Fallout Shelter doesn't want you building a ton of power rooms, hoarding a bunch of power, then destroying them so you can make more useful training areas or food production and otherwise attempt to game the system in some way. So, if you have a Level 3 Power Generator (each resource room can be upgraded twice to increase its production and the maximum amount of the resource you may store) that creates 40 power every time it "pops," increasing the combined Strength trait of dwellers working in that room from 10 to, say, 15, will decrease the amount of time between "pops." So you'll get 40 power every 90 seconds instead of every 120. Got it? It's a lot simpler in practice to understand than it is to write it out, trust me.
Your dwellers' SPECIAL stats can also be boosted by outfits they can wear, outfits you'll get exploring the wasteland. All your adult dwellers can equip weapons, too (also found while exploring), and these weapons are used in events called "incidents." Once in a while, raiders will attack your vault. At this point, you should send two dwellers with guns (and high levels) to your vault entrance, and once the raiders inevitably break in to the vault, a fight will ensue. The fight mechanics are terrible and boring and lazy - it's completely automated and once you have a sufficiently high enough level group of dwellers with decent guns, completely devoid of any strategy or challenge. Worst part of the game, in my opinion. The other "incident" requiring guns is radroach infestations (read: giant, mean radioactive cockroaches), which occur both at random and when you attempt to "rush" a building into instantly producing resources and fail (success rates are typically 65-80%, though, if you don't try repeatedly). Radroach infestations and fires keep you honest in terms of equipping your workers with weapons and raising their stats, but again, just feel like annoyances. "Rushing" a building, by the way, is so far as I can tell just a band-aid Bethesda has put in the game to help people who aren't very good at games. It generally serves very little purpose.
So Your main goal is to expand your vault, equip and train your dwellers, make them reproduce to get new dwellers (note: your dwellers do not age once they are adults that I can tell, so they live forever unless you let them die and don't revive them), and then repeat until you reach the bottom of the buildable space under the mountain, if this sounds pointliess congratulations youve reached the crux of our review.

One thing you have to keep in mind: This game was designed for a mobile/tablet.  Meaning, it's not designed for you to sit and play it for hours.  Everything runs on 'real time' regardless if the game is running or not.  

So, send your guys on a quest... and take a break.  ^_^
ProTip: NukaCola cuts time by slightly less than 2 hours.  So, most effecient use is when a timer is just less than a multiple of two.
ProTip2: They are best used to cut down quest time, as the majority of rewards come from quests.
ProTip3: There is hidden factor on HP->  HP gain is based on their endurance at the point when they level.  So, a char with 1 END leveled to 40, then raised END to 10... with have a TINY amount of HP, whereas a char that raises his end to 10 at level 1 will be a beast at lvl 40.
ProTip4: You don't have to to raise their End to 10, just raise to 7 and put on +3 END gear.

Its free and kinda fun for the first few hours but all in all its pointless and ends up being just a daily chore with no purpose.
You lack food - build 1 of 3 rooms to generate it
You lack energy - build 1 of 2 rooms to generate it
You lack water - build 1 of 3 rooms to generate it
Now you have lots of rooms that need 6 dwellers in them to operate on full capacity so you "make" some babies or lure ppl in with a radio station.
But now you lack food water and energy again, so thats your gameplay loop.

In between you can send dwellers out to freeroam in some text adventure style "bring me weapons, scrap, clothes and money" feature or you send them out for scripted quests, which seems to be interactive but truth is that its just clicking on rooms for your dwellers gang of 3 to walk into, wait until they killed everything in it, click shiny corpses and boxes then click the next room to walk into.
And if you get bored of that (which will happen in no time) you can also choose to increase your dwellers "S.P.E.C.I.A.L" stats by putting them into 1 of 7 special training rooms for about an irl week or so until they reach the cap, then put them in a room for a different stat and wait another week again, so much fun and you even have to do it 7x200 times! Wohoo!

But wait there is more boredom to be had! You can also build legendary weapons and outfits in no more than just 150-400 hours of real time! Why would you do that? Well to have more fun in all those boring quests and vault assaults of course, since these items will significantly reduce the time you have to spend looking at super boring auto fights!

But wait you may ask, there has to be something, some mayor endgame challenge at the end of all that preparation, training, scavenging and outfitting!?
NOOO there is absolutely NOTHING else for you to do in here except buying a few lootboxes with insulting contents such as 1 Stimpack, 100 caps, 1 piece of junk, 50 Water and many more items that you can generate hundreds of per hour while you're asleep!

[b]On many levels. No.[/b]

At first, this game appears as simple resource and time management sim with a unique skin, however, it was so hastily coded that there are gaping holes in the programming. Thus far I have lost two shelters one a max stat and dweller facility.  The code is susceptible to force stop corruption.  It is as if the Devs never considered that a cell phone could run out of power or it is impossible for you to be pulled away from your computer for any reason, or hey how about simple brownouts?  This issue is listed all over goggle and despite there being simple programming fixes to update save configurations, we are stuck with complicated file patching that rarely ever works. 

1) [b]Prepare to lose your vault[/b] - It will happen and most likely it won't come back and it will have nothing to do with being attacked.

2) [b]Yelling at the touch screen.[/b]  - Rather than having the GUI mapped to the foreground of your vault,  everything has to be oriented to the background of your vault.  The space that is actually behind your dwellers.   With the 3d viewer, it will leave you clicking on things that are not really there or trying to drop a dweller in the center of an OFF ANGEL room that does not register.  

3) [b]Click locks can lead to character disobedience prolonging battle and costing resources.[/b]

4) [b]Enjoy endless palm scrolling on a computer = major pain.[/b]  You have at least two mouse buttons, and they could not assign one to scroll and another to interact?  This makes moving from the top of the shelter to the bottom a real chore, as you constantly pick up dwellers by accident.  Great way to mess of dwellers' education when they are bouncing between rooms.

5) [b]Some times missions fail to progress.[/b]  Lots of complaints about that.  Played 3 total vaults just to finish the horsemen quests. 

Obvious room for improvement 
1) [b]Multi saves.[/b]  Oh crap, my first save was corrupted.  Solution = Ok here is a save from last week.  OMW what is this?  Do you mean I don't have to lose everything?  Golly gee wiz you're telling me that game publishers figured that out in the 90s? Simply amazing!  

2) [b]Indicators for full rooms[/b] - So tire of counting occupants for classrooms, Circle it with a color or something.

3) [b]Warn before deleting uncraftable gear.[/b]  That crap is rare and can be easy to mistake when it is mixed in with the rest of the crap you are cleaning out of the warehouse.

4) [b]Reaching max junk capacity is pointless.[/b]  Legend Gear is not a money sink only a deterrent early in the game.  Allow players to buy expensive junk.  We can sell everything to nobody why can't we buy at least the junk we need from some traveling merchant.

5) [b]Make HP retroactive.[/b]  Your HP goes up based on endurance vs your level, Simple.  Supper Dwellers raised from level one with 17 endurance and a % to weapon and armor Pets create game braking indestructible for no point while promoting obsoleting the first generation.  Making HP a flexible stat is easier to code.

[b]That is my two cents[/b] but I doubt I will play this again. It is just too frustrating to lose your progress due to bad coding.  This has really burnt me towards the franchise.  I am less interested in the primary games due to the performance of this side game.

First started playing this on my iPhone, but it's nice to play while watching a show since I'm the type of person that has to be doing more than one thing at once. Can take a long time to get enough caps to build rooms etc, but it's a great game once you get into the quests and things of that sort. I like the fact that I can sit there for 5 mins or 50 mins and play it, it's super simple and easy to understand once you've played through the basic tutorial. Can get really repetitive, but that's not always a bad thing.

It's a slow grind if you don't buy lunchboxes (randomized lootcrates) from the store. You'll be prompted to do so multiple times throughout your gaming experience.

The principle of the game beyond that is okay, but the setup is the same in every playthrough because  they put an elevator right behind the entrance and you'll have to jump through a few hoops to move it if you don't want it there.

Every time you create a new vault, it will be on the same map with just a little change in where the heavy rocks are placed. There's little variety there.

The vault dwellers are varied and can eventually be customized through a barbershop, but it takes a long time to get there.

The missions are decent enough to play through, but it takes hours for your vault dwellers to arrive on scene, and then some more for them to return home.

All in, it's enjoyable to boot up, sink a few minutes in to make sure everything still runs as it should, and then ditch it for a few days again while the background timers run down.
Could have been better, but it's simple enough to be accessible to even the most casual player.

Definitely could have been on Mac/Linux considering it's also available on mobile devices.

Its free and kinda fun for the first few hours but all in all its pointless and ends up being just a daily chore with no purpose.
You lack food - build 1 of 3 rooms to generate it
You lack energy - build 1 of 2 rooms to generate it
You lack water - build 1 of 3 rooms to generate it
Now you have lots of rooms that need 6 dwellers in them to operate on full capacity so you "make" some babies or lure ppl in with a radio station.
But now you lack food water and energy again, so thats your gameplay loop.

In between you can send dwellers out to freeroam in some text adventure style "bring me weapons, scrap, clothes and money" feature or you send them out for scripted quests, which seems to be interactive but truth is that its just clicking on rooms for your dwellers gang of 3 to walk into, wait until they killed everything in it, click shiny corpses and boxes then click the next room to walk into.
And if you get bored of that (which will happen in no time) you can also choose to increase your dwellers "S.P.E.C.I.A.L" stats by putting them into 1 of 7 special training rooms for about an irl week or so until they reach the cap, then put them in a room for a different stat and wait another week again, so much fun and you even have to do it 7x200 times! Wohoo!

But wait there is more boredom to be had! You can also build legendary weapons and outfits in no more than just 150-400 hours of real time! Why would you do that? Well to have more fun in all those boring quests and vault assaults of course, since these items will significantly reduce the time you have to spend looking at super boring auto fights!

But wait you may ask, there has to be something, some mayor endgame challenge at the end of all that preparation, training, scavenging and outfitting!?
NOOO there is absolutely NOTHING else for you to do in here except buying a few lootboxes with insulting contents such as 1 Stimpack, 100 caps, 1 piece of junk, 50 Water and many more items that you can generate hundreds of per hour while you're asleep!

At least it made me want to play a real Fallout game again so there's that...

Its basically at the level of many "free" games out there, just at the lower tier of the genere.  Very little plot, charges for quite a bit of stuff, and programmed to the lowest common denominator that they can get away with and still get people to pay.  Doesn't take much to learn how to play, but you have to micromanage far too much for a "play and walkaway" type game, the characters seem to have labotimized before being placed in the game, and information is some of the scantest I've ever seen for a game.  They include a "skill" bar in the characters bio, but they seem to have forgotten to list what the bars stand for.  You've got to familiarize yourself with it by thaking the individual and check it against rooms until you memorize what bar stands for which.  The characters, as pointed out earlier, are pretty stupid.  You take the character to go and confront an emergency, and the emergency spreads, they will run past the new emergency even though it is the same one they're going to confront.

Basically, this is a throwaway game and not something really worth digging into unless you want to spend your entire day micromanaging.  At higher levels, it is probably more interesting as you'll have enough rooms available/products to recover from your base from running out of items while you were off the game.  But the problems with that plus the random accidents makes it more irritating then fun or challanging.

Ah, one of the good ole' idling game. Bethesda had better not to put Android games into PC, because we all know why.

As expected, this game is like one of the Android games. It's just loads and loads of waiting. Then, most of the time, you can skip things by using something, which you have to buy with real money. Typical microtransaction. You get the picture, I won't explain any further.

However, there's 2 silver lining for this game:
1. You can set the clock forward to pass time. You don't even have to close the game, just save and return to main menu.
2. *cough* [spoiler]Fallout Shelter Save Editor[/spoiler] *cough*

Sure, setting clock forward and reloading the save makes everything faster (even more if I cheat, by loading other people's save), but then it turns into a chore. In the end, I feel like I accomplished nothing. There's no progression. Just adding more and more vault dwellers till you hit 200, and scavenge items from wasteland endlessly.

Conclusion: Just don't play Fallout Shelter. If you want to become an overseer, buy Vault-Tec Workshop DLC from Fallout 4, and claim Vault 88. At least they throw some of the lines from the game.

A fun little management sim. You have several types of rooms dedicated to generating power, food and water. Each of these have minimum thresholds that you need to look after otherwise your vault will start to suffer. You can additionally build rooms dedicated to attracting stragglers, crafting equipment and training SPECIAL stats. You can equip your dwellers with clothing and weapons, which get stored in depots. You need also need to be mindful of invasions, which happen all the time from outside and inside. You can also send out your dwellers on scavenging trips, or full-blown quests. 

There is actually plenty to do, but it all gets bogged down by the typical wait-to-build thing that f2p mobile games tend to do. Could be much worse, since the game is pretty generous with dispensing lunchboxes and pet carriers, which actually have a good chance of giving out good stuff. 

Worth a try. Also available for the phone.

Fallout Shelter is a nice game to waste time or just to relax a bit from stress, because this game is the opposite of skill based games. I recommend everyone that just doesnt know what to do whilst there on the PC or for the people who are frustrated from losing in other games. This game is easy at first, but as soon as you start picking up the pace in building and popullation growing, this game becomes the opposite of "easy". There are alot of things that will frustrate you, and an enemy called RADSCORPION will absolutly destroy your definition of FUN :) . They are OP as fuck and should be nerfed, but oh well, you have to get some action dont you? ;)

In conclusion:

+ Timespender
+ No Skill needed
+ Absolutly Free to Play
+ Creativity

- Radscorpions that will destroy you Power Supllies
- Lack of Game Infos (No specific Wiki in the game)

Recommendation : 90% Yes

If you are looking for free to play games or If you have a slow PC you should give a chance to this game.This game is easy to learn.You have a Vault and you must make your people happy.That's the goal.Also you can do side quests outside the vault.They give you rewards.As I said, If you have issues with playing games on your computer because of the system requirements, this game won't give you any problem.

Have you ever wanted to get your Fallout fix, but didn't have the 2-16 hours that those games require for each sitting? Fallout shelter is your answer.

Fallout shelter is great. This is the perfect game for me when I need a break from whatever I'm suppose to be doing. It's the kind of game you can open up, play for a few minutes, then come back later and before you know it you have over 20 hours gameplay time somehow.

You start off with a handful of dwellers and its up to you to build the shelter up. As more resources are required, more dwellers are needed to work. As more dwellers arrive, more resources are required. You get it. Dwellers will show up from the wasteland or you can have dwellers give birth to the next generation.

You can also send dwellers out for supply runs and on quests. Quests can drag, and after you've been playing for a while I feel they get a little dull. It's just a lot of pointing and clicking, then watching your dwellers fight the raiders or radscorpions. But sending dwellers on supply runs just lets them do their own thing, just make sure they don't die out there.

I've played Fallout Shelter on the iPhone, iPad, PS4 and PC, and I think that PC is the way to go on this one, and I'm really glad Fallout Shelter is on Steam now. I originally played it on Bethesda launcher, and after losing a hard drive and updating windows, I've lost a few vaults, but now with the Steam cloud, my vault is here forever (I hope).

It's fun, it's free, it's Fallout, so give it a go.

At first this game looks pretty cool to play. I did enjoy it for several hours.
You have to click on everything to collect resources or level up.
After clicking you have to wait a few minutes to gather the same resource again.
Of course you can pay in game to increase the speed or get instantly things done.
Graphics is pretty good, this game probably runs on most systems.
Gameplay is average. It sometimes automatically zooms to an event and micromanagement is hard.
Sound is good, nice effects.
After several hours the game gets pretty boring and looks like grinding most of the time.
I can only recommend this game while cooking as I tent to run between my furnace and pc every x minutes, it's ideally for multitasking.
The game would be better if it's not free and the resources are collected automatically. Also level up should be automatic.
I'm also missing an overview of how much resources each room/person is using. There are only a few gauges and no numbers. There's no way to plan into the future. You have to tackle problems on the go.
I do like the idea of this game, story is unique but making it free made it worse.

Start Vault

> 2 people set to work to expand vault
> Vault grows
> Start assigning people to jobs, based on their skills
> Build radio station to cheer dwellers up
> Start training dwellers to better do their assigned jobs
> Give radio station dwellers high charisma, to lure more people into the glorious vault
> Send dwellers out into the wasteland against their will to find loot for the greater good of The Vault
> Breed dwellers, based on their skills to create babies that are better suited for their assigned jobs.
> Collect all money and resources to establish order and infrastructure.
> Overwork Dwellers and potentially kill them in dangerous fires for the greater good of The Vault.
> Orders work, go to bed and work again.
> Build another radio station to remind dwellers of the glory of The Vault
> Build layers upon layers of storage rooms to accumilate growing wealth and resources.
> Dwellers never get richer, you own everything. Life is good
> Throw dwellers out that are now useless.

PROS:
-Fun and thrilling
-Customization of characters
-Getting to breed them is pretty fun
-New elements unlocked over time to keep things interesting
-Pets! Weapons! Clothes! Crafting! [i]Rushing wait times, failing, and watching pregnant women run screaming while everybody else puts out the fire or kills radroaches lmaoo.[/i]
-Game is pretty generous about giving you boosts.
-Eventually you can go on quests and get a lot better bounty, and you get to go on them with the dwellers you send out!
-If you zoom in on the dwellers, they say funny things.
-When you send dwellers into the wasteland, you can view a log of their actions in real time, and it's often pretty amusing.
-[spoiler] You can bypass all wait times by simply setting your computer's clock ahead. You can change it back to the correct time immediately. [/spoiler]

CONS:
-Micro-transactions are incredibly tempting, lol.
-Lots of sitting and waiting; LOTS of "checking up" on the game.
-NO AUTO-SAVE! You MUST manually save the game before exiting or all progress is lost. Blurgh...

FINAL VERDICT: It's free. It's good. Download it.

Probably one of the best free-to-play games out there. I first encountered this game for the iPad, and it seems most suited for the tablet format, i.e it is a game where you set some tasks running and then "collect" on those tasks after a set period of time. Best for occasional and frequent periods of gameplay rather than a prolonged session at the computer/tablet. It is a community-management game where you manage an underground shelter, and send dwellers off on expeditions in the wasteland where they can randomly encounter fights, treasures and so on. Dwellers back in your vault can be set to craft items as well, and fend up the occasional random raiders and other mutant bugs. Great graphics and varied quests make this game very entertaining, especially in bite-sized chunks. Definitely worth downloading - the only drawback is that this is not available for Macs or Linux systems.

For a mobile style game, I actually enjoy it.

Let's go over comparisons to other such games and why I prefer this one:
- Fewer automatic engagements. For example Quests are performed by you issuing orders rather than a message telling you how things went without you.
- Decent time spans. Usually you could be building things, taining characters, doping missions, etc and be lumped with ever increasing timeframes until you're literally waiting WEEKS for a single task to get done. With this game, you could for example get someone from 1 to 10 of an attribute within a few days, plus have rooms to train dozens of people in all the S.P.E.C.I.A.L attributes simultaneously.
- Overall Fallout aesthetic. Blue and yellow Vault-Tec colour schemes, the Vault Boy look to your dwellers and other recognisable things make the game less generic and more enjoyable to fans of the franchise, or at least interesting to new people.
- Liberal premium currency for free. If you do quests, you will earn enough to boost various activities and not even spend a penny.
- Other premium items for free. The Mr Handy robots and pets can be obtained without throwing money at Bethesda, so again you can enjoy the game without constant wallet-nagging.

In summary, because this game was used as a sort of advertisement for Fallout 4, it doesn't have to squeeze, beg and bully cash out of you like your average browser/mobile game does. It makes its money back by keeping Fallout games on your mind in a non-threatening kind of way.

Despite originally starting its life as a mobile game, Falllout Shelter has carried over well as a competent PC 'minigame'. Seeing as it's free, you would expect it to be riddled with in-game purchases and ridiculous pay walls. However, this just isn't the case and unexpectedly it is very generous with giving the player the variety of currencies the game uses. It is also fairly addictive (I have already wasted 6 hrs of my life clicking at the screen), albeit overlooking some of the little annoying  management/planning mechanics (such as defending against raiders and moving vault dwellers between rooms). An entire sims type game set in the fallout universe but based upon mobile micro-transaction mechanics. I heard that Bethesda made more from this POS than all its other games. I doubt if that's true, but when a game is designed so that everything occurs at a glacial pace unless you pay to make it actually playable, then the game is totally hamstrung. I look forwards to the day that games like this are outlawed, and the tide has already turned - yaay Belguium!

To achieve anything without paying for the privilege is excruciatingly slow. If you send your vault dwellers out on missions it can take a literal 18 hours or more IN REAL TIME simply TO REACH the mission, which itself will NEVER last longer than 15 minutes. Of course, you can get there immediately if you are just willing part with 50 cents for the privilege!

It's telling that a number of positive comments say that this is a great game to play whilst watching the TV. If it's a good game to play whilst you are distracted and only giving it a fraction of your attention, then it's not a good game to play.

The game is a despicable cash drain designed to get you addicted before milking you dry with constant insidious reminders about how much more playable it is if you buy their stuff. You'd be better off to buy three premium triple A games than this. You'll get more for your money and they'll be decent games. Shameless exploitation.

That on top of the fact it sucks up a LOT more power on my computer than it should, given it is a mobile turned desktop game. Overall, I am just at a loss how they could take something from mobile that is so fun, and just completely ruin the experience moving it to desktop.

Great Fallout themed casual gaming. Good clean fun

Fallout Shelter is a relatively simple vault management game. In it, you take the role of an Overseer and are in charge of building your own Vault, keeping its inhabitants happy, making them reproduce, and so on. You can also send them on missions to gather items, which you later use to craft stronger weapons and equipment. Overall, I'd say there's not a lot to say about this game; it's a mobile port, so you shouldn't go in expecting a more "traditional" Fallout experience, but rather a casual game with a Fallout theme.

The gameplay, like I mentioned, is like a management sim. You start out with an empty Vault, and you must start building rooms to accomodate incoming Vault Dwellers. There's also three resources you've to take into account: energy, water and food, each with their respective room. As more people arrive into your Vault, you unlock new rooms, including the Overseer office, from where you can send your dwellers into missions. You also have to train your dwellers, as your Vault will sometimes be attacked by bandits, or other Wasteland creatures, even Deathclaws, who can easily destroy an unprepared Vault.

Personally, I found this to be a pretty entertaining game, although by the late game, when you've maxed out several of your dwellers and finished all missions, it gets pretty boring. Also, it really feels like a mobile game with the long waiting times between missions, and the daily rewards, that give you a lunchbox (kind of a lootbox) every week. So, what do I think? It's nothing spectacular, but I can recommend it.

Bethesda coughed up this game to keep people busy until the Fallout 4 release, and made a big deal of it being free to play. I never actually played it as such, but gave it a shot now just because I was curious, and the game has gotten a pretty good amount of positive reviews on Steam.

To keep it short, the game both scratched an itch and annoyed the hell out of me at the same time.

Undoubtedly, the idea of managing a post-nuclear vault is an interesting prospect. The game has a nice style to it, and contains many familiar elements from the Fallout games. The big problem with the game, is that it's not a typical strategy/tycoon type of game that a seasoned gamer might wish for. Instead, it's a game about collecting resources by clicking, and waiting for real-time timers, just like certain mobile type games. It is a gameplay model I'm not very fond of at all, but I might even forgive it if you didn't have to wait a very long time for things to happen. The waiting times are too long - sometimes up to several hours, and I find myself just staring at the screen while occasionally clicking on things that doesn't feel anything close to rewarding. You can actually pay money to skip things, but I feel absolutely no desire to do so.

The game also is quite shallow. While I haven't yet unlocked all the possible rooms, I've gotten the gist of the basics. You assign dwellers to certain rooms, but they don't even appear to be doing anything useful. A looped animation is all you will see, and an occasional random comment if you are zoomed in enough. Sometimes, disasters occur, such as fires, infestations and raider attacks, but you don't really have to do a lot. The dwellers mostly automatically take matters into their own hands as well as they can, and that is usually enough. You might have to equip them and heal them now and then, and possibly order them around if rooms are unmanned. They stick to the room you picked, unless there's a disaster in progress. They have no life, but work in that room 24/7. You can order them to go to the residental area to make babies. They level up occasionally, but what that is good for I do not know. You can train them in certain rooms to improve their attributes.

Building the vault is limited to a certain area, and a certain amount of room types which unlock as your shelter gets more dwellers. Rooms can be combined to form bigger rooms, and rooms can be upgraded a few times. Each room typically focus on one of the special attributes of the dwellers, giving what I assume are bonuses based on those. All you have to do is keep the rooms manned and connected. It is a rather bland experience.

Eventually, you will be able to send dwellers out on quests. Actually, you can send them out to explore earlier, but they just end up dead eventually, apparently not having enough brains to figure out when to return. You have to do that manually. You can track them by watching a log, which hints at a deeper simulation, but I fear it's a lie. Quests are a bit more interesting, since you get to order them around when they reach their destination. You tell them which rooms to enter and you can also pick enemy targets. However, in my experience, it's best to just stick to automatic combat. The combat itself feels like some kind of semi-turnbased kind of thing, but it's not very responsive and trying to affect it in any meaningful matter seems like a waste of energy. You'll also get to grab loot by clicking containers and dead bodies.

I want to like this game, and I like the idea of a management game based on the Fallout setting. However, playing it is mostly a frustrating and unsatisfying experience. I just find it hard to recommend it.

I'd give it a 9/10 below is a much more detailed review.

The game itself is overall fun and addicting I really like how they didn't make it p2w its basically 100% free to play. But some  people call it a cash grab but not really, I've been playing it for over a year now and haven't spent a penny. Sure the game has starter kits and loot boxes but those usually ruin the game and lootboxes can be easily obtained especially early on and late game. 

The base game is very slow progressing but rewarding. I had a vault on the pc version and the android version. I got several dwellers from a few lootboxes I got doing quests on the android version and before I knew it all heck broke loose. The vault constantly got attacked and ran out of power however it had sixteen people and food or power. The 2nd vault on pc had barely anyone at first but was really wealthy  food, water, and power was plentiful. Both vaults were created day 1 and roughly around the same time. This is just how random chance and time consuming fallout shelter is. 

I recommend playing this game along with something else or inbetween breaks, this game is kind of like farm vill or insertfbgamehere but without the begging. The game does get kind of boring late game. I actually had a max size vault containning all fully S.P.E.C.I.A.l dwellers. It got boring real fast, deathclaws were like kittens to this vault they'd usually get to the diner on the 2nd floor and just die without causing any real damage. This is with no money spent mind you just casually playing the game atleast once per day for a few minutes.

The questing is a lot of fun and a good way to get items fast more geared towards f2p players or late game players who want to get some cosmetics or completionists who want every item in the game for some reason.
