Fallout shelter ‚Äì 10/8/2018 ‚Äì 7:27PM


It started out well enough, little men and women came into my vault. You go through the motions, give them names (Darius, Dmitri, Susan, etc), give them clothes, many mouths to feed. Ultimately this is a game about sacrifice, ‚Äúwho will I send on this dangerous mission?‚Äù I rustle my fingers through my overgrown beard, questioning ‚ÄúWill Dmitri survive this night? I hope the Ghouls do not get my Dmitri!‚Äù I choke up, butterflies form in my stomach as I click the little button, sending little Dmitri into the harsh wasteland. 
	
5 minutes later, Dmitri was dead, I looked up from my computer screen, stared harshly at my ceiling and started to cry, tears rolled down into my overgrown beard. I slammed my desk hard with an iron fist, Coke cans and Fanta bottles sprung to life and flew to the ground. I slumped down and sobbed into my hands, I shouted ‚ÄúI should have sent Susan, she had better Endurance stat!‚Äù, my roommate Bogdan Shouted from his room down the hall, ‚Äúyou should have sent Susan! what were you thinking man!?‚Äù The City Hunter OST blared from his bedroom, ‚ÄúGet wild and tough, hitori de wa tokenai ai no pazuru o daite‚Äù I clenched my palms against my ears ‚Äúmake this stop‚Äù. I shut the game off.

I come back to it 2 weeks later to find that I could have revived Dmitri at any time.

Frequently, you will find yourself running low on energy, it is important to keep your energy levels  higher than your other stats because power outages lower the efficiency of the workers. Speaking of power plants, the first line of defense for raider attacks should always be an energy room as the most efficient workers for power plants use the Strength attribute, making these vault-dwellers effective in a fight.



Pro
-Easy to play
-Looks ok
-Gun

Con
-Brought me great sorrow
-Fantastical horrors hide in the shadows

7/10, Thank goodness Dmitri is okay, I will never send him out again.
Nice

Great game overall. Its something you can check up on every now and again. I havnt found any bugs except a few graphical ones like a dweller on a bike in the Fitness Center doesnt exactly use it right though it was funny to see and the dweller's skill still levels up normally so its only a graphics (the way how it looks) bug which is whatever. Though I must say reading some reviews down below that people didnt like this game was mostly because how the game handles random events such as attacks like mole rats or death claws. The game isnt gonna roll over and let you kill it. You have to level up your dwellers, build training rooms to increase for example strength, gather/create cloths and weapons so your dwellers can defend themselves, and so much more. There is more to this game then simply collecting the power, water, and food room resources. You gotta send a dweller out by themselves (click, hold, and drag out into the waste land) but make sure to give them some stimpacks so they can stay out there longer and your dweller over time will gather items such as weapons and caps for you to use in your vault. Anyways this game has more to it and isnt a push over. If you want to have a taste of an unfair game go try or watch a game called Darkest Dungeon. I have over 100 hours into this game and Im loving every bit of it. If you wish for help you just gotta ask :D

p.s. Death Claws attack when your vault has 60+ dweller and Ghouls attack around 45+ dwellers.

At the beginning, it's a lot of fun.  Fallout Shelter follows the typical "free" game formula.  But as you begin to make progress, level up characters, get some decent weapons and get a large number of "dwellers" in your shelter things really slow down.  I'm talking you will play 30 minutes, then have to wait another 24 hours for something in the game to happen; everything in the game runs on a timer system.  The timer counts down even when you are not playing the game.  Want to play a mission?  Wait another 18 hours.  Want to level up a character to max strength?  Wait another 17 hours. 

.... unless you buy loot boxes (with real money)!  But don't think you can make one purchase and enjoy the game at a normal pace.  Oh no my freind.  Even if you buy the largest "bundle" of Nuka Cola Quantum, that's only enough to fully level up about two or three characters.  However, a full shelter will have 200 characters!  I happily purchased $45 US dollars worth of loot when I started playing, because I am willing to support developers that make a fun game.   All in all, that money was wasted.  I have 90 hours into the game and I am still grinding....30 minutes per day.  It will never end....

Even though I didn't make that much progress in the game (or made any in game purchases), I consider this to be such a major issue that I just don't feel like playing it anymore...

This is so bad, and so boring, that i dont even feel like writing a proper review!  Its really THAt boring.. 

Its the base building of X-Com: Enemy Unknown. And thats about it....  

Quests... While they add something to the game, (and are indeed quite neat) trying to get dwellers to go,and  equip them is frustrating as heck!  It allows me 3, but it keeps sending only one, and none of my rad away, or stim packs get equiped!  So Ive repeatedly wsated caps, and Nuka Colas sending them out, ojnly to find they have no way to heal,a nd are alone.. Its my fault for accepting sending them alone, but its only allowing me to send one of my 22 dwellers! Its not telling me why I cant send more, or howe to equipe stim packs!

Raiders get through the door TOO easily, and are hitting every 10minutes!

I have no doubt, there are some minor events, but that doesnt change how mind-numbingly boring, the base game is.. And Im currently playing an Idle Clicker game, to bring some perspective...

Edit:  It actually does get better, but slower.. Severely slower.. As you progress. Im now over 40 Ddwellers, and about 19ish rooms.. The quests are good fun, and pretty neat.. Feels like playing a mobile fallout 3 or NV..

What I mean by slower, is timers slowly increase, you start training specific traits, and quests themselves.. Youre talking 4-8-even a full day in hours.. Now, initially, you will pick up quite a few Nuka Colas.. Especially on quests.. But they stop that quickly.. Itas a great marketing scheme.. give you plenty, and let you see how much fun the game is (most ppl will blow them, expecting them to continue to rain on you) then it begins to trickle, as wlel as progress.. Ive now spent 2 days, and only picked up 3 new dwellers.. 2 of wihch were of my own birthings..Since Im not getting new wdwellers, I cant advance rooms.. If I get too many, supplies get strained (and ive been generous with the 3 basics, keeping the little bar at about the middle of each meter, or lower)I dont understand the radio station, as its timer is sometimes very short, others very long, but only when theres actually a new dweller do I click it like other rooms that gain inventory.  majority of the time, nothing comes of it.. 

basically, it did get fun, but then slowed so much Im likely going ot end up being done wihtthegame, after only a few short days.   So to sum up.. Confusing in the beginning, fun in the middle, and then finally slow into a boring waiting game shortly thereafter..

I'm positive that if you were a sociopath you'd get a ton more enjoyment out of this game, and I simply cannot decide whether or not that's a good thing.

The art style is fantastic, the mechanics work smoothly, the management systems feel unique, and the quests are fun and rewarding. No two people will have the same experience because of how much freedom you truly have over your vault as a whole, and each and every dweller individually. Though there are microtransactions, they are some of the most unobtrusive I've seen, and are by no means necessary to progress at a decent speed.

 Even though the game is just the PC version of the existing (and extremely successful) mobile management game, it doesn't feel like a mere app. It all just kind of, well, works. It all works, and that's really nice. 

Also, it's free, so you might as well give it a shot.

My friend reccommended this game and, after all the great things he said about it, I was expecting an awesome game, but I was very disappointed. First of all, it has in-game purchases (which, in my opinion, don't help a game). The gameplay is repetitive and boring. People rarely come, and rushing almost always fails. Rooms take FOREVER to make anything, so your power, food, and water runs out quickly and everybody just gets mad. It even takes 30-40 minutes just to make something that barely heals ONE person. And don't get me started on the EXTREMELY OP mole-rats and raiders. They pretty much kill the settlers becuase they won't even defend themselves. Also, you can't control your person while they are searching the wilderness. Because the text from your person is just pre-coded, it just repeats it over and over and over again. This game is very bad, and I would NOT reccommend playing the game. At least it is free...

You don't even have to play on survival mode for this godforsaken crap to undo EVERYTHING you've built up. I started a second game after getting a better understanding of the mechanics, got an absurdly powerful plasma rifle as my first reward, used training rooms to amp up the stats of my residents, and how was I done in? A single random group of burrowing mole rats made me burn through ALL of my stimpacks, and killed over half of ALL my characters (levels ranged from about 5 to 20 for an average of 15 or so). We're talking about the 2nd weakest enemies in the series besides RADROACHES HERE! I swear on my honor and sanity, during that same sequence that made me rage quit, I had 1 Vault Dweller armed with an enhanced sniper rifle that I believe had armor-piercing capabilities (I uninstalled the game the second I quit so I can't confirm) vs. the last molerat in the Vault, fired about 3 to 4 vollys of shots, and the the rat STILL KILLED HIM! This would seem to suggest that standard enemies can get stronger if you don't meet some arbitrary gameplay milestones. Not that you'd know given that the Help section says nothing to that effect, there's no level indicator for enemies, and you also can't get a numerical value for their health, or depending on the circumstances, even a health bar! I assume this because to get feral goul attacks in my previous run, but I decided to wait on making babies to power level stats this time. The final record for how long I lasted in the game before getting royally screwed was 3 goddamn days.

To clarify, after the basics have been introduced and your Vault population expands new training rooms that increase stats are unlocked. This is because the only thing that leveling does is increase your character's health, but said health increase is supposedly greater if the Endurance stat is increased. But just like everything else in this damn game, there's absolutely no way to know what the Hell impact it's having. Let me just go over the things the game will never let you know: The aforementioned extent to which Endurance impacts health increase, the numerical value of the character's health, the default likelihood of ANYTHING happening when using the radio to broadcast in the wasteland or having a deathclaw randomly show up at your Vault door, what stat (if any) governs melee weapons' effectiveness, how close/far a character is from building up to a critical attack, and with regards to rooms, almost everything. Want to know to what extent merging rooms helps BEFORE spending money? Too bad! Want to know precisely to what extent increasing training room speed helps before spending thousands of caps to upgrade it? Too bad! Want to know if the Help section (AKA Bethesda) is BSing you regarding training speed going faster with more people in the room? Well I sure as hell didn't notice any difference. Want to know whether you have the crafting resources/recipies necessary to make something in the later crafting menus BEFORE spending thousands of caps upgrading a weapon crafting room? Too bad!

Even the RADROACHES can be completely absurd! Get like one stuck in an individual room with the aforementioned plasma rifle and It'll be dead before the animation or sound of an attack can be heard, but have them spawn in a large room far from anyone and 5 to 6 can turn into 10 to 20 for no reason! And one of the rooms is literally incapable of housing residents despite being a location enemies can spawn in! And just to put the cherry on the garbage gameplay sundae, your little Vault minions could only be more incompetent if they shot themselves! If an enemy walks into another room, your poor helpless flamethrower-brandishing uber-guard suffers from crippling depression that prevents him/her from pursuing due to their profound sense of failure to stop them earlier and must be dragged by you every single damn time! But don't think that it ends there: melee enemies on the other end of the room can still hit your sniper-rifle weilding Vault-Dweller on the opposite side, and they most certainly WILL be on the opposite side because Bethesda naturally understands that if there's one thing that a time-sensitive, resource-draining, cluster f@(# of a combat sequence needs, it's for every single goddamn character to waltz over to completely arbitrary locations within a room before actually opening fire, or putting out a literal fire! And on top of THAT, human combatants will often stumble and stagger for what feels like an eon after loosing all their health dragging out the time that resources can't be produced for even LONGER. Thus putting you in the position of sitting there unable to do anything but wait as a bunch of drama-queen raiders drunkenly stumble about harmlessly with your Vault Dwellers being equally passive, even as the sirens blare and the resource bar flashes like it's actively being depleated. I knew Bethesda were hopelessly inept in most respects but I didn't think they'd find a way to screw up "We're giving you this for free"!

Think that's the end of the BS? Nope. If you look through the Help section, it turns out that the radio that can be used to attract people to your Vault, as well as pretty much any instance in which the Vault door opens has the capacity to bring deathclaws charging into the vault.
...
DEATHCLAWS. And if my experience with the molerats and roaches is any indication I could only expect every character to drop dead the second they enter the room, never take any damage, and somehow fill my computer with malware, take money out of my account for microtransactions, and give me cancer. It's never happened to me, but again, I only ever got as far as feral gouls, so it's probably a late-game thing.

With the gameplay being a mindless grindfest, the only other possible asset is story which, as one would naturally expect from a free game is nigh non-existant in terms of being a source of sincere motiveation. You're a Vault, and there are people in it, The End. Oh, there are quests that you can send Vault Dwellers out on, assuming that you can spare any of them, your valuable equipment, AND you build an Overseer room. Even after all that you're rewarded with staring at a travel progress time for hours on end because it can take up to 30 HOURS (likely more since the travel times seem to increase as the quests progress and I think I recall one having a 36 hour time to start with) to get to/from a location for ONE mission. So good luck trying to stay invested in quests that have you sitting around doing nothing for hours waiting for one or two lines of dialogue to give you any more story before making you do it all over again.

And on a personal note, the game is an affront to biology and REALLY in favor of the Adam and Eve story because there's more incest than a Southern... probably should stop now before I violate Steam's guidelines regarding user posts before I finish that. But the point is, there's no amount of in-family screwing that can't occur in the game. The weirdest thing is that the game actually kind of encourages it with the mechanics... No I'm serious, character names can repeat so it's difficult to keep track of who's related to who, and it takes HOURS for radio calls to bring people to your vault... IF they bring people to your Vault. That was one of the reasons I had only like 30 to 40 characters for so long, I was trying not get parents and siblings to get down with one another. But with the way this game presents them you'd think humans were mice or something. Anyway, that was just a niggling aspect that bothered me, the more substantive issue is the gameplay.

This game has well documented issues with crashes causing corrupt saves, and thus deleting anything you may have paid for in game.
Bethesda's customer support page only loops around to a few premade responses that do nothing to address the issue, and then refer you to Steam if you ask about a refund. The only way to submit any details about the problem is through a bug report that then tells you after you submit it and what ever files or screen caps that no one will respond to you about the issue it is purely for the developer's information.  Steam will then give you a response that everything went through fine on their end and to contact Bethesda. Luckily Steam will provide you with Fallout Shelter's support email even if Bethesda does not want to give out that info.
I'm seriously considering looking into a class action suit, because from all appearances Bethesda just wants to take your money and not let you keep what you pay for.

After putting a decent amount of hours into fallout shelter I feel like it's about time I share my opinion on the game.

To start off: I get that this game is free to play and all, but that doesn't stop it from being a shameless cash grab.

Almost everything in this game requires you to pay up a sizeable amount of money, sure you can get somewhere without paying a single penny but this game was clearly designed around the pay to win route just like most mobile games.
A lot of you might disagree with me on this but if waiting 5+ hours to complete a single quest is the sort of thing you like then be my guest.

On top of that the game is hilariously unbalanced, Bethesda's idea of "Difficulty" in Fallout Shelter is to just spam a fuck ton of enemies at once.

The animations in this game are really unfinished as well, you could argue something like "oh, but that's just the artistic style of the game!" I don't think art style can be used as an excuse for not putting things on the right  L A Y E R S.

I would say more about this game but that's basically all there is to this game,
wait, click, repeat is all Fallout Shelter is when you look at it overall. Pay, click, repeat if you actually decide to spend money on this game for some reason.

Overall:
I can't recommend this game to anybody, I've seen worse but this game is still mobile gaming trash.

This game is free. This is the basis of my review. I am a huge fan of the Fallout series, this is apparent if you've read any of my other reviews. New Vegas and 3 are by far my favorite, with Fallout 4 not too far behind. Fallout Shelter does not come near any of these, but at the same time, it's not supposed to. New Vegas, 3 and 4 were all huge, full-price, open-world releases, while Fallout Shelter is a free to play vault overseer simulator originally designed as a mobile app. That being said, it does a fair enough job making the player feel like they're back in that same Fallout universe they love. It's got it's serious moments, like Raider attacks or Vault disasters, but retains that old goofy Fallout feel. As far as small, free games go, this game is probably worth it.

I had 2 shelters. One with over 40 population (standard mode) and second with 50 on hard, where things went very buggy wise bad.

Otherwise, I rather put warning that game has many bugs, which quickly add up together and will make you frustrated, considering you spent quite some time on it. One attack you are fine. But 2 ways you can speed up things. Change back and forward your operation system clock. I.e. hour, or 10 min. Works charms. You can speed up character movements (useful in wastelands) using cheat ending, Specially you don't want to waste time on moving between rooms and lifts. Fights are long enough. And even using above, which don't affect other aspects of game, true dark nature of game becomes apparent.

I'm giving this a positive, but not by much. It's a VERY lazy mobile port. So many improvements could have been made that were not even attempted. You move dwellers with the left mouse, and you also move around your vault with left mouse, meaning accidentally dragging and dropping a dweller in a crowded vault when all you're trying to do is scroll around is a guaranteed frustration. Would have been so simple to use the right mouse to move around instead. Selecting a dweller when they're leaping around a room is also tricky, since half the time it'll select the room (and zoom in on it). It auto-zooms to events, and locks there for a second, so if you're wanting to prepare for that event (yeah I KNOW deathclaws are coming, can I prep the first room please?) 

In-game documentation is adequate but not more.

On the plus side, it's free and the paid aspects are easier to live without than in normal F2P games. The premium currency Nuka Cola Quantum can be earned fairly easily in-game (especially if you rescue Bottle & Cappy).

Fallout Shelter is at its best early on when your fledgling vault is barely able to scrape by, and every raider attack has the potential to topple your fragile society. Once your vault is firmly established, all fear of losing, and thus the fun, fades away. Combine this with a lack of compelling longterm goals, and you have an experience that‚Äôs fun for a few days, but lacks long-term appeal.
It's good.

Doesn't rely on the 'pay for energy' mechanism that so many of these free to play games have. You don't /have/ to buy the real-money Nuka Cola bottles that speed up gameplay (you don't lose out by not having them) and you're awarded them frequently on quests. It's a good game to pick up and put down again when you want to, particularly if you enjoy idling games whilst listening to a podcast in the background.

Aight, so usually don't review games on Steam. I review news and indies over at GameLuster.com. Exception for this game (well, "game"; well, game, really, but we'll get into that) since I don't have an excuse to talk about it on there and I still want to organise some thoughts.

The game started out as it did when I first began playing it on my mobile phone. I knew full well then what kind of game it was and I knew it two weeks ago, too, when I picked it up again. You get your very standard sim/micromanagement game. All is well in Paradise. Yeah yeah, microtransactions and wait times. I knew all that going into it.

The game started to show promise about one week in. The questing feature was new to me; I don't recall the early phone version having it. Oh, I thought, how neat. I can actually go do que--oh, it's timers and microtransactions. How neat. The game drip feeds you just enough Nuka Cola Quantum (to skip timers) for you to almost forget it wants you to spend 100$ for 1,000 bottles (srs), so you ransom them out and try to have some semblance of fun. Weirdly, doing the quests, i.e. killing monsters in locations, is actually fun. Shallow beyond belief, but a break from monotony if anything. This alone refilled my patience during all the downtime at home base and I was willing to see where it would go.

I kept amassing dwellers at a snail's pace. I began by mating the dwellers tirelessly, but grew really really bored by the finnicky concept, so I quit. They haven't had sex in over a week now, I think. It hardly matters since most only exist to max out the SPECIALs they'll never use. You can only send 3 parties out on quests and I only bother with 2: A team and B team. Now, A team has what are probably the best weapons in the game: flamers and junk jets. One even has a set of 45f power armour I got out of a free lunchbox at random. And all of it is very very neat.

I quit today and uninstalled immediately after for one single reason. I had been slowly anticipating the 75 dweller mark to upgrade the weapon workshop to its third and final level. Then I noticed I needed 60,000 caps, not really that much at this stage of the game, but enough to keep me waiting for a day. Today I finally upgraded the sodding room and unlocked some of the legendary weapon recipes I had picked up 5 days ago. Turns out the game was rigged from the start. Legendary type weaponry is only marginally better than the best rare type weapons, but cost a lot of your legendary materials and, read carefully, 14 days to make compared to the, read again, 8 hours it would take for a rare weapon. Unless, aha, if you spend 100 Nuka Cola Quantum, of course.

Now, I haven't checked the Quantum cost for speeding up the process, but made a simple guess based on the idea that 1 Quantum is used to skip time from 1 minute to 1 hour 59 minutes. You do the maths. I just quit after I found out I had to wait

four

teen

days

to make one measley weapon that is only 2 damage points superior to the best rare type weaponry currently available in the workshop. And these weapons aren't even the best ones in game, just a regular fat man. Imagine waiting another two weeks for another minor upgrade. Unless, you know, you could always spend

one

hundred

dollars

to speed up the pointless process. Afterwards, all you do, really, is go on quests with your stupidly OP weapon that kills low level enemies in one hit, but for what? Materials? Money? Lunchboxes? Getting to end game gear is arguably the only point of the game. Skipping it to do what? Start over? Are you forking insa--

Mobile games really aren't new concepts. No one is surprised or shocked by the blatant player abuse anymore. But I did want to make one simple statement. If we do need some kind of criterium to distinguish between games and schemes it would be this: video games get easier over time as players get used to challenge, mobile games get harder over time as players get used to spending money. The only way to overcome the challenge in this "game" is to simply not play. In other words, the game will try to game you out of your money, and you'll have to game it right back by uninstalling. Consciously, fortunately, deliberately, I walked away without ever spending one cent on this heroin scheme.

For the game oozes superficiality. Combat is as complex as waiting for your characters to not die. There are no explosives, headshots, dice rolled critical strikes, VATS capabilities, chems, weapon switchouts, or even fleeing options. There's no tactics involved; just wait for your opponent to die because you have 25 stimpaks and they do not. The game often forgets your rooms are producing resources and just tanks your reserves if you log in every once in a while, all to keep you looking at a screen of nothing happening. It'll throw enemy raids at you at the most inopprtune moments just to pee upon your countenance, when they're all easily avoided by, again, having too many stimpaks regardless. It throws Mr. Handys and pets your way that are so inconsequential they might as well be giant "frick you; pay us" signs that take up 80% of the screen. Mr. Handys are slow, cannot be repaired, and don't even seem to work when you're logged out. Questing really was its one slightly redeeming quality since you get to talk to NPCs, even if it's just for show, and you get to hold onto hope for a shovel or a microscope to craft a bullcrickets weapon to beat a bullsnail challenge to win a lunchbox that'll give you 50 water, 100 caps, a baseball glove, and a dragon penile member so you can shove it up your--head. You can always go fork yourself, though, and the game takes no effort to remind you of that option.

Do not install this game.

There's some good to be had, but there's a bunch of problems that stack up.

I like the grinding in this game; grinding tends to be seen as a negative, but in Shelter, everything you do has an ultimate purpose, so nothing comes out as a waste of time (having more than enough resources is good, you can grind for better stats, etc.).  So yeah, I liked that.

What I don't like is the interface; I try to move the camera, it moves a guy to a lower floor by accident, or I would try to put a guy to take care of Radroaches, it doesn't do anything.  This is where it gets more grueling than fun, as it happens constantly.

There's also a few nitpicks; a screen where you can see whatever stuff the Dwellers are wearing would've gone a long way, it'd be nice if gaining more resources than you can hold gives you money in return (it kind of does, but at random), and while I did say the grinding is good, because of it you also can't play the game when you're "in the mood", you need to wait for hours for stuff to happen.

But, the one thing that made me decide this game is not worth a damn is this; there's no cooldown on the Radscorpions.  They are easily the worst enemy, as they deal huge damage, can do radiation damage, they go everywhere on the map, and they drain your electricity.  I got three of these buggers in a row, I can't ever recover from those.

Another thing that happened is that, when I sent out a dweller in the wasteland, I gave him RadAways, but he never used them, so he died once because of radiation sickness and I had to pay 1000 Caps because the game is stupid.

Only for those who have a lot of free time and can overlook these issues, but as for me, NO.

Fallout Shelter is a neat spin-off to the Fallout series that has you play as the overseer of a new vault being developed. You acquire new dwellers overtime that have different stats that each do different things.

As the overseer it is your job to assign your dwellers to certain rooms to create resources for you. The three main resources are food, water, and power which each require different S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats to increase efficiency of production.

You also have the power to send dwellers out to explore the wasteland to find items for you but beware, because they can die while out exploring.

This game is great to kill time, but you need to check on it every so often because the game runs while you are offline.
noice game

Another stereotypical "fee to play" game designed to be nothing more than a hook to try and make you pay for something you don't need.

A lot of the game has intended annoyances to piss you off in order to push you to buying lunchboxes for extra loot, such as random events interrupting resource management, the rng on the "rush" attempts causing some random events, raider invasions and the need to constantly send people out to collect items so you can keep your residents protected and increase their stats to improve the overall perfomance of resource management.

The game starts off fine, build your first few rooms, assign people to their best suited areas, get some preggos going so you can boost your population as early as possible to unlock more rooms and complete the little quests for caps and early game lunchboxes.

Once your population is in the 20s resource management becomes more of a juggle game to the point you will find yourself thinking, do I risk rushing to get that early collection of resources or do I not incase it causes a fire/infestation stopping any resource collection in that room and also rolling back the timer then adding extra time to it as well as -10% on the next rush attempt. I normally opted to not rush because I either have really bad luck or the % shown is not the actual chance it will succeed (potentially another attempt to frustrate you into buying lunchboxes). 

Quests when they are available are also weirdly done, you find yourself chasing level and item requirements quite a lot, and even then when you meet them there is no gaurentee that you will be able to do it. I had one that was a level 5 quest with 2+ weapon requirements only for my entire team to get 2hit by a boss with a knife, tried again with more stimpacks, same result.

All this is passable until you start getting big, the larger my vault got the more the performance issues started to happen. there was at least one crash every day. Now I'm at the point where I get in my vault, do one thing then it crashes. What caused this? adding an elevator. Well time to uninstall.

This could have been a good game if they had made it a regular game that you buy and 100% own.  However, the free-to-play freemium model of pay-to-win really destroys this game by making it insanely grindy, and making almost everything in the game that you have to wait for such as dweller upgrades, quest travel time etc. all take insanely excessive amounts of real world time - just so they can turn around and sell you loot crates and Nuka Cola Quantum to speed up the ridiculously slow time delays in the game.  For example, doing a quest may require real world travel time of anywhere from 30 minutes to 12 hours of wall clock time or more, with your characters not actually doing anything during that time except being unavailable.

This game is merely the 2015 version of an in-home quarter guzzling grinder arcade game, with a cool game idea implemented in a way to just maximize profitability while destroying the fun things that could have made it a good game.  I hope some 3rd party takes the general idea of this game and makes a better standalone alternative to it called something else which isn't just grinding and waiting over and over then getting destroyed and starting over.  I'd much rather have an indie game like that either completely for free, or even for a reasonable flat price rather than this freemium stuff that destroys the gameplay.

This game is a port from mobile platform. As such it's inherently designed to funnel players toward in-app purchases (microtransactions, lootboxes). In game this means you will spend around half the playing time waiting for timers to cool down so you can advance (actually play the game).

The game mechanics are too simple and shallow to give the player any sense of satisfaction when completing tasks. The gameplay mostly consists of clicking on flashing squares every 3 minutes and waiting for your in game currency to slowly tick up to the amount you need to upgrade the next room of the vault. 

Personally I find this type of game design where the developers intentionally cripple the game enough to motivate players to pay repeatedly for essentially worthless services in order for the game to approach a good experience. Unfortunately instead it feels like stuttering if you manually wait for the cooldown timers, and like cutting past the queue if paying to skip the timers. A few dollars only last a minute before it's spent and you are right back to waiting again to keep playing. I personally find this businessmodel to be, quite frankly, evil. 

I detest everyone involved with this game.

Wow, this really only has a few hours of fun content in it before it just becomes an annoying grind.

There's nothing hard about Fallout Shelter, it isn't a challenging or particularly fun game. The controls are clunky and occasionally unresponsive, the graphics are interesting from afar and bare bones close up. Everything about the game is compromised from being a mobile port.

However, if you like Fallout the content is interesting for a bit, until the resource management system starts to chafe. Once you start running out of caps and having to resort to the time grind of the game, it's boring. There are some interesting gameplay segments, such as the fact that on top of accepting random wasteland recruits you can breed your vault dwellers together and end up with similar looking children with random stat gains. There's enough Evil Genius mixed into the game to keep it interesting for a few hours until you get tired of dragging and dropping dwellers on top of each other to make them fuck or generate electricity or treat water.

I'll give you a brief summary of the first 12 hours of gameplay:

1) I starting building my own Vault and opened its doors to my first group of Vault Dwellers. 

2) I nearly starved my vault dwellers to death within the first 5 minutes of gameplay because I built too much crap.

3) The game offered me my first free lunchbox (which are usually only obtainable through microtransactions). I managed to luck out and get Jericho from Fallout 3, who happened to have amazing S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats. After I used him to fix the famine issue in my Vault, I made him impregnate every woman in my vault, hoping his special stats transfer to his children via genetics. Spoiler alert: they do.

4) Eventually, all of the regular folks from my vault died off and I had nothing but Jericho-babies staffing the vault and patrolling the Wasteland.

Fast forward to where I am currently writing this review: I have a vault full of inbred badasses that can withstand anything from Raiders to Deathclaws, and pretty much run the gambit on anything out in the Wastes. Microtransactions help, but aren't necessary to gameplay. Everything to managing your vault to doing quests is super fun even if you don't pipe money into the game.

This is a nice simple game where you can build your own vault and train the dwellers within it to help defend it from disasters such as fires, raids, and attacks from the wasteland creatures. Arm your dwellers with guns you earn or find in the wasteland, and heal them with syringes you make in the science lab room. Rooms are easy to unlock by gaining more dwellers, which you can get more dwellers by either mating two dwellers together or building a radio room to attract more. When you're bored and want a good past time where you can manage your own vault, this is the game for you.

The only thing I dislike so far about this game is it's impossible to simply move a room after you already placed it down. You have to destroy the room and replace it back down. Also, if the room is in the middle of two other rooms, you have to destroy those rooms first before you can destroy that room. So make sure you want to place that room in a spot before you place it down.

[h1]Awesome![/h1]
This game is pretty fun.  Unlike most games, you have full control over making things 'easy' by how quickly you build and how you spend your caps.  There's always an element of RNG but overall if you play legitly (without cheats) then you'll have a wonderful time.

[h1]Fire in the Hole![/h1]
The main issue I have is the finicky control that seems a bit too sensitive.
A secondary issue is that there's no easy buttons for 'remove all outfits' or 'remove all weapons' from Vault Dwellers.  There's no way to easily tell who is armed/equipped and having to shuffle stuff around constantly for random events like raider attacks gets a bit tedious.
I wouldn't bother with trusting the leaderboards since there is no real check against cheating.  They're useless in any case.

[h1]Monetization[/h1]
Monetization is minimal and you can even turn off the Tutorial Tips if they annoy you too often.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Play the game.  Try it out for an hour.  If you dislike it?  Uninstall and no harm no foul.  I'm still a bit peeved that there's currently an ongoing 'Free Lunchboxes' E3 event along with a 'Free Pet' event and I've gotten neither of those things :(
I don't believe people want to use save editors but if Bethesda drops the ball and doesn't provide the promised items then this may further mess up the already-shaky community.

If you rush a room when the risk of accident is around 30%, the accident often takes place at 100% and brings numerous bugs and moles! If you leave the game the storage of power, food and water will continue to decrease... 
The longer you play with this game, the more absurd you'll find it. Greedy developers just try every effort to force you to make purchases. Ridiculous and shameless. Worst game I've ever played. But since it's free-to-play, what can we say?

[b]Summary[/b]: "Fallout Shelter" offers a surprising variety of game-play. At its heart, it is primarily about base-building. It also has a whole lot more, and can be [almost?] addictive.

If you enjoy "base building" even a little, then you are very likely to enjoy "Fallout Shelter." If not, then it may not be your "cup of tea." If you have no idea whether you enjoy "base building" or not, then "Fallout Shelter" is a free opportunity to explore possibilities. ;-)

If you enjoy the Fallout games, particularly the base-building parts of "Fallout 4," then you may enjoy "Fallout Shelter." It is an intriguing blend of simplified 3D environment with 2D "Vault Dwellers" (which I think of as "Vault-lings" because they are so very small when one zooms out to get a better look at the overall vault or quest building). It is very much "Fallout"-verse, and will even quiz you about various trivia from "Fallout 3" and "Fallout 4."

If you enjoy casual game play, "standard mode" Vaults should suit you. If you enjoy being challenged, there is a "survival mode."

.

[b]Cons[/b]: your vault [i]will[/i] get attacked, or else have some internal catastrophe (such as fire breaking out and spreading quickly if not extinguished), with frustrating frequency and regularity. These incidents can be lethal to younger Vaultlings.

.

[b]Pros[/b], in no particular sequence: 

It can be played a few minutes each day, updating your vault, rotating Vaultlings in training, and doing a quest or three, and then save and close. After that, you can play any other game you wish to focus upon. Or else you can stay with it for longer, watching your Vaultlings grow and production levels rise, and upgrade or expand your vault.

In addition to base-building, and fighting off attackers, "Fallout Shelter" also has quests that you can send your Vaultlings out to do. Quests help your vault to earn resources more quickly than sending Valtlings out exploring. Quests also break up the monotony of waiting for caps (in-game version of cash) to be earned by Vaultling level-ups, or production completion, or else from trying to "rush" rooms (which will trigger disasters or attacks if they fail).

The "Mysterious Stranger" appears briefly in a random location, somewhat regularly. He will give you caps (money) if you find and click on him before he disappears. He has a musical theme, a few specific notes, which plays when he appears... and a different chord when he vanishes. You will hear the music more loudly if your camera view is near to where he is, or more softly if you are looking at a room farther from him. This can be helpful in finding him. ;-)

The Vaultlings are surprisingly varied with skin tones, hairstyles, and so forth. They can be customized, after you build a barber shop. Prior to building that barber shop / salon, you can change their attire to improve their effective "S.P.E.C.I.A.L." stats. There are also training rooms that can be built. Between training and attire, it is possible to exceed 10 in a few stats per Vaultling. Each Vaultling can also be individually re-named, simply by clicking on the Vaultling and then over-writing their name in the stats box that pops up.

Vaultlings can be sent out to explore the Wasteland, and find resources. They can be left out exploring when you turn off the game. They will continue exploring until they either reach maximum capacity of items they can carry, or else until they die (standard mode allows you to resurrect them, but survival mode does not). When a Vaultling reaches their max carrying capacity, they automatically begin returning to the Vault.

Vaultlings are not inherently monogamous, but they will refuse to procreate with anyone near of kin (siblings, parents, etc.). So it is helpful to make use of the renaming option to indicate who is related to whom. This prevents difficulties when one wishes to encourage the Vaultlings to increase their number. If one knows that John Thompson is the son of Jane Thompson, then one knows to find someone else to pair him with for reproductive purposes.

The game gives tips during loading screens. While many of those tips are thoroughly intuitive, such as "use the weight room to train your Vault Dwellers in Strength," other tips will make you less inclined to think "blinding flash of the obvious" when you read them.  So you'll likely wish to at least glance at those tips as they go by.

"Fallout Shelter" is thoroughly "Fallout"-verse, and very consistent with the lore. It will quiz you, during quests, about trivia from both "Fallout 3" and "Fallout 4." If you don't know the answers, you can learn from trial and error. The quizzes are in some of the weekly quests, so you will have opportunities to try again until you learn the correct answers to the questions. Alternatively, you can deliberately use the incorrect answers, so the quizzers will attack your questing Vaultlings, and those Vaultlings gain experience from fighting. You get the overall reward, if you click the correct sparkling container, regardless of whether you answered the questions correctly or incorrectly.

Variety! It contains mini-games within the game.
There's the base-building core of the game, 
and the quest mini-games, 
and the trivia quizzes in some of the weekly quests,
and the Mysterious Stranger playing hide-and-seek, 
and trying to keep track of "Bottle" and "Cappy" when they visit (prioritize the quest line which rescues them, when you initially build the Overseer's office and unlock questing),
and the customization of Vaultlings
plus special seasonal quests
(and I may have missed something or another else, which is also included...)

... all for free.

Micro-transactions are available. However, over time, one can earn everything available for real-world cash simply by playing the game. So those purchases are entirely optional.

No game is ever entirely perfect. On the whole, these guys do a good job though.

Check it out! It's free, so the only cost is your time.

Happy gaming! :)

The Good : Love having to build own shelter? Being the Vault's Supreme Dictator - Overseer? This is your game. You also able to equip all Vault Dweller with various weapons and armors / costumes.
The Bad : You will be always under management because how fast all problem occurs. The raiders, the fire, the mole rat, etc. Luckily it only happens on the early game.
The Ugly : You have to buy the Mister Handy if you want some help in collecting electricity, food, and water. Without buying Mister Handy, all your vault will collapse because you won't be able to collect all of those things alone.

While I'd whish I could write a positive review, as the developers really created a small innovative potentially enjoyable game, the "free to play"-prices just make it impossible.

The producers have obviously gone berserk, rendering the prices for the stuff you can buy about 25 (seriously:twentyfive) times too high to be anything even close to fair. Though one could argue, as often done, you don't have to buy any of the stuff, that would just ignore dynamics of psychology, which are so offensively exploited here.
High tier crafting is rendered nearly useless without buying the booster, as crafting one single high tier weapon takes between 1-2 weeks. With booster, producing 4-5 of those weapons instantly can cost about 90‚Ç¨... Seriously Bethesda Software? As there's up to 200 dwellers to get equipped?

Apart from the definitly missing "Pause" function and the continually being ripped away from whatever you were just doing by "disaster" and "birth"- Autozoom (especially in survival mode pretty annoying) the developers should be cuddled, while the producers should be hunted out of their offices with wet towels.

A shame, really, I would so like to give it a thumbs up. But the producer just spoils the lovely ideas, the developers obviously put into it.

-You can create your own colony of survivors to maintain a vault. 
-Merge rooms and upgrade them to increase how many survivors you can keep.
-Send out survivors into the wasteland to explore. However, depending on how long you keep survivors in the wasteland, that's how long it takes for them to get back.
-Do quests and obtain items you could use for your vault. Quests require rt hours to get to the quest area.
-This game does have microtransactions where you can purchase items to help you improve your vault/survivors/etc. However, you do not need to purchase them to continue playing. 
-This is a free game. Bonus. 

-I recommend this game because it is fun and relaxing.. unless you get raided and lose all your resources. J.K. you can easily recover from raids :)

As a Fallout franchise enthusiast, this game was instantly something I wanted to play. Sadly, I soon discovered how disappointedly shallow it is. 

Since the resources you gather are consumed even when you're not playing the game, you have 2 options: spend a lot of time doing nothing more than staring at the screen and clicking on different resources or buy some packs containing Mr. Handy to do this automatically. 

Anyway, investing some money in a game that you enjoy is not such a big deal, but, from what I understand, if you start a new game, those Mr. Handy(s) will not be transferred.  

In conclusion, this is just another freemium game, design to grind your time with meaningless tasks.

This is not an idle game - it's casual, sure as progress trickles in while you're away - but you're required to be pretty active to prevent dwellers dieing and complete quest objectives.

Realistically, the final achievements (collect 20 different legendary followers etc) can only be done if you spend a large amount of money on the micro-transactions.

Additionally sorting vault dwellers by stats doesn't work and and if the game, steam or your pc crashes for any reason you lose your save completely so expect to have to back-up your save regularly.

Some of the achievements lacking necessary detail, such as the Overseer achievement which should say level a dweller from childhood to 50, really detract from the experience as well.

So this is the PC port of a game meant to build hype for the long anticipated Fallout 4 back in 2015. This game is really fun, addicting and rewarding to level up your dwellers and expand your vault. The gameplay was originally meant for mobile but still fun on PC. The game is one of those games where you have to use a currency to speed up process, so if you are fine with games that do that(such as Clash of Clans or any other popular mobile game), then you are welcomed to play. System requirements are not high so you can play this on a generic work computer. Highly recommend this game to anyone who likes base building, Fallout series, role-play, mobile. It's also F2P too so all the F2P gamers who like Fallout series can have this game.

It is a fun game to kill time with. I like being able to develop the shelter and the individual Dwellers, especially once you get things to the point where you can use the various training rooms to up their SPECIAL stats. It is fun kicking out the older starter Dwellers with high levels and poor stats and replacing them with stronger, better armed Dwellers to make your Vault run more efficently. It is fun doing the daily/weekly quests. The dialog choices on some of them are absolutely hilarious. I enjoy sending Dwellers out to explore and bring back stuff I can craft with, then making better weapons to go kill stuff with.

The only thing that drives me nuts is when Bottle and Cappy come to your Vault and visit. Many times I can't get the caps bonus from Cappy because you have to hit his feet marker just right and he's dancing all over the place causing you to zoom in on the room instead. Oh and also, when they both leave the Vault within a minute of one another, which causes the Vault door to have to be opened twice and usually results in a Deathclaw or Feral Ghoul attack on the Vault. They really should leave at the same time since that is how they arrive.

Overall, a good game to enjoy while relaxing :D

Highly enjoyable until: 
1. You pass 60 dwellers in normal mode and get wrecked by Deathclaws
2. You start crafting and it takes DAYS.

A few rules of thumb for more enjoyable gameplay:
1. Unlock overseer's office ASAP for daily and (holiday) event missions
2. Don't level up dwellers working in production since it'll increase your average level and thus the strength of your enemies
3. Don't go nuts with 3-length rooms in the beginning before you have good gear
4. Endurance training is CRUCIAL since the E stat is what gives you more HP (the only stat that matters when fighting) when you level up
5. Send out dwellers into the wasteland early so you can get (hopefully) better loot sooner

Fallout Shelter is a very casual management game relying on various time (and pay walls) to extend the duration of a overly simple game. The primary game loop involves staring at your vault, occasionally clicking to collect resources and sometimes moving a dweller around.

It also seems this game is entirely clientside, which besides having huge security risks, means any data in the game is highly susceptable to being lost. Spent money on the game only to get your save corrupted? Too bad. There goes your money.

A great idle time burner if you enjoy idle time burners. And Fallout. The beginning of the game is a slog but once you get to being self sufficient and can make a ton of stimpaks and radaways you can send people out into the wasteland to collect more junk you never wanted! Also for those who prefer to keep games truly Free to Play, there's tons of ways to get Pet Crates, Lunchboxes, and Nuka Cola Quantum so unless you're a massive completionist or play a ton you'll probably get enough of the premium stuff from Quests, Challlenges, and Random Chance. The contorls are kinda janked for scrolling across lists since it was made for mobile devices but otherwise it's solid and has no bugs that I've noticed (except rad roaches....and rad scorps...have fun with those).

[h1][b]3.5/5[/b][/h1]
Fallout Shelter is a simple world/vault builder where you get to play as the Overseer, who's task it is, is to keep your vault and it's dwellers safe.

Will you send your dwellers into the wastes to find much needed resources for crafting armour and weapons or do you send them on quests to help or hinder your neighbours....or just go out to 'play' with the local wildlife... All tough choices in your roll as the all seeing Overseer.
                           
Overall Fallout Shelter is a fun decent port of a IOS/Android game,,,..with a few +'s and -'s. 

[h1][b]Pros[/b][/h1]
[list]
    [*]It's 100% free to play.
    [*]Simple yet addictive gameplay.
    [*]More Fallout the better (imo).....roll on Fallout 5 :D
    [*]Graphics are aesthetically pleasing (imo).
    [*]It works (mostly...see cons), most mobile phone ports are broken messes.
[/list]

[h1][b]Cons[/b][/h1]
[list]
    [*]Save files WILL disappear if the game/your pc crashes etc, back up your save files!!
    [*]Microtransactions included, but you can get everything they give ingame for free also!!
    [*]Microtransaction purchases are per save/vault only and can be lost due to losing saves....so again....run backups!!
    [*]UI ingame is quite clunky to use, can eaily tell it's a mobile game originally.
 [/list]

EXPANDED GAME REVIEW
The concept of the game is great, especially to someone like me who is a fan of fallout. If there was a game that almost perfectly represents being a vault overseer, this would be it. The graphics are good, being a primarily 2d game. The only thing I primarily dislike is the slow start, and at how much mercy you are at when it comes to the vault attacks. I have had some first hand experience getting some bad lunchbox loot, resulting in my vault being mostly if not entirely killed off by raiders, which really sucks considering how sluggish the start of the game feels. The adventure aspects of the game are pretty interesting since they do have "story lines" tied to them, but the travel times are horrible. It does make some sense in the sense that people have to travel in a vast, desolate wasteland, but its bothersome and even infuriating sending out vault dwellers with my best weapons for 5 hours just to proceed a quest or end up having my vault raided while their gone and losing dwellers I have trained. I, personally, do enjoy the game but the wait times drove me to play mostly on mobile (still free) since it was a general waste of space and time to play on my laptop. All in all, if your into tycoon games and waiting, you would enjoy this game.

I originally played this on my mobile device, and I got very far. I found out it was on my computer, and I immediately jumped to download it. It's a wonderful translation from mobile to PC, and vice versa if you played PC first. The control of it is just as smooth as the mobile version, if not nicer. Overall, great experience.

1) It may be free, but the developers really want you to purchase from the store. There is no need to purchase anything if you like waiting for a very long time later on in your vault. If you actually want your store to entice purchases, remove the ways to speed up the time by changing the computers clock. It would make me hate your game more than now.

2) Some of the achievements (though not many care about them), shoehorn you into purchasing Lunch Boxes to have a CHANCE to receive a legendary character. Because achievements are part of the game, I chose to rate it.

3) Quests are the worst part of this game. They have extremely long wait times until you can actually do them, the locations are very repeatable, and the enemies seem so stacked as to prolong your time in the boring quest. 99% of speech options don't change the outcome when in dialogue with an NPC making them seem unimportant. Only upside of these is the fact that they are partly non-linear. You can make it to the end quickly or accidentally go the wrong way (but your characters will hint that anyways)

4) The balancing for radiation needs to be looked at. It's very easy to run your resources on a quest or in a vault because of radiation. Even with a full vault of maxed out characters (and level 17 endurance) and rooms, best weapons and armor, Deathclaws and Radscorpions seem extremely unfair. Deathclaws seem to rip through any health your dwellers have, while Radscorpions will rip through health and irradiate them, making you waste double the resources and waste time micromanaging the vault.

Very fun to whittle away time with. This game involves a fair amount of micromanaging, as you have to assign people individually, and when you get upwards of 50 or so, it gets a tad tedious. But overall, really awesome game!

The short version? 50 million people downloaded the game on Android, before it even got to PC. So get it already. It's free.

The longer version. A serious warning up front. This game seems like a walk in the park - until it suddenly isn't. You can lose an entire vault, the fruits of months of realtime work, within minutes. So, let's avoid this, or more precisely, let's talk about how to avoid the possibility until you feel able to face the challenge.

Resources (energy, water, and food) are produced in production rooms. Rooms need energy, dwellers need water and food. The value of the production room does not give you its actual output. So, 20 dwellers do not need production rooms showing 20 food and water. Instead, every dwellers has skills (in Fallout normally called attributes, "special"), and the skill of the dweller in a production defines its output. More skill means more production, even if the room is not upgraded. In consequence, get a feel for what your vault needs by keeping an eye on your resource storage. If it fills up, however slowly, you're peachy.

This game has clearly defined progressive danger steps. Every tenth dweller adds a new threat (most notable until the 60th). So when you work on getting the feeling for production, I suggest doing so with nine dwellers.

Now that you know how to handle resources, let's go back to the core of the game, rooms need energy. If the energy storage of your vault even once falls below the line on the storage meter, you are in the process of losing your vault. Don't say you weren't warned. The reason why energy is more important than food and water is simply that there is no food and water without energy.

Getting a feeling for resource storage is not rocket science, so the real problem are the dangers. First, on the uppermost level of your vault build your first power room. The dwellers in it need strength for production, which also gives them resilience in a fight. Until you become really good, this is your best line of defense against intruders.

However, the true danger is random fires and infestations. With one exception, both fires and infestations do NOT spread diagonally. I am aware that 50 million people ignore this and every "best vault build" on the net tells you otherwise, but develop your vault keeping this in mind, and you cannot lose your vault...

... until you willingly and purposefully choose to have your 50th dweller !!!

The second your vault has fifty dwellers, infestations include radscorpions. They teleport. They not only rot out every dweller they find, they drain your energy storage even while in an empty room. So as long as you are not an expert in the game's mechanics and as long as you do not have the proper equipment, one of two things will happen. The merciful version kills all but three of your 50 dwellers and you may have a chance to start from scratch. Accent on "may". The cruel version kills only fifteen, but leaves you with an empty energy storage.

Well then, now that you are spared the nasty surprise, let's talk about the fun factor.  FOS is a blast. Could there be more contents? Sure.  Could some things be done better? You betcha. But FOS has that elusive ingredient, which once upon a time made Sid Meier's Civilization legendary. You start the game to do nothing more than the half hour of maintenance - and then your tummy rumbles, because, hey, you didn't even sip some water in the last eight hours.

Oh, one more technical tip. Unlike what the FOS wiki states, a higher Luck skill outside the wault does not give you better items, but more caps. Perception rules item quality in loot.

At the end, a word about shop items. If you don't buy items on principle, you can stop reading here.

The starter pack and the lunch boxes contain resources. The game sometimes asks you to collect a certain amount of resources. The ones from the pack and the boxes do not count towards this goal. So, the only obvious use of purchased resources is emergency fill-up after a botched radscorpion infestation. Throwing money at this problem would most certainly help, but given the hit dweller corpses cause to happiness, don't presume it will solve the pronlem all on its own.

The early value of the pack and the boxes is twofold, skilled dwellers and the chance for a rare or better weapon. A single rare or better weapon in your energy production room guarding the vault entrance makes a huge difference early on. Skilled dwellers before having the rooms to train them yourself are sheer gravy. There is a catch with both, though. 

Part of the game's fun is to figure out, which items are worth keeping and which aren't. When you buy boxes, make sure you have the item storage space - and remember, a dweller, who loots the wasteland, may come back with 40 items. 

The catch of skilled dwellers is a little tricky. You want your highest level dweller to roam outside for loot. The starter pack gives you a brutal advantage to this end. However, when you just started, your average vault level will rise significantly with the starter pack. So don't forget to give one of the weapons coming with the pack to your guard room. Raiders are not much of a trouble throughout the game, except this early.

I hope that this short review gives you a fighting chance without the frustration of a vault wipe-out.

Quite fun, very addictive with a heavy learning curve, the game can be quite difficult to manage until you find the right groove that works for you.

Expect to die a few times and restart your vault! The game has in app purchases but can be played and fully enjoyed without spending a dime on it.

You are an Overseer of your very own vault, unlike the cannon series here you allow people into your vault to strengthen it and to help make life easier as they all work together to stay alive.

The game has RPG elements with each dweller leveling up and having their own stats.
There is a lot of management and strategy involved as well, proper planning makes for a better vault, numerous quests, daily tasks and exploring that can be done to keep you busy in game for many hours.

All in all a very fun Free to Play game.

Game really is a pile of shit. 
Touch screen controls on a tablet/pc are spotty at best. 
No real control and AI is about the worst I have seen.

I'm not an expert on this type of game, but can say that Tiny Tower (Nimblebit) circa 2014 was way less infuriating and way more engaging.

I've played both on mobile and on PC. The game is much more suited for mobile, but it was too difficult on a small screen. Attackers at the door, then a stray touch (easy to do on "bezel-less" and curved screen phones) would zoom way in on a random spot on the screen...zoom back out, try to grab a 3mm tall guy on the screen, but can't do that until the resources are collected...collect the resources, misclick trying to tap-hold the guy 3 more times, zoom back in, grab him, slowly drag him to the vault door at max zoom, have the screen not register your finger for a moment while dragging him, scroll back down to that room, grab him again, and finally.........stick him in the front room. 

Now check his weapon, try sorting the weapon list, but still have to go through a list of 15 weak weapons to find your one rare/legendary that you stuck on someone after a failed rush.......now you have 1 defender! Of course, the fight's halfway over now, people are dead.

Now, watch slow, mostly passive combat with quirky, seemingly redundant controls. Are we having fun yet? TERRIBLE experience, boring as hell. And now you've wasted 8 hours of travel time because you wanted to save a few medpacks for incident emergencies.

Later, once you finally get a little resource security and medpack capacity, even if you don't have a radio station, watch deathclaws rip through your entire vault while you try to stop them with hunting rifle equivalents. Rage quit. Come back a bit later, get hit with deathclaws again before you've even been able to heal up from the first attack. Live in constant fear of the next deathclaw attack--or even the next scorpion attack, now that you're out of medpacks and rushing them is too risky--the next attack could wipe out your entire vault. Extremely mismatched risk for a game that's mostly planning and hands-off waiting. The best way to avoid losing your vault is to keep the game closed as much as possible. Lol?

Next day, your phone screen turns on once in the middle of the night...wake up to a pile of bodies and no way to roll back to the last save. Give up on that vault. There's so much waiting that you'll probably have the same result after falling asleep during all the excitement.

Tried switching to PC to deal with pain of moving defenders around to incidents, but it was almost as much a PITA as on Android. Also, the tap zooming is ridiculous. I just want to turn it off completely and only have it respond to mousewheel zoom. 

--

Positives: 
- Appropriately priced base game.
- The humor is legitimately great, especially for Fallout fans.
- Cloud save doesn't work between Steam and Android, but you can manually transfer unaltered savefiles between the two platforms. 
- You can also back up these files, but it's kind of a pain.
- Possible to edit your saves if you can resist doing things that will ruin progression.
- Critical hit meter is cool.
- Epically soporific excitement. Waiting 7 minutes for your medpacks to finish, 3 hours for your baby dweller, 3 more for them to grow up, 7 hours for your special point training, 6 hours for your team to get to a diner to fight a radroach, 8 hours for your scavenger to return, and 4 days for your weapon, all intermixed with deathclaw panic.

--

Negatives:
Freemium or not, I expect a LOT more from a major studio in terms of design. The basic interface interactions have NONE of the refinement/friendliness of your average knock-off clash game, and there's a lot to be desired in terms of quality of life. Also, deathclaws are ridiculously unbalanced at early levels.

Started on Android, but loads of problems. CONSTANT CRASHING. Had to reload game twice each time after it had been fully shut down. Quests would take like 10+ seconds of loading screen, usually followed by a crash. This is on probably the most popular flagship phone running Oreo. (Coudn't get it past the savefile screen on MEmu either.)  Hey Bethesda, maybe hire some mobile devs...on day 1, my phone actually warned me the app had crashed 10 times and that it was slowing down my phone. 


--

If you could turn deathclaws off in normal mode OR if the controls didn't so often get in the way of reacting quickly (eg preset loadouts, or pausing game while using equipment/garrison interfaces) I'd be way more excited about this game. 

-- 

Edit: Oh yeah, and the rush %sages are absolute garbage.  40%=90%. This mechanic isn't clever or challenging, it's just dumb. Given their obnoxious interface, the number should 1. accurately reflect the base rate, obviously, AND 2. visibly change based on the luck modifiers present so you don't have to tediously check every dweller's setup.

Whoever designed this mechanic should see if McD's is hiring.

Fallout Shelter review
Advantages of the game:
you can play this game just to chill
it's easy, so even if you are not a pro player, you can play that game with no problem
it's rather easy once you understand the game mechanics to gather many caps, which means it's easy to develop your vault
it's addictive, which means it's good pretty much
it's a game which you can max out, which means it is possible to complete all achievements
it's free and although it has microtransactions, they are not necesary to do in order to complete or to develop, make progress in game
Disadvantages of the game:
waiting, which is a part of the game, is incredibly annoyin' (at least for me)
gathering LEGENDARIES is time-consuming and extremely arduous
random incidents can really mess up!
once you reach some lvl and capacity of your vault, random dwellers stops to occur nearby your vault, which basically means you need first to estabilish vault necesary productions to make babies! That's right, you will make kids in that game.
Summary.
This game is fun as long as you are not impatient as I am. Then it will start to annoy you from time to time, frequently and consequently. Anyway it's a good option for people who don't have any games to play or simply are bored with currently owned titles. The game developers are frequently adding new content with new heists, weapons, outfits and many many more! Have fun, daddyo'.

Fan of the Fallout universe? You'll love this game.

Fun, adictive gameplay, fairly lighthearted, not overly challenging, but a relaxing experience in this world.

The only knocks I have against the game:
- this is not how Vaults work in the Fallout universe...I mean, it's a great way to exploit a theme, but these are hardly how the vaults were used in the real game.
- restrictive dimensions of the shelter...out in the world, vaults are often wider than the default size you are given to build your vault, it would be nice if maybe the vault size restrictions could be varied (some wider and shallower, some narrower and deeper...it wouldn't effect gameplay or memory, but would at least vary up the look of individual vaults. This is more of a "wish they did this" than a fault of the game though.
- since when did molerats become the terror of the wasteland? One pack of molerats can utterly destroy or disrupt your entire vault the way they spring up, spread and cause havok...seriously, it should not take six vault dwellers weilding rocket launchers, sniper rifles, machine guns and advanced laser cannons to kill a critter I can kill in Fallout New Vegas with a single blast of a shotgun. They are one of the weakest creatures in the entire universe, and yet it takes FOREVER for dwellers to kill them. What up with that?
- I ony wish they would have included super mutants...
- Wouldn't it be great to have an eyebot pet? Who wouldn't want an Ed-E of their own? (again, just wishful thinking)

Fallout Shelter is a free-to-play game which revolves around a few things:

- You build rooms in your vault and manage the dwellers, positioning them in the right rooms - so they are useful and happy.

- You send dwellers into the wasteland to explore and find junk, armour & weapons. If they have been outside the vault 2 hours before you recall them, they need 2 hours to get back to you.

- You send dwellers on quests, also into the wasteland. There's a wait time involved in getting to and from the quest objective. Once they arrive at the structure where the quest takes place, you direct the dwellers yourself in fighting enemies and exploring the place.

- You complete game objectives. You get 3 at a time and you can skip one per day for free. Skipping more requires you spend a Nuka Cola. They can be stuff like: Complete 3 quests. Gather 175 electricity in a minute. Survive 30 deathclaw attacks. etc. 

------

A lot of the stuff that happens in the game requires you to wait. Skipping the wait time requires you to spend Nuka Colas which are acquired in small quantities in-game, but which can also be bought using micro-transactions. (if you feel pressured to either buy Nuka Colas or Starter Packs, know that there is such a thing as a Fallout Shelter Save Game Editor where you can edit your save to give yourself those items (available here: https://rakion99.github.io/shelter-editor/ ). 

Fortunately, wait times are mostly reasonable, especially involving vault rooms. Resources (water, electricity, food) are produced quite fast. Rooms are built instantly. The longest wait times are the more advanced rooms where you build guns, armour, room themes and when you send dwellers on quests. 

In my experience, the gameplay progresses fairly smoothly and new rooms do not take very long to unlock. Most achievements are naturally acquired during gameplay as well, with a few exceptions.

These exceptions are probably the one place where you might seriously feel pressured into spending money. The problematic ones are:

-  Legend of the Wastes: Complete 100 quests - includes a lot of wait time TO and FROM quest location.

-  Interior Designer: Craft 1 of every room theme - can also take a long time and luck, though I achieved this fairly naturally without spending. 

-  Fashion Statement: Collect 20 legendary items - luck is involved, but if you enjoy the game you‚Äôll eventually get enough of them.

-  Armed and Dangerous: Collect 20 Legendary weapons - same as above.

-  Blast From the Past: Collect 20 Legendary dwellers - biggest problem. They appear rarely from Lunchboxes and VERY rarely in-game. Your best bet are starter pack which have 100% chance to include one each. This one is the biggest hurdle of them all. 

-----

For me the problems were: Legend of the Wastes and Blast from the Past. Since I enjoyed the game, I completed most of the other achievements naturally. However, if nothing else, Blast from the Past will certainly be a problem for anyone that cares about the achievement. 

If you find yourself no-longer enjoying the game, but still wishing to complete the last few achievements, I recommend using the Fallout Shelter Save Game Editor to get yourself a bunch of Starter Packs (for Legendary Dwellers) and Nuka Colas (for skipping wait times for other things).

Just two more notes regarding this: Lunchboxes are useless for Legendary Dwellers. You'd have to waste a ton of time opening hundreds of them to get even a few Legendary Dwellers. They are your standard lootboxes that usually contain trash. So, Starter Packs are the way to go.

Second: Achievements only get ticked while playing your first vault. I speak from experience, unfortunately.

------

I think Fallout Shelter is a fun time-killer and in most aspects a pretty decent game, save for a few hiccups in the port from mobile to PC. It offers a bit of a challenge to newbies and draws in the player with intriguing unlockables, a log of all of the equipment you've found from quests and in the wasteland, and a pretty nice progression system. For those reasons, I'd say the game is pretty safe to recommend.

For those of you who enjoy achievement-hunting like I do, however, I cannot recommend this game. If you're looking for a free game that seems like an easy 100% to add to your achievement profile, I'd suggest that you spend your time elsewhere. There is one achievement in particular that is locked behind a massive pay wall and will force you to fork over either hundreds of dollars or hundreds of hours to earn. Unfortunately, I figured this out after about 65-70 hours. The pay wall is a microtransaction bundle that costs $20. During in-game sales, which are infrequent, this bundle will usually drop down to $10. But even then, the achievement will still be a matter of luck, and the drop rates for what you're looking for are absurdly low.
