[h1]Fallout Shelter review[/h1]
[olist]
[*] [b]Advantages of the game:[/b]
[list]
[*] you can play this game just to chill
[*] it's easy, so even if you are not a pro player, you can play that game with no problem
[*] it's rather easy once you understand the game mechanics to gather many caps, which means it's easy to develop your vault
[*] it's addictive, which means it's good pretty much
[*] it's a game which you can max out, which means it is possible to complete all achievements
[*] it's free and although it has microtransactions, they are not necesary to do in order to complete or to develop, make progress in game
[/list]
[*] [b]Disadvantages of the game:[/b]
[list]
[*] waiting, which is a part of the game, is incredibly annoyin' (at least for me)
[*] gathering LEGENDARIES is time-consuming and extremely arduous
[*] random incidents can really mess up!
[*] once you reach some lvl and capacity of your vault, random dwellers stops to occur nearby your vault, which basically means you need first to estabilish vault necesary productions to make babies! That's right, you will make kids in that game.
[/list]
[*] [b]Summary.[/b]
This game is fun as long as you are not impatient as I am. Then it will start to annoy you from time to time, frequently and consequently. Anyway it's a good option for people who don't have any games to play or simply are bored with currently owned titles. The game developers are frequently adding new content with new heists, weapons, outfits and many many more! Have fun, daddyo'.

Fallout Shelter is a fun diversion from regular gaming with no real end game or ending in mind. Building your vault, unlocking rooms, and sending dwellers on quests are the highlights in a game that is mostly a grinding game and I love grinding games.

Explore the wasteland for legendary gear, craft legendary gear, repeat.

Once you've unlocked and built all of the rooms, removed the inferior rooms, completed all quests, fully leveled all your dwellers from level 1 to 50 while wearing E+17 gear, and everyone has a Dragon's Maw for a weapon, you are pretty much done. I've had a lot of fun with the game and have accomplished everything I can in it without having to spend a single dollar which is great for a f2p game.

[b]The good:[/b]
[list][*]You can do everything without having to spend money
[*]The quests
[*]Crafting outfits and weapons
[*]The vault rooms [i](even though I wish there were more to choose from)[/i]
[*]Customizing your dwellers[/list]

[b]The needs improvement:[/b]
[list][*]Ability to automate a response team to vault events
[*]Ability to see a vault family tree so you know who was born from which dwellers
[*]Improvement when selecting and dragging dwellers from room to room
[*]Needs to back up saves [i](saves can become corrupted. I created a batch file I run that backs up my vault when I finish a session just in case a save file becomes corrupted)[/i]
[*]When your vault has a population over 100, it become difficult to manage them all. Having the ability to change a dwellers weapon, outfit, and pet without clicking on the dweller. A dweller management screen.[/list]

In conclusion, my vault is fully functional with 100 dwellers, 25 dwellers exploring, everyone properly leveled and trained, and everyone with Dragon's Maw weapons and Legendary outfits as well. At this point there's nothing left to accomplish other than opening enough lunchboxes to get all legendary dwellers.
Glad it's on PC, now my 142 dweller vault doesn't make my phone a nuclear bomb.

Pros: 

1. It was FREE. Whats not to love?
2. Get to expand, get more peeps, upgrade shelter, customize peeps, go on quests! So many different quests!
3. Better weapons, skins for rooms, leveling my peeps, ooo pets!
4. Always seems to have things to do. 
5. Pleasant music, stuffed with humor (if you played Fallout4 even funnier), definitely entertained.
6. IF you want too - you can purchase small packages to move things along. Not a requirement, ever, to move ahead.
7. Has special quests and other stuffs for Holidays! So awesome I love this!

Cons:

1. Really can't think of any atm. Lol

the game starts out fun. but once the later game encounters start it starts to feel like you can't play the game anymore. when a bunch of death claws hit your vault you don't get anything from killing them. at most you can get some xp for the six dwellers that kill the last one. there's probably strategies for building up your vault early on to maybe minimize this mid/late game balance issue.... but i'm pretty sure that balance issue is there to push you to spend money. and freemium games that have this balance are pretty miserable.

i really liked it when i felt like i could watch my vault and that the rad roach and mole rat infestations were delt with without the risk of losing a dweller. and i actually looked forward to raiders because i was getting caps and gear from them.... but now that the rad scorpions and death claws are a thing i feel like i'm risking all of my resources getting sunk into the red and having to spend all my caps reviving dwellers because i ran out of stim packs because death claws ran through the entire vault or rad scorpions ended up hitting multiple rooms....

and so the fun feels like it's being held hostage by the freemium economy of the game. and i just wish there was a version of this game that kept all it's charms that make it worth playing without the freemium economy taking away the rewards for dealing with events like death claws, ghouls, rad scorpions and even mole rats. because freemium means all the perks of playing the game are locked behind loot boxes.... lunch boxes.... hell.... if i just got caps and maybe some junk from the late game encounters they would feel more engaging and not just a punishment for playing the game.

i want to recommend this game.... but the freemium balancing poisons the game. i'd feel less shitty for recommending lead as an artifitial sweetner. yeah led will sweeten your wine but it'll make you sick in the end.

also i somehow feel like they managed to capture the fat finger frustration of moving dwellers around that existed on the phone version of this game.... moving people around is tedious and utterly unbearable when trying to do so during an incident in the vault.

the quest system is pretty cool.... but again.... after a while it feels like playing this game is going to result in a punishment of a death claw invasion of rad scorpions.... and then everybody is just always sad... and i never feel like i can deal with individual dwellers because doing anything in the game means i could get hit with death claws and lose half the dwellers because i'm out of stim packs from the last event...... and it's so frustrating fighting with the shitty controls to move the dwellers out of the way and i'm never gonna have the caps to upgrade anything because i have to keep reviving all my dwellers.... and it feels like i have all this sunk investment in this vault that's just not able to keep up with what's getting thrown at it. so it feels like a failed vault.... and that's just a misserable cycle.... and i don't have access to money to spend on this game and with this shitty end game cycle that feels like it's just a money sink isn't the sort of thing i think anybody should be spending money on......

So I went into this game trying to play for free as much as possible, with the exception of buying the Starter pack. 
There is one effectively paid achievement in the Title but everything else is easily doable. My personal goal was to have 200 Dwellers with every S.P.E.C.I.A.L Stat at 10, with Legendary weapons and outfits, this is how long it took. 
If you're not willing to buy lunchboxes and speed up tasks with Nuka-Cola you will have to sit and wait, a lot, for things to happen. 
The way I got around this was just leaving it on while watching videos and playing other games, only paying the minimal amount of attention to this while my Dwellers got on with whatever busy work they were assigned, in that regard it ended up quite theraputic and become a little windowed companion in the corner of my life for quite a while. 
There are so many niggles with this game, it is definitely a mobile port that was probably never designed to be played for 350 hours, the UI needs so much work to make it user friendly, accessible and logical. However, you'll likely only be on this for a couple of hours so don't worry about it. 
So, to recommend, don't 'play' it, just have it running in the tertiary of your life for a while and let your little virtual ant farm grow.
Now, after 350 hours, I found I had achieved my goals except even with questing constantly and logging in every day as well as having 12 Dwellers exploring the Wasteland constantly I had a grand total of 7 Legendary Dwellers, found via lunchboxes. 
This is the one and only aspect of the Title that you essentially have to pay to progress, in my anecdotal experience, it might take me another thousand plus hours to farm the rest of the Dwellers, your mileage may vary, I'm not especially lucky.

==INTRO==

I've played more than it looks. My hours on the bethesda.net version didn't carry over. Fallout shelter is a game where you build your own fallout vault, populate it, and send your dwellers out on missions.

==GAMEPLAY==

Disturbingly microtransaction based, but not enough to make it unplayable. You collect resources from generators and water plants and missions and expand and improve your vault. Missions mean you have to arm your dwellers with guns you can get from raids on your base and ones you crafted or scavenged. You send them out with weapons, clothes, rad-away, and stimpaks into factories, houses, stores, etc which are jam packed with enemies and loot to bring back.

==MULTIPLAYER==

None.

==LENGTH==

Basically unlimited, it's really just one big grind though.

==DLC==

Nope

==MODS==

Double nope.

==PROS AND CONS==

Pros: Free, fallout based, so fans would like it.

Cons: Microtransactions, very grindy with not much actual content.

==RECOMMENDATIONS==

Who I would recommend this game to: People who are fallout fans, who don't have much money, who need to kill time.

Who I wouldn't recommend this game to: Actual strategy fans who want an in-depth game with no grind or transactions.

==FINAL SCORE==
7.2/10: It's alright, but I wouldn't get it unless you're broke from buying Skyrim on all platforms including your pez dispenser.

Review and Suggestions:
Not a fast game, building up a room at a time and hoping not to be eaten. Only 2 crashes in 605 hours where a vault is lost, so a very stable game. When you get by a certain point (unlocking all rooms and having high SPECIAL characteristics for your dwellers) all you will be doing is a High School game organising 50 or so unneeded dwellers between training rooms to increase their SPECIALs. Quests will become routine once you get a couple of high stat people on them, so become simple moving from room to room in far away vaults. So...

...Set your own House  Rules...
To keep the game fresh I just start again with a new history and set some self-imposed limits. I was born 1960 so some of my imaginary shelters may be around that period. Here are some home rules to freshen / complicate your game or just be horrified at:

- Must scrap all rusty weapons. Yes even that rusty minigun from your first Lunchbox.
- No sci-fi. Only use weapons from the 1950's or 1960's.
- Girls only get to use pistols. Only Men may use the big guns. Jim Kirk says so. Sexist reality means girls may not train stats over 5, except Charm. Men do not get kittens as pets.
- Segregation - keep different colours in different rooms. Always. Is there a room management problem here? No simply murdering allowed.  I suppose Apartheid would be 3 colours, and religious separation by clothing. Try to keep the Bishop out of rooms with naughty nightware in them.
- Don't get  Bottle and Cappy - they give out too much easy free caps and Nuka Cola Q.
- Logans Run... kill anyone aged (level) over 21.

...And so on. I'm sure it's got another 600 hours in it.

Chessboard it. Enjoy!

I've been playing this game for quite some time and mostly because I really like to waste my time. And f-shellter is really just a big waste of time, it can be enjoyable from time to time but imho it sucks. Since it's f2p and it killed 80 hours of my life I was 50/50 about recommending it.

The game is absolutely boring. You build resource buildings, then training buildings, then better resource buildings and that's it. You train your dwellers, really the only thing that matters is just better more dmg guns, even legendary armor doesn't make a big difference (I found some power armor early in the game and it changed totally nothing). You send your dwellers to explore, they find some legendary loot, you craft a legendary weapon (9 days) and send them to explore to bring you more loot for another weapon. Truly the game is super pointless.

There are quests, where you find yet more loot and guns. The quests are a disgrace to any fallout spirit whatsoever, fallout series is a masterpiece in the post-nuclear genre, being dark and hopeless, the wasteland is a harsh place, there are ideologies (enclave, brotherhood of steal etc), fight for survival degrades any morale there is left after the nukes fell down. The quests in shelter are so terribly dumbed down that even a class of retarded low-iq irradiated ghouls would find them offensive. You go looking for food recipes or santa clauss, for some baseball nonsense, I mean srsly, is it really that hard just to write a few lines of quality fallout story? If anybody reads that quest BS, why can't it be at least a little bit fallout-like. And this feels throughout all the game, it looks like it was created cheaply with the idea of "hey, it has fallout tag people will play it". Well and I did, stupid me.

There are so many annoying things it's hard to comprehend Bethesda left it at that. There is no search function, if you have 180 dwellers you scroll down looking for the one you need, the same goes with weapons and armor. When dwellers come back from exploration there is an option to sell common items, yet it doesn't sell all common items so you need to sell it manually anyway. You will be raided by deathclaws and attacked by mole rats for no reason at all all of the time you play, where you just have to wait 2 minutes for this irritation to end. And then we come to the point where I decided not to recommend this dumbed-down insult.

There is no end-game, so I was like yeah cool, I will just waste some time, gather the achievements and be done with it. And there is one achievement where you need to get 20 legendary dwellers. First I thought (and read about it) that breeding a legendary baby, which is rare, but happens from time to time, counts. It doesn't, you can get few legendary dwellers from quests, the others come from lunchboxes, which you gotta pay for, and you gotta pay a lot if you want to get this achievement. It would take long enough to get it with legendary babies, but now it's impossible. And here I thought, you sick bastards, you really want people to pay for a product half-done, not even remotely close to anything fallout like, with no endgame. 

I wouldn't play it if I knew all this before I started. I mean it's f2p so go and build your vault, but there will be lots of frustrating things you will encounter, and if you're a fallout fan then dissapointments too. I think even soda dugeon is more fun than this.

The "game" is quite easy once you know the basics and you will only likely feel challenged for a brief period of time.  After that, it is basically the same stuff over and over.  Constantly clicking on your production sites to collect food, water, etc, occassionally dealing with an attack of some sort, building new buildings and sending your dweller out on quests / exploring.  The quests should be fun but boil down to moving to each room and killing what is there, or on occassion hitting an empty room.  That's it really.  There is some cosmetic stuff like themes and haircuts but that is stuff I don't care about.  If you want something to occupy your time and nothing more, maybe it is for you.  It wasn't for me.

[h1] Let‚Äôs review : Fallout Shelter  [/h1]

Create your own vault, where you tend to your dwellers. Give them jobs, give them food, or throw them out in the world to scavenge for treasure and other delights! Put some of them in rooms and watch the miracle of light happen right before your eyes, and have lil‚Äôdwellers running around.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

+ Above all else, it‚Äôs free, and it doesn‚Äôt push micro transactions or paid subscriptions down your throat 24/7.
+ It‚Äôs set in the Fallout franchise of course, so you can expect a serious connection to the universe of the game!
+ Balance water, food, power and much more, while trying to maintain your dwellers alive and happy, which counts allot when you are trying to expand!
+ Quests ‚Äì Send your strongest dwellers on quests, to further peak your interest on what you may find out there in the ravaged world!
+ A multitude of collectibles, from weapons, special outfits, to pets and special dwellers!
+ It‚Äôs a game for the long run, think personal Ant-Farm! You‚Äôll watch them multiply and grow.
+ Create rooms for them to work in or play. Balance the power needs it each addition, and train your dwellers to become more efficient in the tasks you assign them to!
+ Get ready to be invaded and attacked from all directions. Be them Rad roaches, to bandits and the famous DeathClaws!

 [h1] Cons: [/h1]

- It‚Äôs a free game, so you can hardly find a negative in this game, it‚Äôs a time killer and a good one at it!

[h1] Final Review [/h1]

Fallout Shelter focuses on the building of a world for your dwellers, train them, and improve them with a huge selection of weapons and clothes. Manage everything from basic needs to outdoor adversities. And the best of it, its set in a great universe filled with lore, and it‚Äôs a great add-on to the big game! And it‚Äôs free!! So I have to give this game a solid 8 out of 10 for just being what it is.

Enjoy Guys and Girls, and if this review helped you in any way please leave me a Thumbs up, i would appreciate it immensely. And please consider joining me on Curate This ‚Äì A Honest Review at:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31479106/

My favorite mobile/management game. It take some understanding and it does start a little slowly but after about 3 days, it really picks up. I was surprised by how deep this game was. It may seem like it is only a vault creator game but once you unlock and build an overseerer's office, the game opens up. You go on quests and can explore some of the game's most fun moments. The radio tower also boosted how fast I got dwellers which made vault management much easier. I've already played 25 hours of the game, and I still have lots of fun things to look forward to (I haven't even gotten to the deathclaws or power armor yet). Also, major bonus: The game does offer microtransactions but is built in such a way that I was never tempted to buy them or felt like it was the only way to progress.

[h1] The Best Version of Fallout Shelter? [/h1]

[b] This is the best port of Fallout Shelter by far! [/b] The Xbox One version is locked at 30 FPS with NO vertical syncronisation. This version allows 60 FPS with VSync on, so if you're wondering which is the best version of the game. Also, don't bother with the mobile version (unless you want Fallout Shelter on the go).

8/10.

I love all things fallout, and this is no exception. However, this is honestly more the time killer resource management game you play when you have nothing better to do. It is free, which means it's worth at least checking out, but I will recommend that people avoid the microtransactions. You can't really "win" the game, you just get to a point where you run out of space and things to do really, so there's no real "pay to win" tactics in it, the microtransactions just bring you to that "nothing left" end of the game where you lose interest, slightly faster. Even then they may not even do that as it isnt uncommon for your game to crash, or glitch, or otherwise lose your vault so there isnt a lot of reason to pay for bonus stuff that doesnt actually do much and may disappear with no notice and no way to recover those items. Just play and enjoy the game as is, dont waste money on it unless you truly have a strong urge to support an already massive developer

This is a simple game with not much to it and can be a little slow to get going. You build different rooms, train, clothe, arm your shelter dwellers and travel to different shelters doing various quests. Your shelter can be attacked, you can send dwellers to search for supplies and must have enough food, water and power to survive. Dwellers can be customized later which is a fun aspect and a mystery man randomly appears which can give you money when he's clicked. You can also have pets and have your dwellers breed new children. This is a game you play and then need to come back to in order to progress. Once you've done checking in with your shelter there can not be much to do until you go back in and play hours later. Yet you can waste a ton of hours playing this game. 6.5/10

It's a free game where you can purchase some in game currency and lunchboxes that give you different items/resourches. Both can also be collected while exploring the world or doing quests. I never had the urgency to use and real money on the game. It's played in real-time, meaning things can take hours to happen. Collecting resources is usually faster, while doing quests or exploring can take a whole day. You can't play this game non-stop without using any real money to rush. 

I had issues with the fact that the dwellers cannot level up after level 50 and that they don't level up while training. Really annoyed  me, and also the fighting mechanism is repetitive and can bore you out really quickly. Nevertheless, its fun to collect all the items in the quests. You also have to make sure exploring dwellers have enough resources to survive outside the vault and that they return in time. It happened often to me that I had to revive the dwellers because they died on me. The vault keeps getting attacked by raiders or different creatures, but they are usually not too hard to deal with if you keep an eye on the dwellers and keep healing them, and also equip them all with weapons. 

Overall it's a fun game, that can quickly become addictive.

This game is great for those who want to get into fallout. Though this game is not a 3rd person shooter RPG like fallout, it allows you to picture the struggles that the vault dwellers would face underground. You don't need to play any other fallout titles beforehand to understand the game. 

GAMEPLAY: The game is more inclined to the casual player, but die hard players like myself are also fans of the game due to its optional diffuculty change and mechanics. Unfortunately this game has, you guessed it "MICROTRANSACTIONS" everyounes favorate cancerous feture. you can buy "nuka cola quant" to speed up the game, but the game gives you a small taste where you can earn them during quests. you can also buy "lunchboxes" which are your lootboxes (yes even this game unashamefully inclines the purchases of lootboxes) which can provide a range of resources including dwellers, armor, pets, and junk. I do have to say that the game is solid, but from my personal experiance the game starts to slow down at around 60 dwellers, and becomes a chore to play later in the game.

While this game can be very fun to play, please take care not to advance to quickly if you are not upgraded enough with your dwellers. Harder mobs will approach your vaults the moe dwellers you have, not based on level. If you have a lot of dwellers, but not enough higher quality items, you could be in for a very dangerous and possibly vault breaking time. Becareful and make sure to uprgade gear as best as you can. I still recommend this game though. It is a lot of fun. Enjoy. :-)

After 65 hours, 75 dwellers, and an efficient cap-earning system coupled with nigh-impenetrable deathclaw-proof defenses, lvl 50 max. SPECIAL dwellers, I went in tonight to check on Vault 666 and found it had been completely erased. It was soul-crushing, and I'm probably not going to restart for quite some time. I was very attached to the successful haven I had made.

BUT

This game is excellent, especially when you have downtime. If you check on it and make minor adjustments once a day, your vault will be self-sustaining and easy to manage going forward. Missions outside of the vault are a great way to get more unique items, and sending dwellers that have been hard at work maxing-out their SPECIAL skills both levels them exceptionally well, while simultaneously pulling in large amounts of junk items, weapons and armor; which, if you have in abundance, can be sold for extra caps. I spent the last two quarters of my time playing with a constant 999,999 caps, dwellers in pristine condition, incoming threats usually never made it past three rooms at the most, and my ability to manage my resources patiently more than paid off. A lot of patience, proper reservation, and a lot of trial and error can turn this game from a major sensory overload into a casual tycoon-esque experience that demands little. It was pure fun.

I cannot stress enough, however, that you absolutely MUST back up your saves. I wish I didn't have to learn this the hard way, but that's what I get for being arrogant enough to think it couldn't happen to me.

If you're looking for a fun game to play on your own, or a good Bethesda game, or one simply related to the popular Fallout series, the I recommend this game. Very simple and fun. This is a very time consuming game and does require a bit of paitience but I think it is worth the wait.

Honestly, I was actually hooked to the game once I figured it out. When I saved and quit the game and went back to my vault, my resources were all depleted. I remember seeing my resources maxed out before exiting. I couldn`t do anything to fix the problem.

This is a free game and therefor it has the option for micro-transactions in the game. Normally I am immume to MT's and ignore it, but in this game I am really tempted to buy ingame items! This shows that they have been pretty smart with how they have created this game. Even though you can play the game without any extra MT's you are lured into buying stuff and constantly reminded that it is an option. 
 
The game itself is really fun and actually pretty tactical if you want to max out a vault with 100 dwellers. You need to think ahead and plan the layout of the vault wisely or you will shooting yourself in the foot later on in the game. There is lots of stuff to do in the game and you are constantly busy with keeping your vault running in proper order. You can also send your dwellers on quests that will take place on different maps where you can get loot and key items and of course you can send them into the wasteland and let them explore. 
 
The concept of the game is brilliant so in a way it is a bit of a shame that the game has been designed around MT's. I would love to see a full single player game of Fallout Shelter without the MT's and the slow progress, but for now I will just enjoy the game as it is. And I might even turn weak and buy some ingame goodies aswell :)

[h1]  Fallout Shelter [/h1]
Fallout Shelter is a pretty nice managing game. You got a vault set in the dystopian world of Fallout and you manage it. 

[b] Simple, right? [/b]

However, you have to manage food supplies, electricity, clean water, the population and demand of the vault, and be aware of the few deathclaw and raider attacks that are sprinkled about. 
It's an addictive and fun game, for sure, and quite easy really, to manage in general. Except it's easy for things to go downhill if you don't know what you're doing properly. I almost lost a vault to bad power management, but salvaged it eventually. There are also quests, which I like, as instead of just clicking the "Go on Quest" button like in most games, after your dwellers arrive, you decide which part of the area they explore (roomwise, as it's still in the 2D style of the vault), which is a nice feature. The graphics are simple, and look nice, and I like how they mix the paper looking 2D characters with 3D backgrounds. It's a relatively easy game, I wouldn't say it's been too stressful in my experience of it so far, and the attacks on your vault can surprise you, but it's still not that bad. Pretty good game, and would recommend taking a look at.

This game loses its innitial appealing novelty and replayability after, oh, say around 50+ hours, or even less.  The fightings are boring, mundane, and repetitive after you've mastered locking down the enemy attacks on your vault. WARNINGS:
(spoilers here on for combating Deathclaws and Radscorpions) Initially, you can't do much against Deathclaws attacks because they're too fierce in speed attacks, but at least they ONLY comes from way of breaking down your vault door. After putting 2 guards on vault door with either or both vengeance and dragon maw weaps, and 6 sentry guard on the next room to the right of it, which I used living quarter, or barrack, using same weaps, no more problem with Deathclaws.  Radscorpions are much more of a nuisance if you don't equip your guys and gals with potent weaps, as well.  That's it. That's the final challenge of this game, which to me is lacklusters.  But I understood this game would lose a lot of player interests after they've come to same conclusion of meeting most of the challenges of the game.  
I can't see myself playing anymore (post appocalyptic) games like these because it's a real downer to the hopeful spirits of those who get fed up with blasting NPC's/players' characters into exploding guts and gores.  Way depressing after awhile, which is why I tried this dumbed down graphic version of "Fallout Shelter".  Thought I just play a cartoon version of this grim imagery of what Bethsheda is known for in Fallout 1-4.   Not real keen on the atmosphere of these ghouls and zombies type games due to its mostly non-eye candy scenes.  The initial fun of this game is exploring and experimenting of the different type of unlocked rooms and what it does to help and train the vault dwellers, but after that and gathering enough gold junks to make and developed all the high end weaps for most of your dwellers, it becomes mundane and boring without any challenge left. That's the conclusiong of the appeals to this game because the fighting is boring and less than 2 dimentional appeals.  You finally log on and wonder why the hell you're still playing this heap.  Think I'll just go  get a fern plant and water it instead...

[i] Fallout Shelter [/i] is a management game where the player, as an overseer, manage their underground vault where they can customise the vault's layout, its dwellers and collect/ build items such as weapons and outfits, as well as send vault dwellers exploreing, whether that be in the wastelands or on a quest. Players would also defend their vaults from intruders from oversized bugs to massive Deathclaws.

As someone whose never played a Fallout game beyond hearing bits and pieces of the setting, this game really got me hooked in and I literally spent a night just playing this. While this game might be repetitive and perhaps eventually boring, for those who like simple management games this might get one hooked in.

[h1] Concepts (out of 10): [/h1]

[b] Graphics = 9; [/b] While not as HD as the main fallout games, the cartoonish graphics that's also used is the main art style present in this game..

[b] Music = 3; [/b] Outside of quests, this game really doesn't have any music to go along with the game beyond hearing machinery being used in the vault.

[b] Cinematics = 3; [/b] Beyond introducing players to the game, there really isn't any cinematics for this game.

[b] Story = 3; [/b] Beyond quests that feature a mini story, story us practically non-existent in this game.

[b] Content = 8; [/b] With a large amount of ways one can customise their vault, the attributes of vault dwellers both physically and statistically, large variety of weapons and outfits players can collect, and the quest which feature a story of their own, this game will only be a turn-off once one gets a general idea of how the game works.

[b] Controls = 10; [/b] WASD or mouse for looking around and left clicking to interact. Really straight forward.

[b] Gameplay = 7; [/b] The main attraction to this game. As previously mentioned, players manage their vault, its dwellers and what they do. However this might get pretty boring quickly.

[h1][b] Overall = 6.1; [/b][/h1] Obviously, this game will eventually get boring as there's little action to this game. If one likes management game, however, then this game might be worth a play around for a while.

I've spent months playing it on my phone, but it was pain in the butt on a small screen. Really glad I can play on laptop!

An excellent little management game that is genuinely free. There are booster packs to purchase, but the only reasons you might want to spend money on them are :
- you're trying to raise your chances at finding legendary dwellers for the legendary dwellers achievement (good luck with that !)
- You messed up how you started your vault, and you don't want to start over, but would rather need a little help to straighten things a little bit faster
- you're starting a third or fourth vault and you want to accelerate the first phases of development which are no longer enjoyable now that you master the core concepts
- you want to have it super easy
- you're just curious to see all the different bonuses and cool items there is

To sum it up, there's nothing you can purchase that you cannot get by just playing the game. Paying for items will just increase your chances at getting interesting stuffs earlier.

The game isn't hard; it is actually rather relaxing most of the time, and rather satisfying, as long as you're not too impatient, especially in the early stages of your vault development during which there isn't so much to do.

The game looks great, it's pure retro-futuristic fallout advertisments porn. I always loved the concept of the vault boy since the first fallout: it fully embodies the falsely innocent and reassuring propaganda in a world of insane gritty violence expressed as casual and normal.

The game suffers from a couple of ui issues I think, mainly because it was built for touch screens and no effort has been made to make it more mouse friendly: you spend quite some time dragging stuffs around as you would on a touch screen, but sometimes, the game will have you drag this or that guy, when all you wanted was to slide the screen down. Nothing too annoying, although it will usually happen at the worst moment.

A couple of tips : 
- Go for the Cappy and Bottle missions as soon as they're available to you: once you've acquired Cappy and Bottle, they will provide a nice boost to your vaults
- In the beginning of the game, it's usually a better investment to augment the level of a room before expanding it, except maybe for the medbay and science lab (level increase doesn't improve storage capacity for these two). Later, when you have a lot of caps, it's less expensive to do the opposite.
- Train your dwellers' endurance as early as possible, it will make them more and more durable in combat as they level up
- Train luck second, ilt will enable you to perform more successful rushes which will increase your vaults hapiness and therefore productivity, and will raise the change of getting caps while collecting resources
- Clothes stats bonuses will add up to your dweller's stats even above 10, though the game displays stats at 10 max.
- Prioritize low level, low happiness dwellers for pregnancies. Pregnancy boosts happiness of both parents to 100%. Low level dwellers aren't very efficient when dealing with hazards and calamities. A pregnant dweller will run away, so it's no loss.
- I used to create whole rows dedicated to one activity, and found out, that althought it looks nice, it isn't a convenient design. A whole row of storage rooms looks tidy, but when a problem arises there, dwellers take more time to get to it which might lead to having said problem spreading around before they do. So it's better to have a passive type of room next to a productive one, as you will have stronger dwellers in the latter, that you can send in the neighboring rooms to deal with any problem switfly.

So been playing this for a couple of days and it's not bad.  If you have Nuka-Cola it actually feels like a game.  The difficulty can ramp up pretty fast, but that should be expected by now with Bethesda's love for lulling the players into complacency before slamming them over the head with a super sledge.  I originally thought it'd just be an idle game with the Fallout name slapped on, but it can be pretty interactive in everything you end up doing.  The worst part about it, other than the very annoying radscorpion attacks (not so bad if your vault is small) is the wait times.  You have to be very cautious with your caps while waiting on your explorer(s) to bring you more.  It can be tedious at first, as I've found out so far, but it seems like the longer you go the easier the finances become.  There will be a lot of incidents that occur, though, which can be really frustrating if you're trying to get off the game to do other things.  You can't save and exit until the crisis is over, and you can't permanently assign dwellers to rooms or exploring until things settle back down.  A nice touch, however, is that after the battle or fire or whatever ends they'll go back to their original room.

Pay attention to the occupancy limit for each room, and never, ever build your office on the top floor.  You need that space for defenders!

When I switched to playing on the PC, that problem was solved.

Can't see what people found great about this game.  In reality, it's poorly put together and a P2W tragedy.  After starting numerous games and playing each for hours, I've learned the 1 thing anyone interested in this game needs to know.  Your success in this game is solely based on the luck of the draw.  Really, what keeps you thriving is the luck you get when opening their lunch box thingies.  I've started the game (they give you 3 of these lunch boxes pretty much near the beginning after doing just a few quests) and have gotten rare vault dwellers, good armor, and nice weapons...and other times I've opened all of them and not gotten jack.  I tried a play through where I got absolutely nothing and it wasn't just bad--it was horrible.  I sent the one character out that had a weapon and after about an hour they finally found something in the wasteland (and this is me an hour at the keyboard, waiting while doing pretty much not much in the vault.  When you aren't waiting around for the cooldown of your resources or a vault dweller to either find a weapon or return, you're putting out some random ridiculous vault encounter, such as radroaches mysteriously cropping up out of the ground from burrows.  I don't know who thought this concept up, but it was pretty bad.  I love the Fallout series too, but all I give this is a thumbs down, down, down.
In short...
PROS - decent system of building, easy game play, decent tutorial.
CONS - (everything)  This game is 99.9% P2W.  You could spend all your money on lunchboxes and get beefy enough not to have to worry about anything.  Other than that, you're waiting hours for your vault dwellers to find stuff in the wasteland, praying you get lucky to get a sub-par gun (you only find the good stuff from lunchboxes).  The controls are clunky and will often times get you angry at their poor design.  One time I was trying to click on a mysterious man, only to realize that the resources of that room were up and I had to click that first and then the mysterious man.  he had vanished by then.  There is just so much bad about this game.  Don't buy if you are easily frustrated!

Have you ever wanted to raise a toddler through the worst aspects of parenting? These can include things such as the child crying, having self destructive tendancies, inability to think for itself as well as having to clean up its messes, dress it, feed it, and make sure it is happy while sacrificing your personal time with friends, family and sleep just to keep up with it, and that is not to mention all the things to buy to make the experience a bit more tollerable. 

However, usually with a child, you bond with it both physically and emotionally, and eventually it becomes self sustainable, able to feed and dress itself as well as clean up its own messes. This game is the above listed worst aspects of raising a child without the benefit of emotional or physical bonding nor the prospect of ever becoming self sustainable.

I played this game quite close to its release date on my mobile device. I played for about a week or so, growing my vault until I had a good population size and everything was going fine. Then a routine fire broke out and killed everyone. There were 6 people in the area where the fire started, the maximum amount of people for a room, none were pregnant, and none of them survived despite the use of stimpacks. The fire spread and killed my entire vault. So I uninstalled it. 

I played this game for about a week, took my time with it, got all of my vault dwellers good gear and good levels, and molerat broodmothers invaded a room with 6 people in it, no pregos, and killed them all. They then infested my entire vault and they all died. This happened in the span of 3 minutes I was AFK to grab a drink. All it took was 3 minutes to destroy a weeks worth of work. 

If you enjoy that kind of challenge, one that runs on a real time clock and never relents, then yes, play this game, it does not get easier the farther you go. If you are like my and can't stand Dark Souls level games, don't bother with this one, the mechanics are oriented around pay to win and from what I have read in other reviews, paying makes no difference in ease of gameplay. 

Don't get me wrong, I do like the concept of the game and the sim quality it has, I just wish it was redesigned for steam to be more playable.

Recommended.

I spend almost 80 hours on this game.
It's pretty much the old tamagotchi in a new format.
You need to spend at least 1h or so per day (3 vaults) to make sure everything goes well, your dwellers stats are being trained, people are sent out to explore etc.
It starts out fun, but after a while it becomes tedious and repeditive, and I felt forced to log in and do my chores.

After a while you learn how to arrange rooms correctly, but then it's to late and you can't change it anymore, which sucks.

But the biggest annoyance is that after some progress, every time you open a vault it gets raided by Deathclaws and you can't do anything other then just heal your people. You have to wait until it's over to go on and do the rest of the stuff. You can never watch a youtube video/twitch or walk away while a vault is open, or you run into the risk that your vault is getting raided and everybody killed.

Not sure whether or not to recomend it, since i did have some fun at first, but i feel like the time is spend better on another game.

It is not a bad game. It is good for transition period to real life after the latest Fallout game has left a hole in your soul and you need to fill it with something. The visual and audio part of the game is perfect and, as it was already said, it is not a bad game. It‚Äôs just not for everyone. 

Why would not I recommend it? 

It is a time-stealer. As much as the game is beautiful there‚Äôs no ‚Äúhigher purpose‚Äù ‚Äì no engaging story or anything like it. You just do routine tasks: build>collect resources>random small/daily quests>defend the shelter from attacks>repeat the cycle. The game just becomes boring after some time and you are left with the dreadful feeling of guilt over all that time that was wasted on nothing. Meanwhile the game keeps sending you reminders to collect collect collect. As stated ‚Äì this kind of "cycle-like" experience is not for everyone. 

Another con ‚Äì it does not sync with mobile and there are plenty of better "fallout-nostalgia" options for PC gaming (like older fallout games).

Get Oxygen Not Included instead !

This game is a time stealer.  If you have like 2 minutes to check the game since it runs constantly. As soon as you get on it starts bogging you down with maintenance.  Then there's an immediate attack, followed by tons more maintenance then not enough money to fix everything that broke while you were gone.  There's tons of unhappiness that has to be raised.  Fifteen or twenty minutes later you've finally got everything under control but you only had 2 minutes and now you have to rush off to take care of business other than the game.  When you finally get an hour to log in you spend another twenty minutes of maintenence before you can do anything with the quests and it gets tedious after a while.   There isn't enough adventure.  Too much waiting.  Too much of the game trying to beg you to spend your hard earned money on ridiculous perks in the game that you lose in a few minutes. As a F2P game it's a very fun experience as while it does have in game purchases it they aren't anything you need to do well in the game and can be earned without spending money. Overall an enjoyable experience... That would be the end of the review if it weren't for one HUGE problem. I had to start over, FROM SCRATCH, not once but TWICE! This because when ever the game was closed via a method other than hitting the exit button in game wether it be your computer losing power or just reseting for some unexplained reason the game will delete your vault. As you can imagine this can be very disheartening when it happens for the second time after 75 hours of in game playtime. The first time it had happened I had spent 3-4 days IRL building up my vault and the second time I had just spent a little over a week. This is an issue that I hope the eventually fix as it is otherwise a perfectly fine F2P game. So if your looking for a fun way to kill some time than yeah this should keep you busy for a while. As for me it'll be a while before I'm willing to take another whack at it with what will be my third vault...

Somehow this game makes me feel like I am wasting my time doing.. what exactly?

If you start out with a good setup there's not much of a challenge. I have read about dying dwellers or lack of caps in other reviews, but I haven't had those problems and did not pay for anything. 

It doesn't feel satisfactory to keep doing the same things over and over again. Get more dwellers, they need more water and food hence you expand or upgrade, which asks for more energy hence you expand or upgrade.. explore the wasteland, bring back some loot, explore again. Craft better weapons, level up, kill some rad scorpions and put out some fires. And again. And again.

To unlock rooms or certain upgrades you have to have a minimum of X dwellers. To me, it would be more challenging to see how you could cope with as few dwellers as possible (seems way more efficient than having lots of dwellers). You would have to think more, plan ahead, train certain dwellers a certain way. 
Now, it feels like I'm mostly  just clicking and dragging. Need more dwellers? Just get the women pregnant. (Their childern will be pretty stupid, no matter how skilled their parents are, but even that doesn't really make a difference when your vault is running well.) 

The 'fights' are too simplistic for my taste: when on a quest you run into a room and just wait until you have won. Sometimes restore the health of a dweller during the fight. You click on some boxes to get loot, go into the next room, same thing until the quest is completed. I do like that sometimes you can have a conversion with your enemies where it seems your answer matters (you either get to fight or allowed passage depending on your answer) and the enemies do get stronger, but you get stronger as well so again, not much of a challenge.

I guess it's just really not my kind of game. I tried to like it and I get the addictive part of the game, but after playing it I feel like I could have done something better with my time. Anything really.

It's free but I felt it worth getting the one-time starter pack since I'd played for a number of hours and was enjoying it.

A few tips:
- When you can send people out to the wasteland leave them out for a while, it seems to take time before you start getting items.
- Make sure you have nuka cola quantum if possible to avoid long waits for getting to quest areas and coming back from them. That said, once your vault has enough people in it to keep going while people are away questing it can be good to send people off to pick up weapons, schematics and other gear.
- Try to send people who are higher level then what the quest needs and ideally send a party of 3 with as much stim packs and rad away as possible (click the max button for each as due to a bug the items won't be available in the quest if you add the items one by one). Rad away is sometimes useful, but you'll usually need one or more stim packs.

1. GAMEPLAY
Quite enjoyable gameplay (6/10) - especially at the beginning, when you need to discover the game potential. I like to manage my base, relocate dwellers, train them or send on quests, read about their abilities and item descriptions, looking at the room gear animations, planning further rooms and their usage, cloth my people in manner that indicates my strategy (e.g. everyone are suited as soldiers or warriors, the most experienced units got Officers Uniforms) or that complies with room specification/outfit.

CONS: Game start to be monotonous very quickly, because of lack of rooms and its customization. Gameplay is based on real (I mean: REAL REAL TIME) time events, so you need to spend a lot of time waiting for finishing training, traveling to the quest destination or completing current task. If you don't want to cheat (e.g. by looking for Fallout Shelter Editor or manipulate on preferences of your local system time), and you don't like the idea of micropayments suited in the game, you must be prepared to play regularly for a couple of minutes once a day for weeks, to gain measurable results of your progress, and not to waste your life on observing how the clock pointer is ticking. :)

CONS: Base rushes: from outside or inside can be painful, especially when you have unexperienced dwellers or when you are attacked by radscorpions! :) But they variance are countable, and the level of opponents are not challenging after a couple of days you have played and after boosting your dwellers on training rooms.

CONS: armors and outfits do nothing (or this is not visible) except changing dwellers looks. When you boost a dwellers ability to 10 (maximum), wearing an outfit that increases that ability to 15 or 17 does nothing. Moreover, suits do not protect you from enemy damages, radiation or environment dangers (e.g. during a fire).

2. GRAPHIC
Warm and sympathetically graphics (6/10), which reminds me of Pip-Boy icons from Fallout 1 / Fallout 2. But it is not very... time-consuming, precise and well made. I mean: it's ok, but for Casual Games quality flash technology standards. :)

3. MUSIC
Music is almost unnoticeable, not impressing and average (4/10).

4. OTHER
Very smart move with implementing lunchboxes, pet boxes and starter boxes, from where you get randomized items. This is, probably, the most enjoyable element of the gameplay: clicking on cards and waiting for what will be dropped from the box this time. But this is not recompensating the game monotonous - just a little pros for the game retention. ;)

Two words are all I need say in order to justify giving this a negative review.

Molerat invasions.

Yes, I understand the "avoid dirt" and "upgraded/bigger rooms spawn upgraded/more enemies".

However, the game encourages you to build and upgrade and expand, then punishes you for it. I should not have to play the game in unintuitive ways to avoid game breaking bugs. I should not be forced to revive 75% of my shelter due to ONE molerat overcoming the remaining defenses in the room he spawned in. I should not have 12 bodies in the same room, with one single molerat laughing over their corpses as it initiates waves of spawns in neighboring rooms and  promptly vanishes after dispatching everyone that SHOULD have stood a chance.

I shouldn't have to talk about "standing a chance" in battles against molerats. There is no reason for this sort of player punishment. Every other enemy/encounter is manageable, molerats require you to CHANGE THE ENTIRE WAY YOU PLAY THIS GAME just to avoid their BS.

Strategies that work for avoiding molerat pwnage.

Build a jumbled mess of single, unupgraded rooms.

Surround your vault with elevators to avoid any spawning rooms touching dirt.

When a mole rat invasion occurs, do not fight, instead, run away and then run through said invasion to the safety of previously invaded rooms, let molerat death waves wash over vault.

NEVER USE RUSH.

Seriously, *STRONG EXPLETIVE* WHOEVER "BALANCED" THESE RATS!!!

I'm glad it's on PC but it's difficult to keep playing the game. There's challenges and things that can be done daily, but like any mobile game, everything is locked to real-time. The game does give you premium currency while playing and you can use that to fast travel to and from missions as well as speed up any other processes. Farily simple game with the common mobile micro-transactions. 

The game scales in difficulty as you keep playing causing your vault to get raided more often and by bigger and stronger enemies. It's annoying and commanding your characters around is really basic. It has a little more control than other mobile games but it still feels a little too stiff and at times hopeless having to micro-manage every single person around so they don't die. 

It's a fun game for sure! It just gets to a point where it gets more and more repetitive and boring. Waiting 8 hours for your team to reach the new mission and then another 8 hours for them to come back while dealing with fires, rad roach infestations and more. The challenge kind of gets dull after a while but if you play this game a little at a time, and don't burn yourself out of it, you may get more fun out of it. I just lost interest after a while.

Once you start playing this game, you're not going to stop. I've spent over 100 hours on my vault, without spending a penny on in-game purchases. I've had dwellers maxing out their stats so they could be the very best at their jobs and I've got almost all of the achievements in the game.

In all of the spare time I've had between the odds and ends of my real life, I've been dedicating a fair fraction of my digital life to vault 285, where Three Dog works at the Radio station and I have a Mr. Handy on every floor that serves to power the whole facility. If that wasn't enough, I've rescued Bottle and Cappy and defeated all four Horsemen of the Post-Apocalypse.

In hindsight, it was totally worth it. The more time you put into it, the more fun it's going to get.

  -  For such a limited and extremely short game, there sure are a lot of "Premium Content Purchase Packes" available..and in such high quantities?


***I still say it's fun, but...they used to make some game demos larger than this.  I might even go so far as to suggest this is likely an indicator of darker times ahead for Bethesda...considering with the Fallout franchise/universe being rather immense, they're running Interplay's masterpiece into the coals at a rate equivalent to Disney's seeming incapability to produce a good Star Wars movie.

This game... It's enjoyable in certain aspects. I like managing my vault dwellers. I even enjoy the fact that I have seen myself grow slowly more evil the more dwellers I get, caring less about them individually and caring more about the bottom line. Is there enough power? Is there enough food and water? Are my dwellers meeting their mandatory happiness quotient of 75% or more? In that sense, the game is very fun.

Here are my issues with it, and why I can't recommend it in good conscience.

1) Kids suck. I completely understood my kid dwellers having garbage stats when ALL my dwellers were garbage. However, when I pair Lucas Simms and Star Paladin Cross together, goddammit I expect their child to have some decent stats. If they're NOT going to give me the ability to breed a stronger vault population, then I need to be able to stick those little good-for-nothings in one of my many training facilities so that by the time they grow up, they have a BIT of a stat boost. There's more, but I'll move on.

2) If you're going to throw deathclaws and radscorpions at me when I hit 60 dwellers, I need to have the capability to provide my dwellers with better weapons. Frankly, it pisses me off that the ONLY good weapons I've gotten in this game are lucky drops from lunchboxes. Weapons cost too much to make, and the upgraded weapons crafting station is too expensive. I've dropped REAL money on this game. More than a game like this should be worth, and I STILL can't afford it, since my vault dwellers are constantly being ripped apart. Four dwellers with sawed-off shotguns SHOULD be enough to kill 5 molerats, or one radscorpion.

3) Speaking of disasters, when a fire breaks out, or a radroach infestation occurs, or when molerats attack, or when deathclaws break through my front line, all the vault dwellers on that FLOOR should be responding, not just the ones in the room. I gave my door guards a gatling laser and a fat man, and they need to damn well use them to their maximum effectiveness, not just sit idly by while any number of menaces wreak havoc on the rest of my vault dwellers who only have sawed-off shotguns and hunting rifles.

4) I regularly have full stocks of stimpaks and radaway. FREAKING USE THEM VAULT DWELLERS. EXHIBIT SOME AUTONOMY. 

I can feel the tendrils of microtransaction greed gripping every aspect of this game. I don't really mind microtransactions. Obviously if I did I wouldn't have spent a dime on this game. What I do mind, is microtransactions that don't REALLY give you anything. This game is designed to feed off of you like a vampire, constantly biting at your neck to get you to buy MORE lunchboxes, MORE quantum, MORE Mr. Handy's to collect your resources. And that's what I hate about this game.

If you're like me, and easily sucked in by resource management games, do not expect a SIMS-like experience.

Time waster.

I can't recommend this game in good conscience, even though it is a free-to-play.

I played it a lot on Android - about 100 days length. It's a lot of fun, especially in the beginning as you keep unlocking new stuff.

After a while, though, it will become tedious and even frustrating, as you feel the need to micromanage every single dweller to min/max and expand your vault, all while keeping out all the threats and exploring the outside.

There is no endgame. After a certain point, you just keep expanding, exploring and dealing with threats in an endless, meaningless cycle, grinding away for better gear and weapons, all to explore for longer and kill monsters faster, which gets you nowhere fast.

Another negative point is the fact that it's an Android port to PC, of a game that depends on time passing to replenish your gauges and completing tasks. When I played it on Android, I could take out my phone/ tablet a couple of times during the day and play for 10-20 minutes, which I feel is the way the game is meant to be played. When I sit at the PC to play, I expect to be engaged for (possibly) hours at a time, which this game will not provide, especially at the beginning.


All in all, you can expect a few entertaining days/ hours of play, better experienced on Android, but with a rapidly declining amount of fun after unlocking most of the game's content. Don't expect an end.

Two things to point out though, one, if you don't mind paying for the lunchbox/microtransactions, NEVER buy them at full price. They are on sale ALL the time, and usually for 50% off. I cannot stress how BS that acheevo is. This would be a negative review if I was petty enough to judge an entire game off of a single optional achievement. This game is beautiful artistically and has great immersion even on PC. For someone familiar with Fallout its great to see an entire game designed in the style of Vault Boy. End positive discussion here.

"Reward in rushing" is the message that is routinely reinforced as you play. "Rushing" a room is a core game mechanic and something of a miniature gamble that you engage in to make progress. You rush to get resources. Rush rush rush. Rushing brings rewards. That is what the game tells you. Rush, reward. Rush, reward. You must rush to get rewards. 

That is what makes Fallout Shelter's Pay-or-Delay scheme so lucrative. The game conditions you to rush then frustrates you with delays. The way to move forward is to pay for Nuka-cola speed-ups. 

Remember, please, that according to fallout lore Vaults were social experiments done on stupid people. For this game remove "Vault Tech" and replace it with "Bethesda". This is a game that plays you. 

I'm a patient player. I haven't spent a cent. I know the game behind the game, so I laugh at the things mentioned above. I also enjoy the sim-city-like challenge of balancing the little economy. I send my guy out on a 24 hour mission and come back later. 

But this game does indeed treat you like a rat in a Skinner box. Its missions could be played by a foraging rat, no joke. I downvote this exceptional game because the over-aggressive and psychologically exploitive system is not something I will encourage. 

Yes, I will continue to play the game. I find the real challenge is beating the game company itself in the pay-to-play game.

I usually tend not to enjoy F2P games. Either the content is lacking or the microtransactions cripple it. Surprisingly, this game has a large amount of content and you can play without putting a single dollar on it.

It's a colorful and light game which won't let you go. It's very addictive. There's always something to do - something to click on, something to manage. You get potential access to everything the game offers, so there are no unlockables that require you to spend real money on it. If you are patient, all the rare items  ( Mr. Handy, pets, etc. ) will eventually start coming. Investing money only lets you get those things faster... But I'd recommend not to spend too much money on it, otherwise the fun you'll have collecting stuff will fade away much quicker. Then again, I think this game deserves a few bucks just for how it was designed.

Although we have bright visuals, the game retains the Fallout atmosphere. You'll hear sounds you're used to and encounter creatures or characters you know.

Managing your shelter isn't that hard but it still requires some thoughts. You can almost run out of stuff at first because you have to learn how things work, but as soon as you have enough electricity, food and water-producing rooms, you'll get the hang of it. Doesn't take much time.

The addictive part comes when your shelter begins to get bigger and you have more inhabitants to take care of. You assign jobs, breed them together, level them up and (later) can modify their appearance. At some point, you'll be able to venture in the wastelands much like you do in the regular Fallout series and they'll collect rare items, caps and encounter mini quests. A few hours of gameplay later you'll unlock real missions which involve travelling long distances which lead you to buildings where you usually fight enemies and collect items as well.

There are a handful of events which happen in your shelter, but I wish there would've been a little more. At some point, it's just the missions that are truly fun and interesting. Lots of stuff becomes routine and you realize the game has its limits when it comes down to replay value.

If there's one thing truly missing from the game, it's multiplayer. Man, this game would've been a blast with multiplayer. Invading or defending other shelters, trading items or characters, going on missions together, all this and more could've been done. What a wasted opportunity. I would've gladly paid for this.

I wouldn't normally give games like this much credibility. The gameplay is the sort of low skill, repetitive type that is easier to stomach by pumping money into the game. 

What makes Fallout Shelter different is that the gameplay also provides a basic foundation for some really fun mechanics, if you apply a bit of immagination. 

My shelter became a eugenics nightmare after I discovered a case of incest. I turfed all but the best dweller into the wasteland started anew. I tracked lineages, planned for diversity, and ended up with a golden generation of sibling dwellers whose heritage was equally shared from 8 families. The outliers and mistakes during this process became slaves to roam the wasteland, returning with goods for the sheltered, pure class.

Even then enemies and raiders will eventually kill your dwellers and destroy your robots so don't leave it too long! For a free to play game it is a lot of fun. It's somewhat addicting but it gets really repetitive after a while. If you are looking for something to fill time up occasionally this may before you. If you want to do something in longer bits I wouldn't recommend. My biggest compaint is that the percentage of failure on rush tasks are way off. If you have a 20% rate of failure then in my mind you should have a 2 in 10 chance of failure. In reality the rates are much higher. I read similar complaints online from other people. This becomes incredibly frustrating. Somewhat said that the luck and other traits factor in, but if they are going to run an algorithm to tell me a failure rate, I think they should factor in the dweller stats if their hypothesis was correct. The enemies get really repetitive also of which there are 6 main enemies. It is easy enough to get the premium paid content for free so that is a plus. The pets are cute. I wish that some outfits weren't gender specific. I'd like to have a female ninja or night or a male movie goer for example.  If I was going to give this a rating I'd give it a 3 out of 5 stars and the only reason I said 'no' for recommending is a friend was asking me about it and I couldn't recommend because I could see a much higher chance of being disappointed. I feel like after playing a while there is no satisfaction from leveling up your dwellers. It is the same content but harder. After a while I'm not sure what I'm working toward anymore so it's like level 1 but less exciting. I was really on the fence though for the review whether to recommend or not otherwise. It is free so it really doesn't hurt to download it and try if you don't mind a somewhat repetitive click orientated game that is good for filling in time between stuff.

Fallout Shelter is just another experiment made by Bethesda where more genres are tested on Fallout franchise. Instead of FPS open world sacavange hunt (Fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas and later Fallout 4), Bethesda tested mobile device platform and made a scavange hunt simulation. The game is very simple and limited: basically you're doing vault managment, signing tasks to dwellers, sending dwellers on missions, building rooms, etc. Controls are somewhat clumsy, it's bit awkward to pick and move dwellers. Combat is very simple, visuals look nice, there is large variety of weapons and armor, but those are the only good points.
The game suffers from constant critical situations, there are fires in the vault and creatures (such as raiders, ghouls, radscorpions, deathclaws...) attack all the time and there isn't much time to build rooms, send dwellers on missions or assign them to a room. I remember having at least four waves of attack before I got a chance to send my dwellers to explore the wasteland. The game becomes nothing but a nuisance that you start looking around where will radscorpions crawl out next or where fire will start. 
The concept of vault managment sounds interesting, but project execution is poorly made. Players get only a feeling that they just click at stuff and don't get any feeling they accomplished something because the moment they finish something, a fire starts or deathclaws attack, which just keeps them busy. The game would look interesting if there were more difficult missions (with more slots for dwellers) such as attack on a supermutant camp, to get more Fallout experience, not doing silly missions which barely have any relation to the franchise at all. 
In the end, the game was made for smartphones, so it's basically just a way to kill boredom. it's allright to play the game from time to time, but playing more often will start to become annoying since the game doesn't have anything to offer but constant fires and deathclaws attacks.

Which seems really fun at first and feels different then the generic mobile game tropes, like waiting on a timer to do this and that and have to log on every couple hours to play, but then quickly falls back in line with generic mobile games. 

Missions begin to take longer at higher level, creatures that you‚Äôve killed in the past are now stronger seemingly based on MobStength x DwellerCount. This takes the game into an endless grind of artificial difficulty that you will fall out of love with as fast as you fell in.

The user interface problems begin to really take a toll on your psyche after awhile. They use box colliders instead of polygon collider on irregular shaped objects such as dwellers. If that were all then no problem but none of these colliders are aligned correctly either. The game becomes increasingly frustrating with every faulty click.

Could have been a great game if the interface wasn‚Äôt broken and they didn‚Äôt get so lazy with progression. What were left with is a room filled with garbage. You won‚Äôt notice it at first and look past its flaws but as time goes on the facade will fade and you will realize the pile of trash you are sifting through.

TL;DR - Fallout Shelter is fun for what it is - a quick diversion while you drop the kids off at the pool, or when things are slow at work, etc. 

I played the game on my phone for a couple weeks and maxed out my dwellers and rooms, and so forth. 

Opinions and things of note from my playthrough:

It's a pseudo-strategy upgrade'em up, vault-building farmville-like game that is also reminiscent of Sim Tower. 

The comic art-style is well executed with cutesy and fun animations and effects which the dwellers exhibit while carrying out their lives.

Bonerkill Alert: Grabbing and dragging dwellers is awkward and inaccurate, even on PC, especially when zoomed out -> grabbing them accurately requires zooming in, but moving them to where they need to go often requires zooming out again.

DOUBLE BONERKILL ALERT: The emphasis on microtransactions in Fallout Shelter are disappointing, although not unexpected considering the original platform and target audience.

Entitled gamer conclusion: It's unfortunate that Bethesda used their time and effort, and this great IP to make a weak mark on it's legacy. I think I speak for many fans when I say we would have been happier to pay outright for a more serious entry for mobile platforms, perhaps something along the lines of Fallout/II/Tactics.

Honestly I think people are too hard on this game. It's just a fun little distraction, for FREE. I enjoy playing it and checking on my dwellers everyday, going on quests, maintaining the rooms of MY vault. It was my introduction to the FALLOUT series. It atracted me with it's cutesie graphics and appeal, so I gave it a chance, and now I'm a huge Fallout fan

174 Hours Played
200 Vault Dwellers (1 of them cycling due to max 10 waiting dwellers problem)
186 full S.P.E.C.I.A.L vault dwellers
88 max level vault dwellers
100% acheivements completed

Some things I have learned:
Sending your dwellers on quests give you room themes and schematics.
Wasteland scavenging will yield lots of crafting mats and level up your dwellers very quickly.
Chemistry Flasks are the most important commodity for crafting the best weapons and outfits in the game.
Best weapons are Dragon Maw (ranged targeted), MIRV (ranged splash) and Fire Hydrant Bat (melee).
Nukacola Bottlers obviate the need for Agility outfits since the Diner's food production is redundant.
Wasteland scavenging will keep your vault happiness from being able to hit 100%.

I hope this game gets a sequel and more love is paid attention to the PC version. There was a Chinese fork of the game called Fallout Shelter Online which had many of the features that come to mind for a PC game release.

It's an addictive little game. For SOME reason. Don't actually know what that reason is since there's not much point to it.

I mean you essencially use a breeding pair of dwellers to churn out babies. You slowly upgrade each room and unlock new ones and progressively make the vault bigger.

Right up till the point where you have unlocked everything. Maxed out every room. Maxed out the stats on every dweller.

Then what? You can send a number of people out to do missions. Which when the dwellers are maxed becomes too easy.

You do missions to get bits of loot that servers no purpose to a maxed out vault. To find caps, which have no purpose to a maxed out vault. To find people who can't fit into a maxed out vault.

You can explore which again serves no purpose.

Wait for a couple of raiders to come by and give you something to do. Deliberately set up a radio station to lure in a Deathclaw again just to give you something to do.

I don't know. Just seems to be a boat without a rudder, in a glass smooth, man made lake. Not doing anything but slowly being blown around the surface by the breeze.

Where is it going? Nowhere. What will it do when you get there? Nothing.

What happened to the Fallout Vault lore? The human experimentation. The virtual reality worlds? The messed up social manipulation.

It would have been nice there was a proceedurally generated "THEME" to the vault. Where you as the overseer have to make sure that the task is followed through and you have to balance the psychological and physical balance of the dwellers.

Vault Tech wants to see what happens when dwellers are forced live in complete darkness. You have to build tech and equipment to monitor and keep your fragile dwellers sane.

THAT at least would have been interesting. Offer a CHALLENGE. I guess that is beyond the tallents of Bethesda these days.

Mildly amusing, thouroughly disappointing.  

I know you get what you pay for, and I was cautious about trying this free game.  Bethesda has brought some good things, and my son and I enjoyed the Fallout franchise, and thought this worth an experiment.  The concept of managing the shelter is appealing, and some of the mechanics, bells and whistles are entertaining. 

Unfortunately, the game play is poor.  For example, one of the basic functions is moving dwellers to different locations.  Doing so should be easy with a drag and drop of the mouse.  Not so!  About half of the drops are ineffective, or the dweller runs off to a random location.  Even when your mouse is centered in the target room and the gold corners light up to confirm you're hovering your mouse over the right area, flip a coin and maybe your dweller will go there.   F.S. dwellers excel in blind stupidity either walking past foes or hyper-focusing on the number of workers allowed per area while ignoring the blaring red alert that they're under attack. 

After nominal progress lead to modest satsifaction, the game fell South fast.  Conflict with raiding criters could be an entertaining challenge.   The result:  eventually I quit after wating 12 hours I'm not getting back since the revenue generated by the survivors was not enough to revive the fallen.

Later i discovered that i placed quantity over quality, so a few months later after the game came out on PC, i've started to play again. Real fun game of strategy. For people who like games that involves a bit of thinking, this game is for you. Fallout Shelter is a great free mobile game that got ported to PC. Fun is aplenty here as you populate your Vault with the most capable souls that can brave the dangers of the Wasteland while making sure they're fed and happy.

It certainly doesn't take itself seriously, and you shouldn't either. It's just meant to be seen as a fun diversion with no real bearing on the lore. It'll help if you've played the Bethesda games, Fallout 3 and 4, as Shelter has tons of references to those two games, with some quests being pretty much a trivia contest on these two games. No major references to New Vegas unfortunately, but I am not surprised.

It's the same game as it was back on Mobile so if you've had your fill already, it's probably not worth coming back, but they do keep it updated with seasonal events and it doesn't look like it'll go anywhere soon. If you've never tried it.. what are you waiting for? Sure there's microtransactions, but you don't need to spend a single penny to enjoy this one.

It's a fun and simple game, but after a short while caps become useless and junk becomes just that... Junk. There needs to be MORE... 
More room customization, not just barracks and diners (Which are only allowed one theme each per vault, no matter how many themes or rooms you have.) 
More room tiles for building which you enter though quests and at rondom while exploring the wasteland. These become quite tiresom as they recycle the same tiles over and over, It feels repetitive seeing the same rooms all the time. And some places just look wrong. There was a quest where I went to a supermart place and the rooms were office rooms, wtf? And annother was a bottling plant wich also had office rooms. 

More things to spend your caps on, Like turrets, traps or other extra defenses, Decorations for rooms, Maybe even Mr. Handy upgrades and costumes. 

More places to explore in the wasteland, Not just the same tired locations. Add in some caves, mines, forests, farms, lakes, marshes, etc... I mean where are all these Rad Roaches, Molerats, Rad Scorpions, and Deathclaws comming from? Do they all live in the same abandoned buildings the Raiders and Ghouls live in?

More enemies. Where are all the Bloatflys, Brahmin, Rad Stags, Super Mutants, etc.. that are in the fallout universe? Why aren't they in this game??

How about the ability to visit your friend's Vault?? Or even other NPC owned friendly places.

How about Trading, buying and selling between said friendly locations??

The game offers Lunch boxes, pets, Mr. Handys, Nuka-colas and caps which can be purchased with real money, But what for?? You can get all of those very easily by exploring and questing.

It feels like the gae has potential to be great, but as it is now, it feels kind of hollow.
