Simple, fun, relaxing little game that you can play without an Internet connection. Its biggest flaw is that it attempts to squeeze money out of players by making things like traveling to missions and crafting gear take ridiculously long times, in many cases real life days. Change the time on your computer to avoid having to wait days just to craft a gun or travel to quests. Its second biggest flaw is that the game saves progress insecurely locally making it very easy to cheat and edit saved games. The combination of very long wait times and insecure saves is a recipe for cheating the game, even just to make it more enjoyable. Don't believe anyone's excessive progress is real; they either spent money, changed the time on their computer repeatedly, or edited their save games. After a while the game does get fairly repetitive with a lack of surprises and no multiplayer competition to keep it interesting. However, even after playing to the point of boredom, it's still fun to load up and attempt to further optimize vault performance from time to time. The fact that it is free is a big pro towards earning a thumbs up.

[h1]Free Shelter[/h1]

Fallout Shelter is an interesting time sink. I've never played a clicker, but the word comes to mind as I manage what amounts to a game of clicking, waiting, and some planning. There is a fair amount of strategy involved in playing this game, not only as  the Overseer, but in combat, but don't go looking for a lot of depth.

For a free piece of promotional fun, Fallout Shelter really satisfies. As the unseen but all powerful Overseer, you are tasked with managing your inhabitants, or 'Dwellers', building your Vault, and issuing commands during combat. The concept starts out simply, and progresses rather well as your population grows and your vault becomes just a little deeper and more complex.

The rooms all provide something, most of it useful for developing your Dwellers or your Vault itself. There isn't much to do but place your dweller in said room and occasionally click a resource, a level up icon, and such. During a [b]'Disaster'[/b] all kinds of things can happen, and Disasters can come randomly or if you ‚ÄúRush‚Äù a room for its given resource. In most cases these are manageable, but there is one type of disaster that is woefully imbalanced. More on that in a moment.

The game is not without issues. Controls can be pretty wonky, particularly with clicking. I didn‚Äôt remember having too much trouble when my vault was new, but with more rooms and Dwellers it seemed as though clicking on one of the Dwellers would instead click the room. Dragging a Dweller to a room to perform a task also has a lot of inconsistent results. A green silhouette indicates that a Dweller has been selected and when I drag them over a room they will often go to the next room above or below. The same goes with locating the Mysterious Stranger; a random encounter in the vault that if you locate will rearward you with free caps (the game's currency). I would find the stranger, and when I try clicking him, despite where my cursor is located, I will instead get the room and zoom in, but not get him. This can become very aggravating.

One of my other big complaints revolves around the aforementioned disasters, specifically, radscorpions. During a disaster, such as a fire, it will grow, maybe spread to adjacent rooms, and generally just be a minor but solvable problem. These disasters get harder as your population gets bigger. By 50 Dwellers you begin to get radscorpions. They are extremely powerful, and not only do they do great harm to Dwellers, they are tough to kill, drain power (one of the most precious resources in the game), poison your Dwellers with radiation making them harder to heal, and they move around to random rooms. They are incredibly destructive and tough to kill. I had to evict a lot of Dwellers to lower the population to 49 just to keep the menacing attacks away. There are training rooms, better weapons, and other ways to mitigate this problem, but that will take weeks of time sinks and grinding to get to that point. The game's developers could have balanced this much more fairly. As it stands it is a harsh and largely unpleasant difficulty spike.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*][b]S[/b]olid game play
    [*][b]P[/b]lenty to see and do
    [*][b]E[/b]ach Vault and experience unique
    [*][b]C[/b]ombat offers some strategy
    [*][b]I[/b]n-game real market purely optional
    [*][b]A[/b]dvances without constant maintenance
    [*][b]L[/b]ooks and sounds great
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*][b]G[/b]rinding and time consuming
    [*][b]E[/b]ncounters and Disaster spikes too harsh
    [*][b]C[/b]ontrol issues
    [*][b]K[/b]iller Radscorpions need a nerf
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 8/10[/b]

The first thing you need to understand about Fallout Shelter is that it's a mobile game through and through. Even the Steam version has ended up as less of a port and more of an emulation of the original iOS game. All of the needless clicking, microtransations, and timers that are ubiquitous in the mobile market - and so out of place on the PC - are still alive and well here.

The concept of the game itself is simple enough: build a Vault that produces enough food, water, and energy for its dwellers to survive and also protect them from random dangers. The means of producing those necessities and the dangers interrupting that pursuit have a few subtle variations, but exploring the wasteland and embarking on quests are the only things that actually break up the monotony. The dialogue during those quests and the journal entries a dweller makes while out in the wasteland are both surprisingly and darkly hilarious. Combining this clever writing with the excitement of collecting new items, the time spent outside of the Vault invigorates time spent inside it. However, that feeling can only last so long before the staleness of the majority of the experience overwhelms it. The same can be said about customizing dwellers or upgrading their equipment. More options, many of which are obviously worse than others, cannot make up for the fact that there's nothing more to do with them.

Fallout Shelter was made as a promotional tool and the attempt to grow past its beginnings by adding more content has not changed that fact. Modular pieces shoddily rearranged over and over again, sadly, do not make for exciting experiences. And yet, I've spent well over a hundred hours in this game, not counting the time I spent playing it on iOS. Something about Fallout Shelter certainly seems to appeal to me. I just wish I could figure out what it is.

TLDR:  If you want to binge play this game as soon as you install it, you'll need to spend some $$$ (lunchboxes are best IMHO).  If you can only play for a few minutes in the morning and at night, you can still be happy and spend no money.  To understand more, read the long review below.

My wife and I were traveling to Cancun for vacation but the weatherman said it might rain the entire time, so I purchased a Samsung Galaxy Tab A and installed a few games on it.  Fallout Shelter being one of them (via Google Play).
Before we got on the plane, I made a Vault for myself and purchased some lunchboxes, thinking that my wife and I would share them.  As it turned out, the purchases were PER VAULT.  So, I got a bunch of lunchboxes and my wife had none.  She wasn't too concerned because she isn't that big of a gamer and did not think she would like this game.

I eventually opened all of my lunchboxes (waited 5 minutes between them to spread out the happiness) and although most of them were useless resources that I did not need, I got 2 "Preston Garvey's" a "Three Dog" a lot of caps and some other high stat settlers.  Now, you might ask if I thought it was worth the real $$$ I spent.
The high stat settlers and the extra caps allowed me to build a large base quickly and send out multiple wasteland expeditions which allowed me to do a lot of quests soon after purchasing the game.

My wife on the other hand, decided to play without lunch boxes and so she spent a lot of time unable to do anything except watch me play.  Life in the vault moves sloooowly unless you have a lot of vault dwellers.

The weather in Cancun turned out to be pretty good, so we took turns playing while on the plane, in the mornings before heading to the beach and at night after dinner.  We checked our vaults a few times during the days that had an afternoon rain shower.

By the end of the real-time week, I had a massive base, had done a lot of quests and was cranking out high level weapons and gear.  My wife managed to keep up with me as she found 2 Mr Handy robots in lunchboxes and they gave her the edge she needed to keep up with me.  Plus, she was better at finding the Mysterious Stranger and that earned her a lot of extra caps.  Keep in mind that she spent NO real-life money on the game.  It just took her longer to get to the same point in the game where I was.

When we returned home, I decided to install it using Steam and found out that my vaults were non-transferrable.  So, the $$$ I spent on the Google Play account meant nothing to the Steam version.  Just pointing this out for those who are curious.
I have been playing the Steam version for a few days now and it is dreadfully slow without spending money on it.  My wife is still playing the tablet version and is having more fun than I am since she has a fully developed vault.

Once the vault is fully developed, there does not appear to be an end-game.  You just keep sending your dwellers on quests until you get bored of it.

That said, we had more fun playing Fallout Shelter on the tablet than any of the other tablet games I purchased on Google Play.  It was fun to take turns with the wife and watch as she played a game that she did not anticipate enjoying.  

I can imagine this being a good purchase for parents looking to keep their kids occupied if you have a large screen tablet (due to the graphic details, I suspect this would be horrible to play on a phone unless zoomed in all the way).  Just make sure the kids can't purchase stuff using real $$$, because the game makes it VERY easy to spend a lot of cash if you want to.

Moving settlers on the tablet was easier with a little rubber-nibbed pointing device and somewhat difficult with my large fingers.  Moving setters with a mouse on the Steam version is as easy as you would expect.

There you have it.  I recommend it as long as you understand what you are getting yourself into.  If you are expecting to install it and play for hours and hours right away... break out your credit card.  If you are looking for something to waste a few minutes a few times a day, this is perfect.  Once you get further into the game, you can decide if you want to spend more time doing quests.

Here are a couple of pieces of advice:  
1) Breeding new settlers is ultimately better than using the radio.  Breed high stat males with high stat females.  Genetics matters.  Also, brothers and sisters will not mate, so keep that in mind when choosing names, to make it easier to keep track of who is related to who.

2) As soon as you get the Endurance Training room, train your people up.  High endurance means more health and longer survivability.  Although, the bonus is NOT retroactive.  Training a level 1 to max Endurance is more beneficial than training a level 20 to max Endurance.

3) Save Nuka-Colas for quests with expiration times.  Some quests must be finished in a short amount of time and colas will get your people there and back.

4) Dying only costs caps.  Do not be afraid to take chances since you can revive anyone and replay any mission that you fail.... as long as you have enough caps.

5) Put your first large power plant on the top floor opposite of the vault door.  That way you have 6 dwellers with high Strength ready to meet the raiders who bust through your vault door.

6) Have Fun!

Fallout Shelter is a cool little MMO/Simulation game in the Fallout universe. Unlike the main games, there is no single protagonist since you are the Overseer in a vault. When this game first released on the phone back in the day, it was awesome for the first few hours, but once everything was maxed out there was not much left to do. Now, with the new updates, it is like a little MMO too with main quest lines, dailies, weeklies, more armor and weapons to make, theme workshops, and you can even customize your dwellers. The development team did a great job revamping this game and making it a more robust and added a slew of content. I highly recommend if you just want to dabble in a fun little game on PC here and there.

I never thought I would say this but Fallout Shelter is the most enjoyable mobile games I‚Äôve played.

To make it clear ‚Äì I don‚Äôt play any mobile games. I have no interest in them and I probably won‚Äôt ever gain any interest in them either.
Fallout shelter grabs me differently however ‚Äì the game is very simple but keeps me entertained with all the collectables, minor story elements and scripted quests.

[h1]There are various elements to the Fallout Shelter;[/h1]
[b]Caps:[/b] an in-game currency that can‚Äôt be bought with money, only obtained in game.

[b]Nuka Cola Quantum:[/b] used to rush actions instantly like travelling to a quest destination or training a dweller. This can be earned both in game from quests and lunchboxes or through objectives. If you are desperate you can buy them with real world money

[b]Lunchboxes:[/b] basically - loot crates, get weapons, pets, quantum, caps, dwellers and more. These can rarely be earned via objectives and quests but also bought from the store with real world money.

In addition to all this, rooms build instantly, there are multiple upgrades of rooms that may require caps (currency) along with a specific population count (as a means of progression I assume), there are 3 objectives that range from mundane ‚Äúcollect x‚Äù all the way to more specific ‚Äúhave x bald dwellers‚Äù. These objectives either pay out in caps, quantum, lunchboxes or pets. When you complete an objective, you get a reward and a new objective. You can skip 1 objective per day.

At the end of each real-time week you get a free lunchbox based on your performance.

I see a lot of comments like ‚Äúit‚Äôs pay to win‚Äù and ‚Äúit‚Äôs unsustainable‚Äù ‚Äì to which I reply they must be playing a different game to me, because I‚Äôve never had these problems. Even when I come back to my save file after a good 2-3 days my vault is running fine. I‚Äôm not low on supplies and I have plenty of progress to catch up on.

I have also not spent anything on this game whatsoever. Yet I‚Äôm still enjoying it to its fullest because I am collecting an in-game currency to speed up actions via quests or objectives ‚Äì meaning that I don‚Äôt ever feel the need to buy from the store to enhance my game.

I‚Äôm not playing it with 100% efficiency either. My vault is a real mash of rooms that don‚Äôt work well on the same floor but I‚Äôm still surviving just fine.

[h1]I do have a few issues with Fallout Shelter however;[/h1]

1)	Clicking and assigning dwellers can be a pain as they move about a lot.
2)	There is a steep difficulty curve that straightens out very quickly ‚Äì the game throws a lot at you quickly and then doesn‚Äôt have anything else to ramp up the difficulty with.
3)	There are a lot of rooms that do the same or similar things
4)	Dwellers can be quite small and as such I would recommend either a keyboard and mouse or playing on a tablet.

Overall Fallout Shelter is free and is worth your time if you just want short breaks in your day. It can be very addictive.

[h1]Sims, sims never change...[/h1]

The title pretty much tells you what you can expect in this little apocalyptic-themed little computer people game. As someone who was always curious to get into the Fallout games, this is a nice free alternative to learn about the game universe if you can't purchase the original games or the latest games. But enough of that talk, let's get to the real meat of the game.

You run a vault in the wasteland. Your job is to keep the dwellers happy, productive, and most importantly, alive as you build up your vault so it can hold more people from the wasteland. I have the PC version, so I can't comment much on what happens with the Android version (since I have an Android phone). 

[b]PROS[/b][list]
[*]Considering the grime and bleakness of the Fallout series, this game has a surprisingly cheery look to it. Everything takes from the promo material of Vault Tech and their Vault Boy mascot. The big plus here is that the graphics are clean and easy to read.
[*]The audio mix is pretty "laid back" most of the time. The music doesn't try to overwhelm the player, and most of the background noise isn't annoying. Of course, this means whenever there's an attack or failure in one of the rooms, things are really on edge.
[*]Easy to understand gameplay. This is partly because being a mobile game, it gets a very easy to understand interface and everything tells you what you need to truly get the most out of resources and rooms. Just match up the best SPECIAL stats for a given room, use items that boost specific stats, and make the most of your dwellers.
[/list]

[b]CONS[/b][list]
[*]Idling, lots and lots of idling. This shouldn't be surprising for a mobile game (in which the goal is to get money of out people, no offense), but in some cases it feels like there's a bit too much waiting for things that shouldn't require a wait. This is true for quests, in which given the risk/rewards, shouldn't take that long to "get to it" and "get back from it".
[*]Early-game hell. In most sim games, the early game is supposed to be a sort of "honeymoon" period so that the player can get comfortable with what can be done and with what can go wrong. The game however, paired with the idling, can feel very tedious to start off because you simply won't have enough dwellers to get things done. Expect lots of failures when trying to rush facilities, and you might lose a few souls in the early game too...
[*]Clumsy building. For me personally, I feel that placing rooms can be a bit irksome. If you accidentally place the wrong room in the wrong place, you simply can't move it, you have to demolish it for a low refund, and then rebuild it again.
[/list]

[b]MEH[/b][list]
[*]Microtransactions. Again, this is a mobile game, and it's to be expected that good ol' Bethany Esda wants to milk you for money (as if recent trends prior of this post weren't a big sign). However, outside of waiting on a quest or a return from the wasteland, I find that you can just as easily muscle through the game without paying a penny... Besides, some achievements reward Mr. Handy and other rare/useful items.
[*]Repetitive. Well Fallout Boy, this is a sim game, so it's going to feel a bit same-old-same-old after a while due to the nature of what it is. There really isn't a goal except to build your very own Vault Tech vault and perhaps be one of those jerks who uses for an experiment like in the actual games... Or you could try having a vault of nothing but women in lab coats armed with sniper rifles... Really, that's how these games work.

[b]OVERALL[/b]
It's a fun little time waster and for some, a free/cheap easy way into getting to know the Fallout universe.

This game isn't great, but it's ok.

If you're fine with playing it for a bit every now and then, it can be good fun: log in, set up your expeditions, expand your base, log out. Log in a few hours later, check how your guys are faring, play your quests, manage your inventory, log out again. Rinse and repeat the next day if you feel like it.

The payment system isn't too intrusive, and f2p is definitely doable. This game might not be liberal with the meaningful rewards, but it's not too stingy either - although you find way too much useless crap in lunchboxes (the game's loot crates), so I can understand why people who paid for them are not too happy with the results.

Also, it's free, so it doesn't hurt to give it a try.

P.S.: If this concept had been developed as a proper strategy game, it might have been really great. Fallout would be a great setting for a fully fleshed out strategical base-building game.

Simple, fun, relaxing little game that you can play without an Internet connection. Its biggest flaw is that it attempts to squeeze money out of players by making things like traveling to missions and crafting gear take ridiculously long times, in many cases real life days. Change the time on your computer to avoid having to wait days just to craft a gun or travel to quests. Its second biggest flaw is that the game saves progress insecurely locally making it very easy to cheat and edit saved games. The combination of very long wait times and insecure saves is a recipe for cheating the game, even just to make it more enjoyable. Don't believe anyone's excessive progress is real; they either spent money, changed the time on their computer repeatedly, or edited their save games. After a while the game does get fairly repetitive with a lack of surprises and no multiplayer competition to keep it interesting. However, even after playing to the point of boredom, it's still fun to load up and attempt to further optimize vault performance from time to time. The fact that it is free is a big pro towards earning a thumbs up.

Theres nothing new to experience and given this is by Bethesda I'm skeptical that this'll get any of the care I think it deserves. It could be amazing because like I said it's a nice game with an appealing artstyle (cept the dreads those dreads look awful on everyone) and some legitimately funny dialogue, but the redundancy isn't even fulfilling because even the rewards are redundant. Don't even get me started on the bugs, when I first started playing the issues with click and dragging people made me think it was my mouse's fault for a minute and from what I understand these are longstanding issues, so it'll be a pleasant surprise if they're ever fixed.

Fallout Shelter is a dungeon master type simulation game set in the Fallout universe. It nails the visuals, theme, lore and feel of the Fallout games, fits into the universe. You play as the overseer of an underground fallout shelter managing the dwellers and trying to keep them alive.
The game opens up once you build the Overseer's office, because it lets you send dwellers on missions and fight enemies, explore and loot locations, that gives a needed variety to the game.
I have played it on my Android tablet and that actually fits the gameplay well. Still, controlling would have been better on a PC with a mouse. Very often happened that I only wanted to scroll the view, but I accidentally moved a dweller to another room. Annoying.
The game was designed for mobile devices, it is not for continuous playing, because it has crafting, training and traveling times that can be pretty long on higher levels. I had fun with it for a couple of weeks as a secondary game I would play when I had 10-15 minutes to do a mission or two.
The game is free-to-play with micro transactions, but it is well done, does not actually force you to buy anything. Of course the usual money grabbing tactics apply, like special pets, money and resource packs, speeding up training, crafting and traveling times by a special item, and so on. But everything can be looted in missions or crafted as well, 
so you are not forced to buy it, I played without paying any real money.
The basic tutorial is OK, but some game mechanics are not explained at all.
If a dweller dies and is resurrected, he forgets his assignment, and needs to be assigned to his post again, 
otherwise he will just aimlessly wonder around the Vault.
Crafting is nice and simple for normal and rare weapons and armor, but crafting legendary items takes a disproportionately long time (making a power armor with trained dwellers took 8 actual days!)
Combat is a bit too simplistic, you basically send your team of dwellers to a room and watch as they kill the enemies 
while pumping your injured team members with health packs. More interesting combat would have been better, this makes the game feel repetitive after a while.
I experienced crashes and long loading times on my tablet, but it is not very powerful, so it could be just my hardware. On my PC there were no such issues.
The attributes of the dwellers are trained in specialized training rooms and not at all during normal work or missions. That is a weird design choice. This way it is possible to train super-humans that excel in everything, from fighting to water purification, but have never actually left the Vault or worked a minute.
Despite its faults, I had fun with it. If you like the Fallout setting, give it a try as a second-screen game!

Basically the entire game can be summed up in 8 Simple steps:

Step 1) Send Vault Dwellers on quests  
Step 2) Wait 2 - 12+ Hours  
Step 3) Complete 5 minute quests that are all pretty much identical    
Step 4) Return to vault  
Step 5) Wait 2 - 12+ Hours  
Step 6) Collect resources and Loot from quest 
Step 7) Build/upgrade rooms, upgrade dweller skills, Scrap the trash in your inventory
Step 8) Repeat step 1 - 8

If that sounds appealing and rewarding enough to suck you in then by all means it's a good game but that said it also makes me sad at how this sort of genre and gameplay could have had so much potential if they really put a little more effort into it. Hell add some more enemies/NCP's (Where are the Super Mutants at Bethesda!?) Add interesting quests with speech options and stories that actually equate to something and can we please have more locations than the Red Rocket, The Super Duper Mart and a randomly numbered Vault identical to all the others.

That said I still really like this game for some reason but this could have really been something S.P.E.C.I.A.L (See what I did there) and I guess I'm just a little disappointed with what it turned out to be. At this point I'm 46 Hours in but you have to bare in mind that for a long time I've only been opening this game once a day to try and finish getting all the achievements and if they weren't there or once I've finished them I wouldn't/won't have any other incentive to open the game again.
If you like the fallout games you will like this game.

I wanted to see the "end-game", which is probably do all the quests and identify every weapons and armor/clothing. I did play this game at good length on mobile version, but I stopped when I got a new phone and... yeah ...

So anyway, it was good distraction. I did spend about $25 or so into it because I did feel it earn my money. Now do I regret it? I suppose you can say yes. Why? Well, be warned. Should your PC EVER to crash mid game, be prepared to say good-bye to your 50+ fully stats dwellers. I did not how how "significant" it causes, especially when people like me, did not know the importance of backing up data. I was sure Steam-Cloud is reliable, but not for this game it seems ... That $25 bucks went down the drain and can't never be used again, even for new vaults. (No really, I don't really care or its a big deal, but you know?)

This happened almost a month ago and I decided no more playing this product (or any ANY mobile-related games, even on my phone to play with). If my PC didn't crash back then, would I still play? For sure, yes when you did NOT know about PC crashing bugs your save game. :) FYI, my PC crash was un-related to the game, but it WAS running at the time.

Not bad for a free game. As someone who played this via both Android and PC, the game is extremely buggy when played on PC compared to Android. Issues included audio chopping in and out, sub-par game mechanics, and a major bug that corrupts the save file when the game is closed improperly (e.g. Power outage, laptop battery dies).

I invested about 20 hours into my first vault and both my save and backup save were corrupted. Upon opening the save files, all the coding for the save had been wiped with no way to retrieve it. So while fun to play in between other games, I would not recommend making any in-game purchases or playing when there is a chance the game may improperly close.

Fallout shelter, I was having fun with it. I have ~85 hours in it. 
I checked back everyday to check on my Vault Dwellers who ran out and collected loot for me. I ran quests to get all the achievements and what not. I was crafting weapons and legendary weapons after getting the thousands and thousands of caps neccessary for making them. And Finally I got tons of dwellers skilled up to have 10s in every SPECIAL stat.

It was fine you know, menial gameplay that I was enjoying.

But I didn't know that if your computer just crashes while you are loading your game, you lose your files. 
They are gone. Corrupted. And unretrievable.

The game uses a sync feature but that doesn't help at all. Say goodbye to your 80 hours you spent in the game over the countless days trying to grind up to high skills and high weapons. Say goodbye to all 200+ vault dwellers, all those Micro-Transaction lunchboxes, and everything you've worked for.

A game shouldn't have a game breaking bug like this with NO warning. I would have given this game a 7/10 but after all this, I have to give it a 1/10.

Who in their rightmind never fixes this bug? It's happened on smartphones and PC! It's just ridiculous.

I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series, and this gives me something to do on my pad or phone when on breaks!

Fallout Shelter is a waiting game that you get hooked on for a day or two and then forget about it completely.

You build a vault and send your dwellers to quests. 
You may think quests are good, but they are the same recycled copy and paste quests like in Fallout 4 - You go somewhere, talk to someone or kill something or loot something and thats it. Dont get me started on the level design in quests, there isnt any.

Enemies in this game are simply damage sponges - they take 8 quintillion mini nukes and show no response. And if that wasnt bad enough, almost every room in quests has 2 or 3 bullet sponge cockroaches.
And if THAT wasnt bad enough, once you have some high level stuff going on, you have deathclaws attacking your vault, which take ages to kill and they dont even drop anything. And they are so common, because when you send your dwellers to quests frequently, theres like 1/3 chance of deathclaw attack.

The item collecting is miserable.
There is a wide variety of clothing and weapons, but you only find bb guns, .32 pistols, hunting rifles and sawed off shotguns. The rest you have to craft and find in quests.

The graphics are decent for a mobile game, but the animations aren't all that good. The characters dont even hold guns properly.

To sum it all up, this game is wide as an ocean but deep as a bucket. The game is very empty and unfinished.

Overall it is a good little time killer. Not anything I would leave open and stare at, but I do check it a few times a day. It takes a little while to "balance" food water and electricity. Without clean water you slowly take radiation poisin, without food they slowly take damage, and without power the rooms will begin to shut down. Best advice is to not make a whole lot of babies at once. As far as free little games go this one gets thumbs up =)
Good game to have off on another moniter while your playing different game so you can go back to it and do stuff with it.And is a good game

If you are looking for a free game to play here and there for less than a hour, at a time, then here you go.  You can easily play the entire game without paying for anything, and has enough complexity to give you the feeling to play it again and again.

It's a neat base-management mobile game come to Steam. Not much else to it.

First and foremost, if you're planning on playing this fullscreen, you might want to look elsewhere. This game is incredibly slow-paced. Play it windowed, off to the side, while you watch YouTube videos or the news or wait for a real game to install. It is a MOBILE GAME, and plays as such.

You build your very own Vault, and micromanage the residents within. You construct rooms, send brave souls out into the wasteland to scavenge for materials, fight fires, manage your three main resource pools, fight off raider attacks... For a mobile game, let alone a free mobile game, it's quite something.

It's obviously marketed to Fallout fans, but I don't think there's any reason a newcomer to the franchise would be scared off. 

I really like it. I've actually got about 40 hours in it before Steam picked it up and haven't paid a cent. You can buy speed-up items if you're a small impatient child with unsupervised access to your mom's credit card, but otherwise it's just not worth it.


It's free, and surprisingly comprehensive for a mobile game. Give it a shot.

Definitely one to keep for the ages - especially with all the quests!

If you do not have a powerful computer to play the modern fallout games, this is a useful alternative to get into the universe as the game contains many elements found in Fallout 3 and 4 - it is worth revisiting on the PC as the controls are easier to deal with than with mobile devices - i gave up on my previous record on my iphone to start brand new on the Steam version and man, there have been loads of updates since i last played on my iphone!

A note to those who started playing from the time it was initially introduced - the new functions really make the game a lot harder and the odds of getting rare characters are a lot less than the earlier versions - my iphone record has 3-4 rare characters and so far i have NONE at all in my current STEAM record - so be warned!

Also, one of the fun bits is to do quests for all sorts of things for your vault - i really encourage you to check out the daily, weekly quests and especially those near holiday seasons - halloween 2017 was a real blast as i received the ghost sheet and skeleton attires which i get to keep even after the event!

All in all, it is addictive, yet fun - highly recommend it to anyone who loves to manage things!

Overall this game is fantastic. There's nothing quite like it and it's even better that we can play without ads being slammed in our faces every 10 seconds. It's great to play and can get addicted for hours on end; yet I still can't help but wish for more to be added to the game.

Fallout Shelter was great from the beginning but I love the added features over time such as themes for the dining room and bedrooms, but what if we could customise even further than that? Over time it would be great to be able to continuously upgrade our vault doors. At maximum upgrade I still don't get enough time to move workers to defense. Deathclaws do a huge amount of damage, and as you progress in the game you encounter more wasteland creatures but it gets harder to populate, get enough weapons and outfits for each person to defend themselves. Sure the game getting harder is the point but it unfortunately leaves some vaults at the extent of major damage without recovery.

Honestly, the game is awesome for an app processed game! Being on steam as well gives it extra points because I am so on board having it on my phone AND my computer; I can see my little people so much better on the computer, my eyes get tired after a while on the phone. So thumps up x5 for having a steam version of fallout that's free to play!!! So impressed!

Hope to see more stuff like this, would especially love to see more versions of the shelter game; as long as it remains ad free and free-to-play, I'm on board!

Fallout Shelter (FS) developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released on Jul 31, 2016 for PC platform. According to Metacritic (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/fallout-shelter), it has:
[list]
¬†¬†¬†¬†[*]Metascore of 63
¬†¬†¬†¬†[*]An average user score of 5.5
[/list] 

Is this title a worthy additional to the Fallout series? Not everyone will agree to this. Few I knew threw this into the shredder machine [u]without even trying.[/u] 

[quote] The game concept is different. Visually it does not appeal. I am not interested in mobile/mobile port games. I don't fancy sim games. I prefer FPS! [/quote]

While I may be disappointed to hear these words, I've to respect people's opinions. 

FS is the first mobile game developed by Bethesda Game Studios. Unfortunately for me, my mobile phone was unable to run this game. So when it became available on Steam, I grabbed it immediately & suit up my vault spandex and gears!

What is Fallout Shellter (FS) about?
FS is a rpg + simulation game where you take control of the few survivors in this horrible land and manage them/the vault's survivability activities. You're the vault boss. You decide who gets to wear what/do what/and who gets to have "happy" hour. *ahem* 

Base building is simple and straightforward. The prerequisite to unlock a new building is to reach a certain amount of survivors in your vault.

Apart from the common basic rooms that keeps your vault/people alive (power,food,water) you get to build training rooms, 2 form of medic rooms, a weapon & armor crafting room, a theme customization room and finally a hair saloon@character customization.

You can send your survivors on a variety of quests, most of them are fetching types. You will also get a quiz quests. Pick the right answers and you don't need to kill anyone. Pick the wrong answer.. well, lets just say it's a pew pew pew session.

To aid you in this wasteland, you have a robot that helps to defend the vault and also assist you to pick up resources. You also have pets that comes with some form of bonus (weapon damage/damage resistance/more $ or junk pick up and etc). The rest is micro-management. 


Controls, Visuals & Sounds:
Nothing fancy. It's mainly on mouse. 

Visually, It's 2D, cartoonish looking. I am assuming the main target audience are young kids. Despite the art being children-friendly, there is a GREAT DEAL of [b]DETAILS[/b] on everything. Hats, hair, clothing's, weapons, pets, rooms, enemies, objects, animations. Every visual element has been crafted, colored with great deal of effort. Surprisingly, FS is not dark at all. Its pretty and is colorful. This becomes visibly apparent once you are able to craft armor/clothing/theme room. Imagine a room with 6 survivor don in a White cleric like hats and robes. or room with 6 red swim-wears. xD literally its like a mini vault of cos-players..with guns. 

The enemies that in this mad land: Human raiders, creature/monsters; death claws and rad roach/scorpion, moles and ghouls. Each faction has been carefully designed. Some of them will have abilities - especially mini boss/boss fights. The only saving grace which us players have is: 1) Critical Hits 2)Medic/Rad packs 3) Perseverance and if all fails 4) craft a BIGGER gun.

As for the sound, every animation will have feedback sounds. It's simple and sharp. The audio keeps the mood of the game flowing. Good work to the visual & audio team.


Game Mechanics:
There is the base building, the combat, the exploration, crafting, customization, keeping-the-vault-survivor-happy thingy, leveling system, training-stats system. There's a bunch of mechanics in this product. Everything is working as intended - I've not experienced any crash or bugs. Of the surface, people may think this product was designed for kids but if you actually gave it a try, pretty much after a couple of hours, people will realize that there's actually a lot of things going on & incorporated into this product.

One of the things that will keep many players busy is keeping vault survivors happy & leveling up their stats. 
The vault survivors can die. The only way to bring back a dead vault survivor is to revive them by spending credits. Credits rule, baby! Credits play a major role especially base building. Some of these upgrades are freaking expansive. 

Now comes the premium-in-game currency: nuka cola bottles. These colas don't over-write the credits role instead they compliment them. cola's lessens crafting time, sending and calling survivor backs from quest immediately. It also can be used to speed up crafting and base building. a lot. 

Having a ton of credits is like having a sports car. Having colas on the hand, is like having a nitro.


While FS is a free 2 play game, it does have in-game purchases. This is FS's business model. I am not against them because I know, this is a business after all. What I am rather concerened is the legendary dweller. Just how many boxes do i need to open to get 1 ? 

My personal thoughts:
FS is a great game. So many elements has been incorporated into this product to keep players engage. It is fresh and interesting. 

Now, hold on. After 30+ hours into the game. I am having second thoughts. Things are becoming a routine/grind! To make it a mess, if you have above 150 dwellers, you are going to click A LOT. Scrolling the vault becomes a pain when you have a big vault. Identifying dwellers, dragging them around becomes a mess. The spy-like person that comes and goes becomes irrelevant once you have a big vault. You sacrifice your own vault dweller to the wasteland to maintain sanity in your vault management. Rad Scorpion keeps invading your vault and things turn into a big freaking mess. Death left and right, insufficient resources, productivity is low because the entire vault is unhappy -RIPS HAIR ARGHHHH- 

So here's 2 scenario:
1) the game experience does take a dip once everything becomes a routine. When a catastrophic event hits your vault and you stop coming back/When you find yourself repeating the same action over and over again - and you quit. That's the end of its shelf life.

2) However despite all the misery & setback that you've faced and you keep coming back to FS. You know, you either got a special connection with FS/you are person on a mission! That's the 2 major difference in terms of gaming experience.


My Summary:
Despite it's children-friendly visuals, FS was developed for the mass. Not just for the kids. Yes, it may have been ported over from mobile but there were no bugs for me. Some aspect of the UI could be improved. For me, I would love to see:
[list]
[*]a better control in terms of looking/handling vault dweller across the vault. Clicking and dragging one end to the other end may feel a little frustrating.

[*]The same thing could be said about Weapon, Clothing & Junk inventory management. Why cant I set x amount to be sold instead of clicking?

[*]Imagine this, what happens if you send out 50 dwellers to the waste land. With the current UI its gonna be a big mess. I would like a simple, small list. I don't need & don't want to cycle through 50 times!
[/list]

FS left a very strong impression in the first 30 hours. After that it was just routine to keep everything in check and made sure my dwellers were happy. It became a chore. The quests and vault incidents/attacks break up that chore. Achievement was what kept me going.  

*Click & drag myself into the drums room*  It disappoints me but this has to be done. *drums roll*

So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Fallout Shelter is a minced death claw served in rad sauce, worth 6/10. 

As Exquisite this product may be, with long duration of repeated tasks and a lacking objective/a closure to the vault experience, it feels meaningless. It requires so many clicks to perform an action - when a tweak in the UI would save PC gamer all the hassle.

So much to share but I've hit the word limit. 

*Walks out into the wasteland in my vault spandex* Adios Amigos. Peace.
I hate how Bethesda released this game on iOS but absolutely refuses to put it on the Mac! They're dirty hypocrites!

A Fallout Farmville? I'm in!

No but all jokes aside this is the typical "tablet/phone" game that you will spend each day tending to those things that take time to occur overnight and collect resources and rewards from your dwellers. 

However, Bethesda nailed it. This is no typical "farmville/clash of clans" tap game. This game has virtually no paywall holding you back with having fun. This game DOES have things that you may buy, but ALL of these things that can be purchased, can be found within the base game without paying a penny! Ofcourse this may take longer without paying but is still fun to play

- Cute Graphics & Funny Dialogue 
- True to Fallout (Weapons & Characters you'd find in all fallout games) 
- Free to Play/No Paywall (Everything is accessible without paying) 
- Full questlines to explore & complete
- An Addictive reward system (Mystery crates "lunchboxes") 

In conclusion, this free to play game captured my heart. Not only is it extremly addictive but a joy to just check in on every once and a while. I would definitely reccommend
Very fun

Fallout Shelter is your usual idle mobile game with a bit of simulation and some clicking. Made by Bethesda and Behaviour Entertainment, released first in 2015 on iOS and other mobile, updated significantly since then, arrived to PC in 2016 and to Steam in 2017.

Technically, it does have occasional glitch fixed by restarting game, such as when I couldn't remove elevator. And people say that they had their saves wiped out due to error or crash many hours later. So uncool.

And eh, idle games are idle games. As far as I care, they are soulless. Well, though this game has a bit of soul, in artstyle. It's really neat in-universe-cartoon thing. Quite nice, mhm. None the less, the one who wins at these games is not the player who fully maxes it out after 100 hours. Nope, that one loses. The player who wins is the one who checks it out and goes away once it gets shallow.

None the less, I tried. The normal play. There is your base building and basic recource management. Wait long time to get smthing. Can rush, with percentage that it can go wrong. The only microtransactions are either boxes of random stuff that you can get as loot anyway and ability to arrive to quests immeditly, doesn't matter much. Usually you can leave the game for a while unless you sent dwellers out exploring, then it goes against whole idle thing with them possibly dieing out of injury while you aren't paying attention.

I mean, it's not Pay-2-Win but it's still an idle game which is completely shameful on PC.

It's actually funny how game was different combat systems in shelter and quests. In shelter animation matter zero, everybody's health is just getting slowly sapped by presence of NPCs with their stats and only Endurance stat matters for health. Quest kinda does it more with aiming, attacks, critical hits minigames at rare times. But eh, still shallow.

And yea, it's idle. I played normal vault for a while and stopped very quickly after realizing at how easy it will be. So I tried survival instead. And boy, instead of proper challenge I got cheese-land of cheesy tactics. It's hard but in merely annoying way, not the way that makes you think or tests you.

Here are some examples of these pro tactics that are based off real life:

Nothing bad ever happens if you don't pay attention to things. In survival mode you will be bombared with incidents every few minutes which will be sapping away health of your dwellers so in nutshell you want to do stuff and leave ASAP. Leave workers to live happily and restore health, for we all know that presence of exploitative class brings only unhappyness and bad luck.

Just like in real life the best way to handle conflicts is just run away and ignore it. Right? So if you ever get incidents, in order not to get health of dwellers sapped away, you just have to move them away from whatever or whoever is invading you. If it's internal then it will spread to horizontal and vertical rooms and then end. Which also brings the only non-cheesy tactics of how to build base, aha. And if it's from outside then they just go through each row back and forth to the bottom and then go away. Just send dwellers to rooms where they already passed. It doesn't even matter if they have to go through fire on the way, it only takes away health if they are assigned to same room. Raiders also sap away recources while in shelter but in early game it's quicker to just let them run through than confort, thus takes less recources.

Did you know that pregnant women are the best workers? While they can't fight back or do quests or explore, their AI is set to always run from incidents, practically making them completely invincible. And you wait forever about bringing babies out of their bellies. What an utopia.

It also seems that if you have too much population then their odor will spread all over the wastelands, bringing bigger threat in. As a result you will have to stop at certain population and then wait patiently as you grab the needed loot. Send people on quests and exploration to gain better equipment before getting bigger. Idling. Don't upgrade to level 3 rooms early either, makes bigger internal incidents there.

Overall, I quickly realized that in order to progress in Survival I will have to wait for days to get better equipment and once I got into the fairly stable movement in the game I figured that this mobile idle game can't provide any more proper enjoyment and left the game.

I've won.

[b]Fallout Shelter[/b] is originally a mobile game, but it also got released on PC. The game is pretty good and also [b]Free[/b].

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
- Great mobile port
- Base building
- You can train your vault members and send some of them on missions which you can partake in
- You can send vault members out into the wasteland on a looting adventure
- Daily missions
- Vault-Packs can be obtained for free which is like a "loot box" so to say
- Legendary vault members [i](Like Piper)[/i]
- Lot of weapons you can give for Vault members
- Vault members can have pets, which has their own bonuses
- Your vault sometimes gets raided by bandits or mutants come to attack you and your vault members have to be prepared for a fight.

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- Microtransactions [i](It's a free game so they must have a way to monetize it somehow[/i]
- You can't bring your progression from the mobile version [i](AFAIK)[/i]

[b]8/10[/b] This game plays much better on phone than on PC, but it is not a bad port at all. Try it out if you want.

Bethesda introduced paid mods again. 
Protest review!
This game is not designed for pc.

Uninstalling. Had a lot of fun with the game, but it's the principal of the matter. Creation Club is a dreadful paid mod scheme that rips off the creators. Worse, it downloads all the mods in the CC to your hard drive whether you've purchased them or not. You then purchase a piece of software to unlock and activate it. What's this going to mean for my hard drive when there are hundreds of mods in the CC?

Nope nope nopitty nope. I'm not going to be part and parcel to this kind of behavior. Until the CC is sacked for good, I'm not purchasing another game from Bethesda, which is a shame because they're honestly my favorite studio until now.

From Ui issues to simple control problems, this game suffers from some pretty basic, game-breaking problems.

--Clicking on Dwellers is horrifically undependable
--Often collecting a resource from a room will prohibit you from clicking on, say, Cappy or the Mysterious Stranger to collect those extra rewards.
--Combat in the vault is clunky, limited by room size, and annoying as F**K to deal with, especially because of the clicking/selection problem.
--Mission Combat is a little better, but the missions can feel tedious and chore-like if you use appropriate-level characters and weapons.

Definitely do not recommend.

THIS IS ACTUALLY A MIXED REVIEW!!! SEE BELOW FOR DETAILS!


I'm a big Fallout fan and this game seemed to be just my thing. You can manage a Vault as Overseer build resource rooms and assign the right vault dwellers according to their SPECIAL stats to it which alsop raises their happiness which is a really nice way of managing.

PRO:
You can even build scavanger teams that do missions in the Wasteland which brings XP to them and loot for you and the Vault.

There are also mini challenges which bring you additional goodies.

This game uses different kind of currencies:
* There are caps which are needed to build rooms and buy other stuff
* There is real time which is needed for different actions to take place. The time ranges from mere seconds to full hours depending on the action. Good thing is you can log out and the time counts down as well.
* There is Nuka Cola Quantum which let's you skip the time requirements some actions have. You can buy NCQ using real money or find it in the world. I think it's mostly optional to use them.

You can equip your Vault dwellers with new clothes/armor which increase their SPECIAL Values.
You can equip your Vault dwellers with guns which increase their attack values once they have to fight.
There are events that trigger when your Vault dwellers have to fight.
If a Vault Dweller dies you can revive him using caps.

CONTRA:
Well this is a Bethesda game after all and that means the core mechanics and the core game is pretty decent and somewhat brilliant. Sadly Bethesda is the 80% company that starts a game and does a great job and then just drops its tool at about 80% of the way and says "FCK YOU". In this game it shows when you have to do micromanagement during an attack of the Vault:
I had a case where everything was quite good; I had a high happiness, many vault dwellers, almost every room was occupied, most of them had guns and armor. Then a molerat attack commenced in one of the empty rooms and it spread quite quickly from there. I tried to micromanage the situation by sending my best equiped men/women to the infested rooms. I ran very quickly out of stim packs because you may have lots of storage space but only very limited stim pack storage. So one vault dweller after another lost lots of health and I was using stimpacks when it showed on screen. As I said I quickly ran out.

Then the fckup began... While I tried to grab my other vault dwellers from the other rooms placing them in the infested rooms I misgrabbed them. They are running around randomly and you have to try and grab them and them drag them around to another room. Sadly you either cannot grab them because you have to zoom out enough to see more than a few rooms or dropping them fails because he doesn't detect that I wanted to drop them in a specific room and just cancelled the entire thing. This resulted in alot of my dwellers dying because these molerats are 20 times stronger than in games like Fallout 4. The reviving eats away my caps AND on top the happiness drops like hell.

I just wished bethesda would give their games (not just this one) a final polishing BEFORE shipping them. I don't give a FCK that this is a free game or not, the same happens in their other titles.  If the micromanagement wasn't that bad this game would get a definite recommedation by me!

This is my first review.  Don't play this game.  It's disingenuous to even call it a game.  I love everything Fallout and this game could have been amazing, but it's not.  I doubt they spent 3 months developing it.  Here's what to expect; your shelter produces 3 resources (power, water and food) each on a timer.  The timers count down from 4 minutes at the end of which you click on the room generating the resource to collect it.  There's a cha-ching sound and the time resets.  This "game" for lack of a better word requires no strategy.  It conveys no feeling of accomplishment or productivity and as a result imparts zero satisfaction.  It's a spin-off.  A lazy one.  This game is the Jurassic Park III of the fallout series.

PRE-REVIEW WARNING: This game contains a bug that can corrupt and erase saves after hard-locking your computer.  Be aware and backup your saves from time to time.

Now that that's out of the way, this game is a great time waster, and doesn't require real money to progress.  If you like Fallout, definitely give it a shot!

After finishing most of the set and missions, your perspective of this game changes.  In part, it might be because this was my first survival game.  I paid a fair amount to get products later in the game I decided was foolish.  And compared to the art and style of other games I've played recently, this is rather boring.  If more time had been spent on mission management I would have enjoyed this game far better.  The cookie cutter missions really killed it, which is a shame, because the mechanics are very well balanced and thought out.  But once the Fallout lable fades from your eyes, you realize this game is basically either grind or pay with the missions getting very dull very fast.  And I paid.  And that makes me want to buy another Fallout product in the future mouch less.

 My test is this, if I recommended it to a friend, would they thank me, or would they not?  This is made harder as it is "free".  But it really is not free for anyone who has a job and limited free time and wants to really play a game.

In Fallout: Shelter, you are a Vault Overseer. You must ensure that your dwellers are happy, you have to make sure everything is full - make sure you don't run out of power, food or water - and you must ensure that your shelter is safe for your dwellers to live in.

As a fan of the Fallout series on Xbox, I saw this on Steam and thought that I would grab it and see what it was like. I was expecting something a lot more like the original gaming series, maybe walking through the vault itself. It's not like that at all. It's very much a one dimensional game, with just the layout of your vault in front of you. However, there's a lot that can actually be done in this game and it exceeded the expectations when they dropped upon seeing it when I first opened the game.

This game isn't at all what I thought it would be like. It's a lot of strategy and being ahead of the curve, a lot of being mindful of resources and having to know when to send dwellers out, when to rush things, when to build things. There's a lot that needs to be considered at the same time. It's a little hard on this aspect, but it's actually really fun. I'm having a blast with it, and the achievements definitely make it worthwhile to play, if you're an achievement hunter. This isn't what I thought it would be, but it's a lot funner that I originally expected.

It's definitely a bit of fun and it's free to play on Steam, which is a total bonus! This is totally a play to pass time game, but it's fun for sure, in my opinion.

This is a nice little community management game.  What I was particularly impressed by was that Bethesda, creators of some amazing mainstream games, did not see the need to ram in-game purchases down your throat, despite the game being in the free to play genre. Good Game for starters. I've been playing it for a couple of months now, and I'm only just getting to the more advance parts of the game such as exploring, building nuclear reactors and growing my own food. It is definitely formatted for a phone rather than a computer, but shows potential in being an easy-going adventure game. 

It doesn't really need any experience from the Fallout Series but its fun having familiar characters enter your vault (mine was Piper, yay!!). Another good part is the development of the Vault itself and the customisation of some rooms. I found it most enjoyable when you were able to attend quests once purchasing the overseers office. 

Only the only negative is the price. I think it remember being free to download, or costing only a couple of pounds, but after that, that's where they get all your money. To advance quickly you'll definitely need some Vault-Tec Lunchboxes which you have to buy. The prices range from ¬£2.99 - ¬£50!! Which is crazy but highly tempting. Additional purchases can include pets which benefit your explorers, Quantum Colas which can quicken the processes of making weapons or adventures, and Mr Handys which collect money while you're away. 

Overall, it's a good game, but you can end up spending loads of money on it if you're not careful.

Fallout Shelter is a base-building survival game set in the, you guessed it, Fallout universe. You are the overseer of a vault, and need to perform various tasks to build up and grow your vault.

Pros:
-Simple and easy to get into and play, making it the perfect time-waster. Most objectives or completing of tasks or quests take time (anything from a few minutes to a couple of days), making it an idler of sorts as well.
-Set in the Fallout unverse, with some references towards other Fallout games being made as well
-Mechanics are simple, build a vault and ensure that there is enough power for the vault, and food and water for your dwellers. There is also quests which your dwellers can go on to find weapons, outfits or junk to craft the latter.
-There is steam achievements, but they take quite some time to get, as you need to grind to get them.

Cons:
-Microtransactions is the only thing which irritates me in this game, especially for the Nuka Quantum Cola, which is basically a speed boost item within the game. The game kind of tries to force you to use it if you want to skip objectives or get something done immediately.

Overall, this is a great time-waster worth a look if you enjoy the Fallout series and are looking for something to play.

This may be one of the best Free-to-play games on smartphones in my opinion, and here it is on Steam roughly 2 years after the original release. With its gameplay being building rooms and later upgrading them for more resources for your Vault (somewhat similar to something like Clask of Clans in that way), upgrading rooms (and even rushing them) do NOT require Nuka Cola Quantum (aka the games "premium currency"), instead, rooms will upgrade the instant you purchase it with the games basic currency, Caps. The mechanic to Rush rooms to get the resources instantly is a great idea, and it works well in the game! Basically, rushing a room has around a 30% chance of failing, and it increases by +10% each time you do it, the counter will go back down to 30% if you allow the room to work naturally. If the Rush fails, there will be a disaster in the room (ie a fire or a Radroach infestation), if thats the case, the Dwellers (more on them in a second) assigned to the room will have to douse the flames/fight off the radroaches. For the Dwellers aspect, you must rebuild civilization by allowing dwellers to become members in your Vault. Each Dweller has a set of S.P.E.C.I.A.L. skills: S for Strength, P for Perception, E for Endurance, C for Charisma, I for Intelligence, A for Agility, and L for Luck. Dwellers high in strength can work best in the Power Generator rooms, which are vital for powering your Vault. Dwellers high in Perception  work well in Diners, which supplies food for your Vault. Dwellers high in Endurance can work well in Storage rooms. Dwellers high in Charisma do well with, well, talking; Charisma only affects males/females conversing with someone of the opposite sex, which will end up causing the female to become pregnant and after 3 or so hours will birth a new child, which he then grows up to become another worker in the Vault. Dwellers who have high Intelligence will work best in Medbays or Science Labs, where they can produce Medkits and AntiRadiation Packs. Dwellers high in the Agility stat can work well in the Water Treatment rooms, which supply water to the Vault. Then Luck affects the Rush mechanic, allowing the chance of a disaster to go down a little bit. Strong Dwellers are also very capable of venturing out in the wasteland; giving a dweller a weapon (which helps them during Radroach Infestations or Raider Invasions) will allow the Dweller to survive in the wasteland, out there he can find Caps, guns, and outfits (which will help stats for Dwellers) and return them to the Vault. Combat in the game is simplistic, Dwellers will automatically attack threats and fight fires, its your job to heal them though, if they wont survive, you can assign them to another room so they can flee and survive. If they die, you have 24 real life hours to revive them with Caps, which can be handy. When you reach 18 Dwellers, you can build the Overseer's Office, which allows Quests to be unlocked. Quests are like sending Dwellers out into the wasteland, except you select 3 which meet the Quest requirements (i.e. level and weapon power) and you send them to a certain location which can take anywhere from 1 hour or 21 hours in real time, to speed this up you can use Nuka Cola Quantum. When they arrive at their destination, they travel as a group and will fight enemies. However, combat in Quests is VERY different from regular battles in the Vault, and it is, in my opinion, a little hit or miss. If Dwellers walk into a room where there are enemies, they are locked into fighting and cannot flee (I learned that the hard way), so if you intend on doing quests, i strongly advise packing tons of Stimpacks. Aside from that, combat is a bit deeper, it's still simplistic, but you can tell which Dwellers should target what enemy, and there's a random chance a checkmark crosshair will show up above an enemy, which once clicked, pauses the game and enters a timing minigame where you must click the crosshair when it's as close to the center as possible, doing so will give a critical hit that's 5x more powerful than the basic attacks. Quests do, however, offer a chance to score tons of loot that can be used later in crafting (which I myself have not reached yet).

Side Note: if you've played a Fallout game, you will most likely recognize a ton of familiar aspects of the game. As the game, in my opinion, stays very faithful to the Fallout franchise in terms of style and presentation.

If you enjoy Fallout games or Free-to-play games in the style of crafting rooms and ect., you will most likely enjoy this game, whether it be for Steam or smartphone. I give it 4/5 Stars. If you do plan on playing this game, I hope you enjoy it! ^u^

I first played this game on mobile, then downloaded the PC version at some point from the Bethesda/Fallout homepage. I'm really happy it's finally on Steam. It's a lot of fun managing your Vault(s), and you can choose how you spend your time with this game - you can sit there and watch and collect resources or you can log in, pick up your stuff and level your Dwellers really quick, then go do something else.

Only downside I found is that you cannot sync up your Mobile game with the PC versions, meaning on your phone you'll have up to three different vaults than on your computer. And again, the Steam version and the client version you can download from the Bethesda/Fallout homepage do not sync either, meaning you can have three different versions with up to 9 different Vaults. Of course, this can also be an upside if you like to manage that many Vaults. I, personally, like to focus on one or two, and not having the ability to play the "same versions" (for lack of a better term) of my vaults on multiple platforms kind of bugs me.

Despite that, however, it's a really cute game, made with a lot of love and yes, there are microtransactions but those are not in any way nessescary.

It is fine for a short time to remind of Fallout pip boy graphics. But it can be addictive, yet not too much smooth gameplay and not much new soon (yes, new buildings, styles, but no new mechanics). I spent too much time with that. Of course, if I would have too much money, I could spend some money for the extra game currency (possible to gain by normal playing, but slowly) and speed all up to get all soon.
I still think that some SimTower remake is better in the game mechanics than this. But there are few funny things, so if you are bored, try it.

It's a fun little free game. Though don't buy anything, it's not worth it.
There's elements of management, strategy & RPG.
It's fun & easy to master however there's a bunch of UI faults:
-clickthrough UI (click on "rush", levelup a dweller instead)
-unprecise targeting (example: click on a dweller, levelup another one close by not on the same depth)
-no group selection
-no sorting by dweller list health/radiation status
-no UI to show you dweller's ascendents(cause incest IS actually handled, but the game doesn't show you)
hence I resorted to naming them by family branches (daughter of margaret hicks & paul grants would be Janet HG )

dweller's health is not shown in detail and is not retroactive : e.g. leveling up a dweller to 50 then leveling its endurance to 10 is .... uterly useless

-it's actually better to equip max endurance armor before leveling each dweller  .... (hoooo the micro !!!!)

-raiders continue to steal while they are agonizing, the alarm keeps sounding until they are FULLY dead.

Yeah I know, lots of negative traits. Well I think there's lots of positive reviews out there and it didn't need yet another one. I still recommend this game, it's fun, it's free, and it's forgiving enough on default difficulty that those issues don't really matter much

A company with a reputation for bugs plus in game purchases equals a disaster. I tried to buy one of the in game items through Steam. The item popped up in the Redeem tab in the game, but failed to actually redeem. I contacted Bethesda. Since the item showed up in the redeem tab, it seemed like a bug on their side. After several days of back and forth emails getting nowhere with Bethesda, Bethesda told me they were closing my ticket because Steam issued a refund. Steam had not issued a refund. Please save yourself the disappoinment and frustration, and don't buy in game items for this game.

Fallout Shelter is a freemium mobile game, that has since been ported to Steam, in advance of Fallout 4's release in order to build up hype. Sadly, that's really all it's really good for. Shelter is a 2D city builder sim where you get to live out your dreams of being a Vault Overseer, and use resources to get weapons and outfits, train your people, and send them out to collect more resources. Since quests have been added, there is a lot more to do, but there really isn't a point to the game. You collect stuff, use your stuff to make bigger stuff with bigger numbers, and use that bigger stuff to get the biggest stuff. As with all city builders, you hit a critical mass at which there just isn't anything to do with your city as it will be mostly self sufficient, and the period of time that it takes to reach this critical mass is artificially extended through the classic freemium strategy of making you wait a period of time for a certain task to be accomplished, with the option of using Nuka Cola to speed up the process. There are a lot of references to Fallout 3 and a handful to 4 and New Vegas, but there is little to actually accomplish, even through quests.

This game is good if you want a bit of a nostalgia trip for the modern Fallout games, and does an excellent job of roping in old players to come back and fire up one of the main series games again, but has no depth past that. It's best played on mobile, where you can constantly check back in on the game for the time based actions, but if you have never touched Fallout it's probably for the best to stay away.

Played this so much on iPhone and iPad when it first came out...got to the point that I was killing dwellers just to start over with the "master race!"  with MAX S.P.E.C.I.A.L

Ok...some tips

DON'T build rooms on top of each other.  Leave a gap between levels so that fires and molerats can't go up or down directly to the other rooms!

You can get MORE Caps by just sending out dwellers to search the wasteland rather than doing difficult "achievements" with the worst case scenario being that they die.  Then just spend some caps to revive them and you will still profit from all the junk, weapons and outfits they bring back...remember they don't get attacked on the way back!

Once you get the Endurance Room, NEW dwellers should go directly to that room to MAX Endurance.  Then give them a Wasteland Outfit for additional E points.  This way each time they level up, they will get Maximum hit points per level.  If you can get a +7 Wasteland outfit you are golden !  After that it won't matter what other abilities you pad...

Always put 2 guards in the vault door room.  It will at least slow down Deathclaws so you can get ready to react.  Ghouls and Raiders will just be an annoyance.

When you get to the bottom level, that is where you should put your Dweller Living Quarters.  If fires, molerats or other problems occur it won't affect anything.  You can concentrate on the rooms and floors closer to the top.

Have fun...

An amazing twist on the Fallout franchise to Steam from the mobile platform. A wonderful game to sit back and relax to after playing a competitive match of Counter Strike: Globel Offensive with a bunch of Silver ranks. I suggest this to everyone who loves or has never heard of the Fallout franchise (how do you not hear about these types of games losers?!) for a fun, relaxing and creative game... with brief moments of rage!

This is by far the best game I've gotten for free from Steam. It is very well balanced and well designed, and the addition of the "Quests" feature adds a more enjoyable dimension to the game than it would have otherwise. Fans of the Fallout franchise will find many familiar references, although in structure it is very different from the rest of the Fallout titles. For example, unlike other Fallout fames, there is very little strategy or tactics beyond deciding how to outfit individual characters.

Usually when you get a free game from Steam, the reasons for it being free immediately reveal themselves. This is not the case with Fallout Shelter, which is an extremely playable game that is much better than the price tag would suggest. It is true that the game is set up to offer many possibilities of spending money, but spending money does very little to make the game more playable. Paying for additional resources helps to speed up the game and increase your options a little faster, but this works very well as a standalone game without any additional money spent.

There's a great counterintuitive lesson here for game designers: the more playable the game is without extra features, the more likely players are to spend additional money on it. This is the only "pay-for-more-stuff" game in which I have actually paid for more stuff (about $5, not necessary but no regrets about it either), but it is the game that plays the best in its original form anyway. The games that play the best *without* add-ons may be the ones *most* likely to get revenue from add-ons.

This is not a rapid-fire game with much action, nor a lot of decisions to make every few seconds. It is a resources management game juggling several variables trending at different rates, and there are stretches of time where you are waiting for some clocks to wind down. On the plus side, it is a game that continues to 'play' by itself in relatively safe ways after you log off. It is an ideal game for 30m-1hour in the morning and 30m-1hr in the evening, or a game that you can switch back to once in a while while you do other things.

P.S. For those academic-minded people who like to analyze the fun out of video games, Fallout Shelter is a treasure trove for your Poli Sci or Gender Studies courses. The male and female NPC's are equivalent in all attributes except the fact that the female ones can get pregnant. This is the only game I can think of that features pregnant women, who in this game are simultaneously completely useless in a crisis and also completely indestructible. Combine that with the fact that you as a player have to practice eugenics to be successful, and you have a nice little outraged undergrad paper waiting to be written on this one.

While it's a port of a mobile game, I say it's a bloody good game to play while waiting on things.

Got a video to render? Boot up Fallout Shelter.

Waiting for your crush to text you back? Check on that quest progress.

Had a stressful day at work? Rush your workers too much for the job they're paying you to do.

Report in,
220 hours played 

Recipes: 100% (last one received around 180 hour)
Achievements: 97% ; "Blast From The Past" achievement: 8/20
Dwellers: 195+ / 200 LIMIT (you always need spare for new ones)

From the time your Vault becames resource independant, the gameplay is limited to log once a day, do 3x Overseer's* Quests (yes, you are the Overseer, and yet you have to do all the work!). The Overseer quests ARE limited and the player will be left with Daily/Weekly/Special Quests only.

The quests are very repeatable and boring, and they are full of glitches.
..as the game itself.  There are numerous bugs reports on forums and I presonally confirm:
- the game freeze and hangs itself,
- the game could roll back to an old save point,
- despite countless clicks/taps you still don't click the object, due to broken in-game hitpoints,

The caps doesn't matter - later in the you'll use millions to:
- move some rooms
- upgrade some 
- buy some high lever items

Summary:
The game will take around 200 hrs to complete,
The steam achievement (Blast From The Past) is randomly aquired from lunchboxes and is very unlikely to get,
The game itself is a tap mobile game to kill your time.

Overall score: 6/10.
