Fallout Shelter is a free to play game that is a fun little time-killer that doesn't require you to spend money to be enjoyable.  I first played this game on an iphone, but they've added quite a bit and improved the experience for the PC.  There are plenty of tie-ins to the Fallout universe that I really appreciate and you can do a lot to entertain yourself through customization.  I'm not sure that I would recommend this game to someone who isn't a fan of Fallout in general, as the simulation aspects are fairly weak, but at none-fifty, why not give it a shot?

This game is actually pretty fun, especially if you're already a fan of the Fallout series. It has potential for those who enjoy base-building and management-style games, as well as side quests thrown in for a *tiny* bit of story here and there. There is no overarching story, however, so don't expect there to be anything beyond a surface attachment to the characters. The downsides of Fallout Shelter are that it takes a great deal of time to accomplish anything big, and the quests timers seem to be pretty extreme. These things make it pretty clear that the developers were intentionally coming up with ways to make a little quick cash on the side, offering goods for real money to speed the processes up. Still, for a free to play game and a way to kill time when you're bored and want something "different" to play, this is a good game to try. I definitely recommend giving it a shot, especially since you get to poke the Mysterious Stranger with your mouse from time to time.
Not a bad game, great if you just have some time to waste.

Unless you wanna throw your monitor outta the window, better stay away from this game until the devs pull their hands outta their arses. There are simply too many instances when you get dozens of dwellers wiped simply because the game does not allow you to do what you are trying to do, either moving them to the wrong room (you have to position them to the correct BACK wall frame, not FRONT cutout), or grabbing a wrong dweller or even a room (again, because it checks not where it's on the screen, but where it projects on the backstage).
So fun, but will be difficult when you have a very big shelter.

While the Android version of Fallout Shelter was fun, the biggest problem was the lack of "end game" content (I use the term loosely, since there is technically no end). You eventually ran out of things to buy or upgrade and couldn't figure out what to do with your 200 dwellers.

The Steam version plays mostly the same, but with some simple yet crucial additions that make the game more satisfying. You can now do more with your dwellers than just move them from room to room. There are quests, random encounters in the wasteland, crafting, customization and more enemy types. On the mobile version I always ended up with too much Radaway since there was barely any need for them. In this version your base can be attacked by Radscorpions and radioactive Ghouls which you can encounter on quests, too. Now it's always necessary to keep up the production of both Stimpaks and Radaways. It's also possible to customize your dwellers' appearance in the Barbershop and collect themed interior designs.

While microtransactions exist (you can buy Nuka-Cola bottles to speed things up), it's very easy to earn what you need by completing quests, without too much grinding.

A couple of annoyances include pixel-hunting when you want to move a particular dweller hiding behind several others and end up clicking a dozen wrong things, and the frequency of attacks on your base. I've barely had time to nurse everyone back to health from the last Deathclaw rampage when another one is already starting.

Apart from these quibbles, the game remains an addictive little time-waster.

Fallout Shelter is yet another great design by Bethesda that incorporates the survival in a post-apocalptic wasteland into a tycoon/simulator style game. There are countless hours of gameplay included, frrom desigining your own Vault, to exploring abandonded buildings that come across you while in the wasteland on a pure luck basis, I can easily see how people have devoted hundreds of hours into the game.

The way the tycoon progresses, with so many different options to choose from and full control over your own Vault, really makes me want to play more. It might not be very fun to sit down at it for over 2 hours at a time (unless you have a ton that you can do on the game) but it's a great time-killer or one of those things I check every few hours to see how my progress is going.

If I had to suggest one thing to the game developers, I'd have to ask you to place a timer on the buildings that you add in. It ruins the immersion to just magically have a power plant appear out of nowhere, and having a 1-24 hour timer on everything you can build would seem great. Another thing that I'd like to see implemented in the game is the ability to spectate your exploring wastelanders. It would take an immense amount of time to create and code, but overall I think the experience of seeing that fugitive slave who needed to be patched up would help the game seem a lot more enjoyable and realistic.

Lastly, I'll throw in the pay to win aspect. There are many purchases that you can make to help aid you, from lunchboxes, to nuka cola bottles, and while sometimes the game can require a lot of idiling and it will help a great amount if you purchase these items, you will do just fine if you do not purchase anything in the entire time you've played the game. I'd do it only to support the developer as there's no point in boosting something taht you can just awit overnight or go to work and come back to have it done.

Final words: please give this game a try. It's a great entry level game, it's a great time-killer. It's simple, runs great on a bad computer, and I promise that you will find some kind of enjoyment in building your own Vault.

I'll give this game a thumbs up because it sets out what it means to do - scratch that Fallout itch with a light-hearted take on this fallen universe.  The mechanics are simple and easy to learn within minutes, the dialogue is funny, and the art direction is colorful and fits Fallout lore, albeit repetitive on the quests.  It's great to pick up and play for just a few minutes.  

The game does have its problems however.  I already mentioned the repetiveness of the quests and the combat is painstakingly SLOW at times.  There is almost variance to the enemies you'll defeat - get used to killing a lot of radroaches, mole rats, raiders and the occasional rad-scorpion.  I would be remiss not to mention that even though it is free to play, there really isn't a way to push through the game very quickly without spending some dough on nuka cola quantums and lunch boxes, which don't come cheap.  And getting all the legendary characters, weapons and clothing?  Forget it.

Still, if you like Fallout then this is certainly worth dabbling and having some fun with it.  If I wasn't into Fallout myself, my review might be a bit different.

This will be a longer review;

Despite what is shown here, I have played this game, up, down, sideways and diagonaly, most likely for well over 500h and went late game, just not on steam but in the mobile version, in the past year and a half.

This is a great great game, with a few notes. It's not meant to be played continuously for hours and hours, although after a while you can. The great thing in the game is balance, while early game you'll spend most of your time tweaking your vault, later you will spend less time there and more time on quests or looking for nuka-cola.
The by far best thing is the fact that they took time and ironed out all the bugs from the android version, at least as far as I can see. I've have many month old vaults wrecked by a disaster that never ends, and kills everyone, and the loading time on android tended to get silly in some of the patches.
Over time the developers have indeed added many things to the game, expanding it, and there is still plenty of room left. And by far best, the game trully is F2P, everything can be achieved without spending anything, though it takes longer ofc., but these aren't obcene timers like in some of the other "f2p" games, ranging in hours, rather than weeks.
Indeed spending money on survival mode feels rather like a cheat than a bonus.

And the comedy in the dialogue is both hilarious, and ofc, sometimes heavily tied to the Fallout series.

For me this is without a doubt the best F2P game out there..... ever.

I think I will even write up a guide in the forums.

Probably the best concept for a fallout game, which is to build, upgrade, manage and survive in your own vault as overseer. Gameplay is casual and centered around logging in at least once a day to run your vault.

[b]PROS[/b]
> Good concept of vault basebuilding.
> The quests are great.
> The character dialogue is fun.
> Weapons and clothing interesting to discover, build and collect. 
> Addition of pets, vault attacks, and objectives were great ideas.
> Casual gameplay. 

[b]CONS[/b]
> The game likes to hijack my camera angle and zoom distance often, and it can become a bit tedious and annoying. 
> If your character is ready to level up and you do a special attack it levels your character up afterward regardless of the fact that you didn't click to level up. 
> If a character is maxed out in a training room like perception, and you want to swap them out for another character in another training room like strength, it sometimes swaps in a character from the strength room who is already maxed out in perception, despite the fact that there were 5 other better choices. 

[b]CONCLUSION[/b]
None of the cons are potentially game breaking, they're just annoying. More fun and interesting than fallout 4 and more replay value. If Fallout 4 followed base building along these lines it would have been more engaging for me. Would definitely recommend playing if you enjoy the fallout series.

Fallout Shelter is a waiting game/simulation game based on the Fallout universe. You are the overseer of a vault, and it is your job to build up your vault and its population, looking after them and protecting them. This seems really neat. And honestly, it is a really cool idea, and it is fun for a while. But eventually you realize that the game is an enormous addiction engine, and underneath that addiction, there‚Äôs actually not all that much game. After a while, you will notice that the game becomes repetitive and you will start playing just for the achievements. One of them (collect 20 legendary dwellers) is almost impossible to get by legitimate means (or by spending real money). I reckon developers are just encouraging cheating, and I really feel bad about it. The game is too long (slow progression), it has a lack of depth and is very repetitive.

Nice little game about clicking to get resources in an endless turn of repetitive events without a real story but fixed-steps quest lines.

I've enjoyed very much exploring other places, but maintaining the bunker becomes a chore after 4-5 hours. You have many choices and action and such, but it feels very soon like you go into maintenance mode. Obviously, there's an explanation for this:

> THE GAME LOOSES VERY QUICKLY ITS MOMENTUM AND TO KEEP IT GOING YOU HAVE TO SPEND MONEY ON IT.

That's what was expected of a "FREE TO PLAY" game. More like "FREE TO PLAY for 3 hours until you get hooked, then come and whale all over the place". Sadly for them, I don't whale and I wasn't hooked at about 6 hours.

TL;DR: same old F2P story...

This is the 3rd version of this game I have played. I currently have it on my iPad and the Windows 10 version as well in this steam version. I do admit I put some money into this game only ¬£10 for 50 lunch boxes during the sale. But this was mostly due wanting me to give something back to the devs for giving me an addicting and fun game to play. At the point of buying the lunch boxes my vault was coming along very well. I simply wanted to reward the devs and at the same time see if I could obtain some of my favorate characters to live in my vault from the other Fallout games.

I don't sit here playing this for hours on end as it's not designed to play like that. This is designed to play in short bursts at a time. For example ill throw this on for a half hour while am waiting for a game to download or even while am trying to decide what game to play next.

Again, this is not a game you play all day. This is just a short bust game. Again, you also don't have to put money into this game at all (in my opinion) as I think you can earn your fair share of lunch boxes by doing easy tasks.

[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Fallout Shelter is a supervisor/mantinance/managment simulator, which puts you in the role of a Vault overseer overseeing a vault.
Fallout Shelter was developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released Mar 29, 2017.

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] There's not much to the story... well... not on it's own anyway. If you've played the fallout games there are plenty of nods to the lore within the fallout universe.

To put it simply, the fallout universe takes place after a nuclear exchange October 23, 2077, and now the people survive in complex underground systems known as Vaults.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] In fallout shelter you need to keep your dweller's happy and content, maintain water, food, and energy levels, build new rooms, send dwellers out to gather resources, and much more.

The basic gameplay loop is "Make sure your stats are maxed" [i](That takes a bit to get balanced out at the start of the game)[/i], then slowly arm and equip all of your dwellers in the best gear possible.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] I started playing Fallout Shelter to do something different with my time, and to wean myself off clicker-heroes.
If you're looking for a time sink; this is as good a choice as any. While not as complex and satisfying as other simulation styled games... I enjoy booting up the game, checking my stuff and then logging off to go about my day.

[b]My Thoughts Video:[/b]

Fallout Shelter is a F2P game that originally surfaced on mobile devices a few years ago shortly before the release of Fallout 4. I remember completely failing at the task at hand and had my Vault and its Dwellers silenced forever due to a series of unfortunate events. I can only remember Deathclaws and my poorly equipped bunch valiantly defending their incompetent Overseer. 
 
Recently the game was released on Steam and I thought it best to try and redeem this Overseer's tarnished record. The good news is that Vault 757 is flourishing nicely and has a lovely bunch of Dwellers who either wander around taskless or work 24/7 365 days of the year doing what they know best... constantly turning a valve. 
 
I have to say that having had a fresh approach to the game, it is really accessible and it  is refreshing  not to have microfractions constantly pinging up asking you to spend more and more until your savings are  non-existent.  You can have it running in the background while you do some work or browse the latest news. Yes, tasks can be repetitive and you do have to wait to reach quests(Which is the interesting part). However I'm sure you have more important things to do rather than mindlessly click on tabs... If you get tired, you can buy a few  Mr Handys to automatically collect resources. Just be careful not to have them engage with raids or infestations as these lovely machines cost 2000 caps each to repair. 

It's a neat little management game and I would recommend you give it a go. Just remember to keep those Stimpaks and RadAways stocked and you'll do just fine!

So far overall it is quite a fun game but please Bethesda it could have been so much better.
I do love the spin-off of the fallout universe here but it is too simplistic and mole rats that wrecks your bunker and crawl through walls and floor like it was made of paper thin aluminium, that is just intellectually offending for the player.
Everyone in the room takes damage from 1 radscorpion as if it actually was a fire in the room, too obvious and it is just as annoying to see.

Only 2 dwellers can occupy the vault door room which is the most important room you would think to actually defend and there is no option to build a defense system? turrets? guardbots? hello? How about a guard/security room that will automatically send dwellers occupying the room to the area of emergency?
The vault door is made of what? Ghouls breaking down a solid metal heavyduty vault door with punches and kicks, sigh..

Would have made it more interesting to be able to be sieged by raiders/creatures, forcing you to break the siege so your wanderers could return inside the bunker and be able to send out people to explore or go for quests again.

Being able to choose if you want to start building outside the vault to setup trading routes with settlements which you unlock through exploring would be a thing, being able to build up a town connected to your vault would be cool aswell.
Doing so would increase the risk you would be discovered by raiders/mutants/ghouls/creatures.

Raiders stalking your wanderer to your vault which would lead to severe attacks on your vault/outside settlement, you being able to launch attacks on raider/mutant camps to stop those attacks.

You are saying you are a million dollar game company yet release shallow games, where is the passion and creativity?
Make proper spin-offs of the Fallout universe and you will shower in money.

Make a new game called Fallout: The overseer, make it roguelike or at least that option to have that. If you dwellers die they die for good.
Make it so you have to hunt for food, have your own greenhouses inside the bunker and such.
A fallout bunker simulator! make it happend please !

Loved this on iOS.  Unplayable on PC.  So friggin' buggy.  It will not run without an error of some sort, the latest I've encountered is the animations freezing, but the game continuing to run in the background; even in the loading screens.  I have to minimize the window to the taskbar then bring it back to get three frames of animation only to have to do it all again.  So very disappointed.

I can say that this is probably my favorite thing to do on my phone, so take my time and quadruple it if you want an actual value.  I have been playing this since late in 2015 on my phone.  It came to Steam and I love to be an achievement completionist on the games I really like, so that's what I am doing now.  This is one game I wish I had never seen, I can forget how much time I am in it to easily.

This game is addictive.  It is not a pay to win game, you can win it by just playing as it is.  If you really like it though, buy a pack or something to let them know they did a good job.  But, back to the game, it is kind of like a Fallout themed Sim Tower (a Maxis title from way back when)  but has some more interesting diversions in the form of quests.  Train your dwellers, send them on quests or just to explore the wateland.  Setup your base to balance out the needs and to have the rooms to help make your vault more successful and customizable.

Starting out the game is tricky, I have found it takes me a little while to get things rolling smoothly and to get the balance worked out.  I have built probably seven or eight 200-person vaults but the challenge for me has been to try to get a 100-125 person vault working stable, then I can weed out the riff-raff as I find legendary and rare dwellers, pets, armors and weapons.  The Mr. Handy's help immensly in keeping the base stable for gathering resources.  Being of a collector nature, this game preys on my weakness.

So if you are immune to collectionism, completionism, loss of time-ism, and addictivism, this is not the game for you, it would be too boring.  Otherwise join the rest of us, everyone is doing it.  Oh, and the first one is free. ;)

Review for Update 1.12

PROS

- Clean design, although the characters do get very repetitive as well as the environment
- Easy game, if you frequently play the game, you will realize how easy it is, you just need to grind for money.
- The ability to do quests and receive loot (weapons, clothes, junk, pets, etc). Pets give boosts. Weapons improve damage, and clothes improve the abilities of the survivors (Strength, Perception, Charisma, Intelligence, Endurance, Agility and Luck).



CONS

- Saving does not work properly, when you log off, your base may suffer a rollback, or it could save in inapropriate times like fighting an impossible wave of mole rats that will kill all your survivors. Leaving you to grind money for a long time to be able to bring them back and probably lose all of them again on another attack.
- Monsters will keep spawning inside your base (in huge amounts per room) after you get a certain amount of survivors, something that turns to be almost impossible to defend while having survivors outside doing quests or having them pregnant.
- After a while the game starts getting boring because its always the same thing, get energy to power the other rooms, get food and water to keep your survivors happy, put the designated survivors in their rooms, and grind for resources, get money and upgrade rooms, do quests that are pretty much all the same.
Gr8 game 10/10 would recommend

Fallout Shelter is a simulation game in which the player runs a Vault-Tec vault as the overseer. As the overseer, one controls all of the vault's functions including: power, food, water and the number of vault dwellers. To advance through the simulation one needs to increase the size of the vault by adding and upgrading new rooms; each with their own function and then adding dwellers to run each room.

This game is adorable. It also stands alone even if you know very little of the Fallout franchise. It's sexist, but it is set in the 50's style apocalypse, so that gets a pass. The conversations between your residents are hilarious. For those alone I would play. Add in quests to complete, and S.P.E.C.I.A.L. abilities to train, and items to collect and I'm hooked. I will say that the lunchboxes, though a great prize in the beginning (and yes, buy the one that is "one per vault" to start you out), are pretty pointless later on. So I don't recommend dumping money into any but that first one, you don't need it to make it, so there isn't a need to keep dropping real world money into the game after you toss the developers their $5 for your starting pack.

Though the mobile version may be better for some due to being able to play on the go, the PC version is better in my opinion. I'm not able to bring my PC wherever I go, so I'm forced to not focus on the game at times. This makes things seem to go faster compared to staring at my vault waiting for my outfit to be finished in 13 hours. Both versions are fun, nonetheless.

Even though this game is free, I cannot recommend it.  The critical bugs and poor mechanics can't make up for it being free or even that you can have some fun playing it.  I do play it a lot, but it has become monotonous and at times extremely frustrating.  TL:DR at end.

The most problematic bug that goes unaddressed is the one that will corrupt your save files leaving you to start anew.  While the game says it uses the cloud, your saves are local and if they are corrupt there's nothing that really can be done.  There are no saves on the cloud to rescue you.  You have to manually back up your saves frequently.  The bug occurs if you're playing the game and your computer shuts down, either by power loss, blue screen of death, frozen and you have to reboot to do anything, if you can't exit the game normally your saves will be forever lost.  What makes this most insidious is that if you paid money for the lunchboxes or colas then they, too, are gone forever.  Bethedsa will not give you back the items you received from them.  It becomes lost money.  Steam will not reimburse you either.  So spending money on the game is a gamble.  You must make those manual backups daily to protect yourself.

Another bug is actually with buying these items.  While I have never spent money on the game, so many others have and when they buy items it becomes stuck in their inventory without the ability to get the in game.  Steam will tell you to go to Bethesda and they will tell you to go to Steam.  You have to go back and forth in order for Steam to reimburse you and you only get that with proof of going to Bethesda, having the items in your inventory, and showing how they can't be brought into game.  It's a real hassle and so far I've only seen a few actually get their money back.

The last frustrating bug I'll discuss is when you send a group on a quest, there's a chance for you to become stuck into a cycle of click on the group to enter the quest and then getting sent back to your vault instead of the quest location.  You have to select the group again, try to enter the quest again, and hope it will send you to the quest location.  On average I must repeat this cycle about 5 times before getting into the quest and it happens every other day.  There are times I've been stuck in the loop 10 times before I give up and exit the game, restart, and then try again.  I have better luck with it working then.  

The mechanics that I dislike are how you loot, how the focus and zoom automatically changes on you during events, inability to see who's wearing what eq in a list form, poor ability to search for people, radscorpions leaving the room they are fighting in to go to another in your vault.  

On quests you can loot containers and bodies, but frequently your dwellers are in the way and it can become a pain to do this as when you try to click on them you get a dweller not the lootable item.  I've learned to loot containers after I've left the room to make it easier, but you can't loot bodies unless you are in the same room.  It becomes a game of moving people out of the room and back in to try to get them to reposition so you can click on the feet of the bodies, because that works best.  Sometimes the bodies fly into other rooms, or the wall because there is no room and you can't see them.  So you just have to click on the blackness to make sure there was nothing there.

Whenever there is an event the focus will immediately go to that event and zoom in.  This is highly frustrating.  When you have 170 dwellers, 100 rooms, an you're trying to train people, move them around, level them up, change their eq, it's the biggest pain your patootie to have the focus move from the room you were in to the vault door because of ghouls that will be stopped by your guards in seconds.

While you can find your dwellers on a list, it's hard to get them to focus.  Sometimes a double click on their name works, sometimes right clicking, other times, nothing will work.  There's probably some bug with that too.  But when you get to having over 100 people it's really hard to manage them when you can't find where they are wandering around.  And those events that pull focus make it harder.  

When your dweller has a baby it will move the focus to the top of the vault even though you were at the bottom.  So if you happen to have a population boom at the bottom of your vault you're going to be annoyed with how many times you have to move back down to the bottom of your vault to click on the next pregnant woman.  Issues like that keep coming up.  The game decided you should be zoomed in and over here even though you don't want to be.

On your dweller lists, it does not allow for outfits or weapons.  So you can't see who doesn't have them and who does.  You can see by looking if they are wearing something, but not if they have a weapon.  So you have to click on each and every dweller to make sure they have a weapon.  This is annoying and added to that the focus change stuff it makes you want to pull your hair out.

Then we have the radscorpions.  I don't mind them, but one behavior is downright buggy maybe.  If you have an attack at your vault door you have x amount of time to kill them before they move to the next room.  This continues until they're dead.  No problems with that.  If something pops up in the middle of your vault, dwellers in that room will fight it until it's dead or they die.  If there is no one in the room and no one comes to fight it they will spread to other areas of the vault until all killed.  Still not a problem.  Radscorpions drain energy like crazy.  If they appear in a room without dwellers, you will have a problem.  Even if you send dwellers in from next door and have a robot fighting it from the very beginning the radscorpion (if not almost instantly killed which is very hard) will leave the fight and appear in another room.  Even if that room has dwellers and fighting starts right away, it will keep leaving the room and appearing elsewhere until it pops up into a room with 6 people it in that can kill it rapidly.  By the time this is done you have little energy.  I don't think the mobs that popup like that should be able to relocate while you are actively engaged in fighting them.  It seems to be a bug since it doesn't happen with other creatures that pop up in your vault through the ground.

And finally, after a while, the game becomes boring as it's just the same thing over and over again.  I have fun in the beginning setting up my vault and trying to train everyone, but the quests are the same.  You don't do anything but click on the rooms to send your dwellers and then click on the loot.  Sometimes there's a question you have to answer, but they're all the same.  I now dread the daily maintenance of questing because it's long and boring. 

The good is that it's free.  The base building is limited, but designing what goes where is important and there is strategy to that.  There is no pause for a bathroom break, so just exit to the main menu to prevent an event that might kill your dwellers if you're not there to click on their healing.  There's leveling up and level stats on characters, outfits with different stat mods, weapons, and you can craft your weapons and outfits from blueprints you find on quests.  So, there's some fun to be had and I've played it for a while now.

TL:DR  Don't pay money on this game.  You MUST manually back up saves daily or risk corrupted games and lost purchased items forever.  Bugs and mechanics make it frustrating and tedious.  But some fun to be had for a little while if you are not invested in the game.

Let me start by saying the game is fun. Very fun. It is probably the best freemium game I have ever played, and you can reach the endgame easily and reasonably quickly without paying anything.

The reason I can't recommend the game is the prevalence of game-breaking bugs. The first one is objectives randomly resetting. A big part of the game is completing objectives for rewards. Some can be done in a few seconds, other may take hours or even several days. The problem is that they will randomly reset all the time, for no reason whatsoever. Extremely frustrating, although not relevant at all compared to the second bug, which is...

Random savegame deletion. Your vault will usually be deleted if the game or your PC crashes, but also just randomly for no apparent reason. After spending ~60 hours on my last vault, I'm finally done with this game. Stay far, far away from it unless you want to be extremely disappointed.

Fallout Shelter is a Free to play Construction/Management simulation game styled in the Fallout Series world. The game tasks the player with building and managing their own Vault (fallout shelter) and dealing with collecting resources as well as invading enemies.

You take the role of Overseer, the leader and coordinator of the Vault,  your job is to make the inhabitants happy through meeting their needs (power, food, water as well as tasking them to work in the correct areas). Dwellers (inhabitants) produce resources for their respective jobs at a different rate dependent on their "SPECIAL" (Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck). Most of the game revolves around this concept of balancing resources.

Pros:
+ Fun Gameplay until you hit a certain point
+ Free to play
+ Visual style is enticing and fun to look at
+ Items and NPC's from the Fallout Series are in the game

Cons:
- Lack of depth, ends up being very repetitive
- Unneccessary amount of microtransactions
- Lack of end game content

TL;DR:
6/10
Construction/Management simulator based in the Fallout Series's world, gameplay gets repetitive and lacks any end game content or a goal. Fun for a while but loses interest fairly quickly.

PS: On a side note, the game's files are stored client side, meaning you can edit your saves and adjust the times on your computer to affect your Vault.
A game that you can easily spend tons of hours on and get hooked, if you love managing games. Would highly suggest this game to Fallout fans

Have been playing the game quite a bit, i haven't had any save file gone corrupted so far, had to mention that since this seems as a issue people have been having.

It's a simple yet fun entertaining game that you can play for small pockets of time each day. The additon of quests adds a lot to the game since it gives you something to play for. Even though quests at their core are really similar they still present a thin narative to each quest.

Technical whise there are bugs here and there and i don't mean the rad roaches and over grown scorpions. The mouse interaction could've been done a bit more smooth and the UI could be more user friendly especially when handling events / desaster in the vault. Some quests fail to load sometimes and it thakes a few attempts for the to boot up at times. There are also some positive glitches that might help make the game easyer for people.

Regarding Microtransactions i feel they really trivialise the game, so if you want to give the game some longevity i'd advise in avoiding them, for your own wallet's sake and your experince in the vault. You can earn Lunchboxes and pets through out the wastes or through quests and they add to your sence of achievement, the rewards feeling a lot more earned then if you just throw 50 bucks at the game.

Overall i do recommend the game whether you play on steam or your mobile. 10 Minutes ever cople of hours is in my opinion the best way to experience it

If you played Fallout Shelter on Android or iOS then you should already know what to expect.

You play as the Overseer controlling a vault, the more time you spend, the more resources you need to keep everything running. It's a fine concept, for a mobile game where you pick it up from time to time.

The mouse support does help a lot, especially on situations where your vault is under attack or doing side quests, but don't expect more content if you already spent hours in the mobile version.

The only thing I think is missing is some sort of sync with the mobile game, would be nice to continue where I was.

If you like Fallout and never tried the mobile game, then go ahead, there is some fun stuff to do.

This is a fun low-maintenance game that does a good job of using the Fallout world, giving you missions to collect loot and makes good use of the SPECIAL stats system.

Main criticism is the UI which is ported from touch screen and it can cause some annoyance when trying to select a particular character as you can easily miss. Also, it's too easy to inadvertently pick someone hidden behind a wall when you move the screen around. 

I haven't spent a penny of real money on this and I'm up to something like 140 dwellers. Each time I log in I usually have a new dweller waiting to join my vault. In fact, I have so many of the little guys in there it's getting hard to juggle them around properly.

Some tips: Training dwellers by assigning them to training rooms where a particular stat is improved is essential to getting the vault working efficiently. After they have improved a stat assign them to the corresponding work room so they can level up. Having high level characters and arming them all is the best way to give your characters a good chance of surviving vault attacks and having success on missions. The only reason to spend money is if you're REALLY impatient, but it would be poor value so I don't recommend doing that.

[PROS]
+ The concept is based on the Fallout series
+ Nice interface and design
+ Quests
+ Tons of weapons, outfits and items
+ Fallout "S.P.E.C.I.A.L" dweller stats
+ Funny interactions between vault dwellers
+ F2P and it's balanced

[CONS]
- needs time and constant attention
- limited space and dweller number
- illogical incidents

Vault boy is back !!

Ever wanted to manage your own Fallout's Vault ? Here is your chance with this free to play Bethesda game. It's a simple base building single-player game, yet well made, entertaining and can even be addictive at the beginning.

The objective of the game is to cleverly build your Vault and manage the produced resources : energy, food, water, stimpaks and radaway. You can attract people or make your Dwellers have babies ; then, assign them to the right rooms according to their abilities (for example the power room needs workers with strength) or make them train their SPECIAL. Send other Dwellers to explore the Wasteland or on quests to gain experience and find loot. Don't forget to equip armors, weapons and pets : the Wasteland is a dangerous place and your Vault is not safe from Raiders or Deathclaws attacks. Improve your Vault and you'll be able to craft armors, weapons, themes and to build new types of rooms, for example the barbershop that allows you to customize your Dweller's appearance.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=938929825

Most of the negative reviewers mentioned a problem with the save files : they kept randomly losing their Vaults and had to start over. In 79 hours, it never happened to me, so in case you wondered, they surely corrected it.

As a free to play game I can but recommend Fallout Shelter.

I find Fallout Shelter to be an amazing game.

Just don't use your money to buy anything, like.. Ever. I spent $30 on my game and had weapons for everyone, everything was perfect. Then out of nowhere, invincible molerats overran my shelter. I paused and Googled if paid-for objects and such carried out between saves but sadly, they did not.
I wasted $30 on this game just so I could be easily overran. It was basically like me spending $29.99 for the game but once you lost, you lost the game too.

This is the only reason I do not recommend this game. I strongly disapprove that they be locked to specific saves. Especially considering the fact I spent my hard-earned real money.

"Oh, you lost? Thanks for playing. Please insert another $29.99."

It's like a sick, overly-expensive arcade machine that instead of quarters, costs $29.99. And you don't get 3 lives. Nope. Just one. Lose it and you have to pay an arm and a leg just to start over.

[h1][i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is a simplistic [i]Fallout[/i] experience that only [i]Bethesda[/i] could deliver.[/h1]

 [i]Shelter[/i] at its core is a free-to-play mobile game, successfully transitioned to the bigger screen. Being a free title, in-game purchases are included, but as always they are not mandatory and do not seem to haul the natural gameplay progression that much.

 This new installment, however, is pretty shallow and bares almost no resemblance to any of the other games in the franchise. 

 [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is a mediocre resource management game with the [i]Fallout[/i] image slapped over it and in that turn it lacks anything expected from the series: no personal character, no player choice whatsoever, no story, minor customization(outfits, weapons).

 [i]Shelter[/i] is a decent mobile game, an average PC game and a terrible [i]Fallout[/i] game, but that's what you get with [i]Bethesda[/i]!

 [b]5/10[/b]

Fallout Shelter is a simple and addicting Vault management game. Obtain more vault dwellers, gear them up, send them on quests, keep them happy with ample food and electricity and repeat the process until you have a flourishing vault. There are plenty of themes, weapons, armor, crafting recipes and quests to unlock. 
It may be free to play though be warned, the game is filled with micro-transactions. All the items that can be purchased include:
-"Lunchboxes"- contain resources, caps, weapons, armor, dwellers and pets, all ranging in quality.
-"Nuka-cola Quantum"- used to pass time, when you may otherwise be required to wait numerous hours.
-"Pet Carriers"- contain a variety of pets with different benefits and quality.
-"Mr.Handy's"- used to auto-gather resources instead of having to click on them, or send them outside the vault to search for bottle-caps.

7.5/10- The game is a great time sink, though the amount of time required for waiting around for time to pass (without purchasing bunches of Nuka-Cola Quantum to make everything instant) becomes a bit of a bore later on in the game. Expect to spend at least some money on the game, just don't go nuts gambling on too many lunchboxes.
it`s a really fun game to play

Fallout Shelter is an Enjoyable and Addictive Game.  It reminds me of Sim Tower from back in the day, which is a good thing.  It looks to be a great addition to the Fallout universe of games.

I can see getting a lot of mileage out of this game.  As of writing this I have played 10 hours, and have unlocked 8 of 35 achievements and can see a clear path of how to unlock the remaining achievements. 

The Lunchboxes (the loot crates of the game) are handy, but are not required to enjoy the game.

I would recommend all fans of the Fallout Series and those just dipping their toes into the Fallout universe (like myself) to check out Fallout Shelter.

[Update]: There was one drawback of the game. Near the tail of end of reaching all the achievements it became clear that one achievement, "Blast From The Past" where you are tasked with Collecting the 20 Legendary Dwellers was impossible unless you purchase lunchboxes (loot crates).  This was a real drag and did drag down my level of excitement for the game.

At first I saw it had "match random character to stat room" gameplay and gave up on it, but it has way more than that.  Missions that go on rotation so they're not samey, actual things to do instead of having to wait for everything, risk/reward based gameplay, and of course it's all in a Fallout game with plenty of humor to boot.  I'd suggest giving it a go if you need something to do while watching twitch or listening to podcasts and so on.

Fallout Shelter is a casual mobile game, ported to the PC and Steam. It's fast and easy to get into and it's got just enough content to keep you entertained between real games or real tasks. If you want to get every Steam achievment, it does get stale very quickly, however. In the end, though, you spend a couple of minutes to learn the ropes, you get a couple of hours of contented enjoyment.

It's flashy, popcorn entertainment. It's also free, so there's that. If you like mobile games, you'll like it. If you like Fallout stuff, you'll probably be entertained for a while. It's worth trying out, at the very least.

I knew this was just a conversion from the mobile application, therefore, my expectations for this game should have been low. It is impossible, however, not to feel some excitement when engaging with new material from the Fallout universe - and excitement walks hand-in-hand with high expectations. Fortunately, Fallout Shelter has, to a great extent, met those expectations. 

Why? This game is so simple to play, which makes it perilously addictive. Everything can be controlled with just the mouse. For instance, to assign vault dwellers to specific roles, you just drag and drop them to SPECIALised rooms. That‚Äôs right, the pun was intended. Your vault dwellers have the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system, just like Fallout, and some of the rooms have a preferred S.P.E.C.I.A.L.s. The Science Lab required high Intelligence, for example. While it isn‚Äôt compulsory to adhere to the assigned S.P.E.C.I.A.L., doing-so will make you vault dweller very happy; and happiness, as you will find, is very important. 

The rooms of your vault, weapons and armour will be limited in the beginning, but your options quickly grow with the growth of your vault‚Äôs population, which can be increased in two ways: you can build a Radio Studio to attract dwellers from the Wasteland, or, in a more novel way, assign a male and female dweller to a Living Quarters, then sit-back, and let the amorous spectacle commence. Fortunately, for those sick-minded individuals out there, the game won‚Äôt let you force incest, or exile a pregnant dweller. 

As for the graphics, they are, of course, basic, but not repulsive or retro-feeling. In fact, the endearing Vault Boy cartoon-style pervades the game and makes each dweller quite endearing. The power armour suits, though, look a little compressed, and a little too comical.  

The replay value of the game is somewhat limited, which, of course, is because Fallout Shelter was intended to be the launch-pad for Fallout 4. This is evident in the missions, which, after incorporating some witty dialogue in keeping with the Fallout universe, fail to vary and challenge the player: the management in combat is limited, the same half-a-dozen locations become dreary, and the enemies equally so. In short, the missions can become something to run in the background, in order to gain revenue, whilst being more attentive to another task in your Internet browser. 

Overall, this game is definitely worth playing, but only if you looking for a bit of light-hearted fun. The serious gaming, and long-term gaming, remains with Fallout 4, or for more avid Fallout fans, like myself, Fallout: New Vegas.

What can I say about Fallout Shelter? 
   It's addictive, it's cures boredom, and it's free! 
   Normally, I only play 3ish hours on a game every other day (sometimes more, sometimes less). Yet with this game I found myself playing 6 hours straight everyday. 
   You only need a mouse (point and click), an hour to get the hang of it, and to get your first lunchbox where a bulk of the rewards and goodies lie. Likewise, they also lay out in The Wastes where you can send your residents to explore for a multitude of interesting objects, including obtaining experience points and gear. I would love to say more, but I don't wanna spoil anything. 
   I've been playing videogames for 20 somethin' years, and I can assure you that if you love The Sims or similar types of genres where you directly control your avatars, situations that abrubtly arise, etc., you will definitely lose your precious time in Fallout Shelter. It will be worth it ;) I even bought a Starter Pack for $4 cash, thinkin' I'd regret it, but no... It was 110% the value of that $4 cash. This is likely the greatest free game I've ever played, no doubt in the top 3.

OVERVIEW:
Fallout Shelter is a time management game where you as the overseer trying to keep your happy dwellers alive. You can build rooms and join them together, assigning dwellers to do certain jobs or sent them out to explore the wasteland. Crafting items or doing quest requires a lot of time, but that's the whole point of time management games. The ingame timer is still ticking while you are not playing the game.

What I like:
- It's free and not pay to win. You can easily complete the game without paying a cent.
- You can farm nuka cola and speed up the timer.
- Everything is obtainable without the need to pay real money.
- Interesting combat system while doing quest.
- It does not requires a lot of your time. You can run it on your background & do other stuff.
- The 2D art is refreshing and cute.

What I hate:
- One achievement is almost impossible to unlock unless you cheat. I only got 4/20 process while having over multiple hours of playtime. That's just a bad gamedesign choice imo. No one will be that crazy to keep playing for so long after completed the game without any new content.
FOR MORE: https://www.loganspace.com/
If you've got a few minutes to waste everyday, I definitely recommend this game.

Bethesda, if you guys read these reviews, here's my 2 cents on improvements.  Now while I believe you have a solid game, moving dwellers from room to room is a bit clunky.  Instead of drag and drop, how about a move-to button, maybe found on dweller stats.  makes it more precise that way, and also eliminates scrolling through rooms and accidentally moving dwellers, which is quite common.

Another improvement would be to find and repair the memory leak that is hogging resources and lagging gameplay.

it is also a bit challenging to read dwellers thoughts.  when a dweller isn't happy, it can sometimes be frustrating trying to figure out just what he/she is unhappy about.  the text dialogs sometimes hint at dwellers feelings, but arent very clear.

and lastly, when you rush power, food, and water, sometimes it fails.  the issue isn't with the failure, the issue lies within the effects from failing.  it is common sense that a fire can break out in a kitchen, or power room, but in a water purification plant?  kind've silly.  also, failing any of these shouldn't bring on the effect of radroaches invading the vault.   fires, chemicals, gasses,sure, but not radroaches.  kind've absurd.

Thanks for listening! (i hope)

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding lemon bars recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1) 2 cups Flour
2) 1/2 cup Sugar
3) 1/4 teaspoon Salt
4) 2 sticks (1 Cup) Salted Butter, Cut Into Small Cubes
5) Filling
6) 1-1/2 cup Sugar
7) 1/4 cup Flour
8) 4 whole Large Eggs
9) Zest And Juice Of 4 Medium-sized Lemons
10) Powdered Sugar, For Sifting

Directions:

1. For the crust: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grease a 9-by-13-inch pan with butter.

2. Stir together the flour, sugar, and salt. Add the butter to the bowl and use a pastry cutter to cut it all together until the mixture resembles fine crumbs. Press into the prepared pan and bake until golden around the edges, about 20 minutes.

3. For the filling: Stir together the sugar and flour. Crack in the eggs and whisk to combine. Add the lemon zest and juice and mix until combined. Pour over the crust and bake about 20 minutes.

4. Allow to cool in the fridge for a minimum of 2 hours, then sift powdered sugar over the top before cutting into squares.

(Use an 8 x 10 pan if you'd like the layers to be a little thicker.)

Never spend money on this game. It's entirely too easy to lose your purchase one way or another, with no way to get it back. (Also, this is Bethesda we're talking about.)

Spending money is also redundant. There are no items you can only buy with real money, and there are some items you can only get by playing the game. Even loot boxes and speed-up boosts can be earned in-game.

Getting 100% achievements, though, is Pay to Win, as the Blast from the Past achievement can take hundreds to thousands of hours without spending (lots of) real life money (or save editing). If you're one of those max achievers and you just can't help yourself, skip this one.

I love Fallout Shelter! I like to keep in running in the background while I am doing paperwork at home, it just keeps working a little bit more fun! My husband knows that before I sit down to play any game with him, I got to check on my people and set the most unhappy dwellers up to mate and have a baby. At first it was a little slow...you have the option of playing it fast, but mistakes are made when you play it fast. Everything factors on everything else working properly.  I have paid money into the game at very dull moments with my vault. I pay $1 dollar per hour played, but I have to play those hours first. And it seems to be a game that you don't have to worry about if you are too busy to play. Everything picks up where it left off beautifully!

I didn't really care one way or another what kind of game this was. I was just looking for a nice, free waste of time. Oh boy, did I ever get that and then some. How such a simple, game comsumed all of my free time (and some of my not-so-free time >< !) is beyond me.  Maybe its the stupid easy mechanics. Maybe its the totally true "Fallout" feel. Maybe its the fact that I got an insane happiness from ejecting people from my vault.  Well, whatever it is, it reeled me in hook, line and sinker.

Do I recommend this game?

Only if you have free time and free will. Otherwise, steer clear because it will CONSUME you =)

Enjoy!

I played Fallout 1&2 "back in the day". They were a nice blend of grit and crit with a nice dose of tongue in cheek cheese. Fallout Shelter passes on so much grit and focuses on more on the humor. It is resource management at heart with violence. What seperates it from most resource games is it has dungeons. Not super complex, as a matter of fact, Fallout Shelter is built around fun.
If your a "power gamer" who wants to test their skills versus super challenges, this may not be your cup of tea. However, it may be the "guilty lil pleasure" you enjoy on the side. Istarted playing it because my main computer is in need of repair and the system requirments aren't massive. Attacks on your shelter can be a little hectic; but, in general, it is fairly laided back, nothing the average 12 year old couldn't handle.
It does have one "adult theme". Especially early in the game, your Dwellers will probably need to have children. It is not graphic. Male in female in barracks, little chat, little dance and they go behind curtain. It is not the romance fest of Sims.
I have seen many negative reviews based on bugs. I haven't experienced any that affected game play. It is Free to Play with micro transactions. The purchases are not required. It is not "pay to win". You can earn everything for sale in game and it is not a grind fest to get them.
My last note on the game is that it can kind of follow many mobile games where you log in, do some stuff and don't need to do much for the next 8 hours, day or week. It has enough to do to keep your attention for straight play or set it and forget it for a while.
As far as the micro transations go, you can get all the stuff in game and many of them lose value after you are established. The one for someone who really wants to "rock and role" is the Nuka Cola. It speeds up times. They are great if you only have an hour to play or its "binge day". They can be earned in game.
Free is great. There is some stuff you can buy; but it is not required.

The game starts off interesting. But quickly loses value. 

The pros: The game is nice, not exactly a fallout game but its nice to be the overseer for once. In the early stages of a vault, you can fill up spaces rather quickly and you have to keep on it to harvest your resources. Staying on top of the game means logging in for at least an hour a day and playing his little game, which does keep you interested as it can be done while you do other things. Just keep it in windowed size and minimize when you need to focus on something else. You can build up to 30 dwellers in a few days without much effort and you can build rooms to train their attributes. The variety of junk, Weapons, armor, and incidents is entertaining at lower levels. 

The cons: After you have 35 dwellers, you usually have 1-3 Mr Handies. SO now you dont have to worry about havesting your resources constantly, they do it for you. by now you have an established breeding pair(s), a pair of dedicated door guards, many people working in the resource departments, a fair amount of storage space, and have successfully fended off mole rats, Rad Roaches, and raiders to the point you dont even look any more except to collect the loot when they die. You likely also have realized that armor is ornamental and you can train your dwellers in specific atributes to function as specific things regardless of what their base line is. 

By now you also know that you either go on quests constantly toget lunchboxes that often just overload your inventory with useless weapons and low grade armor (seriously. a rusty BB Gun does 0-1 damage and they are very common. you get one on every quest, even the higher level ones). Selling weapons becomes useless after a while because by the time you ahve 45 dwellers you hit the max caps because Bottle and Cappy come by 5 times or more in a single play run. Bottle drops Quantum rather often (usually betwen 1-5 every time you click his dancing animation. have gotten as high as 6 before), and Cappy drops a ton of caps every few seconds. WHen your vault reaches huge size, keeping up with them without zooming out is near impossible. And makes it hard to even click on them. At this point, forget finding the mysterious stranger when he pops up. Even if you have high end headphones and get directional pitch to the sound to guide you toward his general location, you wont get there fast enough to click on him. 

Crafting is utter bullshit, because to upgrade the crafting rooms you have to find recipes in the quests (i have found duplicates before. 3 of the sme gun from the same quest. that was irritating) and armor does nothing but make your character look pretty. It has no effect on combat stats at all. you need 75+ dwellers to upgrade the crafting stations to make Legenday Armorand weapons. unfortunately you also need levenday junk which is about as easy to obtain as proper medical treatment for cancer. 

Sending a wanderer into the wasteland is a great way to kill them. you cant reject ppl fast enough once you hit max dwellers because even with radio off, no breeders in the vault and you kicking 10ppl an hour you have a constant line of 10ppl waiting to get in. 

By the time you have 120 dwellers you have max res production to the point you need about 1% of what you make and one mr handy can harvest it all for you no issue. your dwellers are so strong they kill deathclaw attack at the door and your quests are the only reason you keep returning in the vain hope of scoring something unique and new. 

TO get pets, mr handy bots, etc you need to drop serious cash because just buying the specific crates will often generate the exact same ones as you already have with the sme abilities you no longer need. 




In short, this game becomes very boring and unplayable after 10 hours. Even restarting with a new vault you end up with the same issues because you know how it works now and hit that brick wall even faster. SO unless you play 3 min, once a week you should have 3 max vaults in under 9 days. its not even a time waster at this point its just a waste of time and effort to find enjoyment in the game.

Great game! It's free!

"Well".
"where do I start"?
It's a good game, "but",
it has some real flaws.
1. INCEST. unless you start writing down names for geneologies, you're going to either practice incest or polygamy or both in your vault. It's near impossible to keep track after 20 people.
2. MMO KIDNAPPING
you will spend "real-time" HOURS in this game, it will kidnap you with the threat of killing off your inhabitants while you're offline through neglect and abandonment. Not to mention the hours of TRAVEL TIME which can be offset by spending nuke cola but you'd need an unlimited supply of money or nuke cola for that.
3. GAME SAVE. You have the option of saving the game but it's kinda pointless because when you close the game without saving, it does an autosave that overwrites your saved game. That is to say, you don't have control over where the game is saved.
4. SPACE INDICATORS. When you're builiding, you're spending caps (currency) but you don't really know if it will fit or not (in the space availablle) because you're left guessing while eyeballing the size of the room.
On a number of occasions I have torn down rooms I JUST FINISHED BUILDING because of a slight misfitting, and lost all the invested money in the process. This doesn't even mention when I've gone for a redesign or rebuild where I've had to tear down "MAXED OUT" rooms. "booooo"
5. IN VAULT COMBAT. Yes I understand that the AI factors in "intelligence" and I'm happy for that, "BUT" I refuse to believe that dumb members of my vault would just sit in the middle of the room absorbing hits.
Not to mention that when they run around the room, it's sometimes hard to hit the stempack icon over their heads, causeing their deaths needlessly.

HAVING SAID THAT, the game has DEFINITE POTENTIAL and is overall "enjoyable" if not taxing.
I recommend the game but only just and would not pay for any version of this game in it's current state.
Very nice BETA though.

DO NOT play this game if you a diehard Fallout fan AND you own, or have access to, a credit card. This is the BEST GAME IN THE WORLD and you WILL convince yourself that just another 6 Quantums is harmless. 

On the plus side it inspired me to replay through 3, NV, and 4, and play 1 and 2 for the first time while I impatiently waited for my vault dwellers to do their thing. Playing these games kept my hands busy, preventing me from running my fingers back and forth across my credit card for hours, silently weighing the 2 minutes of fleeting yet gratifying pleasure provided by our favourite irradiated beverage against the ever-increasing interest charges I will inevitably incur sooner rather than later. 

So, 5 stars.

I recommend this with a strong caution. It is designed to drive you/your kids to the DLC. I am only recommending it because I've played 100+ hours w/o purchasing any DLC. I could play more, but I'm kinda burned out on it. It's fun but not difficult. It's purposely cumbersome and clunky w/o DLC. I'm not against the use of DLC. I am cautioning you that some parts of this game use "drug pusher" tactics to promote the sale of DLC. 

It should also be noted:
The gameplay perfectly demonstrates the principles of communism. Workers are placed according to ability and necessities are provided for. Education and population growth are controlled by the state. All production is state controlled and all produced goods are state property. 
[While it doesn't bother me, there exists a cultured paranoia about communism. As such, there are some to which this would be of concern.]

I started playing this game on my tablet.  It had glitches and was hard to manage when my vault got up to 200 people due to the small screen size.  I was excited when it came to steam.  With a bigger screen and using the mouse it is much easier to manage the vault.  There is one glitch that is annoying but doesn't break the game.  When you click on a dweller to select him, the game moves him to the room below.  It doesn't happen all the time.  I have not spent any money on the game and I have one vault with 60 bottles of nuke cola.  I love all the additions they keep making to the game, like the quests.  
You do need to have patience with the game.  It takes time to train and level up the dwellers.  So for me the game is pretty stable and playable.  Its a great way to take up some time.

After 11 hours of playtime I can honestly say that in the market of free to play resource management/tower builder games, Fallout Shelter definitely stands out. It has a unique art style, unique, quests, unique weapons and outifts, as well as unique dwellers. From one quest I earned 2 "people" called Bottle & Cappy. They randomly show up to the vault and reward caps or Nuka-Cola Quantum (The in game purchaseable or rare currency which can be used to skip quests, skip wait times, etc.)

Fun Game. Already spent 50 hrs on my vault. But it has the typical mobile gameplay, so you have to be patient and wait to get things or pay with real money to get what you want fast. It's ideal as a companion/idle game if you are playing the main Fallout series.

You can decide if you want to use 5 min or several hrs in this game, since it is a "semi turne based  game". A thumbs up for sure.

Very addictive, casual, game. Been playing it for a while on my phone, had no idea it was even on Steam until a friend advised me that it was easier on here then on the app. Either way, I really enjoy it, though the quests can get a little frustrating but that's likely more down to my poor planning then anything.
It's got a lot of resource management qualities, and it can be difficult to get enough caps to improve your shelter without going on quests or exploring the wasteland, but the game is certainly worth a playthrough. It plays like a Sims game sort of, where you need to manage the dwellers and their resources, think of the quests and wasteland exploration as jobs they need to to make money.
You can get directly involved in the quests as well, but not the exploration (which could be considered a bit bleh), but it is still a pretty decent game, and it's free!!

This game is neat to do on the side while multi-tasking, and the game looks like a cartoony Fallout game. The problems I have with this are sorted into three catergories.

For one, the animation is not so great. I do not have a problem with the cartoon-ish style or anything in that sort. The problem I have with the game is so noticeable that in the first minute of gameplay you might notice it. It seems like the animators did not even try a lot of times.

Second, the game seems very simple. I do not mean the game needs to be very complex. What I mean is, it seems like there is so little after getting to 90 people. I wish there was more there, like caravans that could visit you and you could buy item from them. Also, I found the defensive part of the game lacking too. I wish you could build something outside of the vault or have people stand there, or even nicer, robots.

My final problem with the game is what I have been trying to do for awhile, it is that this game lacks a workshop. I am not asking for cheat mods and weapons, I am asking for things like retextures, additions to the game, or fixes, like dead dwellers vanshing after a day, which frusterated me. If this is not posible, then I would really like to have an easier access to the image files because I have been searching for days for the files and all I found was code, left and right.

These are the things I wished were changed in this game which I think might make it more fun, but overall it is okay. I just wish it is was less boring and plain.

Once upon a time, I was playing multiple facebook games on a daily basis sometimes for hours. One was a farming game, an aquarium fish breeding game and another a Cafe running game. One day it suddenly dawned on me that in all of these games, I was doing the same things over and over and over with no end in sight, no real goals and ultimately no point . 
I would just build up my farm, aquarium or cafe to make money to build more, make more money, build more, ect...ect...ect..

Fallout shelter gives me the exact same feeling. It is a decent game I guess, can be somewhat addictive but there is ultimately no point to it. It's just a non productive waste of time. Ultimately I have decided to uninstall it. Maybe now I'll spend time on a game that has an actual point to it. Maybe I'll just read a book instead.

This game is mad awesome! At first, I didn't that it was only available for mobile devices, but when I saw that it was for PC for free finally, I had to download and play. This game is quite challenging in a way, but if you understand the concept well enough, anyone can progress with ease.

This game is a horrible phone port that is not optimized for the pc at all. 

Aside from that, the game really has nothing to it. You fill supply bars while adding more dwellers uses up more supply bars. Basically this game has nothing to it. It seems the devs made this game to eat at customer wallets, cause all the fun stuff is behind paywalls.

They give you 1 lunch box, which normally costs you $5... but it has ALL the equipment that makes the game interesting. Of course you can complete 1 of 3 tasks to hopefully get a new task that will grant you an additional lunch box. But still, they put the end game fancies in reach if you just open your wallet up, and I mean all the way up. You can spend real money on making this paint drying game go faster, on nuka colas. You can spend real money on buying a pet icon so that your scavenger returns faster. 

There are more things to blow your real money on, but not only are they way expensive for a tiny boost, the game just moves at a snail's pace.

Buy "cards" and maybe you'll find one... or maybe not.. maybe you'll just get resources...which..if you already have full storages of... won't give you anything... but hey.. we got money for it.

Don't want to gamble on maybe getting somethign and maybe not getting something? Buy something. 

People taking too long to show up so you can get the next room? Buy something


Why am I recommending it if this is my summary of the game?

Because it's free, and entertaining for those first few hours. As long as you have no intention of finishing it (or don't mind waiting LITERAL days befoe ONE THING happens... then waiting days again until somethign else happens...), it's a fine, fun, free game.

You are a Vault-Tec Overseer with no mischievous experiences to do, a pretty opened migration policy and a strong willingness to help every wastelander (Looks like someone cheated on his G.O.A.T.)
Congratulation, Three Dogs would be proud of you and your Karma-meter, you Messiah.

This review is of course for the PC version of [i]Bethesda[/i]'s & [i]Behaviour Interactive[/i]'s [u]Fallout Shelter[/u]. It originated as a mobile app which from its initial launch in June 2015 I enjoyed on my phone very much, up to a point. I remember being so excited to hear this announced at E3! The PC version works identically, which means some pros and cons in the transition from mobile to PC.

The way games are designed on one platform or another can reflect the nature of the platform and intended use of or vision for said games. [u]Fallout Shelter[/u] is one of those that just works better as a mobile app.

Ultimately it comes down to time gated activities and rewards. It's tough to sit down and play this for prolonged periods of time as a dedicated PC game. On my phone, it feels totally natural to fire it up, hit all my resources, queue missions and all that then close the game to check it later.

Now there's potential here for additions or improvements that bring the game more firmly into the PC space; I'm sure anyone who's tried it could brainstorm up a few ideas! My own run towards a more fleshed out questing system and deeper RPG elements. I'd also request a combat speed setting of some sort (on PC) so I don't have to sit through the plodding, drawn out fights during a mission. A little too slow as is.

I don't enjoy how certain events seem to be scripted. The specific example in mind is that some type of incident triggers shortly after game startup each new day (in game or real time, not sure). Early on these crises are simple, manageable. But they increase in magnitude as your vault grows. Presumably a bigger vault has more personnel with better weaponry to repel invaders, put out fires, etcetera.

At some point though, it's just a deathclaw raid each time! So tiresome since deathclaws take a little while to kill and really burn through stimpacks keeping vault dwellers standing. That lengthy, costly routine is the last thing I want to greet me every time I go to check on my vault. It quickly becomes off putting.

It's gratifying to see ongoing support for the game, including balancing along with all new content, quests, items, etc. Bravo. They've also embraced the trend of seasonal events and mini-holidays, although that seems mostly relegated to cash shop discounts. The cash shop offers various perks and upgraded versions of regular things that can't be obtained otherwise.

One noteworthy bug to warn you of: On rare occasion should the game crash, you may lose your save! Even if the files are still there. Regular manual backup of save files is the only sure way I've found to protect against this.

I'm giving a positive review since this replicates the fun of the mobile version. Just bear in mind it can't necessarily be played for hours on end like a conventional videogame; that should be apparent from the outset.

TIP: Frequently back up save files.
TIP: The help section is useful in that it explains some mechanics & info you couldn't learn by any other means.

It is an amazing little free to play game, addictive but not as stupidly addictive as clicker games ‚Ä¶ it at least has a point to it‚Ä¶ to some degree.
 
I really love this little free to play game, got lost in building the perfect vault and getting all the damn achievements !!! Side note, don‚Äôt go into this thinking you can get all the achievements, even after playing 42 hours I have 2 that I just simply can‚Äôt get and won‚Äôt get unless I play aloooooooooooot longer, all the other achievements are quite do-able but the last 2 that I couldn‚Äôt get would basically require me to start new savings and I‚Äôm not up for that.
 
Anyways!!! Back to the review, you don‚Äôt ever need to spend money in this game, it is really an optional thing in this game, you CAN spend money but it isn‚Äôt at all needed and I got through the game without ever needing to pay anything. And because of that, this game is even better.
 
I don‚Äôt know why I‚Äôm still rambling, a quick mention of what the game is about, imagine XCOMs base building but you build the base and manage the people in it, giving them the correct jobs, equipping them, sending them to the wasteland to get new items and eventually training your dwellers. It gets quite addictive at first and the implementation of Quests really added a lot of hours to the game for me and adds a nice little extra fun into the game.
 
And there we go, I cannot think of much more to say about Fallout Shelter, oh! It is a lot better than the Android port for me, after playing 20 hours or so the Android port started crashing after opening or just not working, I only encountered a problem with the Quests once on the PC version and it was sorted out with the latest update. So get this version if you want to play Fallout Shelter. 3.5/5!
 
PS it only gets 3.5/5 from me because it just lacks something, something small but I can‚Äôt place my finger on it, [url=store.steampowered.com/app/356040/Sheltered/]Sheltered[/url] is a lot better post-apocalyptic XCOM-ish base building game and because of how good that game is at what it does it overshadows Fallout Shelter a bit for me‚Ä¶ (This is just my opinion if you disagree then that is fine, the fact that Fallout Shelter has the theme of Fallout is really awesome and makes it an excellent game as well, and its art style is a lot better than Sheltered but for me, Sheltered was a better experience).

Pros:
-Addictive
-Oddly satisfying
-Not PAY to win (as long as you pay with real life time)
-Interesting process of upgrading your vault and MAXing your SPECIAL stats on your dwellers

Coins:
-Rad scorpions , raiders , deathclaws and ghouls attacking your base can be really annoying and can also make you feel like deleting the game , we all hope the game will change the cringy attacks.
-Getting more dwellers is a dead end if you rush it (take your time to upgrade your people and structures or else your entire VAULT can get wiped out in seconds)
-Rushing is kinda glitched  (the times I failed rushing on -20% FAIL chance are way too many , but it's only natural , the game is trying to teach us not to RUSH things , if you know what I mean)

Tips:
-Plan your vault (Don't just place random buildings)
-Check your dwellers and get rid of the useless ones
-Keep track on your resources , keep them above normal stat
-Don't go nuts blazing and impregnate all the women (Take your time to improve your SPECIAL stats first)
-Train your Endurance and Luck if you are to send dwellers to the WASTELAND , those stats helps a TON (Don't be a duck and give your people that you send to the WASTELAND more stimpack and radaway - this will keep them alive for a bit)
-Train your dwellers to 10 ENDURANCE and give them +7 heavy wasteland gear + train all of their other SPECIALs to 10 and send them to the WASTELAND after giving them a HIGH END weapon like MIRV (22-27 DMG AOE DMG) or Dragon's Maw (22-29 single target DMG) will help them become GODS , tbh you need 200 dwellers like this and the game would be broken (there won't be anything left to do , if you did completed all the quests (not the weekly and daily ones , cuz they are infinitive)  and you did all the room upgrades.
-Radscorpions comes at 50 dwellers and at 60 dwellers Deathclaws strike , so be smart and keep your people to 49 or 59 that really depends on the fact whether you are ready or not , good luck and may the radiation never be on your way ;) !

Horrible game, but it could be so good.  Here is how the game goes.
1. get resources stabilized
2. deal with random emergency (fire, roach infestation, mole-thing infestation, raiders)
3. use most of your resources to heal your people
4. run a mission
5. slowly growth your shelter
6. goto 1.

It wouldn't be so bad, but #2 in the list is so obviously deliberate attempt to stifle growth/attempt to have you buy a microtransaction.  It also wouldn't be bad if there was some type of AI that would deal with the current random emergeny.  For example if you have a fire in a room with no one in it, you have to manually drag a person to that room to fight the fire.  When he is done putting out the fire he will just stand there, even if the fire moved right next door, until you either move him again or all fires are put out.

Moving the people with a mouse is also very touchy/clunky at times.

In the time it took me to write this review, I had 2 'random' incidents occur; a massive fire and a massive mole-rat outbreak.  Just making some repetitive just to drain resources doesn't make for a challenge.  It just makes it grindy and boring.

Pretty good game to play in short sessions. Not enough going on to try playing for longer than an hour at a time.

I had started my vault with purchasing a booster pack and a couple extra lunch boxes. 100 dwellers later, I had everyone at 5+ SPECIAL stats, starting to gather legendaries, doing really well.

Game crashes after a mission. Local save files are deleted. Steam Cloud save files are deleted. No vaults showing up in game. No saves located on my computer, anywhere. Just lost the cash I spent on micro transactions (shoulda known better, but just wanted a boost), along with my time played.

Not worth starting over after just throwing some cash down the drain. Don't bother playing if you want a sense of accomplishment. If you just want to kill time and will be playing for free, can't hurt?

If you're a fan of Fallout, you'll enjoy this game, it's a light take on the Fallout world with you in charge of a vault all your own. There's several missions you can send your vault dwellers on, and eventually you can set a theme for several of your main rooms, and make your own weapons and armor for your vault dwellers. If one of your people happens to die on a mission, no worries, you can pay some caps and revive them, no problem. After about 20 hours or so you'll have enough caps and resources to do just about whatever you what to do in your vault. The only real issue honestly is keeping your men and women separate in barracks, because if you don't, well, expect another kid to pop out, which eventually can cause issues with overcrowding.
