It's a fun little free-to-play game. 
I've never played any fallout games, and when I saw this on steam I thought to give it a shot. If you can't figure it out from the ~80 hours I've spent with it, I actually do enjoy the game. Alot.

Sure it has the same "f2p" elements as they all: You can spend real money to get lunchboxes, Nuka Cola quantums, pets and Mr. Handy's. But I wouldn't say you are forced to do so. You'll find all of those from the quests (which are really funny and entertaining, the whole reason I've been playing so much) and from various tasks you complete. Quest's take various times; Some have 22 hour travel times, some have an hour and others are something between those two. With Nuka Cola you can speed up the travel times, but as I said, you don't necessarely need to actually buy them. You'll find some from the Wasteland (either quantums or from lunchboxes) and if you do the quest about saving Bottle and Cappy, you'll get those two coming for your vault multiple times a day and the other one gives you Nuka Cola when you click him while he waves his hand for you (I don't know does he give them more than once a day however).

Probably the only minus what I can think of now, is that the quest lines will eventually finish. I think I have three quests left and without quests the game gets really boring really fast. But I guess nothing good lasts forever.

I actually enjoy this game quite a bit, even though someone could easily argue that it probably doesn't have much depth to it (plot-wise). It's essentially an app. For that reason I wish Bethesda would do more with it, like find a way to make it multiplayer or make your steam game connect to your facebook and other systems so that you could have it on your phone and take your little vault with you wherever you go or perhaps share it with others (there is a version available for free in the appstore through Googleplay, but from what I understand, this is a separate file from Steam, so you would have to start over and make separate purchases, etc if you decided to do so).

Altogether I love this game, it's very casual, but it does require a little strategy and carries some modest entertainment and cute little quirks which are all what keep me coming back to it. I look forward to seeing what the devs decide to add to it.

This has to be, without a doubt the most frustratingly difficult game I have ever played and a waste of every hour I have invested in it. I started 7 different vaults and every one either ran out of power, or was littered with dead dwellers after multiple attacks by radroaches, radscorpions, mole rats, bandits, deathclaws etc. Every one became non-viable after hours and hours of building, exploration and allocating dweller X to room Y...rinse and repeat.
Considering it is a nucear fallout shelter, the the vault is far from impregnable, creatures just tunnel in and slaughter, while bandits can open the vault door with swords and .38 revolvers!! Resources are hard to come by; every cap is a prisoner because they want you to buy more in the store. As a "free to play" game it is impossible and, rather than spend money on more caps or 'starter packs' I simply uninstalled it. Someone needs to remind Bethesda that games need to be FUN as well as porfitable for the developer. I will not be playing this ever again because I'm liable to burst a blood vessel.

I am a HUGE fan of all of the Fallout series, even when they were beind developed by Interplay. With the release of Fallout 4,  my love for the series came back. So when I went on Steam and found this game, I was very excited, then dissapointed. 

I can sum this game up in two words that any professional gamer like myself would automatically stay away from: mobile port.

The game is a good concept: running and establishing your very own vault set right in the Fallout universe. But it lacks in many places, the biggest I think is keeping your interest in the game. There's been points where I just stare at the screen for (I kid you not) ten minutes straight without anything other than resource icons appearing. Not only is the game lacking in design, but like most other mobile games, there are the dreaded, microtransactions.

If the word "microtransactions" didn't set off some kind of warning, then nothing is stopping you from playing this game.

Besides the fact that there are microtransactions, they're used in the worst of ways. You can pay money for a couple things like Nuka-Cola quantum, which can be used (to my knowledge) to buy these weird lunch-box things. And guess what these lunch boxes have in them? Nuka-Cola quantum. Usually less than what you paid for the box itself. It's little things like this that just make this game unplayable for me, but I think that if this game went a little faster, more things happened, and the microtransaction were removes completely, I think it would be a decent game. Not a great one, but one that I would play if I was waiting for something or on a plane.

I really do love this game. It's addicting and it's a nice little cool down game between my long Fallout 4 plays. The dialgue is intertaining, the characters are cute. The quests are fun and I do enjoy the little surprises. It's a nice way to kill time if you're bumming out too. It's pretty well rounded.

Although I do have some complaints. Nothing too big to make me stop but enough to cause annoyance.

The lack of a pause button. I don't want to have to go to the main menu if I walk away to grab a snack or something.

The battle system is kind of clunky. I honestly thought it was broken when I'd drag the target to an enemy and not have my Dweller attack it right away, until I did an internet search and learned those with high agility can attack faster.

A pregnancy meter would be nice. I know pregnancies are 3-4 hours, but there are some that have been longer and I've been sitting around waiting for a Dweller to pop long past the 4 hour line.

Again these are just small things, not big enough for me to hate this game as the pros outweigh the cons, but if they're still applying updates to this game these would be nice additions/fixes.

Terrible game... With a game like this, it has to be intuitive and smooth - it is not.
I was enjoying it to some extrent until my first deathclaw attack (up until then it was just raiders). The deathclaws basically ripped through my base and killed everyone. I had my two best fighters stationed at the front door, but attackers never stay in the first room, they move from room to room, seemingly randomly. all you can do is try to drag you fighters to the room where the attackers are (and the attackers move to another room before your fighters kill them), or click on a vault dweller in the room and awkwardly scroll through your weapons to try and equip them with something useful, only to find they have already left that room! I play games for fun... These sort of game mechanics aren't fun or rewarding.  Why not just nominate two dwellers as your fighter/defenders and equip them with your best gear, and in the event or an attack, they follow the attackers around and defend accordingly. I could go on about the fighting mechanics but I won't. Do bathesda even play their own games?

Hoo boy. When they said that you were going to make your own fallout shelter and leave you in charge of maintaining it, I wasn't expecting it to be this hard! Every time you upgrade a room, it draws double, or even triple the amount of power that those power plants can provide, and then you have to build another one somewhere in the vault.  Then later in the game you're tasked with keeping your expedition alive while you go on quests.  Someone gets killed during the expedition and you don't have enough caps back at the vault? T-O-O BAD! I ain't dragging your dead ass back to the Vault!  Why can't this game let you use the caps that you earned DURING the espedition to revive them on the spot?  This game doesn't even spawn enough dwellers and my Vault is very stretched thin.  Can somebody say "understaffed?"  I finally set up a radio room and it's taking 2 damn hours to get anyone out in the Wasteand up here.  The only way to make more dwellers is to cohabitate a male and female Dweller and procreate.

I also hate how they go on coffee break after they return to the Vault after exploring the wasteland or coming back from the expedition.  The most nagging part was right after I put in the Overseer's office and the damn Fallout Boy tips guy would not go away!

I might have to remake my vault the way things are going, but the overall happiness of the vault is at 97% last time I checked and I don't want to start over.  Also, this is one of them "pay-to-win" games, so if you're the casual sport that hates waiting on a quest to get started by the three dwellers you sent out and you don't have any Nuka Cola Quantums, this game is definitely NOT for you.

This game is a great time killer, with lots of things to do like building your vault in a way where the elevators don't give you OCD and making your dweller's hairs multiple shades of the rainbow. The saving function has given me problems, though, so be careful with progress, its set some of my quests back pretty far (and they aren't quests you can do in a short amount of time).

As a whole Fallout Shelter is a great game, It's a few years old now and updates like quests and weapons/clothing factories have made it that bit deeper and more playable. I've got probably 100 hours both on Android and I'm not far off the same on Steam. I've enjoyed all these hours.

Pros:
- It's great to jump on for 5-30 minutes once or twice a day, do the quests, check how your dwellers are doing and just generally play around in the Fallout universe in a different way.
- It's free. Also more importantly the pay to win side isn't needed. I've got over 100 Nuka colour sat as I don't mind waiting to start quests or for dwellers to level up alone etc. There is plenty of content for a free game and you don't feel like you need to spend money.
- It runs well, the graphics have a nice feel and look good.

Cons:
- Using a mouse can be painful at times. I think it's because it was designed and out first on touch screen devices. The amount of dead dwellers I've had from not being able to click on the healing or the amount of times I've raged from not being able to drag a dweller. it's not a huge problem and doesn't affect the game long term, just frustrating!
- It gets predictable at times, I guarantee that I'll have a Death Claw attack within five minutes of getting in game every time without fail. Again nothing major but gets a little dull.
- Achievements. If you're an achievement hunter, don't bother unless you're worth millions or have years of time. I'll explain as it frustrated me greatly as an achievement hunter wanting perfect games.

- Get off my land - Survive 50 raider attacks. After 60 dwellers you mostly get everything apart from raiders. This ends up in starting a new game to try and get them more frequently. IMO it should be stop 100 vault attacks. This way as you progress and get Ghouls or Death Claws you can carry on getting the achievement.
- Blast from the past - Find 20 legendary dwellers. Don't bother... I've done my 200 ish hours on both devices and had five. I should be due a couple more from the last quests but that totals maybe five after 100 hours. It's basically a case of waiting for lucky lunch boxes. 

All in all the game is good, I've enjoyed my time on it and will log in once or twice a week for some time still. Maybe they'll update at some point and add more game time which would be nice. The bad points aren't huge and don't get in the way so I'd recommend this game.

I was willing to let the naughty nightwear issue go because, sure, women like them some sexy lingerie sometimes. What made me quit and uninstall is the fact that female characters cannot wear the mayor's outfit. It's 2017 folks. Stop telling people what they can and can't wear.

One of the best games of this genre I've played, with a *slurp pop* NOICE artstyle, kinda cute, it has a nice sense of humour to it and it's actually fun to manage the Vault. I remember playing it when it had just come out and I'd immediately been like GODDAMN IT WHERE ARE QUESTS, I WANNA GO OUTSIDE THE VAULT, I WANT MORE STUFF TO BUILD! MORE MORE MORE! And then I came back to it a while later and voila, it's all added. 

The Questing system is fun and rewarding, and it's actually satisfying to sustain your Vault and watch it slowly grow. There are a few bugs and sometimes the controls using a PC is a little annoying, however overall it's worth playing. If the Quest system was expanded further and there was more stuff to do upon completing a Vault etc however it'd be even SEXIER ;)

I think something went a bit screwy in the balancing in Survival mode.  I was chugging along great, my guys were having no problems with opponents, until I got to the boss on the final stage of the Bottle & Cappy quest.  I had 1 guy at full health, and 2 a little wounded.  Boss drops a grenade in the 3rd round and the fight is over.  Total wipe.

If I'd been struggling with opponents I'd be like, ok, boss is clearly more powerful and I was already outmatched.  But there was no warning.  My guys were 4+ levels above the minimum level for the quest.  They had cruised through 10 rooms already and used maybe 3 stimpaks total..and 1 guy was at full health.  I never saw a 1-shot total wipe coming.

Up until that it was kind of fun. But this game is just broken.  Glad I didn't spend money, since money wouldn't have solved this problem.

This game is horrible. 

It get old after a couple of hours, it's extreemly tempting to spend money getting past the "Startup", only to realize, that was the whole game. There is no "interesting" endgame. It's just an endless repeatable grind, for ..nothing. 
The whole game is set up to milk you for money at every angle. Most things can be bought. Infact, most good things have to be bought. 

The game makes NO sense. You can have the best of the best base defense, but still get whiped out by a single radscorpion invading a empty room, draining MASSIVE amounts power. Yeah, it didn't kill anything, it just drained all your power.

After a while, you'll realize you'll need to kill 75% of your dwellers, because they didn't have enough Endurance while they were leveing up, and now cannot survive lategame. But Endurance training is a lategame feature, so you really never had a choice. 

You'll get attacked by Deathclaws five times an hour, for no reward, what-so-ever. If you can't produce enough stimpacks, you're dead. Oh, and that vault door you maxed out, it falls within 10 seconds to anything that attacks it. How about a giant welcome mat. 

Oh, and you can spend $1000 and have your savegame go corrupt. Sucks to be you, start over. Refund, lol?

I'm sort of a fan of idle games myself, the thought of a game playing all by itself with you just stopping by to collect a couple of things is half decent for me, even if it seems like play-to-wait games nowadays are one of the many problems of the game industry.

Now, this game....Well, I'm looking at this from the eyes of a person who isn't really that savvy when it comes to Fallout, but who's got an interest in the setting of the series nonetheless. (So, I know little about the plot other than basic stuff and whatever I've seen in the games I have played so far.)

This game isn't all that bad. It starts slow and painful, and I do agree that the whole "Wait for shit to be done" hurts the pacing and the general enjoyment in this game. It would've been better if they fleshed out the combat and building aspects of this game, got rid of the sit n' wait, and made this a paid product. I'm totally up for that, the idea doesn't seem that bad. Being an idle game, this is one of those games that you play for 20 minutes - an hour or so each day, and then you just move on with your day, and that is kinda bad, there are times when I just want to do another quest or explore another place, and I realize I can't because I have to anywhere betwee 2 hours and a day for my dwellers to reach their destination....Or you can use the premium currency of the game, nuka-cola quantum. Yep, that's pretty much the hook, take it at a snails pace, or cough up some cash. And it hurts me that a fairly interesting game gets reduced to that. 

I wouldn't recommend spending money on this game, though; As far as I know, lunchbox/Mr Handy/Nuka Cola purchases only affect a single vault (AKA save file), and if you lose that vault, like for example, a bug (More of that later), or just a standard game over because all of your dwellers died, your money is gone with that save file. 

And even if you think you can handle it and you're 100% sure that you want to spend money in this game and that you aren't going to lose all your dwellers to some catastrophe, this game is still a bit buggy. It has never happened to me personally, but people have lost their files in the past, with all of their hard work deleted, and yep, that's right, even purchases. And even if you don't suffer from said dreaded vault removal bug, there are other bugs here and there, like losing the progress of your objectives, and that one has happened to me at least 10 times. From what I understand, the chances of your save file getting corrupted are reduced if you don't tab out of the game when it's loading your vault after a quest, and I've done my damn best to avoid disturbing my game while it's loading, and so far, my objectives haven't been fiddled with anymore. 

That being said, the combat in this game is a bit lacking, your dwellers attack automatically, and the only things you can control are who they are shooting at, how much damage your are going to inflict with a crit (When you get one), and when to use radaways/stimpacks, kill every enemy in the room, loot, move to the next one. Rinse and repeat. A 2-D Fallout game would work if combat was a bit more fleshed out, IMO. Now and then, you get to choose dialog options in a quest, but as far as I know, your choices rarely matter. In some cases, the enemies will/won't attack you based on your dialog choices, or might/might not give you an outfit/weapon or come with you, but other than that, there's not too much to it.  

The enemy selection in this game is still relatively small, you get radroaches, mole rats, radscorpions, feral ghouls, raiders, deathclaws, and that's about it. When you send a dweller to explore the wastelands (Basically, you just wait for hours and they will find goodies and deal with enemies, but it's only text based) they mention mirelurks, dogs, yao guai and super mutants, but they do not appear physically in the game. So, your worst nightmares are going to be the radscorpions, feral ghouls and deathclaws, and as far as I know, the first two aren't all that threatening in the main series. 

I personally like the artstyle, it's pretty much the retro style that you see in the trailer of Fallout 3, with your dwellers pretty much looking like Vault Boy. I like the visuals, and I think the Power Armor, as scary as it is in the main series, looks rather cute in a way in here. 

TL;DR 

It's a nice game if you like idling, it's one of those games where you check what your vault/dwellers are up to daily, and then you move on with your day. It's fun, I would give it a try, but I would recommend not spending money in this game yet. With its dreaded vault wipe bug, and purchases only applying to a single save file, it feels like you aren't getting much out of your cash. Plus, everything can be obtained in game, even if it's a bit grindy.
It's ok I guess.

Fallout Shelter is a time management game where you as the overseer trying to keep your happy dwellers alive. You can build rooms and join them together, assigning dwellers to do certain jobs or sent them out to explore the wasteland. Crafting items or doing quest requires a lot of time, but that's the whole point of time management games. The ingame timer is still ticking while you are not playing the game.

[h1]What I like:[/h1]
- It's free and not pay to win. You can easily complete the game without paying a cent.
- It does not requires a lot of your time. You can run it on your background & do other stuff.
- The 2D art is refreshing and cute.
- You can farm nuka cola and speed up the timer.
- Everything is obtainable without the need to pay real money.
- Interesting combat system while doing quest.

[h1]What I hate:[/h1]
- One achievement is almost impossible to unlock unless you cheat. I only got 4/20 process while having over 150 hours of playtime. That's just a bad gamedesign choice imo. No one will be that crazy to keep playing for so long after completed the game without any new content.

A solid well done and simple game really no reason not to try it.

This is simply resource management and a very simple take on it at that, you have food, water and power, build rooms which produce these, populate with people who consume 2 out of 3 of these and of course the rooms them selves consume the 3rd resource.

You can also do a lot of little fun time sink things, collecting and crafting weapons and cloths, these help with the occasional raid on your vault or other little misshaps, you can even send a group of 3 on quests from the overseers office where you lead your group of 3 through a series of rooms looking for some item, person or just to kill a bunch of things.

Keep in mind the game is 100% a time sink, there is no epic story, no multiple ways to play or anything groundbreaking hidden here. Its a very basic resource management game ported over from mobil with tons of great polish and presentation set in the Fallout universe.

Somewhat interesting game. It's fun for couple days and probably even longer, since it requires only about 1 hour of attention every other day. However, all negative things that I have faced, drives me away from it. I can't enjoy it as much as I would like to.

The game uses real life time to progress, meaning that scavenging trip out in the wastelands literally takes hours of real time. There is no speeding it. You put your vault dwellers do tasks and close the game. After couple hours or days, you open the game again and see the progress. There are some events that fire only when the game is running.

Pros:
[list]
[*]Tasks takes real time hours to complete. It's nice to close and forget the game and tomorrow return to it and see the progress.

[*]Quests and stories are nice.

[*]Lots of references to events in Fallout 4 (duh).

[*]Micro-management is light.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]Combat takes forever. Now I know that this is port from mobile game, but seriously speed up the combat!

[*]Horrible UI. Again, I know that this is from mobile game, but god damn this UI and forced camera. It frustrates me. Animations takes forever to finish and cannot be skipped.

[*]Gets repetive quickly.

[*]While dragging camera around your vault, you keep picking dwellers accidentally up and replacing them to wrong rooms.

[*]Raid events cannot be resisted at all. They will beat that 50-ton door down with a fire-axe and harm your dwellers. Use security? What security? Only thing that you can do is to equipt weapons to dwellers (I'm okay with this), but I wish for dedicated security that can HOLD the attack at the front door.

[*]Quest requirements are stupid. They should recommend level and equipment.

[*]A veteran BOS officier, who happens to become pregnant, loses her skills and willpower to fight a threat? Sure..
[/list]

Being a fan of Fallout 4, I did not bother trying out this free-to-play game.
As the overseer of your own personal vault, you have the possibility to do a lot of things, such as customizing your vault as you like to.
On top of that, although the game does not have a price, you can do/achieve everything without needing to spend any real money on the game.
Very good.

I did not experience the save bug people are ranting about and I firmly believe that anyone who spends money on this kind of games needs professional help.

But what makes me give thumbs down is the zero variety, non-existence of late game content and the click-on-something-every-5-seconds management. It's enjoyable for a while but at some point you just snap and realise it just stopped being fun.

Legendary, rare and common equipment work 90% the same. The neghbouring tiers differ 20% in performance but 500% in price and crafting time. This is the bait for all the morons spending money on this shit.
There are several types of weapons. Long story short, they have different visuals and damage but that's where variety ends.
Quests = walk through a set of random rooms, go home.
Quest dialogue choices = 3 categories: 1. fight/not fight, 2. get item/nothing, 3. doesnt matter altogether.
5 or so types of enemies total. Not like they really differ in any way to begin with.
Quest combat mechanics = health potion + choose target + use crit when it appears (or save it for later).
Vault defence combat mechanics = normal things you can do with your vault out of combat - 90% of them because its combat.
Wasteland exploration = stock up a dweller on health potions, let random events happen to them and let them die (look it up, that is actually how it's done).
And vault management? At some point, it stops being an idle clicker and becomes just... clicker. If you don't babysit every single level-up, production success, crafting finish, critical event and raid, you begin to stall. This would be okay if it wasn't happening every 5 seconds.
I started playing because it was something to do during working on other stuff. I stopped playing because it stopped being that and instead turned into a failed abortion.

I wonder what else they might add later.  Even if they don't add anything else, this is still a great game. Plus, you cant't beat the price of free.

I had heard of the Fallout game but never had a chance to play any untill about six months ago when a friend gave me his copy of Fallout 3 for PC. I played it, finished it and loved it. Now I've finished it about 8 or nine times and still I play it more. when I discovered Fallout Shelter I thought it must be good and fun... I was right!

Instead of being the one who goes out and saves the land, you are the Overseer(GOD) and you controle the people's fate in your vault! Set them to work, breed them, cloth them, arm them, send them out to explore or send a team out on a mission. After viewing just a few videos online for tips from other gamers about better layouts for your Vault rooms and population and training the poeple inside, my vault progressed like crazy but I'm not done yet perfecting my ideal underground Utopia!

So if your a Fallout fan I deffinitly recommend this game for you!

But the few negetive things about the shelter....

1 Themes : When I was able to fabricate my first theme for the dinners I thought this will be great because there are four(4) themes for the dinners and four(4) for the living quartes. So a made sure to have four(4) of both ready so I could decorate the way I wanted and that was to have a dinner and living space each dedicated to a theme so that I could have them all visible at the same time and on display for the fun of it but when I activated my first theme for a dinner it changed all my dinners to the same theme... BORRING so I have put off making the other themes because if I can't decorate the way I want MY VAULT to look them why bother! I will eventually complete all the themes but only for the achievment then I will convert them all back to the default theme.

2 Miss-clicking : When bottle and cappy show up (after you complete the mission to rescue them of course), they split up and wonder your vault. The problem here is that when you pass your curser of a dweller they light up with a green outline around them but not bottle and cappy. It has happened many times that I could not collect from either bottle or cappy and what happened was the camera zooming in or out of the room their in, which changes the view and position of your mouse and yet my curser was directly on them and the end result was missing out on some much needed caps or nuka-cola quantums. That was very frutrating and it still is frustrating. I feel the developers should fix this so that when you do find them they should have an outline around them to confirm there are no miss-clickings. Also I had a vault dweller training in a room and I had finally saved up enough Quantums to speed up his training. To speed up his training you need to double click the room their in and click the nuka-cola quantum bottle for that dweller... here's the problem, two(2) dwellers side by side and their bottle images overlapped and the wrong dweller got boosted....MAJOR PISS-OFF RIGHT THERE. when you boost a dweller with your nuka-cola quantums a window pops up and asks confirmation " Are you sure you want to boost this dweller with X number of quantums?" it does not give the dwellers name for a more accurate confirmation another issue the developers need to address I believe.

Aside from these issues that I have a frustrating problem with, it is a fun game and yes I will continue to play  and yes I recommend it to anyone who has played any of the Fallout games even other people who haven't. it's a good way to relax at the end of the day or a good start to a gamers day.
I'd rather play Minecraft with 8 year old kids who cry over people stealing their dirt.

God I've sunk so many hours of my life into this game on mobile. I remember watching the Bethesda E3 conference in 2015 when this was announced and being overly excited because Todd Howard had said Fallout Shelter was coming out that night, then actually had to wait a fair few months because he forgot to mention that is was Apple Store only apart from Google Play. 
When I finally got to play on launch, I was instantly hooked with no surprise, I adore both Fallout and management games so this was an instant addiction to me. I have been playing ever since it launched on Android and I've loved every minute of it.
Surprisingly Todd did not lie about this game during the conference, there are no paywalls if you want to build a facility it's instantly built, you will get caps and lunchboxes rewarded to you in fair amounts for completing quests and sending your dwellers out into the wasteland etc. (You can buy more lunchboxes if you choose too but it's never shoved down your throat),
I did not mind starting a new vault because it's no secret I love this game and I am willing to put more hours in on PC.

Fun, cute little graphics with a familiar Fallout theme. A slight ‚ÄúTiny Tower‚Äù type of dweller management and room upgrades. An addition of quests, funny dialogue and sometimes difficult missions makes this game pretty dang enjoyable.
I played this game as long as I did only to complete all achievements‚Ä¶ With that being said, I'm going to help you get them all.

Note: There is ‚Äúalmost‚Äù no way you can earn all 35 achievements without paying (or cheating). I was able to get 34/35 by with some patience and allowing the game timer to run overnight and during the day. 
I‚Äôm only listing a few of the non-obvious achievements, or, some difficult ones with tips that might help you get them a bit faster. Keep in mind to check your vault in the morning and at night. Should take several weeks to complete them all.

QUEST ACHIEVEMENTS:
---Big Pharma (Collect 100 stimpacks‚Ä¶)
---Decorator (Collect all pieces of 4 themes)
---Survivalist (Complete 60 quests)
The key with these is to constantly have dwellers on 3 quests at a time.

TIME-CONSUMING ACHIEVEMENTS:
---Fashion Statement (Collect 20 legendary outfits)
---Armed and Dangerous (Collect 20 Legendary weapons)
---Interior Designer (Craft 1 of every room theme)
With these, keep x1 outfit and x1 weapon being made at all times. They must be legendary and keep in mind what type of SPECIAL is needed to make it go faster (This depends on what you are making.) Also keep the crafting room themes going at all times as well.

THE TWO HARDEST ACHIEVEMENTS:
---Get off my lawn (Stop 50 raider attacks)
The reason I‚Äôm stating this as a hard achievement is because if you progress too fast, raider attacks become very few and far between; Raider attacks depends on the quantity of dwellers you have. 
1-39 dwellers = Raider attacks. 
40-79 dwellers = Raider, Ghoul attacks. 
80+ Dwellers = Raider, Ghoul and Deathclaw attacks.
With this being said; 70+ hours in, I stayed steady at about 190 dwellers and completed all but the Blast from the Past and Get off my lawn. I was at 37/50 attacks and I was only getting attacked by Deathclaws. I saved my game, made a backup and evicted all but 39 dwellers. I got attacked by Raiders 3 times within an hour. (changed the game to Windows mode swapped from Chrome to the game every 10 min) A pain I know ‚Äì but I recommend staying around 30 dwellers until you get about 40 Raider attacks, then I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll get them all later

---Blast from the Past (Collect 20 Legendary Dwellers)*
OK, honesty time here. At about 75 hours in; I was about to give up hope. I had two achievements left, Get off my lawn and this one. Also, at this point, I didn‚Äôt spend a dime on the game. I researched how to get legendary dwellers and, besides earning 1 or 2 from quests, you can get them ALL from lunch boxes. So I thought to myself ‚ÄúSelf, you threw down 75 hours of free play, buy a few lunch boxes‚Äù ‚Äì However, $5-$10 bucks doesn‚Äôt get you much, and what lunch boxes it got me‚Ä¶ didn‚Äôt help. So I ‚Äúobtained‚Äù a save file with 9999 lunch boxes and went to town opening- with  9999 lunch boxes, clicking to open them for several hours and BAM, 485 lunch boxes later, I got the achievement. So this means: (from my own experience)

485 / 20 = approx. 0.04% drop rate per box
485 * 5 = 2,425 cards (there are 5 cards per lunch box)
2425 / 20 = approx. 0.008% drop rate per card

The reason I‚Äôm saying all this is because if you plan on buying lunch boxes just for this achievement, then you may want to rethink it. I also feel cheap ‚Äúcheating‚Äù to earn achievements, but shit, Bethesda has earned enough of my money over the years. They can take one for the team; I sure the hell did with Fallout 4

I've been playing this game since the time it was released on Android and this is the only RPG simulation game i'm still playing. The concept of this game is one of its kind. It requires a lot of mental planning on how to make your dwellers survive attacks and where to spend Caps (the currency in this game). You can not buy Caps with real currency so buying Lunchboxes with real currency is probably a waste of money. You don't need to worry about Caps if you keep your Dwellers happy and strong (which is also the main goal of this game). The game is extremely slow paced and rushing your vault can lead to Ragequit and kind of depression (LOL). Also the game doesn't have an end or there is no specific ending. You can always start survival mode which is more challenging.

I've seen people playing this game on Steam have problem where their save files have been deleted and there is no way to recover their precious vaults. There is no Cloud Save on steam. I have more than 100 hours on Android and would love to play this game on my PC which has more achievements but I can't because of no Cloud Sync between platforms and I think lot of Fallout Shelter players would want this feature. 

Overall a great experience and a must play! Enjoy!

I can't recommend this games for one reason only.  I love all of the Fallout games.  I really like Fallout Shelter with the ability to level up my people and train them.  However, I am actually thinking of quitting this game for one simple reason...  "Radscorpion Attacks".  I have 83 people in my vault who are well armed, but one Radscorpion goes from room to room, steals all of my energy (which I had a TON extra built up), kills multiple people, seriously injures a dozen more, goes to random rooms, and is almost magically impossible to beat.  The Radscorpion attack is absolutely ridiculous and needs to be removed or greatly reduced.  These scorpion attacks make me want to quit because they destroy so much of your hard work that it's just not fun.  One scorpion attack kills way too many people, uses almost all of my radaway/stimpacks, steals pretty much all of my resources, and makes it just not fun anymore.  I've had them maybe 5 times and every time they basically destroy half my base and it takes forever to try to recover.  If it wasn't for these attacks, it would be a pretty darn good game that I would recommend.

Best free game out there I think, massively addictive, here's a few tips from my experience with the game

You don't need to buy the lunchbox's or bottles you can get them on quests and even more bottles later from bottle when he visits with cappy.

Post some guards with good weapons at the vault door.

If you build a radio room, even if it's for the achievement of build one of every room, don't set it to broadcast to the wastelands it just attracts more DeathClaws and out weighs the rubbish people it attracts.

When you send people out on long quests do it before you exit the game, the time counts even when your not playing.

The easiest way to lift the happiness score of anyone is to send them of for some sex, instant 100% happiness for the grumpy git.

Have fun, I'm sure you'll find loads of other tips as you play.

I've always detested Bethesda games because they're poorly made.  However, I end up playing them all because of the mod community - they fix all the little bugs and make the experience much more entertaining.  I should have realized that this play-on-the-toilet game was something to avoid because it's not available to be modded.  There is no game I've sweared at more than this, and I've been gaming for a few decades now.  The unwarranted zooming in, the incessant lag (like it needs all the processing power of all existing computers), and the frustating interface.

Once you expand enough, you can't fit your shelter into one screen.  That's not that bad, but when you want to scroll up or down, you almost always click some dweller and move them to another room and that makes something from that room leave.  But wait, maybe click outside the vault to make sure you're not selecting a dweller?  Nope, because now you bring up the display of dwellers outside and have to wait for the animations to load so you can close it.

On top of that, the mouse is not aligned to the rooms you want to drag someone.  You need to try and see it as the silhouette of the dweller, not the cursor.  Otherwise, you're moving dwellers to other rooms or letting dwellers die because the help your sent are picking their noses above the room you actually wanted to send them to.

Combat is a pain.  You characters stand there and get smacked, then play musical chairs as they cross the room to get smacked on the other side of it, and shoot once every 15 seconds, while the enemies seem to attack more often.  Dwellers that just walk around unassigned could give two s**ts about what's happening in that room to help out with combat.

Seems like all outfits work for all males but not for all females.  So that's nice.

Want to do some renovations?  Nope. Even though a neighbouring room is connected to a room and an escalator, you can't remove it.  You'll need to demolish the neighbouring room and THEN the room you actually want to remove.  So that's doubles your cost.  Lovely.

Want to make sure your vault's resources are being collected while you're doing a quest?  Too bad.  Long quests, you'll come finish it to see your resources are in the red.

Storage rooms and living quarters.  Zero point to have them except for increasing your capacity for people and resources.  Empty rooms are always targets for attacks from inside.  But you don't want to put anyone there because you'll impregnate someone and never get XP just to eliminate some threats.  What a nice balance if being a perfectly needed waste.

They say crazy is doing something over and over and expecting something different to happen.  I think I need to unistall this game once and for all before I actually end up in a padded wall.

Terrible F2P money grab.

You literally sit and wait for shiny things to pop on your screen so you can click on them. Most of the time there is nothing you can do to progress in the game (except pay money to get free stuff).

The game doesn't tell you about important bonuses and limitations so you end up building your base in a clearly unoptimal manner at the start and then you don't have the ability to fix your issues anymore as it's too costly.

The game seems to provide very little in terms of engaging content, it's simply you waiting for things to happen for minutes at a time.

Just get something actually good of the genre instead of this. Try e.g. This War of Mine, Sheltered, Oxygen Not Included, Project Highrise, and the many others out there and you will probably have a better time.

Really really fun game. Its Micromanagement to a whole new level, sprinkled with a little Fallout spice. Fallout Shelter puts you in the position of an Overseer controlling your very own vault. To me, its a very awesome experience. Even I introduced this to my friends and they all enjoyed it. The rewards system is great, the loot system is great. And also, learn to have self-control. You can play this game and have fun with it without spending a dime on it. Even I didnt spend money, and i still had fun, had some good loot and enjoying the Fallout Shelter experience.

You are the overseer of your very own vualt, now do your best to help it grow and keep your people happy and...... alive. :D

The game can be very frustrating at times but its very rewarding when things go well for your vualt.  Patience is key.

Nice looking game, good sounds and music etc.  I give it a 7/10.

Game developers are sadists. This is proof. The game is too hard and you waste your time collecting resources instead of building.

I lost 5 people from a radroach invasion. An unnaceptable loss in this game because if you lose that many then you can never recover. You might spend 24 hours recovering from that kind of loss but then you'll have the chance of losing even more and I'm not going to waste my entire life on this fucking stupidly designed game. This game goes at a snails pace.

Sure it has great graphics, great mechanics and great items. But it all takes too long to get those items. You might spend a week entirely focused on this game and get nowhere.

Also the game severely restricts the amount of people that are coming into your vault so you can never grow your vault at any speed at all. It does this in various ways. it not only stops completely the influx of new people into your vault after you make a new vault but it also gives you stiff penalties towards trying to create more people through reproductive means by having such incredibly long waiting periods between conception and birth and then adulthood.

The game goes far too slowly. I was hoping that it would be something like Sim Tower but it is not and it is a painful game to endure. Its not worth my time and concentration.

You also need to be focused on the game nearly all of the time, you would be able to watch a movie but then you'll get distracted and if you don't pay enough attention your people get killed off by some raiders or a radroach invasion.

Too much of a time waster. If you waste 8 hours of gameplay per day on this single game then you are an idiot that is throwing his life away.

The game developers are money hungry fuckwits that want you to perpetually buy in game content and you need that in game content to get anywhere.
Too simplistic and boring. I think it's mostly made for children below 9 years of age.

A free game is a free game, but you often get what you pay for. 

A lot of the game's design choices are about grabbing more of your time, and it offers to exchange your time for your real life money.

There are F2P games that are more fun and aren't as aggressively trying to take your money.

Also, the game runs when your not playing it, so unless you plan on playing it daily you're going to come back to a vault in dissarray.

I am telling you now: if your like me and had only played the crappy mobile version THIS VERSION IS 100X BETTER!!! It has everything the mobile version has except that it runs better and doesn't crash! I love it!

This game is a good game. But there is one key reason why I cannot recommend it. 

The bugs. Mainly the game breaking bugs that take away all of your progress. I have encountered a few where my Objective Progress would be inexplicably erased. 

But most importantly, twice now I have encountered a bug where the game would crash, and all of my data would just be erased. I lost the 4.99$ I spent on it and nearly a week of progress. 

If Steam refunds me my 4.99 I have spent twice, then I will give the game a recommendation. 

Cause its a fun game. I really do enjoy it, and I want to recommend it. But the fact that the game can crash and all of your data goes away... 

It is why I cannot recommend this game.

Fallout Shelter
Mh what can I say about this.. I had this game on my Mobilephone, on my Tablet and now on Steam on my Pc and Laptop.
I've allways loved this game it sure is timeconsuming but its such a nice game to get time over with, and it had the Fallout feeling I adore.
I heard about this game first before Fallout 4 came out and I was like.. I wanna have it, so I tried it. I was really far in the game suddendly my game kinda lost all its progress and I never touched it again since I've spent so much time to get that far so I was like mh F*** it and I left it there to dust.
Suddendly I heard: "Fallout Shelter ready for Windows 10 gamestore!" I didnt think much about to get it but I wanted to try it and suddendly there comes Steam, I was online roaming around doing some things and then I see a friend of mine playing "Fallout Shelter".. at that point it was clear, I NEED IT AGAIN! and thats what I did and still play now.
Its a free game where you CAN spend money in, or youll just take the time and wait its not like you cant wait for something to finish in 4h, you dont need to buy Nuka Cola Quantum in the game because you can get them normaly in the game.
I love all games of the Fallout Series and even this simple one is great, so its a 10/10 for me but you should plan lots of time in this game like in all Fallout Games.
In the meanwhile when you "wait" just open the game later again and it should be done I open it in the morning and once in the evening thats more than enough. 
(Also you should know some about the Fallout history to understand certain questions which will be in the game but pshhht)

I started playing this because I was under the mistaken assumption it provided unlocks in Fallout 4. It does not, if you have the same misconception.

So, why the negative review? And the answer is that the game uses tedium and enforced grinding as a gameplay mechanic, and it doesn't have to.

The game concept itself is novel enough, and if you like the Fallout universe, it's pretty cute. It's simple, but it was meant for mobile devices, so that makes sense. Build a vault, manage your settlers, fight baddies for loot, rinse, wash and repeat. All of that is just well and dandy.

The problem arises from the fact that there's basically no ai, and everything is AGONIZINGLY manual. Resources got produced? Gather those suckers manually. Loot got found? Gather that stuff manually. Danger at the vault? Manually tell people to go help. And then go to the next room when the danger spreads, rather than remember why they were sent. Ready to give birth? Not until the Overseer delivers your kid themself. It goes on and on.

It's micromanagement without depth, which means that it's just a chore, at the end of the day. Well, that and waiting. The combat system is 95% waiting, and not whilst the app/game is closed; sit there, and watch healthbars slowly fall, hoping you'll get a crit and somethingf to do.

And then they hit you with the paid content to make things quicker, easier, and more automated. You literally pay to play less, and be bothered less. Nothing against paid content, they have a right to make money from their work. But paid content should give you more of the game, not less of the annoyance. Top tier weapons? Just less waiting in combat. 

You can  bypass the whole process by not playing it at all.

If the hours I've clocked up don't tell a story, then hopefully this review will. Actually I highly suspect the hours I‚Äôve put into this game say less about FS itself, than it does about me. At least this recent addiction seems a lot less harmless then spending time at the Pokies or a Casino, though I do think FS uses some of the same cues to draw the players in, sounds, colour and constant feedback loops.  I originally played the Android version and whilst designed as a mobile game, I found the screen size to be an issue, especially on a phone, though also on a tablet once your vault reaches a certain size. This was also a problem when selecting vault dwellers on the touch screen and led to much frustration accidently dragging dwellers between rooms. Thankfully not really an issue with the Steam version
. 
If you have played this on mobile then it's more of the same, just easier to navigate. The gameplay is pretty uncomplicated. You will be spending most of your time playing a lite resource management sim with some RPG elements. Different rooms you build provide resources such as the cafeteria, food, or nuclear reactor, power.  Each room can be upgraded and must be manned by vault dwellers. Each room type is also based around fallout SPECIAL stats such as Strength for power or Charisma for the radio room. Assigning dwellers with high points in the respective stat for each room decreases output time and lessens the chance of a catastrophic event such as a fire in that room.

Aside from the vault and dwellers management you can send dwellers out to the wasteland to collect Caps or junk, weapons, armour etc. Junk is used for crafting ever better items including some which requires you find the recipe first. Dwellers can also be sent on quests. A party of up to 3 can go on adventures allocated through the ‚ÄúOverseers Office‚Äù finding ever more loot and gaining experience points to level up. As this is a free game there are time constraints applied to everything. As an example it may take you up to an entire 24 hours (real life time baby) to reach a quest location. Nuka cola can be used to skip these restraints, though these are scarce. Nuka cola can sometimes be earned as quest rewards or once Bottle and Cappy are unlocked via one of the aforementioned quests trees, randomly provided during visits from the duo to the vault.

 Of course you can also purchase Nuka using your real life money if you desire and don't have the patience to wait for the meagre supply in game. Your hard earned can also be spent on things like Lunchboxes (another scarcity in game) that give out random items from Caps to Legendary Dwellers.

 By no means are you required to do so to win, it's really up to you if you want to line Bethesda's pockets further or not. I did indulge in a few lunchboxes and Nuka Cola bottles early on to speed things up, but now that I have a vault nearing the maximum amount of dwellers allowed, I have found through a combination of visits from Bottle and Cappy and from questing that I have a near constant supply of both Nuka bottles and everything else.

 As far as free game's go this is not a bad little game, if a somewhat casual in gameplay as one would expect from an experience built for mobile gaming. Still there is plenty of fun and some depth to be found so I recommend it, especially to fans of Fallout.
So far so good! I've played 12 hours or so of it. It's fun to do on your spare time, haha. I'd recommend this to those who like this type of games.

+ + + BACKUP YOUR SAVEGAME + + +

If you don't do this, you are liable to lose your progress, and with it any purchases you've made. They will not apply to your next new game.

https://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Fallout_Shelter#Save_game_data_location
https://archive.is/OIEcf

1. On a PC, open File Explorer and find the Users folder in the root directory. Now pick the folder with your username and then Appdata and Local. (As an alternative, just enter %LOCALAPPDATA% in the address bar.)

2. In that Local folder, find FalloutShelter, and alt+click drag it to c:\games or the desktop (wherever you like) so you have a handy shortcut next time.

3. Now ctrl+click drag the FalloutShelter folder to an empty spot in the panel you're in, or to where it says Local in the address bar above. Windows will automatically number your new copy so it doesn't overwrite your previous backup.

4. If you don't want incremental backups cluttering things up, make a folder called FalloutShelterBackup, ctrl+click drag the FalloutShelter folder there instead, and confirm the overwrite.

5. Double check to be sure you haven't accidentally moved the savegame folder instead of copying it.

Since this is a recommendation, I'll note that the game is better than it looks. What starts out with the appearance of timer & boost sleaze eventually gains momentum and offers plenty of actual gameplay. Most of this is a Tiny Tower style job optimization exercise, made more interesting with buffs granted by gear and the fact that the characters level up. It's ruined a little by lack of a good overview for juggling gear, but that's an artifact of the mobile format and forgivable since this is mostly a very good port.

This game is quite addictive!

Your mission is to be a vault overseer - this means that you have to keep the people inside (vault dwellers) safe from raiders, radscorpions, ghoulers, etc. You also have to make sure you have enough resources, such as power, water and food.

By assigning a male and a female inside a living room/barrack, you can reproduce popularity inside your vault until you hit the maximum capacity, which is 200 dwellers.

Alongside this, you have to assign the correct dwellers to the correct room by looking at what stat the room acquires and what the dweller has, this is called S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats.

S = Strength // Power generators and nuclear reactors
P = Perception // Water treatment and water purification
E = Endurance // Nuka-Cola bottler (makes both food and water)
C = Charisma // Radio studios and living quarters (radio studios make people in the wasteland know about your vault)
I = Intelligence // Medbay and science labs (these makes "Stimpaks" and "RadAway" )
A = Agility // Diner and garden (these produce food)
L = Luck // Increases chances of rush attempts succeeding

Having the correct S.P.E.C.I.A.L stat dwellers in the correct rooms makes the room finish producing resources faster.

You can also, when getting the command center, go out in the wasteland and do various missions which also gives you some items like bottlecaps or wasteland junk which you can make clothes or weapons out of.

[b]SPOILER ALERT[/b]:
[spoiler]There's also a "mystery guy" which appears when you hear the piano sound playing, he will be hiding in random locations inside your vault for about 10 seconds, if you click on him you will get a random amount of bottlecaps. Try to navigate towards the sound as it is a hint of where he is.

[url=http://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/cf896781d49b9368a878696008ef5aa0.jpg]He looks like this. (CLICK ME)[/url]
[/spoiler]

Resources will slightly be used when you exit the game, pregnant women will start giving birth after around 3 hours, even if you're away. Kids will use plentyfull of resources until grown up, so if you do not have plentyfull of living areas or resources, you'll have quite a bit of problem. You can also not drag them into a room of your choice, they will roam around your vault as they see fit.

Also, some quick tips: Do not randomly place the rooms, if you have 3 rooms right next to each other, they will merge and produce more and can store more resources, 3 is the maximum merge limit. Also, if you upgrade one room, you might not be able to merge another room to it. And you should only upgrade rooms when they are merged together, it's cheaper. You should also equip all your dwellers with weapons, so they can defend themselves if neccessary. You should upgrade your vault door and assign 2 dwellers with heavy armor and the best guns in the vault entrance.

So I saw a lot of negative reviews on the game and I do understand where they're coming from. 
BUT, to be fair this is originally a mobile game and most of the problems that are pointend out come from the fact that it is a MOBILE GAME...

To get straight to the point do I recommend?

Hell Yeah! If your a fallout fan and hungry for some extra fallout content definately go for it. Its even FREE.

And really by all means try it out cause its not a bad game at all. If you've played mobile games before you'll aprreciate that it is one of the gems in a shit storm that is the google play store...


For a more detailed overview, here are the Pros & Cons

Pros
-Its Fallout
-Decent vault managing content.
-Nicley polished Fallout style graphics.
-Lots of loot and equipment.
-Not a pay to win.

Cons 
-Quest lines can become repetitive quick.
-No strong story line or dialogues treading in grey areas.
-Difficulty drops pretty fast.
-Can take long to perform upgrades or crafting.

Now with all of the above being said...I'd like to point out that some of the Cons are quite inevitable for a mobile game.

"-No strong story line or decision making dialouge"
For this I have to say I do agree that life or death deciding moral decisions will spice up the game a lot.
BUT, you have to take into account that this is F2P. People spend cash to get there rare equipment or dwellers.
Imagine the shit storm the devs will have to go through confronting angry players who had there cash items disappear to an ingame event... 
(The main Fallout games can give you difficulat decisions cause you have a savegame to fall back too. Plus if you fuck up you can always start a new game with out having to pay extra for anything...)

"-Can take long to perform upgrades or crafting."
ITS A MOBILE GAME... guys... people who play mobile games usually don't spend hours to play a game in one sitting. They usally play while on break, while they go home, during lunch, etc...The hours don't matter to much because they spend most of that waiting time to do what they do. Plus the game isn't a public service. The devs need money to create new content. Upgrade speed boosts are a good way for them to monetize the game.
You can hate on microtransaction all you want but, this game has one of the more reasonable microtransaction schemes I've seen in years for a mobile game... Plus for Fallout Shelter the paying is really just for time reduction. There is no PVP elements so your not missingout on anything even if you don't pay.


"-Quest lines can become repetitive quick."
"-Difficulty drops pretty fast."
These two I actually have to admit are probably the biggest flaws of this game. Even considering the fact the devs can't really throw you difficult decisions, the questlines available are very bland. Just to be fair I think the devs decided to add the quest content as an afterthought because it dind't exist at launch.

For the difficulty, it gets really easy pretty quick. The raiders/death claws/roaches become easy to repel soon enough and serve nothing much than a minor annoyance in the later game. Occasionally fires might breakout in the vault but, that is also a minor issue. Until the devs introduce some new threats and new buildings, after you build up your vault(100+ dwellers) it will get repetitive.

Thats pretty much all I have to say about this game. It has a fair share of flaws but, if your a Fallout Fan its deffinately worth checking out. It might serve as a good filler in between your long journeys in the Mohave and Capital Wasteland.

I remember hearing about Fallout Shelter shortly after it was released. Since I didn‚Äôt own a smartphone at the time, I ignored this game. Then, last year during the summer, Fallout Shelter came to PC via Bethesda‚Äôs launcher. Gaming companies have been releasing their own game launchers, like Steam, and they‚Äôre getting numerous, but I love Bethesda, so I installed it.

I played the game for a little while. It seemed like a game that contained a lot of waiting. It‚Äôs easy enough to play and the game does a great job of teaching you how to play and providing some great tips. Dwellers can act on their own, but it‚Äôs up to you to manage them. Each dweller has their own S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats, each of which is good for something. For instance, you‚Äôll want to put your dwellers with high Strength in your power production rooms. Perception is good for water production, while Agility is good for food production. Intelligence is good for the medical room that produces Stimpaks and the science lab, which produces Radaway. Charm is good in the Living Quarters where you can breed your dwellers.

You can ‚Äúrush‚Äù rooms, hurrying their production of a resources. If it goes well, you‚Äôll get a bonus and caps, but if it fails your dwellers in the room will have to deal with an incident. Before rushing, the game will tell you the percent chance of an incident, so if you find that percentage is high, then it‚Äôs not a good idea to rush the room. The room can catch on fire, or creatures can appear such as Radroaches, Mole Rats, and Radscorpions. If your dwellers get hurt, you can given them Stimpaks. If they die, you can revive them after the incident. If not taken care of quickly enough, the incident could spread to other rooms.

In the meantime, there are chances that Raiders, Feral Ghouls, or Death Claws could invade your vault. Once they get in, it‚Äôs up to your dwellers to fend them off. These enemies always work their way from left to right on each floor, going to the next floor if not defeated in time. If you have a Mr. Handy, it will fight them, too, if it‚Äôs on the same floor or you can drag it there. Mr. Handy can also help protect your dwellers during an incident. It can be destroyed, but can repaired for 2,000 caps.

Rooms can be upgraded and expanded. Most rooms can be three room wide and it‚Äôs a good idea to make your rooms three wide. This means that 6 dwellers can fit inside. More dwellers working in a room, means it can produce quicker. You unlock rooms by getting dwellers. Once you get closer to 50-60 dwellers, you‚Äôll be able to build new, better rooms for resource production. I have three of each, I removed the old resource rooms.

There is a limit to 200 dwellers in your vault and having that many can be a bit of a nightmare, especially if you have not yet made every room. The rooms that train dwellers S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats are really good. You can train a certain stat in each room and rotate dwellers in and out. There‚Äôs also a Barbershop for customizing your dwellers, which I‚Äôve made, but haven‚Äôt used. Also there is a theme workshop that lets you create themes. You‚Äôll find theme recipe pieces on quests. It looks like the themes are Brotherhood of Steel, Railroad, Institute, and Minuteman. 

There are a good number of quests to do. On most quests you can have up to three dwellers, but some quests only allow one, or have other various requirements. They can be difficult so it‚Äôs a good idea to bring your best dwellers with the best gear and the max amount of Stimpacs and Radaway they can carry (25) from the Vault. You can get a variety of rewards such as weapons, outfits, pets, lunchboxes (which can contain anything), junk, and more. If you fully upgrade the Overseer‚Äôs Office, you can have three groups out on quests at once. If your dwellers die and fail a quest, you can retry for a cost, or revive them and send them back home. I have a few certain dwellers I send out on quests. Many quests take some time to reach and get back from, but you can speed this up by spending Nuka-Cola Quantum, which is a very rare resource.

Speaking of quests, there‚Äôs a Bottle and Cappy quest line and when that is completed, B&C will occasionally visit your vault, raising happiness. While they‚Äôre exploring your vault, you can click on Cappy for caps or Bottle for caps or Nuka-Cola Quantum when they‚Äôre dancing. This is so valuable that I highly suggest doing this as soon as possible.

I like this game a lot more than I thought I would. I think this is about as much fun as another Fallout game. I‚Äôve clocked 67 hours in Steam. I‚Äôm not sure how many hours I‚Äôve spent playing on my phone or via the Bethesda launcher. I‚Äôm often surprised that this is a free game, you don‚Äôt always expect free games to be so good. You can spend real money to make in-game purchases, but I haven‚Äôt found that to be necessary.

Here is my review of Fallout Shelter.

(It should be noted that i've played this game for about 5 years now, on my phone). 
First of all it is a great game (Considering its free), thats not only funny, but also a cool concept, for a game. 

GAME INFO:
You are the overseer of your own vault, and it is your job to gather food, water, electricity. You are also tasked to provide safety for Raider, Deathclaw and Goul-attacks. And you can create a lot of weapons and armor in the 3 qualty-classes Commen, Rare and Legendary. The game it self has some pros and cons (obviously), here are the following:

PROS:
+Funny.
+Time consuming af! 
+Lot's of different thinks you can do in-game.  
+Lot's of weapons and armor to craft and skavenge. 

CONS:
-The missions in they game can become very repetitive and boring.
-Savefile-bugs (Haven't had the problem myself though).
-Time consuming af! 
-Maybe a bit more building space.

SO SHOULD YOU PLAY THIS GAME, YOU MAY ASK YOURSELF?:
Why not, ! I hope my review could help you :D

It seems Bethesda have their hearts set out on making video games that are so unhealthily addicting now that as soon as I get my hands on one of their franchises, I just cant stop playing it. Such is the case with their new titles Fallout: Shelter and Fallout 4. I could spend entire days binging these games like a leech sucking blood. Fallout: Shelter is a special case, with a real-time game mechanic that engages the player to continue populating, building, and supplying their vaults with occasional yet repetetive situations requiring vault dwellers to defend the vault, may it be fires, radroach infestations, raider attacks, or deathclaws, there will always be something to keep you on your feet. Once acquiring enough dwellers, you are able to create various rooms to further improve the expansion and happiness of the vault. The game also features a working offline mode achievemnt system, for those who dont have the time to play online to ensure their vaults survival, and is easy to micro-manage with or without transactions for a smoother experience, and does not recquire constant interaction which is VERY helpfull for busy gamers like me.

[h1]Excellent for the one handed[/h1]

I recently spawned a small human, and have found myself sitting at my PC for hours with one hand available and the other attempting to rock an angry gremlin. One hand is useful for a wide variety of things - but most games seem to be rather bias in favour of two. In short, I've been playing a lot of Fallout Shelter this month because I can do it with a single mouse click. Since I've managed to rack up 60 sleep deprived hours on the game, I figured I'd write a review. I'll make it brief, do you know how slow it is to type with one hand?!

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Only requires one hand.
[*] Free to play that doesn't require you to spend money to build an awesome vault.
[*] Very extensive amount of gameplay, way more than were on mobile on release.
[*] Quests have interesting and amusing lore / dialogue.
[*] Very polished, everything is well implemented and balanced.
[*] Addictive.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] You'll lose a great deal of time.
[*] You can give your vault a significant boost with spending money - but you don't need to.
[*] Extreme micromanagement might get boring fast for some.
[*] Addictive.
[/list]

That's all I'm gonna say - you don't need a breakdown of what it is and how to play it. If you're bored and have plenty of free time, enjoy micromanaging and want to save the lives of gingers from a cult in a quest, this is the game for you.

[h1]It's a free to play game well implemented, in a lore-rich universe. Really no reason not to try it and see if you enjoy.[/h1]

At first I used to play this game on phone and connect it with my smart tv. Now, I don't need to.

I was originally going to write this game off as just another mobile microtransactions cash grab, but Bethesda has surprised me with this one. There is absolutely no reason to use their in game store, the game does a pretty good job of standing on its own two legs. The game starts with a decent enough tutorial, and there is no penalty if you want to reset your vault because the drops weren't terrific. Base building is fun and addictive, and the downtime that plagues mobile games (which is how they rope you into buying things from their store) is actually pretty acceptable, given that they throw in the Mysterious Stranger (who gives you caps if you click on him) and the Disasters, which often require your attention as you send your Dwellers to fix whatever the situation is.

Quests and Objectives are nice, as they grant tangible rewards, unlike venturing into the Wasteland, which is dependent on the Explorer's Luck Stat (which is likely to be low, unless you got a good Dweller from the Lunchboxes). Even though the Wasteland's rewards are RNG dependent, they do exist, and a good haul (especially the outfits) can really bump up Vault production.

I think the only real gripe I have is that the bedrooms have a nasty case of catching fire (and not in the good way) which is odd to me, considering I've stopped placing people there since I built the Radio Room. Maybe it's just my bad luck, but I'd like to find the idiot who keeps leaving lit cigarettes by the bedsheets.

All in all, I fully recommend this game if you're looking for a free time sink. And like any mobile game, I also recommend staying the hell away from the in game stores. If you can do that, there is literally no reason I can think of to pass up this game.

Fallout Shelter is a click game simulator where you are the controller of a Vault-Tec Vault. At the start of the game, you are randomly assigned a number from 000 to 999. The number you receive will the vault ID and will determine the attributes of your Vault, similar to the lore in Fallout.

The goal of the game is to grow your vault and keep your population happy. To grow your population, you need to increase the space in the vault, grow more living quarters and feed them. You feed your dwellers and keep them happy by maintaining Food, Water and Power supplies. To maintain the supplies, you need to build Diners, Water Generators and Power Generators, man them and click on them to collect the resources (just like Farmville). 

As your population grows, you can unlock other facilities such as the Storage Room, Medbay, Science Lab, Overseer's Office, Radio Studio, Weapon Workshop, Weight Room, Athletics Room, Armory, Classroom, Outfit Workshop, Fitness Room, Lounge Theme Workshop, Game Room, Barbershop, Nuclear Reactor, Garden, Water Purification, Nuka Cola Bottler. As you complete objectives, the game will reward you with lunchboxes which is basically a bundle of Caps, Item Cards and other equipment.

Conclusion, it's just another P2W click simulator. Best price is $150 for 1000 Nuka Cola. You can safely ignore Fallout Shelter without missing out on anything.

Note: I am surprised that Bethesda Games would fall prey to the P2W business model. 

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Simple to Pick Up
It's easy to learn and you can just pick the dwellers and hover over the respective rooms to see if it's a + or -. 

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Pay To Win
The grind currency are Bottle Caps and the cash currency is Nuka Cola. 1000 Nuka Cola for $150.

2. Click Farm Simulator
No auto collection. Remember to log in to click-farm.

3. Can't Remodel
Want to demolish a specific room? It can't be connected to 2 adjoining rooms, otherwise you're screwed.

4. Caps?
Seriously, caps to build a room. I mean, there's a limit that the imagination can stretch to.

Vault techs most neferious vault ever.

So nearly gave this a thumbs down, this wasn't a vault tech vault I said, where are the experiments designed to drive residents insane or make mutants? Then I saw it all, a front door designed to protect against nukes, that falls to raiders with swords. Random fires and infestations of molerats and radroaches. A strange man that appears without opening the vault door and explodes into caps when hit. The ability to breed a single woman into creating a whole army of new residents with random men (sadly not yet with her own children (you would think that would be right up vault techs street considering)). Forcing pregnant woemn to vault hobby horses and climb ropes for endless hours until the stress makes them give birth.

No this is vault tech being more sadistic but subutle about it and as overseer it is your job to have a hand in this madness, working from behind the scenes invisibly moving people around so they work in areas they are no good in and watch as their happiness drops then force them to work harder to set rooms on fire and force them to battle OP radroaches.

Or you can make them happy and put them in the right room and enjoy highly productive vaults. But where's the fun in that?

Pros
Free to play
Good time sink
Reasonable learning curve
Good selection of missions
Naming the dwellers what you want

Cons
OP Radroaches
OP fires
Raider attacks that break down the vault door.
Lack of early information on room fusing bonuses.

Overall: 8/10 good game reminds me of Xcom EW but with less aliens.

I came back to this game only recently after playing it on my mobile for quite some time when it was released. I quit because there wasn't enough content. By introducing Crafting and Quests the game is interesting again.

About the payed content: The prices aren't as high as in other games and paying is definitely not necessary for progressing since you get some Lunchboxes and Nuka Cola bottles by doing said quests for free.
game is fun at first once ya start to feel safe the game gets super unbalanced, mole rat attacks that take 5 minutes to kill, the all powerful deathclaw attacks that kill your vault

WTF the game is good but some shitty scripts i was returning a explorer after 2 days he was almost home and I though why not let him explore while i sleep sence he will be back in 1 hour. but when he tried to return right after hitting explore it's fucking 20 hours. wtf eplane the logic other than you're making America great again and hireing shit programmers.
TBH...I would rather just play Fallout 4.
meh mainly a big time killer and pain number, 7/10 gets boring fairly quickly though...

I really like this game I played this on a lot of other devices. It acts like every other one but it glithces more. Its weird that I had 2 feral ghoul attack in a 2-3 min peroid and i had 41 people and a lot of room so i dont know why. But other wise i like this game and it dosen't subtract a lot of reasores when i get out the game.
i love the game . i wuold recomend this if you sre 9-24 or if you just like this type of game
I really like this game!
Recomendad√≠simo

Terrible, Just terrible, why does this exist? first off, the whole "manage a vault" idea might be a good idea on paper, but when executed like this, whats the point in playing? the game is super tedious, for example: get on, collect water, collect power, food, and repeat. sure there are quests, but thats pretty much what this game is, going on quests. and what makes the quest system so bullshit is that you have to wait for your "dweller" to travel to the destination, this can take from 30 minutes to 12 hours. which is ridiculous.

    the worst part is, there are microtransactions. you have to pay in order to get these cola bottle things. you can however, use these to skip the quest waiting time. its pretty obvious bethesda made this game for money. 


      Honestly, the game lacks content and replay value, I downloaded this on my phone. (thus explaining why I have so little time on this game) go ahead and download it. its only really good ifyou have nothing to play.
Don't have a gamepad. Looks like I need a gamepad. Can't get camera to move anywhere. :P If someone can tell me how to turn off gamepad controls I will give this a thumbs up. :P

The only F2P game that does not squeeze you for every dollar in your wallet while still providing a well designed, balanced and entertaining game! Using the great setting of Fallout, this Vault Simulation game will provide you hours of casual entertainment while making your close relatives tell you how they would never live in a world ruled by you, despite having provided 100% happiness to hundreds of dwellers!

Definately a game that Fallout fans will enjoy, It's mostly about strategy; organising your power, food, water and even which vault dwellers work best using their atributes. Overall, it's a pretty decent game and I would recommend for those of you avid Fallout fans out there like me. :)

Takes awhile to set things up to a point of where you can really move around and do the things that you would normally expect such as quests and grinding. 

Fun for passing time, but the slowness of the game can be boring at first. 

My vault dwellers randomly died once my population hit 40 people and bumped all the way down to 16, I don't know if this is a glitch or not --perhaps there are lifespans but I doubt it.
Great game, may be my favorite free to play game.

Great little Game But if your pc crashes or powes off mid game there is a good chance you will lose your vault and all the ingame purchaces. 50+ pounds gone due to a power cut. steam support says contact Bethesda and  Bethesda support says contact steam. by all means play it but dont spend any money you dont mind losing

~ 9 / 10

Fallout Shelter! What a magnificent little mini-game to have on the side. If you, like me, love Bethesda's Fallout universe and like to have some of these small mini-games on the side of your other games. I can highly recommend this as a good option! It has a nice way of scaling, options to explore and collect in the Wasteland and to create unique places for your dwellers to live!

Great mini-game!
Addictive as hell, makes you feel like a teenage girl high on heels, energydrinks, playing Sims because of zero soc. life.

Mint.
