Well, it's fun up to a certain point where it just turns into grinding for resources. The quests do add a fair amount of entertainment. What killed the game for me are the Deathclaw attacks. They are 'a tad' too frequent.

If you enjoy a daily bit of resource management, give it a try. Just don't spend money on it.
If the end of the world is like this, the adventure is just beginning  :)
fgfgfgfg

Well actually I didnt expect it to be this good. After playing for a few hours straight, thinking I would've gotten bored after 10 minutes. You can cheat pretty easily but its not needed, by playing enough and playing smart u can build everything up pretty fast ! 


I for sure recommend this game, solid and not too much pay to win :) .

I'm really half and half about this. I feel like the game itself is good but its too much of a mobile game in the sense that it is P2W and you really feel that too. Progression is heavily timegated, leaving you attempting to speed things up without spending money which fails a lot, I think the fail % and luck on dwellers seem to go up against each other rather than it being the fail % that matters if that makes sense. It's addicting but it's heavy P2W but the issue is if you spend cash you feel no progression either because in these type of games there's always either too easy or too hard, which is done on purpose to make you spend money.

It's a good game but like I'd rather spend 2$ on it than play another cash grab game.

1.) What this game needs is an "Loot All" Button. (This function will use all ready dwellers, meaning if they have a level up or the powerplant is ready to harvest or a skill up - it will be collected automatically.)
2.) Option to speed and lower the combat speed... x2 x3 x4 And why not make Pets loot corpses and items? (everything is so slow i wanna throw up watching the slowmotion animations.)
3.) Proper way to select and send units to specific designated areas. (Managing 50+ dwellers slows the actual gameplay down even more - i suggest a proper interface to send dwellers to either other stations or directly into the wasteland - the finding the dweller "game" is getting tiresome or selecting them via the wheel -> looking for them - selecting them via pixel grafix is hard enough but then dragging them to the wastelands for a mission... its funny the first 1000 times but after that it just encourages me to throw up)
4.) Inventory management is terrific - first you loot thousands of items - some via chest you cant automatically sort out and others like rare pistols - yeah i need them definetly so i can throw that crap away - scrolling and sorting weapons, outfits and junk should be made much easier and quicker. For example there could be an option in the inventory to always automatically sell specific outfits and weapons. And for selling junk i recommend a function were you can set "how much junk" you want to sell... selling one or all is pretty lame....
Overall an addictive, fun and lame game. Those freemium games were you can purchase items which speed up the gameplay are as pathetic as one can imagine. Especially if everything in the game is about slowing your gameplay down... I hate the guy who invented that "freemium - ingame speedup purchase" addtition...

This is a recommendation with reservations. The game is free to play and I've played it for a number of hours so all good so far. Watching your little dwellers level up is good fun too but then it all gets a bit repetitive and the micromanagement elements start to become tiresome. I have a ton of training rooms in my vault and have ended up scrolling around to see where there is space once a dweller has maxxed a specific skill. This gets a little dull particularly when it dawns on you there's not much else to do except send dwellers out on increasingly similar missions which result in rewards that, after a while you don't really need anyway. Every now and again some radscorpions or raiders tear up the place but the biggest inconvenience of these invasions is that you're usually in the middle of rearranging your dwellers. I go back to this game for a few minutes a couple of times a day and it passes the time but then, I am currently working in Qatar, one of the dullest places on the planet so I have an excuse. If you don't have an excuse you'd be better off taking up golf or something.

Oh what could have been.  Anyone who starts playing this game is immediately going to enoy it.  It's fun, fast paced, and you even get to care about the little characters you have in your vault.  With that said, it's a freemium game, and although there's nothing inherently wrong with that the point of problem is that with most freemium games they don't want you to lose out on anything, they just want you to spend money.  So here are the main problems I have with this game because... well, there's absolutely nothing to lose except time.

Cons (rather than do the positives, which are numerous because of the joy that Fallout brings to so many fans, here are the negative aspects that make the game totally bland within one week)

 - Never lose a character - someone die?  no problem, just give 'caps' that are so numerous you'll never have to worry about risking someone

- Missions - your characters train so fast that missions are ridiculously easy, never having to worry about not making it back

- Family unit - It's a free-for-all when it comes to making babies.  Trust me, you'll start out worrying about the right people making babies so you don't confuse blood lines, etc., and it's pointless.  No penalties for anyone at anytime making babies with whoever they want.  This could have had a "Sims" feel to it and at first I thought it was going to but it doesn't.  It's just, 'hey, need a kid, throw any two together, no worries'.

- Weapons - Good weapons are easy to come by, no work required to get them.

- Bottle & Cappy - these little idiots NEVER STOP showing up, it's every 3 minutes it seems which is so annoying

- Stranger - the Stranger shows up, and at least you have to find him, but he also shows up every 1 minute it seems and it's pointless to keep worrying about him, he just becomes annoying

- Can't attack other vaults - this could have been a great aspect to the game if they included it... but they didn't, so enjoy clicking on your factories every minute and going on a mission every few hours because... well... that's about all you get to do.

I've played for 87 hours, and at first it was a lot of fun to build up my little vault, but it's just in the way now.  I actually sit down to my computer and think about the game and then kind of dread having to do all the little mundane things.  In fact the only reason I've continued is that I hope updates are released or something to make the game more fun for a computer gamer, but alas this game is a tablet/phone intended freemium game, so the game that I want isn't going to be released or 'updated' any time soon.  Oh well... I've got board games to make anyway.

It's been a while since I played a simulation game. The first vault I built I expanded too quickly (too many inhabitants and too many rooms) and it is suffering for it (not enough weapons to fend off intruders and constant issues with power, water, food, the 3 resources you should have plenty of or your vault will fall apart). And money as well. My second vault fares much better, and leaves me actually time to go questing and exploring at a regular basis. 

I have not had any issues with "save" of the shelters thusfar, as I read that some experienced in the reviews of this game (although it appears linked after investing rl money in the game, which I have not). I'm also glad to see that after being away for 8+ hrs I didn't return to the vault finding all my dwellers dead, I feared a bit for that, but even though time does not come to a halt upon logging out (babies are actually ready to be born by then, or children grew up, both taking a bit of time) I can start collecting all the resources. So that's pretty cool. 

I enjoy the micromanagement (keep tabs on every inhabitant and keep them happy, have enough resources, enough medpacks, weapons, ... ) and the diversity of things to do. There are various ways to earn money (caps) in this game : collect resources, explore, quest, catch the intruder in the brown outfit (not easy, he announces himself with a sound and another sound when he disappears). The caps I received for his capture varies. The most I ever received was 4800ish caps. Which is very welcome in my first vault as an unexpected attack of rodents wiped out almost my entire vault, meaning I had to resurrect them all (the price of ressurection goes up with their level). And this is best done asap, as any surviving inhabitants will get very unhappy very fast (they don't like bodies in their vicinity, and can't say I blame them).

I suggest not to leave the game running when going for a stroll or doing something else meanwhile as things tend to get out of hand then, such as low on the main resources or an attack (and when you don't monitor those, casualties tend to fall unless your habitants are well armed I suppose). You can save and go to the main menu, or save and exit. Talking about saving, I tend to save now and then, not that you can load the game from the last saving point, but force of habit.

I'm playing the game for a few days now, and see myself doing so for a while longer.
A fun way to spend your time. The perfect game to study while playing. I set up the training and all the time-requiring actions and study for the duration. And repeat :)

[quote]Combining banal gameplay mechanics and abuses of the weaknesses of the human mind along with tens of timers and a pay-to-skip business model, Fallout Shelter embodies much of what is wrong in today's gaming industry.[/quote]
Fallout Shelter is compelling and addicting. It draws you in and it doesn't want to let go of your attention. It is cute, has a lot of attention to detail and it is fun. It is also devious, manipulative and abusive.

The game uses a combination of various banal gameplay mechanics:

[list]
[*]Timers. There are timers everywhere. It is the one mechanics that is introduced first and it will follow you everywhere. After a few hours you will juggle tens of timers. 
[*]Clickers. Pretty much all timers must be acknowledged and restarted with a click (or a tap).
[*]Hidden objects. The mysterious stranger, Bottle and Cappy or looting the dungeons are hidden object minigames
[*]Quick-time events are used during fights.
[/list]
These four mechanics are combined so that the game forces you to compulsively check it out regularly for short moments, but if you want to move the story via quests, you must wait hours or even days. These long timers can be skipped by paying real money in what is one of the worst gaming invention of the last years.

There are other considerations for the player: How to lay out the shelter, how to breed and train dwellers, what quests to tackle in which order. These are all hidden behind the layer of the aforementioned juggling of timers, clicking to harvest and looking for hidden objects.

Fallout Shelter not only preys on the weaknesses of the human mind with a devious mix of banal, casual and meaningless gameplay, not only it adopts a business model that goes against fun and fairness, it also represents abuse of the name of an old game series that used to stand for clever writing, branching quests, meaningful choices and consequences and a lot of possible ways to play through the game.

Fallout Shelter is a compelling and addictive abomination.

My opinion of this game is (letter grade and explanation):
* F / Unfair game mechanics
* F / Poorly implemented "random events" system
* C- / Game progress is much slower than ideal, leading to too much waiting
* F / Game forces you you pay for in-game currency if you want to progress
* C+ / Many game mechanics are poorly explained, leading to a lot of wasted time/resources as part of a "learning process"
* A+ / Visual style of game and 3-D effect
* A- / Load screen menus and intro sillyness
* D- / Mouse usability within gameplay (being able to click what you want to click)

WOULD NOT RECOMMEND (not even worth being free / you would have to pay me to play this)

Now before you conclude "oh this guy just don't like this type of game..." I actually do. I think the visual style of the game is beautiful and I'm a huge fan of slow-paced clicker games. This game was in fact free to try, but it leaves you with the feeling that someone is constantly nagging you about buying in-game currency to be able to do basic things. The difference between this game and what I would have wanted/expected is like the difference between:

1) Standing in line and...
2) Standing in line with 100 toddlers that are screaming.

If you know what nagging, uneasy feeling I am talking about then stay away from this horrible game. The game did not have a sense of urgent post-apocalyptic building-a-city-from-nothing. It was like struggling to find ways to actually play the game that the developers had not thought to charge for.

This is the end of the review. The following is more specific details about why I am about to delete this game.

Firstly, I don't like Bethesda. I won't go into why, but I think they do more damage than good for the gaming community. I ran across this game several times and said "no" to it because of the developer. Nonetheless, I gave it a try due to the visual style and I have a friend that said it was "an okay game." I'm not about to read every how-to before playing it, and understand my first attempt will probably not be ideal, but the game has serious issues.

Today I was playing, trying to do the questing as well as explore and keep my shelter slowly growing and dwellers leveling up. The problem I ran into is that the fires/roaches just continue to randomly spawn, even when your not rushing, causing your dwellers, who only some of which are armed, to constantly have health issues, causing your healing "Stimpak" to be in short supply. If you then run into the situation where you have an power emergency, you end up having to stack a ton of people into the reactor room and then "rush" it. The more you fail, the longer it takes and the worse your percentage is to "rush" again.

I found that when it says "33% chance" to fail, that actually means 90% chance to fail, and it never changes. I'm not saying that the percentages are slightly off, I'm saying I think it is stuck on 90% fail rate no matter how low the displayed percentage is. I've failed at 30-40% far too many times for this to be an actual percentage. Keep in mine 33% means you should fail about 1/3 of the time. not 9/10, which I was experiencing.

In addition to the "Stimpak" issue, dweller death causes the same issue, because you need to revive them, which costs caps, which are always in short supply and are even more in short supply if your dwellers start to die and therefore cannot assist with the gaining of caps.

Hopefully even players that have played this game can understand my frustration by this point.

Free.  To.  Play.

Do not treat this game as a serious representation of the Fallout universe.  But if you love Fallout, you will enjoy all the little references.  Shelter is about as addictive as an ant farm.  Check in on your dwellers once or twice a day, waste a little time, exit the game and go back to more important things.  Let the game go through its stupid timers (or cheat as others have suggested) like any usual port of a mobile game.  Lather.  Rinse.  Repeat.

Atmosphere is cute and comical (even deathclaws) and the script is corny.  There are reviews complaining about unrealistic combat and microtransactions.  Again, this is not a serious game.  And you do not have to (or should) spend a dime playing.

(There was one game breaking bug in the initial version that was fixed by early April.  I've not had issues with the game since though others have complained of vaults getting corrupted or lost.  The only oddity I've experienced is that my gamepad, which Shelter can use, rumbles on occasion though I just use mouse and keyboard.  Not a bug-free game but you get what you pay for.)

I definitely recommend this game. If you're like me, who used to own the mobile version, but hated how time senstive the game was, the PC version is your solution.
The original moible version was amazing, and i loved it, but if you didnt collect your resources in time, your shelter died out in no time. This PC version, is the solution to this, as when you close the game, it also 'pauses it' in a way where:
1) your shelter's resources dont take into account your time away
2) any quests, or expeditions, continue going, so you can come back after your quests return, and they will be there.
I dunno if this was intentional or not, but i love it.
Besides that, there are some minor performance issues, especially when you try and rush rooms for the first time since opening, but that's forgivable.
I love this, and it will probably remain my favorite tower building, however you call it, game currently available.
faaaaaaaaaak

There isn't really any longterm investment unless you're a hoarder like me and just want items. Then you quickly realise that collecting items is the only reason you still play this. I honestly had no other reason.

The most optimal way to get into this game is if you play in short bursts. Log in now and then and check on your vault dwellers exploring in the wasteland, do that quest which took your dwellers many hours to get to. When that's over check out and come back later. Otherwise it's just an interactive screensaver I suppose, which can be fine too.

Quests are 'meh'. They're just an excuse to get to see a different location to your vault, but they're not too different visually or even interesting. Combat in quests is awkward as well, you just wait a very long time until your vault dwellers finally attack the targeted enemy. I've read that the attack speed can be increased by upgrading certain stats, but till you get to that point you're spending a lot of time waiting for your people to finally do something. Dialog options, which rarely come up, aren't that interesting either.

It works okay as a mobile port, but dragging and dropping vault dwellers to different rooms feels off. Sometimes you have to hover them over a room above the room where you want to place them to. This gets annoying if you quickly want to move a lot of people to help in combat during an attack. It also seems that its possible to edit save files in order to cheat.

While it is a free game, the lack of any compelling reasons for long term investment kindof defeats the purpose of what I think its its designed for: to keep you coming back every time and eventually spend money. There's not too much to get from this experience considering the combat is so dull, which is one of the main reasons why you'd want to get good gear. The other reason why you'd want gear is for your vault dwellers to perform slightly better in their act of standing around all day to give you resources to tap on. That's it.
If you've played the mobile version then you know what to expect here. Only gripe I can think of is carrying over saves from said mobile accounts, other then that, a solid f2p game

If you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients
- To Make the Dough
375 grams (3 cups) plain flour
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 eggs
1/4 cup (50 ml / 3¬Ω tablespoons) olive oil
1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) water
Extra flour for dusting 


- To Make Cheese Filling
15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese
5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) "3 Cheese Italian Blend" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago)
Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend.
1/2 cup cheddar cheese
2 eggs, lightly beaten
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon pepper


- Extras
Your favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana)
Parmesan cheese
Basil
Fried vegetables
Shrimp
Fish slices
Chicken pieces 
Make the Ravioli filling.

- In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork.
- Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper.
- Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency.
- Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. 

Make the Ravioli dough.

- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.
- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.
- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.
- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.
- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.
- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).
- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesn‚Äôt suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor. 

Fill the Ravioli shells.

- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.
- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.
- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a ‚Äúhomemade‚Äù touch as well.
- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.
- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. 

Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.

- Roll the dough into two sheets
- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.
- Fill with the ravioli mixture.
- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.
- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.

Cook the Ravioli.

- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.
- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.
- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest 
- Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed plates

Serve it up.
Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!

The basics are:
- Add rooms for energy, food, water, housing, storage, weapons, consumables, clothes, customisation, training.
- Put dwellers to work, have them make babies, send them out to explore or send them on missions.
- Exploring and missions yield currency, crafting material, weapons, armor.
- Equip dwellers with weapons and armor for missions and for defending the vault against monsters and raiders.
- Dwellers will level up while working, exploring or doing missions.
- Dwellers can also train up their stats in certain rooms which makes them stronger, smarter, etc.
- Add dwellers with a Radio room or by letting dwellers do naughty stuff ;)

All in all i like it. It's very casual friendly as you can just put them to work and send them exploring or on a mission (traveling there takes Real Life hours) and then you can do RL stuff and check back later.

Someone, at some point, thought [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] was a good idea. I'm not really sure who that was since the core mechanics are awful and don't translate well to PC [i]at all[/i] but someone decided it was worth the time to port, so I figure that means it's worth the time to review.

The Good:

It's another [i]Fallout[/i] game?

Seriously, though I didn't notice as much lag in this version as the original mobile one. That could just be my Vault was never big enough to reach that point, but we can discuss that later.

Adventure Mode/Quests: These weren't part of the game at launch (I remember when quests were added, anyway; the basic expedition is a core mechanic) and they make [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] feel like a really crappy, [i]Fallout[/i]-themed version of [i]Dwarf Fortress[/i], or at least they would, if your Dwellers weren't both incredibly stupid and incredibly lucky. Stupid in the sense I've had them get beaten by [i]bloat flies[/i] before, and lucky because I've had Dwellers leave the Vault in nothing but their suit and make their way back in high tier or Legendary armor with fifteen different guns on their person. None of these will save you from the game's most deadly enemy, though, which I'll get to soon, fear not.

The Bad:

If you needed a very succinct, painless explanation of why the Bethesda-made [i]Fallout[/i] games are inferior, [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is as good a place as any to start. Aside from the absurdly large number of references to [i]Fallout 3[/i] (and later [i]Fallout 4[/i]) this game has nothing to do with the rest of the series. Weapons, characters, and enemies don't appear, despite them being logical additions: every weapon in the game, just about, is from [i]Fallout 3[/i], with the fourth numbered game's stupid pipe weapons thrown in for good measure. It's almost as if Bethesda thinks if they just don't mention the four core games they had nothing to do with the creation of (well, three, since they published [i]New Vegas[/i]) everyone else will forget they exist.

Balance. Your Vault can be doing very well for itself. You can be churning out medium-grade weapons and armor, generating enough electricity to power a small island, and have enough purified water to fill a swimming pool, and it won't matter one bit because a sudden infestation of rad roaches or, God help you, [i]mole rats[/i] will [i]literally[/i] kill everyone unless you're very lucky. Now, I can believe a deathclaw or three could pull this off, but it's ridiculous how hilariously overpowered joke enemies like these become. It's not a matter of me not equipping my people either: I've watched mole rats kill Dwellers in Combat Armor armed with scoped M29s and lever-action rifles before. Never will I feel guilty about completing the "Wasteland Survival Guide" quest in [i]A Tale of Two Wastelands[/i] again.

There's also very disappointingly little opprotunity to actually chose how your Vault is set up. There are only a handful of really power-gamey set ups that will give you a good return in the longrun, but more than that, you can't even decide [i]where[/i] your Vault is. You should at least get to pick a state to put your Vault in (I like to think mine is in Missouri, but it could be Nevada for all I know since the Wasteland is depicted as a desert at all times). 

I will give Bethesda credit here, though: this game is free, unlike the Vault-Tec Workshop DLC for [i]Fallout 4[/i], which is still like $10 and actually adds considerably less content.

Mobile game ported to PC. Fun for the first few hours, after that it may as well be dead. High RNG risk game unless you spend money. Good tip is to rush room and exit game right away if "FAILED" to prevent the RNG of failing.

Challenges/Objectives are your main source of lunchboxes and pets but they can get very painful and almost impossible with minimal rewards to the point where I gave up and I cannot be bothered to wait a day just to re-roll one of the 3 challenges which could end up being worse. 

Even though I keep the dweller population low the objectives only get harder as you complete them, so after completing 20 you could still have 10 dwellers and you will get objectives such as "Survive 30 mole rat attacks", "Craft 15 outfits", "Get 9 perfect critical hits" and one of my most hated objectives.... "Explore 7 locations while in the wasteland" seriously dumb considering how random and long it takes to find a location while having to be active 100% of the time. If you don't get a pet early on which gives multiple objectives completes per an action then I wouldn't even consider progressing as it will only get painful.

Game can be otherwise fun if you intend to play just to collect resources once or twice a day but exit the game quickly as you will always get attacked after being away a while when you come back which is a waste of time. Exploring locations for quests should have an automatic mode as it gets boring quickly.

The game is fun in the beginning, but it gets repetitive after a while and the micromanagement gets very annoying. Yes, you can reduce microamangement by not expanding your vault, but then there's no more progress to be made.

It just lacks good end-game content and features that could reduce micro-management.

Whack-A-Mole. Deluxe.

However, it is hampered by UI issues stemming from being a port of a mobile game. It was not optimized for mouse/keyboard input at all. This leads to some floaty, bad, and downright unreliable behavior when attempting to select or move dwellers from the main screen. For general management, this can be mostly sidestepped through some secondary menus, like the master vault dweller list, however, the master list doesn't give you all the important info you need--like their equipment, or which power plant they are working in. 

The secondary menus are also useless when trying to recruit help for dealing with incidents--and given the native cowardice of dwellers, that's a problem. The worst is a radscorpion event, because they're tough, and they move around randomly. Even with a small vault, they're an enormous pain because of how difficult it can be to snag assistance and direct them to the room presently being thrashed. That plus the fact that a typical radscorpion only stays in one spot long enough for that dweller you finally got sent to fight it to get there, and that you can't really do anything else until the radscorpion is killed, and you now know why I uninstalled the game.

The game is great for what it is, but the UI is horrible for anything.

Not worth the time to play let alone spend money on.  It's designed to completely trash your vault.  You can have one invader that will obliterate your entire structure.  If you happen to get very lucky and get a rare weapon you can survive for a bit, but they continue to send foes that can enter your vault with impunity.  The only invaders that are usually okay are the raiders because they are about equivalent in strength.  The mole rats and radroaches are very inconsistent in their strengths, sometimes they can be dispatched relatively easily, but other times they just mow down your entire fortress.  Deathclaws and Radscorpions almost always leave my vault with numerous dead dwellers.  I can't see a significant difference in dwellers that are level 25 and those that are level 1.  The main thing is the weapon they weild and the armor they wear and those aren't easy to obtain, especially the really good ones.  As a result, you can play along and think you're doing well when one invasion will literally decimate your forces and you'll struggle just to keep vault resources coming in enough just to let it survive, let alone prosper.  It's too random and you are too vulnerable to attack to make the game worthwhile, of course, this is what they want... they want you to spend money to get out of jams (and there are plenty of jams).  It is fun for awhile, but very disheartening to spend a few hours getting your vault established then to have one event destroy everything.  At least, I didn't spend any money on it (which is probably one reason game is so difficult, they almost make it that you have to spend money.)

I went into this with very low expectations, looking for something casual but with enough gameplay to keep me interested.

I should note I'm a fairly big fallout fan, played it since Fallout 1 back in them there 90's, and almost every game since. The use of fallouts music, sound effects and pipboy cartoon style graphics are almost enough to garner my interest from the start, but the game has enough merit to keep me going for at least a few days.

The game is essentially a real time anthill strategy game, with about the same level of depth as a reasonable board game. You construct a vault from small number of settlers, add various rooms, and assign your settlers to work in the rooms, do quests outside the vault, and then theres the breeding... which is highly amusing.  you put a couple in a room together and if/when they hit it off, they disappear into the back of the room and the lady comes out pregnant. There is a degree of entertainment here just in making sure you don't breed out the genetic diversity from your settlers. Not too difficult but but novel nonetheless. 

Earlier I mentioned realtime. When I say realtime there is a lot of waiting around... the idea (from the publisher) being that you get sick enough of waiting and start paying to win (in the form of nuka cola quantum bottles which speed up various tasks). I should note that 'pay to win' type games are something I normally run a mile from, but Its buried enough that It doesn't interfere with the gameplay for me.  In regards to waiting around this is (primarily though many things take time) for your teams to go on quests and for the babies to gestate, and then grow up (about 4 hours each in real time). One nice thing is that the game time keeps running (for about four hours max I think) whenever you shut it down, so ideal if you have a real life as well. You can come back and spin the plates, match up some new couples, set off on a new mission etc, and then step away again. 

Quick summary.

Great if you like casual wee strategy games with about a board game level of depth, and indeed being a fallout fan will help keep you interested. 

It is addictive, and really quite fun, great for hourly doses a few times a day. 

Biggest negative is that this was a mobile game ported to PC, and the interface is a little clumsy as a result, but still bearable. Pay to win not an issue if you are fairly patient and don't need to binge this game.

I remember when this was first released, and I enjoyed it, although it being only on my mobile was frustrating, particularly the wonky screen attention movement and the really bad zooming and focusing.  ultimately gave it up and uninstalled.
Now, I see they have somewhat improved it and released it on steam. Great!   that wonkyness with zoom and focus is still there, but much better on a larger screen, and the pc  mouse control is way superior to the tiny touchscreen interface.  I like the additions of the pets and workshops, and the quests! 
HOWEVER, and that is a big however, the RNG event generator is broken.. I mean really, frustratingly *ing broken.  I think I understand how the algo is supposed to work, and it IS effective. however is there a better algo rng than "whatever will * over the player repeatedly, and make the experience less enjoyable"?  come on.at first it was multiple deathclaw attacks in a row laying waste to multiple layers of dwellers.  ok. some levelling, and it's down to one, maybe 2 vault layers.  so now it's  10 unkillable radscorpions in a row?  Seriously? I can see if it's only 2 or maybe 3 dwellers in an attack, and it gets bored and runs off, but laying waste to at least 3 full rooms of decently armed dwellers before running away.. seriously? oh, and spawing other unkillable rs's to do the same simultaneously? seriously? 
another item that needs be addressed  is the scaling.  on the quests, you have the three dwellers that can take on a full structure of radscorpions, or irradiated ferals, or what have you, and  while they take damage, it's not the insta-drain it is when the same # attack the vault.  if there is a weird scaling, where on the quest,  one is one, but at the vault one is 5, I could see that, but not the one is apparently 10... 
Because it is initially enjoyable,  I am giving it a recommendation. it IS at it's core a good  work.. it just REALLY needs to have better clarifications and some tuning to make it more about difficulty than just being mind-numbingly frustrating.

I would like to start by saying the game does have a good overall concept, and I believe that the issues here can be fixed.

The biggest reason I find the game unplayable is that combat is very confusing. Frequently, you will get raids by sword weilding samurai. They don't come for resources, they just come to kill your survivors, and suck their soul into a pokeb- sorry, wrong game. 

If an attack does happen, your characters just kind of stand around and do nothing. You can equip weapons and all that, but the effectiveness varies. You also have to manually move either the weapons around between characters, or move your characters to the room under attack. 

This could be improved if the survivor AI is updated to automatically seek out and destroy threats, and to automatically move to rooms under siege. 

It would also be kind of nice to have more mechanics in the underground. In XCOM, you build chambers very similar to the game here. In XCOM, geothermal caves will spawn underground which provide extra electricity if you build a power plant on it. It's little things like that which could really add to the game's playability. 

So summing up, I ask that Bethesda makes combat more fun, and less confusing, as well as adding a few mechanics to give the player a reason to keep coming back. It's that thought of, "gee, I can't wait until I can build my base up to reach this cool looking location."

This is a very fun free game, but not without it's share of faults that need to be addressed

Pros
- Gameplay is pretty fun and varied. From vault building to quests to exploration, there's a lot to do.

- Quite a bit to the strategy of this game. It looks simple on the surface, but it's quite complex, with it's SPECIAL stat system, which determines how dwellers perform in different situations. A lot of trial and error is needed to master this game.

- A bunch of different rooms, allowing you to craft your own gear, train your people to your liking, as well as producing the basics to keep everyone alive

- You can earn all the pay shop items through regular play, which is always a plus to me.

Cons
- I saw another review use the word "chaotic", and that is a perfect word for the game as you progress. You very quickly  jump from simple to challenging to completely insane as you're bombarded with things like Radscorpion invasions, which will not only beat you senseless, but deplete your resources as they do it. It can be very hard to just tread water once the difficulty ramps up. I like a challenge but I'm finding this to be a bit over the top and the level of micromanaging is also a bit much.

- The programming is on the poor side in some areas. You can tell it's a port. There's a mystery man that pops up every once in a while, and you've got about 10 seconds to locate him. There's nothing like hearing his music, being right in the middle of looking for him when you have a raider attack, which centers the camera on them, hearing the music of the mystery man disappearing, then killing the raiders only to watch one spend 10 or 15 seconds limping across the screen as he drains your resources in the process, and you're helpless to do anything until he finally collapses. It can also be painfully difficult to click on things such as the mystery man, finding that the game thinks you intend to click on the room itself, and you may lose him in the process. Hopefully things like this are addressed because they seem like unnecessary punishment for doing nothing wrong.

- Not impressed by some of the cash items. Mr Handy, for instance, moves painfully slow when he's on resource gathering mode. I find it much quicker and more efficient to just manually collect, as you lose resource production time when he's dragging himself all the way across the floor to collect. In my opinion, if it's a cash item, it should be instantaneous. Also, not much to say for his cap collecting ability on exploration. Even though he can't take damage, it's much more lucrative to send a regular dweller exploring. He seems like a jack of all trades, master of none. I found mine through the course of the game, but if I had spent money on this thing, I would feel ripped off.

- There seems to be one gamebreaking issue where save files become corrupt, and if that happens, support will not help you. That.. in a word, sucks. In fact, I might be tempted to spend money on this game, but after hearing that, I will not. Not if that's the level of support they provide.

So in closing, it's a perfect free game. That's the right pricetag in it's current state. It's fun and worth your time to try it out. Enough to earn a thumbs up, but not a glowing endorsement. If they address some of the issues, it would raise it above that level.

Cons: 
- you have to pick up the resources manually, and more you upgrade a room the faster it produces, so at a certain point you find yourself picking up resources and not having time to do nothing else
- no real sistem to organize your citizens, so it can be difficult to give them the best tasks for their SPECIAL once you have more than 100 people down there
- same for weapon and clothes
- if you build 2 rooms next to each other and later you want to change the first one, you have to demolish everything. and that is quite annoing specially later on the game

Pros:
- the irony is the same as the main game
- graphic is nice, dialogues too
- MIssions are interesting and vary
- the reward sistem works well, and even the nuke cola awards dont make you feel the feeling of being in a Pay to win
- the weapon and clothes sistem is nice, even if the storage could be bettered
- free

Summary: 
a nice game, can be addictive and requires many brief sessions of play during the day but even if you leave it for few days and then come back nothing disastrous happened.
take it if you are looking for something to distress you for few minutes several times a day, dont if you are looking for a game to start and that keep you playing it for hours without stopping

The game is designed to have you on the verge of making a microtransaction, and there is plenty of reason to. BUT, it is definitely something that can be avoided. That is if you don‚Äôt mind going in for the long haul and grinding for the pleasure of enjoying the game and its surprises when you finally do achieve something. The concept is not bad, I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs a free to play. Honestly though there could be some dlc. There should be an option to change your pip boy HUD color just like the real fallout games. There also should be a trade room where you can trade between vaults since the game is single player and all exists in the same world 1 game for 3 game saves. So, all my vaults numbered as they are technically existing in the wasteland together. 

It would be nice if the devs actually read these. Anyways other than that the 3rd and finally improvement would be more variety in actual gameplay. in other words, if it was a little more immersive and hands on between modes. Adding a mode that is more challenging and rewarding for players would be nice. Otherwise it‚Äôs an idle game with 2 modes random location dungeon crawling with combat that works mostly by itself and the main vault building management mode. Those two modes make up most of your actual gameplay and what you will mostly be looking at. I wish there could have been a few more modes or at least more player involvement. 

The AI in the game could be smarter they could actually do a little more on their own inside the vault. The game is ok considering you spend hours looking at the same things and dragging and dropping like hell. It‚Äôs also a pretty good incest/inbreeder simulator 10/10 because literally the only real way to increase your population is by intermingling mom, dad, son and daughter brother sister cousin‚Äôs nephew‚Äôs niece‚Äôs aunt‚Äôs uncle‚Äôs grandma and grandpas and great ones in the sickest web a family could possibly achieve. Otherwise you will spend days (irl) maybe even weeks‚Äô juts getting 1, just 1 survivor to show up. The real challenge of the game is all luck. hoping that next objective will reward you with a vault lunchbox and some decent cards. And hoping that you will get some of the Nuka-cola bottles too. 

The game is good its addicting and interesting. but the more you play it the more you realize how boring it is and how much of the same it offers. so really if you did just spend money on lunchboxes or Nuka cola bottles the game is now ruined and pretty much a huge waste. because you just have created a finished virtual fish tank and there‚Äôs nothing more to do and all the great stuff you have is pointless cause there‚Äôs nothing it REALLY does. It‚Äôs all just a simulator that you play to pass the time. It‚Äôs a cool concept but they could do more with t if they really are taking it seriously. Flash game Inbreeder sim 5.5/10.

Don't be turned off by the app/iphone game vibe. There is a huge amount of content here, with incredible polish. Must play for Fallout fans. And you can't beat the price. Not a hint of scam as of this review. They could charge $10 and it would still be worth playing. Pay addons are completely unnecessary and just move the game along faster. 
Beware though, it can be tricky and its very possible to screw up your vault early on. Don't hesitate to restart if you did something stupid in the first few hours of gameplay. this is the third time I am playing it, first appstore, then online and now on steam. So I know what to expect. combat is entirely SPECIAL based, weapon stats are dmg only and armor only boosts stats. But, that just happen just a minute before I got another 2 for free: one from a Lunchbox from quest and one from Objective completion. [i]"WTF!? Are you kidding me!?"[/i] And then [i]"Okay, just take it as buy-one-get-two-free"[/i].

But then time passed for another hours, that I started to lose my appetite. Few moments later when I open steam overlay I see something disturbing: [b]SAVE EDITOR GUIDE[/b]. F-ING HELL!? I edit my save immediately, give it full 999999 number in all text box, and play it a little bit just to feel bored even more, because no challenge, so I revert my save to my original unedited one, and play for another hours, finishing all room upgrade, unlocking all room until I get to unlock Nuka-Cola bottler, then there is my bore comes again, even stronger.

And after 13 hours, I think I don't want to play this anymore.

What an incredibly awesome gem of a game.  With it's roots on mobile devices as a persistent world, you take oversite of a vault.  By building various rooms that bestow applicable assets to your vault, you can build a thriving community.  Outfits and weapons can be found throughout the wasteland while questing outside of the safety of you vault.  Did I say safety?  Well, mostly, but you'll have to fend off attacks by raiders from time to time.  There are also fires and attacks from infestations of the local fauna.  Quests offer fun mini-games and offer you a chance to find some valuable loot.  Weapon and Clothing crafting are present, and the occasional appearance from the Mysterious Stranger and a bit of "Where's Waldo" as you try to locate him in your vault rounds out the experience.  I cannont more highly recommend this game, especially if you have an experience with the Fallout world.

***Don't spend money on this game unless you plan on manually backing up your save files regularly***

I was enjoying the game and spent money on the vault starter pack for it. A few days later my power went off while playing and when I reopened the game my save would not load. I did some research and found that this is a common problem. The game is basically constantly writing to the save file so if anything interrupts it (game crashes, windows crashes, computer turns off) there's a very good chance it will corrupt your save file.

That wouldn't be so bad if you could at least get the content you paid for and use it on a new save game. But you can't, believe me I tried. Steam Support tells you "it's a consumable item" and refuses to reissue or refund it. Bethesda Support tells you that they can't do anything and you have to talk to Steam.

If you still want to play the game and especially if you are going to spend money on it, download a utility to regularly back up the game save file so you don't lose your progress/money when your game ends up corrupted.

Also: You might think, "But won't I be able to restore my save from Steam Cloud?" Nope, the corrupted save gets uploaded to the cloud so you're screwed there too.

Fallout Shelter is an excellent mobile game based on the Fallout series. Originally released on the Apple store, not much has changed in the PC port except for a few updates and tweaks. Essentially you are tasked as the Overseer of a vault, which you can choose to populate and design however you choose. Time management and planning skills are necessary, as you are faced with problems like radroaches and fires. You also need to manage your resources and the people in your vault wisely. Like the other games in the Fallout series, it is a unique addition, and it's free-to-play, but not pay-to-win structure is a bonus.

In Fallout Shelter, the player takes on the role of overseer of a vault from the Fallout franchise.

You can construct twenty four different rooms within your vault, each of which serves a specific purpose. The dining room and water treatment facility will generate food and water to keep your people alive, while the power plant will generate electricity to keep all your rooms operational. You can increase your population by using a radio room to attract new settlers from the wasteland, and you can place male and female dwellers into living quarters so that they‚Äôll have children who will grow into adults. Other rooms will let you craft stimpacks, radaway, weapons and outfits (which boost the wearer‚Äôs SPECIAL stats).

Each room is linked to a SPECIAL stat (for example, the power plant requires strength) so ideally you need to assign people to work in rooms that make use of their best attributes. There are separate rooms dedicated to improving each of a dweller‚Äôs SPECIAL stats.

You can also build an Overseer‚Äôs office, which will allow you to send teams of 3 people on quests. Unfortunately this is where the game becomes extremely flawed.

The story on these quests is almost non-existent. Its mostly a case of ‚Äúwe need to find a thing‚Äù, ‚Äúoh look here is the thing‚Äù or ‚Äúwe need to find a person‚Äù, ‚Äúsorry you just missed them, try looking in this other location‚Äù. Fallout games usually have varied dialogue choices and multiple ways to solve quests. Fallout Shelter even has an achievement for making 25 dialogue choices during quests, but this is misleading. Most quests don't actually have any choices, and you can't control what your people say. My achievements page shows that I've completed 33 quests and only made 17 dialogue choices. This means that literally half the quests have 0 choices, and the other half have a total of 1 choice each.

The combat is also terrible. During quests you‚Äôll fight the usual Fallout enemies ‚Äì raiders, feral ghouls, mole rats, radroaches, radscorpions, deathclaws. (These creatures will also periodically attack your vault, which is a complete waste of time ‚Äì 3 enemies making a suicidal run against my 100+ vault population is not even a challenge). Your people attack on a cooldown timer, so they'll fire 3 times and then wait about 10 seconds before firing 3 more times, repeat. Enemies seem to attack quicker, so you just sit there thinking "you're taking damage idiot, fire back" while your people just stand there doing nothing.

The most infuriating part is that sometimes your people will randomly decide to move to a different position instead of attacking. But this serves no purpose. They aren‚Äôt moving to get into attack range. I've seen guys equipped with a sniper rifle move into melee range, and guys with a melee weapon or shotgun run to the other end of the room. Its just stupid. After making sure your people are equipped with weapons that have the highest damage values, the player will mostly just watch the combat play out, and occasionally click icons to do critical hits, and use stimpacks or radaway to heal your guys when they're on low health. If they die you can pay caps to resurrect them after the quest ends.

There‚Äôs also lots of waiting. Its a free to play game with microtransactions that was originally on mobile devices, so obviously the whole game is set up to try to make you spend money to skip the waiting. When you send people on quests, it can take anywhere from 2 to 15 real world hours for them to arrive there (and the same time to travel back to the vault after completing or failing the quest). You can also only have a maximum of 3 active quest teams, with a fully upgraded Overseer‚Äôs office. That‚Äôs 9 people on quests, even if you‚Äôve got 100 guys in your vault. You have to wait hours for babies to be born, and more hours for them to grow into adults so you can assign them to work rooms. You have to wait hours to train SPECIAL stats. You have to wait hours to craft stuff. Its pretty much a case of play for 20 minutes, get to the point where you can‚Äôt do anything else, close the game and come back a few hours later. But of course, you can use nuka cola quantum to skip the waiting and do stuff instantly, which you can either buy with real money, or occasionally find for free on quests.

Now, maybe you can say these criticisms don‚Äôt count, because the game is FREE. But when deciding whether or not to play a game, you don‚Äôt just think about the money. You think about the time investment as well. I‚Äôve put 18 hours into Fallout Shelter, and unfortunately I can‚Äôt say that I ever really enjoyed it.

Okay, this might come off as a tad hypocritical seeing as I do put time into this game and I do enjoy it despite what it is. But the thing is, what it is, is a skinner box game. Seeing as it is a mobile port this is hardly surprising as the majority of such games fall into that category, in fact I even used to play it on my pad before it came to pc up until the glasses patch where 90% of all dwellers were stupidly given glasses for some reason.

For what it's worth its not among the worst of such kinds of games, the replacement currency of nuka cola bottles aren't super rare or anything and lunch boxes, pet boxes and Mr. Handy boxes are all available as drops, nothing is really behind a pay wall so with patience it is very much a free to play game if you want it to be and have the willpower and patience required. But having said that, that's like saying it's a mild form of cancer. These types of games really shouldn't exist in their current form, and while I'm aware that having that opinion and still playing the game isn't very conducive, I can only shrug at that. I care, but I don't care enough to meaninglessly boycott and trying to drum up support for the cause, that's just the sad truth of it.

But I cannot in good conscience give this game a thumbs up, even if I can enjoy it, because I'm as far away from the target audience of these kinds of games as humanly possible, heck I even have it as an ironclad principle to never pay a single dime for something I can get for free (within legal limitations ofc). But the target audience for games like these, are gambling addicts, people who chase endorphines by clicking buttons and seeing flashing lights, dinging sounds and seeing bars slowly fill up, the proverbial Pavlovian dogs of humanity, the weak and vulnerable. The cynical mobile developers even call these people whales, and they are the small percentage of f2p players which keep monsterous games like these afloat. Because they actually pay for these games, and they pay ALOT. Much more than what is advisable and sane, because they're addicts, because they can't help it.

It's especially disgusting for a well established developer who are already making tons of money on actual games to dive into this cesspool side of mobile gaming. And I am a bit ashamed of being passively an accomplice in this but at least I'm not paying for it and never will, so there's that.

-

As for game mechanics, there are some ways you're getting screwed. One of which is the UI and the Rush mechanic. While it may say that it's 30% chance for an incident to happen, it's probably more accurate to say that you have about a 30% chance for an incident NOT to happen. I'm in no way exaggerating this, if it says 30% or higher, you're almost guaranteed for it to fail. I've even had it say 18% and it still failed twice in a row. Statistics-wise this may be possible, but it is in no way probable and I've had it happen with such consistency that I can guarantee that the UI is lying to you and like with all skinner box games/badly weighted RNG in general similar to one armed bandits, the odds are weighted against you.

Another failing of the UI is not giving you the information you require. There's no hard data being displayed on how much of a resource you are currently using, there's only a little line on a bar giving a weak indication. The further to the right the line is on the bar, the more of the resource you're using. But there's no compilation info available on how much you're producing in total, at what rate you're earning versus losing resources, so you're constantly either overproducing or struggling.

The available in game help is extremely lackluster and doesn't go into detail regarding anything either. Like how anything actually works. Is it better to have one power station with a full staff or two with half staff in each? Is it better to have two unupgraded power stations versus a single upgraded one? Is it better to have a few fully trained workers and are there any stats besides the primary room one and luck that matters at all? Does having low luck affect the rush mechanics somehow without it showing in the UI? What's the difference (if any) between the different types of weapons? Is it like in Fallout that they simply use different S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats (which is bound to become pointless once you've maxed all stats) or is all combat dependant on the same stats no matter the weapon? Does the DPS rate differ? Is there any reason whatsoever not to always use the weapon with the strongest attack available? 
None of this is mentioned or explained. 

And while some of these questions could no doubt be answered using spreadsheets and careful monitoring, why should the player need to put that much effort in? Having crossed the boundary from mobile to pc, I see no reasons why this game shouldn't be held to the same standards as normal games, at least when it comes to things like clarity in UI and explanations available. Mobile games look and function the way they do because of the limitations of the medium, these same limitations disappear when we play it on PC, so there's really no valid excuse for it, especially when they hope to monetize it the same way on here.

Another way a mobile game just isn't fit for pc consumption is the way you're intended to play. Mobile games are meant to be played a few minutes at a time, and this game even goes as far as to punish you for actually actively playing it. It does so in the form of incidents, which range from fires to various raiders.
Now, one could argue that without these events, it would get kind of boring with nothing happening and there are some events which even have some inherent reward to them, for instance defeating the raiders gives you caps as well as some random drops and even recipes, which is great. 
But there are also events which give no rewards and are only there to punish you/discourage you from playing at any length of time and waste your resources, and sadly every single other event except the raiders are just that. Feral ghouls, mole rats and death claws definitely belong to this category. You get no reward for killing them and you're usually forced to waste rad aways and stim paks when they appear. On top of that, you can't build anything as everything goes into lockdown mode when an incident occurs. 

The longer you play for, the more incidents occur. The severity of the incidents also goes up as you upgrade rooms and build up your base. So it's not a good idea to upgrade too many rooms too early.
I would also wager that the risk of some incidents occuring increase when you have an empty room, and some rooms are always bound to be empty so that could definitely pose a problem depending on how you build your base, as if an incident goes unchecked it will spread to adjacent rooms. You can get around this problem by building rooms like the storage bays and bunk rooms (which are likely to be empty most of the time) separated with one empty level with nothing but 2 elevators on it, but doing so is expensive, requires planning ahead and will only be possible during late game. There's also the possibillity that some of the late game incidents can bypass this, as I haven't really gotten to the very end yet in this version, but I know that so far it works for fires, rad roaches and mole rats at the very least.
But that's only helpful for the empty rooms, incidents can and will still occur in occupied rooms as well and failing a rush (which is bound to happen often seeing as the RNG is heavily weighted against you and the UI is lying to you) results in an incident as well. 

-

Anyways, tl:dr; if you know you lack patience, have a disposition towards addiction and/or is just under the age of 18, I would strongly advise you to stay far away from this game. I  gain some enjoyment out of this game despite it being what it is, not because of what it is and only because I'm not its intended target audience.

This is one of those games that either wears off reeeeeeeally fast, or draws you so far in you can't stand to be away from your vault for too long.

For me it wore off just after the first week. 

There is terrible balance in this game, very unforgiving and seldom rewarding. When you ask for assistance via the forums, everyone tells you the same thing "Don't get more than 49 dwellers until EACH AND EVERY DWELLER HAS A FREAKIN' LEGENDARY WEAPON AND OUTFIT." Basically "Don't play the game" 

Best thing you can do is build about 6 rooms, get a mister handy, put a Diner, Power plant, and Water treatment on the same floor, and simply never play again.

Radscorpions will stop your game  solid, and whats worse if yo utake too long to defeat one, as soon as you do kill it, another oine spawns right after the other. Draining power faster than Mole Rats, draining health quickly, AAAAAAAAAND dealing radiation damage. Whats the official solution? Don't exceed 49 dwellers. 

Want to rush the medbay at 25% chance after a sequence of repeated radscorpion attacks? Too bad that 25% is all it took and it failed. The punishment? A radscorpion attack. Have fun.


I recommend the game to try, but I don't recommend playing past the first week. The game runs on REAL TIME meaning everything matters because you have to wait REAL TIME for things to happen. And it takes less than 5 seconds for all that work and progress to drop dead. 

Everything you know about Fallout, the armor, the weapons... .you can forget about all that because only SPECIAL applies. If you so much as STAND in a room with an enemy in the room on the other end of the room, you will steadily lose health and/or gain radiation damage. 

Expand your vault, but do not progress. Kinda an oxy moron isn't it? Because morons are the ones who programmed this asinine combat system.

While a quirky little human ant farm, it has MUCH WORK to be done before it is polished and becomes actually fun.

Sadly the forum community finds their illogical solutions more reasonable than admiting the fact that the game might just be flawed and needs a few patches, if only just better in-game instruction.

I'll keep playing it for a few minutes a day, I'll give it that much of a chance, but so far after ignorantly evicting about 7 perfectly useful dwellers in hope of curbing the radscorpion madness, I had a molerat attack that spread faster than I could assign dwellers to the room. The result was half the vault dying as the mole rats were in every single room except the Overseer's Office and I couldn't possibly keep tabs on every single dweller, happieness went from 96% to 82% in less than a moment.... not to mention the dwellers were still recoverign from the previous 2 consecutive radscorpion attacks, in whihc the medbay was drained of all its stimpacks fighting that one.....

Christ, the game needs work. Some game mechanics need some changes... 
No one gives a mole-rat's arse about my opinion though, I'm pretty sure on Bethesda's perspective, as long as they get people buying their glorious Quantums and lunchboxes they probably won't do anything about the game balance.

"Play by our rules, wuss. We are right and you are wrong."

If this was played on a mobile phone I think it would be more enjoyable as a PC game (and I use the term game very loosely) it's awful. Basically a waiting simulator. Click to gather power, food or water and then wait. Once the rooms are ready click again to gather. 
The people do level up and you can give them items and send them into the wasteland to explore / do quests. Each person also has different attributes making them work better in a given area of the vault. Drag and drop them into a room and that's it. You can also get them to breed to make more people. That's basically the whole game play for 10% of the time, the other 90% of the time is basically waiting for something to do.
You do get rooms come under attack at random and your people deal with this themselfs but you can also micro manage your people to stop them from being hurt to much.

 I can see that after a lot of time and effort spent this could eventually become a semi decent micro management game, however getting to that point is itself a challenge with basically nothing to do but wait or pay real money to speed things along.

It is worth stating that the game continues to run in real time (1 minute of real life time = 1 minute of game time and each day in game takes 24 hours) even if you are not playing. So if you want a game that you log in for a couple of minutes click a few things and then leave alone while you play something else until the next day you can do that but it's not the sort of game your going to want to boot your computer up to rush back to. It's clearly aimed at mobile user where this sort of short term play works best. As a PC game...

[i] Vault-Tec. We'll be there! [/i]

Fallout Shelter is a free-to-play base/resource management spinoff from the critically acclaimed 'Fallout' franchise by Bethesda Game Studios, and runs on the now-familiar Unity engine. The game originally released on mobile devices (iOS, Android, etc) in 2015, but has been recently ported to and released on Steam at the beginning of April 2017.

Fallout Shelter places the player into the role of Overseer of a Vault, and has to build rooms, manage resources, keep attackers and threats out, and keep their Dwellers happy by assigning them to the workplace that suits them best depending on their S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats. A Dweller with high Strength performs best in a Power Generator, a high Perception works best in a Water Treatment Center, and so on. As well as workplaces, Dwellers can also be assigned to Residences (where Male and Female Dwellers can... *ahem* , leading to the birth of a new Dweller), Weapon/Outfit Workshops, Radio Stations, and many other rooms that I have yet to unlock.

As well as managing your Vault, you can also send out Dwellers into the Wasteland to find items, weapons and other items, or on Quests, which yield harder challanges, but greater rewards. Daily reports are also handed in each day, measuring up the average happiness of your Vault and rewarding you depending on the level of happiness. 

Life in the Vault is not all a bunch of flowers, however. Your Dwellers will find themselves in danger from threats both inside and outside of the Vault they live in: From minor workplace incidents such as fires and Radroach infestations, to bigger dangers such as Raider attacks and Deathclaw assaults. Without adequate weapon power and protective armor, Dwellers will face little to no chance of survival against those which threaten them on a daily basis.

Gameplay-wise, Fallout Shelter is designed to be a game that you have to come back to at least once every day for half an hour or more, as to cater to any uncollected resources, any new Dwellers who are seeking to move in, and constantly shuffling around and managing storage space and assigning new jobs to everyone. Another reason is travel/return times when a group of Dwellers travel to a quest location, which can vary from half an hour to over a day's time - much like the kind of gameplay you see in mobile games. Which kind of makes sense, considering this was originally a mobile game.

Following the tradition of obtainable 'premium' resources in mobile games, Fallout Shelter provides an in-game store where players can buy Lunchboxes (Containing random items and outfits), pets which can give major buffs to individual Dwellers, and Nuka-Cola Quantum, which instantly ends the cooldown period of any time-based activity. In most mobile games, 'premium' resources are a major curse to the games fun factor, which usually harasses players to cough up real-life money just so they can avoid waiting 48+ hours just for a weapon to finish upgrading, or something else which follows the same principal. However, Fallout Shelter gets the big thumbs-up from me by giving the player FAR more than just a few chances to obtain Lunchboxes and Nuka-Cola Quantum: In one minor Quest, I recieved 5 Nuka-Cola just by looting cabinets, and then a further 3 Nuka-Cola and a Lunchbox as Quest rewards. And this was only the first quest in the storyline chain!

The games graphics are a big change to what most Fallout players are used to in the main games. While Fallout 3 and 4 have realistic graphics and big open-world enviromments, Fallout Shelter ditches this for 2D cartoon graphics and toned down violence, making the franchise accessible to younger players and those who lack beefy PC specs. The games sound effects and music sound great too.

The only bad things I have to say about Fallout Shelter are perhaps the combat animations which lack dynamic elements (Imagine this: 2 Dwellers and 2 Raiders running about in a room, the Raiders are armed, they fire off 2 shots, then just stay in a standing animation for a few seconds before firing again), and the fact that the game doesn't really have too much of an endgame goal: Sure, completing all of the Quests, filling up your Vault to max Dweller capacity and unlocking all of the rooms, weapons, outfits and pets will certainly take a very long time indeed, but there's no big endgame boss or encounter to fulfill.

9/10. [b] By avoiding the problems which plague most mobile games, Fallout Shelter manages to be a brilliant base management game which entices the player into caring about their Vault and Dwellers for a very long time indeed. The fact that the game is completely free too only adds to the games appeal factor. Very highly recommended. [/b] ^.^

TL;DR - Don't spend money on this game, especially if you play on multiple devices, or care about your save data syncing correctly.

Fallout Shelter is worth checking out for the first time, or returning to if you haven't played since it initially launched on mobile (lots of interesting new depth with crafting and quests).

The fun just ended for me, though. Lost a week's worth of progress due to Steam Cloud Save shenanigans (booted up a laptop I'd left the game running on over a week ago). The game generates 1 backup save that I found after digging for a while, but it was overwritten before I realized what had happened. Lost over a week's worth of progress.

Syncing is destructive with no regard for time spent in game. There's no confirmation/indication that you're stomping local saves with cloud saves.

I've written cloud save integration, for Unity games even. I know the Steam Cloud API is garbage, but you work around it by building redundancy into your local saves, then sync the whole lot of those, and implement your own UI to guide users through reconciling cloud vs. local data.

I'm flabbergasted that you're taking money from people with such a terrible cloud save solution in the game. Especially where redeemed purchases can be affected.

A great and truly Free To Play game.  It plays both like an idle, and an active game, where you get more action and fun for watching the game play, but can also do a few things and close the game, letting things happen why you are away.  You can get everything you can buy, if you just play patiently and enjoy the game.

It has some rules for when it is not maximized that I don't quite understand.  I think you are supposed to be able to idle it in the background while playing other things and be alright, but I've had harmful incidents occur while idling that could have been disasterous if I wasn't better set up.  So I try to either play active, or exit the game if I'm not ready to watch over it closer.

Also, there are some issues if you play to expand too quickly, and more harmful enemies might come before you are ready for them... the moral, take your time, and be prepared (possibly look up some guides as well)

The game plays so well without having to pay, that I'm actually having a hard time trying to find something to spend a little money on, because I feel the game deserves it, but I can't find anything to buy that I won't get for free with a little patience anyway.

First off: it's hard to not recommend you at least try something that is free. Go out there and see if you like it. The game is definitely better than it was on launch. There are quest lines, silly "dialogues", random locations when exploring the wasteland, and more.

That aside, there are some major issues with the design of this game. Or, rather, lack of its re-design for PC. And I am not talking about the timers present everywhere. The game was originally designed for tablets, where one "button" and dragging can do everything. This doesn't exactly translate well to PC though.

Steering. Both left and right mouse buttons can be used to move your view around the vault. They are also used to move dwellers around. Both done in a click and drag fashion. As the time goes, you will have your entire screen consisting of rooms filled with dwellers. Guess how many times you will drag the wrong thing around. Spoiler: quite often. At least you can also pan the view via edges of the screen. Then there's the problem that when you drag the dwellers around. The active zones for each rooms are probably their back walls, because the further away from the centre of the screen you are, the less sense it makes as to where you need to drag a person to drop them in a target room. Far enough up or down that zone is literally outside the room you are aiming at. Which brings us the a vide spread problem with this game...

Precision. Precision is something that this game does not require, but sadly also does not exactly let us participate in either. Rooms are three dimensional, with sprites of our dwellers and the enemies moving between front and back. This helps the immersion, but also causes a lot of problems of clicking on the correct thing. If there's a lootable object or corpse behind your characters, you will have to play around with the camera to hopefully see it, and only then click it. Health bars of the enemies also love to be layered one on top of another, so that you can't see the effect of your shots unless you are attacking the enemy most towards the foreground. Targeting specific enemies can also be a nightmare.

Same precision issues go for automatic prompts for using stimpacks and radaways. Radiation damage can reduce your dweller's healthbar down to 50% at most. Stimpacks heal 50% health. It would be logical to remove radiation before applying healing if you have full radiation poisoning. Prompts will usually have you heal dwellers first, then use radaway. It takes them quite some time to realize that it's time for a radaway before stims. "Well let's do it manually", you'd say. Great idea! Except you need to select your dwellers by sniping their legs, because clicking too high will apply the prompt above their heads. Guess hitting that prompt was too precise for tablets, so its hitbox is massive to compensate.

Then there are some utterly weird design choices like doing a critical hit automatically applying all stimpak and radaway prompts. Why? I couldn't tell you if my life depended on it. To hell with efficiency. Applying a stimpak on a fully irradiated person before radaway so that it heals maybe 2/3 of what it could is a great idea! The game knows better, shut up.

Then there are minor things like the mysterious stranger mechanic. He will randomly appear around the vault along with a sound que. You then have a limited time to find and click him for caps reward. Except the game just loves to drown that que sound with other sounds (so that you don't even know it's happening) or, better yet, give you the que and then immediately proceed to start a random event (e.g. raider attack) and take over your camera to shove said event in your face. Have fun having only half of the very short time to find the mysterious stranger. That is, after you use half of that to get the camera back to where it was.

This game has issues that could've been easily avoided. It's still playable though. And free. So give it a shot and decide for yourselves.

Having tried to get into the game over the weekend, I finally said "screw it" and uninstalled. I think I'd enjoy it if there was a casual mode where I could play around with the systems without things being ruined by an RNG-driven failure cascade, but it's incredibly unsatisfying to see a Vault representing a significant span of time ruined because you failed six dice rolls in a row.

On the plus side, the game's handling of offline time is far better than my last game of this sort, State of Decay. Here the game's representation of what went on while you were away feels fair, as opposed to that game's ridiculously punitive penalties for spending even one second with the game closed.
Quite addicting, and incredibly fun. However it can sometimes be a bit tedious, it all depends on how many resources you have!

A strategy game in which we manage our own crypt.
We give orders to the residents and build other necessary rooms.
In our crypt we must take care of contentment, drink and food.
Our base is exposed to attacks by bandits and monsters. That is why it is worth equipping every inhabitant with a weapon and a good armor.
We can send our residents on various trips in which we can find many useful things.
To facilitate or speed up the game, lunch books and Nuka-Cola bottles were added.
For me 6.5/10.
