LOTS of bugs.  Suffers (sometimes severe) stuttering at some point in the growth of the game depending on the power of your device (have a platform that is pretty close to bleeding edge or be prepared to limit growth substantially).  Controls are imprecise and create errors in game play (moving Dwellers instead of the vault view, etc...).  The game has an auto zoom that is not optional and forces a redisplay at the most inopportune of moments.  Overlapping events make game play difficult, especially when the auto zoom feature decides to enact itself.  The cost of packages is too high (just because you CAN get that price doesn't mean that you SHOULD).  Important Dweller info is scattered over multiple menus making it difficult to evaluate moving or changing resources (weapons and armor).  Great concept, fun to play (and I DO still play it, for the moment.  But, I am getting more and more frustrated), but loaded with annoying little things that make what could be a great game into something much less than it could be.   I'd give it a middle reccomendation if it existed, but since my choice is only Yes or No, it will have to be a No.

I have played Fallout Shelter on PC using Bethesda Launcher (without spending money) for some time and now on Steam for short amount of time (spent about 10‚Ç¨) and here's my thoughts.

I think some people are overreacting when it comes to Fallout Shelter in my opinion. Yes, it's free-to-play game with microtransactions, yes it's mobile game port, and yes it is sorta cash-grab game, but some people ignore the fact that you can manage without using real money to buy lunchboxes, nuka-cola quantum etc. Since this is a spin-off game, I don't mind that it doesn't have anything else to do with Fallout other than the setup, characters and equipment. It isn't a canon, so just having characters like Three-Dog in your vault is actually a bit funny and it doesn't take away from the main series.

I might be greedy capitalist for saying this, but I don't mind the microtransactions in this game. It's a free-to-play game, so Bethesda needs to get money from somewhere and thats OK in my book. You can manage your vault without spending money if you don't build too quickly and take a lot stimpaks for quests, while also saving some of them incase of accidents and raids. In fact, you can get lunchboxes and other stuff (that can be bought with real money from shop) from challenges and quests. In-app purchases mainly boosts your speed in gameplay. While it is technicaly a pay-to-win, I should mention that this isn't a multiplayer game, so it shouldn't be that bad. If there is something to complain about MT's in Fallout Shelter it's the fact that you lose every lunchbox when you lose the game. It doesn't transfer your items to other vaults even if you wanted that, so money would not be wasted. If I'm wrong on this issue, please correct me.
It's purely your choice if you want to spend your money on Fallout Shelter. Find out what they do, what you could get and are you willing to spend money on them? 

But what about the game itself? I'll make this short, because I'm lazy.

GOOD:
+Art style is typical Fallout and vault dwellers' look is based on Fallout vault boys/girls
+Though limited at early stages, you can customize your vault dwellers and your vault
+Legendary characters and items from Fallout 3 and 4 (No New Vegas unfortunately :( )
+Quests and random encounters offer something to do and you usually get good rewards.
+Simple gameplay, simple fun
+Free updates that usually add something new (quests are in my opinion the best one so far) to game and aren't just bug fixes
+It's free and a good time waster. Nothing too serious

NEUTRAL:
*It's up to you if spending money on in-app purchases are worth it. They speed up the game, but it's not mandatory to survive
*Since this is a mobile game, it's about doing something for 5-10 minutes and most of the time is about waiting
*Obviously this game isn't for everyone and it might be boring to some people. Understandably so

BAD:
-At later stages, the enemies are bullet sponges and that includes radroaches too (seriously?!!!)
-Some enemies have BS abilties (like teleporting) and weird enemy spawns (raider place with mole rats at front entrance), though understandably for gameplay reasons
-While microtransactions aren't that bad, however you don't want to lose since you lose everything when it happens
-Lacks the global inventory for your bought items

If there is a better mobile game, please tell me in the comments and also let me know if I missed something important or if my review has mistakes. For now, I think this is one of the better mobile game in the market.

The combat system in this game is stupid... The visuals are not representative of what is actually determining the outcome of the combat.
It is just time based like everything else in this game... 

Here is an example... If you have 2 people shooting at 3 radroaches the roaches will die at random times even when your people are not shooting at them... And your people will suffer damage overtime by the enemies just being in the room with them... The equipment and weapons you stick on your people just improve these times but there is no real combat even going on in this game.

And this was what i thought the meat of the game could have been... But everything in this game is just timers timers timers... Nothing at all else... Not the combat or the exploration... building or relationships between your people... It is all just timers and randomness.

Its lazy game design.

can't recommend, it has horrible game design flaws and the port from mobile to pc made it worse.
- crucial tips like "the special endurance increases the dwellers hp each time they level up." have to be seen at random during 1 secong long loading times or by going through wikis / reading guides.
- even worse the room to increase endurance is only unlocked after your vault increased drasticly in size. So resulting in dwellers that have little to no hp and radiation resitance (VERY IMPORTANT STATS)
- so you name dwellers after friends and families and what ever you fancy and then realise that they half way to max level and have next to no hp. So the game encourages making vaults with dwellers you care about but then fucks you over by not giving you crucial information and ruining their stats in the long term.
- those stats become ever more important, if your vault increases in size stronger monsters attack and so far the worst is the radscrorpion, he teleports / digs from room to room, radiates and kills ever dweller in the room and more than once even a full room of highly equiped dwellers can't kill him AND WORSE HE SIPHONS ENERGY, ONE SINGEL RADSCROPION CAN BRING YOU FROM 4000 ENERGY TO 500. It's mindblowingly stupid 

So you might think now "hey just don't level your characters up until they have endurance maxed" which is what i thought but then you come to realise that the port is utter shit because the game more often then not interprets your "i click in the VERY FAR CORNER of this room to harvest the energy and not click on a dweller." to HE MUST WANT TO LEVEL UP THE DWELLER.

This can be a very addictive game because it combines the best of the beloved [i]Fallout[/i] lore and characters with the game mechanics of [i]Sim Tower[/i]. The main (perhaps only) downside to this free-to-play game is that exists for a single reason: to make cash money (for the developers) for perks purchased in the game. For this reason, the wait-to-complete resource gathering can be very tedious in the beginning stages of the game, and you (like me) might find yourself ALT+TABbing out of the game to do other things while these timers run out. If you can weather these bits, expanding your underground empire can actually be quite satisfying.

I'm really surprised with this one. There are quite a few free to play games based on popular series, which aren't free and are made only to milk some money from fans. How is Fallout Shelter? It's not pay to win. Sure, you can spend some money and have some things done faster, but that's everything. I played (while making this review) this game for almost 13 hours in total and there wasn't a single moment when I thought that I need to spend real money for something. Maybe the beggining of the game is kind of slow and boring, but once you get quests and build something more than few basic rooms, that's when it starts to get really fun. And it's all for free. Try it out yourself and see if you will like it.

I did try and tire of Fallout Shelter back in 2015 when it came out for Android. As a Fallout fanboy I of course clicked again when I saw the Steam debut. Two years ago I got bored of the micromanagement right quick and called it a day, this time around I found the game (now) has quests and quests I have been doing for almost the entirety of my 19 hours.

The game's been designed to make you buy power-ups, but as things such as VAC bans are hardly an issue here, I Cheat Engined myself 99999 Nuka Cola Quantums and skipped any and all countdowns. Some of them would have been a real pain - 11 days just to craft 1 theme to get 1/8 of an achievement, for example. Did manage to get all but 3 achievements - 100 objectives, 50 raider attacks and 20 legendary dwellers are too much of a grind even for someone as pedantic as myself. Human lifespans do have a limit to them.

This'll hopefully be the only Fallout game I'll ever give a negative review to. Although Shelter does get you hooked very well from the start, quests are mildy funny and it feels good to score phat loot, without hacking you wouldn't even have that. So unless you're a vampire and don't mind waiting for 14 hours for your dweller to get back - there are better Fallouts, there are better micromanagement games.

[h1]Post-Apocalyptic Human Resource Manager + Landlord simulator!!![/h1]

Yes, this is one of those "PAY ME, I'M A MOBILE GAME" games and no, I'm not a fan of the [i]Fallout[/i] series.  Though I've seen many people boot up [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] and thought to boot it up.  Needless to say, [i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is a non-canon spinoff of the original series.

Essentially, you get to play the "Human Resource Manager" and a "Landlord" in a vault filled with post-apocalyptic survivors.  Make them make your base thrive by generating food, electricity, and water.  Additionally, you can have your survivors make medicine and health kits as you build more and more rooms.  Of course, you're going to need in-game money too, which you earn by sending survivors on quests (or into the wasteland...they pick up resources you can use as well), leveling up survivors, daily bonuses for happy survivors, rushing survivors to complete tasks (risky since incidents may occur), or by spotting the "mysterious stranger" who appears in your base at times...good luck finding him in bigger bases, though...

The look and feel of this game may feel familiar to a few Nintendo RPG fans as the aesthetic feels almost exactly like [i]Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door[/i].  2D characters with similar animations while moving about in a 3D world.  I don't know if people who worked on that game worked on this one, but I feel like it was a good call to make this game feel more casual.

Overall, you give survivors a shelter in exchange for them becoming your slaves to push around.  I'm actually surprised that Bethesda is just giving this game away for free given the quality of it.  Yes, there are microtransactions, but I think you'll get along just fine without them.  Only sink money into this game if you really loved how Bethesda presented it or if you want to excel further into this game.  Sadly, after a while, this game does end up feeling dull.  Play in short bursts for higher satisfaction.

So I was super excited for this game, played it on mobile a little bit and liked it but I never really can get into mobile games so when this came out on here I was more than happy to try it. I played for a bit on a test vault to get the feel of it and then made a new vault and deleted the old one. I spent almost an entire days time working on this vault (spread out over a few days; not one continuos session) and then one day I get on and my vault is gone! Almost 20 hours of work and $5 in in-game purchases gone. I contacted them about this by email and basically said here's my issue, I would like it if you could recover my vault if that's possible but if not I think I should get my money back. The closest thing to a reply I got was a general email with a list of forums (that I got almost immediately as if they only have the email to send out this auto-reply) which didn't help me at all. I don't think I will be getting any help as it has been a while now since I emailed them so I'm out $5 and a good bit of my time because of this. I don't recommend this game because even though it's a fun game this bug just completely ruins it...

[h1]It's really great game. Really. I may even make the thing that others do. Dividing it's cons and pros.[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
1. You can change your dwellers names.
2. You can rule your dwellers into worst sh*t and they will still love you.
3. You can turn off game's music and listen some '80 songs, like I do. Or not.
4. You get Vault-Tec boxes, Nuka-Cola, Animals, Rare or Legendary Weapons and Outfits by finding them in Vasteland.
5. You don't have to buy anything.
6. Your dwellers love you as you could be their god. And you are.
7. You can make yourself there and be the best over dwellers.
8. Attacks on your Vault are easy, when you equip every dweller with gun. Also attacks are only when you're watching, no attacks while you're not in your Vault. Raiders are only three in group. And they all give caps.

[b]Cons[/b]
1. Start can be a bit painful.
2. You need to be patient. Because otherwise time will be your worst enemy.
3. To upgrade Workshops you need more dwellers. Problem can happen, when you need them, but radio is working slowly and dwellers in living quarters not really want to sex with each other. (radio is better imo)
4. Sometimes reward for Vasteland Quest sucks, so prepare for few bad rewards. But it's rare.

Pretty good game, some issues though. 7.9/10

Since I'm really bad at planning ahead on the spot, I've spent a lot of caps just moving rooms around. (Which is mostly my fault) I recommend looking at the IGN beginner's walkthrough to get a better grasp of the game, instead of me giving a few pointers. They have it all there.

The problems I've had were that it's sometimes really frustrating to click some people on one room to assign them to a problem area or whathaveyou. On the top floors are fine, but you'd think that if you hover your Dweller dead center or around a room it'd go to it, but it skews it a lil' bit above the room the further down the floors you go. 

When problems occur, you have to send your dwellers after the problem. Whether it'd be deathclaws or fires. The game expects you to have all of your dwellers to have good weapons to take care of whatever problem that's happening. The thing I just wish is that if there was an option to select a room and send the nearest dwellers there, or if a radscorpion to pop up it'd send my big guns people. (of course the smaller the rooms the weaker they are, so it should be fine if everyone in that room has a gun)

All in all, my opinion of this game is positive. I mark it 7.9 since the room hitbox issue is really annoying, but hey, it's better than most Free 2 Play games of this nature. 

P.S. Rip Vault 566. Pretty sure they're all dead since I've started working for a week now and haven't paid much attention. 

P.S.S Just make sure that the Minimum for your resource bars is no more than a 3rd if you're going to be busy all day. It should be fine for about 12hrs off-game.

TLDR: get it on your phone instead, this is a straight mobile port and makes for a terrible PC gaming experience.

I spent hundreds of hours playing this game as an interesting/ fun diversion on my phone, however it doesn't translate to the PC well at all. 

The mechanics are based around the idea that you can pick it up for a couple of minutes every few hours, but not really intended for anything more than a few clicks here and there; which doesn't hold up on an actual gaming machine.

They could have done something very interesting with the gameplay, perhaps making the quests from the overseer offices more in depth (with mouse and keyboard controls, why continue to limit the controls/mechanics to "drag character to next room" "drag to target enemy"), or they could have had interesting turn-based/strategic elements; but instead it seems like no effort has been put into making this game anything other than a mobile port and another opportunity to double down on the micro-transaction income.

I really hope they invest some time and effort on making this a more interesting experience on the PC. 
I've got to say the ratings on Steam seem to be for the phone version of this game, putting little effort into evaluating the PC version.

TL;DR:

+ Great time waster
+ Well polished
+ Fun if you like to micromanage
+ Respectable F2P setup
+ It's free! Try it!

While playing Fallout Shelter, I am very aware that I am wasting my time. I can never quite rationalize [i]why[/i] I am giving the game my full attention. However, there's something there. Is it the art design? The RNG loot to collect? I'm not quite sure, but [i]something[/i] is keeping me interested, and playing, hour after hour.

What I definitely do enjoy, is thinking about how I can optimally layout the vault, and distribute the dwellers, so that I am keeping incidents to a minimum, and efficiency close to maximum. The quests are a fun addition since the 1.0 version, and I do appreciate that it's not completely pay-to-win (in that you can get everything without paying, if you were so inclined).

So far, with a maxed out vault in mobile, and 24 hours on the PC version, [b]I haven't spent a single cent on this game[/b]. But I think I will. Not cause I am a victim of a devious F2P scheme, but because I've enjoyed this game enough that the developers and publishers actually deserve it - which is a rarity with F2P titles.

If you are going to play a F2P game, make it Fallout Shelter.

This game is fun and addictive at first when you are first building your vault and trying to establish it. 

Then it becomes a game you can't play much at all as you try to increase the number of your vault dwellers, it takes 3 hours for a woman to give birth and then 3 more hours for a child to grow up and be able to work as children in this game are useless and can't do anything.

So you just check your game every 3 hours and play other games. Though I often would leave the game running when trying to get achievements and do some art. As just sitting there watching a slow paced game is quite boring.

Then once you have reached the amount of dwellers you want in your vault, it's even less time playing as you train them which can take over 8 hours to gain 1 point in a stat and then make better guns which takes around 12 hours for every gun made. And the quests are quite fun, but yet again it takes 3 hours or more for them to travel to the quest location.

But you can skip most of the waiting if you cheat, but I refuse to or spend money on nuka cola to speed up time. You can find nuka cola sometimes but the amount you find is never enough and you can't speed up birth time or child growing up, unless you change your clock on your PC or use some save edit program. But I don't like to mess with things or cheat.

I recommend as you can play it now and then and I play it as I love the Fallout world and the feeling of running my own vault. But that said it's a rather boring job being a overseer.

This is a good game... on a mobile device.

But port it to a PC, and that is where it falls apart. When I play games at my PC, I want to be engaged for hours. This game makes you wait for hours (unless you want to pay tons of money or cheat.) Even though there are "events" every few minutes, you still sit there and wait for those. 

Also this game is very bad to have in a window to the side. If you have multiple monitors, it keeps jumping back to the main monitor if you change the size of it at all. And because it requires your attention every few minutes, it's hard to do something in another window.

Unless you want a game that you play for 5 minutes once or twice a day, I don't recommend this game. And I don't recommend buying their in game items. If you lose your save for any reason, you lose it all.

I suppose the big question on everybodies mind is: This is a waiting game with microtransactions. Are they intrusive?

[i]Absolutely not[/i]. You can pay if you want to and they will accelerate you're progression in the game. That's what they're there for. But that being said I have never felt even once that I [i]needed[/i] to buy them to progress. Even completely destitute of them you can still find lunchboxes ((microtransaction random item drop; may include legendary dwellers or weapons. Also may not)) naturally in the game. You can get them from quests and random daily objectives from time to time. I also got one from a loot chest once.

And it's never like you need those legendary weapons or dwellers, as your (normal) dwellers work they level up to gain a little bit more health and when you actually progress you unlock training rooms to increase their stats. Does it take a long time? Yes. Can you speed it up with microtransactions? Yes. But even a dweller going up from 9 to 10 (max stat) in any category I don't think it was ever over 16 hours. I may need to check that. And it sounds like a long time. Guess what? It's a waiting game. Go to sleep and check it in the morning. The game progresses training and everything else even while closed and your computer is shut off. This isn't something you micromanage.

But of course: Is it fun? Yes. It can genuinely be entertaining to see your Vault expand like most any other waiting and/or strategy game. But what really makes this is how even though it departs from normal Fallout gameplay it VERY much feels like Fallout. Obviously the setting but even down to the character interactions. [u]This little gem actually happened[/u]:

"My birthday is coming up. What are you going to get me?"
"A one-way ticket to the Wasteland."

The punchline? That was her father! HAHAHAHAHAHAHA! ...reminds me of my childhood.

This is a survival sim that's part base builder, and part tower defense. I'm 50+ hours in and I still feel rewarded when I unlock a new piece of gear/weapon/junk. Designing your Vault requires as much skill as you want to invest, but the true beauty of this game is in it's variable ways to play (I have seen some seriously bizaare Youtube builds). 
While Fallout Shelter may not be challenging, it has depth beneath it's cute exterior. 
Yes, it is a Mobile port with mission timers designed for casual play (login, check on dwellers, logout etc.) -but that shouldn't be a problem unless this is the only game in your library. 
Breeding a family can be a lot of fun if you're willing to RP, there's loads of things to find for collectionists, and all the easter eggs/ 'nods' /cookies for those familiar with the source material. 

all that aside..

this game can be uncomfortably grindcentric
the mission timers often feel unforgiving
your efforts are rewarded with junk for crafting items, caps to buy more junk, dwellers to equip, pets to help dwellers
it's a circuitous loop without end. <<<that's right! Does this game have an ending? NO. It's a Free To Play ... FOREVER!!
also
the "Pay to Win" nonsense, is just that.. there is no winning and the microtransactions are completely optional. So, if you're willing to invest time, and you're not allergic to grinding, Fallout Shelter will warm your feel-goods.

Fallout Shelter is a free to play side-scrolling City Building RTS game.  It worked on Win 10, looked ok, sounded ok, played ok.  Now ported to PC from the mobile versions that the Devs made first.  You can move your mobile saves to the PC version.  Game is completely themed with artwork and lore from the Fallout series of games.  Gameplay is a fast paced resource gathering and base building with increasing wait timers.  Has many quests you can complete and random goals to fullfill. 

Has a tutorial and help tips but still leaves some mystery that you have to figure out from reading someone online wiki or trial and error.  Challenging game, especially if you don't know what you are doing or not paying attention. But can get boring once you completely built out your vault and finished all quests. Suggest you find out more info from videos and guides.  You can increase the difficulty of your normal game by several ways and has a Survival mode.  Might be better to play the PC version versa the mobile versions.

You have to actively play the game or you might miss loot or lose money.  Production takes time and you have to click to collect or your people will be idle. People level up, you have to click on them to gather money.  Room disasters pop at random and can spread to other rooms and causing damage if you not attending to it.  A mystery man pops up at random in your base rooms for 10 seconds, you find and click him, you get money.  Cappy and Bottle visits, you have to click on them when they wave or dance.  Pick up base raider bodies for loot. When you save and exit game, everything freezes in base except babies timers, children timers, crafting timers, wasteland exploring and quests travel.  

You get some lunchboxes, Mr Handys, Pets, Nucka Cola for quest rewards and 1 lunchbox every 7ish days of play.  Mr Handy is not very usefull or game changing with certain base builds.  Buying these in the store is not worth the money.  The other stuff you get from lunchboxes are not worth buying lunchboxes with real money in the store.

Has 35 Steam achievements, some easy. Has full controller support, can be played with one hand on mouse.

CONS:
-  Game has RNG loot boxes and events, so Lady Lucky might hate you.
-  Some Gameplay take extremely long amounts of real time to reach.
- Has a bug of corrupting save files which destroys your vault, and Devs have not addressed this problem or not supporting losses,  according to many negative reviews.
- Once you build a good base and have nothing to worry about, game gets boring and a grind. Endgame is to finish the in-game and steam achievements, and to finish the quest chains.

TLDR: Awesome way to waste time, for free.

The thing to remember about this game is that it was designed for mobile.  

Having said that, it is free to play, and you will never NEED to spend a dime.  Not to win, not to progress, not at all unless you just want to.  You may want to, because instant gratification is an illness, and that's fine.  For those unwilling to wait for quests to finish, or who want an item right now instead of working for it (which takes time), fortunately there's a way to buy such things. 

This game is about time and resource management.  It's not exceptionally in-depth, nor is it particularly grim.  If you're looking for a light-hearted time-killer, this is a good one.  If you're a Fallout fan, this game seems primarily based on Fallout 3, featuring familiar faces, weapons, locations, etc.

It is extremely polished for what it is, and without doubt is a finished product.  The gameplay is described as "slow" by many a negative reviewer, and this is unfortunately less than accurate.  There is a good bit of downtime, and that's intentional in a casual game, however, when incidents occur, the pace is quickened considerably as you scramble to organize your dwellers into something resembling preparedness.  

The true joy of a game like this is what you do with it.  It can be a casual experience, a somewhat immersive roleplaying experience, something you're dedicated to checking frequently or once a week.  You can design and develop your vault and the dwellers within as you see fit, though there are advantages to employing some strategy here.  For example, this game is not difficult, though if you build thoughtlessly, you will find it difficult to work with what you have designed.  This game is easy, it is fun, but it is not mindless.

This game was a ton of fun at first when I was able to devote a couple hours to it and just sit down and play. A base building game with characters and a neat character aesthetic design. However, that being said, I have one game-breaking design flaw that I very much dislike: There is no opportunity to pause. I play this on my computer (not a mobile device) so if I have to use the bathroom or go to something like work, I am almost guarenteed to lose all my dwellers in the wasteland, as well and some of my supplies. 

The better rewards in the wasteland exist farther out which requires more time, but if I can't devote the hours needed for them to get out there before recalling them because I have other things to do, such as work or school, it's barely worth sending them out there at all because I need to recall them fairly quickly. 

The addition of a simple pause feature would be hugely helpful and would draw me back into the game very quickly.

First off, I wouldn't consider this a proper game, and I wouldn't give it a score out of 10. It's a distraction, and a fun one in that. Judging from other reviews, it seems alot of users have issue with it being a mobile game, being expected to wait hours to do anything, microtransactions and boring 'gameplay'. Just because it's a mobile game on PC, doesn't mean you're expected to play it like a PC game! I think the progression so far is really fun (I have amassed about 60 dwellers at around level 25, I reckon I'm halfway through the standard progression chain), as your vault and dwellers change aesthetically and in size. You get new features as you play, like the Overseers Office that let you dispatch your dwellers on quests (AKA stimpack simulator) and a wealth of weaponry and other customisation options which fits the universe.

It's a fun experience to boot up before bed or during a revision break to do quests or queue something up for the next time you boot it up. If you're looking for anything more, there're 5 other Fallout games available. I've spent ¬£4.99 on the games starter pack in my initial hours, and have no intention of spending anymore than that, the game doesn't feel pay to win.

Microtransactions. 

Yes the game uses them  - but you can also *totally ignore them* - with no real penalty. 

If you're looking for fast paced then this game isn't it. It's a bit of a grind and many actions take hours - so don't expect to sit down and play for half the day and see any quick wins. Things take time. 

I've been treating this game as something to pop on to for 15 / 20 minutes at a stretch, do a few things and then put down again, only to repeat a few hours later if I fancy it. 

In that, it's really pretty fun and while it's not exactly deep or complex - it does allow you to quickly build up a 'vault' and muck about some more in the Fallout universe. 

Considering it's free - that gets my recommendation. 

That said if they plan on doing a sequel I'd strongly recommend greater depth and control, more missions and events and so on... it's a shallow game made for mobile and it does come across as such. Don't treat it like an in depth PC title and you'll be fine.

It's... okay.

It fits solidly in the catagory of being a waiting game with options to pay to get things done quicker. Nothing is impossible to get without paying for it though. And - if complaints made in the discussion threads are true - paying for things is risky since it's completely possible it'll just take your money and not give you what you paid for. But again there's no reason to pay for it. The game is pretty generous on giving you ample lunchboxes (chests of rare loot) and Nuka Colas (items used to speed up wait times) for free on quests and for accomplishing achievements.

The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats are not what they are in other games. When it comes to combat the endurance (HP) and agility (attack rate) stats are the only factors. Combat is pretty much a [i]"watch the characters do all the work automatically"[/i] thing while you give them a stimpack or radaway when needed. The closest thing you get to any tactical decisions is whether or not you'll use a charged-up critical attack now or save it for later in case it's needed. [i]That's it.[/i]

As a Fallout franchise fan myself I wanted to dabble with it a little. It pokes at my nostalgia. I see a lot of familier weapons and armors from the games. It feels like someone that didn't actually play much of Fallout made it. They may have peeked at the wiki, looked at some screenshots, talked to the devs, ect but they weren't likely actual fans of the series themselves. There were just too many "thats not how it works" moments. Which brings me to...


[h1]Lore Nitpicks[/h1]
[list]
[*]Vaults, in fallout Shelter, send out radio signals to add to their population. In any other Fallout game vaults are pretty xenophobic. Other vaults seem much more happy to see your dwellers visit than they ought to as well. To put this into the realistic light: In fallout 1 you are sent out of your vault to find a water chip. You save your vault eventually - as well as potentially other places depending how you play. But the overseer abandons you because you've been outside of the vault too long and are deemed an outsider for that alone. Your character is left outside to what the overseer can only assume will be your death. Fallout 3's Overseer was even worse.

[*]Deathclaws appear in packs similar to molerats or radroaches. In any other version of this series when you get a whiff of a single deathclaw you're on high alert. In this case however you brawl through 10 of them to get through a room. This game failed [i]so hard[/i] on what makes a deathclaw a deathclaw.

[*]In some quests feral ghouls talk to the vault dwellers. [u]Feral[/u] ghouls; the ones that have rotted out minds and are completely senseless zombies that just scream and growl and attack anything with flesh.

[*]The vault door - the big iconic cog-shaped door - responsible for holding off the explosion of a nuclear bomb and protect the residents from outside danger falls apart during raider attacks as though it's made of paper mache. Typically about 3 hits with a sword tears a hole right through it - I don't mean they knock the door down. I [i]mean[/i] they rip right through it.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's oddly addictive. It's free even if it's an obvious cash grab. It's okay as a time killer or as a game that you might play on the side while doing something else - like reading or youtube. It's nothing great though. Even the guys that made this game probably don't like it enough to play or update it.
bad game

Ya know, I was really enjoying this game for a while. In many ways, it's a time-based free-to-play done right. 
Going in the game's favor are a lot of things:
1) There's no competition from competitive whales. 
2) The game has numerous ways to expand and grow across your dwellers, their items, and the base itself. 
3) It has some fun and semi-engaging gameplay in the form of quests. 
4) The aesthetics are fun and offer a nice tie-in to Bethesda's Fallout universe.
5) And its free-to-play model is generous in a number of ways, providing means to earn lunchboxes and having Nuka Cola Quantums be a pretty regular item drop in quest locations.
But. It's still just not worth it.
There is still very little gameplay here. Yes, it's much more engaging, kinder, and better looking than your average "collect the resources, reset the timer" free to play game. The big problem is, though, that's still all it is. I think that it honestly is about the best iteration this video game subgenre is ever going to get. But it's still a shitty subgenre, and the game suffers because of it.
Why would you ever want to play a game who's main gameplay element is watching timers reset when, instead, there are literally thousands of other games a few clicks away with FAR more exciting things to do? This game is still out to break your will and get your money instead of providing a fun gameplay experience up front.
What broke my will was having three incidents in a row deplete all of my stimpacks, then all of my vault resources, and then all of my dwellers. It was literally gameover. Unless, I felt like dropping some money to revive my 60+ dwellers and then grinding my way back until the vault was back in shape. That's a steep penalty that even some of the laziest and most aggressively monetized free-to-plays don't saddle a player with.
Or. I could say "fuck this" and realize I was wasting my time with a game that, after 30 hours, still had not had a fun payoff.
It's also got a lot freezes, frame rate drops, and audio-visual desync issues that are easy to ignore at first. But by the 100th time, you have to wonder how they never got around to fixing these issues after being out for almost two years.
Don't waste your time. Just play Fallout 4.

Fallout Shelter is a good fun little game where you manage the development of a fallout shelter.
The cartoon-style drawings are nicely done.

The general structure of this game seems to have been well thought out.
You acquire resources to expand the size of your base, recruit people, and send out some hardy adventurers on quests.
The requirements for food, water, and power seem to be balanced.
The emergency incidents that occur have not seemed to be out of proportion to the resources at hand (so far, at least).

Fallout Shelter is essentially a management game.
However, in some ways it is almost like a clicker game, albeit quite an advanced one. You have to keep on going back and forth between production units to keep the resources flowing. And there are long waits for the completion of quests, and the production of some resources and skill levels, to encourage players to get impatient and purchase upgrades (microtransactions).

Sending Vault-dwellers out on quests can take a long time, unless you use your bottles of "Nuka-Cola Quantum" (which speeds up the journeying), but such bottles are few and far between  unless you feel like spending some real-life money on buying some more (yes, there's the catch).
Your questers engage in battles versus enemies in various buildings, but it's action of just a very basic nature (no first person shooting happens in the game).

The fate of those people who go out into the Wasteland, to explore, is relayed to you via lines of text; you don't actually see them in action, unless they go into a quest building (which you have to authorise).

Mostly the game is about managing the resources of your base, or "Vault".

I quite like Fallout Shelter. From my point of view, the pros far outweigh the cons.
Be warned that you will need a goodly store of patience to play this game (which brings to mind the old prayer, "God grant me patience, but hurry up about it!"); so, if you aren't a patient person, you might want to let this one pass by; but, if patience is one of your virtues, then this might just be the game for you.

If you're a patient person who enjoys a bit of post-apocalyptic fun, then I recommend that you give this game a try.

*********************

P.S. People should be aware that there is a major problem with this game, although it is easily overcome.

After Fallout 3 I've become somewhat of a fan of the series, and although after hearing this was a mobile-to-PC port I was skeptical, even considering this was free of charge... BUT I have to admit this is a VERY nice little game that gets you hooked. 

If you ever played a Fallout game you'll feel right at home with both the visual themes, characters and music.The animations are cartoony but crisp, vibrant, well done with attention to detail and loyal to the PIP Boy theme.

Most of the game takes place in your Vault location where you, as it's Overseer, plan and expand it's structure,  assemble teams to take on quests, send out Dwellers to scour the Wasteland for resources and and attract new Dwellers via radio broadcast (or play Match Maker to get you current Dwellers to procreate). Building your Vault isn't as easy as it seems because there are may surprises and variables that influence your status and progress...

Quests let you take direct control over your chosen team to explore new locations and are often very worthwhile beacause of the potential loot found on location. This is a nice feature because it takes you away from your Vault for some much needed diversion.

If you can get this for free (or for a few bucks), and don't mind a relatively slow paced Fallout-themed building sim, don't hesitate and take it, you won't regret it!
Probably the best free to play survival game on steam.

After almost 11 hours I'm getting very bored. The game is extremely repetitive. The missions are pretty much just "go from room to room and wait for the enemies to die and then collect the stuff. The base management is rather annoying due to clunky interface and lack of information.

I can't see in numbers how much health my people have. The defense part is not fun at all. Enemies come in and run into rooms randomly. Attacking enemies also seem to have much higher health compared to enemies on missions. Ghouls are very devastating and cost a lot of radaway and stimpacks to keep people alive. Outside of the defense and missions it's pretty much just waiting for timers to finish to gather ressources.

Breeding new people is also extremely random - at least it seem that way. I have used high level characters and such with high special stats and the new born are usually just terrible, meaning you will have to train them intensively.

Oh and I want to meantion that the ressource gathering is a pain. You have timers of 1-10 minutes based on your character and you buy yourself helpers to automatically gather the ressources. However they only seem to do it occasionally. This is extremly nasty once your log out for a few hours, come back and your power is deep in the red. You are then forced to rush to get the ressources back up and that is literally like playing with fire...

I don't get how this game even though it's F2P has such a high positive rating...

Good game overall, something to past the time but nothing to amazing and it is free

This game is a stripped down version of the modern Fallout games.  I've played for a few weeks on ther version from the Windows store, and the Steam version has just a bit more menu options compared to that (stress on "a bit").

What I like about it:

1.  Fallout vintage vibe to look and sounds
2.  Levelling up of dwellers
3.  Earning caps, crafting, and exploring like the other fallout games
4.  Sending Dwellers on missions, etc.

And now for what sucks....

1.  You are limited to one vault with a maximum of 200 dwellers
2.  it takes Dwellers ages to return back to the vault...unless you want to use up (or pay for) Nuka Colas to speed that along.
2.  You have to click on each dweller when they are ready to be leveled up - no "master button" for doing all at once.
3.  You have to click on each room when it finished collecting it's given resource (water, food, whatever) - no master button for that either.  Adding a Mr Handy can help there, but you pretty much have to buy those with real money
4.  It's too easy to accidentally drag dwellers to the wrong place when scanning around the vault.
3.  Children are completely usesless until they grow up.  Why not be able to assign them to the classroom and have a random SPECIAL attribute be higher than the rest?
4.  Microtransactions - get rid of them and just allow a one time payment for the game
5.  Allow for turrets to be posted by the vault door to help fight off attackers, and allow them to be upgradable.  The Vault door can be breached even after 3 upgrades and you can only post 2 dwellers there which is pretty useless when the Deathclaws start attacking.
6.  Need to be able to better swap weapons between dwellers or at least be able to better find the ones with key equipment so you can send them on missions
7.  The rushes on rooms gets tedious, and there should be more variations as to what happens when they fail - fires and critter infestations get boring quickly
8.  There should be more things for the dwellers to do besides work, train, fight, or f*ck.  No resting or sleeping?
9.  Add more variety to the Mysterious Stranger character.  Right now, he is the "Where's Waldo"of the game and gets nearly impossible to find later on.
10.  Dwellers should be able to either auto heal/remove rads or allow for a one click button to do it to all of them (do you see a theme here?)
11.  The game really has no end - after you reach 200 dwellers and do the missions....ehh, then what?

I'll recommend it because it's in the Fallout world, but it needs some tweaking to make it very good.

Having sunk countless hours into Fallout Shelter, I can say with confidence that the best possible outcome would have been for Fallout 4 to directly port over the mechanics of this game for settlements and, to a certain extent, equiment.  For example, it makes sense that the institute laser rifles would be more powerful than standard ones - they've had centuries to perfect the old tech that most wastelanders can only get through salvage.  Having happiness and settler attributes directly tied to output for various posts would have made the settlements in FO4 so much more dynamic.  There's a lot to like about the design decisions made in Fallout Shelter, and the game has been updated even though the game it's a tie-in for has been out for at least a year, so it's worth more than the price of admission in my humble opinion.

The addition of playable quests, item creation, and side-quests to wasteland exploration has extended the shelf life of this game significantly.  While the action can become repetitive as you reach the upper population limit of your vault (which, in my opinion, should be raised in light of the number of different positions and quest slots for your limited number of dwellers to occupy), there's a 'fish bowl' quality to FS that makes it something easy to waste time on.  The conversations the dwellers have are occasionally amusing - no one expects the Belethor refference the first time - and little nuggets of the classic Fallout black humor bleed through the cartooniness.

 If I had one complaint about Fallout Shelter, it would be stability issues.  While the computer port has resolved a number of them, there remain a few times when the game has crashed on my otherwise high-end PC without warning or explaination.   Some optimization, stability fixes, and tweaks to the drag-and-drop mechanic to make it more accurate would be nice.  I'd also like to see some sort of accounting for familial relationships between dwellers added to the game, such a family tree, both because it can get quite confusing  figuring out who will breed with who (relatives can't) and because it always struck me as odd that a retro-futuristic send-up of 50's American society would effectively be comprised entirely of open relationships without any refferences to drama when, say, a dweller cheats on the other parent of their child, even though there are gossipy refferences to this kind of thing in dialogue.  Then again, that might be overthinking the mechanics of a casual game, so your mileage may vary.

Overall, I rate Fallout Shelter a 7/10 - not groundbreaking, but a satisfying time-sink with forgiveable flaws.

The game itself is excellent, but it is still an average Android port with some technical problems. 

First off, the game "hangs" in the background if you exit through the main menu. The only way to bypass that is by only playing in windowed mode and exiting by closing the window (not through the main menu)
Second most anoying problem, is controls. You can accidentally send a dweller to another room while clicking on resources, or you may use a stimpak during battle, when you actually want to select a player and use radaway and then stimpak (which happens a lot on higher levels). Sometimes labels are misplaced in the tracking window.

What's not really an issue, is microtransactions. It is not forced upon you, like in many other mobile games, there are no annoying popups, and overall the game looks fairly clean from the aesthetic perspective.

Regardless of bugs and glitches, I still do recommend it.

So look, the thing about Fallout Shelter is that it was originally a free-to-play mobile game. Like it or lump it, that's typically how these games make their money. They're designed for a very specific kind of player in the mobile market, and that was never going to translate to PC in a way that didn't leave a bad taste in some people's mouths.

I'm not typically into mobile gaming, I don't much care for the free-to-play model, but I am enjoying Fallout Shelter. When I first began, I spent about an hour running a vault and getting a feel for the way the game would play, then I started a new vault and spent $10 on a starter pack, some lunch boxes, a couple of Mr. Handy robots, and a pet. That $10 dollar investment has seen me through nearly 11 hours game play in the same vault, with the same dwellers I've been building since the beginning, and the same two Mr. Handy robots that I originally purchased.

I like micro-management games, and while I'd rather have a game that I can sit and play for hours without having quick progression locked behind a Nuka-Cola Quantum pay wall, I'm perfectly happy to spend 10 to 20 minutes at a time managing my Dwellers, running a quest, sending Dwellers out into the wasteland, setting Dwellers up to breed, and so on. Then I move on to other games for a while and can check back in on Fallout Shelter when I feel the need to break up my play time in other, more substantial games.

Know what you're getting into before you download this game -- or decided to drop any money into it. I feel like I've gotten my $10 worth out of the game, and so long as my vault continues to steadily develop, that feeling isn't liable to change.

Fallout shelter is a fun little game that you play for five to ten minutes at a time that can get pretty challenging at times. A lot will complain about it being a 'pay to win' game, but it isn't; if you're impatient or make stupid decisions, like send your dwellers out into the wasteland with no stimpaks or horde your weapons instead of equipping people, then you'll be tempted to buy lunchboxes and other items. But that's why this is a 5-10 minute session game: you check your vault(s) in the morning, at lunch, after dinner, or whenever you have a few free minutes with nothing to do, fiddle around, and go about your day, including playing other games. There's no need to spend money on this game in order to enjoy it. 

There are a few issues that do prevent me from giving this game a better score and will irritate you: 
-The cursor isn't precise in some situations, the most common one being needing to place dwellers on the ceiling of the room you assign them instead of in the room itself. 
-When combat takes place in some of the rooms, dwellers will stack and stand behind each other, preventing you from clicking on the right person to heal them. This happens rarely, but when it does, you will need to pay to resurrect your dweller what feels unnecessarily. 
-About a third of the Mysterious Stranger's spawn locations, namely those with forebround and background areas, are cheap; as in, he's behind a wall or one of your dwellers and unless you dramatically change the angle of your view, you won't see him, even if that room is the only thing you see. You'll get sick of this fast and is something that, like the dwellers stacking in rare combat instances, needs to be patch-fixed so it's less cheatsy BS. 
-Click and draging to change perspective is not recommended. Accidentally click on a dweller and you'll end up sending them somewhere you don't want or just unasign them. Also, double-clicking while doing this causes the camera to focus on the person or room you double-clicked, fighting against your manual controls and require you to double-click and let the camera do what it wants before you get control back or else you'll be camera-locked in that one dweller or room. 

These are all minor annoyances and irritations that could due to be patch-fixed out or are just part of the game's mechanics and need to be kept in mind when playing. Playing for short lengths of time will keep you from being bothered by them too much or feel tempted to buy anything. 

Recommended if you spend a lot of time on your computer, but the iOS version is more convenient and enjoyable.

It's a waiting/eugenics simulator. It's free. It's a lot of fun at the beginning but quickly loses steam as things seriously slow down during middle game, and picks up again as you're entering late game. You do not need to pay to win in this game, and there really isn't a winning condition to begin with. You mostly spend cash to speed through the game, which I wouldn't personally recommend. It is far more satisfying to earn your way to the top.

The graphics and sounds are minimalistic but charming, and the game is really good at rewarding your actions. The only real downside to FOS is that it has no multiplayer component, not the micro-transactions, which I think is a huge oversight and would have added far more re-playability to the game. There are also some questionable gameplay decisions, and there are frustrations when dealing with dweller combat in the vault and some disasters (radscorpions), but it's nothing you won't be able to deal with if you're adequately prepared.

Many players find enjoyment by conducting social experiments. For example, is your vault only populated by women and all the men are sent into the wasteland? Or maybe your vault has everyone named Jerry? Maybe all the kids born into the vault have to go through a rite of passage in the wasteland or die trying? You can decide all of that, and I highly recommend that you do. FOS is all about making your own fun, so be creative. For added bonus, try survival mode. It's actually pretty easy if you know what you're doing, even if you're completely new to FOS.

A few tips right off the bat: The game is based around several key concepts, and if you don't want to get completely destroyed by rad roaches or fires, make sure you aren't upgrading your rooms unless your dwellers are all armed and in their 30s. This is critically important by the time radscorpions start showing up (60 and 35 population for normal and survival). Keep you overall dweller level down if you don't want to be minced by deathclaws (60 and 35 pop). SPECIAL stats only matter for manning rooms and exploring the wasteland, and questing to a lesser extent.

Endurance should be your number one priority, since health in FOS is only determined at level up and does not work retroactively with endurance. Endurance does stack past 10, so you want to level up with the best endurance gear you have to get the most health possible.

As a bonus tip for survival mode, you can avoid disasters by isolating rooms in a checkerboard-like pattern, since everything but radscorpions cannot travel past dirt tiles. This won't work past 35, when the radscorpions show up, so I suggest being well-armed and well-trained after that point, and then hitting nuclear reactors as fast as possible. The rest you can read about online, if you desire to know more about the inner workings of the game.

Nice little game with a nice feel for the Fallout games. Build a Vault, fill it with residents and keep them happy and occupied, train them, feed them, armor them and upgrade their weaponry.  Send them on quests or let them explore. I found out it's not realy an easy little game . If you go too fast you'll face bigger treats. You'll have to keep an eye on several things to keep everything going nice and smooth. I made a lot of mistakes the first few tries but my 4th Vault seems to do allright for the time being. 

The first few days you'll have to check in regulary to keep an eye on things but when things are running smoothly you can leave your dwellers alone for days. Just don't forget to stock your explorers with enough Stims and Rad-aways and train them for long walks and fights. And plan your quests. Some of them will take more than 10 hours to get there. Send your troops out before you go to bed. The next day you can do the quest and send them back home (and if you found some Nuka-cola you can have them home in no time). 

Some other nice Fallout touches in-game that Fallout players will recognize and appreciate. Made for Mobile and now for pc gamers. I like it a lot for a casual game.

Pros: 
Fun cartoony Pip-Boy take on the Fallout universe.
Worth the price of free
Amusing humor

Cons:
Poorly adapted from mobile. Or more accurately; Not adapted. Change up the pacing and make the controls more PC is not asking a lot.

But my main con is this: I spent the past couple of weeks playing this game pretty consistently and I dropped $6 on it. (Starter pack and a Mr. Handy). Then it unexpectedly shut down. Upon restarting, my vault save file had disappeared along with my $6 dollars and all the time I had spent on it. I tried contacting Bethesda for technical support or a refund. Only get automated answers.  

After this happened I delved into the reviews. I'm not the first that this is happened. Be forewarned, you could lose any save file you make. That includes the time you put into building an awesome vault and any money you spent.

TL:DR

Good game, nice features, get it, don't buy stuff for RL Money, how can you shoot in this game?!





This game is first of all for free available within some buyable features, well, there are ways to avoid this 'I need stuff and have to pay for it', but I don't give a damn about it, coz the game is just great.

For the people who spent money on the game: I'm sorry, but if your SAV file went kaputt or anything like that, your own fault to be honest, use a website to make yourself up there where you used to be and don't even spend money on it, otherwise you're seriously a dumbnut if you buy the features once again.

I haven't found personally any negative points, besides some small one which doesn't even have to be listed.

So far I've really enjoyed it more than I should. It's quite simple, a phone game ported to PC but there is something quite addictive about it. Up until now it's been a great casual game, play a little bit once or twice every day (or a little more) and no you don't have to buy anything as long as you accept it as a casual game.

That said I might change my mind as I continue because thins are getting tougher now. It's still not tough, but definitely tougher and they could do a lot of quality of life additions when you're browsing through your list of dwellers trying to find who's got a certain weapon, outfit, dog etc. Sometimes dragging and dropping a dweller at the right place just doesn't really seem to work properly so being able to change room in the list and other minor things like that would greatly benefit the game experience. Just adding a little extra touch instad of just porting it straight over would've made a huge difference.

Oh... And playing this with my steam link (with mouse/kbd) is the ultimate couch potato slacker casual gamer experience. Strangely addictive for no good reason.

Edit: Some notes after a lot of game time.
- You will go nuts fighting the controls. You can use both mouse and keyboard, but when you try to use them at the same time - zooming out with the mouse and moving up with the keyboard, or the reverse etc - the game "snaps" you back resulting in lost time and killed dwellers during incidents (like deathclaw attacks that get a lot more frequent).
- You also go bonkers when dwellers trade places with you because the game thinks you double clicked or dragged a dweller to the floor below when you actually just tried to click the dweller. Even dropping dwellers is very inaccurate resulting in dwellers dropping on a floor lower than you expected. Suddenly your STRONG dweller is trainging Perception and a Perception dweller is working on you nuclear plant.

And the only real way to solve that crap is to have an empty room in the middle of "hot spots" where you can drop a dweller temporary to reassign them.

- Around 100 dwellers the game sort of either comes to a grind/halt or you get very busy managing explorers while waiting for the caps to invest in legendary weapons and outfits etc.

That said, for a free game, this is fantastic fun and so much better than playing it on a small screen. (I'm really to old for the phone version. Played plenty of hours on my SGS6 but.. I have no clue what the text says, just click and hope for the best or screen mirror the phone screen to my TV).

[b]Almost Great, But Poorly Ported From Mobile Platform[/b]
---------------------------------------------------------------

I've put a good amount of time into this game and, for a free-to-play game, this is actually fairly decent and I won't bash it for it's business strategy in order to make the game pay for itself - at least Bethesda isn't releasing the game in a series of DLC's (yet?); but the game suffers from not being very PC-friendy in a number of ways.  These issues could be remedied by making a few very simple tweaks and here are my suggestions:

[olist]
[*] [b]No Drag-to-Select[/b] - Because the players on this PC-port of the game will generally use mouse and keyboard, the game should have been more well-adapted to this.  Being able to select multiple dwellers, then moving them all at once, should be a basic feature in a game such as this.  Adding click-and-drag selection (and perhaps even a feature where double-clicking a vault dweller selects all dwellers in the same room) would go a long way toward making this a more PC-friendly port.

[*] [b]No Right-Click[/b] - Right-clicking has hardly been incorporated into the game.  Mostly, the player drags-and-drops the dwellers to move them.  Lack of an aforementioned multiple-selection feature coupled with no right-clicking suggests that Bethesda hadn't put a whole lot of effort into porting this game over and must not think that a proper port might make them a bit more profit.

[*] [b]Long Quest Timers[/b] - On a mobile platform, players can carry their devices everywhere they go, then take it out in the waiting room at the doctors' office or when work is slow and the boss isn't looking.  PC's aren't nearly as mobile-friendly (or discreet) as smart phones and tablets, so coming back to the vault during lunch break to roleplay as the Overseer isn't too feasible for the typical PC-user.  PC-users want more eventful gameplay.  Honestly, I get that Bethesda wants to use the typical free-to-play business strategy popular on mobile platforms and I'm fine with it; but on PC, 12 hours is a bit too long to wait for my dwellers to arrive at a quest.

[*] [b]Not Enough Radio[/b] - Fallout 3 spoiled me with it's fantastic radio and was one of the things that kept me hooked on the game.  I would like an option to hear more radio after making a radio room without having to zoom in to the radio room.  It would also be nice if Bethesda could add a little more music to add to the atmosphere of the game.
[/olist]

In short, I believe that if Bethesda added multiple-selection, right-clicking, cut their quest timers by at least half, and added more music this would become a far more enjoyable (and profitable) game for them.  For now, I'm giving a thumbs down; but I'll give the game a thumbs up after Bethesda, [i]at the least[/i], makes the game more PC-friendly by adding improved selection and right-click features.

[h1] Game good, medium bad. [/h1]

This game is good. Like, really good. I often find myself glued to the screen for more than an hour just working to increase the efficiency and productivity of my vault. It is addictive. VERY addictive. However, I cannot, in good heart, recommend this game for anyone who is limited to a PC and cannot play the game on a mobile device. It is not MEANT to be played on a computer. The game requires you to check in every thirty minutes or so, and that means that if you're not on your computer all day - like most people - you are going to get fucked in the ass. See, in the game, you need to keep three meters stable so that your vault can survive. These are electricity, water, and food. If your electricity meter gets low, rooms will start to lose power and the entire vault will begin losing functionality. If your water meter gets low, the people in your vault, your "dwellers," will start losing health, and that lost health will be replaced with radioactive illness, which you need RadAway to get rid of. If your food meter gets low, your dwellers' happiness will drastically fall, which you want to keep up so that you get a good daily grade so that you can get a lot of money. It also means that your dwellers will start losing health and other S.P.E.C.I.A.L (strength, perception, endurance, charisma, intelligence, agility, and luck) characteristics, which you need up so that your dwellers can fight raid attacks and radroaches. If one is low, it's pretty easy to get back up. If two are down, it usually takes a good chunk of time to get back up as it is costly. If all three are down, exit the game, reload it, delete your save, and start a new game, because no matter how hard you try, you are not getting those fuckers fixed - they are dead for good. Because it is so important to check in and keep your vault stable, you need a quick, easy way to access your save file. The game on mobile does really well, but it is absolutely dreadful on PC. On mobile, you just open your phone, click on the app, do what you need to do, and then back to real life it is. On the COMPUTER, you need to login to your Steam, go to your game library, find Fallout Shelter, start running the game, wait for the game to load, open your save, wait for THAT to load, do what you need to do, then "X" out of the game, and log out of your Steam. It does not work on PC, period. If you must play this game on the PC, so fucking be it - but please realize there are better options that make this game one-hundred and seven percent more enjoyable! It really is a great game, and I don't want your first experience with it to be... [i] this. [/i]

There's a lot of hate for the game on Steam, so I thought I'd chime in.

I played the original Fallout Shelter on Android when it was released, it was a novel and fun take on the fallout universe that you could play on the go and enjoy. On release it felt a bit one dimensional, and after a few sessions I got bored of it.

Playing the PC port feels nice. The game has been updated in the past couple of years and has a lot more content, which gives it a lot more purpose in my opinion. The introduction of quests at a certain progression level amps up the entire gameplay loop. You receive a ton of rewards per successful mission and can loot nuka currency (which you would "need" to buy otherwise).

Let me repeat that last part: you DO NOT need to purchase anything, in any microtransaction to enjoy this game. I use nuka currency to speed up traveling to/from the wasteland and loot more nuka than I use by doing quests. There are also various miscellanous ways to earn caps which you can find out for yourself by playing.

This is not a big time-sink RPG. It's a really nice game to play for short periods of time. If you really want to play a long session you can easily do so by questing, which gives it more of a singleplayer Fallout vibe and disproportionally positive rewards compared to the start activities.

HAVING SAID THAT, the PC port itself is very basic. Mouse control is finnicky, and I often find myself not being able to click and drag properly. To some people this will be a very big deal, so it's worth mentioning.

the mobile app is very enjoyable, and i've had it since it was released on IOS, puting it on PC was all i've ever wanted from it, and so far it's held up and is enjoyable to start all over again. Fallout Shelter is a waiting game/simulation game based on the Fallout verse. You are the overseer of a vault, and it is your job to build up your vault and its population, looking after them and protecting them from the dangers of the world around them.

This seems really neat. And honestly, it is a really cool idea, and it is fun for a while. But eventually you realize that the game is an enormous addiction engine, and underneath that addiction, there‚Äôs actually not all that much game.

The game seemingly centers itself around your vault ‚Äì you can build various rooms for various purposes, but the big three are power stations (which provide your rooms with power), water stations (which provide water for everyone), and food stations (which provide food for everyone). You assign vault residents to these rooms in order to produce resources, which are consumed over time. When you log out of the game, these continue to accrue somewhat, though there‚Äôs a limit on how much you can accure. You can also rush production in these rooms to gain the benefit immediately, but at the risk of an ‚Äúincident‚Äù occurring.

You start out the game with 8-12 people who wander up to your vault,  and you can produce more people via three main methods ‚Äì sending people out to wander the wasteland looking for survivors, building radio stations in your vault to call out to people outside‚Ä¶ or, your residents can make babies with each other. If you send a man and a woman to quarters, after a while the woman will end up pregnant; four hours later, she pops out a baby, and four hours after that, the baby becomes an adult. The game doesn‚Äôt allow inbreeding, so you have to figure out how to manage your family lines a little, though honestly it wasn‚Äôt much of an issue.

Each vault dweller has a set of seven stats ‚Äì the same SPECIAL stats from Fallout ‚Äì Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck. Sadly, the game doesn‚Äôt really explain what these stats do at all; while it is obvious that they are tied to the function of rooms (making them produce faster), beyond that it is pretty mysterious what they do, doubly so as most of your vault residents will have low stats. As it turns out, they do have some influence on combat and other things.

While I said that the game seemingly revolves around your vault, what it actually revolves around after a while is quests ‚Äì you can send someone out on a quest into the wasteland, and after waiting X amount of time, they‚Äôll go encounter some place. You move them from room to room, with them auto-attacking anything inside, and them auto-attacking back ‚Äì it isn‚Äôt very interactive, though you can use stim packs to boost your health (something you can produce in your vault, and which I quickly maxed out on ‚Äì turns out, they‚Äôre really useful to be able to spam endlessly). As you explore these places, you find stuff lying around you can bring back to your base.

You can also just send someone out to wander around the wasteland aimlessly, hoping to find stuff; this is kind of marginal, but it gradually does accumulate stuff (especially if you have high luck).

The problem, ultimately, is that the game‚Äôs interaction ends up almost entirely becoming busywork. While building up your vault is sort of interesting, after a while it becomes obvious that there‚Äôs a fairly simple optimal strategy to it, and after that point, it sort of becomes rote. While rushing stuff in the early game is an easy way to quickly build up xp, later on you start encountering worse disasters from it which discourages it a bit ‚Äì which is probably a good thing, because it ultimately becomes a lot of busywork. But the problem is that most of the game consists on clicking on rooms to gather resources from them and otherwise engaging in a lot of micromanagement as you move around people to make babies or set up equipment on them or whatever else.

Once you realize that the cute veneer is just a layer over a pretty Pavlovian addiction engine, it frankly loses its charm. I really liked the idea of this game, but ultimately it is the mechanics of it which killed it for me.

Which is interesting, because a lot of people complained about microtransactions, but I never saw much value in them. Seems like it would sort of defeat the point of the game.

All in all, this is pretty, but ephemeral; you might enjoy messing around with it for a bit, but after you‚Äôve done a few quests, there‚Äôs really nothing more to see here.

At its best it can be a wonderfully addictive game, especially for those who like management games, and at its worst it‚Äôs nothing more than something moderately interesting to stare at. As a game it firmly stands on its own two feet but a lot of its success has to do with the nostalgia and popularity it lends from the [i]Fallout[/i] franchise

Always wanted to play this game, but my cellphone is an old shoebox and I can't play pretty much anything on it. But that s–Ωi—Ç is still working, so, yeah... I keep using it. 

Anyway, I got carried away a bit. Thanks to modern times, the devs and steam... Now this game is on steam. The game itself, it's good. It's a managment sim of a sort. You make your own vault, you build rooms in it, take care of problems, make random people dance in living room and populate your shelter and stuff. Also, you can send your guys outside to collect stuff or do quests. That's pretty dope too. And s–Ωi—Ç is reaaally addictive and free. Just like candy the strangers used to give me when I was little. There is a donations sistem of course, as in most FTP games. But it does not feel that invasive as in most of the free to play games. You can play the game well enough without giving a cent to the devs. I encourage to do the oposite, though... They seems nice enough and they got this game on steam.

This is a fun little game, I am a big fan of Fallout and was quite gutted when my tablet/phone wasn't quite powerful enough to run this. So when steam announce that they had this as there new game and it was Free to Play, I was all over it.

Of course you can tell it was meant to be played on Phone/Tablets, with how long you have to wait for things/quests/etc to finish actually working. But for me personally that makes it good, it means I can drop in and out of the game in between doing other things on the computer, I'll set up someone to go on a quest and go do a load of laundry or play a different game. So it works in my favour. 

Obviously if you are looking for something that you want to stare the screen for however many hours a day this won't be a satisfying game and there are games out there that would do that for you. 

Am really glad that Steam have got it, I won't be spending money to buy anything, but I do enjoy coming back to this game every day. It breaks the day up a bit for me, when I know I should go back and see how my little Vault Dwellers are doing.

Fallout Shelter, the other Fallout game. 

Fallout Shelter is a free-to-play mobile platform game, released by Bethesda Softworks in 2015, just before the release of Fallout 4, as a sort of teaser for things to come. In 2017, the mobile game was released on Steam.

One of the fundamentals of a Fallout game, is the music; where would we be wandering without some classic tunes? In the menu, you can hear some jazzy music playing in the background. There is no music playing in the background while you actually play though; however, in any menu tab you open, you will be greeted with some jazzy music. Slightly disappointing, not being able to listen to the ingame music while you actually play.

There are no accusation to be made in the graphics department of the game. For a mobile game, the graphics are great, casual, pleasant to look at. Comparing the graphics to games on PC, well, there are certainly worse graphics than what Fallout Shelter offers. Even on the PC platform, the graphics still meet a satisfactory standard with no crime punishable.

Originally, being a mobile game, the game itself needs to be easy to enjoy. No confusions with controls or gameplay, no need to look up on the internet how to do this or that. Passing its mobile game criteria of being an easy, casual game is also eligible on the PC platform. No one likes a game with difficult controls. With Fallout Shelter, there is no controls, only your mouse which would‚Äôve exchanged your thumbs if you were to be playing this game on a mobile device. Fallout Shelter is now one of the many other ‚Äúclicker‚Äù games, needing only a mouse to do everything.

But can Fallout Shelter offer a persisting amount of entertainment on a PC?

As a mobile game, it has distinguished itself a worthwhile title. But moving a mobile game to a PC platform is moving an U/10 into an U/20‚Äôs match. It may have skills in its area, it may even be able to show them skills in the new field, but it just can‚Äôt compete compared to the games, specifically designed for the PC.

You turn your computer on, you get into the game, you click on your vault rooms to collect what resources and profit they have made to make your vault and the dwellers inside sustained, and then you're finished.

It‚Äôs fine on a mobile platform, where you only need to pull the device out of your pocket, but for the demands of the game, you need to turn your computer on. Wait for everything to load and startup. Enter the game. Click on everything that needs clicking. And then you‚Äôre done. That‚Äôs all you need to do.

All you do in it, is click on a few rooms to gather resources and supplies like power, water, medical supplies etc. Maybe send someone outside your safe haven to gather some pre war materials, clothing and defensive weaponry. That‚Äôs all you do. It‚Äôs a repeated cycle of doing those things. Every Time you get into the game, that‚Äôs all you can do. And on a PC, that gets quite boring after awhile.

It lacks a required depth, storyline, mission. It‚Äôs too small for the PC platform. You enter the game, and you‚Äôve already done everything that the game has to offer in a matter of no time at all. After you‚Äôve done everything, you‚Äôre simply just playing the game to meet your vaults mundane requirements, and all that is, is clicking on maybe five-six things. After that initial playthrough, the game loses its charm, its creativity; you‚Äôre not playing the game for any purpose, except to perform some mundane task to keep your vaults dwellers happy.

Concluding this review, the game is great on the mobile platform, for something casual to play while you're waiting or are bored somewhere. But on a PC platform, the game is too small, it lacks depth and a persisting entertainment. After five minutes of game time, you‚Äôve pretty much done everything, and everything after that is doing the same thing.
