This one may be the best that mobile games have to offer, but ultimately, it is too shallow to stay entertaining and the frustration over all the little issues like mild lag on a powerful system and unprecise room borders while dragging and dropping gets annoyingly overwhelming.

Once you set up a health and rad-away production line, you are ultimately going to boot this up for like 5 to 10 minutes every other hour, but you will soon lose the reason to do even that.

In the end, this is a very elaborate PR gag that even stands on its own two legs, but you should only bother if you have a day to waste until the excitement wears down, or if you positively have nothing else to play.

For a port, the most basic functionality seems lost.  Everything seems fine on load.  Check settings, all is normal. head to select vault.  This is where the problems start.

  Of the 3 digital vault number, the first one always snaps back to 0.  online people report selecting numbers like 369 and so forth.  My choices are limited to 000-099.  This may be tied to the next problem.

Upon actually trying to select a vault number, everytime I move my mouse, I get this incessant clicking sound.  I assume it is the 'mouse over' sound one gets.  Stop moving mouse, sound stops.  I pick a vault number just to see further into the tutorial.

Build a generator: tells me to press Y - does nothing.  try to check settings but I can't  as I'm locked into tutorial.
End Task - load, settings,  No key bind settings. must be my YYYYYYY key is broken only in this game.

create vault again under same conditions reach the build generator tutorial phase again.

Again moving mouse always leads to a click sound at the rate of about 1 every 10th of a second never stops unless I don't move the mouse.  Mouse must be broken in this game only.

I notice while moving the mouse, a little hammer appears by the press Y recomendation.  Move the mouse, the hammer flashes (and yes constant clicking sound). build the generator.

Phase 2 dwellers show up in tutorial.  view stats - no description what  S P E C I A L means.  My Guess: Such Peculiar Engineering Cheap Interface Always Loses

Tells me to assign first one to generator.  Oh boy another problem.  it's off screen  trying to use mouse  to pan is pointless, can only get it to pan as far as elevator.  You can sometimes succeed  if you click drag the dweller as far as he goes, and at the same time use the arrow keys to pan the map, and let go of the dweller.

Assign 2nd dweller to the generator: attempting the same work around as above led to the game locking up as soon as I let go.

If this  is how their games work I'm glad I stopped with fallout 2. and after this experience I won't be quick to waste time with their other titles.

Needless to say I've seen much smaller companies do better.  Heck even Hello Games with  NMS managed to get a working interface on both console and PC at the same time.

Bethesda:  If you can't even manage to port a simple onscreen cursor from Xbox to PC with out inscessant clicking sounds, failed functionality to the point of causing lockups, pick one or the other and leave the porting to the professionals.

Many people will complain that this game is pay to win. While expediting is something you can pay for via 5 dollar purchases of lunchboxes, the entire game as it is can be accessed with a sufficient time investment, and since it is not multiplayer, "pay to win" is a pointless complaint. At best you're paying for instant gratification, not the actual possibility of winning.

A better complaint would be a lack of options for improving graphics or for the core repetitiveness. Much of the value in the game is in pushing your base forward to become an engine for sending groups of followers out into the wasteland, where a lot of the true action and any storytelling the game does offer is placed.

This is not a PC game. It wasn't good on mobile, and it's even worse on PC. 

If this game was redesigned as a proper game (ie. without the waiting mechanics and IAPs), it might be worth to buy. But as it is, it's just a waste of time.

Wew, boy. This game came out a loong time ago, it's been what, a year? Two? Anyways, a quick TL;DR is in order: a game I wouldn't call fun or interesting, or even good, but a good time-filler. Perhaps it would benefit from a few changes and improvements, but nothing is going to make this game interesting. 

Fallout shelter was probably the bane of my existence for the week or so I initially played it. Everytime I clicked that notification was immediately followed by the thought of "why am I playing this again?", before tapping here and there. I have several complaints and suggestions, all ranging from very minor to barely above mediocre. We'll start with complaints, finish with a load of suggestions, and a summary.

[h1]COMPLAINTS[/h1]:
I'm just going to let my inner grandpa out here, and complain about small issues for a paragraph.

For some reason, the game will auto collect certain rooms. This is one of those minor issues. For some reason, when I'm in the vault, I will randomly collect water from the purifiers. Can't really explain this one, but not even menus can stop these auto-harvests. It's odd to have multiple legendaries, say Preston Garvey, running around, managing the same power plant. Nothing game breaking, but certainly an odd thing to see happen. Perhaps a limitation on the amount of legendaries appearing is in order? Sometimes small dialogue errors sneak through the usually chuckle worthy dialouge. "Just what I'm looking for"? Where's the period? Obviously this game isn't worth playing now. In that same vein of miscellaneous complaints, what is an NPC in the "A little off the top" achievement description? I know it means dwellers, because you can't customize anyone else, but this seems like a really weird mistake to make. Using WASD or the arrow keys while scrolling does this weird lock on thing that frustrates me, mostly because I can't stop doing it on accident.

Alright, onto more greivous concerns. First off, the calibration for picking up and dropping survivors(a system that obviously came from being a mobile port, and makes little sense to have in a PC management game) has a very odd displacement. Recalibration is in order. It's pretty annoying to drag someone in the middle of a raider attack to have to drag the same person to the same tile multiple times. Why not have a "pursuers" mechanic? At the least, have the 2 slots available at the vault door chase down invaders. I think that's what Mr. Handys are for, but I honestly can't think of any purpose for them: you have 3 choices: send them into the wasteland, only to have them come back a full day later with caps in the hundreds, which, for comparison, in the same time frame, a dweller with a ton of stimpaks and enough radaway will bring back thousands of caps. Or, you can have them take permanent damage when they fight invaders, to be revived for a cost in the thousands, apparently, since everytime there was a fight I just dragged them into the lowest floor in my vault. Or, last option, have them "collect things"? I can't even remember what they're supposed to do while floating around on a floor, I've never actually seen them do anything besides float around and crack a joke once in a while. Seriously, what are these things even supposed to do? Can't send them to fight, too expensive. Can't let them collect things, because I've literally never seen them do one, and the other is just a waste of time.

I originally thought Endurance was the dump stat to end dump stats, but apparently it effects the HP gained upon level up, which I'll take at face value. But I don't think it does anything else, besides run the Nuka Cola bottler, the only room that does that, not like you'd know that until you had 80 (or 100, I forgot) dwellers, because the dumb game doesn't let you know. Seriously, what's the benefit in hiding this stuff? Let me know all the numbers. I'm just going to go on the wiki to look at the numbers myself if you don't let me peek behind the curtains.

Speaking of stats and applications, what do stats do in combat/quests? All from hearsay and wiki browsing, Strength increases melee damagae, Perception increases gun damage, Luck increases loot, I mean, christ man, some transparency would be nice. I'd like to know what the best person to send into the quest is, or if there even is a difference between them. Quests are SO boring. I don't think I've ever done anything but yawn on them, except for the first one, because "hey, this is different than farmville" was the quests' singular selling point, but then I went on the second one, and I realized they were all pretty much the same; Go into room. Kill baddies. Click shinies. Repeat until entire area cleared. Do again with slightly different layout. But, I found it hilarious when the first quest was cleared by a single dweller holding the worst gun in my inventory(2-4 damage). Other quests with similarly equipped dwellers resulted in death. Nothing of value was lost though, since my other dweller came back from his 2 day trek into the wasteland with enough caps to fill a room, probably. Last point about quests- when a party all have crits ready, it's hard to tell who's crit I'm clicking when there's one target. A face or some other indicator next to the marker would be nice here.

I might make it sound like this is an utterly broken game, but it's not. It's just really boring. Mostly because it was designed to be played on your phone for 5 minutes at a time, and I'd rather be doing pretty much anything else than waiting at the vault for my Preston clones to crank out more power for the Piper harem to cleanse more water.

[h1]SUGGESTIONS[/h1]:
Here's just a ton of things I think would make the game better, either because it's now on PC, or because it just would, in my eyes.

Can we get a dropdown tab? Like, please? I seriously loathe dressing my dwellers up in their suits, because each time I switch to a different room, I gotta cycle all the way from P to E to C to ... to L to "abilities" to S. A form of mobile and desktop sync would be nice, but it might be too hard to implement, I don't know. I'm not a game desginer. Please, for the love of all that is holy, make a mass unequip button. If I get another quest asking to kill 9 deathclaws with my bare hands, and I have to actually make sure no one uses their guns, I might just do something drastic, like not play this game I dislike. Something that would help since the game is now on PC, and presumably with a mouse with two buttons, can we use right click as a cancel? And while I'm at it, the inventory menu should have a 3rd option for equippables: equip, where you choose it on a weapon, then choose a dweller to assign the equippable to. I can't tell whose cat that is, I can't tell which dress the pregnant lady is wearing under her latex strech shirt (what the hell is that thing), and I definitely can't tell what gun anyone is using, because if they aren't shooting, they holster it into the black hole they carry around in their back pocket. A for gun safety guys, but that is a living hell for me to manage. Also: [b]WHY ARE PREGNANT LADIES ALLOWED TO BE GIVEN GUNS OH MY GOD[/b]. They can't use them, why even have the option?

It's Positively Excellent! The way you build a vault, it's like every builder's dream

This game eats your time, Its really fun and does entertain those who like building. The idea is amazing. If you want to mess around on a level head to my youtube channel (Pafiro) and youll find a video on how to get 9999 free lunchboxes, I use it on my second level just for fun. Enjoy ;)
Very addicting and awesome!!!!

This game is BEGGING to be an idle game where you manage very little and things like the waterplant, powerplant, and foodplant (er, diner) just do there thing automatically with no need for you to tap on them every 3 minutes. Seriously, you're "buffer zone" between being capped out on 'resources' (food, water, power) and being in critical condition is ~8 minutes. That's right. If you're not on top of things all the time constantly you'll stop having enough power/food/water to keep things chugging along happily.  All because the dwellers can't move the produced 'resources' from the generator to storage on their own.

On top of that, those resources aren't meaningful. They really should be "supply/demand" ratios. You build more rooms, your total power usage goes up and your capacity stays the same. Build a powerplant, your capacity goes up. Done.  Your only REAL resource is bottlecaps, which you primarily get from....achievements and lunch boxes (which you ALSO get from achievements, I meant objectives).

And everything else you can do is basically devoid of entertainment value. Build rooms, upgrade rooms, give people pets. Woo.

Ok so i have played the mobile version, tried the PC version. 

1: Great graphics for what it is. And if your familier with fall out at all. it will bring some nostalgia.
2: Its a good simulator if somewhat hard.
3: Dont rush your buildings. 

ps: On the dont rush your buildings. I think im the only person in the world who can fail 23 rushes in a row even with 15%
chance to fail.

There is a huge problem with the saving system, everytime there is a power outage or a blue screen the save file and backup save file get completely ruined, worst thing is that it syncronices with the cloud and ruins that one too,  there are many complaints everywhere about this issue and it looks like they are not even trying to fix it, allmost every negative review I've read in steam is about this issue, otherwise the game is good, casual and fun but untill they fix this I won't be playing it again.

I can't believe how addicting this game is. I find myself coming back to check the vault status all the time. A little boring until I got the overseers office. Then the real action started. Love the simple not overly complicated game play. Just enough story in the quests to keep me interested. Remember... Keep the vault dwellers happy.

addictive
This game is ver enjoyable, it just requires stratergy, too many retards making review explaining how hard it is lmao. Very very enjoyable

So I played this game on my iPhone and the PC version is just as fun. This game does start out slow in the beginning, but once you keep playing, more starts to happen and the game gets more fun. And the fact that this game is completely free is what makes this a game that you have to play because if you don't like it, you can uninstall and feel like you haven't wasted any of your money. Unless you buy the in-game products... oops. Just give it a shot because you may or may not like it.

I don't mind microtransactions but holy hell, this game requires you to pay money to expedite processes or otherwise you tend to be just sitting and waitnig for things to happen for long periods of time.

This game reminds me of the Clash of Clans pricing model which is just a terrible way to do business (in my opinion).  I found that this game rips off a lot of what the PC game "Sheltered" tried to do and whil it is more polished, the microtransactions really kills it for me.

I do not recommend this game.

Fun and addicting game to pass time by.

1 flaw though. You aren't able to link your Bethesda account to any of the mobile (Android/IOS), Bethesda's game client or Windows 10 game versions to have your vault on both mobile and PC. Bethesda living in the stone ages?

What does this mean? That means your save from the mobile app, etc can't be played on Steam. You can't transfer it or port it over.

Because of this reason, I will be sticking to the Windows 10 version since you can play it on both Windows 10 and Xbox One without having to worry about your save (oddly enough, Microsoft is smarter than Bethesda, who knew).

If I could, I would put my recommendation of the game "neutral." Only until they add this feature, which they probably won't since it's almost been a year since the release of this game (E3 2016).

This is a mobile game. Don't waste your time. There is also no way to stop time when you leave or pause.

I generally recomend this game. For a free-to-play mobile port, it's of a pretty high quality. There are some frame rate issues, and it doesn't work as well as it would've on mobile, but I still had some fun with it, and I'd definetly recommend it, especially considering that it's free.

This game is one of my favorites. Most of the reviews are people who don't understand how the game works. Mircotransaction is not what this game is about. There are quest you can do that happen quite often that give you the items you can buy with real money.
Piece of shit, despite it's price.

Actually Liking this game alot.  Playing on PC (Hate smart phone, refuse to create a 3rd bethesda account in 10 years) so glad it's on steam.  Trick is to play long enough to get your stuff done, then save and exit until you need to go back in (Hit your training rooms, Quest group arives at destination, crafting completed, etc.)  That way you are'nt watching the kettle boil.

I would actually like to see this gameplay in the Fallout 4 Engine and think it would have made a better game then Fallout 4's Main Story (But that is a whole nother discussion.  

It's probley not for everyone, but if you have time to kill there are worse ways to spend time.  Haven't spent any money (may in the future just to recomp the fun I had, then again I may take it in Liue of Fallout 4's lackluster story and stunted roleplay).

It's an okay game, and it's free.  The free part is the most important part; it's worth a try because it is free.  You might like it.  However, give it a few hours and the limited scope, frequency of annoying emergencies, accidental reassignment of dwellers, lack of useful equipment, lack of useful dweller stats, and overall wonkiness will start to wear on you.  It is definitely a good mobile game, but it's a bit mundane for PC.  5/10

Its very much a mobile style game, and it has microtransactions, but you don't need to purchase anything to have fun. In fact the depth and options in this game put a lot of these self-described triple-A games to shame. 

It may not be right for you, but its free to try. Quick learning curve. If you like strategy, puzzles, RPG, sims, theme parks and 4X builders, you will find something in here to enjoy. I'm runnning win 10 with no issues on a top end rig.

Played this on my phone for a long time, got it when it ported over.
It has it moments but anyone saying its Pay to win clearly can't figure out the rewards you get for free. I've never spent a dime on this game ( not even on my phone ) and I find it rather enjoyable and obtain quite a few lunchboxes, pets, mr handy's all along the way. It really is rather simple if you pay attention and try to complete things. 
Overall I would recommend this game to those who have patience, and to those who do other things, this is not a game you play for 6-8 hours straight at one time. Get on, get some stuff done, build up the shelter, and then take a break.

This game looks like it has a LOT of potential. I downloaded it two weeks ago and have suffered through 25 minutes of playing. It is designed for a game controller, which makes it a great choice for game consoles. I, however, have a PC. I eventually had to unplug the flight stick, pedals, and throttle quadrant to have any control over the game. No menu exists for choosing anything other than the default gamepad. Even with all those controls unplugged (from the back of my crowded PC) I still have trouble selecting and viewing characters. I can't drag them to the various rooms because the game drags them to the lower right corner of the screen. It also doesn't let me select different rooms to work with. Maybe there's a workaround or a wiki that addresses all of these issues but I have not seen it.  Other than not being playable without a controller, I think it's well worth the price. It is FREE after all. Once I see a few updates to make it at least a little more user friendly I'll play it again. Until the authors put some work into the interface though, I'm content to just look at the icon on my screen and say, "Relax, Pip boy; your code monkeys will address this soon enough if they seriously want people to spend money in the game".

Pros:

Fun game. Good sense of humor. Lovely design.

Cons:

The difficulty spike around mid game is too much. I felt like I was losing everything to simple enemies like roaches.
Requires almost no thought process and almost none of the lategame stuff can be gotten withought paying or cheating. So for your own sanity I wouldn't advise starting in the first place.

An interesting spin-off for the Fallout franchise that puts you in control of your very own vault. It's your job to build it, grow it, and keep the inhabitants happy. Things like crafting, collecting supplies, and sending your vault dwellers out on quests really capture the feel of the Fallout universe.

The free-to-play nature of it is handled incredibly well. You really can do everything and not spend any money. The microtransactions are barely noticeable. You can still feel like you are making progress while waiting on the timers.

Various updates have removed the need for almost constant attention the game required before. Now you can take some time off and not have to worry about your vault being in horrible shape when you return. They finally fixed it where you can pick up play it whenever you feel like rather than having your time with it being dominated by the game's needy nature.

It's a completely free-to-play spin-off that feels completely part of the Fallout universe. Building and managing your very own vault can be a blast. The pick up and play at your own leisure nature of it makes it worth a look for any Fallout fan. It's also worth a look for those who enjoy these kinds of building sims and don't want to feel like it's constantly shaking you down for money.

Most fun I've had for free in a while.
Charming graphics, decent background music, fun resource management.
The difficulty steadily follows your progression and stays challenging, though never becomes completely overwhelming (unless you've planned your vault defenses poorly).

A tip I would have liked to know when I started is to place your power rooms at the very top and outfit the dwellers with the best weapons, as this will ensure strong and well-levelled defenders when the deathclaws start rolling in.

Although it is very tempting to buy resources and goodies, the game is more than perfectly enjoyable without them and luch boxes are given out so seldomly that they really feel like you've earned them.
Great little sim game but don't spend money on this game as if it crashes you will lose your vault completely and everything you've spent on it.

I hate the Fallout series, and that's because of two reasons: It's too boring, and too grindheavy.
...but I still kinda like this game, mostly because I don't have to pay anything for it.

This game started out as a mobile game before being ported to PC, so the only controls are pointing and left-clicking, but they still managed to get a lot of gameplay out of that mechanic.
I hear that there's still plenty of bugs, though - even SAVE BREAKING bugs! ...but while I've noticed plenty of graphics not showing up, so far the game hasn't crashed on me personally.
Yes, you can buy equipment for real money if you want to, but from what I can see, you can get that equipment anyway with a bit of patience, so this is NOT a Pay-to-Win game. I've never felt the need to spend money on this game.
However, like the rest of Fallout, this game is kind of repetitive and grindy too. However, this is a game that you play by checking in on every once in a while during the day, while it plays itself "in the background", so you won't motice it that much: If you send your guys out on a mission at 8 o clock IRL time, they will arrive at 8:00 + 14 hour travel = 22:00 when you go to bed.
...so if I need to fill your empty days with something, then this is a "good" time waster.

Update:
Warning: There is quite a notable difficulty spike when you get 50 dwellers, because that's when the radscorpions show up. They can show up as random encounters every five minutes, or if you fail a rush, and they will slaughter you. If you are fully stocked on stimpacks and radaways, you can withstand one or two attacks with some skill, but after that you will just die. Your base will just go bye-bye. You will be the overseer over a bunch of corpses, that you can revive until your money runs out.
...but the game was fun up until that point.

The game is the best in its genre. People need to understand the mentality of its gameplay, you are not suppose to open and play it for hours. Its a side game, a multi task game, a coffee game to spend that 10 minutes and look forward for the next day to send more dwellers into the wasteland, build more facilities, breed and expand. Its gonna be slow, its gonna take time but it is worth it, because this is YOUR Vault with YOUR people.

Some notes for new players. 

-The game is free but extremely fair. You can cheat some premium items without any repercussions. I would personally recommend it.

-This is a casual game as you don't need to worry too much if you make some mistakes. But it has great depth and interesting mechanics to research and improve your vault and make better decisions.

With that being said it not without its flaws. The managing of your dwellers can become  a huge chore later on. The UI doesn't help since it's build for mobiles. But that is my single complain. I wish they make some improvements there but I don't see that happens especially since its exactly the same game everywhere, iOS, Android, Bathesda PC client, Windows 10 and steam versions.

Unfortunately for those wondering, you can't auto sync your game with the mobile version, even though all the platforms share the same kind of save file. That means that the game doesn't support autosync but you can easily manually take your save files and use them in any other platform. 

**I played on different platform so I don't yet have a lot of time f to display here, but steam has achievements so yay!**

I'd like to give this a neutral review but since that's not an option, i'll give a slight recommendation.

first, i'd like to address the elephant in the room. this game was originally developed for tablet, which, as you should know, means that if you expect a real game, you're gonna be disappointed. if you want a real game that you can play for at least two to five hours without taking a break or getting bored, you may wanna take a look at Sheltered or something similar. generally, it's a good idea to stay away from f2p or tablet games if you want a real game. also, obviously, the controls are mediocre at best and annoying at worst, it really shows that it wasn't originally designed for pc.

ok, now that that's out of the way, let's get to the actual review part. the core gameplay mechanics seem pretty generic, as it can be expected from a f2p game. that's not really a bad thing though since it's basically a waiting game which means it is expected to deal with pretty basic mechanics. click on things to collect resources and items, click on people to let them level up, and so on. if you want to loose, you have to try very hard (if it's even possible to let everyone in your vault die, unless you play on survival), if you want to "win" you have to spend money or play for a very long time (what i mean by "winning" is having built everything that you want to build). nothing new.

the game will continue to run if you are logged out, and obviously while you're not online, you won't be able to collect anything. that is also not really bad though because after a short while, the resource consumption will be halted. so you will have a little less resources when you log back in but they won't be completely depleted.

generally, if you don't want to spend money on it, it seems to be a good idea to just log in every couple of hours, collect everything, send some people on quests, start a new weapon/armor production, maybe use speed-mode a couple of times to get a few caps and fill your resource-storage faster and once everything seems good, you can log out again. just don't forget to check your statistics-screen every once in a while, to make sure that your production per minute is still higher than your consumption per minute.

also, there are a couple bugs, crashes and other issues. if you decide to play this game, maybe you have already played some early access titles where the developers simply stopped to care and never fixed any bugs or anything? this game will remind you of that. there is absolutely no communication from the developer, certain bugs have been known for years but no one cared enough to fix them. after a simple look at the discussions you will also probably find that you shouldn't get too attatched to your vault and definitely shouldn't spend any money on it. almost every day i looked, there has been at least one thread on front page complaining about the game being unplayable due to crashes/freezes/etc or the save file being corrupted/disappeared. so it definitely is a bit of a gamble.

if everything works and you are lucky enough to not run into any game breaking bugs it can be fun but that is definitely not guaranteed. so if you like waiting games you can definitely give it a try but i would strongly suggest to not support the developer by buying anything in this game until they start to care a little bit more and fix bugs and other problems.

Probably one of the best free-to-play type 'mobile' games currently available. It isn't freemium by any stretch, you're not pressured to buy currency with real money around every corner. You can buy 'Nuka Cola Quantums' to speed up certain actions that would normally take a lot of time, but the nice thing is that these Nuka Cola Quantums can also be obtained by simply playing the game. And in decent numbers too (I currently have 27 of them without spending a dime). The waiting times aren't really all that bothersome anyway. Time keeps ticking when you're not playing so you can just come back later.

This game has come a long way since it was first introduced on iOS and Android. Bethesda keeps adding new content and mechanics. Going questing with your dwellers is a fun getaway from building and managing your vault.

Overall this is the type of game you check in on every few hours or so. It doesn't nag you for money (much) and is engaging and sometimes challenging to play.

Your only supposed to play like 10 minutes, then go on with your life until 8 hours when the mission is done. Why change the one whole portion of the game just so you can finish the game without waiting for anything and taking the realism out of doing a quest. Even if people are bothered by these long waiting times, it's a free game, why even give a negative review for a free game. I would only do it if the game is genuinely bad. Fallout Shelter is fun and addictive and only has few problems that don't bother me.

So, you know the good kind of free-to-play game, the kind that's basically just a normal game, except you don't have to pay money for it? Yeah, this isn't one of those games. This is the kind of free-to-play game that I like to call "faux-to-play" (I don't really. I don't know why I said that. Just go with it). That is, a game that lets you play for about 2 minutes, and then charges you (inordinately large amounts of) real money to keep playing.

Actually, that's not quite right. Let me take you through my gameplay experience so far with this game (bearing in mind that I've only played 20 minutes, and don't intend to play more).

1: Do the tutorial.

2: Sit and wait.

3: Get a tutorial message (it calls itself a tip, but from what I could see, the tips were just telling you basic things that should have been in the tutorial)

4: A new dweller arrives. Take a minute to put them to work.

5: Sit and wait.

6: Get another "tip."

7: Repeat steps 4-6 until you have 12 dwellers (this took me about 20 minutes, mostly of sitting and waiting, with the occasional "tip")

8: Get a new room, which allows you to store more weapons and armour for your dwellers (incidentally, weapons and armour won't actually be unlocked for at least another half hour of playing (correction: another half hour of "playing").

9: Sit and wait some more.

TL;DR: This "game" is a mobile port at it's very finest. The best this about it is the 2.5D graphics.

Incidentally, it's also a perfect example of something I've never understood; why do free-to-play mobile games always get such good reviews? The only thing I can think of is that the people "playing" them have nothing better to do.

[u]About the game:[/u]
Fallout Shelter is primarily about [b]creating, organizing, and developing a Vault.[/b]

[u]So:[/u][list]
[*]The graphic is nice to look at
[*]Gaming performance has no any serious errors
[*]In general a nice change[/list]
[u]What I find personally irritating:[/u][list]
[*]is the regular, non-optimal movement of residents from A to B
[*]People outside of the Vault are not the brightest - [spoiler]apparently, it is too difficult or demanding to use the meds you give them.[/spoiler]
[*]Even after carefully planning the breeding combination of females and males, I mostly had children with an increased charisma value - [i]maybe I'm too stupid.[/i][/list]
Some players mention that Bethesda is pushy (offers for cash and frequent ads), which I can't relate to; of course, you're not bombarded with items, but you can earn them without spending money - only slower, as in other games.

[u]Conclusion:[/u] For in between and on a long-term it definitely fulfils its purpose - and it's free for God's sake.

Six hours in....

It's a good thing this game is free, because Fallout Shelter is the very definition of a grind: inconsequential clicking and long waits with the sole purpose of making small numbers grow into bigger ones. 

There is actually very little to do. If it wasn't necessary to click on your vault dwellers when they level up or give birth, or click on rooms to collect resources, the game would probably play itself just fine. Raider attacks and radroach infestations are a joke, as your dwellers will easily overcome them without your input. You can equip them with weapons, outfits and pets to make them more effective, but they don't seem to matter much. Their attributes (the SPECIAL stats that Fallout fans will be very familiar with) seem to dictate how well they do certain jobs, and their level seems to have a major influence on survivability; however, despite the wealth of tips that pop up, it's unclear exactly why or in what way these things matter. Is a vault dweller with high Perception better with a pistol than a vault dweller with low Perception? Fallout lore would say yes, but in Fallout Shelter it doesn't seem to make much difference.

You can send your people into the Wasteland to explore, where they randomly gain XP, caps and items as well as slowly have their health whittled down by enemies. They can be recalled at any time; the longer they are out, however, the longer it takes for them to return, meaning even more waiting. Once you have the Overseer's Office room, you can also send groups on quests that consistently turn up much, much better loot but again have irritatingly long travel times to and from the destination. The gameplay when they get there is a huge disappointment; click on a room to explore, click on an object to loot it, wait as combat happens automatically, click on the End Quest button when it's all over. Again, with a little automation, this rather boring questing could take care of itself while the player concentrated on more interesting activities - of which, sadly, there are none to speak of.

It occured to me at about this point (right before I decided FS wasn't worth any more of my time) that Bethesda missed a golden opportunity with this game. The Vaults in Fallout were each the site of some kind of social experiment. Why on earth did this not carry over to Fallout Shelter? Couldn't we have built the Overseer's Office and then, having built the foundation of a stable Vault, been randomly assigned some crazy end goal to give the player a purpose?

Ultimately, though, that purpose is to send Bethesda a steady trickle of your hard-earned cash via microtransactions. The wait times can be skipped or shortened with Nuka-Cola, and random loot boxes - with caps, vault dwellers, pets, weapons, outfits and crafting materials inside - can help expand on your collection of practically useless equipment, and both can be bought from the store. However, it's just money tossed on the fire to push you more quickly to an endgame that may or may not exist. 

Then there are the little things that make the game....less like a game. For instance, your Vault Dwellers will level up over time, but they stop gaining XP until you click on them to acknowledge that fact. Unless you buy the feature from the store to get around that. Which, if I'm reading this right, means that you can pay Bethesda to remove activities from a game that's pretty anaemic when it comes to gameplay already. I mean, I can see the point (money), but I can't see why Bethesda don't even try to hide it.

I think we're hitting microtransaction critical mass these days, in which gamers are so accustomed to pointless cash purposes that devs don't care whether we notice them fleecing us or not. That probably describes Fallout Shelter in a nutshell, so let's get this review over with.

Summary: A freemium game with the life and soul of Fallout sucked out of it and a microtransaction system that will make you weep with it's pointlessness. There may be some goal worth working towards later in the game, but after six hours I've seen no evidence of it and have lost all motivation to keep looking. It gets a point for the Fallout aesthetic, but everything else falls flat. Watch paint dry instead - at least you won't be tempted to pay someone to accelerate the process.

I got to play this game for a bit on a friend's ipad back when it was first released and i was pretty intrigued. I really liked the idea of running my own vault and I'm glad i finally get the chance to try it again. It's changed a fair amount since I first played and I like the pets, robots, and quests that you can use to help level up your dwellers and make more caps. It's a much more engaging game than it used to be. It's still a waiting game, for sure, but I find that there's a lot more to do than just collect resources and caps and wait-over and over. The quests and locations let you pretty directly control your dwellers while exploring locations. There are plenty of quests with a decent amount of story to them and I like that they give you dialogue options and bring the charm and fun of Fallout's world and lore to this style of game. I like that you can get robots now that will collect your resources while you're away. Being able to find, scrap, or use the junk and salvage from the wasteland to make outfits and weapons for your dwellers. I don't see any features for trading supplies with other vaults or friendly settlements, but I hope a feature like that gets added as it would give even more moneymaking options and give more uses for the junk, weapons, and outfits you find. Being able to buy weapons, outfits, pets, robots, and the like from other settlements would take this game over the top. And it's already such a good game already. I like that you can train all of your dwellers in all of their special stats to help them be more efficient at their various jobs. Plus pretty much every dweller can mate with any other dweller (so long as they're not related). It makes increasing your population fairly easy. You can just use a few males and get all the women pregnant and have new babies and adults every hour or so if you time it right and have enough resrouces stockpiled. Utilizing your dwellers' SPECIAL stats becomes more and more important as the vault expands, it seems. 
In all, I would recommend this if you are looking for a nice casual game to play. It's not the best if you're looking to be fully engaged for a whole day, but none of these kinds of game really are. It's why they're usually free to play like this one is. 
(Also, it gets annoying trying to control your dwellers manually with the mouse. It is very obviously designed for touch screen controls and it gets frustrating during infestions and raider attacks to control your tiny dwellers as they are frantically running all around getting killed. Pregnant women won't engage in combat either, so make sure you space them out in case of an animal or raider attack as they are useless in combat but sometimes seem to get stuck in a room during a crisis and take up a slot in the room that forces you to manually remove them so you can manually move someone else in there to help out with whatever the situation is.)


Edit: the deathclaw attacks and radscorpion attacks are getting more and more tediious the higher level my dwellers reach. each one nearly wipes out out my stockpile of resources and all my stimpaks and radaway. why are they so overpowered? this is insane. since i wrote my reeview i've noticed i'm spending all my time dreading the next deathclaw or radscorpion attack as i know they'll deplete everything i have. why is it setup this way? this is not fun.


Edit: changed my review to a negative one as i can no longer enjoy/really play the game. every time i come back, i have 10 seconds or so before i get stuck with yet another deathclaw attack. my resources are gone and my vault is in shambles because of these relentless attacks. i'm not even playing anymore-i'm just trying to survive deathclaw attacks. what did you do to this game, bethesda? is this intentional? because i have no idea how you rationalize deathclaws busting down a door designed to withstand a nuclear blast. not only can they not do that, but there's no reason for them to. i am fine with all the other aspects of this game-the raider attacks, the radscorpion, radroach, and mole rat outbreaks. but these deathclaws are too much-it's literally unplayable as you can't rush rooms, build rooms, breed dwellers, or do pretty much anything until the deathclaw attack is over. so glad i didn't waste money on this. please fix this so i can play the game-because it really was fun until that got out of hand.
This game is awesome !

I have over a 100+ hours on this on my Ipad. Here's a full review, including the "late game" experience.

In short: Cute little game that has its flaws, but is fun if you are patient and can adapt to its special way of doing things. However it's a bit of an odd package, because it doesn't fit either the "hands off, mining while I am away" nor the "active game, give me things to do and micromanage" mold. It's somewhere in between and most problems come from that aspect.

PROS

- Fallout universe, experience what it can be like to be an overseer and managing your own vault
- Great design, simple yet efficient and fitting the universe and graphic design set by the other fallout games
- Relaxing! It's not about stress or micro management, it's about patience, resource accumulation, and seeing your vault grow.
- Once your vault grows a bit and you have around 80-100+ dweller, things are more fun. You will have a lot of explorers (max is 25 on ipad, not sure if there is a limit on PC) who will find stuff for you. You will have multiple crafting rooms to make weapons, outfits, themes, etc. You will train your dwellers and make them better. You will also be running up to 3 quests at the same time (sending dwellers out for specific tasks that have micro stories and better outcomes than exploration)
- A good way to start your day, check on your dwellers in bed while you are waking up a bit, and then check on them again in bed before sleep. Twice a way is enough to keep this game going.

CONS

- Resources don't accumulate while you are offline, except for your explorers finding stuff (which might be enough)
- Forces you to do some stuff you don't want to do, misplaced micromanagement. For instance, each time someone levels up, you have to click him to acknowledge it or else he will stop getting experience. 
- Same thing with training dwellers, if you put someone on strength training, you have to be there to approve each of his level up or else they will gain 1 stat then stop and wait for you... for this reason you can't just leave a dweller in a strength training room for a couple of weeks then come back and find him with maximum strength... you have to validate each level up. It's annoying but not game breaking, since this is the kind of game that requires you to check on it a couple of times per day at least, else don't bother playing.
- Very slow start. It pickups mid to late game and has more things for you to do when you get 100+ dwellers, but when you start it is very boring to watch resources accumulate. The early game needs more gameplay to make it more interesting. My advice is to NOT play this game actively at the start. Make babies, leave, check a few hours later to check on kids, then leave again and come back to see those new adults and put them to work. Don't play it too actively at the start because you will get bored. 

REVIEW

This game is about having a relaxing time building your vault and accumulating loot. It starts off slow with only half a dozen dwellers and everything yet to be built. You start producing food, water, and power, and focusing on growing the number of dwellers, either through attracting some from the wilds (building a radio station, which attracts dwellers but also attacks from raiders and other monsters), or through mating your dwellers and making babies. 

Midgame as the number of dwellers grow, you unlock more buildings and more possibilities for gameplay. This includes the "overseer office" that lets you start quests, which are like little adventures in the wild that you micromanage. Training rooms so you can enhance the SPECIAL attributes of all your dwellers and make them better at their jobs. Production rooms to make stimpacks (healing) and radaway, and also rooms that let you make weapons, outfits and armors, themes (different designs for your rooms inspired by the institute, rail road, minute men, etc.), and better production rooms such as more powerful power / water / food production facilities. There is also the barbershop that will let you customize the look of every dweller, chancing their hair, face features, and accessories.

You will surely also chase the steam achievements obviously, and it is fairly possible to get them all by late game.

The late game is mostly about getting your dwellers perfected with great stats, running 3 different teams on the quests to try to finish as many quest chains as possible for the rewards, perfecting your vault layout (at that point you will have used every available space and have to think more about what you want to keep and delete), and finally a bit of roleplay as you give your dwellers specific names and customized looks inspired by your favorite characters, and finally sending them very far into the wild to get better loot (the farther they go the better loot they find, every SPECIAL stat gives them an edge, also their weapons, outfits, and quantity of stimpacks and radaways). At this stage in the game, you are mostly a collector, trying to get every recipe and blueprint, making guns and outfits, and just enjoying having a great fully functional vault and pushing it to perfection.

MICRO TRANSACTION, PAY TO WIN OR NOT?

It is not. I played on my Ipad without spending anything, and i eventually gotten all the things that you can purchase with money. I got the legendary dwellers, i got the legendary weapons and outfits, i got all the caps i need and more, and my explorers regularly bring nuka cola (it lets you speed up things like travel time or train time) if i am actively playing to collect them, and i even got enough Mr Handy (they collect the resources from dwellers for you so you don't have to click them), and i even got a lot of pets from exploration. No need to spend anything! If you spend it will be because you want to advance faster or be more comfortable, which is your decision to make.

That being said, here's some advice if you want to spend your money and what is the best way to do so :
1. If you buy something, start with Mr Handy... it will reduce the micro management and let you focus on other things
2. The starter pack is nice ONLY because it gives you a pet that lets you return faster (4 times faster which is quite a lot, most pets you will find will give you 1.25x speed to 2x speed, a 4x times speed boost is very rare and valuable) from exploration and missions, the Mr Handy is also nice. 
3. Avoid the lunch boxes, they guarantee a rare but is often a rare salvage and rarely a weapon or outfit, meaning it is often a waste of money (crafting a legendary weapon takes about 9 legendary salvage, so even in the off chance you get one legendary salvage from a box it is quite insignificant). You will get lunch boxes from quests and active exploration, and it is too much hit and miss to be worth the money.
4. Pets are rare enough and powerful enough that they might be worth buying, but again not necessary. Some of the most valuable ones are travel time, damage resistance, added damage, and crafting time reduction.
5. Nuka cola speeds up things, especially travel times to quests. But the issue is, you'd need a lot of it and it can be very expensive (1 nuka cola saves you about 2 hours of wait time). I would not bother, just practice patience as you will be playing this game over weeks and months, and speeding a few hours or even days at a time is a very tiny advantage over the long run.

freemium shit

[h1]What is it?[/h1]
Fallout Shelter is a simple game that takes simple exploration and RPG elements of Fallout (of course) and combines these with base-building from games such as Sim Tower or Project Highrise.  You don't need to have played any of the Fallout games to play.  Your task is a simple one: build a vault that will provide food, water and power for vault dwellers who have survived a nuclear attack, and assign them to the most suitable rooms in the vault, defend the vault against various forms of attack and send some intrepid explorers on adventures to loot buildings, help people and tackle typical Fallout enemies such as ghouls, raiders and deathclaws.

And to address the elephant in the room: it's a freemium game that does try to encourage you to part with your cash, BUT this is not intrusive and allows you to play and enjoy the game regardless (you don't have to spend ANY money to enjoy the game in full).  As is typical in mobile freemium games, this one allows you to play for a little bit, and then you need to wait in real time for a few hours before things happen at first.  This improves though as your vault begins to fill out, and you'll then be able to play pretty much constantly with up to three vaults simultaneously.



[h1]What's good about it?[/h1]
It's fun!  After the initial hours where you play a little then have to wait for a lot of time, there is plenty to do.  Additionally, Bethesda incorporated exploration and missions to the game that aim to emulate those in the proper Fallout game, and these have been done brilliantly.  Freemium mechanics weigh in by making you wait several real-time hours before your chosen explorers arrive at their mission (and will try to sell you upgrades to fast-forward this waiting-time) but you can just leave that vault and play another, or just let the game run its course overnight.  Once your vault has a good number of people in it, you'll find you're kept much more busy and waiting-time isn't so noticeable.  Every vault dweller has their S.P.E.C.I.A.L Fallout traits that can be improved with training (for people new to Fallout, these stats reflect strength, perception and such).  Combat is simple and based largely on whether your people or the enemy have more points of strength.  There is also a simple crafting system where you can weaponise and armour your vault dwellers.  Finally, the in-game introduction tutorial is superb, ensuring players unfamiliar with Fallout will be able to play too.


[h1]Anything not so good?[/h1]
The worst aspect of the game lies again in its freemium nature: any pack you purchase is only usable just once.  Should you start a new vault, the pack will NOT transfer.  Whether or not this will trouble you will depend on whether you intend to spend.  It IS tempting and the game will try to sell you one-time introductory packs periodically, but you CAN ignore them and play without spending anything whatsoever (you don't get less of a game - you just have to be more patient and wait for things to happen).  

And the waiting-time (in real hours) can be very frustrating at first - but as said already, this becomes less of a problem the bigger your vault becomes.


[h1]Recommended![/h1]
You can ignore the prompts to spend real money if you want without sacrificing any aspect of the game.  While at first you will be waiting around for things to happen, there will soon be plenty for you to do as your vault expands.  This is a worthy game to download and huge kudos to Bethesda for not limiting gameplay for people who don't want to spend their cash on upgrades.

I read a lot of complaints about this game, that make little to no sense if you ask me.
People complain about micro payments, you dont need to buy anything, the wasteland and quests provide for everything you want to find/own, so paying for things, is optional.
Others claim this game forces you to come back every 5 minutes because of the resource gather system, this too isnt correct thinking, when you are not in the game, the power/water/food supply, does not drop under the minimum required amount of said goods. So, your dwellers wont starve if you have not played for 2 days, it would not make sense if it was the case now, would it?
And yet others complain that their dwellers die of lack of water or food, and that too is ridiculous, just make sure you got enough dwellers working the cafeteria(s), water refineree(s) and most importantly, the generator rooms, without power, other important rooms may stop functioning, and you can run out of water/food that way. 
Also, make sure you add dwellers to jobs, that they are meant for, look at a dweller's stats before you assign him or her to a room, for example, if you have a dweller with 1 S(trenght) and 4 P(erception), you dont want that dweller to work in the generator rooms because those demand S(trenght) so instead, you send that dweller to the water refinery because that room demands P(erception), the higher the skill level of a dweller, the better he or she is suited for tasks that demand those skills, it speeds up the process of said rooms.

Ok review time, is this an amazing game? hmm, i guess that would be pushing it, but it sure is a fun game, looks good, has a million references to current and previous fallout games, with patience you can get all those items and dwellers from grinding the game itself, no cash needed.
Unlike what some people try to claim, this game is perfect for casual play, but also for constant play.
Questing is fun to do, exploring yields a lot of nice goodies as well, especially the longer you let a dweller explore the wastelands, the trick to do this succesfully is to make sure they go out there with a high damage weapon, and at least 25 stimpacks + say 10 or so, radaway, get them an outfit that gives them a bonus on strenght, perception, endurance and/or luck (there are a great variety of outfits, some with 1 added bonus, others with 2 or more) and also make sure the dweller you send, has decent levels of these skills, then you're set, and can send a dweller out for days at a time (actual days).
Do keep in mind, that whenever there is a fight (raiders invading, radroaches, molrats, gouls, deathclaws) that you dont need to do the fighting yourself, the dwellers will do this (if they have weapons) but you will have to apply stimpacks and radaway to keep the dwellers alive during a fight (same in quests), an icon will appear above the dweller when low on health, click it and he/she will use a stimpack or radaway, just make sure they have good weapons and gear.
But all in all, this game demands patience, and some people dont like to wait, thats 80% of the negative reactions on here i guess ;)

I am not sure I would bother. It's an "okay" game if you just have it running in the background while you are doing something else, but later on in the game the tables just turn to the absurd. I have failed like 7/8 rushes in a row when they had a 30% or lower failure rate. This happened because radroaches spawned inside and started siphoning off all my energy, and mole rats for some reason at higher levels siphon energy extremely fast also. Everything siphons energy when you get above 60 people in your vault. The game just spikes in difficulty when you get to 40 and to 60 people so I think the smart way to play the game would be to just sit on your hands and try and pump up all your characters below 39 people and then play the game afterwards. 

Even so, the mechanics are stupid. If someone breaks into your vault and nobody is in a room (which happens it seems 90% of the time they go for an empty room) you have to send people from another area, then they inevitably get there too late and the invader burrows to another room, so eventually all your people are running everywhere and you can't keep track of which character has a good gun to actually fight off this invasion. All the while everyones taking radiation damage and physical damage, and they're siphoning off your energy--which in turn shuts down the majority of your vault buildings. Its great. So then you have to temporarily pull people off of every other duty they were doing when your vault was humming like a swiss watch and put them onto energy production then you have to manage to remember to put everyone back where they were before hand--a near impossible task. Its just an annoyance. A huge annoyance.

Then if you're "lucky" you spend the rest of the time just clicking on status updates, like gathering energy, or gathering food, or the rare opportunity that you are able to to level someones stats up. I think this game would be a lot better if the endurance stat did not exist. Apparently the only way to really level up your heroes health a lot is to pump up their endurance. So you have to put all your low levels on endurance training for like 4 real time days to pump up their endurance. Only then can you really make use of them in other capacities if you really want to maximize their experience. 

It's pretty dumb. The whole game feels like a waste of time sadly. I just don't have much else to play so I am doing it. I swear though, the first time someone comes in and wipes my vault I am done with this game forever. 

Its really a micro transaction game about gambling with the lunchboxes they give you early on. Because lunchboxes (that you have to buy with real money to get in any regularity) contain cards which can help you when you are struggling. But they can also just give you useless legendary materials that 99% of people will never be able to use because they'll quit the game before they can make the stuff. Its stupid. Even then manufacturing a rare weapon took ~16 real hours. I can only imagine a legendary one would take 5 days or something,

So in short. Stay away. It just is not fun enough over the long term...the only real fun I have is going out on quests and even those require you to wait hours and hours unless you buy some nuka cola (yes, real money again) to speed things up. It's just a way to siphon money and its too nakedly obvious to want to even do it. Generally games like this have you provide you with a fun experience along the way, but this one just feels 100% designed to siphon money.

On mobile this game seems good, but on PC it doesn't fit; the game requires you to pick it up multiple times a day and only needs your attention for short periods of time, so I found myself easily bored.

One thing I give this game credit for is how much it made me laugh in the short time I played it.  To gain additional vault dwellers you either accept outsiders or mate your existing inhabitants.  There was 1 man, of whom become known as Stud McQueen, whos designated post was the living quarters (aka the insemination chamber).  This sexual beast of a man became the father of every child born in the vault.  Unfortunately, the children all came to term at the same time when I checked up on them last evening and panic ensued.  Six babies were delivered with no medical assistance onto the living room carpet, those stains will never come out.  The resulting population boom saw a period of shortages of food and water, the vault's inhabitants began to suffer.... everyone except Stud McQueen, who was perpetually at 100% happiness... the cvnt..........   One mother even came to term in the chaos, however there were no more beds to house her baby as the overseer didn't pick up enough bottle caps from his mate's stag do last week to construct a new birthing pit and hovel combo for said mother;  she just had to hold it in...  the baby is now a grown man and has even landed a job, he works from home, of course, concidering the mother needs to be wheeled to the power plant everyday and her umbillical cord doesn't streatch that far.

In short, the game is designed to be used on mobile devices, maybe you can play it on PC while on facebook or doing some typing, that way you can check up on the game every now and then as you need to wait real time untill you can interact with it again.

[h1] I see a lot of misunderstanding and misinterpretations when it comes to Fallout Shelter. Please let me help you out![/h1] 

[b] THE GAME IS BETTER ON PC THAN PHONE: [/b] 
You can open this game on PC and let it run for hours. No phone can do that. Mainly due to battery life and pause-screens. This game is easily manageable from PC while you watch television, browse Imgur or watch some chick series on Netflix.
Besides, controlling the game on PC is a joy compared to navigating fat fingers on a 5" phone screen. There's just so much more room on a PC screen. 

[b] YOUR SAVE GAMES ARE COMPATIBLE WITH OTHER DEVICES - BACKWARD AND FORWARD COMPABILITY! [/b] 
I used to move save games between my phone to a PC running BlueStacks. 
Now I'm moving those same old save games between phone and PC. And you know what? It works!
It's so easy a 5 year old child could do it. Just copy the vaultx file between the devices you want. 
I even expect the cloud sync function might actually work betwen phone and PC. (unconfirmed - haven't tested).

[b] SPEND MONEY ON INGAME PURCHASE? [/b] 
Well, just copy and paste that save game to a save location. Or copy the vault where you've spend your real-life-cash and paste it in twice more, to have a total of THREE vaults with ALL the benefits of a paid vault. You've already paid, so why not harvest those benefits thrice over?

[b]Fallout Shelter[/b] is a great Vault management sim! for the first hour.  Then pacing falls off a cliff, and it becomes a generically non-interactive mobile game, that you can poke for about 5 seconds once per day.  Still, its free, and has decent features, and arts, and Fallout flavor.

+ Fallout Theme
+ Lite management sim
+ Story text for dwellers sent to the wasteland

- Very limited playtime per session
- Can't freely move rooms once built
- The map is stupidly setup so you can only build 3x3x2 rooms, instead of 3x3x3.  
- Having a controller plugged in, breaks the game, and doesn't seem to be a viable input method to begin with.
- The quest system is... a thing.  Its combat system is horrible, it isn't entertaining to watch, and has literaly no gameplay/input involved.  The timer to begin and end a quest is pay-walled.  And basic inputs while on quests are combat locked and buggy.

This is my first experience with a mobile-themed game. After sinking $65 in and having nothing to show for it, the only conclusion I can draw is that the mobile gaming market is a scheme to devalue the returns on microtransactions over time. 

This game starts you off in a small vault of digestable scale. You're having fun figuring out how to make it "just work." Stick the guy they give you in a restaurant or a power plant and before you know it you're king of the castle. Everything is coming together quickly until you realize that you have to maintain any growth by backtracking to grow and staff these resource centers. That's alright, you can sit back and click on mysterious stranger to earn the caps and upgrade your plant. Wait, you have to upgrade it again if you want to leave basics? Well that next upgrade is expensive, so you'll try out this quest. After a 3 hour timer?!

3 hours later and you're ready to enter the dungeon. Finally, this feels like a Fallout game! For a brief moment, you battle rad-creatures and raiders to earn some decent rewards. You now have enough caps and materials to get caught up. That is, after a 3-hour trek back. You dump your reward into whatever resource room allows you to expand, but now you don't have the caps to expand. This is precisely the moment when the impatience sets in and you become desperate to believe you are playing a game. You buy that big, glowing starter pack that pops up when the game predicts it has you hooked. And what a return you get on that $5.

A Mr. Handy to put out fires or collect resources. Isn't that lovely to have a passive, invincible wasteland roamer collecting caps for you? 
A pet. Who doesn't like adding some flair to their lemmings, especially when they have passive bonuses themselves?
A bunch of resources... Enough to build the first tier of your next room without having to wait and wait and wait.
A good number of quantum colas? Now I can get this show on the road!
A legendary dweller?! ALISTAIR TENPENNY?! NOW you're excited. An established, beloved Fallout character is now under your command. Oh, the adventures you'll have! From Knob Creek to Hodgenville you'll roam. 

You send your Mr. Handy into the wastes and after 3 days he has 1400 caps. Not much of a return, so you call him back and keep him on fire duty. As fires break out, he rushes to treat them and suffers damage quickly. Can't seem to heal him either. This robot has a death wish. Eventually some raiders come in and Mr. Handy decides to take them on himself. He rushes in and dies almost immediately. There is an option to revive him for 2000 caps. It costs more to revive this thing than it gathered from the wasteland! So you forget about it and move on, acknowledging that you paid for this drain on resources.

Your pet is cute, but its effect is unnoticeable. -7% crafting time or something. Well, there's nothing worth crafting unless you're ready to wait a year to get 80000 caps. 

With the fast resources you earned and the quests you blazed through with quantum, you build more stuff. The quests are broken down into as many as 15 pieces to force you to choose between buying quantum and waiting 20 hours up to 30 times before they're truly done. Those wait times are increasing, and so are the prices for rooms. The currency in this single-player game is inflating to prevent you from achieving growth without investing in Todd Howard's next sports car. 

Even if the resource game is rigged, you still have Tenpenny. Good ol' Tenpenny. Until you realize he has none of the personality that made him prejudiced, petty, but ultimately memorable. He's the same as your other dwellers; The only difference is that he has a couple of equipped items that can be unequipped and added to another character to turn THEM into Tenpenny. These empty "legendary dwellers" are the main attraction, and 20 out of 23 are from Fallout 3. The other 3 are followers from Fallout 4. Bethesda is as likely to acknowledge New Vegas as Vince McMahon would be to induct Chris Benoit into the WWE Hall of Fame. 

As a closing statement, I'd like to point out that Bethesda knows how hard they're ripping you off because there's an option to buy $99.99 worth of quantum. That's $40 more than Fallout 4 was and that was most definitely a game. This is not a game.

The PC port of the idle/exploration/simulation fusion Fallout Shelter is a near ideal version of the mobile game, incorporating all the mobile game's expansions while adding a few other improvements of its own.  It fixes two of the biggest problems of the mobile version:

1)  On mobile, you are effectively unable to control the camera.  On PC, WASD+Q/E control the camera and make it simple to get to exactly where you're going, rather than having to edge your phone's touchscreen to get it to the right point.

2)  On mobile, you quickly have nowhere to go.  On PC, in addition to the Quest system, which you unlock shortly after you've got your vault self-sufficient, you have several rooms that allow you to craft items directly, which you unlock shortly after you've got your Quests underway, and at ratios that are more forgiving than the microtransaction-heavy mobile port.

Curiously, this makes microtransactions even less attractive than usual - the same junk system that lets you craft gear also competes for storage space with your initial bequeathed weapons and armor, so microtransaction purchases could go to waste.  Acting against this, the creators added a new microtransaction currency, Quantum...  but there's more than enough free quantum from quests, daily quests, weekly quests, and randomly available from challenges, the Mysterious Stranger, and the wasteland.

There are some bugs - but largely ones that also existed on mobile (such as trying to drag characters from one room to another needing to hit an unlabelled 'drag zone' to complete).  But few are really troublesome.

In short, this is the definitive version of Fallout Shelter.  Get this if you're looking for an idle game that offers you more in-depth challenges than "buy the next upgrade" when you start it up.

After playing this game for a couple of days, I have found that the following is true.  One: after the first game, if you don't know what you are doing, you will fail the first time. Two, there are a lot of stastics, percentages, and luck with the system to get a positive outcome. Example: You can upgrade all of the rooms and connect them together; however, in doing this, you actually cut probability in half or thirds depending on the amount of people, upgrades, people levels in that catergory, and just strait out luck! Three, you have to rush rooms or find the secret agent to make money. The level ups make money, but the real money makers are the risk-taking room rushes! And the secret agents are a good find! Four, you have to make love! The levels are really based on having kids or attracting random people through the upgraded radio room. These increase your level more than missions. Also, you kids grow up within a day and give you money to build as they level up! Five, you can upgrade your people in upgrade rooms! You can train people! Six: you can gain experience with quests, as well as , gain helpful objects! 
    I guess I do not see as many problems with the game. Yes, there are  times where Radroaches kill characters, but you can paid to revive them. You can move people from other rooms to combat them and other foes. Also, you can always leave your men/women unequiped with a  weapon and pawn  weapons oftens as needed in different rooms! In other words, there are loop holes you can exploit in the game. 
    My only objections in this game are the raiders who have the abilty to break into a "nuclear volt" with swords! Yes, swords! Other than that, this is a fun addictive game if you do not have as much spare time on your hands.  Just enjoy it as a relaxed gaming experience!

[h1]‚ÄùIt‚Äôs not a good Fallout game and it‚Äôs not a good mobile game either."[/h1]

[b]My TL;DR recommendation is DON‚ÄôT BOTHER:[/b]
[list]
[*]Too much micromanaging to enjoy Vault life
[*]Menus needed a lot more polish before porting to PC
[*]Loading screens are long
[*]Good god, having people attack your Vault is ANNOYING
[/list]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Category[/th]
        [th]Score[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Plot[/b][/td]
        [td][b]2/10[/b][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Gameplay[/b][/td]
        [td][b]4/10[/b][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Graphics[/b][/td]
        [td][b]7/10[/b][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Soundtrack[/b][/td]
        [td][b]0/10[/b][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Replayability[/b][/td]
        [td][b]0/10[/b][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Overall[/b][/td]
        [td][b]2/10[/b][/td]
    [/tr]

[/table]

[h1]Plot [2/10][/h1]
If you come into this game expecting gameplay choices like you do in Fallout, prepare to be disappointed. Keeping in mind that this was originally a mobile game (a medium that traditionally lacks the ability to dive into lore), there‚Äôs very little to learn about the world of Fallout. Interactions with outside characters are thrown in amongst hours of tedium and impacts on the world are longlasting. This game will leave you wondering, ‚Äúwhy the hell do I care about this Vault again?‚Äù Also there‚Äôs no end-goal, so you‚Äôre just grinding for the sake of grinding.

[h1]Gameplay [4/10][/h1]
Starting from a mobile game and porting to PC, there was so much opportunity to improve on the basic formula. Many of the menus are *very* clunky and leave you clicking in and out. My biggest grievance ‚Äî the bigger your vault gets, the more you have to scroll out to manage your dwellers at the macro level. Unfortunately, the hitbox or clickable area for almost all clickable objects in the game might not line up with the sprite. If you‚Äôre anything like me, you‚Äôll end up having a lot of wasted clicks that pile up as minor annoyances into a gargantuan garbage heap. A big improvement would have been menus or buttons for auto-assigning dwellers. Actually, no, my BIGGEST grievance is when your vault gets attacked: you can only assign 2 dwellers to guard the door, and the invaders will run right past them! The rest of your dwellers just walk along or twiddle their thumbs while the vault is being torn to shit! And you can‚Äôt get dwellers, even the ones assigned to the entrance, to follow the invaders around! (Also, during the duration of that event, you cannot let in new dwellers or get your old ones back from the wasteland. Very irritating.)

[h1]Graphics [7/10][/h1]
It did start as a mobile game, and in keeping with the medium, the style is cartoon-like and keeps with the quintessential spirit of Fallout with all of its anachronisms and art influences. It can be difficult to differentiate dwellers unless you assign standard outfits (which will take a long time to collect) to specific rooms. Ex., all of the dwellers working in the hospital wearing labcoats, dwellers working out wearing fatigues, etc. As a result of many-generational breeding in my vault, almost everyone has dark skin and dark hair. They are *very* difficult to tell apart and due to the menu system sucking, it leads to a lot of confusion. The graphics aren‚Äôt great, but I suppose they could be worse.

[h1]Soundtrack [0/10][/h1]
I don‚Äôt actually remember music playing during the game except small cues when I accomplished something. Could be a bug, I suppose. The jazzy, classic soundtrack of Fallout 3 and 4? Forget it; you‚Äôre not getting any of that here. Also, points off for having blaring alarms while your vault is being attacked. It‚Äôs annoying after the first two minutes, and you will be hearing it a lot over the course of the game.

[h1]Replayability [0/10][/h1]
I haven‚Äôt completed this game. While I do have all of the rooms unlocked and built, I find the progression to be very empty. It‚Äôs not rewarding and a lot of mechanics that should have been addictive fall flat because of the aforementioned awful menu system. There‚Äôs a lot of micromanaging involved and with 100+ dwellers, it just becomes a massive pain in the ass.

[h1]Overall [2/10][/h1]
I enjoyed this game for the first hour that I played it, and kept playing out of a love for Bethesda. This isn‚Äôt a good Fallout game and it isn‚Äôt a good mobile game either. Also, though my computer is a bit outdated (I have a GTX 260 in my box), I figured a mobile game should run very quickly. Not true; there are still decently long loading screens when exploring the wasteland and making changes to the vault. I would expect a game with such simplistic graphics, programming, and mechanics to run much faster, even on old machine. 

[h1]Game-Specific Comments[/h1]
In the short-term, you might enjoy this game, but in the long-term, you will probably experience frustrations with the menus, hitboxes/clickable areas, and loading times. If you want to support Bethesda, put money into one of their games that has more than an hour of play in it.

Hope you enjoyed my review of Fallout Shelter! If you liked it, please upvote. :)

I love this type of game, and I love Fallout, but this game is absolute garbage. It was obviously created entirely to bilk money from whales, and the gameplay is awful. I really wish it didn't have the Fallout name. Bethesda is really killing the Fallout brand.

There's nothing fun about it. It's literally just a game of maintenance. There are no fun exploration aspects. When you send people out to explore, it's just text about what they're doing, and all you can do is recall them or tell them to continue exploring. There is a "Rush" mechanic to make your workers produce faster that sometimes fails and causes fires or nonsensical radroach invasions. There are loot boxes and every other manner of pay-2-win-style mechanics. I can't actually think of a single fun aspect of the game. I think it was literally designed just to psychologically manipulate people in to paying for their microtransactions. I wouldn't even call this a game.

It's a disgrace that damages the Fallout brand. Gross.
