I would like to begin with the style of this game: [u]management.[/u]

Long story short, this game is boring.
At first when you start off with the beginning of the game, where upgrading rooms and building new rooms made you feel like you are accomplishing something. However, the more rooms you add, it's just a boring clicking simulator.

I am a fallout fan, and I love management games, (such as city skylines and Basement) although, this game is a boring clicking and gathering game. You can send your people on quests and that's pretty much it, but all you do is just click and gather. With most management games, there are challenges, such as using your BRAIN to solve issues rather than spamming the rush button, logging off, and checking your base next weekend.

A person in the comments pointed out that this game is meant to be played in increments. That might be the best way to play this game because unlike him, I played this game 7 hours straight and I got really bored fast. Let's pretend that this isn't a Fallout titled game, and it's just a clicker game where you rush materials, wait a long period of time, and then eventually send people on quests (wait a long time for them to start and a long time to return). It wouldn't be as good of a game, wouldn't it? 

In conclusion, if you're into clicking simple management games, I would recommend you play this one occasionally. But I cannot recommend this game to people who want to play more "complex" management games, because simply, you will get very bored :/

note: the 24th May 2017 update seems to completely fuck up the mouse pointer and keyboard drivers of my Lenovo Win10 laptop after exitting the game, only the touchscreen works fine. The machine needs to be restarted to work normally again. The initial release before had no such - if any - issues on my machine.


PROS:

+++ The visual representation is bloody awesome. You command a herd of Pip Boys in Pip Boy wasteland as their overseer. How cool is that, for a die-hard Fallout fan?

+++ The audio is amazing, both FX and music bits.

+++ The Overseer missions are fun. These exploration minigames were the most enjoyable to me. Well, apart from waiting for my squad 5 hours real-time to reach the area of an interesting mission and additional 3 hours to return.

+++ Because of the game concept (later) it has a different game pace from your average Joe Fallout. You give the commands quickly and check back many hours later for the results when you have a couple of minutes again. It works well for players who are busy with their lives I guess.

+++ The overall game design / concept is so great that it is fun to play despite it's a freemium waiting simulator in the core.


CONS:

--- The game has a freemium business model: the base game is free but you have to pay for having a faster game pace and some fine goodies. Fact is, I'd absolutely buy a full game of this for a fixed price, and I greatly dislike that it's freemium that aims kids who spend the money of their parents using their iPhones. NO WAY.

--- It is a waiting simulator in the core like C&C Tiberium Alliances. I can understand that this game style fits many players. Well, despite that I'm a fan of turn-based strategies that tend to have a slower pace, I am not THAT patient. I had to take RadAways to remain patient while playing this one.

--- Combat system management is quite awkward. I'd prefer having them turn-based, with fewer rolls and bigger hits. C'mon Bethesda guys there is an AWESOME set of combat rule models in Fallout: Tactics, if we are already in the same franchise...

In a nutshell, it is a great, seriously addictive and forgivably annoying game. I dearly hope that one day a fix price version will come out. I'm a fan of the series and this is a good game concept, I'd definitely buy a complete version.

EDIT: I was sort of wrong about the game mechanics. After th initial idle periods it revs up and there is always something to do as the game progresses. This is a good game in my book.

FINAL SCORE: 4/10

The perfect minigame for killing some time, if you manage not to get lost and suddenly have hours of gameplay.

Fallout Shelter was originaly released as app for Android and iOS a few month before the Fallout 4 launch. Since then a lot of extras have been added.

If you like Fallout, then no question, this is for you. 
If you don't like Fallout might as well try it!

TL;DR: Maybe it is because it got updated for Steam or maybe it is because so much time passed and so much was added to the core game since its launch... Either way, for a true Fallout fan like me, this game is fleshed enough to be a good stand alone game. And if you are worried about the microtransactions, which are still possible in the PC version, know that there is no incentive whatsoever to buy anything. This is NOT a pay to win game.

Long version:

I remember when this game came out. It was some kind of promotional stunt alongside the developer wanting to jump on the microtransaction wandbagon... But the game itself always interested me since I'm a Fallout fan. Never played it since it wasn't available for PC and I was quite salty about it... Until now!

In a nutshell, this is a Facebook game about building a Fallout shelter in the Fallout universe. However, unlike the very vast majority of Facebook games nowaday, this one is actually quite decent and well made. It shows that a lot of thought have been put in this project and that it has not been put together in a few days only to cash in on microtransactions.

The mechanics of the game are quite polished and the game itself shows the mark of gem games: very easy to play with and start on but hard to master. There is quite a few unexplained quirks going on in this game that you slowly catch on as you get more experienced and if you are the kind of person who want to know right away without waiting then you can simply go on the game wiki which, while kind of bland, is quite complete. Another nice touch is that the game timers continue to tick down when you are not actively playing the game either because you get bored or more likely because real life get in the way, which mean that once you have established your vault you can decide to simply leave and come back later while still progressing on your goals.

The strongest downside of the game is that its interface leave a lot to be desired. This is unfortunately completely expected since this is a direct port from a version aiming for mobile users. There is no way around the fact that the game is built with touchscreen in mind and thus the controls completely suck to the point of being frustrating for a keyboard and mouse user. On the upside, you could play one vault on your PC in the comfort of your home and play the same game on your phone with another vault. Many guides also offer insight on how to copy one specific vault from one medium to another so technically it would also be possible to play a single vault if you are willing to cope with the extra work. This drawback can thus be either a curse or a nice addition to your playing experience depending of the direction you wish to take.

The nice thing about this game is that it is completely free. You just click install on the Steam store page and start playing. There is a tutorial for new players which gift you all what you need to start with alongside a decent amount of Nuka Cola, the "higher end" currency of the game. If you are intelligent about your spendings you can stretch that starting amount a long way and I have found that there is plenty to be found in the wasteland if you are patient enough for your explorers to find the stuff, which add to the "microtransaction available but you don't absolutely have to without being screwed" feeling. Meaning that yeah, if you go and buy a bunch of stuff you'll get going very fast and be "successful" very fast... But then again it is completely possible to play the game without it. And to be frank... The whole idea of the game is to be the overseer in charge of a vault. Waiting is part of the experience. If you're not willing to wait a tad then you probably already know this game is not for you and I'm left wondering why you are even reading this.

Good luck in the wasteland, overseer!

[h1]Fallout Shelter[/h1] has arrived for PC, as a [u]mobile port[/u]. It‚Äôs still a Bethesda game and it‚Äôs still Fallout, but can a mobile fallout game work on steam??

First of all the game is free to play, so yes you guessed it, it has micro-transactions in it, but I will write about that a little later.
The grafix in the game is very true to Fallout and that pleased me when I saw that, it‚Äôs very well made and you actually get the feeling that you are playing a Fallout game.

Now the game starts of as you been a manager of a Fallout shelter and you give it a name. Then you are taken through a tutorial of some of the basics and then you are set and go for the rest. The problem is though you still don‚Äôt know half of what you can do in the game, or what the game later will introduce you to. There is a help section, and I can only recommend you reading it, because it gives you valuable information on how to management your dwellers into the right places, so you get faster resources.  And this is where the problems really start in my opinion, and where it shows that it is a mobile port. The waiting time you have to wait for resources are pretty long when you really can‚Äôt do much else. 2-4 minutes to be allowed to press a button to get resources is a long time. The first 30 mins you are pretty occupied with the game because everything is new, but then it starts getting boring. There are small events that happens like animal infestations or attack on your vault but that‚Äôs pretty much it. I am missing a more eventful game, maybe earthquakes or something else than a fire that can happen because you tried to be greedy with rushing resources. 

The game has different items, armor, guns and pets in it, that makes it more interesting, and it is cool having your dwellers running around looking different. A way to increase your population is to make love and produce baby‚Äôs and that is a funny feature, again though it takes soooo long time to actually produce a new dweller and have it grow up to be able to work in your rooms. Now if you get passed the waiting time, and play it as a normal pc game, you will eventually get enough dwellers to unlock the Observere room, where the more interesting part of the game opens up. Being able to send your dwellers on quests is a nice feature, but yet again the time it takes to do something is brutally long. Ranging from 30 min to 5-6 houres for your dwellers to get to a location is something you just wont sit and wait for. This is yet again a place where the mobile part of the game shows, because you are more inclined to close down and look at it again later when you are on your mobile phone, than on a pc. You don‚Äôt want to open up a game, to play for 10 minutes to close it down again waiting for new things to do. When you actually get to play a quest, you get a new mini game where you have to kill something or answer questions about fallout. I like this part in the game, I just don‚Äôt like having to wait 1 hour plus to be able to do it.
Off course IF you use Nuca cola which is the real money currency in the game, you can get there instant, and now my rant starts. The starter pack is 4.99 Euro, which is fine, you seem to be getting a decent amount of things, but then the price goes up. 4-5 Euros for 6 Nuca-Cola when it cost maybe 8 to go instant is WAY overpriced. I am inclined to say that if you do not pay money for the game, you can‚Äôt play it as a PC game, and has to play it as a mobile wait game, and that is where I get annoyed.
 
If you port something to a specific console, you should really make sure that the game is still fun for none paying players, or ask a decent price for it and lower the time for things to finish. 
Even minimising the game to try will eventually pause the game (having it to reload when you return), and if you haven‚Äôt bought the starter pack you don‚Äôt have the handy auto loot machine running around picking up loot for you. Yet again you are losing out when you don‚Äôt pay. 

The sound in the game is standard for a mobile game, it‚Äôs not great but it‚Äôs all right, it works for Fallout Shelter. 


[h1]Should you play it?[/h1]
 
Well that depends, if you want a game where you are occupied all the time, and having to wait for things to finish is a bother for you, without paying for it, then this game might not be for you. If however you don‚Äôt mind having a game you open up from time to time, and play for 10 minutes maybe 30 if you do a quest, then this can could be just what you needed in your life. :)

At first this seems like a good way to waste time, possibly while watching tv or something. You go through the initial moves of placing dedicated production areas and putting people to work at them and it seems like something is happening.

You do the objectives (collect 50 food resource for example) and get boxes of "cards" which flip and reward you with random stuff. Sometimes you get items for your people like costumes and/or weapons but most of the time you get a pinch of resource (water, power, food) or money used to buy more space for your vault making it bigger.

much of the time you get "junk" which is sold for chump change.

In the end you find yourself playing what devolves into a "waiting simulator". You have to collect a certain number of resources to get a minor reward which then opens up another task to do the same damn thing, but with a lot of waiting in between.

you can send people out of the vault but their "adventures" merely consist of single descriptive sentences and random minor rewards over an extended period of time, nothing more.

i restarted the game many times and found that the random drops of cards are not very helpful. obtaining weapons/costumes seems to be second only to getting a new character with comparatively enhanced statistics. most you get game currency (caps) or a smidgen of resource (water/power/food).

in the end i feel like the developers of this app purposely made the "dead time" way to long in an attempt to pull in more in game real money transactions. those transactions should be avoided as they are one time only and gone once applied. i have tried to save the game before flipping reward cards to no avail, the rewards remained once the card was consumed.
finally, the game is an obvious port of a very generic sim title (sim tower i believe) with downgrades to gameplay in exchange for the fallout guy theme.

i suggest trying it, i enjoyed it for a few hours. maybe i missed something? what could it hurt? its free, it didnt take long to download, and no one is obligated to keep it.

It was designed for mobile, so you'd expect the waiting times for missions or training like in other mobile games (Clash of Clans, Game of War, so on so forth), which of course you can pay with in-game currency to surpass. I'm not planning on ever needing to buy the microtransactions, because everything you can get from buying those you can get from just playing the game. 

A time waster, like many have said, and it's very good at being a time waster. Polished, addicting, and funny in odd forms (I don't know about you, but Vault Boy randomly appearing at the corner of the screen holding a smiling baby that looks just like him makes me laugh every time).

It's okay for a free-to-play game, a couple of hours of activity for the price of 0‚Ç¨ is not bad. There's obviously no depth to talk about, the quests are not interesting, and the "gameplay-elements" are clunky at best, but it's a charming little game with lot's of references to Fallout and other game-series.

I've been playing Fallout Shelter since its very first release on Apple Store and I must say it's entertaining! Although, on the PC it's another story. Don't get me wrong, this game is fun but only if you got time to waste. This is literally a waiting game. As a beginner, you will eventually wait for a room to be done producing whatever you need in the next 5 to 20 minutes depending on your Dwellers' statistics. You can always rush a room to produce anything much faster but there's always a risk. Same goes for quests. Once you unlock the Overseer's desk, going on a trip can take times. I imported my save data from my iPhone to my PC using iExplorer application so I already have tons of Nuka Cola, maximum amount of money and a Vault full of level 50 and maxed out statistics everywhere and loaded with Dragon's Maws, Plasma Rifles, Fatman and so on so doing quests wasn't challenging. The problem seems to be the trip though. It must depends on the level and the difficulty of the quest, but a trip can take up to 5 hours before your Dwellers arrive to their destination where you can finally begin your quest unless you use some Nuka Cola to skip the trip. The whole game is basically based on waiting or skipping tasks using Nuka Cola so it can be very boring as a start. Once your Vault is pretty much full of rooms and Dwellers, you definitly won't have to worry about waiting because that won't be the case. There's always going to be a room somewhere, ready for you to collect resources or caps. I don't know if that's the same thing on PC but on mobile, if I was not playing the game for a few hours and I came back to it later, my Vault was always lacking of something. either power or food or water. That was until I aquire a few robots to collect resources automatically. They manage the Vault while I'm not around but without a robot I remember how difficult it could be if I wasn't playing the game for a long time. The difficulty of the game will vary on the amount of Dwellers inside your Vault. If I remember correctly, once your Vault has 25 Dwellers, Molerats will start attacking your Vault from time to time. Otherwise you only have to deal with Raiders. Then I believe with 60 Dwellers, Deathclaws will start attacking the Vault, as for the annoying Radscorpions, I don't really know since I stopped playing after they released an update for them so I couldn't really analyze their arrival since my Vault already had 200 Dwellers. Rare/Legendary loots used to be easy. All I had to do was bring 20 Dwellers outside the Vault and after a few hours, they came back with rare scraps to craft rare weapons and armors/clothings. Now it seems to be just from quests because I don't remember collecting any rare loots from them in a long time.Quests aren't that easy. You always need a lot of Stimpacks and Radaway to deal with whatever is out there. So I got to say it's not the best way to make caps. Just send your Dwellers out in the wasteland and ignore whatever location they can find, let them travel around for more loots. Money is pretty easy, as long as you send a high level Dweller long enough in the wasteland and give them a good weapon with an outfit that gives enough Luck, your Dweller will definitly return with enough stuff for you to sell and make money. But of course you have to make a sacrifice at first. If a Dweller is low level, they will probably die outside. If they do, revive them. It cost caps but at least they're going to get stronger and stronger, and whatever they find out there should eventually bring back the money you lost. My advice is to raise your Dwellers as high as possible from the very beginning. It doesn't help at all with how many Dwellers are in the Vault, it's quite the opposite. More Dwellers always means more risk of getting your entire Vault wiped out by Molerats, Radscorpions or Deathclaws. If your Dwellers are not strong enough, it's pointless. Even if someone is carrying a Fatman or a Dragon's Maw. If your entire Vault is wiped out, it's going to be expensive to revive your Dwellers. If a Dweller dies and you don't have enough caps to revive the fallen one, just click or tap anywhere outside the window and wait until you got enough money. Although whoever is inside that room with a dead body will bring down their happiness and effectiveness. Quotes between Dwellers are pretty entertaining to read. The higher their Intelligence and Charisma, the "smarter" their quotes will be. Like two Dwellers flirting with each others. If two Dwellers are totally dumb, they're gonna throw some really weird stuff. lol Stats do affect a few things. Perception for instance will increase the productivity inside the water purification room. Even if the Perception is up to 10 on a Dweller, you can use an equipment to give +5 or +7 Perception and it will actually improve the productivity even more, reducing the production time as well. Same with Luck, the higher the Luck, the greater the chance to rush a room without causing any incident. The higher, the better. It might even give you a 0% failure if everyone has enough Luck and other stat for the particular room. Well, that's pretty much it. The game is fun but only if you're playing on a phone or tablet and you got nothing to do at all. Unless you're the type of person who sit at their computer without knowing what to do with their day, then that's a great way to spend the time.

simple vault creation simulator

I was excited about this game on steam. Free to play and all, awesome. I had played this back when if was first released on my phone, and I enjoyed it. It had a short life back then, but it was good.

That being said, I still enjoy it, but with one small issue that has ruined it for me. Radscorpions. They are so op that it makes the game not as fun, and more frustrating. I end up rushing a room, and getting one of those little b*****ds. They drain my energy below sustainability, which renders my recourse rooms un-capable of producing anything. They have very hard to kill, they move randomly. I usually end up with 4-5 dead dwellers. After the attack I am usually out of Stimpaks. So I have to rush rooms just to gain back enough energy to keep my dwellers alive, and I get another d**m Radscorpion. 

Maybe introduce them later into the game, when at least all my dwellers have weapons? But as of right now, I won't be playing for awhile. I am annoyed and frustrated. 

Otherwise, I do like the updates, the missions are cool. The new rooms are fun. Being able to build weapons and outfits gives the game depth. If they made radscorpians less powerful and random, I will come back, until then adi√≥s.

I cant believe this is a free game. I would have paid a couple bucks for this. It's very addicting. It's a very basic survival simulation ala this war of mine or even a Banished. Even though its basic and not that challanging, you still have a bevy of options. The random events makes things interesting even if it is the same for the first few hours of the game. I put in about three or four hours so far and its suprisingly strategic even if it is on a basic platitude. You need to manage your dwellers jobs, switch them out when new ones arrive, micro manage their performances, move them for rush failures, suprise attacks, know when to put a dweller in one area or another, when to send one out to explore, when to change equipment, what to craft and how much, where to place the rooms in your vault, what objectives to complete, what quests and so on and so on. The rewards for the objectives are very good. Getting those lunch boxes are exciting.

And ofcourse this is all Fallout themed with the pip-boy motif. Plenty of Fallout lore is put into this game and if you are an avid fan like me, it will get addicting quick. It runs on real time as well...which may be a hit or miss with people. It's a free game. Its great.

the game itself is a mobile port and a time sink management game. however, unlike the mobile game (or at least back when I played the mobile version) there's an expansion on gameplay. You can now acctually quest into the wastelands (taking you to other vaults and locations), craft weapons and clothes and collect companion pets among a few other features. 

However it's still a free to play game that wants you to invest money to speed the process up. Money which is for items and once they are used on a single save they are gone for ever. 

Personally I'd preffer it if the game was say ¬£10 and most of the timers where removed (so it was just a resource and people manangement game) OR that the iems purchased transfered across saves. Since neither of those are the case I personally feel no urge to buy anything or recommened you buy anything for this game (but of course, how you choose to spend your cash is up to you).

Fun game if you like Fallout and want something to drop in and out of between other gaming session OR you like management games. Not so fun if you get caught up wasing money on micro transactions as no amount of purchases will ever be enough.

If you aren't in the know, the game its self...it is what it is. It's like Sim City: Fallout Edition. You micromanage a vault. This is a 1:1 copy of the mechanics from the other versions of the game. It's interesting enough but it very quickly loses it's luster once any challenge vanishes from the game later on when resources are no longer a limiting factor. To me, anyways. Your mileage may vary.

That aside, I'm not really sure what Bethesda is playing at with this. The obvious answer is for more money from microtran$action$ but anybody who wanted to play this game has already played it. Also as of now this is just a very poor port of a mobile app to Steam. Just play the mobile app or the iPad version if you haven't played the game already and want to.

Yeah so. Fallout shelter.

When it came out on mobiles I played it... I played it so frigging much. Addicting as hell to have the most perfect vault ever. Although my Samsung Galaxy S5 handled the game well, once you had a big vault and all that the game got laggy and also strained your phone. I uninstalled it right away once I heard about the PC version. No more phones heating like a cooking pot, no more laggy playing with big vaults.

I always knew somehow this game ended up on Steam and I waited for the Steam version until I started playing again. So what it is? The most fun and simple building simulator and the best part is the Fallout theme. It has a lot of content but you will grind like hell, micromanage and wait. I mostly do some stuff on my PC like editing photos and such, this game runs on the background and keeps going automatically until something needs to be done (Mr. Handy <3)

Best part of the new features are the wasteland quests and exploring some buildings in wasteland. It's fun for first 3-5 weeks but you can get bored. 

Overall this game is propably one of the best mobile games ever created. You can do just fine without paying for the starter packages and all that but who cares, I threw 5 euros for the starter package. Not a big deal. A must play for any Fallout fan.

Seriously, the MMOs, the mobile gaming and the console gaming has destroyed the gaming industry.
We get crap like that instead of getting a real Fallout game, when was the last time we had a real Fallout game? Last time I checked it was in 2010.
Fallout 4? Please, that's not Fallout.
If they were competent enough, they wouldn't care about the mainstream, we could get a Fallout similar to the first one or second.
But nope, too complicated, let's make something that even a 8 years old kid could make and let's make it a game for everyone, even if they are not real gamers but just posers and fakers who only played games such as Call of Duty, Candy Crush, and all those other crappy Facebook/mobile crap that should not even exist in the first place.

I'm seriously tired of this crap, and the worse is that people seems to encourage that kind of crap.

A message to the developers and publishers; if you really want to make such low quality crap, then keep it for the consoles and the mobile gaming, I'll talk for the real PC gamers community;  we want real games, we want a true Fallout experience. Not the kind of crap that required you to be always online to play (no offline play), that has microtransactions and that looks exactly the same as those crappy games made by incompetents you can find on Facebook.

Honestly, I don't know where this is going, but crap, as a gamer, it hurts.

And to those who's gonna come and say "you can be a real gamer even if you have only played Call of Duty or Candy Crush".
Well, I have nothing to say to you.
Call of Duty may be is a crappy game but oh well, at least it's a game, those Facebook and mobile "games", what are they? You could spend more than 600$ and you'd be kind of done with the game, and if you don't pay, either it will be really slow to progress and you won't be able to get/access to everything or you just won't be able to advance at all.
Don't get me wrong, I love some grind, in games that are fun to play and that you don't have to pay with real money to speed up the process or whatever.
And as long as it is fair, I don't want to spend my life finishing one game.
We, adults have obligations and other stuff.
And even if I could be a kid for the rest of my life, I wouldn't want to waste my time on just one game, especially not a crappy one such as this one.

Ahh the Fanboys of Fallout will be happy with their Fallout Shelter mobile app now on PC! Now they can play it on their phone and PC.This is a build micromanage game of vaults, by Fallouts Vault-Tec. With the world being a giant wasteland, house and keep dwellers happy and well fed in your vault complex that you built and protect. Build special rooms of energy, water supply and food supply for those must have needs. Then you have dozens of other rooms for weapons and stim pacs and such. Build the perfect complex for your dwellers so they stay happy and work to keep the vault alive. You also can equip the dwellers with weapons, armor and pets to help protect or perform better in their workrooms. Also questing and sending well equipped leveled dwellers out into the wastelands to quest and explore to gain loot is another micromanagement thing to do. Lots to keep track of here, Food, water, oh and your dwellers you can have breed. FUN?! It has lots of humor and all ties taken from the Fallout games. It's not missing anything and all cartooned and based on the famous Pip boy. Its rather charming. Difficult? Well, with raiders, rad roaches and fires attacking you vault complex, it can be. So manage well!

I don't know what to say. Again, would deserve a neutral vote. Why? Because the game itself is not bad. It works has intended and it can be fun. But it was originaly a mobile game and it should've stick a mobile game. It's not the kind of game that worth to be played on PC. It's more the kind of game I'll grab my phone once in a while to play it. So it's not a bad game but it was a good mobile game. I'm less excited by its PC version. Still I wanted to try it to see if there would have anything different from mobile game and nop. It's the exact same thing. 

Why it doesnt make sense on PC? Sometime, you send your dwellers to the wastelands for hours and then you would need to get on computer just to recall them? Isn't a phone more convenient when you just want to spend 5 miuntes on the game to recall a dweller and gather ressources? So having it on PC can be "ok" if only it was possible to sync the PC version with the mobile version in a shared cloud so you can access the same save file from both computer and mobile but you can't. PC save file is a thing and mobile save is another thing. You must work hard to transfer file from platform to anohter.. why? A shared cloud could have make the PC version viable. You play on mobile and from time to time on PC. But a full time PC version is plain dumb in my opinion.

So overall, it's free, try it, enjoy it but you'll quickly notice that the mobile version does a better job since you'll most likely spend 5 minutes on the game once in a while. But turning computer on just for this.. nop... and if you don't, your dwellers will die in the wasteland... so nop... i'll have to give it a bad review for that reason.. again, the main reason they ported it on PC is probably more aimed at selling lunch boxes to make few bucks more than anything else. Because overall, it's not a smart move. :s

And nothing... I'm angry as f*uck because i lost a lot of things in the meantime and ruined my gameplay. so THANKS BETHESDA

This is the game I was looking for, for all of your picky gamers(like me) I recommend this game.

I remember Bethesda's announcement for Fallout Shelter, it was originally meant for mobile, and it worked perfectly.

On PC? I'm definitely enjoying it, but there are some cons, as well as pros

Pro's:

- Off the bat, it's fun, there seems to be a lot less waiting around than when I played on mobile.
- For what it is, it's graphically pleasing, each room has it's own feel to it, and you can upgrade and merge the rooms, and they change their look. It's had the thought put in and it's aethetically pleasing.
- I never experienced quests on mobile... I feel there is more content being added, or has been added since I last played the game.
- It's fairly addictive, and there's lots to do. It's obviously not the perfect game for PC, but it does still work.

Con's:

- It feels like a mobile port, lots of the dragging, either through your menu's or vault, it's very jumpy and it feels like it would work better with a touch screen (which mobiles obviously have these days)
- Local saving is a let down, you've probably read it already, but it makes micro transactions a bit of a waste, as they're solely on that save and only that one, along with your vault.
- Feels in leagues with like 'Clicker Heroes', it's definitely more of a background game, you don't sit there and play for hours, you have it open in the background and come to it every now and then. (Maybe not a con, but not a pro either)

All in all though, I'm enjoying it, it's fun, addictive, 8/10

[h1]For the Fallout fans:[/h1]

I'm happy that Fallout Shelter is on Steam.
Made for mobile devices first, this is a game purely made for the fans of the FALLOUT Series (and not for everyone). Since I'm a big fan of the Fallout series and the wasteland, I cannot avoid to play this.

In this F2P game, you have to manage a vault built in the underground, and help your dwellers to survive, providing them water, electricity and food, and equipping them with weapons and clotches. That's it.
Lots of stuff to collect, to upgrade, and to discover, helps the game to have a little bit of more variety, but it remains a very simple, casual game, to play in relaxation sometime in the day.

About the shop items, those are not necessary. They just help you to advance quickly, but they are not required to anything you can achieve in the game.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
For who loves the Fallout series, the wasteland and the survival/casual games in general, this is a must b.. ehm,, play!?
For who simply don't like too much those, avoid this, or maybe give it a quick try. Can't be booring and not satisfying. Not funny at all.

Don't like it. It is painfully slow, at the same time it demands constant attention when running. The dwellers have no personality. It doesn't make sense you are building a vault in the lore of fallout. These were pre-war "bomb shelters", not post war construction projects. The scavenging is dumb (yao guai are "easy" enemies"). The way you make money is dumb. The constant suggestion that spending real life money will make the game easier grates on the nerves.

If you want to play, well it's basically a freemium browser game sort of thing. Just make sure you close the game after checking it and DO NOT leave it running in the background or your vault will go to crap. As a browser game it's just ok.

To me it just lacks personality and reeks of cash-grab.

Nerf the death claws already you bastards, the event frequency is insane... every 2minutes there is a disaster, if you had opened the vault door in those 2 minutes and have 30+ followers guess what, death claw attack! Oh you silly thing, you don't know that by opening the vault door you attract deathclaws because there was no such explanation in the game? No problem here is another deathclaw attack in 2 minutes to help you understant, oh and a sprinkle of raiders to wash it down with. But wait! I guess those raiders really loved animals because, you guessed it! Another deathclaw attack! Ahh... Isn't it lovely outside? Well, normally you wouldn't see deathclaws for miles when exploring the wasteland, but when it comes to the vault it's like you have a locker full of deathclaw eggs in the back of the vault and even though deathclaws trash your whole place up countless times they still can't seem to find them, it's like the synths are printing the claws out with a 3d printers and sending them your way for population control.

No but seriously, I understand that they did this so you would have to pay to play, but come on guys, that's not how you get me to pay for something, I was considering buying some pet boxes maybe a mister handy and a few lunch boxes but now? Now I remembered why I quit the phone app and honestly, bethesda, I despise you, you sell out whore! You have destroyed one of the best games out there by creating that linear, kill everything, be everything so called RPG Fallout4 (I even preordered a season pass that's how much I trusted you bastards (first game I ever preordered and the last)) and I will never forgive you for that crime, but you could at least give a damn about something and fix fallout shelter.

I would gladly pay 20euros for this game if it wasn't free and I always support games that I like (sadly there are very few of them) even though I live in a poor country and don't really have much money to spare. 

I love this game, I love how you have to earn things in it, I love all the art, quests are a great addition to the game, this game is superb and it breakes my hearth that I will give it a negative review because of some design flaw that breaks it.

Just add a restriction on deathclaws so there can only be one attack over a period of time of gameplay or that they  don't attack you after a certain perion of time after they did so you can lick your wounds. Honestly? I would like to see deathclaws wreck even more havoc, something that makes it feel like they actually are the ferocious unkillable armored beasts that they are. But I don't want to see them kill people faster or go through rooms faster or have more health, I want them to damage rooms that they pass through so that you need to repair them after, I want them to feel like a threat. What I don't want them to be is something that destroys everything I've been working for and then return after 2 minutes with new friends. I want to have consequences for not killing them all off, in terms of much faster return, for example in a day instead of 2 days, I want the radio brodcast to actually make a difference on how often they show up. Oh did I mention that I don't even have a radio studio since I DIDN'T WANT THREE DEATH CLAW ATTACKS IN A ROW!!!! But now I see that radio studio can only spawn an event of death claw attacks, but obviously doesn't actually infuence the frequency of them... Now it feels like deathclaws are like stronger raiders in the wasteland.. Which I think we fallout fans all know is not the case. 

P.s. I'm sure this review will never reach many eyes and it's even less likely that bethesda will see it but it's healthy to vent once in a while.

P.p.s. Wtf are these power armors it gives me 2 strength and 1 perception? Are you high? Some camaflaged rags give me 7 strength but a mother freakin POWER ARMOR a LEGENDARY drop gives me less than a few slightly polished battle metal plates. Also water energy food and common garbage in a box I paid nearly an euro for? Legendary trash junk is fine if I can use it in the future for some good gear but other trash is a no no. Also weapons of no less than 6 dmg. And these boxes I pay for better be in my whole playthroughs not just that particular one save that I bought them in, there can even be 2 types of items 0.5euro boxes for a single play through and 1euro box for all your playthroughs I don't care. Balance your shit out or I will never pay you a dime ever again. I will even one up that one for yah, if you don't stop treating gaming community as money bags for you to exploit and start giving a fuck I will make sure to point out all the flaws on any of the games you work on even before they come out, over eight years of fanatic experience in game design philosophy and psychology gives me that ability.

This game comes highly recommended on *mobile*! Here's a review of the PC version:

MAIN CON: This game is designed for a mobile experience, through and through. It's a game you start up, play for a little while to manage things, and then set aside to let more things happen. Meaning, if you approach it like a regular PC game, you're going to spend a lot of time just waiting for things to happen. Or buy stuff for real money to make them happen faster.

OTHER CONS:
- Controls manage to be almost just as annoying on PC as they are on mobile.
- UI is same as before, designed for mobile, which means it feel really big, clunky and unpolished.

PROS:
+ I still can't put it the feck down.

DISCLAIMER: There are some features that are new to the PC version, which I haven't unlocked yet, like quests and crafting. I'll edit this if those things change my mind about the game.

CONCLUSION: Please do play this on mobile! Although the controls can be a little frustrating, everything else about it is great, and it's super addictive. Works really well to play in short intervals, before work, on the bus, on breaks, etc.

A very casual idle game made to promote Fallout 4 before its launch.

In that regard, even though it has micro-transactions, they are completely optional. Anything and everything in the cash shop is earnable in the game. Its only purpose is to speed up game progression.

Even though it was made as a promotional gimmick, it's actually a very addictive, solid base-building game with a good assortment of unlockable underground room types that you can design and lay out any way you choose, goals, crafting, group missions, solo missions, base defense, character stat-building and level-ups, rare loot drops, character enhancements via assignable pets, and more.

All that and it's free to play to boot, with nothing locked exclusively away behind pay-walls. Definitely a thumbs up. Well-designed, totally free to play, and solid, addictive gameplay.

PC Port of a mobile game: usually I hate these types of things but Fallout Shelter is an exception. It improved upon the mobile version. The rng (Raider attacks for example) seems more balanced and now I have precision controls which were my only real gripes with the mobile version in all honesty...
Since this game is Free-To-Play, the microtransactions (as always) are present to snare the idiots who impulse buy, but you don't need them to "win" so don't buy into those and you'll be fine. If you do, just know that they do NOT carry over to your next game. Gameover = money wasted. There isn't really any "gameplay" to talk about since it's basically just about you as The Overseer of your own vault managing it's resources. Vault Dwellers being the most important resource of course, LOL. It's more or less an idle-game, Clicker Heroes being a good example of what I mean. Start it up while you listen to some music, read something, chill out and have a beer, ect...

All and all if you want a F2P resource managment game you can play to relax a bit after work/school or before bed, this is one that I'd highly recommend. Plus it's set in the Fallout universe. What's not to love?

Minister of Mobile Gaming: And so in conclusion, the successful freemium game is based on five principles: Entice the player with a simple game loop, use lots of flashing cashings and compliments to make the player feel good about themselves, train the players to spend your fake currency, offer the player a way to spend real currency for your fake currency...

Prince of Canada: So they'll forget they're spending money.

Phillip: We understand micropaying, but can't the game hidden inside the charade it - just at least be fun?

I'm actually really enjoying this and it's why I'm kinda torn with this review. I'm a huge Fallout fan, coming up to 30 and followed the games all the way from the first. I'll likely continue to play only for a short while though -

Fallout Shelter could have been so much more. I'm not sure what went wrong at Bethesda, because there's a real gem game hiding underneath the monetisation.
It's such a lovely, charming game. The artwork is brilliant, the audio is fantastic, and I like how much you can customise different aspects of your vault. I like that you send your dwellers out into the wastelands, and the logs they record while they're doing it. I played on release on ios as well, but in all honesty it didn't last very long.

The game is weighed down by microtransactions. I wholeheartedly believe that if this was treated like the single player game it is instead of parroting that crappy model that countless games on the mobile stores follow, if the wait timers were divided by 10 and all of this stupid quantum cola stuff was removed altogether, if questing was fleshed out somewhat and timers were reworked to timers in the range of 1-3 hours, long enough to put down but quick enough to ride through if you kept yourself distracted,  if you had slapped a ¬£17.99 price tag on the front of it, I'd imagine it'd have sold like hot cakes and the reviews would be immeasurably in your favour. You could have added card expansions in the form of paid DLC if you really were looking to squeeze a bit extra and it would have raised a lot less eyebrows.

If you had slapped it on the ios store like that at ¬£9.99, it would have sat at the top of different mobile site's top charts for years to come. There's very little in the way of deep strategy games on mobile without in app purchases, this probably would have made a mint done the right way with integrity, instead of taking this trashy route that only serves to annoy people into paying money. A Fallout themed strategy game with  no iap that cross synced between my PC and my iPhone? It'd feel like Christmas.

I'd like to imagine that many of the designers were not on board with any of the monetisation stuff and I'd like to believe there's probably a few guys out there that wanted to do something entirely different but had to keep the bosses happy. I feel like this is a good example of what happens when the quest for money interferes too much with a player's experience. You pick these designers up because they are talented people who are passionate about their work and art, let them do their jobs properly!

Bethesda in my eyes is respectable when I compare them to other companys in the industry. Get off this road, it leads to ruin. And from a fan's perspective, Fallout deserves better than a honey trap. Shame on you, Bethesda. >:(


The jist of my review is that the content is fantastic, I can't fault it. The problem is the way it's served is questionable and why I have not recommended it. Fallout is a flagship title and holds weight in regards to normalising IAPs in the PC gaming marketplace, and said games are more often than not shady, anyone who is familiar with mobile gaming will understand what I mean. Their design makes it easy to irresponsibly mine money from people in an irresponsible way, and I fear that this title will help make it easier for this price model to become commonplace.


Cont-
So why would you use the microtransaction model? As others have touched on in the comments, part of the reason is that it makes more money, particularly by badgering players into spending small amounts a lot of times to make it harder to recognise the value of things. It's a deceptive price model and the majority of the reason I didn't recommend the game is because I see a brilliant game underneath a model that is unhealthy for the industry.

There's a perfectly reasonable arguement that places the responsibility entirely in the hands of the person spending, and I believe the majority of people who thumbs up or downed me are probably divided specifically on how they view that. Is it the responsibility of the designer or the player? I'd argue it was both and I'm not one to complain incessently about games, but this kind of price model is notorious for going after what you call "whales", and I just think it's in bad taste. 

It's not where I want to see PC gaming go, and in my opinion it's dishonest game design and irresponsible because the majority of income from this game will come from players on both extremes, the ones with oil baron parents and addictive personalities or "low hanging fruit". I work in mental health and these kinds of games can end up pretty much robbing vulnerable people, where the model is most effective. You could quite literally lop the microtransactions off this beautiful game, readjust the timers to compensate, and have an honest title at a set price.

I get why people don't like it for the most part.  It really is a mobile game because of the waiting and it isn't a click-fest so people aren't enjoying it because instead of watching resources build infinitely while they click like monkeys having seizures located primarily in their fingers, it's a slower-paced game where resources build over time. 

I see people whining about having their money "stolen", although that would mean the game is taking money from them without their permission which is just a lie.  You don't get anything stolen, you choose to pay for items in a F2P game on Steam.  I'm not sure why these people are lashing out at someone else for something they clearly chose to do, but in either case it's just a lie.  I don't care if purchases don't carry over to a new vault (how many do you need, did you screw up that badly, that many times?) especially for a game that doesn't need *any* item to actually be bought in the first place.  You wanna toss a tip to the devs and buy a box or pet or bot?  Ok, it's your money to toss.  But don't buy something then turn around and scream they stole your money.  It's pathetic.

Graphics are fine, it's a pretty fun game to play while drinking a cup of coffee and reading something or watching a video on the side.  "Sing" & "Fantastic Beasts" just came out, I'd suggest either of those I think they were very good.

Good game, good resource management means you need to do some actual thinking, or you could buy something to make it a little easier.  Or you could do the daily quest things and get caps & boxes for free like most people.

(This is a complete redo of this review)
I have played this much much much longer on my xbox one soooo I"ll be talking (more like typeing and you people reading) from the experiences I've had from that version.

There are multiple issuses with this game. Which I will be talking (i need to say typeing about) about in seperet sections since I have alot of hours on the xbox one version.

Issue number 1.) Your starting people are so weak and pathetic that you will have a hard time keeping your needs up at the beginning. I HAD TO pay for lunchboxes (loot boxes) in order to keep my needs up or i would have lost. You have to reach a certain point in the game to lvl your people up in the required S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats for each different rooms. For example you will be given people with HORRENDOUS stats for the begining rooms (which are the life blood of your vault) Power, Water filtraion, and Dinner. Which need Strength, Perception, and Agility. Even if you have more people in the room (you can build more of the same room next to each other to merge into a bigger room) the time to make the resource increasses with the size of the room.

Issue number 2.) Like i stated in issue number 1, you must pay for lunch boxes in even an attempt to keep your vault up in early game. Since you need 6 rooms at the begining of the game. Bedrooms, Water purifire, Power generation, Dinner, Med bay (stimpacks), Science lab (Rad away). Each needing power, so in your mind you make a bigger power room to have more power income. Tho in the same time you need more food and water production for all the new power workers. Which needs even more power so you go into a spiral which drains your power. (but when you can train a specific S.P.E.C.I.A.L stat this dosent become a problem)

Issue number 3.) The production of recourses are WAY TO SLOW in the early game, but in the later game once you have trained people in the "right room" (games words not mine) this dosent become a problem. However, the training time takes little time in the early game but becomes way to long in the later game when you have people high lvl in the S.P.E.C.I.A.L stat that you need. 

Issue number 4.) If you have weak people exploring the wastland you WILL have to babysit the person. You will have to know what the stats do in this game to even be good. Fully lvled Dwellers will have a VERY clear advanteg than you begining Dwellers. (Endurance will increase the HP of the Dweller EVERY LVL UP so you will need to train this at lvl 1 to be usefull.).

Issue number 5.) The clothes have a very different point in this game than the other fallouts. In here the clothes just increase your Dwellers S.P.E.C.I.A.L stats, but not increase you Dwellers defence and damage resistance. Unlike in other fallout games the either do increase your stats, Damage resistance, or will do both. So at lvl 10 stats on you Dwellers they become just cosmetics.

Issue number 6.) The dwellers cant reproduce with family members. (know your asking why is this an issuse) This is an issuse do to there being no way to keep track with the family trees when you have 100+ dwellers in your vault. (unless you write down every name and who reproduced with who, and who had whos baby. Which you probly wont do.)

Fallout Shelter is a spin-off 'Fallout' game that delves into the 'mobile gaming' genre. Usually these mobile games communicate whether you should be playing a lot online or leaving it to run offline, and this one can't really decide.

For a Steam port, I expected a graphical upgrade since you can really see these textures up-close, and they are pretty reminiscent of N64 games. The UI overall is actually pretty poor, I find myself struggling to put people in the right places and to pick up things on quests because the spaces are so tight and crowded. There isn't a lot of organization either, there should be some sort of family tree categorization as well as organization by chronological appearance. To use every single 'dweller' to the perfect advantage would actually require studying because of the annoying options here. There should be an option to see every weapon and outfit even if it is held by the characters.

Quests are actually fun enough despite the idea being so bland. Combat does feel slow though, and like there should be more interaction. I feel like this game would be very fitting for some strategic combat. 

There is a pretty good variety of outfits and weapons wielding different stats as well as different rooms to use and some good humor as well. For a free game I can't complain, but for a free game that has been out for a while and obviously still containing issues like these I'm not really impressed. I look forward to future updates if there are any, in hopes of these small issues being fixed.
It's great for a multi-tasker like me. I need to do other things while I do stuff like homework or draw, and this helps immensely with that. Fun little game, but not over-the-top. ^^

This game is free. It is a mobile port. It has microtransactions. It is a waiting simulator. It is singleplayer. Graphics are cartoony.

It is literally just a free, micro-managing, waiting game that you check in on once in a while. That's it. That's ALL it is. Whether you prefer to do this inbetween other obligations while working on your PC, or simply once or twice throughout the day, or even every other day. 

Fallout Shelter just puts you into the propaganda-style Vault introduced in the Fallout series, it has good humor, and it is interesting enough for a free game to warrant my recommendation.

And to all of the people who passionately dislike this game. It's still Fallout, maybe not an open world shooter. This is not a game you are supposed to rush. It is not a game you are supposed to "win". It does have microtransactions, but you can earn those readily ingame as well, without paying. All those negative reviews bitching about these various non-sensical issues are just trash. 

The game has good humor, it is very relaxing to watch your dwellers do whatever they do, and frankly since its release on mobile platforms, it has come a long way with a lot of updates and new features. For a FREE game, it is absolutely recommendable. But buyer beware I guess, if you are an elitist moron who thinks you HAVE to rush through the game and "win", then you probably will not enjoy it.

I'm surprised at the "Very Positive" status of the reviews for this. 

If you didn't know, this is originally a mobile game. The developers did very little to polish this up...excuse me, the developers did nothing to make the controls something even close to reasonable for the PC. As other reviews mention, the snapping is absolutely awful. Addtionally, there are a lot of miscues brought on by clicking. Such as, I wasn't trying to click "the room" I was trying to click my dweller. Since it's free, go ahead and play it and see what I mean.

Speaking of clicking on dwellers, there are a number of bugs, such as you click on one dweller, the menu pops up correctly, you then click another dweller and the menu does NOT change to that dweller, it instead disappears.


But the biggest problem, THE ABSOLUTE WORST PROBLEM of this game, that even applies to its mobile form, is that this is just another ... ... ... ... "Play to wait, Pay to wait less" piece of .........


Now, if this was $10 to buy and you didn't have any of the BS "pay to play" aspects, it would be worth it. But sitting there staring at the screen is NOT a good PC game. You can trick people into thinking they're receiving something on a mobile game, where you can easily go and do something else, but when you sit down to play a PC game you should not have to sit there with literally nothing else you can do! 

Spent all your caps, got all your dwellers working, and sent off an expedition? Congratulations! You get to waste the next 5 minutes of your life watching...nothing.

Don't waste your money on this. Seriously. Just don't. Don't do any of the in-game purchases. Don't support this kind of .... through Steam.

What should you be aware of?

- You can create upto 3 seperate Vaults (3 save games). If you decide to spend money in one it will only apply to that vault, not your other 2. You cannot transfer / carry over characters or weapons.

- If you have played on your mobile device spending countless hours (and possibly money) do not expect to be able to transfer your save/s over. They do not allow transfer of games to/from iOS, Android or PC. "Please note that it is *not possible* to transfer your Vaults between different platforms (Andoid, iOS, PC) in Fallout Shelter."

I enjoyed playing it on my phone and looked forward to playing it on the pc instead. Not being able to transfer my saves over is a deal breaker.

This is a rewritten review after I finally got the game to run without crashing.

It is actually a sweet little game, good for killing time or run while doing something on the other monitor.

When playing on PC through Steam your progress is transferred to other PCs running Steam. That is pretty nice and hardly surprising - but I have read elsewhere that the progress is tied to the device when playing the android version, so I thought it relevant to mention it.

Two annoying things in the game:

1: When dragging your dweller from one room to another the placement is not intuitive - it is very easy to place the dweller in the room below the one you intended.

2: When your shelter gets attacked by raiders you will send dwellers to stop them. If you send the dwellers to - say - the diner, they will do battle. But when the raiders decide to run on and further down into your shelter you can not stop them from doing that. But what is really annoying is that your dweelers say "Ah, nice, the unppleasant chaps finally vacated the diner. Let's sit down and take a cup of tea." And that is what they do - instead of chasing the raiders. 

Some have complained about micro-transactions. I haven't played enough yet to have anything to say to that.

All in all, an enjoyable little game - and gratis to boot (at least when I got it).

It's a fairly decent game, very fun to play. And the nice thing about the PC verison is that you can get to see all of the details up close that you wouldn't be able to see on a smaller screen like the phone.

 HOWEVER!!! It's painfully obivious that this was originally an mobile game, due to the fact everything is on a timer. like you have to wait 14 to 4 mintues before you collect engery, food, and so on forth. the thing about casual browser and mobile phone games is that they're designed for people on the go. you send commands to your settlers/dwellers, etc and then shut the phone off while you do things such as work-related stuff... and then get back to it on your lunch break.
  It's not really meant for long-term gaming where you can have fun building endlessly for hours. It's not that kind of game.

 Better stick to playing this on your phone instead of on steam.

Fallout Shelter is a nice little F2P micromanagement game where you build one of Fallout's infamous vaults from scratch. Every vault consists of many different rooms which all serve one specific purpose like generating energy or drinking water. Then there are your inhabitants or dwellers which are necessary to do the actual work. Every dweller has his/her own unique strenghts and weaknesses which makes some of them better suited to perform certain tasks (rooms) than others. When you click on a power generation room, for example, a new display will pop up, there you will notice a circle with a capital 'S' in it which stands for strenght. Now you wanna check your dwellers' stats and assign the ones with high strenght (S) to the power generation room. To prevent things from becoming too easy the game will randomly throw threats at you which threaten your inhabitants. Usually, however, are your dwellers quite capable of handling such situations on their own as long as you have enough of them assigned to the room where the threat will initially occur or spread to. Weapons, armor and pets can help to deal with threats inside your vault easier and are also recommended to increase the chances of survival in the wastes. When you drag a dweller outside of your shelter you can order them to go on exploration missions or build the Overseer's office to send your dwellers on quests for rewards. 

That's more or less it. What I still should point out is that Fallout Shelter isn't a game you could play for hours on end! You wanna load it up in the morning and before you go sleep, for example, to get maximum enjoyment out of it. It WiLL definitely bore you out of your mind if you think you could get entire gaming sessions out of it! I have played the game for about 5 hours now and didn't run into any annoying F2P crap yet. Those loot boxes or Nuka Colas which you can buy for real money aren't exactly necessary in my opinion to enjoy or survive in the game (at least not yet?).

While I liked the first 10 hours I lost interest pretty quickly once those feral ghouls started to constantly attack my vault. Annoying, especially due to the fact that those suckers do not even drop any rewards except for contaminating my vault with radiation.. Constantly swapping weapons around where they are needed also became infuriating way too fast to ever even consider putting any real money into it.. 

Shelter is still alright but it can go and fuck off as far as I am concerned ; P

A Mobile-port F2P Waiting-game cookie cutter that uses the appeal of Fallout to try to mix things up in the heavily over-used genre. As such, since it's a game spawned from the cancer that is the Mobile gaming industry? It's full of microtransactions that really don't do much but try to tempt you to throw your money away for the sake of vanity or completionism. The best advice that can be given is that you play the game patiently during your free time, or when you can multitask this and other games to make the best of collecting resources while on the PC while playing any other game during intermissions - (Like say you're playing CSGO, you die, so you quickly collect the resources and go back in-game, rinse repeat).

The pros, I'd argue involve it having a lot of things to do, a lot of things to collect for those that like collecting things, the game seems to have improved in the amount of things you can collect or do since when I last tried it on Android when it first launched.

The cons, it's a mobile game and you can draw numerous negative conclusions from just that. Don't waste your money, quests give you 'Cards' and they are preying on you being impatient, preying that you have a gambling-addiction, and preying that you give them money that as others point out? The things you waste your money on IN-GAME are purely connected to your ONE save file, your one vault. If that vault is deleted or anything happens to it? All that used money is gone forever.

I give this a Recommend only because I like having something to do inbetween other games and I'm sure I'll be content and pre-occupied with this quite fine in comparison to other games of the same genre - that and I give them a Recommend because they actually ALLOW you to get the Premium (Lunch boxes) via quests, where other money-grubbing devs normally save those behind a paywall and a paywall only.
Dont spend money?

They were told that unless they did this, everyone in the vault would be killed. The experiment continued until there were only five original inhabitants left, who all refused to continue rather than choose. At this point, the survivors were told the true nature of the experiment - that sacrifice had never, in fact, been required, and they were ‚Äúshining examples of humanity‚Äù.

I created vault 11 in this game, now it's time for the experiment to commence.

(Edit after 100 hours of play)

so advise for the developers:

-Fix the room dragg box.
      The lower half of a room is actually the room underneath it, resulting in people being allocated to the wrong rooms.
-When a room finnishes it's production run, you HAVE to empty the room of resources before ANYONE can be dragged to another room (very enoying in crittical situations.
Vault Lunchboxes are WAY to unreliable in it's payout to warrant paying real money to shortcut.

Tips for players:

THIS GAME IS A PORT, treat it as such.
-right and left clicking produce the same results.
-there is a way to keep the numbers up under the resource bars, top center of the screen, however this happens more as an accidental result and not clear information on how to do it in game.
- as rooms produce resources, people will wander within the room, this meens them running back to their production spot (running from right side of room to the left) which makes it imposible to grab a dweller to assigne to another place within your vault in case of emergencies.

So, with that out of the way (and believe me, there are more bugs and i senceerly hope the developers will spend time to help fix this game), here is my Verdict:

Play it
For free
the game is entertaining and addictive, fun and indepth, varied and allows for roleplay to change each vault experience you deside to make.
However, do NOT allow yourself to be lulled into spending money on the ingame store.
the vault boxes, nuka cola quantum, mr Handy(s) and pet boxes are all collectable within the game.
If you deside to play survival (ironman) mode, i suggest getting a starter pack otherwise the randomness and unrelaibilty in the contence of the Lunchboxes will see your vault Fail very rappidly. The Starter pack costs 5 euros/dollars and is a ONE TIME USE. Change vault (yes you can have more then one vault each with it's own save) and your Real Money items will have to be rebought for that particular playthrough........... yeah a bit to easy to make money that way and not one i endorse.

Youtube has several playthroughs and tip/tricks videos from well known entertainers and well worth checking out to get a good idea about the game.

The game is fun, but has allot of consumer unfriendly mechanics which makes it agravating from time to time.
It's way to earn money to warrant this game though, is a rip off.

Luck = better chance to succesfully rush a room, better loot chances, higher critts and critt chances

Fires are easy to put out and also give exp.[/spoiler]

I had 8 people die within 20 minutes of a rad roach infection. Not even that far in the game yet.

Radroaches are the easiest fucking thing to kill in fallout, yet when I have people fighting them all with guns die, even after I give some of the stimpacks, they still die and im stuck with either paying money to revive the starting people or just let them lay on the floor untill I have enough.

In the beginning I enjoyed this game, but theres a lot in here that needs working on. For one, the fighting in general is just flat out retarded. Oh, raiders just attacked us! There coming to our room! Fight for your lives! Ok... Wait... They left mid battle.. There going to the next room... Im just gonna keep working and let them run around our vault willy nilly. What in the actual fuck. Like your not gonna just let them leave the room and go fight the next people. They go back to work as if nothing is happening. This, is by far the worst mechanic in this entire game. Defending your vault against whatever is just flat out dumb right now. Judging by how far and long this game has been out. It wont be changing.

In the beggining I enjoyed this game, it was fun. But, this is not made for PC. This is a mobile game, and all mobile games have waiting mechanics. I cant play this before I go to work, then come back to people starving and all that. They should have came out with a PC version of this game. Plain and simple. There are mobile mechanics in a PC game and it just doesnt work out.

The defending of your vault is downright awful. I cannot believe I lost 8 people in one rad roach infection. I dont have 3k caps lying around cause I havnt progressed in the game at all. Fuck, I just unlocked the med bay. All the sudden I have all these people coming in and killing everyone when I cant even handle myself yet. The difficulty just jumped all the sudden and now im stuck with a vault thats slowly dying. Fix the defence of your vault. Seriously. Fighting in this game is just flat out dumb. The rows or whatever your trying to do dont work out, just makes them stand 5 feet from eachother doing the same animation over and over. Somehow, a dweller with a shotgun lost a battle to a radroach. A single fucking radroach killed my best equipped dweller, even after I shoved a stimpack up his ass.

Going out into the wasteland is a joke too. You expect me to sit here and wait a few hours to check in on him here and there to make sure that hes still alive and kicking? No, fuck that. Thats not how a game on this platform works. Like I said before, this game has mobile mechanics shoved into a PC platform. I will not wait 20 minutes for the med bay to make one single fucking stimpack. During that time, I get attacked and whatever. Then people lose health. Boy, whos life should I fucking save out of the 5 people that are on the verge of dying from fucking roaches. 

I will continue to play this game, but from I can tell it will be a slow and painful death of my vault just for me to start all over again. Less then 5 hours in. Maybe 30 min of me actually being active in the game. Fix the mobile features and this would be a great game. But for now, I can not recommend it. I will still play, and I will keep updating this review with whatever happens.

Also, they dont auto collect resources, so while im working my ass off in the adult world my dwellers in my vault back home are starving because they cant click the fork and spoon icon. and no, I will not pay money to have a fucking robot come around and auto collect that stuff, when it should be auto collected on this platform to begin with.

-Edit one day later-
I have now lost 4 more people to a simple rad roach infestion. All equipped with weapons that do 6-8 damage consisting of one old lazer pistol and the rest with shotguns. They have all died due to a rad roach infestation. One. Single. Infestation and they currently have the best weapons that I had. I used up 9 stimpacks on all of them, and yet they all still died, after having there health refilled on some of them, multiple times. The rest I only used one.

This games defending mechanism is the worst I have ever seen in a game. Upon zooming into the room that they are currently fighting in, they arnt even near eachother and all of there health starts to deplete. Even with more than one person in the room, the health of all people in the room being attacked starts to deplete. One raider, 4 people all shooting at him, all losing health at the same time. Hes halfway across the room with a machete and hes somehow hitting everyone in the room at the same time.

I had 13 stimpacks, and by the end of one rad roach infestation and one Raider attack, I lost 5 people and used up 13 stimpacks to heal the weak. Everyone was equipped and had some type of outfit on them. Once the last person hit the floor, I couldnt fucking believe it. 1 single radroach had just killed 3 people. That was the last straw that I could take from this game. This shouldve never been ported over to PC. This shouldve had its own release on the PC platform. Seeing as this game has been out for as long as it has been on multiple platforms I think it is safe to say, from a person who loves the series and has played every single game. That this is the worst out of everything that they have released under the fallout name. 

Dont waste your time with this game, in the beginning you will enjoy and invest some time into it, but once you see its obvious major flaws you will regret ever playing this game to begin with.

With everything being said in this edit, I have uninstalled the game and plan on never coming back to it unless its obvious flaws and issues are fixed. Sad to see a game with obvious potential be ruined for me, a fan of the entire series and everything that comes with it, dwindled down with this mobile game. Never again

Pay now for a miniscule chance for a legendary dweller (no, seriously, the lootboxes in this game are THE WORST lootboxes I have ever seen in a game. 90% of the loot is literal junk and they're the only way to get legendary dwellers - outside of 3 you get for quests, but you need 20 for the achievement).
