Unremarkable at its worst, a distraction at best, Fallout Shelter is a great mobile game, but fails to stand on it's own two feet on PC, but is still worth a time, again, as a distraction from the seemingly infinite repetition that is life.

*NOTE: I have played this on Android and on the Bethesda launcher. Playtime here is irrelevant. Also while I like the game, I do have several gripes about the game, mostly about the microtransactions, and lack of content but we'll get to that.

Fallout Shelter is a game where you are the overseer of a vault (Which you can number yourself, I really want a statistic on how many Vaults 69, 420 and 666 have been made) and your job is to build it and make your dwellers happy. The building mechanics remind me of a mobile game by Kairosoft called Mega Mall Story, but the building mechanics are almost the same. Some would also compare this to the classic Maxis game SimTower, which I've personally never played but the gameplay I've seen of that game is pretty similar as well.

Building a vault is as simple as selecting a room and placing it next to an adjacent building. You have 25 floors, each able to hold up to 8 rooms and two lifts. While that sounds like a lot of rooms to max out your vault, you can merge up to 3 of the same room to get better effects. Rooms can do things such as produce Power, Water and Food, which are the basic needs of the vault that will decrease as time goes on, a room to train your dweller's SPECIAL stats (which I'll get into later) and crafting rooms. It is also worth noting that each room has to be unlocked when you get enough dwellers in the vault, and each room can be upgraded twice at the cost of caps to improve said room's stats.

Crafting is a mechanic I have grown to like. Your collected junk ain't junk no more, when you assign dwellers to craft weapons or outfits to equip them with. You can get cool recipes when you adventure and then craft the best items if you have the junk required. (Although how you make a 10mm pistol out a desk fan and specifically that kinda makes no sense if you ask me)

How do you get said junk, either from exploring the wastes or from questing. Exploring basically sends a dweller out into the wastes, collecting resources and gaining xp. Oh yeah, there is a levelling system, each dweller being able to go up to level 50, though you still have to train SPECIAL stats via training rooms. A good SPECIAL rating can max out your dweller's performance out in the wasteland, each stat a modifier as to how well they'll do. Questing is probably my favourite feature, even if it is a pain at times.

Building an Overseer's Office allows up to three dwellers to go on quests, and with it you can control where they go in a dungeon, which really is the most Fallout part of Shelter. While battles are automated, there is a bit of player control in this system, where you can select who or what each dweller attacks, and occasional critical hits, which involves a mouse QTE (I think that's a QTE anyway) to determine how much extra damage you do. The end results could go from common weapons, armour, caps and the occasional recipe and then it's back to the vault with your loot. It has to be noted that while your vault can be attacked by raiders, you cannot select who to attack in defense or do crits, due to the quests actually being an update and Bethesda not updating the new system to the original defense mechanic.

So the game is overall very in depth for a mobile game. Unfortunately, this is PC, so there are a few gripes.

So everything in the game I've said so far sounds entertaining to you? Here is to me the SECOND worst mechanic in a mobile game, WAITING. There is a lot of waiting to do here. Heck, almost everything requires you to idle. Get resources, wait. Craft, wait. Get a freaking haircut, wait. Exploring, wait. And you have to wait another half of the time the dweller travelled for the bugger to come back. Questing? The best feature in the game? WAIT. This game is full of it, and eventually you realise the best thing to do is just let the game run in the background while you are doing something else.

Believe it or not, you couldn't even skip the waiting whatsoever in the beginning. Then Nuka Cola Quantum happened. Which is the typical skip the waiting currency. Now would be a good time to get to the microtransactions.

Now, before anyone says ANYTHING, this ISN'T, repeat, ISN'T, pay-to-win. It's pay-to-be-incredibly-lazy or as I like to call it, pay-for-random-stuff. Unless you are buying Mr. Handys outright (which by the way do nothing but collect the resources for you so you can do nothing even more), you can't control what you buy. Lunchboxes are a blind bag mechanic, where you get 5 random things in game, such as more resources, caps, quantum and new dwellers, weapons and outfits. And you can't choose what you get. This isn't pay-to-win because you can't just buy quantum outright and go all the way to maxing your vault within a week. No, the randomness is like opening a pack of randoms, can be anything. FIFA Ultimate Team Packs, Hearthstone packs, Magic the Gathering, Pok√©mon TCG cards. That's what it is. Cards. That are completely optional because you can get lunchboxes from quests and objectives. So it's not completely gated off. There are a few problems of course, such as everything you buy is locked to ONE SAVEFILE. So if it gets wiped, goodbye money. This is a bit of a problem to some, but really, since I have never bought anything on this game ($70 for your bloody Fallout 4 Season Pass is enough Bethesda) and just get lunchboxes for free, it's not THAT big a deal to me, though if you do plan to drop money on lunchboxes, this is your warning.

Another thing that grinds my gears is the lack of endgame content. Once you hit the dweller cap or building everything you pretty much have nothing left to do. It then becomes busywork. I myself only play this game in long bursts whenever the game updates or I feel like it.

One more aspect. I know Shelter isn't meant to be canon, but come on. Why does the vault open AFTER the bombs fall? And I'm pretty sure raiders and ghouls can't just break into a vault. And what IS the experiment for your vault? Vault Tec vaults are meant to be very dark social experiment so just... what is it supposed to be. Unless it was meant to be a utopia that also trains the settlers for survival, but that's just to kind of Vault Tec considering their reputation.

Despite these complaints, I have no issue with recommending Shelter. It is a good game, but it can only hold your interest for so long. And hey, kudos to Bethesda for their most stable and crash free game to date. There are bugs (of course) but nothing game breaking for me in about 30 hours of total playtime. It also has a better building sytem than Fallout 4. So there's that.

If you like Fallout or building, or are a newcomer to the series and want a glimpse on what the twisted wasteland is like, give it a try. I enjoy it and I love that this is on Steam.

Also if anyone wants to comment on this, please keep it polite. Don't throw names around and be civil for once please Internet.

[i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is game that lured me in for tens on hours playing it on my tablet back in the day. Even then I was able to realise, how dumb this game is, how easy it is, and that there isn't much of a gameplay going on. 
Basically clicker with Fallout clothes on. But I was persistent. It kept me busy while watching movies, tv shows, whatever, so I didn't mind paying my attention to something that doesn't require a lot of it ... if any, for that matter.

Now this gem, came to our beloved [i]Steam[/i], and what I started to do? Playing it while watching movies, tv shows, or whatever. This game isn't great in anything particular. If you want hardcore management game, great simulation, you won't get that. What you will get is time filler, for killing some downtime during other more meaningful sessions with something else. Nothing more. Nothing less. 

There is a planty of things I would change. UI menus aren't as intuitive; screen from time to time is doing its own thing; moving population is sometimes pain in the ass; not a lot of depth; and so, and so on. Plenty of things that are wrong with this game. And yet, my time sunk in this game is raising, only because I like the theme, simplicity, and just look at it every five minutes while I'm watching movie. 

This isn't first, and certainly won't be last game that had this fate in my history. I just like to spread my attention to different things, and yet still be focused mainly on one particular. 
[i]Fallout Shelter[/i] is letting me do this, therefor I'm ok with all flaws ... and because it is free game, of course - otherwise, this tune could change really fast.

If you are not familiar with this tittle, give it a little try. 
If you are familiar from mobile devices, let me assure you not much has changed.
If you want kill some time, there is probably no downside to it, so do it.

This game is fun and challenging.

In this game you build a Fallout Shelter. Then the dwellers arrive at your vault door. That is when things start to become a challenge.

You have several things that you need to keep an eye on. The first of these are three meters which measure how much food, water and energy you have in your vault. These are very important. You want to keep them full. If they fall too low, it lowers the overall happiness of your vault dwellers.

The more rooms you build in your vault, the more energy it consumes.
The more dwellers you have the more food and water they consume.

The other things you need to watch for is the happiness meter and the bottlecap meter. The hapiness meter tells you the vault's average happiness and the bottlecap meter tells you how much money you have. 

You can also bring up a view of all your dweller's and view their status, which includes happiness, their job and how they are equiped. You can equip your dweller with clothing, weapons and a pet.

Now the most important rooms that you will want to build when you start out are Living Quarters, Power Station, Water Station and Diner. This will allow you to get the first of your dwellers started. These rooms cost bottle caps to build, so be careful of how many you start off with right away. You don't want to use up all of your bottlecaps. 

Now will start out with 7 Dwellers at the vault door. You can drag them to the appropriate rooms and assign them jobs. You can determine the right jobs by another meter called the S.P.E.C.I.A.L Meter. Dweller has their own. This meter shows you the dweller's

Strength
Perception
Endurance
Charisma
Inteligence
Agility
Luck

If your dweller is high in Strength you would assign them to the Power Station.
High Perception would be assigned to the Water Station
Agility would be assigned to the Diner.

More rooms will unlock as you play. Each of these rooms will be governed by one of these SPECIAL stats.

Your Dweller's can also produce baby dwellers as well. Baby dwellers happiness will remain at 50% until they are grown and can be placed in a job.

To make things more interesting, your vault can have various disaster incidents occure. It can be attacked by raiders or infested by radroaches or even catch on fire.

Lastly, you can send your dweller out of the vault on quests in which they can fine and bring back various loot and bottlecaps.

It is a fun game and more challenging you might think.

Fallout Shelter is the best Bethesda-made (studio, not publisher) game since Fallout 3.

It's a simple, but rather polished idle game, based on managing a Vault from the Fallout titles.  There's three main resource productions to balance, Food, Water and Power, and then Caps is the currency for building stuff, with Nuke cola allowing you to skip wait times.

It's, at its core, a simple time-killer mobile game but that does not make it less enjoyable to play. The animations, personalization, theming and soundtrack are very well made, making you engage in one of those famous reward loops.
 
Time is the main gate to your progress, it is true that wait times can feel long occasionally, being this a title to be played in a "Pet Game" style, more so than some other idlers or city builders of the genre.

The game also offers the option to explore the wasteland, where you get a log of your pawn's progress delivered through their PipBoy, and the feature of quests, which add some very basic looting, combat and exploration mechanics, that are, however, rather fun to play.

I'd recommend investing some time in this if you are into this genre of games or are looking for a decent time waster.

First of all ignore my steam playtime, I got this game on my iphone the day it came out and put probably 40 hours on it there.

Made a super vault that went all the way to the bottom.  Top four floors were designated for the vault's watch (Game of Thrones rip off) whose sole purpose was to train their SPECIAL to max out and defend the vault from raiders and deathclaws.  Those who were not training and manning the door were out exploring and doing quests.  Imagine a 200 person vault where 50 of them were in the watch, indestructable!

PROS
-simple game with no pay wall timers
-mindless gameplay you can do while waiting with your laptop
-Bethesda constantly updates it adding things (junk, quests, nuka cola quantum weren't in the game at launch)
-always side missions and mini tasks you can do, or you can close it and wait for your resources to regather

CONS
-the DLC or purchases for the game are linked to a save slot, so if you buy something and delete that vault it goes away.
-not too much gameplay if you are looking to make a guy and explore with him this is not the game for you (think tiny tower type game)
-can be slow going if you want to make a huge vault, it will take time and patients 


Overall a fun game, it is free so if you do not like it you've lost nothing but your time. Not somehting you'll be able to sit down and play for hours, but when you get the vault going it gets intense.

I've poured hundreds of hours into this game on other platforms and all I can really say about the Steam release is, "Why now?"

At first, the game seems fun. It's very new, still got that new car smell, and you're figuring out all the features. Once you've hit 100 dwellers and created all the rooms, you still want to snag all the achievements, right? So now you're building multiple skill-up rooms, more living quarters, more Nuka-Cola rooms, more power plants. You're still interested at this point, but you're losing it slowly. You've now found a routine, where you hop on the game for short moments at a time now. You complete the skill-ups that are waiting, you send some dwellers out for a quest. Your interest is still slowly dropping, but you're invested in it enough to continue playing at least once or twice a day for about five minutes at a time, not including quest time. At this point, you realize how inconvenient the game has become. You're still trying to finish each session more quickly with each passing day. You're a busy person, you have other, better games to play, but you dropped some money on this game months ago and you don't want that money to go to waste now, do you? Only now you really do know just how inconvenient the game is since you've been trying to only get in a few minutes at a time each session. Every time you log into the game, you're now trying to complete your tasks as quickly as possible in order avoid the elephant in the room. You've finished your task, you're hitting the Save option and you're about to exit the game when it finally happens: Random deathclaw attacks.
You say to yourself, "You kidding me? I was a half a second short from exiting the game and doing anything else and NOW I need to spend another 5 - 6 minutes here to deal with this crap?" I mean, you need to kill the deathclaws at some point. You could just go ahead and quit the game, but they'll still be there inside your vault when you log back on, so you might as well keep playing to make sure your dwellers aren't killed.

That's pretty much how I feel about this game right now. Just one more inconvenience, but I'm invested, I spent the time and the money, so I might as well keep playing so I can at least get my money/time's worth.

I picked it up last year when it launched on PC via Bethesda net. This version had issues even patching the game to keep it updated.
In my honest opinion, I don't know if this is a popular opinion here, but I believe the BEST version of this game is the Windows 10 version for two reasons.
The Windows 10 version included gamepad support (only handy if you're on a laptop and don't have a mouse) and it included Xbox Play Anywhere. Xbox Play Anywhere is a feature on the Windows 10 version that allows your save data to be shared in the cloud with your Xbox Live account so that you can play the game on your Windows 10 desktop or laptop and take your save data with you to your Xbox One console, hence the gamepad support. There aren't too many times when I'm playing the Xbox One instead of the PC version, but this also allows me to take my save data with me from my desktop to my laptop. For this very reason, I'm NOT leaving a positive review for the Steam version.
If you don't need the additional Windows 10 features, or you just can't stand the thought of using UWP games (how dare they, I know) or you've never played Fallout Shelter before, then by all means, check out the Steam version. Just keep in mind the inconveniences of this game. Again, I don't know why it took so long to bring this to Steam. This was the only game I even booted up the Bethesda Launcher for. =/

Fallout Shelter is a free to play time management mobile game port where you manage your own Fallout Vault-Tec Vault. You have to manage food, water, and power to keep your Vault Dwellers happy. You can also send Vault dwellers to explore the wasteland or out on quests that you can play thorugh. Other than chosing your targets on quests and clicking on resorces, there's not much gameplay. It does have microtransactions, but I recommend it's not worth spending money on, you get free lunchboxes through to-do quests. It's simple to play and fun for awhile, though It's getting boring after the Vault gets to a point where it can survive without you. It's a great time waster if you need one. And I give this a 7/10.

[h1] Good phone to PC game, but not very attracting [/h1]
I have played this game on my phone [b]for months[/b], so as I played it on pc and found nothing different or new, I think I am ready to review it.
I won't bore you and therefore keep it very short. You're meant to expand and prosper, create rooms in your [b]VAULT[/b] for dwellers.
You're meant to assign dwellers to different rooms based on their [b] S.P.E.C.I.A.L [/b] statistics (like Power generator room needs dweller with strength, therefore assign your strongest dwellers to Power generation room). New dwellers come randomly from wasteland or your dwellers can make out and have babies if you assign a male and female to a, [i] I forgot the exact name[/i], living room. 
[i] okey you know what? I'll skip to the end [/i], the game is a bit engaging at the beginning, but soon it washes off. You don't even feel accomplished if you fully dwell up your vault, and for people like me who played it hours and hours on phone, it's just a download-try-remove game.
[b] TRY IT [/b], if you haven't played it yet, do it. It's a good game. It needs you to reopen it once in a while though, like clicker heros or something, so best way to play it is play it while doing something else.
P.S. I will edit my review if something new comes up.

Fallout Shelter gives you control over your own vault and you as a overseer build it, keep your dwellers happy and out of the harms way. You can customize your dwellers appereance, change their habitat in vaults, explore wasteland and special quest areas outside your safe heaven while collecting, building equipment such as weapons, armors etc. Any action takes time, classic mobile game.  Fine for moments while you can't really play something but...why not play this on mobile/tablet then?
This is basically same thing as seen on iOs, Android or Bethesda Launcher for PC.

+ Fallout theme f2p sims
+ Random events, new dwellers, interesting mechanics of sustaining your vault
+ You don't really have to to spend any money on it, all you can get from game itself. No pay wall.
+ Achievments to gain for collectors
+ After all this time still new content rolling in
+ Hardcore game mode
+ Same as real life. Kissing for a while and faster than you know it, bam, you got kids!
- Mobile game graphically
- Time waiting better works on mobile than PC
- After a while very repetetive
- Singleplayer only. I would love to send invaders to some other vaults!

So far I've found Fallout Shelter enjoyable. The Free to Play aspect can make certain things like characters and weapons inconvenient or a little difficult, but given the state of the low price indie game market on Steam or the rubbish coming out of Greenlight in the past few months, I'd say you get your money's worth out of 'buying' this. In that I mean it's entirely based on whether you enjoy resource management and casual building games. If you don't, you're going to not enjoy this game. Honestly, it's not so bad beyond the knee jerk reaction over a Free to Play game with microtransactions. I can't say you can call this pay to win because I've spent no money on this game, nor can I afford to, but I've gotten some pretty nice stuff from the scavenging and Wasteland exploration. To be honest, this game is entirely what you make of it to be. But it's a casual time-waster kind of game, so you shouldn't expect it to be a free game with AAA storytelling or something, it's a settlement management mini-game, basically.

now you may be thinking "ohhh boy another shitty mobile game on steam! Bet it's full of pay 2 win crap" but personally this is a truly fun game! You don't need to buy anything in the store, as most of it you can find out in the wastelands. Tired of having games make you pay to unlock good weapons? "pay 30 to unlock this minigun!" This game is not one of those! Later on you can send out dwellers and scavenge for supplies out in the wastelands! When you have a god-tier vault and can send out dwellers with good equipment and 20 of each (Radaways and Stimpaks) you can find legendary recipies out in the wastelands that can be used to craft some of the best items in the game. The only thing you truly need to pay for (unless I just haven't found it yet) is the Mr. Handy. Caps, Weapon recipies, Legendary dwellers, Legendary weapon recipies, Pets, they can all be found without paying! Not only that but unlike other games with "tier crates/boxes" there are none of those in this game. One type of "box" and it dosen't matter! You can get something legendary from your first ever box in the game! (if your lucky!)

So get out there and lead your vault to the great beyond Overseer! Your dwellers need you!

I've already spent almost 100 hours playing this game on the Windows Store, and I have to say that it's one hell of a time waster. Fallout Shelter doesn't have any specific goal in mind, so you can spend your spare time increasing your vault's population (and have your own Gary-themed whacko-fest); training your dwellers' SPECIAL stats for gameplay bonuses; or send them all out in the wasteland, and battle a dozen Deathclaws, for that chance to find a rare item - just remember to send them back to the vault if you're going to exit the game, because the timer keeps ticking even when you're out, and reviving a dead vault dweller costs a lot of caps. Tip for new players: a high food level keeps everyone happy and smiling in the face of danger; therefore, invest in it early in the game (or send the useless dwellers out to die in the wilderness), because it dwindles fast if you have too many people.

Overall, a fun casual game. There are microtransactions available, but your vault can survive even without purchasing any of them. You might have to spend more time playing and managing if you want some of the loot that can be purchased in the store, but a day or two of waiting wouldn't hurt.

[b]Fallout Shelter is a great game, but it is not meant to be played on PC.[/b]

It first came out for mobile, and it sure seemed to be designed for it. You make a vault, gather resource and wait. Oh yes, there is a lot of waiting in this game: You wait for your resources, crafting, going to the wastelands, etc. The good thing for mobile is that you can open the game anytime, anywhere. This is obviously not the case for PC.

Also, your save files do not move over to different platforms. All vaults have their individual save files that are saved locally. This means, whatever progress and in-game purchases you made STAY ON THAT VAULT AND ONLY THAT VAULT. I don't know about you, but to me that seems to be an absolute waste of money. There are ways to import save files across mobile to PC, but really who would waste so much effort just for that. If they supported automatic file sync across platforms, this game would be much more enjoyable.

Don't misunderstand, I love Fallout Shelter. I have over 80 dwellers in my phone and it took a lot of time to reach that level. I just feel like playing the game on PC would be a waste of time since you can't sync your files anywhere else; it just stays there.

[b]EDIT:[/b]
First of all, a lot of you guys seem to think that I don't know that the save files can be moved from different devices. It is, in fact, possible and I acknowledged it in my review. There are dozens of websites that guide you on how to do it and even a Steam guide on that topic. 

Second, I marked this review negative not because I don't like the game nor the PC port; both are great. I'm did this because having played it on mobile for months, I just feel like the waiting and low maintenance made it seem like a mobile game. If you like to play idle/waiting games on PC, then this game is for you.

I spent months playing this game on mobile so I don't see a reason to suddenly move to PC just because it is released here. I've grown comfortable playing with my phone and I've decided to stick with it. I have moved my save files to PC just to try it out and it really works, but still not enough motivation for me to switch platforms.

[b]You prefer playing it on PC? Then continue to play it on PC.[/b]

I first picked this up for android while waiting for Fallout 4, since this was launched in the meanwhile as part of the hype. It has always been free, and is now available on Steam as well. Compared to other free tablet ports this is pretty decent, but it's nothing more than a timesink, to be honest.

Basically, you get your shot at constructing your own Fallout vault. A variety of rooms provide different bonuses or resources, and 4 main resources are needed: power, food, water and caps. What this game is about is pretty much down to expanding your vault while making sure you have the resource needed for it. 

As such, this is not a game that will challenge your intellect that much, neither will it require cool nerves or lightning reflexes, it's more about planning, building and then waiting while your resources stock up. The waiting I figure is part of making players buy certain add-ons, wich are sold in-game, but these are not necessary for the game, it just makes progression quicker. If needed you can also do quests to gain additional resources, and belive it or not, but the quest stories are sometimes better than the ones in Fallout 4.

All in all, as a timesink and considering it's free, there's worse alternatives out there, and for someone that's a fan of the Fallout franchise, this is a good way to quickly kill a few minutes when needed, or even an occasional hour.

If you don't have the autolooting/resource collecting robots then this game is absolute trash on top of the fact it's a "waiting simulator." You send guys out into the wastelands and it takes hours upon hours for them to find anything worthwhile and to have them come back to your vault also takes hours (yes real time). You save and exit to come back in and find everyone starving, pi.ssed off, and dying because they're too stupid to auto collect anything they produce in the vault since the developers expect you to use the robots. It also takes 3 hours real time for one of your pregnant vault women to finally give birth... On top of this I feel as if the "rush" option is a lie when it comes to the percentage chance of you succeeding/failing as you progress more and more into the game. You fail way more often then you succeed and it's quite sad.

When you send people out into the waste lands it takes half the time spent out exploring for the return trip back home. My best guy died out there when he had a minigun, survivor armor, and a golden retriever equipped to a radscorpion. He spent 12 hours and 15 mins in the wasteland and now it's going to take 6 hours and 7 mins to have him come back to my vault after resurrecting him for 643 caps... Boring.

The alarm sound also needs it's own specific checkbox option to be disabled because it is way too annoying. Having to disable all of the game sounds just to turn it off isn't what I wanted...

It's no different then most mobile games that make you wait and wait to accomplish something. Which in my opinion is extremely boring and ruins most of these decent free to play mobile style games.

Unless you're spending real cash to buy robots (to autocollect your resources on one specific floor so you need a bunch...), cola (to reduce times), and anything else they offer in their store then you might have fun. But if you're playing this for free it will only provide a few hours of fun before it becomes a nuisance/bore. 

On top of this it regularly crashes upon launch (at least for me) and to fix this I had to restart steam everytime and relaunch the game.

You can get more enjoyment out of a free internet flash game than this garbage. Like "The Last Stand" zombie flash games etc. Or better yet another free 2 play game like "Leauge of Legends" etc...

UPDATED REVIEW:

Since I've played it quite a lot now and know what I'm doing I'd say this is quite a decent little game. Build up your vault, go on quests, get loot, craft stuff, make children and that's about it. Pretty simple but since its all fallout themed its quite a nice game.
There are some problems with it for example in a single room you can't have two people both with pets, zooming in & out and moving the camera with the mouse is a bit annoying, especially when you keep accidentally grabbing a vault dweller instead of moving the camera. The graphics aren't good, could atleast make it look a bit better for the PC verison. The elevators aren't realistic, a character can go down an elevator right after another one just went down. After a while you see every location in the game and stuff just repeats, would be better to get a bit more of a variety. Perks/skills don't work like they do in the main games, you can have a level 50 dweller with the best weapons and armor and still have a bit of trouble killing high level enemies, whereas in the main games you just 1 shot everything at that level. There's also a lot missing that are in the main games, not many enemies, locations, items, or characters aside from the legendary ones. Hope they add more to it eventually.
Since its a FTP game it does take a long while to do things like beat quests and pretty much everything else, you'll probably just keep going back to it once or twice a day until its all done however its not a pay to win game although there are micro transactions. You can easily get everything done without having to pay a cent. Just takes a while.

Overall a decent little game. I'd give it a 8/10. Needs more content really. 




Original:

Bout time it came to Steam. Now I actually want to play it. It's a pretty cool little game but it does have its problems. Would be good if there was a paid version cause I'd prefer to get a nice big vault up and running easier without having to wait weeks while I make 50 children. There is a dumb glitch where if you alt+tab in and out it sometimes messes up parts of the UI which is a big problem really cause its one of those games where you just leave it open and wait for things to happen so it'd be good if minimizing worked better. Aside from that it's a fun experience even though it's full of FTP garbage but you don't have to pay for anything, you just obtain things much slower which is fair for a free game. A fun mini-experience for all Fallout fans.

[h1]I played this game for a very, very long time on my phone, and I would like to share this story...[/h1]

It was a quite day in vault 326.
112 Veteran vault dwellers were home, going about their daily duties. 10 More children. Mike and Lisa are expecting their 2nd child. Hoping for a girl this time.
They had created a strong hold, here in the rock. The raiders and deathclaw, easily held at bay by their strong door, and battle hardened guards. Mike had become comfortable in their home under the waste. "We're safe here.", he told himself.
Mike looked at Lisa over the clipboard he was holding. She was pruning some plants in the hydroponic guarden.
"Did you hear that?" asked Mike.
"No, hunny. What did you hear?" She stoped her chores and walked over to her husband. He looked back at her with a concerned look in his eye.
"I thought I just heard something downstairs"
"It's probably just Tony dropping boxes off the shelf again. You know he thinks he's stronger then he really is."
"Heh. Yeah, you're probably right." 
The sound of Jim's 44 rounds rang out through the 6th floor halls, and echoed violently up the elevator shaft. Mike's head jerked around tward the elevator door, and then back to Lisa.
"That definatly wasn't Tony."
The screams of the storage room workers could be heard, frantic and desprite, between the sparatic gun fire. 
"This isn't a normal attack," Mike thinks to himself, "usualy Bob and Ray have this under controll by now."
A new sound can be heard outside the door. It's getting closer.
[i]Bang... Scratch... Bang... Bang...[/i] The door shook. It was not ment for this kind of treatment. It couldn't hold out for long.
Mike took his wifes hand. This was the end. They both knew.
The molerats burst through the weakened door, into the garden room. They were hungry. They were relentless. 
None could stop the molerat menace. One by one, room by room, they mercilessly slaughtered every man, woman, and child. The vault was theirs now.
Molerat kind has a new home.

TL;DR
~10/10
~Molerats OP
~Will build more molerat habitats

::edit 2020 update::
Still broken for those with multiple flight sim devices.
Initially devs denied the issue existed, but now the acknowledges it but does not fix it, only suggesting to unplug the joysticks.
In my setup there are 4 such devices and unplugging and re-plugging them to play a faulty game that has done nothing to deal with a well known Unity issue is not sensible nor ideal.

Self proclaimed elitist clowns need not reply to this. It would seem they are unable to read or comprehend plain and simple words. The nature of PC is that we all have varying setups, and occasionally slip into a situation where something doesn't work for your particular setup.
Sometimes it's an issue the devs didn't think ahead to (like this one, where Unity engines default enabling to accept joy input without option to disable causes the issue).
I'd probably lay the blame more on Unity than this title in particular, but the lack of willingness of Fallout Shelter devs in tackling the issue is concerning.

I have reported to to both the Fallout Shelter devs and the Unity devs, going back several times of the last 3-4 years. I suspect it has been fixed in the most recent versions of Unity, but anything based on previous versions still suffers.

Another game that suffers the issue is Yet Another Zombie Defense HD, along with a few other Unity titles.
::edit 2020 update - end::

The move to PC is not well thought out.
I'm a flight simmer, and thus have about 4(*) joystick type devices connected to my PC.
This game might work great on a game pad, but with all the devices i have connected it is unplayable.

Unplugging them is an option, sure, but the real issue is if you're going to code joystick support into a game, you also need to code the ability to disable joystick input.

There are hundreds of other games that support joysticks that don't suffer from this issue.
It might be a good game, but the experience is needlessly ruined by lazy coding.
Back be up here guys, we all have unique setups and developers can't forget this.


So a few years have passed, tried this again, issues still remain however a dialogue saying to disconnect joysticks now appears.
If it were a single joystick connected to an accessible port then fine, but i have 4 such devices and none easily accessible (flight sim enthusiast).


(*)Yes, 4 joysticks might not make sense to some, here is the detail, and is fairly standard for a keen flight simmer...
1 for Stick or yoke, containing usually 2 axes and a few buttons
1 for Throttle quadrant, up to 8 axes + buttons
1 for rudder pedals + toe brakes (1 - 3 axes)
1 for radio comms, buttons and axes ext..

Short: A good game to waste away some time. Aside from controls, I see no difference between the PC version and the Mobile version of Fallout Shelter. Which ever device floats your boat.



Long:
1. It can be played via Keyboard, Mouse (my method) or controller(*).
2. While you can make purchases, you do not need to spend any money to progress.(**)
3. Most of the excitement, for me, is in the overwatcher's missions.

Alright, first keep in mind that this came out first as a mobile app. The graphics are simple and cute. The playstyle is also fairly simple and does not really offer anything 'new'. But it is a good game to play if you have a few minutes to waste but cannot or do not want to get invested in another game. OR if you want to multi-task for some reason. (Window-mode movie watching or working on homework/projects.

Keep in mind that boxes earned in a game (the free boxes) can not be opened in another save. But you can get pets and Mr. Handy from them. You get one box every 7 days you check in and you can randomly get a task that rewards with a box as well. (Same with the overwatcher missions. Some times they reward boxes, pets, outfits, etc.)

Customization mostly comes later in the game, but you are free to re-name the people as you get them (or randomly during play). Once you unlock (via x amount of people living in the vault) certian facilities, you can alter their hair style/color and make clothing/weapons without relying on chance. Dinners and living quarters also have themes (fairly new) which auto change during certian events. You can also collect themes to change it anytime you want.

Holiday events are enjoyable enough without feeling overwhelming. But you will find lots of slow periods while playing. Especially on Survival mode where building up too quickly has deadly drawbacks.


(* Not sure if it auto detects for a controller, as I rarely use them on PC gaming.)
(** That being said, progress can be very... very slow at times. It is a pay to be lazy mechanic more than anything.)

Fallout Shelter is simply a freemium "Game" using the Fallout series as a crutch. It is, in essence, a clicking simulator with no thought, no way to lose and no actual point to playing. Every action just leads to another action, and in essence forms an infinite loop. Look no further than silly "Clicker" or "Idle" games. Of course, if this is your cup of tea, then I'm certain that you'd enjoy this game. It has been out on Mobile devices for quite some time, so take it as you will.

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
[i]The reason as to why Vault Boy is always smiling.[/i]

[h1]The Good Stuff[/h1]
+Dark Fallout humor at its best
+Easy to learn survival strategy
+Protect your Vault Dwellers from the wasteland, gather resources, and find pets AKA Dogmeat
+Scavenge the wasteland for goodies like junk and outfits, trust me those are goodies in this game
+Quests that provide bigger rewards than scavenging
+Can easily walk away and come back and have nothing catastrophic happen to your Vault, as this game is not time based long term 
+Deathclaws. Yes, they go under the Good Stuff section. 

[h1]The Ok Stuff[/h1]
=Login, logout, login, logout, logout, login, login, deathclaw... definitely logout. 
=Slow start, but it picks up after a couple days/deathclaws
=Rocks.
=It's annoying to build elevators, as all rooms become more expensive the more you build of each one

[h1]The Bad Stuff[/h1]
-An iOS to PC port, those usually never work well
-In-game ads for the game... really bro? 
-Dragging dwellers is very glitchy

[h1]The Truthful Hard Facts[/h1]

A free game which is designed for mobiles and tablets.

It is enjoyable if you are the type of person that enjoys clicking repetively on rooms to collect power, food and water, which in turn slowly builds your bottle caps (money) allowing you to expand your base over time.

As per usual with these type of games, they make it relatively easy in the beginning so that you feel you've accomplished something, some form of base which you're happy with, just before the real slowness sinks in, and the possibility of your wallet feeling the weight of your growing lack of patience kicks in. 
To speed the game up, which is another typical feature of mobile games, it has got a 'pay to win' system where you can buy additional lunch boxes to collect junk, food, water, power and those trusty bottle caps. Without these purchases you may experience boredom and even death due to the extremely slow and grindy nature of the game.

What's a couple of pounds/dollars here and there? Nothing until you realise you've lost track of how many small purchases you make and you end up living a real life desolate waste land experience in an alleyway out the back of Burger King.

I write this review from my friends couch, as I suffer paranoid flashbacks each time a bottle cap drops or a lunch box rattles.


I would recommend this to achievement hunters or people with bad computers, otherwise there are definitely better games to spend your time on.

I've "played" some of this game on mobile, then on the bethesda pc platform a lot, then on the windows store version which was a terrible thing to do for the immense pain that it is to even create an account on that freaking service.

Frankly if Steam had a "mixed" option to rate games, I would probably be rating it that, since it doesn't, I tend to lean a bit more in the whole "negative" rating area.

For a simple reason really.

Fallout Shelter is a mobile game that has been ported to pc, problem being that when detracting this game from the mobile "ecosystem" you essentially missed out on any incentive to keep playing it, just try it for a while and you'll see it's true, and it's for a basic reason, it's simply easier to give a follow up and a check up in the phone that you don't use always for games or work, than it is to give that kind of attention and consistency on the pc.

Pair that up with the fact that since it is a "free to play" title, the game obviously has in-game transactions, something that's no bother, makes sense really, but again, the incentive for even paying for this transactions goes out the window when you take into consideration the simple amass of trainers, as well as memory editing tools that are out there.

Some people might start comparing those tools to piracy when being used in "games" such as this one...

The pc version of this game is no more appealing to anyone that hasn't played the mobile version than any other flash incremental game, which in a way, if that's what you're looking for, then this game it's fine, just know that is one of those "keep opening every day to do stuff that you'll continue the next day" in order to actually end up simply getting flustered and annoyed once you get most of the stuff there is to get in the game and whatever motivation, or satisfaction you had to keep opening lunch boxes in order to get yet another replicated outfit or weapon, its gone.

Just like any other mobile "free to play" game this is nothing more than a successful attempt from Bethesda to create a game that essentially uses the already amazing Fallout popularity as a pedestal in which to have a name, but besides the superficial similarities don't think you'll get more from this than you will get from any other "free to play" game, you'll enjoy it at first, then you'll stop playing it after spending some cash on it, or cheating to give yourself everything, making the game in whichever way you choose, redundant, and a dull experience in anyway you see fit.

Some might say i'm being "ungrateful" or "entitled" because i'm posting this in a "free" game, but let me just remind you that right past the "play now" button on Steam, there's a series of items that charge money for you to get them.

Others might add that any game becomes a chore once everythings unlocked, but I differ, Dishonored, Styx, Deus Ex, even freaking Fallout, become if anything a lot more interesting once you get a lot of your locked abilities available to you, they expand and they open areas in the game in every sense of the word, for you to keep exploring, for you to keep experiencing, and enjoying.

This game doesn't expand on anything, because it's a simple formula, a cycle if nothing else.


This is fine for fans that want to throw more cash at Betheda's feet, not for fans that want to get unique or interesting experiences like the ones they got from playing the actual Fallout games.

If there's anything positive to say about this, it's that at the very least it succeeds in what it sets out to do.

I'm not saying it shouldn't be on pc, The more games the better right? I'm just simply stating that when removing this game from it's mobile "enviroment" there's little to no incentive to actually play it the "proper" way, mostly when you take into consideration the proper way of playing it, signifies nothing more than: Wait till you get tired, and want to spend on some random item to follow the absurd and ridiculous skinner's box scheme set by this game to succeed.

You might as well be "playing" a Fallout themed slot machine.

At the time of this review I haven't put much time into the Steam release of this game. I've played it a lot on my phone, & from the PC Bethesda Launcher, and Windows 10 Store. This game is really good. It starts off slow but gets better the more you play it. It's a much better game than I thought it would be from looking at the trailer & gameplay footage. It has optional micro-transactions but isn't pay to win. Over all the versions of this game, I've never put any money in and I have more than enough caps, dwellers, Nuka Cola bottles and so on. I'm stockpiling resources on every version because the game without putting money in gives you more than enough of each. The game has a lot more depth than I originally though it would, and now you can also leave the vault and go on quests. I highly recommend giving this game a serious try, and putting some time in with it. If you're a fan of the Fallout games, you'll understand things a bit more, but I can image even a non Fallout gamer enjoying this game. In my opinion this game works really well with a controller, but is far better with keyboard and mouse. It's free, so check it out.

I've already spent almost 100 hours playing this game on the Windows Store, and I have to say that it's one hell of a time waster. Fallout Shelter doesn't have any specific goal in mind, so you can spend your spare time increasing your vault's population (and have your own Gary-themed whacko-fest); training your dwellers' SPECIAL stats for gameplay bonuses; or send them all out in the wasteland, and battle a dozen Deathclaws, for that chance to find a rare item - just remember to send them back to the vault if you're going to exit the game, because the timer keeps ticking even when you're out, and reviving a dead vault dweller costs a lot of caps. Tip for new players: a high food level keeps everyone happy and smiling in the face of danger; therefore, invest in it early in the game (or send the useless dwellers out to die in the wilderness), because it dwindles fast if you have too many people.

Overall, a fun casual game. There are microtransactions available, but your vault can survive even without purchasing any of them. You might have to spend more time playing and managing if you want some of the loot that can be purchased in the store, but a day or two of waiting wouldn't hurt.

I saw this on Steam this morning and was worried I would not be able to transfer my saves from my main non Steam game, those worries were somewhat unfounded. The game doesn't sync to your bethesda.net or mobile data but you can manually put the save you have been using into the game and have it work mostly fine. It was strange Fallout Shelter did not come to Steam sooner, I think it is pretty good. 

In Fallout Shelter you build, manage, and customize your vault and its citizens all on the fly. It does seem grindy at first because most things are time based, but it was designed to be a game you'd play on and off all on the go, so that's understandable. I really enjoy the game and while I was playing through Fallout 4, played shelter on and off that entire time, and more! 

If you are a Fallout fan, or are a fan of mobile games, or even just looking for a stress free, simple idle game and don't want any pay to in garbage this is a game you should check out! I have played it hundreds of hours and can still get enjoyment from it, but maybe im just weird.

I have been playing FO Shelter from the beginning (as soon as it was available on Android). Also I am a big fan of Fallout Series (played all of them starting from Fallout 1, including tactics and latest games).

It's a highly addictive from the begging and most of the fun (it's a pity) are nearly the initial game start. At least over a month. The game never ends. As a FO fan, you can see all the beloved graphics, dwellers  and monsters. As it free to play, there are some boosters you can spend money on (and for this game this is completely optional).

Pros:
* Highly addictive (first month only)
* familiar and cool graphics
* proper micro and macro management (for no more than 20 dwellers)
* payment content is not a stopper for F2P users

Cons:
* Once you reach high level, micromanagement is a mess
* For a big collony you're easily lost in dwemmers and rooms
* have to play every single day for max boost
* no more fun end-game content

Summary: For fans it's a must-try, for others - yes, definitly try either. Hoewver I doubt that you will play it more than 3-5 weeks.

Added 2017-11-23: I like that developers still support the game, in-game holiday items and bugfixes. Still enjoybale if you have long pauses from that game
